column2: The Scott’s oriole, a fluffy yellow visitor never before sighted in New York, had come to Union Square, where it seemed utterly at home.

VALENTINE’S DAY brought “something even sweeter” than candy hearts or chocolate for the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, said Coleman Casey, the museum’s acting director and president of its board of trustees. “The Wadsworth got the absolute best person on the face of this planet to lead the way, and that is Susan Lubowsky Talbott.”.

An article last Sunday about James A. Amann, the speaker of Connecticut’s legislature, who is exploring a run for governor, misstated the surname of the winner of Connecticut’s 2006 Democratic primary for the United States Senate. It is Ned Lamont, not Lamott.

EVERY few weeks, two fifth-grade classes from Eugene Auer elementary school in Lake Grove take a field trip to the nearby Robert J. Henke Memorial Nature Preserve. Their mission: to find black squirrels.

The “Living In” column on Feb. 10, about the East Village, misstated the number of city-recognized historic districts in the area. The East Village does indeed have one district: St. Mark’s Historic District, designated in 1969. It is not totally without such districts.

A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about lawyers who sue their neighbors in apartment buildings misstated the circumstances under which lawyers can be refused housing in New York City. Although a 1977 court decision upheld a landlord’s right to refuse to rent to a lawyer, the city’s human rights law was amended in 1986 to bar discrimination in housing on the basis of a lawful occupation. Co-op and condominium boards may, however, reject lawyers and other applicants based on specific actions — for instance, a pattern of filing lawsuits against neighbors.

GWENDOLYN STRETCH, the medical director at the Elsie Owens North Brookhaven Health Center, in Coram, had a lot to do during the 20-minute appointment with her next patient. After examining Nelia McPherson, 44, a chronic asthma patient from East Patchogue, Dr. Stretch renewed prescriptions and discussed some of the risks that could trigger an asthma attack — including rugs and plastic covers on mattresses. Atop the doctor’s priority list was to encourage her patient to stop smoking.

Specializing in seafood and other dishes in the Cantonese style, Aberdeen in White Plains is one of the county’s few regional Chinese restaurants holding out against the recent Pan-Asian invasion. Dishes of Canton reflect the region’s mild climate and its position on the South China Sea, where a full supply of fish, meats, fruits and vegetables available throughout the year has helped establish Canton’s reputation for producing China’s most varied, creative and savory dishes.
The theatrical interior of BOE@324 Restaurant in White Plains is so distractingly elaborate that what’s on the menu almost becomes a vague afterthought.

Fratelli Market is not the sort of Italian place that carries more types of cheeses and dry-cured sausage than you can shake a pepperoni stick at. Its specialty is pasta, particularly ravioli, with so many choices you may take to shopping there week after week.
There is no shortage of Italian restaurants in Connecticut, but Finalmente Trattoria in Westport has warmth and intimacy.

dishabille / (dis& e be\l) / n. / (From the French déshabiller, “to undress.”) The state of being partially or very casually dressed, as in, “The teen star gives an extremely naked performance in the CW remake of ‘Bilitis,’ spending the entire movie in varying degrees of dishabille”; a front-row buzzword in a season in which designers have stripped back the silhouette to its conceptual, neoburlesque bare bones, e.g., “The collection was very mid-’90s Madonna dishabille in Seville meets Dita Von Teese in Greece.”.

At the Wiener Werkstätte, artists believed that a piece of jewelry should serve as something more personal than an advertisement for wealth. Josef Hoffmann, one of the workshop’s founders, used semiprecious stones including coral and moonstone to create brooches that resembled stained glass (left). His pieces also referred to Gustav Klimt, who happened to be an important patron. The artist Dagobert Peche went a more organic route with nature-inspired bracelets and pendants. “They were thinking in more abstract ways,” says Janis Staggs, who curated the show “Wiener Werkstätte Jewelry,” which opens at the Neue Galerie in New York on March 27. “It was about experimentation of color and pattern.” But not necessarily about perfection. As Staggs explains, “No two pieces were alike. There were always inconsistencies, which add to the charm.” [?][?][?]MAURA EGAN.
[?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE AND COURTNEY A. WEINBLATT.

Born as common as nondairy creamer, the daughter of a stableman and a domestic servant, Jane Burden rose to the crème de la crème of fin de siècle English society. The tousled-haired Pre-Raphaelite beauty not only became the wife and muse of William Morris, the founder of the British Arts and Crafts movement, but she is also believed to have been an inspiration for George Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion.”.

To get a modern stained lip, Page blended two lipsticks on the back of his hand: a Bordeaux cream, like M.A.C. Media, and a fuchsia cream, like Nars Funny Face. Then he used his fingertip to blot it onto the lips.

Just as her muse Jean-Michel Basquiat used to say, “Believe it or not, I can actually draw,” the British knitwear sensation Clare Tough says she can actually knit. Still, grandmothers everywhere may grumble that some of her graffiti-inspired creations (like her Brooklyn Bridge bra, a skimpy creation in wool and balsa wood) break every rule of the purl-one-knit-two set. Ditto for the zippered cardigan with an overload of ribbed patchwork and vibrant embroideries, which she says has about 50 types of yarn. Tough first got noticed in 2004 with her Central Saint Martins graduation show: the string outfits of Jamaican dancehall queens re-envisioned as cobwebby knit dresses. But her real obsession is ’80s New York, having grown up in the picture-postcard spa town Malvern listening to Fab 5 Freddie and old hip-hop compilations. Tough, 27, is bent on expanding the definition of knitwear. “I didn’t invent crochet, obviously, but I really think the way I patchwork garments together hasn’t been done before,” she says in her East London studio. “Knitting has got a frumpy image, and it really shouldn’t.” [?][?][?]SUSIE RUSHTON THE REMIX.

I was about 20 years old and determined to wear a red Valentino dress to my friend’s debutante ball. I had a crush on a boy who was going to be there, and had seen how when my mother wore Valentino couture she immediately became the center of attention. Without fail, a moment of silence would occur as she stepped into a room, much like a pause in a music score. I wanted to experience this intense feeling for myself. When I asked to borrow Mom’s dress, she flatly refused, saying that red at a coming-out party went against all codes of etiquette. So I did what any savvy New York girl would do: I called Valentino himself, who was thrilled at the idea of making me the social scandal of the season. He gave me my own gown, and since then, I have worn many more — recently to his anniversary in Rome and to Elton John’s birthday party. The effect is always the same: his shade of red is so rich and beautiful that it makes you want to slightly misbehave. Oh, and about that guy I liked way back then — it worked.

Swap-a-rama Razzmatazz is one of London’s most fashionable club nights — and certainly its most eccentric. Its origins date to the time when a chap named Alex Collins studied abroad and lived on a commune where many garments were communal property. Eager to recreate back home that “year of my life when not having possessions didn’t bother me,” Collins held a party at which guests were told to swap outfits every time a whistle blew. The mayhem inspired Eloise Markwell-Butler, Dean Slydell, Dani Mazzer and Nick Frew to take the concept public, aided by donations from the vintage megastore Beyond Retro. Swap-a-rama Razzmatazz is now held at Favela Chic in the Shoreditch neighborhood once every month. Clotheslines festoon the club, and when the klaxon sounds, you either swap or split: ogling bystanders are evicted. Markwell-Butler likens it to “being in a mad person’s laundry.” Since partygoers keep their booty, at £3 for admission, it’s London’s cheapest way to get a new wardrobe. [?][?][?]SARAH NIR.

STYLE MAP | SAVANNAH In the 1997 film “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,” a New York writer visiting Savannah, Ga., describes the town as “ ‘Gone With the Wind’ on mescaline.” It’s easy to see what he meant: the Spanish-moss-draped streets are lined with stately Southern homes, barbecue joints and dusky bars. Recently, however, a little cool has been injected into the antebellum mix, with style-savvy design students, smartly restored inns and a handful of trendy new shops. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER.

On a recent trip to Moscow, I heard about a fancy Fabergé egg being sold for $18.5 million. The news came across as I was looking out a hotel window at the ugliest, most stolid gray building you could find from the Soviet era.

1. Christophe Decarnin is revamping Balmain with Native American, Indian and animal prints, as well as a surfeit of beads, fringe and studs. Who’s afraid of a little boho? At Jeffrey New York and Intermix.

We’re entering the “Just-spring” portion of the year, according to E. E. Cummings, when the world turns “mud-luscious.” The Samurai Shopper has already sprung from the hibernal freeze to roll around cheek by jowl, a prehistoric swamp thing adrift in mud-luscious eddies. There’s mud on my scalp, mud on my face. Ripples of viscous silt voluptuously coat my nutrient-starved skin, nestling in nooks where the sun don’t shine.

There’s a school of style slut (and I’ll own up to being a member) that likes to believe changes in fashion reflect broader shifts in society, geopolitics, the arts, the economy and so on. Maybe it makes us feel less guilty about spending quite so much time and money on what we wear, or perhaps it gives us an excuse to talk about it longer.
The shipping news? Brash prints and bold lengths.
They’re not just slimming: when priced by the pound, this season’s most diaphanous dresses might make you lightheaded. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER.
Insanity. The style industry loves it. And why not? Fashion itself.
Dear A.P.: Here are six pitches for the spring T. Personally, I think they’re all solid. Just let me know which ones (all?) you want me to do. A big mwah two inches from your cheek.
1977 Me as Ingres’s “La Grande Odalisque.” Those are my mother’s wedding sheets.

Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of Vogue Paris, bequeathed her children her soigné style as if it were their birthright. Her daughter, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, is a freelance art director for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier and was the face of Tom Ford’s latest fragrance; her son, Vladimir Restoin-Roitfeld, is a film school graduate and a sometime model. Going to a fashion shoot when they were young, says Mom, was as normal as tarte Tatin. (The photographer Mario Testino is their godfather.) Many consider Roitfeld the stilettoed embodiment of modern dressing: she describes her style as “tacky chic.” Never afraid to take a risk, she has put a bearded drag queen on a cover and printed a fashion story with a model dressed as an Anna Wintour clone. After 20-plus years in the business, certain things have changed: “I don’t go too much to the parties now, but my kids do.” Like their mom, they’re always on the list. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.
Paging Nurse Blabla! Caroline Weber checks into the style hospital.
Head into spring in the kinds of revved-up colors that would look great on an old ‘56 Chevy.
Donatella Versace.
Calvin Klein Collection silk organza molded dress, $1,450. Go to calvinklein.com.

The model Liya Kebede has made great strides for racial diversity in fashion (see her in “Toga Land,” Page 236). Now, she’s starting Lemlem, a mostly hand-woven line of children’s clothes made in Africa, in the hope that a younger crowd will embrace her multi-culti ideals. “The name means ‘to bloom,’ ” says Kebede, who on a visit to her native Ethiopia met talented weavers struggling to survive. “I wanted to help preserve their art while creating job opportunities.” The outfits, at Scoop and Barneys New York, have an Ethiopian vibe with a New World ease. Finicky tots will approve. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER.

Who needs television writers when you’ve got big-city housewives willing to bare all? The women who star in “Real Housewives of New York City,” which premieres on Bravo on March 4, recently provided enough material for a novel, but a thousand words will have to suffice.
The sensuality of William Morris is alive and well, thanks to Tamara Salman’s new prints for Liberty of London.

As a child in southern Provence, Christian Lacroix, the master of maximalist chic, would haunt a small museum filled with dusty wax tableaus illustrating the Spanish influence on local costumes and customs. He decided then that he would be a museum curator, but life had other plans. With the opening last November of a retrospective celebrating the 20th anniversary of his couture house, curated by Lacroix himself, that long-held ambition was finally realized.

We hope you will understand.” With typically fervent Japanese politeness, Yayoi Kusama’s staff warned me that the resurgent queen of the Japanese art world, now approaching 80, no longer permits herself to be photographed. But when she learned that the photographer in question was Nobuyoshi Araki, the celebrated master of nude bondage pictures, it turned out that Kusama was only too happy to oblige. And so, on a quiet Thursday afternoon, after an hour or so of failed efforts to interview Kusama, I waited with the artist and her staff around a conference table for Araki’s arrival. Wearing a bright red wig, matching lipstick and her signature polka-dot motif — a red kimono-like dress adorned with circles of black and white felt — Kusama looked like a small grave clown, in the lull before a birthday party begins.

American culture has long fetishized the eyelash. Designed by nature to be the simple shrubbery that protects the cornea from dust and small particles, the humble strip of cilia has evolved into an object of sensual fascination, aesthetic peacockery and, most recently, federal concern of such magnitude that the F.D.A. and a squadron of marshals were forced to intervene.

As a Baby Star of 1927, Sally Phipps seemed destined for silent film immortality. The organization that bestowed the award — the Western Association of Motion Picture Advertisers, or Wampas — had a genius for spotting talent. Joan Crawford and Clara Bow had been Baby Stars, and in 1927, the 16-year-old Phipps shared the accolade with future fan-dance sensation Sally Rand.

1. Sarah Rutson doesn’t take no for an answer. The fashion director of Lane Crawford, a bevy of luxe boutiques in Hong Kong and Beijing, digs her Louboutin heels in when it comes to the designers and trends she believes in: “I won’t shut up until the order is written!” Here she wears a dress by Roland Mouret.

Jane Holszer, who is nobody's baby, has channeled her passion for contemporary art into a superstar collection. 
COLLECTION.
Her outfits can be as controversial-or as critically acclaimed- as her film choices, but Chloë Sevigny couldn't care less.

This is the Year of the Goddess, judging by the clothes that designers sent down the runway. So much for the sirens: they had their day, and now they’re tired; some are in rehab. More preferable, as archetypes go, is the goddess, with her ancient Grecian pedigree, her aloof demeanor suggesting self-possession and powers of divine intervention, her sensuous revelry in her own body. The goddess ratchets our standards considerably higher where sex is concerned: only gods need apply.

The latest addition to the fashion world’s motley crew of multitaskers is a group of drug guerrillas turned handbag designers. Not to be confused with the feminist art gang the Guerrilla Girls or Comme des Garçons’ temporary “guerrilla” stores, these unlikely artisans work with Egg, a Bogotá-based nonprofit organization that is teaching reformed Colombian rebels how to make crocodile totes. Currently, a battery of 20-something men — all from the Antioquia region, where the Colombian armed conflict still has legs — learn construction techniques from native craftsmen. “They’re fiercely dedicated to their work,” says Claudia Gaitán de Caballero, Egg’s co-director. “And it’s a great way for them to become regular citizens.” The bags, which have been picked up by decidedly imperialist institutions like New York’s Takashimaya and Saks Fifth Avenue Mexico, retail for about $1,300. No one can ever accuse Gucci of doing things halfheartedly. Outrageous!, for example, is a work of talent, originality and vision. It smells deeply artificial in the best sense, intentionally bearing the same relationship to the natural world that Tang does to orange juice. Outrageous! is not a synthetic version of nature but a free-standing creation that refers to the natural world ironically and revels in its own artifice. It is, in fact, the smell of Tang sprinkled on a plate of polyurethane on which sit grapes, apples and pears made of polyvinyl chloride. The scent of kerosene ingeniously adds alarm to the soft, dystopian glow. Frowning, I once said to Sophia Grojsman, who created it for Barneys New York Co-Op, “It makes me think of a Mondrian: rigid, unnatural rectangles of artificially bright colors.” She put her hands on my shoulders and squeezed with delight.

NOBUYOSHI ARAKI : The legendary Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki shot the artist Yayoi Kusama (center) for “Kusama Dot Com” (Page 266), but it wasn’t the first time the icons crossed paths. “She and I go back a long time,” he says, adding that he first photographed her for a 1980s Japanese porn magazine for which he wrapped her in toilet paper. Despite their history, Araki admits there are still some unfinished chapters in their relationship: “I’ve never slept with her, so we’ll never come to know everything about each other.” After more than 40 years snapping everything from painted flowers (above) to scenes of fellatio, Araki is one of the most prolific and passionate artists working today. “Photography is my nutrition, and the sound of the shutter is my heart-beating pulse.” A show of his work at the Kestnergesellschaft in Hannover, Germany, runs through May 12.

If you’re in Paris and you want to see Ingres’s 1862 masterpiece, “Le Bain Turc,” or his earlier flirtation with neo-Classicism in “Oedipus Explaining the Enigma of the Sphinx,” or the Greek Classicism that inspired it, you can take the Métro to an art museum called the Louvre. If you want to smell the original 1966 Aramis, which descended from the 1944 Bandit, which itself was built on the principles of Fougère Royale created for the house of Houbigant in 1884, you can take the RER to another Paris art museum: the Osmothèque, at 36 rue du Parc-de-Clagny.

There were a few blousy moments during the spring collections when you could be forgiven for thinking you were attending an 1850s suffragist rally or a gym class at Vassar in the 1920s. Bloomers — sometimes diaperish, usually subversive and most women’s idea of fashion hell — produced smirks and double-takes in New York and Europe. Gaultier’s iteration had a “Pirates of Penzance” picturesqueness. In an unusually insane show, Comme des Garçons advanced the possibility of bloomers that were not just frilly but also falling apart. Prada’s take, short-short and sewn in shiny fabrics, was straight from the stroller. Betsey Johnson, well, you can guess. While today’s bloomers can be traced in a straight line to the pumpkin breeches that Renaissance men wore at the top of their hose, they are but fuzzy cousins to the garment favored by the early women’s libber who lent them her name, Amelia Bloomer. She rebelled against the petticoats and floor-grazing skirts of the mid-19th century in favor of knee-skimming designs layered over ballooning trousers gathered at the ankles. The bifurcated look had something weirdly haremlike about it and, however liberating, was light only in relation to what had come before. Bloomer was ridiculed but of course vindicated with the hindsight of history. Designers have fallen in and out of love with bloomers at least since 1976. Bonnie Cashin, the sportswear pioneer, celebrated the bicentennial with a collection of “Amelias.” “Bonnie loved bloomers because they could be completely customized by the wearer,” says Stephanie Lake of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. Is there any designer who hasn’t dabbled in bloomers? You can wear out your search engine trying to find one. Saint Laurent’s fling was in 1987. Vivienne Westwood cast her vote in velvet in 1998. Armani has shown bloomers off and on for several years. Spinning positive, one buyer called

Cecil Beaton possessed a keen eye for all things fashionable. While he found his métier as a portrait photographer, he also played the role of dandy, diarist, Oscar-winning costumer and, oddly enough, fabric designer. Now, through the London interior design company Beaudesert and the archives of Ascher Studio, reproductions of Beaton’s checks, florals and stripes are being sold at Liberty of London. The Cecil Beaton fabric collection — on silk, cotton, linen and wallpaper — was inspired by a scarf that Beaudesert’s managing director, Andrew Ginger, found on eBay; Beaton had originally designed it for the textile firm Ascher. In the 1940s and early ’50s, Zika Ascher commissioned artists such as Henri Matisse and Henry Moore to design fabrics, paying them £25 per motif, according to his son, Peter. All the big designers, like Balenciaga, Givenchy, Lanvin and Yves Saint Laurent, would buy their fabrics from Ascher Studio. Although not known for his brush strokes, Beaton was an obvious choice for fabric, and Zika allowed him free rein. “An artist with a color sense is not someone you mess with,” Zika has been quoted as saying. The timing couldn’t be better, as this spring’s runways were full of blossoms. Can’t you just see the Beaton bouquet on your fainting couch? [?][?][?]MELISSA FELDMAN.

ON most days, Matthew Davis, a 28-year-old portfolio manager, can count on spending about two hours getting to work and another two hours getting home. That's going against the tide of commuters going into New York City for work. Mr. Davis, who rented an apartment in Park Slope in Brooklyn when he landed a job in the securities industry in New York, found himself not on Wall Street, but in Ronkonkoma, working for a financial services management company. He starts his morning with a stop for tea and a bagel at his neighborhood delicatessen, and walks 30 minutes or takes the subway to the Flatbush Avenue terminal of the Long Island Rail Road. In Jamaica, Queens, he changes trains and settles in for a 60-minute ride to his company's office near MacArthur Airport, deep in Suffolk County. There, he keeps a car for the last leg of the commute, a total of two hours each way. ''Usually, until I get to Mineola, I have to stand, but then I find a seat and read the paper,'' he said. ''I tried to find an apartment closer to work, but after 20 minutes of driving, I still wasn't anyplace that was close to anything. I really like living in the city.''

In February 1962, Sports Illustrated sent the illustrator Robert Weaver to cover spring training in Florida. Weaver relied on observational drawing, not photography, to record his impressions. He then created a series of paintings that appeared in the March 5, 1962, issue of the magazine. Weaver's drawings capture the timeless qualities of spring training: confident men in easy postures, unfurling themselves to throw, to bat or simply to wait around. Weaver, who died in 1994, brought a journalist's mindset to illustration. His sketchbook reports on the stadiums and the social order they represent. Fans and vendors get sensitive treatment, even as nettings and railings double as implied barriers. Advertising messages are amplified. An integrated game is bracketed by segregated stands. --D.B. DOWD, a professor of visual communication and American culture studies at Washington University in St. Louis

He's hardly a household name, but more than 60 years after Bernard Rudofsky became an intellectual celebrity, his work still resonates in our lives. The Vienna-trained architect was a polymath who questioned every aspect of modernism, from design, architecture and museum installations to textiles and fashion. The 1944 show ''Are Clothes Modern?'' that he curated at the Museum of Modern Art included shoes, some of which he ridiculed for their unwearableness and others, modeled after sandals from antiquity, that he praised. Throngs of visitors were wowed by the exhibition: there was an uneven floor (to reconnect you with your feet) and a mirror by the exit (to force you to confront yourself). Soon after, Rudofsky founded Bernardo sandals (relaunched in 2001), and by the 1960s Jackie Kennedy was said to own 16 colors of the same pair. After helping design the American pavilion for the 1958 world's fair in Brussels and decamping to Japan, a culture he later analyzed in ''The Kimono Mind,'' Rudofsky staged ''Now I Lay Me Down to Eat'' at the Cooper-Hewitt in 1980. The show finally allowed him to present his take on bodily functions (anyone for a urine tube?). Promising to be just as lively is ''Lessons From Bernard Rudofsky'' at the Getty in L.A. from March 11 to June 8. CAROL KINO

Through Wednesday, the films of 2007 had grossed about $9.7 billion at theaters in the United States. Ninety-five percent of that total came from films that peaked within two weeks of opening. But many of the films nominated for the Academy Awards on Sunday -- like ''Juno,'' the runaway independent hit -- took much longer to reach their peak. Nominees in categories like best picture are not always audience favorites, and word of mouth or critical acclaim can help them build momentum. GOLLOBIN--Ruth, 86, died peacefully on February 17th after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Ira, ''Ruchel'' to cherished cousins Mary Mazur, Josephine Mazur, Bonnie West, Eva Siegel, Bill, Hamish and Adam Norton, and Jay Axelbank. Caring stepmother to Ruth and Peter Basta and Jeanna and George Beker; devoted grandmother to Matthew (19) and Caitlin (18), Basta and Emily (17) Beker. Longtime friend to Freda Birnbaum, Ruth Selman and Jerry Sider. Ruth was a courageous lifelong activist for fair treatment of immigrants and for a socialist society. She had a love of Yiddish literature, classical music, paintings, anthropology and photography, and adored babies and cats! Ruth will be greatly missed by those whose lives she enriched, both here and abroad. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 6th at 4pm at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to World Fellowship, P.O. Box 2280, Conway, NH 03818.

NEARLY half of the world's 1.3 billion smokers live in China, India and Indonesia, the three largest consumers of tobacco products. In China alone, more people smoke than live in the United States. Those countries and others in the developing world represent promising frontiers for the big tobacco companies as they move to win over existing smokers and, according to a new report by the World Health Organization, convince teenagers and women to light up. Smoking has declined slowly in the West. But over the last four decades it has grown steadily in the developing world. LEWIS--John D. B., Esq., age 64, died at home on February 22nd, 2008 after a short, valiant struggle with lung cancer. John, a tireless fighter for justice for those most in need, is survived by his beloved wife of nearly 40 years, Justice Laura Visitacion-Lewis; his cherished daughter and son-in-law, Cari Lewis-Osborne and Dr. Joseph R. Osborne, and his treasured granddaughter, Eva Jade. John is also mourned by his loving siblings, Roger B. and Bonnie Lewis, and his cousin Dr. Elizabeth Kantor; his beloved nieces, nephews, and in-laws; and his many admired and admiring friends. His love for his family and friends was enormous. We shall miss his warmth, exuberance, humor, and -most of all -the indomitable spirit with which he undertook both the challenges of international mountaineering and the representation of the poor. Details of a memorial service will be forthcoming.

As a wise philosopher once noted, life is a lot like high school. And so, these days, is the New York stage. Already ''Grease,'' ''Hairspray'' and ''Spring Awakening'' are taking attendance on Broadway. And now Liz Flahive is stepping into the breach for the Manhattan Theater Club (after Kenneth Lonergan's ''Starry Messenger'' was dropped from the schedule) with her black comedy ''From Up Here.'' Ms. Flahive, whose former day job was as a beauty editor at prom-night primers like Lucky and Teen People magazines, still writes odes to eyeliner to get by. But despite her play's high school setting, ''those two parts of my life are very separate,'' she said. ''To me as a young writer with young characters, it's all about the interplay between your school life and your family life,'' and high school appeals to audiences in general ''because it's a pretty dramatic place.'' ''From Up Here'' opens April 16, with Julie White playing the mother of a troubled teenager (Tobias Segal).

Attention, students: If you want to skip a few reading assignments, just go to the theater, where American authors are as prominent this spring as they are in sophomore English. We begin with Mark Twain. His comedy ''Is He Dead?'' has been running on Broadway since November, and he's a character in Cinna Productions' ''Mark Twain's Blues,'' playing through March 8 at Altered Stages. In ''Blues'' Twain is giving a lecture when his own characters start interrupting, insisting they've been misrepresented.

SHIVITZ--David I., died February 19, 2008, Palm Beach Gardens, FL, at age 100. Survived by his loving wife Floren and by daughters Barbara Isaacs of NY and Stefanie Roth of London, son Richard Roth of London and granddaughter Elise Roth. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton, NYU, and NY Law School, David had a distinguished career in public service, as NYC corporation counsel during the LaGuardia mayoralty and as counsel for the Kefauver US Senate Crime Investigating Committee. As a lawyer in private practice, David was admired for skill, judgment and integrity; his friendship cherished by many far beyond NYC and Nyack, his home for many years. Funeral service Noon, Friday 22nd February, Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach, FL.

8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 80TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS An etching of a grand Roman space by the 18th-century Italian artist Piranesi was the inspiration behind the set design -- five columns containing Oscar statuettes and Streamline Moderne elements -- for this year's ceremony, broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. The end of the writers' strike means that Jon Stewart may have witty lines, that the show will feature performances of the five nominated songs rather than a montage of clips, and that the red carpet will be more fun to watch. Jessica Alba, Katherine Heigl, John Travolta, Hilary Swank, Renée Zellweger and Denzel Washington are among the presenters. Additional Oscar programming includes ''Celebtv.com's All Star Tribute to Movies,'' at 5 p.m. on ABC; ''Whipple's World Academy Awards Show'' and ''Academy Talking Pictures,'' at 6 and 6:30 on NY1; ''An Evening at the Academy Awards: The Arrivals,'' at 6:30, and ''Oscar's Red Carpet 2008,'' at 8, both on ABC. 7 P.M. (ABC) BARBARA WALTERS OSCAR SPECIAL Ellen Page, Harrison Ford, Vanessa Williams and Miley Cyrus sit down with Ms. Walters and try not to get weepy.

TAKING her cue from Surrealists like Man Ray, Dalí and Duchamp, all of whom experimented with jewelry design, the artist Megan Marrin has introduced a collection of handmade, one-of-a-kind necklaces under the name M. Graves (her family name). Fashioned from 19th-century porcelain doll parts recovered from a bombed toy factory in Germany, and semiprecious stones like white turquoise and jasper, the pieces have a perverse beauty that, like Meret Oppenheim's necklace made of bones, is meant to delight.

ON most days, Matthew Davis, a 28-year-old portfolio manager, can count on spending about two hours getting to work and another two hours getting home. That's going against the tide of commuters going into New York City for work. Mr. Davis, who rented an apartment in Park Slope in Brooklyn when he landed a job in the securities industry in New York, found himself not on Wall Street, but in Ronkonkoma, on Long Island, working for a financial services management company. He starts his morning with a stop for tea and a bagel at his neighborhood delicatessen, and walks 30 minutes or takes the subway to the Flatbush Avenue terminal of the Long Island Rail Road. In Jamaica, Queens, he changes trains and settles in for a 60-minute ride to his company's office near MacArthur Airport, deep in Suffolk County. There, he keeps a car for the last leg of the commute, a total of two hours each way. ''Usually, until I get to Mineola, I have to stand, but then I find a seat and read the paper,'' he said. ''I tried to find an apartment closer to work, but after 20 minutes of driving, I still wasn't anyplace that was close to anything. I really like living in the city.''

Confession: I have probably seen more episodes of ''Law & Order'' than can be considered healthy, even for a New Yorker. This small obsession is easily fed, of course. There are about 700 episodes of the various ''Law & Order'' programs running and rerunning on at least four television outlets in New York City. This constant stream transports me into a better place, where the late Jerry Orbach is still snarling about real life. Reruns revive the old Fred Thompson in all his precampaign savvy. They elevate Sam Waterston to his ethical pedestal, even though he appears elsewhere pitching investments.

When Broadway producers search for talent abroad, their first stop is London. But for artistic directors of large Off Broadway theaters, the overseas search has increasingly led to Edinburgh, where every summer the behemoth Edinburgh Festival Fringe presents more than 2,000 potential hits. Peter Tear, the executive producer of 59E59 Theaters -- which produces ''East to Edinburgh,'' a sneak peek at a few shows going to the next Fringe -- has been a driving force behind the increased American focus on that August festival. ''I've been going to the festival for decades,'' Mr. Tear said, ''and the standards have really gone up.''

THE NEWSFidel Castro announced he would resign as president of Cuba after nearly 50 years in power. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Castro, 81 and bedridden for the last 19 months, had already handed over day-to-day authority to his brother Raúl, 76, the commander of Cuba's armed forces and probable successor. But Mr. Castro kept making his views known anyway, sometimes undercutting his brother. And in his resignation letter he signaled that ''Comrade Fidel'' was still not ready to quit the political stage completely -- raising the prospect that he may continue to wield influence behind the scenes, and that the Cuban government would effectively have two presidents to answer to.

STERN--Eli, 96, on February 11, 2008. Mr. Stern prepared this obituary himself some time ago: I dearly loved my wife Ruth of 67 years, my daughter Sheila, and my grandsons Adam and Gabriel Many. I enjoyed being a painter and sculptor, writing poetry, and woodworking. I was happy to be active in the Workmen's Circle and to write and prepare the monthly bulletin of my Penn South Branch 1076 for many years. I enjoyed conducting a discussion group at the Penn South Program for Seniors. One of my life's greatest satisfactions was attending New York City's John Jay College after I retired, graduating summa cum laude at age 68. I enjoyed the flowers and vegetables I grew on my apartment balcony. I enjoyed playing bridge, Scrabble and other games. From my youth onward I was a believer in democratic socialism and cooperation. I was always curious about everything. On the whole, life was good.

HERTZ--Sally A resident of Great Neck for 50 years, died at her home in Maplewood, NJ, on January 23 at the age of 83. Political and community activist. She devoted herself to progressive causes and cultural projects which have enriched her community. A founding member of the Great Neck Chapter of Womens Strike for Peace, she devoted much time, energy, and effort to the causes of international disarmament, peace, and civil rights. Sally was instrumental in finding an apartment for the first Black teacher in Great Neck. Her deep commitment to integration and fairness meant that anyone who came to her with a just cause could receive a financial contribution or a sincere effort to help with their struggle. She spent many years as the driving force and Director of the North Shore Community Art Centers ''Off Center'' shop, which raised much needed funds for the Center. She will be greatly missed by her many friends in Great Neck, as well as by the many less-privileged members of our community who benefitted directly from her energy, commitment, and work on their behalf. Sally enjoyed weekends of sailing the Long Island Sound with her husband, Harold. She and Harold visited many countries around the world, including India, Turkey, Cuba, U.S.S.R, much of Europe and Asia. Sally was a small person with a tremendous zest for life. She was extremely energetic and continued to enjoy the many cultural events that NYC had to offer. She was always ready to fight the good fight, stand up for the little guy and had very strong beliefs in integrity and right and wrong, perhaps fueled by her first hand experience of Anti-Semitism as a child in Poland. Sally loved a good story that was well told and even better, a good joke, and her laugh was legendary. She spent the last several years of her life in Maplewood, NJ. She is survived by her daughter, Madeline Hertz, of New Providence, NJ, her son, Robert Hertz, of San Diego, California, her sister, Dorothy Lastfogel, eight grandsons, two great-grandchildren, and several nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her husband of 55 years, Harold Hertz, her son, William Hertz, and her grandson, Jason Hertz. A memorial service will take place March 2 at 2:00pm, at Winchester Gardens, 333 Elmwood Avenue, Maplewood, NJ 07040 in the Great Hall. Donation, Gay Men's Health Crisis, Susan G. Komen, Peace Action .

EATING A BENTO BOX LUNCH AT UENO METRO STATION, JUNE 26, 2007 Amanda Barden Stradling, 25, right, an Ameri-Corps volunteer from Provo, Utah, with her visiting sister, Katherine Barden. Ms. Barden Stradling was in Tokyo for three months accompanying her husband (not pictured), a diplomatic intern. ''We had just gotten back from Ueno Park, where they have all these temples to explore, and we were hungry so we wanted to grab some lunch. We knew we were going to have to wait for the train, so we just broke out these bento boxes. I later found out that it was kind of a faux pas to eat in the Metro. The man in the suit leaned over and said something to me, and I just smiled at him and he smiled back, so he was probably asking me how my lunch was; I had no idea. But that was a cool thing about Tokyo -- the people were so nice because they knew I had no idea what was going on.'' As told to Austin Considine

SMITH--Judyth L. Schaubhut, Judyth Louise Schaubhut Smith, 64, of New York City, died February 9, 2008. Ms. Smith was born September 6, 1943, in Providence, RI, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gordon Schaubhut of Upper Montclair, NJ. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College and received a master's degree in Italian from Middlebury College. Early in her career, Judyth was the director of the patron program of the Metropolitan Opera Association at Lincoln Center. Her legacy at the Met includes numerous translations of the Mozart Libretti. She lived for several years in Florence, Italy, where she taught English to Italians, both in Florence and Bologna. She was admired for her mastery of the Italian language, which she spoke flawlessly, as well as for her stunning red-headed beauty. She loved the fine arts and dedicated many years to the Save Venice Foundation, where she coordinated fundraising events in both New York and Venice. Judyth spent the later part of her life dedicated to her love of translating and teaching the Italian language. Her many devoted New York City students will miss her lessons. Perhaps her most interesting translation work was for Pope John Paul II. She did both research and English translations for the various versions of the Holy Father's only CD, ''Abba Pater''. She loved nature, animals, and gardening; this love of all living creatures led her to care for abandoned animals. Judyth was a loyal friend who had both inner and outer beauty; her friendship was a precious gift to those who loved her for her brilliant intellect and sense of humor. Judyth is survived by her brother Stephen C. Schaubhut, sister Margaret Ellen Sonandres, brother Gordon Schaubhut, and six nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, in the Chapel, Park Ave at 51st St, New York City, 11am, Saturday, March 1, 2008. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to: the ''International Vocal Arts Institute'' http://www.ivai.org/sup port.htm ; ''VNS NY Hospice Care,'' 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001, attention Stefanie Steel; and the ''Friends of Animals'' friendsofanimals.org/ donate/ memorial-donate.php

BERGER--Denis. The Staff, Board and Advisory Committee of Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A mourns the passing of Denis Berger, our longtime friend and Director of Development. Denis, who was 61, passed away Wednesday, February 20th, after suffering a massive heart attack and falling into a coma for the past two weeks. Denis' entire adult life and extraordinary intelligence, dedication and skills, were devoted to the cause of justice and empowerment for low income and working people. Prior to his 17 years with Brooklyn A, he served as an organizer in Springfield, MA, a founder of the Venceremos Brigade in Cuba, Executive Director of the Nation Institute and of the United Electrical Workers Union, staff of the NYC Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, and cofounder of the National's staff union. He remained a mainstay of the NYC Labor Chorus. He was a devoted husband to Alice, his wife of 40 years, and father to their wonderful daughters, Jennifer and Sabrina, who carry on their father's spirit. Denis was instrumental in creating an amazing network of support from prominent members of the legal, banking, and corporate communities, for Brooklyn A's legal work, particularly its representation and collaboration with a network of very effective neighborhood based, community controlled non-profit groups that build and sustain housing, schools, and day care, health and senior citizen centers. Denis always stayed in the background, and invested his incredible abilities to the greater good. He will remain in our memories and serve as a model for us all. Our love and thoughts go out to Alice, Jenn and Sabrina.

FREEDMAN--Eugene. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Eugene Freedman, a Life Member of our National Board of Governors, friend, advocate and true champion for America's young people. Gene Freedman's involvement with Boys & Girls Clubs of America covers more than two decades, including his service on committees for both government relations and marketing, and his sponsorship of one of our most important annual events, the Congressional Breakfast in Washington, D.C. Just last fall, Gene was presented the Jeremiah Milbank Medallion for his years of generosity and commitment to the Boys & Girls Club mission. He is also a recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, the organization's most prestigious honor. Gene Freedman was an elegant and exceptional human being who will be greatly missed by everyone throughout the Boys & Girls Club family. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Rick Goings, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO

Imagine, if you will, the Tony Award-winning musical of 2108. The set, created entirely by Industrial Light & Magic, is a black box filled with constantly shifting 3-D animation. A virtual orchestra replaces musicians. And as for actors, who needs them? Holograms of Nathan Lane and Patti LuPone will be earning standing ovations. To some this may seem like a dystopian nightmare. But we've been inching toward it, and maybe that's not an entirely bad thing. In the last few years Broadway set designers have experimented with increasingly sophisticated animation and projections, to mixed results. But perhaps no Broadway show has so ably integrated computer-generated animation and real, old-fashioned sets as ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' a Roundabout Theater Company production at Studio 54. Its director, Sam Buntrock, points to the future with virtual characters, like an animated dog that gets some of the evening's biggest laughs.

Peoples' eyes constantly deceive them, and that was certainly true in Paris in the fall of 1996, when Rei Kawakubo, the designer behind Comme des Garçons, presented a collection of dresses swollen with huge lumps. In profile, the models looked like hunchbacks or camels tipped onto their sides. There were smaller, kidney-shaped masses on shoulders and arms, most covered in cheerful gingham. The clothes confounded critics, even those used to Kawakubo's abstract methods. Amy Spindler wrote in The New York Times that Kawakubo had ''invented whole new deformities for women.'' During the show, which was conducted in silence, one photographer muttered, ''Quasimodo.'' ''Lumps and Bumps,'' as the collection came to be called, illustrates the difficulties for a designer of being not merely original but also a modernist. Kawakubo said she was interested in exploring ''volume and space.'' If you begin with the outline made by her shapes (the classic ''silhouette'') and then pull back -- moving away, as it were, from the confinements of fashion -- you realize that Kawakubo has in fact recreated a reality of the late 20th century: the individual seemingly joined to her backpack and her burdens; even the act of talking on a cellphone assumes a spatial connection, producing what appears in the abstract to be a growth. Kawakubo's objective was not to distort the female body but rather to express a thought that probably, for her, began with a gesture or a glimpse. Some designers, like Alber Elbaz of Lanvin and Azzedine Alaïa, solve problems of dressmaking -- putting darts in a skirt to give it softer volume. Kawakubo, working more in the spirit of an artist than any designer today, attacks the problems of consciousness.

LEHMAN--Orin, educator, philanthropist, civil rights advocate and conservationist with a life-long commitment to public service, died February 22, 2008. He died peacefully at home in New York City surrounded by his loving family. The cause of death was pneumonia. He was the son of the late Allan Sigmund and Evelyn Schiffer Lehman, and the brother of the late Ellen Lehman Long. He was the grandson of Mayer Lehman, founder of Lehman Brothers investment house, and grandnephew of Herbert Lehman, the former Governor of New York and U.S. Senator. He was 88. Mr. Lehman grew up in Tarrytown, NY, graduated from the Scarborough and The Taft Schools, Princeton University and New York University where he earned masters and doctorate degrees in American history. In 1947 he partnered with Eleanor Roosevelt and Bernard Baruch, and founded Just One Break (JOB), whose mission is to find competitive employment for people with disabilities. JOB is the nations's oldest not-for-profit employment service for people with disabilities. Over half a century after founding it, Orin Lehman remained Chairman Emeritus of its board of directors until his death. In 1975, Gov. Hugh L. Carey offered Mr. Lehman the job of Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation and he jumped at it saying it is ''The greatest job in the world.'' He was re-appointed by Governor Mario Cuomo, and by the time he retired in 1993, he had served 18 years as Commissioner, the longest period of any individual in that position. He was a soft-spoken man with a quiet bearing which belied his sense of humor and fun-loving nature. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family. Mr. Lehman was married to the late Jane Bagley Lehman and is survived by his former wife, Wendy Vanderbilt Lehman, his three daughters, Susan Lehman Carmichael (Trent) of Greenwich, CT, Brooke Lehman of New York City, Sage Lehman of New York City and his four grandchildren Avery, Haley, Ryan and Whitney Carmichael. His companion Monique Van Vooren and his beloved Boston Terrier, Snookums, also survive him. A Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Tuesday, February 26th at 5:00pm. The Rabbi Ronald Sobel will officiate. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations may be made to Just One Break (JOB), 570 Seventh Ave, NY, NY 10018. www.justonebreak.com LEHMAN--Orin. Lehman Brothers mourns the loss of a community leader who devoted time selflessly to a number of causes to better the lives of others. Notable among his many philanthropic efforts was a lifetime of devotion to Just One Break and to the enhancement of our quality of life through the preservation of New York State's parks. The Firm extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Richard S. Fuld, Jr. Chairman and CEO Lehman Brothers LEHMAN--Orin. In sorrow Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our distinguished and longtime member, Orin Lehman. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Rabbi David M. Posner Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel Sr. Rabbi Emeritus, Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary LEHMAN--Orin. The partners and staff of Ceasar & Smilow LLP regret the passing of our friend and client. We extend our sympathies to Orin's family and friends. He will be missed, and we thank him for all the good work he did for those less fortunate.

THE WILD SIDE From the abyssal depths to the tropical shallows, the ocean teems with myriad creatures. On land, too, organisms occupy every conceivable niche, from deep in the bowels of the earth to the tops of the highest mountains. The air is different. To be sure, many creatures travel through it. Some flit briefly, as when a flying squid bursts from the ocean's foam, zooming 20 meters or so before plopping back into the brine. Young spiders balloon off on silken threads, wafting in the breezes, to find new territories. Other animals make more lengthy journeys, as when butterflies and birds fly for hundreds of miles, migrating to Europe from Africa for the summer.

BRENNAN--Robert. The Board of Directors, Directors Circle, staff and members of Metro International are deeply saddened by the loss of Robert J. Brennan, our friend, teacher and benefactor. As Board Chair since 2005 and a member since 1990, he led with vision, heart and humor. His 30 years with Ernst & Young took him around the world, where, as he used to say, he ''came face-to-face with his stereotypes about people from other cultures, and the stereotypes lost.'' As head of AIFS, in his service on the boards of Richmond and NAFSA, and as an advocate for international exchange in Washington, DC, he was a valued mediator between the non-profit, for-profit and government arenas. Bob was truly a global citizen and he is greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved Helen, his sons Bob and Kevin, and the entire family.

HUNTER--Renate Alsberg, 91, died February 20 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in NYC while courageously undergoing a heart valve repair. Renate was remarkably fit, feisty and free-spirited to the very last day, and was dearly loved by her family and friends. She was fortunate to have had a full, fascinating life: born in Berlin and educated in Switzerland, Renate successfully escaped Nazi Germany and continued her studies in London and later New York, graduating from NYU School of Law to become an attorney and then the cherished wife of Allan B. Hunter. Renate was a deeply devoted mother to Andre Hunter, a loving and supportive mother-in-law to Kelly Hunter, and the much adored grandmother of Max, Cameron and Casey -all of whom will miss her terribly. A celebration of Renate's life is planned for this spring.

STEINHARDT--Roger W., M.D., of Rye, New York, died peacefully on February 22, 2008 at his home at The Osborn. Born on April 6, 1913 in New York, New York, he was 94. He was a loving husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather, a caring and accomplished doctor, and a true friend. He was a graduate of the Franklin School in Manhattan, the University of Pennsylvania and New York University College of Medicine, completed his residency at Bellevue Hospital, and was a medical captain in the European theatre in the U.S. Army during WWII. An internist for four decades in private practice in Manhattan, he was affiliated with Doctors, Lenox Hill and Mt. Sinai hospitals. His patients fondly recollect his reassuring, knowledgeable manner, his gentle wit and his readiness to make house calls night and day -on his bicycle. He was an early advocate of medical peer review and served on many professional committees including as Secretary of the Board of Ethics and thereafter as President of the New York County Medical Society (1980-1981). After leaving private practice in 1986, he was a medical advisor in the Office of Professional Medical Conduct-State of New York, Department of Health until 2003 when he retired his stethoscope at the age of 89. A life-long golf enthusiast, he was a longtime member, among other clubs, of Fairview Country Club and shot a hole in one shortly after his 80th birthday. Boating was another joyous pastime, enjoyed on many weekends on LI Sound captaining BonBini, his boat, moored on the creek at Fairfield Beach. His early attachment to Maine and Camp Winnebago never withered; indeed, he returned long past counselor age limits to serve as camp doctor. His deepest and most constant passion and love was for his growing family. He was predeceased by his wife of 29 years, Susanne J. Bleecker of New York, in 1974. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Alice Rogers of Rye, NY; two daughters, Jill Steinhardt Goldman of Bedford, NY and Manhattan and Nancy Steinhardt Fuzesi of Greenwich, CT; three step-children, Tom Rogers of Larchmont, NY, Barbara Rogers of Chevy Chase, MD, and Tracey Rogers of Newton, MA; eleven grandchildren: Jeff Goldman of Portland, ME, Stephen Fuzesi of Washington, DC, Daniel Goldman of Cincinnati, OH, Robyn Sue Goldman of San Francisco, CA, Timothy Fuzesi of Greenwich, CT, Robert Rogers of Cambridge, MA, Jessica and Jason Rogers of Larchmont, NY, Isaac and Jake Schwartz Rogers of Newton, MA, and Cassia Williams Rogers of Chevy Chase, MD. He is also survived by his sister, Peggy S. Laval of Manhattan. Friends are invited to a family memorial gathering on Sunday morning, February 24, 2008 at 11:00am to be held at The Osborn, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY 10580 (914-921-2200). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dr. Roger W. Steinhardt's name and memory to a charity of the donor's choice.

One hundred years ago, a nickel bought admission to what President Theodore Roosevelt called the “greatest subaqueous tunnel in the world” and a “bigger undertaking than any Alpine tunnel which has yet been constructed.” He meant the Hudson & Manhattan Railroad, which linked New Jersey and New York for the first time on Feb. 25, 1908.Today, admission is free.

The fearsome “blowtorch effect,” which has killed 11 people in New York City fires since 1980, has drawn firefighters and engineers to Governors Island in an expanding search across the nation for better ways to prevent or contain high-rise infernos, Thomas J. Lueck reports.

Allan Ishac’s “New York’s 50 Best Places to Find Peace and Quiet,” a guidebook he started in 1991, offers a rich trove of suggestions for any New Yorker who wants to get away from — but perhaps not too far away from — the busy bustle of the city. But keeping the list fresh has required Mr. Ishac to make some editorial choices over the years. Earlier editions recommended the Russian and Turkish Baths, but then Mr. Ishac heard from readers who felt an uncomfortable vibe from other clients. Mr. Ishac also removed the Carapan Day Spa after a reader told him she had been yelled by the staff for complaining about construction noise. (The spa’s staff confirmed the customer’s account. The spa has since closed and is now a boutique health club called Clay.)

For many years, the feeling among my friends was that you couldn't get a bad meal in Paris, or even in France. That's changed, of course. Chalk it up to globalization or anything else you like. But the feeling remained that the serious restaurants were still serious, and that, music and odd clothing aside, the French, especially Parisians, really understood good taste.
(Jessica Antola)

If Jerry Yang is upset that Microsoft bid to buy the company he co-founded 13 years ago, it didn't prompt any angry words as he spoke Monday morning at the Interactive Advertising Bureau's annual meeting in Phoenix. Rather, he talked about how the bid for Yahoo and the company's frenzied search for a way to fend it off has been an exciting journey of self discovery.

In December, when Activision and Vivendi Games announced they were joining forces, Brent Thill, an analyst at Citigroup, said "we expect further industry consolidation." He named Take-Two Interactive, which makes the popular video-game series Grand Theft Auto, as a potential takeover target.

There is plenty of bad news in the existing home sales report, even if there was a slight uptick in the seasonally adjusted annual rate of single family sales. Actual sales -- the monthly number before the seasonal adjustment -- are the lowest in a decade for single family homes. For condos, where they have been keeping the data only since 1999, the figure is a record low.

In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes, that "political analysts and journalists, in judging a candidacy gone bad, invariably focus on a campaign's bad moves and wrong turns, with a dash of the requisite infighting among powerful staff aides and complaints by contributors. And the Clinton campaign, after starting off smoothly and with such self-assurance, provided a wealth of that: Wasted money, bad strategic calls on what states to contest, a message that failed to grasp how the mood of Democrats had changed and the questionable deployment of a certain former president."But could even the best-operated campaign have done better against Mr. Obama?

Today, with the NHL stretch run heating up, we start a new feature here on Slap Shot at The Times: Hockey Night in Blogdom. Why? Because a newspaper or TV network has never been able to capture the passions of fans who avidly follow a professional sport and, after all, make the whole thing happen. And besides, who's more passionate than hockey fans? So we'll be asking specific questions of 30 independent bloggers, one for each league club, and through their fevered rantings they'll tell us about the team they support and express their, ahem, core beliefs.
A larger and more spirited crowd of 23,000 turned out in Hawaii for the final two games of the Pan-Pacific Championship.

The Clinton campaign struck back today at suggestions that it was behind the release of a photo of Senator Barack Obama in African garb. In an intriguing response to the Obama campaign's charges, the Clinton campaign manager, Maggie Williams, turned the matter on its head: it essentially suggested the Obama campaign was deriding ethnic dress by making an issue of the photo. At the same time, it did not deny any role in distributing the photo. Here's her statement:"Enough.

The sea scallop is one of the most perfect of nature's convenience foods -- because almost nothing cooks faster. They're also in season through most of the year. Make sure you buy "dry" scallops -- they should not be sitting in liquid (and they should smell like the sea).

Collecting autographs is one of the essential parts of spring training. Fans carry baseballs, caps, pictures and jerseys and hope that their favorite players stop and sign them.

IndyCar: It's official. As reported last week, the Champ Car World Series will fold into the Indy Racing League this season. The I.R.L. schedule will expand from 16 races to 19, and it will include the Long Beach Grand Prix, which had been on the Champ Car calendar.

The unsolicited -- and possibly hostile -- deals keep on coming. The latest example hit Sunday when Electronic Arts, the video game giant, made a $2 billion offer for a rival, Take-Two Interactive Software. Take-Two, the maker of the wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series, quickly rebuffed the bid.

HBO looked awfully smart on Sunday night. The premium cable channel bought the rights to the film "Taxi to the Dark Side" last week, just days before it received the Academy Award for best documentary feature.

As a deal to sell Clear Channel's TV stations looked near, Wachovia now seeks to back out. CNBC's David Faber explains.

He's still only one man, but he's also still two branches of government: Vice President Cheney is still clinging to the notion that his duties as president of the Senate make him part of the legislative branch as well as the executive branch, a Washington Post editorial notes.

If all had gone according to plan, Pakistan would have been the latest government taking part in an unsettling trend from Brazil to Thailand: YouTube blocking. Unlike its predecessors, though, Pakistan also affected thousands of people beyond its borders.

Democrats Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged niceties at a debate last week in Austin, Texas. Over the weekend, however, Mrs. Clinton took a decidedly different tone against Mr. Obama (calling his message one of "magic wands" and "celestial choirs") and said she couldn't wait to debate him in Ohio.

Getty Images, the world's biggest pictures and video distributor, agreed Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

What is an outfit to do when it is confronted by all manner of movies with no runaway hit? Why not spread the hardware around? When the Bagger went to the Governor's Ball following the awards, he noticed that the Oscars were very evenly distributed about the room, as were the smiles.
The Brinks Company, which has been under pressure from activist investors, said Monday it would spin off its home security unit into a separately traded company, Reuters reported.

This week, The Moment is coming to you live from our new Paris headquarters, Colette. T Magazine has invaded Paris's chicest boutique, where we're showing off our films, flaunting our Web site, giving away our new women's fashion issue and making friends with the cool crowd. If you've never been, Colette is more than a hip shop - it's ground zero for Paris's fashion-week scene. Imagine the coolest product-design store with well-curated fashion, books, the best in beauty products, and a subterranean bar that specializes in premium water. Can't wrap your head around it? Stay tuned this week for more news from the shop and it's owner, Sarah, who is our guest blogger.More On Colette:

My colleague Andy Revkin recently had a good chat with Ed Begley Jr. during a pedicab ride in New York, which you can watch at DotEarth. It was the perfect vehicle for discussing Mr. Begley's famed green lifestyle, and it got me wondering: Is a pedicab really more virtuous environmentally than a taxi?

The Bagger went 16-8 (a correction from PriceWaterhouseCoopers to the Bagger's original report of 18-6) on his picks, not magnificent, but good enough in a complicated year. (You can see the winners here.)

Behold the power of plastic: Visa said Monday that its highly anticipated stock sale could raise nearly $18.8 billion, which would make it the largest initial public offering in United States history. In an updated regulatory filing, the credit-card giant said it would sell as many as 446.6 million shares for an expected $37 to $42 per share.
Congress returns from a week-long break today as senators anticipate the reappearance of an issue that has been relegated to the background so far in 2008 - the war in Iraq.

Glam Media, a network of fashion, style and entertainment Web sites, said Monday it had raised $65 million in new venture funding and $20 million in "revenue-based debt financing." The latest financing round was led by Hubert Burda Media, a German publishing group, and includes GLG Partners, a publicly traded hedge-fund firm.

Shares in the Royal Bank of Scotland jumped more than 5 percent on Monday on hope that Qatar's sovereign wealth fund could take a stake and the expectation it will lift its dividend and post strong results this week.

Citigroup said on Friday that it had provided a $500 million line of credit to its Falcon multistrategy fixed-income hedge funds, and as a result will move the funds' $10 billion of assets and liabilities onto its balance sheet.
The New York Philharmonic readies to make its historic journey to Pyongyang, North Korea.

Cablevision has been quietly working with Bear Stearns on ways to enhance shareholder value, including putting a value on its Rainbow Media unit ahead of a possible sale and drawing up a list of targets for potential acquisitions, according to The New York Post.
A deal between the CME Group and The New York Mercantile Exchange to create a $40 billion futures trading powerhouse could be formally announced by early March, The New York Post reported.

Two former Wall Street chieftains and the head of the nation's largest home lender will testify next week before a congressional committee examining the link between executive pay and the mortgage crisis.
Another buyout is in danger of collapsing - but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

Having exhausted its best ideas on how to deal with Google, Microsoft is now working its way down the list to dubious ones - like pursuing a hostile bid for Yahoo, says Randall Stross, writing in The New York Times.

The weather forecast may call for snow and good skiing conditions in Avon, Colo., on Monday. But no one at the luxury resort, near Aspen, will be hitting the slopes - or eating $105 Kobe steaks - on Countrywide's dime this week.

Temasek Holdings, a decades-old Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, has its roots as a financial backer of domestic companies. In recent years, however, Temasek has moved aggressively, first within Southeast Asia, then Asia as a whole and finally to the West. It has acquired stakes in critical industries such as telecommunications and in companies that are household names, most recently Merrill Lynch.

United Airlines is pondering its strategic options as stalled talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines threaten other linkups, including a potential tie-up between United and Continental Airlines, The Chicago Tribune reported.

Royal Bank of Canada has won one of Canada's last remaining independent money managers with a 1.36 billion Canadian dollar ($1.35 billion) takeover bid for Phillips Hager & North Investment Management.
Philanthropies, discovering that for-profit status and financing can be a useful tool, are changing their spots and making use of some of capitalism's virtues, The New York Times reports.

Congratulations to Tilda Swinton and Marion Cotillard, who won top honors at last night's Academy Awards. Both ladies played leading roles on the cover of T Magazine and we couldn't be more proud of them. Ms. Cotillard won best actress for "La Vie en Rose" and Ms. Swinton's role as a corporate climber in "Michael Clayton" paid off. Get caught up on Hollywood's new royalty: read T's profiles of this year's best actress and best supporting actress.
Got a good idea for a health care application? If so, you could get as much as $500,000 in funding from Microsoft.
The Vanguard Group, a fund manager known for its low-cost portfolios, surprised the industry on Friday when it announced that its chief executive, John J. Brennan, would step down.
Three suitors vying for Morgan Stanley's stake in China International Capital Corporation have cut the value of their offers, The Wall Street Journal reported.
HSH Nordbank, a state-controlled German bank, said Sunday that it planned to sue the Swiss bank UBS over a portfolio of complex debt products it contends were mismanaged and improperly sold by UBS.

China's increasingly aggressive sovereign wealth fund is poised to unleash a $10 billion investment spree in Japan and is initially expected to set its sights on the energy sector, The Times of London reported.
Shares in Biffa , a British waste management company, fell more than 6 percent Monday after the company disclosed that all but one bidder for the business had dropped out.
Two former executives of Marsh, the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

UBS, Switzerland's largest bank, on Sunday denied a newspaper report that its chairman, Marcel Ospel, would definitely leave after another year at the helm, but reiterated that his future after that period was undecided.

Aon said Friday that it has agreed to acquire Arthur J. Gallagher's reinsurance brokerage operations in the United States and Britain for $30 million, plus an additional sum based on the performance of the businesses in the coming year.
China Railway Construction has cut the size of its initial public offering in Shanghai amid signs a slew of new shares entering the market is overwhelming investor demand.

Nakheel, the state-controlled Dubai developer, has purchased a half interest in a Mexican resort, its first foray into Latin America. Nakheel paid $315 million (€213 million) for the 50 percent share of Palmilla, a high-end resort and condo development outside Cabo San Lucas, on the southern tip of Baja California.

Our review of the hastily prepared, strike-challenged Oscars broadcast says its host, Jon Stewart, had "a few amusing lines but clearly didn't have time to put together a polished and cogent monologue." The main coverage notes that he riffed on the three-month walkout by writers:

For Newport, Ind., the removal of chemical weapons agents is a blessing and a curse.

The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.
A 38-minute documentary about the struggle of a New Jersey lesbian to win domestic partner benefits beat out three other films to win for best documentary short subject.

Minnesota tackle Bryant McKinnie was arrested for aggravated battery after a brawl outside a nightclub in Miami early Sunday. McKinnie was also charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest without violence, according to a police report.The police report said that the authorities were called to Club Space after a fight broke out; McKinnie had been thrown out by a nightclub security guard and was arguing and spit on Eric Otero. Otero, 32, said he would not press charges if McKinnie left. The police said McKinnie then went to a nearby strip club, but returned and fought again with Otero.The 6-foot-8, 335-pound McKinnie, a starter on the Vikings’ offensive line who was drafted out of Miami in 2002, was arrested and bonded out for $9,000, the Miami-Dade County Corrections Department spokeswoman Janelle Hall said.
The passenger, returning home from Haiti, collapsed and died aboard an American Airlines flight after initially being told by a flight attendant that he could not give her oxygen.
A 6-month-old infant in the Bronx suffered critical injuries on Saturday when she was accidentally struck by the head of a golf club that snapped off her grandfather’s club.
The Rangers were clearly the stronger team Sunday and they dominated the first period, outshooting the Panthers by 12-5 and keeping the play overwhelmingly in Florida’s end.

The Chicago Bears and tight end Desmond Clark agreed to a two-year contract extension through the 2010 season. He has averaged 13.2 yards a catch over the last two seasons, the most among N.F.L. tight ends.

David Nalbandian earned his eighth career title, rallying to defeat José Acasuso, 3-6, 7-6 (5), 6-4, at the Copa Telmex final in Buenos Aires. Acasuso took advantage of Nalbandian’s errors on long rallies in the first set, but Nalbandian’s serve improved in the second.

Maria Sharapova defeated Vera Zvonareva, 6-1, 2-6, 6-0, in the Qatar Open final, improving to 14-0 this season and earning her 18th career title.Sharapova earned $414,000 for the victory, the largest prize on the WTA Tour outside of the Grand Slams.

Shani Davis of the United States won his second speedskating title in three days, edging Denny Morrison of Canada in the 1,000 meters in Heerenveen, Netherlands.Davis finished in 1:08.63. Morrison was 0.12 behind and Simon Kuipers of the Netherlands was third. Paulien van Deutekom of the Netherlands won the women’s 1,000 in 1:16.77. Fei Wang of China was second (1:17.09) and Ingeborg Kroon of the Netherlands was third.

Maria Riesch of Germany won the women’s World Cup super-combined, defeating Marlies Schild of Austria by nine-hundredths of a second in the only World Cup event in Whistler, British Columbia, before the 2010 Olympics.Lindsey Vonn led the United States with a sixth-place finish, but her lead in the overall World Cup standing was trimmed to 54 points over Nicole Hosp of Austria, who finished fourth in the super-combined.Riesch, who had the fastest time in the super-giant slalom in the morning, took a careful approach in the slalom in the afternoon, finishing with a 2:10.07 total.

Tottenham won its first trophy in nine years Sunday, rallying to beat Chelsea, the defending champion, 2-1, in extra time in the League Cup final in Wembley, England.Jonathan Woodgate scored the winning goal in the fourth minute of added time. Chelsea goalkeeper Petr Cech saved Woodgate’s first header off Jermaine Jenas’s free kick, but the ball ricocheted back onto Woodgate’s head and into the empty net. It was the Spurs’ fourth League Cup title, moving them into a tie with Chelsea and Nottingham Forest for third most in tournament history.

Bernard Gruber of Austria won a Nordic combined World Cup event in Zakopane, Poland, for his first victory of the season.Gruber, who was second after the ski-jumping portion, won with a total of 18 minutes 51.8 seconds after completing the 7.5-kilometer sprint. Tommy Schmid of Switzerland was second, 12 seconds behind, and Bill Demong of the United States, who was the fastest in the sprint, was third, 13 seconds back.

Tiger Woods’s 8-and-7 victory over Stewart Cink in the final, the largest margin in the history of the event, concluded an astonishing week of play.

BERMAN--Stanley. The lawyers and staff of the law firm Bryan Cave LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Stanley Berman, of counsel to Bryan Cave and name partner of our predecessor firm Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman. Stanley was a true man of the people. He touched every constituency of the firm, lawyers and staff alike. He served as Chief Counsel and Associate Deputy Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration prior to joining Robinson Silverman, and for his entire life remained devoted to the cause of affordable housing. He was a champion of diversity of all types. He was a charter member of Women in Housing and Finance, and to date, the only man to serve on its Board of Directors. He served on the Board of Jewish Association for Services for the Aged from 1971 until his passing. Stanley had a unique blend of legal acumen, loyalty to clients and colleagues, and warm devotion to family and friends. We will sorely miss his wise counsel and wry humor. Our heartfelt condolences to Sharon and Alec, to Stanley's grandchildren and to the entire Berman family.

(49) BUFFALO BILL Born in a log cabin in Iowa in 1846, William Cody, left, fought Indians, worked as a Pony Express rider and earned his nickname while hunting buffalo to feed construction crews building the Kansas Pacific Railroad. After the Civil War he was a frontier scout before transforming himself into a showman, touring across the United States and Europe for three decades in ''Buffalo Bill's Wild West'' show. This ''American Experience'' documentary explores the life and times of the man who helped create the myth of the American West that still lives today. 8 P.M. (ABC) A RAISIN IN THE SUN Kenny Leon's television adaptation of the 2004 Broadway revival of the Lorraine Hansberry play, which he also directed, starring Sean Combs, Phylicia Rashad and Audra McDonald.

The Texas and Ohio Democratic primaries on March 4 are critical to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has lost the last 11 contests. The latest polls show that the races are close. In Texas, Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama are neck and neck. In Ohio, Mrs. Clinton has a slight lead. Those likely to vote consider Mrs. Clinton to be a stronger leader, while Mr. Obama is seen as more electable. But voters are more evenly split on the question of which candidate will bring change to Washington, a main tenet of Mr. Obama's campaign.
