DANCIS--Ethel, 94, died on Friday evening in Sacramento, California. Wife of 59 years to the late Winston Dancis and sister to the late Eleanor and Monroe Schachner, Ethel graduated from Eastern District H.S. and Brooklyn College in Brooklyn, NY. A life-long socialist and activist, Ethel was a street-corner orator as a 14 year old and an active member of the Young Peoples Socialist League, the Socialist Party and the Workmen's Circle. A teacher at JHS 127 and Theodore Roosevelt H.S., both in the Bronx, she was a committed member of the United Federation of Teachers and a leader in the 1960 strike that led to the union's recognition. Ethel was also a proud member of the Three Arrows Cooperative Society for more than 70 years. She is survived by sons Douglas Dancis of Laurel, Maryland, and Bruce Dancis of Orangevale, California, daughter-in-law Karen DeanDancis, and grandchildren Chloe Taylor, Lily Dancis, Alexis Dean and Nick Dean. At Ethel's request, no funeral services are planned. Contributions in her memory may be made to Planned Parenthood.

WILLIS--Cynthia Mirei. The board and staff of Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors extend heartfelt condolences to Cynthia's husband Nicholas and to the Willis and Kerr families. Cynthia's capacity for kindness, dedication and enthusiasm inspired us all. She was in many ways the heart of our organization. Her memory will endure as a blessing to all who knew her. Kevin P.A. Broderick, Chair, Board of Directors Melissa A. Berman, President WILLIS--Cynthia Mirei, died on February 20th at the age of 30. For all of her brief, shining life, Cynthia dedicated herself to making the world a better place. She served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Morocco, and committed herself to work in the nonprofit sector and philanthropy, first with the Woodcock Foundation and then with Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors. Cynthia's joyous warmth, charm and creativity endeared her to everyone. Her generous, caring spirit leaves a remarkable legacy of grace. She is survived by her beloved husband, Nicholas Willis, her loving parents James and Eiko Kerr, her adored brother Marshal Kerr, and the entire Willis family: Joseph and Joan Willis, Kathryn and Michael Smith, Benjamin Willis and Ann Willis. The viewing will be on Tuesday, February 26th from 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm at Farenga & Sons, 38-08 Ditmars Blvd., Astoria (718 - 726 - 6060). The funeral will be held at the same location on Wednesday, February 27th at 10am. Donations to honor Cynthia's memory may be made to the Peace Corps Education Fund, 1111 20th Street NW, Washington, DC 20526

LEHMAN--Orin, educator, philanthropist, civil rights advocate and conservationist with a life-long commitment to public service, died February 22, 2008. He died peacefully at home in New York City surrounded by his loving family and friends. The cause of death was pneumonia. Born January 14, 1920, he was 88. He was the son of the late Allan Sigmund and Evelyn Schiffer Lehman, and the brother of the late Ellen Lehman Long. He was the great-grandson of Mayer Lehman, founder of Lehman Brothers investment house, and grandnephew of Herbert Lehman, the former Governor of New York and U.S. Senator. Mr. Lehman grew up in Tarrytown, NY, graduated from the Scarborough and The Taft Schools, Princeton University and New York University where he earned masters and doctorate degrees in American history.In World War II, Lehman was an Army pilot with the rank of Captain. He was badly wounded in Germany during the Battle of the Bulge and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Purple Heart. In 1947 he partnered with Eleanor Roosevelt and Bernard Baruch, and founded Just One Break (JOB), whose mission is to find competitive employment for people with disabilities. JOB is the nations's oldest not-for-profit employment service for people with disabilities. Over half a century after founding it, Orin Lehman remained Chairman Emeritus of its board of directors until his death. Mr. Lehman's first public appointment came in 1950 when President Truman appointed him to the advisory board of the Economic Cooperation Administration where he succeeded his great-uncle Herbert Lehman. In 1952, while an associate in the Lehman Brothers firm, he was designated New York City's Outstanding Young Man of the Year by the Junior Chamber of Commerce. While prominently engaged in public life, Lehman explored a variety of careers. He served as an economic adviser to the U.S. mission at the United Nations, became the Chairman of the New York Board of Corrections, and published weekly newspapers. He served as Chairman of the Board of the New School of Social Research for ten years, where he also taught. In the 1970's he produced theatrical plays offBroadway, among them two hits by Jules Feiffer and the Pulitzer Prize winning play ''The Effects of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds'' by Paul Zindel. In 1975, Gov. Hugh L. Carey offered Mr. Lehman the job of Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation which he accepted, calling it ''The greatest job in the world.'' He was re-appointed by Governor Mario Cuomo, and by the time he retired in 1993, he had served 18 years as Commissioner, the longest period of any individual in that position. Mr. Lehman understood the value that parks would play not only in lives of New Yorkers, but also their overall benefit to the environment. His highest priority was making parks and open spaces accessible to all, long before it was the fashion and the law of the land. He was loved and respected by state park employees who affectionately called him ''Father Nature.'' During his tenure, the Empire State Summer and Winter Games, Senior Games and Games for the Physically Challenged were created. In addition to his public service, Mr. Lehman lived life to the fullest, playing golf, flying airplanes, and never letting his need for crutches interfere with his active schedule. Mr. Lehman was Chairman of the Board of Governors of the American Jewish Committee, a trustee of the Taft School, where he received the Citation of Merit Award, a director for UNESCO, 1968-1971 (United Nations Educational, Scientific & Cultural Organization), a director of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, 1965-1974, a trustee of the Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial Foundation and a member of The Council on Foreign Relations. He was, until his death, a member of The Century Association in New York City. He was a soft-spoken man with a quiet bearing which belied his sense of humor and fun-loving nature. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family. Mr. Lehman was married to the late Jane Bagley Lehman and is survived by his former wife, Wendy Vanderbilt Lehman, his three daughters, Susan Lehman Carmichael (Mrs. Trent) of Greenwich, CT, Brooke Lehman and Sage Lehman of New York City and his four grandchildren Avery, Haley, Ryan and Whitney Carmichael. His companion Monique Van Vooren and his beloved Boston Terrier, Snookums, also survive him. A Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Tuesday, February 26th at 5:00pm. The Rabbi Ronald Sobel will officiate. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations may be made to Just One Break (JOB), 570 Seventh Ave, NY, NY 10018. www.justonebreak.com

Chumby Open, but Not for Business The Chumby is fascinating for a lot of reasons. Meant to replace a clock radio, it is a $179 device with a Wi-Fi connection, a 3.5-inch touch screen and a squishy leather case. It displays various on-screen widgets with information pulled off the Internet, and it plays podcasts, Internet radio and some Web video. Chumby is also interesting because its business model is unusual. It wants to sell its hardware at the break-even point and make its profit from advertising shown on the device. It also publishes technical information so hackers can take the device apart, or install new software, to turn it into whatever their imaginations can concoct. The company isn't going to make any money from these customers, but it's not going to lose any, either.

ERYKAH BADU ''New Amerykah: Part One (4th World War)'' (Universal/Motown) In 1997 Erykah Badu introduced herself with a sweet and to-the-point R&B record (''Baduizm''), transmitting all the basics about her light and efficacious coo, her liquescent phrasing, her mixture of Nation of Islam philosophy and home truths. Then she started getting expansive and interior. Her next hit, ''Tyrone,'' was a routine over a vamp she had worked out onstage. Those long vamps became her direction, at the expense of songwriting and concision. The last time we saw an Erykah Badu album, four-and-some years ago, it was called ''Worldwide Underground,'' the perfect two-word telegram for expansive and interior; it was marketed as an EP, and it was 50 minutes long, full of extended studio jams.

JANET JACKSON ''Discipline'' (Island Def Jam) Some pop stars sing about sex because it sells. Not Janet Jackson, 41, who has been ridiculed -- tirelessly, mean-spiritedly, wrongheadedly and bafflingly -- as an aging sex kitten for the last four years, ever since the 2004 Super Bowl, when her nipple-exposing performance with Justin Timberlake sent her career on a downward slide. (His, too, presumably. Whatever happened to that fellow?) Her sensual, squiggly and quite lovely 2004 album, ''Damita Jo,'' was a flop. So was the flirty -- and quite unlovely -- 2006 follow-up, ''20 Y.O.''

The opening of the trial of three New York City police detectives in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell is the top local news story of the day, and every news outlet seemed to have its own take. In a front-page article in The Times, Michael Wilson describes the sharply diverging perspectives of the prosecution and the defense. Updated, 5:43 p.m. | William Bell, the father of Sean Bell, testified this morning about the final night he spent with his son. The testimony, on the second day of the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, was striking because of the short amount of time that passed — about an hour — between the last time the father saw his son alive and the son’s death.

With New Jersey confronted by staggering debt and shrinking revenue, Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled a grim budget today that calls for eliminating thousands of state jobs, $3.2 billion in program cuts, the trimming of every state department and reduced hours at motor vehicle offices and state parks.

Updated, 4:14 p.m. | After 14 months of negotiation, New York City has agreed to pay more than $21 million to settle a federal class-action discrimination lawsuit filed against the Department of Parks and Recreation and will make “major changes in certain of its personnel practices” as part of the settlement, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund announced today. The settlement, which is expected to be ratified by Judge Denny Chin in United States District Court in Manhattan, includes $11.9 million in back pay and compensatory damages to a group of about 3,500 former and current workers.

For many, a morning cup of coffee is crucial, but in Texas a man tipped a waitress a thoroughbred racehorse after his cup of joe... Democratic House members and university professors of color held two events in Washington within the past 24 hours where they spoke frankly about the issues facing their communities.

Roger Clemens was 50 feet in front of me, walking fast and talking into a cell phone. He was headed to an off-limits area at the Houston Astros' minor league complex here in Kissimmee, Fla., so I rushed forward and asked him if he had a few minutes. He put the cell phone down and agreed to answer some questions.

With Ralph Nader's announcement of a fourth (or maybe fifth) run for president, it is worth taking a minute to recall his most infamous previous campaign: his 2000 presidential bid. The rosy and imprecise glow of memory might lead one to remember it as a well-intentioned effort to make a point that simply went awry. But such a view is far, far more benign than the reality of the Nader 2000 campaign, and therefore a review of that effort is in order to put his current campaign in context.

Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin? Pretty good. Add Marian Hossa to the mix and suddenly you have an absurdly nuclear offensive array. Can this put them over the top for the Stanley Cup this year? (Will Ty Conklin turn into a pumpkin at midnight?) Can they re-sign Hossa at the end of the season? Both good questions. But for now, a power play with Gonchar-Whitney-Crosby-Malkin-Hossa will be feared in the East.

Earlier this month the wine industry held a conference in Barcelona on the effects of climate change on winemaking. I just followed from afar, but I was especially intrigued by the slant in one article, "Bordeaux Big Guns Bullish About Climate Change,'' posted on the Decanter web site.

CINCINNATI, Ohio-A conservative radio talk show host who helped introduce Senator John McCain before a rally here Tuesday used Senator Barack Obama's middle name, Hussein, three times, while disparaging him, prompting Mr. McCain to apologize and repudiate the comments afterward.

Ruth, according to TSN and Sportsnet, prefers to be called Theo rather than Ted. But Notre Dame and CollegeHockeyNews.com list him as Ted or Teddy, in case you were wondering.

The Columbus Blue Jackets have traded defenseman Adam Foote to the Colorado Avalanche, according to Rogers Sportsnet. In return, the Blue Jackets will receive a fourth-round pick this summer and a conditional first-round pick in either this summer's draft or in 2009, depending on whether the Avalanche re-signs Foote, who is eligible to be an unrestricted free agent after this season. Foote, who began his career in the Nordiques/Avalanche organization, waived his no trade clause to return to Denver.
Dennis Letts - who was Tracy Letts's father, and whom many of us saw on Broadway playing Beverly Weston - died last week. The cause was cancer.

The roll call at Rangers practice was complete, save for their two injured players, forward Colton Orr and defenseman Paul Mara. Rangers management was absent, preferring to work the trading deadline business from their Manhattan offices. That left everyone else to pretend it was a normal day.

The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, the graphic designer, sometime muse, and daughter of Carine, shares with The Moment a few of her stylish essentials. Roitfeld Jr. currently freelances for clients such as Peter Som, V Magazine, and Jean Paul Gaultier. No word yet on if she'll be hitting up Paris fashion week.Name: Julia Restoin-RoitfeldAge: 27Occupation: Art directorRetail Standbys: Kiki de Montparnasse, Marc By Marc, Fantasy World (for the latex clothes), and Dary's, a vintage jewelry store in Paris.Book Shop: Le Comptoire de L'image in Paris and Strand Bookstore in New York.Provisions: Sunrise Mart on 3rd Avenue, WholefoodsGifts: Kiki de MontparnasseRestaurant: Omen, Indochine, Caviar KaspiaCocktail: Vodka tonic or a lychie martiniParty Central: Matisse in Paris, The Beatrice Inn in NYMomentary style obsessions: Miu Miu's Spring '08 collection, Repetto, and the new turban cashmere hat I got for winter!Reading Material: Paris Vogue!Art Pick: Cocteau drawings; GauguinMuseums: Musée d'Orsay (more for its architecture than its content)Vacation: Anywhere where I can disconnect a bit from NY!Winter Survival Tip: Tons of Moisturizer!

Somebody trashed a San Francisco landmark that doubled as temporary housing for local officials, resulting in as much as $25,000 in damage, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. The boyfriend of the city's recently installed planning director is under arrest in connection with the vandalism, which included tossing furniture around and painting the place red with a can of crushed tomatoes. (In San Francisco, even the graffiti is organic.)

Shrimp-shell stock is the most easily and quickly made stock there is, the one that provides the most punch for the least hassle. It's perfect, too, for a shrimp-based pasta sauce. I first tried this little ragù -- it has some of the same seasoning as the classic meat sauce of central Italy -- in Venice, where it was made with the soft, small local shrimp and fresh pasta.

News agencies are reporting that the Pakistani government lifted its restrictions on its citizens' access to YouTube after a video that it deemed blasphemous was removed. And the nation confirmed that its decision to impose those restrictions accidentally led to a global disruption of YouTube for two hours on Sunday.

Wachovia is seeking to have the court declare that it is no longer required to finance Providence's $1.2 billion acquisition of Clear Channel Communications' television unit.

Creating a video game costs around $20 million. So for $2 billion, Electronic Arts could develop 100 new titles. Instead, it wants to pay $2 billion for Take-Two Interactive, known primarily for one particular game, Grand Theft Auto.

[UPDATED, 8:30 a.m.] After several years of planning and digging, the world has its first secure, deep-frozen repository for backup supplies of seeds from hundreds of thousands of plant varieties that underpin agriculture. The Svalbard Global Seed Vault was built into a frigid mountainside in Norway's northernmost archipelago, deep in the Arctic. It had its ceremonial opening Tuesday morning in the frigid gloom of the Arctic winter. [UPDATE: Many readers wondered about whether it was too close to sea level. But, as I learned in my three Arctic trips, things up there are way more spread out than they appear. The tunnel entrance is 130 meters, or about 400 feet, above sea level. So all can rest easy on that front.]
Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines shares fell on Monday partly on concerns their merger talks may fail on the inability of pilots to agree on how to combine their ranks.

Goldman Sachs said it expects additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup estimated to record the highest amount of about $12 billion.

French President Nicolas Sarkozy stepped up pressure on the head of Société Générale to quit over the bank's record trading scandal on Tuesday, but France's top business lobby warned him not to interfere.

FriendFeed, the social, shared feed reader similar to Facebook's news feed, has announced a $5 million round of funding from Benchmark Capital as well as FriendFeed's co-founders and former employees of Google, Paul Buchheit and Sanjeev Singh.

Hong Kong gets a bad rap for not being much of a "culture" city--the old cliche is that we're all too busy counting our money to think about Art. Meanwhile, the HK government, along with various cultural promoters and poobahs, are tripping over each other trying to promote schemes to Culture-ize the city. For without Art, how can Hong Kong ever hold its head up as a Great World City?
Two hedge funds trying to elect a dissident slate to the board of The New York Times Company have raised the ante in their bid to push through changes at the media company.

Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund investor mired in turning around Sears Holdings, has been looking for a chief executive to run the retail giant since last fall, a longer time period than publicly acknowledged, according to The Chicago Tribune.

The first three dresses at the Balenciaga show this morning were modern takes on the black cocktail sheath--I should say, extremely modern takes. Nicolas Ghesquiere cut everything close, in fabrics that might typically be stiff--like patent leather and thick wool crepes--but the effect was very light. You could see that his aim was to make everything light: the fabric, the cutting, the mentality. If you think of the couture structure from the 50s and 60s, and from his own recent collections, Ghesquiere still had subtle volumes in his opening dresses but it was as though he had stripped it down.

The Justice Department approved UnitedHealth Group's $2.4 billion acquisition of Sierra Health Services on Monday, but required UnitedHealth to sell its Medicare Advantage business in Las Vegas to Humana as a condition.
Lawyers for Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, and the government will soon face off once again as his side argues to erase his convictions while prosecutors seek to maintain them.
Brink's has decided to make its home security unit a separate, publicly traded company, following pressure from activist investors to spin off one of its two business segments.

Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan's $48.5 billion proposed takeover of the Canadian telephone company BCE, the largest buyout in history, will comply with foreign ownership restrictions and broadcasting rules, the pension plan's chief executive officer said Monday as the federal communications regulator grilled him about who will control the company.

Novell said Monday it plans to acquire PlateSpin, a provider of virtualization services, for $205 million, a move that could bolster Novell's software for helping customers manage their computing operations.

Radar Networks, which is preparing a public beta launch of Twine, a Web application that organizes and manages information, has raised $13 million in Series B funding from Velocity Interactive, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, and Vulcan Capital.
HDFC Bank on Monday offered $2.4 billion in shares for its smaller rival, the Centurion Bank of Punjab, in an attempt to bulk up before the banking sector is opened to foreign competitors.

The British cable operator Virgin Media said Monday that it would appeal the British Competition Commission's ruling that BSkyB must cut its stake in the rival broadcaster ITV, arguing that the regulator was not requiring a big enough divestment.
Five former insurance executives were found guilty Monday of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.

Following Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

In his first home game with the Dallas Mavericks in more than 11 years, Jason Kidd had 11 points, 9 rebounds and 8 assists Monday night in a 102-94 victory against the Chicago Bulls.
The Mets’ Duaner Sánchez’s journey back to the mound began in the wee hours of Aug. 1, 2006, after Sánchez separated his right shoulder in a taxicab accident near Miami.
Peter Forsberg, the league’s most valuable player in 2003, has agreed to return to the Colorado Avalanche through the end of the season.

The chairman and chief executive of American Express received compensation valued at $53.2 million in 2007, nearly double the $27.3 million he received in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday.
Maya Moore scored 18 of her 29 points in the second half to lift No. 1 Connecticut to a 74-69 victory at No. 6 Louisiana State on Monday night, ending the Lady Tigers’ 14-game winning streak.
William A. Barclay, and his Democratic opponent, Darrel J. Aubertine, both laid claim to the Independence Party nomination in Tuesday’s hotly contested election for a vacant State Senate seat.

Officials of the New York City Marathon started accepting lottery applications Monday for the Nov. 2 race on their Web site. Applications will be accepted until June 1 for those with a United States address and until May 1 for nonresidents and runners eligible for a guaranteed entry. The applications are being accepted online at ingnycmarathon.org. The entry fee for runners chosen in the lottery and those with guaranteed entries are $125 for New York Road Runners members, $155 for nonmembers and $210 for international entries.

Cycling’s international governing body will not recognize this year’s Paris-Nice race in an escalating dispute with the group that also organizes the Tour de France. Pat McQuaid, chief of the International Cycling Union, sent a letter Monday to all professional teams asking that they not compete in the Paris-Nice race organized by the French group Amaury Sport Organization. The rift is also threatening the Tour, with the cycling federation threatening to withdraw antidoping regulators from the event if the A.S.O. and French cycling authorities do not hold their events under the federation’s jurisdiction.

The former Dallas Cowboy Ron Springs, who has been in a coma since fall after surgery to remove a cyst, is listed among the 11 plaintiffs challenging Texas’ medical malpractice cap in a lawsuit filed Monday.The lawsuit challenges the 2003 Medical Malpractice and Tort Reform Act that limits awards in Texas. The lawsuit asks the court to declare the cap unconstitutional.In January, Springs’s wife filed a medical malpractice lawsuit against two doctors she says caused brain damage to her husband during a routine surgery to remove a cyst.Springs, who suffered from Type 2 diabetes, had received a kidney from his former teammate Everson Walls last February. Les Weisbrod, Springs’s lawyer in the medical malpractice lawsuit, has said the coma had nothing to do with the kidney transplant.

Zab Judah was cleared Monday to reapply for a license to fight in Nevada, a move that paves the way for a bout against Shane Mosley in Las Vegas in the next few months. The Nevada Athletic Commission reinstated Judah nearly two years after a melee during a welterweight title fight with Floyd Mayweather Jr. The panel said it was satisfied that the 30-year-old Judah (36-5) has behaved well in four recent fights in other states.

The Chicago Bears and quarterback Kyle Orton agreed on a one-year contract extension that runs through the 2009 season. The deal comes two days after Chicago re-signed Rex Grossman, their starter two years ago, to a one-year contract.

The United States will play host to France on indoor hardcourts in Winston-Salem, N.C., in the Davis Cup quarterfinals April 11-13. Russia plays host to the Czech Republic on indoor clay in Moscow, and Argentina takes on Sweden on outdoor clay in Buenos Aires. Germany will face Spain in Bremen; the matches will be played indoors on a surface yet to be decided.
The former Philadelphia television news anchor who was arrested for punching a police officer was told the charges would be dropped if she performed one day of community service and avoided trouble.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Countrywide Financial’s decision to cancel a gathering of bankers at the Ritz-Carlton Bachelor Gulch ski resort in Avon, Colo., referred incorrectly to the resort’s location. It is near Vail, Colo., not Aspen.

An art review in Weekend on Friday about “Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe,” at the Guggenheim Museum, misidentified the southern Chinese city where Mr. Cai was born and raised. It is Quanzhou, not Guangzhou.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about suggestions that the economy may be entering a period of stagflation misspelled the surname of an investment strategist who commented on moves to bolster the economy. He is David Darst, not Durst.

A front-page picture caption on Saturday with the “This Weekend” summary carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph of a wounded soldier in Afghanistan was by Lynsey Addario for The New York Times, not by Joshua Lott.

A headline in some editions of The Arts on Monday with an article about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated, in some copies, the title of the film that won best picture. It is, of course, “No Country for Old Men,” not “Old Country for Old Men.”.

A front-page picture caption on Saturday with the “This Weekend” summary carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph of a wounded soldier in Afghanistan was by Lynsey Addario for The New York Times, not by Joshua Lott.

A front-page article on Feb. 21 about Senator John McCain’s record on lobbying and ethics, including his role in the Keating Five case, described incorrectly the reprimand delivered to three other members of the Senate in 1991 for intervening with government regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. The Senate Ethics Committee rebuked the three senators for improper behavior, but under a parliamentary agreement the full Senate did not censure them or take any other vote on the matter.

The police issued arrest warrants for four Temple University students charged with beating a man outside the former location of a Jewish fraternity, and categorized the attack as a hate crime. Investigators said the students used anti-Semitic slurs during the beating Feb. 15 outside the former Alpha Epsilon Pi house. The chapter of the international Jewish fraternity moved recently to a new location. The victim, who was not a Temple student, was seriously hurt, school officials said. The four students were suspended. School officials said they were awaiting results of the investigation before deciding whether to expel them.

An Austrian tourist died after being bitten by a shark while diving near the Bahamas in waters that had been baited with bloody fish parts to attract the sharks. Markus Groh, 49, a lawyer in Vienna, was on a commercial dive trip when he was bitten about 50 miles off the coast of Fort Lauderdale, said Karlick Arthur, Austrian counsel general in Miami. The crew aboard the Shear Water, operated by Scuba Adventures, based in Riviera Beach, called the Coast Guard, said Petty Officer Third Class Nick Ameen. Mr. Groh was airlifted to a hospital, where he died. It was unclear what type of shark was involved; it got away before anyone could identify the species. The Scuba Adventures Web site says the company offers the opportunity to get “face to face” with sharks.

Immigration agents say they have learned the identity of a van driver charged in a bus crash that killed four children. The driver, Olga Marina Franco of Guatemala, is accused of running a stop sign and hitting the school bus. Investigators say she gave them a fake name after last week’s crash and told them she was from Mexico. Ms. Franco, 24, is charged with four counts of criminal vehicular homicide and lesser crimes. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers say they believe she is an illegal immigrant.

Union Theological Seminary in New York City named the Rev. Dr. Serene Jones, 48, as its new president, making her the first woman to hold the post in the institution’s 172-year history. Currently a professor of theology at Yale Divinity School and chairwoman of its department of Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies, Dr. Jones is only the fourth woman to run an independent, mainline school of theology in the country. In the case of Union, Dr. Jones is taking on an institution emerging from serious financial problems.

Immigrants in the state, about 35 percent of adults, are far less likely than native-born Americans to commit crimes, according to a study by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. Among men ages 18 to 40, the group most likely to commit crimes, native-born Americans were 10 times more likely than immigrants to be incarcerated for crimes in California prisons and jails. The study included both legal and illegal immigrants, without focusing separately on illegal immigrants. But it found that native-born American men ages 18 to 40 were at least eight times more likely to be imprisoned for crimes than Mexican immigrants in that age range who were not naturalized citizens — a group likely to have a high percentage of illegal immigrants.

The Pentagon said the mission to launch a Navy missile-interceptor at a dead spy satellite appears to have succeeded in destroying a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel. The Pentagon said it had reached the conclusion based on studying remnants from the missile strike on Wednesday. The statement said a joint space operations headquarters based at Vandenberg Air Force Base, in California, was tracking less than 3,000 pieces of debris, “all smaller than a football.” Most of the debris, the statement said, had already re-entered the atmosphere or would within coming weeks. There had been no reports of debris hitting Earth, the statement said, adding that “it is unlikely any will remain intact to impact the ground.”.

The Internet scholar Lawrence Lessig decided not to run for a vacant seat in the House of Representatives. Mr. Lessig, the founder of the Center for Internet and Society at Stanford University, had posted a Web video last week hinting of a run for California’s 12th Congressional District, which was held by Representative Tom Lantos, who died on Feb. 11. Mr. Lessig used the same medium to convey a different message Monday, saying that despite seeing an outpouring of support, he had also seen a poll showing him “losing in a big way” to the favored candidate, former State Senator Jackie Speier. Mr. Lessig said he would instead to try to change Congress from the outside. “Losing big in the first important battle is not an effective strategy,” Mr. Lessig said. “My running and losing big would do more harm than good.” The special election to replace Mr. Lantos is scheduled for April 8.
The rapidly mounting fight in Texas has reminded strategists yet again of the state’s unwieldy size and geographical differences.
The buyout packages are among the richest ever offered to factory workers, including one-time cash payments of $140,000.
An elderly woman was found dead in a burning house in Queens on Monday afternoon, fire and police officials said.
Efforts to help imperiled homeowners have met resistance from people who consider the assistance undeserved.
Almost 19 years after the murders of Seymour and Arlene Tankleff, a new grand jury has been impaneled to determine who might have killed the Long Island couple.
The body of a 52-year-old man, his mouth covered by duct tape, was found in a hotel bathtub in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, the police said.
A bill approved by a Senate committee in Trenton, N.J., would help workers with new babies or sick family members. The full Senate and Assembly should approve the bill.
The cozy relationship between the Corps of Engineers and its pork-loving paymasters in Congress has produced dubious schemes over the years, none as patently absurd as this one.
Ralph Nader argues that his voice is crucial to combat corporate greed, Pentagon waste and unworkable health care plans. (Remind us. Which candidate is for any of these things?)
The fund received approval on Monday from the Bush administration to sell gold bullion to stabilize its own shaky finances.
Congress needs to ensure that federal prosecutors appointed by the Bush administration are not using their positions to throw patronage to friends and political allies.
The effort reflects a belief among Clinton advisers that she can win over voters by finally drawing attention-grabbing contrasts with Barack Obama.
A model called the I.B.M. z10 is far faster and has three times the data-juggling memory of its three-year-old predecessor, the z9.
Brad Guzan, an up-and-coming goalkeeper for Chivas USA and the United States national team, was oh-so-close to being gone to Aston Villa of the English Premier League. Enter the bureaucrats.
The executives were found guilty of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.
YouTube was back up after Pakistan, in an act of information provincialism, inadvertently made the video-sharing site inaccessible on Sunday afternoon.
An intriguing element in the drama between Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee is whether or not any of the used items McNamee turned over to authorities may contain Clemens’s fingerprints.

The government said it would start killing elephants beginning May 1 to reduce their growing numbers, ending a 13-year moratorium. Environment Minister Marthinus van Schalkwyk said it was “a last option” to reduce environmental degradation and rising conflicts with humans. There would be no “wholesale slaughter,” he added, but did not specify how many elephants might be killed. The announcement follows months of impassioned debate, with some conservationists, including the World Wildlife Fund, cautiously arguing for elephant culling to protect the ecosystem, and other groups outraged. South Africa had just 200 elephants at the beginning of the 20th century and now has 18,000, a number expected to double by 2020. The new regulations say killing must be through “quick and humane methods,” preferably a single shot to the brain by a marksman in a helicopter.

Belgium’s political parties finally agreed on new reforms, setting aside major differences that have prevented Dutch- and French-speakers from forming a government almost nine months after elections. “At last there is an agreement,” said the leader of the French-speaking Socialists, Elio Di Rupo, after a “wise men’s group” from the main parties hammered out an accord on a first raft of reforms, including the transfer of some federal powers to the regions. Dutch-speaking parties also welcomed the deal, although it fell short of the powers they were seeking for the Flanders region. The protracted political crisis had led to concerns that the country might split in two. Barring any last-minute hitch, the agreement also means that the delayed 2008 budget could be drawn up this week. Then, on March 20, Yves Leterme, the leader of the Flemish Christian Democrats, would replace Guy Verhofstadt, who has been leading an interim government.

Aleksandr V. Kazulin, a former presidential candidate who has been serving a five-and-a-half-year prison sentence since leading anti-government demonstrations in 2006, said that he would refuse all food and fluids beginning Tuesday unless the authorities allowed him to attend the funeral of his wife, Iryna, who died of cancer on Feb. 23. He said he would then die swiftly in prison — a person on a “dry” hunger strike can usually live no more than a week — forcing the authorities to bury him and his wife together. The West has been pressing the Belarussian government for his release. Javier Solana, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, urged Belarus to release Mr. Kazulin “immediately and unconditionally, so that he can be reunited with his family and attend his wife’s funeral.”.

Pope Benedict XVI called for those caring for the dying to be granted “death leave” similar to maternity leave for couples. “Similar rights should be accorded to close family members at the moment the illness of their loved ones is at a terminal phase,” he said.

Thousands of protesters — leftists, labor groups, opposition members, students, teachers and representatives of the powerful Roman Catholic Church — took to the streets in Manila, the capital, and 14 other cities to demand President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo’s ouster as the country observed the 22nd anniversary of the popular uprising that toppled Ferdinand E. Marcos. In Manila, about 4,000 marched. One group was blocked by the police from approaching the People Power Monument along the main thoroughfare. Mrs. Arroyo, who has survived three impeachment attempts and four attempted coups in her seven years, still holds the support of the powerful military.
Frustrated with the pace of progressive change in the United States, Ralph Nader did what he once said he would never do: run for president.
UConn’s best and most productive player is Maya Moore, a freshman of seemingly unlimited talent who is a major reason her team is 26-1 and ranked No. 1 in the nation.
The president of the Boston Public Library is objecting to City Hall’s plan to take control of the library’s $54 million in trust funds.
The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.
American Airlines officials said that oxygen had been administered in a timely manner to a passenger after she had trouble breathing, contradicting her family’s story.
The Tigers’ lineup has been bolstered by the trades for third baseman Miguel Cabrera and shortstop Édgar Rentería and given more depth with the acquisition of outfielder Jacque Jones.
Nielsen wants households to let it eavesdrop on Web surfing and cellphone use, but it is finding it a tough sell.
Criticized that its ads are misleading, Pfizer said it would end a campaign using the artificial heart pioneer Robert Jarvik as a spokesman for its cholesterol drug Lipitor.
The European plan is the latest part of the West’s so far unsuccessful carrot-and-stick strategy aimed at getting Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions.
Three police detectives, who once worked undercover, sat at the defense table 15 months to the day after Sean Bell was killed in a blast of 50 unanswered police bullets.
Signs that two embattled bond insurance companies are getting close to restoring their reputations and credit ratings bolstered stocks on Monday.

Undaunted by recent turbulence in the financial markets, Visa Inc., the nation’s biggest credit card network, said Monday that it would forge ahead with what would be the largest initial public stock offering in United States history.
A veteran medical examiner testified that 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown died solely from a blow to the head — not from the blow combined with chronic abuse, as the prosecution contends.
The Service Employees International Union reported that it had spent $1.4 million in Texas and Ohio on Barack Obama’s behalf.
A lawyer for Reggie Bush has asked a court to bar his adversary from turning over a deposition of Bush to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes has posted many entries on his Web site since Jan. 16, offering contests, chats, song lists and the occasional cellphone picture.
Two men were stabbed on Monday at their Manhattan jewelry business by a business associate who claimed they owed him money, the police said.
An explanation of why deals fail: It’s about timing.
After an investment of more than $60 million, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said New York City was ready to track patient’s medical records to provide better preventive care.
A 71-year-old waitress in a Houston restaurant received a retired thoroughbred racehorse this month as a tip from a regular customer.
After Sunday’s game, the Ducks have won 9 of 10 games since Teemu Selanne’s return. They had been winless in their previous six. Coincidence?
Mexicans working in the United States sent back almost $24 billion to their families at home last year, about a 1 percent increase over 2006.
Few commercials aired during this year’s Academy Awards broadcast could be considered Oscar-worthy.
A federal jury has ruled in favor of an Arkansas woman who sued Wyeth after developing breast cancer after taking the company’s hormone replacement therapy.
A top official of the European Union has warned the bloc’s member countries not to pass broad laws to restrict investment from sovereign wealth funds.
The nation’s second-biggest home improvement retailer said that a softer housing market helped drive its fourth-quarter earnings down 33.4 percent.
Beth Mason, who contends that the many suits she has filed are intended to illuminate how Hoboken is spending its $79 million budget, is gaining ground.
The president told governors that he wanted to see the effects of his economic stimulus package before increasing spending on roads and bridges to revive the economy.
As Northern Illinois University reopened after a deadly shooting on Feb. 14, nearly everyone was left wondering what the lasting scars will be.
Leatrice Brewer, previously accused of neglect and abuse, called 911 to say that she had murdered her sons and daughter. She even spelled her name for the 911 operator.
Riders were given a free pass from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. in honor of the 100th anniversary of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation, now known as the PATH.
Manager Joe Maddon said Monday that he knew “little” about what was going on, but he acknowledged that some thought had been given to Barry Bonds.
An Alabama television station that went black during a critical report on Karl Rove said the disruption was unrelated to the broadcast’s content.
The world’s biggest photo and video distributor agreed to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman.
As president of Slovenia, Mr. Drnovsek helped lead his country to independence from Yugoslavia.
A recent oil spill in San Francisco Bay helped demonstrate that “volunteerism can be moved a notch,” said Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.
More than a quarter of adult Americans have left their childhood faith for another religion or no religion.
Less than a week after barring most lawsuits against medical device makers, the Supreme Court is determining whether drug makers should receive similar protection.
Mr. Freedman turned Samuel J. Butcher’s two-dimensional art on greeting cards into the popular Precious Moments figurines.
The commission is considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from delaying the downloads and uploads of heavy Internet users.
Nordstrom cited a “challenging” holiday shopping season, but nonetheless beat Wall Street estimates.
The Pentagon is projecting that when the United States troop buildup in Iraq ends in July there will be about 8,000 more troops on the ground than when it began in January 2007.
Mr. Raab helped extend the button-down preppy look of the early 1960s to women’s clothing. He was also an executive producer of “A Clockwork Orange.”
Senator John McCain said the way voters judge the war would be the way they would judge him.
Nearly a quarter of New Jersey’s school districts may have received beef unfit for human food from a California slaughterhouse through a federal school lunch assistance program.
Despite wanting Johan Santana, Hank Steinbrenner said he supported the direction the Yankees had taken under General Manager Brian Cashman, who has been in his job for 10 years.
The Supreme Court appeared ready to reject the government’s expansive definition of the term “money laundering” on Monday.
The hedge funds are fighting for control of four seats on the 13-member board.
Discount airlines are courting a more lucrative travel market.
Mr. Marlowe was a prolific writer of popular fiction best known for his crime novels featuring the globe-trotting private eye Chester Drum.
A year ago, Eddy Curry was the Knicks’ No. 1 scoring option. Now Coach Isiah Thomas frequently leaves Curry on the bench in fourth quarters and sometimes for entire second halves.
Women are working longer into pregnancy and returning to work faster than they did four decades ago, the Census Bureau said Monday.
Mrs. Carr joined a childhood friend, Rosa Parks, in the historic Montgomery bus boycott and stayed involved in civil rights activism up to her final days.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez is pressing ahead with a project providing free eye surgery to Latin America’s poor, as well as other efforts aimed at lifting his country’s profile across Latin America.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,961 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday :.

The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 20 through Feb. 24 with 1,266 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,115 said they were registered to vote, including 427 self-described Democratic primary voters and 327 self-described Republican primary voters.
But between my techie toys and all of my airline travel, I have become concerned about my carbon footprint.
Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters and is now viewed as the candidate best able to defeat Senator John McCain, according to a poll.
Tonight, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate in Ohio. The Opinion section asked five experts what questions they feel have not yet been answered by the candidates.
The morning after the Academy Awards dawned here with a realization: There will be a lot of gold leaving Los Angeles in the next few days.
To the Editor:.

After a long battle two rare sixth-century B.C. marble sculptures that once belonged to the New York businessman Maurice Tempelsman go on view Tuesday at Italy’s presidential palace. For nearly 30 years rumors circulated that tomb robbers had dug up the statues on a hillside in the ancient Greek settlement of Morgantina in Sicily. After amassing evidence that they were looted, Italian investigators began seeking a handover of the acroliths — statues usually made with wooden torsos but with stone heads and extremities — in the late 1980s. Mr. Tempelsman, a diamond importer perhaps best known for having been the companion of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, remained unswayed until the Italian government threatened to sue him, an official said Monday. “He hadn’t wanted to give them up because he’d paid for them; that’s what he told me,” said Mario Bondioli Osio, who formerly headed of an Italian commission that sought to recover the country’s lost cultural patrimony. Mr. Tempelsman, who was said to be traveling and unavailable for comment, bought the acroliths from the London dealer Robin Symes in 1980 for a reported $1 million. In 2002 Mr. Bondioli Osio, Mr. Tempelsman and the University of Virginia worked out a deal under which Mr. Tempelsman would give the university partial ownership of the statues for five years and then cede them entirely. On Jan. 1 the acroliths — their wooden bodies long ago lost, leaving two heads, three hands and three feet — became the property of the university, which promptly returned them to Italy. The statues, one of which is shown above, arrived in Rome on Friday along with nine classical antiquities from the private collection of the New York philanthropist Shelby White that were ceded to Italy in January under a separate pact. Italy says Ms. White’s artifacts were also looted from Italian soil.

A painting by the Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood will be auctioned this week to raise money for the Royal Academy of Arts, the BBC reported. The sketch of the Royal Ballet stars Carlos Acosta and Darcey Bussell will join works by Tracy Emin, Mary Fedden and Ken Howard that have been donated for the sale. Mr. Wood, who has been exhibiting his art around the world since the 1980s, will be the guest speaker at the auction to “support artists through the Royal Academy Schools so people like me can continue to be inspired by new talent.”.

Putting pixels on body parts didn’t save Fox from the wrath of the Federal Communications Commission. The agency has rejected the network’s contention that an episode of the defunct reality program “Married to America” did not violate decency standards because female breasts and buttocks were pixelized during a raunchy bachelor party scene in 2003, Reuters reported. The commission said: “To be sure, the pixelation of the female strippers’ naked breasts and buttocks does render the material less explicit and graphic than it would have been in the absence of pixilation. However, the material is still sufficiently graphic and explicit to support and indecency ruling.” Fox disagreed. The commission, acting against only those stations subjected to complaints, fined 13 stations and affiliates $7,000 each. Last week it fined ABC stations and affiliates a total of $1.2 million for showing a woman’s bare buttock during an episode of “N.Y.P.D. Blue” in 2003. ABC paid but will appeal. The Supreme Court is expected to consider on Friday if it will hear the F.C.C.’s appeal of an appeals court decision that declared its rulings against fleeting profanities to be “arbitrary and capricious.”.

The Museums Association, founded in 1889 to represent Britain’s museums and galleries, reversed a 30-year ban on selling art and urged its 1,500 members on Monday to get rid of objects that are gathering dust, the BBC reported. “Museums typically collect a thousand times as many things as they get rid of,” Mark Taylor, the association’s director, said in a posting on its Web site (museumsassociation.org.). “Wonderful collections can become a burden unless they are cleared of unused objects.” The association told its members to give unused art to other museums or public institutions or, in exceptional circumstances, to sell it. The organization expressed hope that its new policy would encourage museums to put some pieces on display, and said it expected only a few sales each year. Vanessa Trevelyan, convener of the association’s ethics committee and head of Norfolk Museum and Archaeology Service, said, “Although disposal of items is not without risk, it is preferable to transfer items to an alternative home where they will be treasured, rather than retain material that is not supporting a museum’s research, display or interpretation functions.”.

Ireland has chosen Dustin the Turkey, above, a glove puppet known for belching and a thick Dublin accent, to restore the country’s glory at the Eurovision Song Contest in May, Agence France-Presse reported. The bird, a star of television programs for nearly two decades, defeated five finalists late Saturday, when judges chose his song “Irelande Douze Pointe” (“Ireland 12 Points”), a parody of voting procedures at the Europe-wide competition that also pokes fun of “Riverdance,” the international hit Irish dance show. Composed by Darren Smith and Simon Fine, the song includes the lyrics: “Shake your feathers and pop your beak, shake it to the west and to the east, wave Euro-hands and Euro-feet, wave them in the air to the turkey beat,” The Times of London reported. Ireland has won the contest a record seven times, including three straight in the 1990s, but finished last in 2007 in Helsinki. Dustin has previously run (unsuccessfully) for president of Ireland and recorded with the Irish rock star Bob Geldof.

China plans to promote its traditional culture by adding Peking Opera to the music curriculum in 200 schools in 10 provinces, Reuters reported. “The aim of this program is to help the children develop an interest in the nation’s unique cultural treasures,” said Wang Jun, a cultural official in the Beijing Education Bureau. But hot on the heels of the announcement, reported on Monday in The Beijing News, came critics who complained on the Internet that untrained teachers and forced instruction might discourage students from this 200-year-old art, characterized by complex gestures and trilling vocals. An Internet user who called himself Little Monkey, said, “If the students are forced to learn, it might backfire and make them totally lose interest.”.
To the Editor:.
Lil Wayne's performance on Sunday at Newark Symphony Hall felt positively historic.
Siemens plans to announce that it intends to eliminate up to 40 percent of the workers in its troubled business telecommunications unit in Germany and Brazil.
Both David Sheff and his son, Nic, have books just out; both are memoirs of Nic’s methamphetamine addiction.
The Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions has long drawn ardent audiences of opera buffs and insiders, including managers, company directors and talent scouts.

The results of Perez Hilton's effusive postings have attracted the notice of a major record label.
A House panel has taken steps toward asking for an inquiry into whether Roger Clemens committed perjury.
“Adding Machine” is an impossibly bleak, improbably brilliant little musical.
A new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York contains more than 200 objects and images that may evoke a “whoa” or an “ugh” or simply “huh?”
To conservative ears, recitals like Markus Groh’s at the Frick Collection on Sunday can be said to taketh away, then giveth back.

How long did it take Christo and Jeanne-Claude to realize “The Gates”? Here’s a reminder: One of the four directors of “The Gates,” an HBO documentary about that saffron-hued extravaganza in Central Park, has been dead since 1987.
“The Cherry Orchard Sequel,” written and directed by Nic Ularu, is a sparkling surprise, helped along by fine performances all around.

“When you perform music, something gets in your psyche,” the composer and pianist Joan Tower said before a concert at the Chelsea Art Museum on Saturday honoring her 70th birthday.
Two car bombs exploded in Baghdad and killed at least four more Shiite pilgrims marching to the holy city of Karbala on Monday, just one day after a bombing left 52 dead.
Scientists are writing the Book of All Species on the Web, in the hopes it will be useful to scientists and nonscientists alike.
The presumptive successor to Vladimir V. Putin committed to long-term support of Serbia against an independent Kosovo.
Vladimir Jurowski opened the Russian National Orchestra's program on Saturday with the Schubert Eighth Symphony, the “Unfinished,” in a completion by Anton Safronov.
Four later Godard films, from 1982 to 1993, are included in the “Jean-Luc Godard Box Set.”
Now in Pyongyang as a cellist with the New York Philharmonic, Valentin Hirsu is asking about the fate of three Korean boys from his music school in Romania.
The Taliban has demanded that cellphone companies in Afghanistan cease operating at night because American forces are tracking militants through their mobile phones.
What age is the right age to have “the talk,” not just about where babies come from, but also about sex and AIDS?
People who have trouble controlling their temper may take longer to heal from an injury, a new study finds.
More cases of carbon monoxide poisoning might be caught if doctors began routinely testing emergency room patients for exposure, a new study suggests.
Is there any truth to the idea that if you eat heavily late in the evening, you will gain weight?
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged arms upgrades and other Pentagon support for Indonesia on Monday, as the Bush administration forges closer ties to the country’s military.
Several thousand Palestinians joined peaceful protests in the Gaza Strip along sections of the border with Israel for several hours on Monday.
One of China’s best-known human rights lawyers has been repeatedly beaten by police officers in recent days, according to his wife and associates.

A common test to see how well diabetics control blood-sugar levels can be misleading when the patients are on hemodialysis, researchers say.

Dealt a bad hand at age 29, I decided my only option was hope.

Kofi Annan, the former U.N. secretary general who is trying to broker a political peace treaty in Kenya, expressed rare public frustration, blasting Kenya’s leaders for failing to compromise.

Boxing will survive Wladimir Klitschko’s spiritless defeat of Sultan Ibragimov Saturday night. But can you imagine boxing generating new fans by watching Klitschko throw an endless supply of jabs?
Kadiatou Diallo, the mother of a West African immigrant who was shot to death in another police fusillade, plans to meet with Valerie Bell, whose son was also killed by police.

ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines have again raised domestic fares, adding $10 to round-trip prices on most routes. The latest fare increase, the third this year, was initiated by United Airlines on Friday and matched the next day by the five other network carriers, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that there would probably be some “competitive price jockeying” as airlines roll back the increase on various highly competitive routes, but that over all the higher fare should stick.
Researchers who studied a string of Pacific Ocean atolls are painting the first detailed picture of pristine coral reefs.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said he was concerned that the divisive campaign has gone on for too long.
Scientists are building the first worldwide portrait of human impacts on the oceans, which have left just 4 percent of the seas pristine.
Yahoo plans to introduce a service called Buzz that relies on users to help it compile the most popular articles from around the Web.
Electronic Arts’ $2 billion bid for Take Two — and its popular Grand Theft Auto game — has analysts asking why E.A. is having trouble building new hits on its own.
A diagnosis of prostate cancer is scary enough. But just as scary is that nobody can tell a man the best way to treat it.
Any decent person who looks at John McCain’s record sees that while he has faltered at times, he has also battled concentrated power more doggedly than any other legislator.

JASTRZEMSKI--Christine L., passed away on Saturday, February 23rd from pulmonary hypertension. Chris graduated from Hofstra University and spent the last 20 years with the New York Times Co. She was predeceased by her father Jack Lozier. She is survived by her mother Grace Morris, her husband Jeff, son and daughter-in-law Michael and Nicole, her son Matthew, her cherished pit bull Killian and Kiani, a siberian snow fox. Services are being taken care of by the John Day Funeral Home in Red Bank, NJ. Viewing will be Wednesday the 27th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made to The Lupus Research Foundation.

BERMAN--Stanley. The New York Housing Conference regrets the loss of Stanley Berman, indefatigable housing expert and attorney with a heart. We will miss his knowledge, dedication and friendship. John Kelly and Carol Lamberg
I am taking it seriously, but it's really hard to think about leaving. JERRY THOMAS, on a buyout push by Ford Motor Company. [A1]

A TOP EUROPEAN UNION official has warned the bloc's member countries not to pass broad laws to restrict investment from sovereign wealth funds, despite fears about foreign predators gobbling up European companies. ARROYO RIESTRA-Carmelo. On February 24, 2008. Loving husband and father. Survived by wife Maria, daughter Orietta, son Antonio and grandson, Raul.

GERSHON--Irving. The members of Scarsdale Synagogue Temples Tremont and Emanu-El mourn the death of Irving Gershon, long-time and devoted Officer, Trustee and member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ruth, and daughters, Judith and Hilorie, and the entire family. Our hearts and thoughts are with them. Stephen A. Klein, Rabbi Chanin Becker, Cantor Gerald Cohen, President GERSHON--Irving, on February 23rd. LEHMAN--Orin, educator, philanthropist, civil rights advocate and conservationist with a life-long commitment to public service, died February 22, 2008. He died peacefully at home in New York City surrounded by his loving family and friends. The cause of death was pneumonia. Born January 14, 1920, he was 88. He was the son of the late Allan Sigmund and Evelyn Schiffer Lehman, and the brother of the late Ellen Lehman Long. He was the great-grandson of Mayer Lehman, founder of Lehman Brothers investment house, and grandnephew of Herbert Lehman, the former Governor of New York and U.S. Senator. Mr. Lehman grew up in Tarrytown, NY, graduated from the Scarborough and The Taft Schools, Princeton University and New York University where he earned masters and doctorate degrees in American history.In World War II, Lehman was an Army pilot with the rank of Captain. He was badly wounded in Germany during the Battle of the Bulge and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Purple Heart. In 1947 he partnered with Eleanor Roosevelt and Bernard Baruch, and founded Just One Break (JOB), whose mission is to find competitive employment for people with disabilities. JOB is the nations's oldest not-for-profit employment service for people with disabilities. Over half a century after founding it, Orin Lehman remained Chairman Emeritus of its board of directors until his death. Mr. Lehman's first public appointment came in 1950 when President Truman appointed him to the advisory board of the Economic Cooperation Administration where he succeeded his great-uncle Herbert Lehman. In 1952, while an associate in the Lehman Brothers firm, he was designated New York City's Outstanding Young Man of the Year by the Junior Chamber of Commerce. While prominently engaged in public life, Lehman explored a variety of careers. He served as an economic adviser to the U.S. mission at the United Nations, became the Chairman of the New York Board of Corrections, and published weekly newspapers. He served as Chairman of the Board of the New School of Social Research for ten years, where he also taught. In the 1970's he produced theatrical plays offBroadway, among them two hits by Jules Feiffer and the Pulitzer Prize winning play ''The Effects of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds'' by Paul Zindel. In 1975, Gov. Hugh L. Carey offered Mr. Lehman the job of Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation which he accepted, calling it ''The greatest job in the world.'' He was re-appointed by Governor Mario Cuomo, and by the time he retired in 1993, he had served 18 years as Commissioner, the longest period of any individual in that position. Mr. Lehman understood the value that parks would play not only in lives of New Yorkers, but also their overall benefit to the environment. His highest priority was making parks and open spaces accessible to all, long before it was the fashion and the law of the land. He was loved and respected by state park employees who affectionately called him ''Father Nature.'' During his tenure, the Empire State Summer and Winter Games, Senior Games and Games for the Physically Challenged were created. In addition to his public service, Mr. Lehman lived life to the fullest, playing golf, flying airplanes, and never letting his need for crutches interfere with his active schedule. Mr. Lehman was Chairman of the Board of Governors of the American Jewish Committee, a trustee of the Taft School, where he received the Citation of Merit Award, a director for UNESCO, 1968-1971 (United Nations Educational, Scientific & Cultural Organization), a director of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, 1965-1974, a trustee of the Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial Foundation and a member of The Council on Foreign Relations. He was, until his death, a member of The Century Association in New York City. He was a soft-spoken man with a quiet bearing which belied his sense of humor and fun-loving nature. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family. Mr. Lehman was married to the late Jane Bagley Lehman and is survived by his former wife, Wendy Vanderbilt Lehman, his three daughters, Susan Lehman Carmichael (Mrs. Trent) of Greenwich, CT, Brooke Lehman and Sage Lehman of New York City and his four grandchildren Avery, Haley, Ryan and Whitney Carmichael. His companion Monique Van Vooren and his beloved Boston Terrier, Snookums, also survive him. A Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Tuesday, February 26th at 5:00pm. The Rabbi Ronald Sobel will officiate. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations may be made to Just One Break (JOB), 570 Seventh Ave, NY, NY 10018. www.justonebreak.com

CANTOR--Cecilia Lola (nee Aaronson), died February 23, 2008. Lola was born in Staten Island, NY, on January 5, 1931. She received her Ph.D. in psychology from NYU and taught child development at Queens College. She moved to Scarsdale, NY, in 1968, and maintained an active practice of adult and child psychology until her retirement several years ago. She was a founding member of the Grasmere commune in Rhinebeck, NY. Lola was the loving wife of the late Dr. Morton B. Cantor. Survivors include her sons, David Gersch of Bethesda, MD, and Jonathan Cantor of NYC, their wives, and two grandchildren, Ben and Max Gersch. CRABILL--Frank W. , 1913-2008. Age 94, formerly of Riverside, Connecticut, died on Saturday, February 16 in Stamford. Born in Red Cloud, Nebraska, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Nebraska in 1935. Awarded a Rhodes Scholarship to Lincoln College, Oxford, Mr. Crabill received his B.A. in Jurisprudence in 1938 and in 1939 a First in the B. C. L. and the Vinerian Scholarship. After joining the Wall Street firm later known as Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, he served as an officer during 1942-45 in the Army Air Corps. He returned to his law firm to become a partner in 1952. An ardent sailor, he became Commodore of the Riverside Yacht Club in 1971-72. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Innis Arden Golf Club and the Rocky Point Club. In 1949 he wed Dorothy Jean Smith of Lincoln, Nebraska, a happy marriage ended only by her death from cancer in 1989. He leaves a daughter, Linda Crabill Dowling of Princeton, New Jersey; a son, Robert Ernest Crabill and two grandsons, Miles Andrew and Simon George of San Anselmo, California. A memorial service will be held at 11am. Saturday, March 1, at First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to First Congregational Church, 106 Sound Beach Avenue, Old Greenwich, CT 06870.

PLAYER In Australia, Danny Vukovic, a goalkeeper with Central Coast, was suspended for nine months and put on probation for six months after he struck a referee, Mark Shield, during Sunday's A-League title match against Newcastle. The suspension applies only to league matches, but could be extended to international games. If it were, it would rule out Vukovic's participation in the Olympics; he was expected to be Australia's No. 1 goalkeeper. TEAM In Spain, Real Madrid has lost two consecutive games, and its lead over Barcelona in La Liga is only 2 points. Real lost to 16th-place Real Betis and to 10th-place Getafe. Barcelona, meanwhile, has an eight-game unbeaten streak.

With the writers' strike settled, the stars were back in Hollywood on Sunday for the 80th annual Academy Awards, but many viewers stayed away. Nielsen's ratings estimates suggest that the Oscars telecast on ABC attracted significantly fewer viewers than in recent years, falling short of the previous all-time low set in 2003, when the ceremony coincided with the start of the war in Iraq. Although final ratings were not expected to be released before Tuesday, Nielsen's time-zone adjusted ratings showed the live telecast earned an average of 32 million viewers, down from 33 million in 2003. Last year the Oscars averaged 39.9 million viewers.

JONES--Baird Baird Jones, 53, died last week at home of natural causes. Lively and irreverent, he blazed a swath through New York nightlife as a writer, photographer, party promoter, art critic and raconteur. The son of the late Cranston and Jean Campbell Jones, Baird had a notable collection of academic credentials, from The Buckley School, Groton, Columbia University (undergraduate and two masters degrees) and NYU (a law degree and master of social work), all printed on his legendary nightclub party passes. A witty and skillful interviewer, he wrote under his own byline for ''The East Village Eye,'' various British tabloids, the Daily News ''Rush & Malloy'' column, artnet.com, and contributed freelance items to others. He was the author and photographer of ''Mark Kostabi and the East Village Art Scene 1983-1987.'' His intentionally provocative and daring promotion of nightclubs, from Studio 54 to Webster Hall, earned him the tabloid nickname ''Bad Boy Baird.'' Behind this invented persona, Baird found solace in art and in helping artists. He will be missed by his family, his friends and the many people all over New York who enjoyed his parties. Fittingly, a memorial party is in the works. He is survived by his sister Abigail Jones, his brother-in-law Jeffrey Mandell, his niece Juliana and his nephew Alex Mandell, all of Beverly Hills, CA.

JENNY--Robert, 76, of Mountainside, NJ, formerly of South Orange, NJ, died on February 23. Mr. Jenny was founder and CEO of Jenny Engineering Corp., one of the worlds preeminent experts in the design and construction of tunnels and underground structures. He was named the Engineer of the Year in 1993 by the American Society of Civil Engineers and the Small Business Person of the Year by the U.S. Small Business Administration in 1988. He was a decorated Army Veteran of the Korean War and served in the New Jersey National Guard. Mr. Jenny was on the Board of Overseers of NJIT, and an active volunteer in the Coast Guard Auxiliary as a Flight Observer. He served as Flotilla Commander of Flotilla 10-20 in 2004 and as National Officer, Branch Chief, Public Info. since April 2006. Surviving are his wife, Marcelline D. Jenny; son, Matthew J. Jenny of Madison, NJ; daughter Barbara Rita Jenny of Portsmouth, NH; and four grandchildren.

PRAVDER--Ruth. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Nina Koppelman, President Richard J. Shapiro, Rabbi

RUBIN--Albert L., M.D. The Board of Directors of The Rogosin Institute deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Albert L. Rubin. Dr. Rubin was the first nephrologist in New York to provide kidney dialysis (1956) and renal transplantation (1963). To implement his comprehensive, integrative approach to kidney disease, he created The Rogosin Institute, an affiliate of the New York - Presbyterian Health care System, 25 years ago and had been The Institute's President and Chief Executive Officer since then. He provided the remarkable vision, leadership and compassion that are the heart of The Institute's clinical and research programs. The Rogosin Institute now provides comprehensive treatment of renal disease for thousands of patients. In addition to his work as a physician and teacher, Dr. Rubin had initiated and shepherded The Institute's major research programs in renal disease, diabetes, lipid disorders and cancer. From the beginning of his extraordinary career he had promoted bringing basic research to the bedside as rapidly as possible in order to improve patient care and quality of life. His extraordinary vitality, enthusiasm and wisdom have nurtured The Rogosin Institute and enriched all those who have worked with him. He will be deeply missed. RUBIN--Albert L. M.D. The Medical Staff and Employees of The Rogosin Institute mourn the passing of its founder and leader, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., who served as Director of The Institute from its founding until his death on February 23, 2008. We came to know him as a compassionate physician, accomplished scientist, wise teacher, and friend to us all. His vision and leadership created an Institute of which we are all extremely proud. The combination of the very best in patient care and innovative research programs to make that care even better was central to that vision. He made The Institute an exciting place to work, and we are glad to be part of it. We will miss Dr. Rubin deeply, but count on his example and inspiration to help us continue and expand the work of The Institute so that we can help many thousands more patients in the years to come. We share his dream of ending kidney disease as we now know it. We believe that his dream is one that can be realized, and we plan to work hard to achieve that. We cannot think of a better way to honor his memory. RUBIN--Albert L., M.D., a physician, researcher and executive of Englewood, NJ, died peacefully at home on February 23. He founded and led The Rogosin Institute, affiliated with New York-Presbyterian Hospital, from its inception in 1983 to his death, building The Institute into a world renowned treatment and research organization specializing in kidney disease. Born May 9, 1927, he attended Williams College from 1944 to 1945 and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He received his medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950. In 1957, he and his team performed the first hemodialysis for the treatment of kidney failure in the New York metropolitan area. In 1962, the unit became known as the Renal Laboratory located at the Cornell Division at Bellevue Hospital before moving to The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where it expanded to the Rogosin Renal Laboratories and to The Rogosin Institute in 1983. A true visionary, he pioneered the advancement of the treatment of kidney disease and spearheaded promising research and treatment programs in lipid disorders, diabetes and cancer. He was a talented physician and researcher who not only foresaw the future of medicine and the true purpose of research, but understood that collaboration and cooperation among institutions and organizations was necessary in order to bring developments to patients as quickly as possible. He will be remembered by many as a talented leader and inspirational mentor. He married Carolyn Diehl, M.D., in 1953, who preceded him in death by 20 months. He is survived by son Marc Rubin, M.D., his wife, Jennifer and three grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Rogosin Institute, 505 E. 70th Street, New York, NY 10021. A private service will be held Saturday, March 1. Family and friends are invited to the home of Marc and Jennifer Rubin, 130 Walnut St., Englewood, on March 1 from 3 to 6 pm.

O'CONNOR--Robert J. of Manhattan died at age 72 on February 22, 2008 after a brief illness. He was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1935 to the late William and Kathleen (Cruise) O'Connor. As a child, Mr. O'Connor modeled in print media ads for war bonds, cereals and soap powders and was chosen to sit for famed artist and illustrator Norman Rockwell. In his youth, Mr. O'Connor acted in various stage productions including an appearance on Broadway in the original production of Showboat. He graduated from Immaculata High School in Manhattan and went on to major in Business at Brooklyn College. Thereafter, he began a successful professional career in publishing, retiring in 1991 as Publisher of Hearst Corporation's Motor Boating and Sailing Magazine. Mr. O'Connor was an active member of the New York Athletic Club for the past 28 years, serving on the Social Activities Committees as well as participating in many of the intra-clubs of the NYAC. During the holiday season he could always be counted on to escort local high school choirs around the club to sing Christmas Carols for the members. A strong vocalist, Mr. O'Connor often sang the National Anthem at major club functions and could always be counted on for a moving rendition of ''Danny Boy'' at the annual Irish Night event. In March 2006, he was honored as ''Man of the Year'' on Irish Night. Robert J. O'Connor was also a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the Knights of Columbus and was a communicant of St. Paul the Apostle Church in Manhattan. A life long Mets fan, he was eagerly anticipating a World Series Championship in 2008. He is survived by his loyal and loving wife Margaret Bergin O'Connor and a sister, Mary Jane Gavin. He is also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, grand and great-grand nieces and nephews. In sum, Robert J.O'Connor was known by all as a true ''good egg'' and he will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved him. Viewing will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home located at 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday from 7-9pm; Friday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held at St. Paul the Apostle Church on Saturday at 10:30. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting contributions to the Xavier Society for the Blind, 154 East 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.
