SMITH--Gloria Kaufman, Klein, Smith, retired United Nations official, on February 21st, 2008. She lived at 800 Fifth Avenue, New York City. Born March 8th, 1925, daughter of the late Erna and Emanuel Kaufman of Easthampton, L.I. Mrs. Smith was the widow of the late Sol Klein, President of Paul Art Press, NYC and a former wife of the late Irving Smith of Palm Beach, FL. She graduated from Freeport (L.I.) High School. She attended Miami University, Oxford, OH and graduated from Penn State University. She was a member of the Alpha Epsilon Phi Sorority and of the Phi Sigma Jota and Tau Phi Sigma honorary societies. Mrs. Smith earned an M.A. degree in Public Law and Government at Columbia University. She joined the United Nations in 1947 as a clerk; and at a time when women did not easily achieve success, she reached the rank of First Political Affairs Officer with the Department of Political and Security Council Affairs, retiring in 1985. During her career she served as President of the United Nations Theater, Secretary of the Society of Writers, and Member of the U.N. Panel of Counsel. In retirement, Mrs. Smith earned a diploma in Paralegal Studies at NYU and worked as a Legal Assistant at the New York firm of Newman, Aronson and Neumann. A former resident of Greenwich, CT, she was a member of the Soroptimist Club of Greenwich and Secretary of the Stamford, CT chapter of the American Jewish Congress. At the time of her death, she was a member of the Jewish Genealogical Society, the United Nations Society of Writers and the Representative to the United Nations of the University of Mississippi Center for the Study of Southern Culture. She was a member of the Board of Trustees and a ''Guardian'' of the Sutton Place Synagogue.

HANNIGAN--Judson, 83, of Kittery Point, ME, died peacefully at home Friday, February 22, 2008. Born in Boston, MA, on November 17, 1924, he was the son of the late Judson and Erdine Hannigan. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Grace Chandler Hannigan, and their six children, Kathryn Hannigan Frye and her husband, William, of Clarks Summit, PA; Michael Hannigan and his wife, Betty Jo, of Rye, NY; Timothy Hannigan and his wife, Mary, of Oakton, VA; Patrick Hannigan and his wife, Albina, of Tuxedo, NY; Francis Hannigan and his wife, Debra, of Sudbury, MA; Daniel Hannigan and his wife, Bonnie, of Kittery Point; his half sister, Noreen Hannigan, of Arlington, VA; 23 grandchildren; one great-grandchild; and several nieces and nephews. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Nita Hannigan Crawford. Jud graduated from Traip Academy in Kittery, attended Phillips Exeter Academy for one year and entered Dartmouth College in 1942. He enlisted in the Marine Corps during World War II and earned a field commission during the battle at Iwo Jima. He returned to Dartmouth after the war, captained the football team in 1947 and graduated in 1948. Jud spent his entire 42-year business career in the paper industry, starting in the International Paper Company mill in Corinth, NY, and holding executive positions with International Paper, Continental Group and Champion International. When asked to describe his life for a college reunion publication, Jud said: ''papermaking and family, not necessarily in that order.'' A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on Tuesday, February 26th at Saint Raphael's Roman Catholic Church, Kittery, ME. Memorial remembrances in Jud's honor may be made to: York Hospital (16 Hospital Drive, York, ME. 03909); Beacon Hospice (529 Main St., Suite 101, Boston, MA, 02129); or the Judson Hannigan Family Scholarship Fund, c/o Jack Healy, (5737 Jenness Hall, Orono, ME 04469-5737).

HORNOR--DeWitt, 91, of New York City and Osterville, MA, died in Barbados, February 24. Beloved husband of Edith, devoted father of John and Gurdon, daughter - in - law Heather and grandson Walter. Memorial service in New York at a later date. Contributions may be made to Phillips Academy Andover, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810.

If your eyes glazed over at revelations that Hillary Rodham Clinton used $1,200 from her campaign war chest to splurge on Dunkin' Donuts, that expense turns out to be just the icing on the cake. An hourlong investigation by The New York Times has found, in the 10 months ending in January, that the Clinton campaign reported expenditures of $1,884.83 at Dunkin' Donuts in New Hampshire and Florida (which she won) and in Virginia (which she didn't), and $504.02 at Krispy Kreme stores in South Carolina (which she also lost). So much for dollars to doughnuts. Or just desserts.

Here’s one way to sum up the feeling at this week’s Super Return conference: A leading figure in the private equity business predicted a 40 percent drop in deals in 2008 — and went on to suggest it could be a lot worse.
Can’t get funding from a bank? Forget the bank.
What is a private equity professional to do when all the talk about credit crunches and distressed debt becomes too much? Shake it off with a spin in a virtual race car.

As the founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, David Rubenstein gets asked a lot of questions these days about the fate of the buyout business.

Updated, 7 p.m. | The story of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s rough-and-tumble first year in office is, by now, well documented: his fight with fellow Democrats over the selection of a state comptroller; his staff members’ handling of the seemingly interminable scandal known as Troopergate; and his abandonment of a plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants. Can the governor recover, and if so, how?
What we’re looking at on the Web today…

In a major victory for Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his party, a Democratic assemblyman scored an upset victory in a State Senate election on Tuesday in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century, Trymaine Lee reports.

Educators typically refer to middle school as the “critical years,” the time when students either hunker down and succeed or get distracted and begin to fail. In January, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his State of the City address to propose ending so-called social promotion for eighth-grade students, just as he has done in earlier grades.
Video

Beverage-centered artsy recycling seems to be all the rage these days. We have bottle caps transformed into coffee cups reborn as coasters, beer bottles recycled as Okinawan glassware, purses, aluminum can tabs woven into handbags, and water bottles refashioned as pet jellyfish (note the Volvic and San Pelligrino versions).

It’s official. Hillary Rodham Clinton carried New York City in the Feb. 5 presidential primary with about 56 percent of the vote, compared to Barack Obama’s 43 percent, according to the returns certified on Tuesday by the city’s Board of Elections. But Mrs. Clinton won Brooklyn by a mere 1,225 of the more than 273,000 votes cast. The borough has more enrolled Democrats than nearly any other county in the country, and the New York senator had been endorsed by the Democratic county leader and all of Brooklyn’s members of Congress. Mrs. Clinton carried the 15th Congressional District, represented by one of her earliest supporters, Representative Charles B. Rangel, by 60,573 to 53,165. But within that northern Manhattan district, in the 71st Assembly District, where she was endorsed by Herman D. Farrell Jr., the former Democratic county and state chairman, she narrowly won by only 11,843 to 10,178.

Updated, 3:55 p.m. | William F. Buckley Jr., who died today at 82, ran for mayor of New York City in 1965, in a bizarre but memorable chapter of the city’s political history. Asked what he would do if he won, he famously replied, “Demand a recount.” He injected a rare degree of lofty oratory into city politics — has any other mayoral candidate ever promised “a vision of a new order” and “the beginning of a new dawn”?

All those probable Democratic mayoral candidates who may have been hoping for the Midas-touch endorsement of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg next year should stop holding their breath. At a news conference this morning about the greening of the city’s black car fleet, the billionaire said that he would not be making any endorsements in that 2009 primary.

This time, no may really mean no. On the heels of a WNBC-Marist College poll [pdf] showing that two-thirds of New Yorkers think Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should not run for president, he suggested that an independent campaign is not in his immediate future.

Following is a second set of answers from Leslie Day, the author of “Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City” (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), who is taking questions from readers through Feb. 29. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment box below.

A Harvard economist’s idea — giving free cellphone air time to high-performing students as an incentive to continue doing well — is now in effect. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein today started the “Million” Motivation Campaign, an experimental program involving about 2,500 students in seven middle schools. The students will each receive a free cellphone, called the “Million,” with opportunities to earn minutes and other rewards if they achieve academic goals set by their principals.

This morning, after a humbling defeat in a heated and expensive State Senate race in a heavily Republican district upstate — a seat that Republicans had held for a century — the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, rallied his troops in Albany on Wednesday in an attempt to bolster spirits.
A selection of haunting, late-19th-century photographs by Jacob A. Riis from the collection of the Museum of the City of New York.

Dmitri A. Medvedev is set to become the new president of Russia, having been personally chosen for the job by President Vladimir V. Putin.
Tuesday's duel between Democratic candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama earned MSNBC the highest ratings in its 11-year history.

My Thursday column is from Juba, Sudan, and argues that the Sudanese government in Khartoum is moving to restart the brutal war between north and south Sudan. I'm afraid that the genocide in Darfur is going to be remembered simply as the prologue to an even more bloodier slaughter that stretches across the entire south of the country as well.
After teasing us for months and months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York is letting us down easy in an Op-Ed in Thursday's New York Times.

Last week, The New York Times created a Russian-language Live Journal community to give Russian readers a chance to read and discuss articles written by the Moscow bureau. So far, Russian readers have posted more than 4,000 comments.

Should we save the American Time Use Survey? A coalition of social scientists hope the Bureau of Labor Statistics changes plans to ditch the annual report on budgetary grounds, saying that the trove of data is unlikely to be duplicated elsewhere.

SAN ANTONIO -- Senator John McCain got support on Wednesday from an important corner of evangelical Texas when the pastor of a San Antonio mega-church, Rev. John C. Hagee, endorsed Mr. McCain for president. Mr. Hagee, who argues that the United States must join Israel in a preemptive, biblically prophesized military strike against Iran that will lead to the second coming of Christ, praised Mr. McCain for his pro-Israel views.

Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for "soft news" - coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma'am.Tilda Swinton may have picked up a red carpet win for Damiani by wearing their diamond cuff, but the jeweler's Milan showroom wasn't quite so lucky. Seven men dug a tunnel through a neighboring building and stole $20 million worth of jewels... Next year's male Oscar nominees wanting to sport a little bling should check out the diamond cufflinks that Thom Browne has designed for Harry Winston... If real estate is your expense of choice, why not throw down for Michael Jackson's Neverland ranch when it hits the auction block on March 19th... They may not have a theme park, but Curbed's got a list of the top 10 private pools in the city that may make you spring for a new condo... Having trouble waking up in your new pad? Check out this aromatherapy alarm clock that will wake you to favorite scent...Amy Winehouse may not be the freshest fashion icon in music, but her style is unmistakable. Now you can buy a piece of the action when she launches her new clothing and make-up line... A sad day for fans of felonious fashion. Mayor Bloomberg and the NYPD raided and seized $1 million in goods from Canal St. counterfeiters... In Shanghai, the trend is not towards knock-offs, but "the rebirth of individualism"... You'll be hardly alone wearing Marc Jacobs re-launched Hillary tee, but as least it one-up's Senator Clinton's boxy pantsuits... Soft Serve is sick of today's politics. Check us out tomorrow for more of the spin.

Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The Times Book Review and Week in Review, is writing a biography of William F. Buckley Jr., who died Wednesday. Mr. Buckley was for decades the intellectual standard bearer for American conservatism, and he was also one of the 20th century's truest men of letters: a magazine editor, newspaper columnist, novelist and essayist - the author of 55 books.
(Jessica Antola)

Whitey Bulger has found himself at the center of another "mandatory kill," though this one was ordered by a photo agency seeking to delete an image from their archives. The alert was prompted by the F.B.I.'s admission that they misidentified a German couple vacationing in Sicily as the reputed Boston crime boss and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig.

Electronic Arts's unsolicited takeover offer for Take-Two Interactive is unfolding fast: Take-Two, which makes the popular Grand Theft Auto video-game series, has responded to Sunday's public bid by Electronic Arts with the flurry of activity that usually follows these kinds of things: golden parachutes, rapid strategic maneuvers of questionable shareholder value and general hostility.
Some tributes and other ephemera surfacing across the Web as news spreads of the death of William F. Buckley. The New York Times's obituary, written by Douglas Martin, is here.

Barack Obama, once vocally opposed to outside groups' involvement in campaigning, quietly has been letting pro-Obama ads from the Service Employees International Union run in Ohio without much comment.

Dubbed The Opium Experience (very soixante-huitard!), the persimmon lacquer and pale stone space also features a hint of green: namely CO2-emission-busting ductal concrete that will also reduce water waste.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Tonight in Cleveland, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are debating one another for the 20th time. Experts are calling it "redundant," "unnecessary," and "the most exciting thing that ever happened inCleveland."

There are a couple of very real challenges when you roast a chicken: You need high heat to brown the skin, but superhigh heat may burn it. You need to cook the thighs and legs through before the breast dries out. You want to do the whole chicken as quickly as possible. And if you are interested in minimalist cooking, you must accomplish all this without a lot of fuss.

Several of our Open Caucus voters -- including one from Ohio -- tuned into Tuesday's debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, held in Cleveland. A few also watched last week's debate between the two Democrats in Texas, as well.

Congress can't get enough of sports and performance-enhancing drugs, so the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection will hold a hearing Wednesday in which the commissioners and union chiefs of Major League Baseball, the N.F.L., N.B.A. and N.H.L. are testifying.
Musicians from the New York Philharmonic receive a tour of the North Korean capital, including a visit to the Grand People's Study Hall, before performing at the East Grand Theatre.

As if there were some other way to determine which is the best soccer team, other than playing the game, a German consulting firm reports that, win-or-lose, Spanish clubs are more popular in Europe than English teams.

The Yankees will hold an intrasquad game in about two hours, but the only thing darting around the field now is a cat. Can't say for sure if it's black or brown, so I don't know what kind of omen that is. But I bet the Yankees lose today. (And win. Ha, ha.)

After last night's debate, the folks at The Corner, National Review's staff blog, have come down with a case of Obama Fever - meaning, the prospect of Barack Obama as the Democratic presidential nominee is making them feel a little sick to the stomach.

Statistics released on Tuesday showed that more than 233,000 properties in the United States were foreclosed in January alone, so the addition of just one more person this year would hardly be cause for news coverage. Except, of course, that the person is Michael Jackson, and the property is his Neverland ranch.

James Kanter and I have a story in today's paper about a new tack by the Bush administration aimed at clarifying, for Europe particularly, that the United States is not opposed to any new climate treaty -- just all of the formulations that have bubbled up since 1992, when the first global pact was accepted by nearly all countries (it was signed by the first President Bush).

I never thought I'd see the day when The Times could offer a first-rate course in playwriting gratis online, but that's what Marsha Norman has provided in her last post. So if any of you haven't read it, take a step back and enjoy.

This is a chart that lots of well-paid corporate executives probably do not want you to see. Based on consumer complaints to the Federal Trade Commission, it purports to rank the overall vulnerability of the world's largest financial institutions, phone companies and retailers -- and their customers -- to identity theft.

Wall Street ideas are creeping into the world of online advertising. One of the most controversial topics at the Interactive Advertising Bureau's conference in Phoenix has been the rise of advertising exchanges, that are mean to trade impressions on Web sites the way Nasdaq trades stock.

The Bagger is outside LAX at Terminal 6, a phrase that pretty much brackets his last six days. Normally, before he hits the red-eye to Newark, he hits the smoking cage to be among his fellow cellmates, they of the off-brand ciggies chain smoked through tattooed fingers. But the smoking cage is closed, with stickers all over it. This was one of the last airports in the country that accommodated smoking - in a town where correctness and prevailing vibe of well-being-whether-you-like-it-or-not persists. It was too good to last.

Have the Oscars and the industry it celebrates become a microcosm of the American economy? Think about it. High costs to market something the consumer doesn't seem to want; a reliance on imports, as well as on selling a traditional product at a time when consumers have all manner of new options. Then there's the stubborn unwillingness to meet those consumers on the platform and device of their choosing.

Just days after Take-Two Interactive, the troubled video game maker, received a buyout offer from a rival, Electronic Arts, the board of Take-Two approved a measure that significantly increased the compensation that management would receive in a merger or takeover, according to regulatory filings.

The Bagger saw Gary Busey on the carpet last Sunday, but did not ask him a question, in part because he could not think of one besides, "What makes your teeth seem so threatening?" Is it their size? Their shape? The Crazy Guggenheim stare that floats over them?

A hedge fund, Elliott Management, accused Cedar Hill Capital Partners in a lawsuit on Tuesday of corporate espionage by misappropriating Elliott Management's proprietary trading software.

Citadel Capital, an Egyptian buyout shop with $7 billion under management, is in talks with four international banks to help it sell shares to the public to raise funds for new energy, food and manufacturing ventures.

Canada's takeover-friendly securities laws have helped make the country the easiest in the world for foreign acquirers, according to a new study that shows Canadians are the world's biggest net sellers of corporate assets in terms of the nation's market size.
The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

Reddy Ice, the packaged ice maker whose $1.1 billion buyout collapsed in January, may be in for further turmoil as a group of investors, including the Shamrock Activist Value Fund, has increased its stake in the company to 15.6 percent.
Switzerland's troubled flagship bank, UBS, was expected to face a disturbed bunch of shareholders at its annual meeting on Wednesday.
Cherry, Domino, Edge, Hornswoggle, Jimmy Wang Yang and their friends will soon have a new home.
Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines have been held up for a couple of weeks while pilots at each carrier discuss how to combine their union seniority lists.
Four years ago, NBC made Jay Leno the lame-duck host of 'The Tonight Show,' announcing with fanfare that he would be succeeded by Conan O'Brien in 2009, Bill Carter reports in today's New York Times.
The legal battle over the $700 million merger of the shoe retailers Genesco and Finish Line is coming to a head.
Alan Feuer reports:
Petroplus Holdings has signed a $2 billion deal with private equity firms the Blackstone Group and First Reserve to acquire crude oil refineries in the United States.

The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, a hedge fund, has tentatively begun buying troubled home loans and will likely expand more aggressively in residential mortgage markets this year, its chief executive, Daniel Och, said on Tuesday.
Sun Microsystems on Tuesday announced that it had completed its $1 billion acquisition of MySQL, the open-source database company, and is now on the prowl for similar prey.

Novell's $205 million acquisition of PlateSpin, a Canadian provider of virtualization services, represent its biggest bet yet on the server-virtualization business and its largest transaction since 2003.
The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation bought the Westin Tokyo hotel from Morgan Stanley and the Starwood Capital Group as Morgan Stanley shuffles its Japan portfolio.
Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday that it had appointed J. Michael Evans and Michael S. Sherwood as vice chairmen of the firm effective immediately.

The Chinese aluminum giant Chinalco, which led a $14-billion investment in the global miner Rio Tinto, has not increased its Rio Tinto holding, despite an agreement that allows them to buy more, according to Reuters.
Sirius Satellite Radio reported a narrower loss on Tuesday as it awaits regulatory action on its plans to combine with a rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

China Railway Construction announced a larger-than-expected $5.4 billion initial public offering that would be the world's biggest so far this year, despite a cut in the number of shares to be listed in Shanghai amid market weakness.
Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

Rich Oppel examines the decision by the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr to extend his militia's cease-fire for six more months. Listen at left or download the MP3 to a portable player. Browse a list of other Times podcasts here.
FusionOne, which creates applications and services for mobile devices, has raised $6 million in a Series A-1 preferred stock round for its mobile content backup services.
Lucky Pai, a Shanghai-based home-shopping network that hawks jewelry and electronics to millions of Chinese households, is showcasing-itself.

ABN Amro, the Dutch bank bought by three European rivals last year, said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing "strategic reasons."
I.B.M. said on Tuesday that its board had authorized a $15 billion share buyback program that could increase 2008 earnings by up to 5 cents a share, sending its stock up 4.2 percent.
Gazprom, the world's largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets American accounting rules, will have two fewer members and the power of its chairman will be increased, the board's oversight body said on Tuesday.
Recent penthouse sales at the massive MGM CityCenter, which is now half-owned by Dubai World, set new records for price-per-square-foot in Las Vegas, according to the agent who made the sales.

"Hurry up, Mom, we don't want to be late," I called my mother after I heard the sound of an I.E.D., an improvised explosive device, blowing up. They would seal off the area and we would be trapped, that was my concern. My mother was running here and there in the house trying to pack as much stuff as she could. It was our last day. We had decided earlier that we couldn't stay in our house anymore; the area was getting more and more dangerous and deserted.

Below are their thumbnail analyses for each deal, but there were so many trades that we have to split them into three separate posts. Here's the first:
In their quest to bring us the biggest and best of everything, the Emirati billionaires are leaving no game unplayed.

“I was eight and a half when I moved to South Central Los Angeles, the city’s large inner core divided among 775 different gangs — Blood, Crip, Sur, 18th St., or MS — which ran the different neighborhoods like training grounds, enforcing the laws of the street more strictly and consistently than the police enforced the official ones.”
Update | May 21, 2009
“Chop Shop” is concerned principally with the kind of hard, marginal labor that more comfortable city dwellers rarely notice.
Oysters and red wine might seem a bizarre pairing, but 20 years ago white wine with cheese sounded strange.
Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy.
The Humane Society sued the federal government over what it said is a legal loophole that allows sick or crippled cattle, called “downers,” into the food supply.
Regulators issued the fine for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that Microsoft had abused its dominance.
A ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked about potential financial conflicts among doctors involved in the clinical research that led to F.D.A. approval of the Prodisc.
Stocks ended little changed when doubts emerged that the lifting of investment caps on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac was enough to prevent deeper damage to the housing market.
Senator John McCain attacked Senator Barack Obama for what he called a naïve approach to the conflict in Iraq and the effort to combat international terrorism.
President Bush and the leader of the Czech Republic said that they are close to agreement on a plan for the United States to install an early warning radar system in the Czech Republic.
Bowing to critics, Aetna said it has suspended a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.
In a move that could help the housing market, a federal regulator said that it was removing limits on the investment portfolios of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two large buyers of mortgages.
The telecommunications company reported a $957 million loss for 2007. The company also said it would cut 2,100 jobs and move 1,000 others, mostly to China and Turkey.
Sharply lower prices failed to perk up sales of new homes in January, a government report showed, as a closely watched index fell to its lowest point in 13 years.
Mr. Buckley marshaled a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse.
The federal regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will lift an investment cap, in a move that will free up billions of dollars for the companies to invest in the U.S. housing market.
The dollar breached the level of $1.50 to the euro on Wednesday for the first time as fears of weakness in the U.S. economy mixed with evidence of resilience in Europe.
A Greyhound bus accident cut off road access to the Port Authority Bus Terminal for about an hour on Wednesday morning
The fate of the Fed’s strategy could depend on foreign confidence in the dollar and willingness to keep financing the United States’ huge external debt.
Consumers’ pocketbooks are being hit hard as the oil shock coincides with turmoil in the credit and housing markets.
James H. Simons, a math professor-turned-hedge fund manager, is giving Stony Brook University the largest gift ever to any public university in the state.
A Democratic assemblyman won a stunning upset in a State Senate election in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century.

A 43-day stretch without a homicide in Newark — the city’s longest such period in decades — came to an end Tuesday night in front of a bodega in the violence-prone South Ward, where the police said a young man was fatally shot in the head.

Venus Williams, the top seed and defending champion, was upset in the opening round of the WTA’s Cellular South Cup in Memphis by Petra Kvitova, a 17-year-old qualifier. Kvitova won the fifth WTA Tour match of her career, stunning Williams, the winner of four Wimbledon titles, 2-6, 6-4, 6-3.
As close as the Nets kept it until the closing minutes, it was not enough for the Nets to break through and avoid their second defeat in four games since Jason Kidd was traded.
The Wild traded a sixth-round draft pick for Chris Simon, the troubled left wing. He left the arena before the Islanders lost to Pittsburgh despite outshooting the Penguins, 52-20.
Jeff Adrien, a junior forward, had a career-high 27 points and pulled down 11 rebounds as No. 15 Connecticut defeated Rutgers, 79-61.
Sergei Samsonov tapped in his own rebound 1 minute 36 seconds into overtime Tuesday night to lift the Carolina Hurricanes to a 2-1 victory.

Wide receiver Justin McCareins and cornerback Andre Dyson were released, and the starting left guard Adrien Clarke was waived by the Jets on Tuesday. The three veterans were cut three days before the start of the N.F.L.’s free-agent period as the Jets tried to create salary-cap room.

Hunters killed about 220,000 deer in New York last year, up 16 percent from the 2006 season. The state Department of Environmental Conservation said the number of hunting accidents declined to 14, with five people fatally shot.

Connecticut Coach Randy Edsall’s new contract includes a buyout clause that would have him pay back up to $1.5 million if he takes a job with another university or an N.F.L. team. The university released details of the five-year deal that Edsall signed Feb. 14 after a season in which the Huskies won a share of the Big East title.

Arizona State has begun an investigation into accusations of academic fraud and recruiting violations in its baseball program. The former player and team manager Mikel Moreno told The East Valley Tribune that he made the allegations to university officials, who began the investigation. Virgil Renzulli, the university’s vice president for public affairs, confirmed that an investigation had started.

The New England Patriots released linebacker Rosevelt Colvin, who was a member of two Super Bowl-winning teams but also missed significant time with injuries. Colvin played in the first 11 games last season before missing the rest of the season with a foot injury.

The Kenyan distance runner Susan Chepkemei was suspended for one year by the I.A.A.F. after testing positive for salbutamol, an asthma medication.Her agent, Valentijn Trouw, said Tuesday that Chepkemei was given salbutamol in September by a doctor after she became pregnant and developed pneumonia. Trouw said Chepkemei got a shorter suspension instead of the usual two-year ban for a first-time offender because of her illness.

Kevin Faulk, the New England Patriots running back, has been issued a misdemeanor summons in Lafayette, La., for possession of marijuana. Captain John Babin of the Lafayette Metro Narcotics Task Force said that Faulk was on his way to watch a performance by the rapper Lil’ Wayne when a search by a sheriff’s deputy turned up four marijuana cigarettes.

Receiver Brandon Lloyd has been released by the Washington Redskins, ending a disappointing tenure. Lloyd caught 25 passes with no touchdowns in two seasons with the Redskins, who traded two draft picks to the San Francisco 49ers to acquire him before the 2006 season.
Shan Foster scored 32 points and No. 18 Vanderbilt knocked off No. 1 Tennessee, 72-69, on Tuesday night — a day after the Volunteers were voted No. 1 for the first time in team history.

The High Court upheld the plea bargain last year by which possible rape charges against former President Moshe Katsav, left, were dropped in exchange for his stepping down and pleading guilty to lesser charges. There has been fierce public criticism of the deal, and the court’s five-judge panel split 3 to 2 in its opinion. Chief Justice Dorit Beinisch was in the minority. The judges unanimously agreed that there was not sufficient evidence to charge Mr. Katsav with rape. Although Mr. Katsav has protested his innocence, he is to plead guilty to committing indecent acts without consent, sexual harassment of two women and harassing a witness. He faces a suspended sentence and payment of compensation, but no prison time.
An article on Feb. 18 about the cancellation of some campaign events in Wisconsin because of a snowstorm misspelled the name of a town there. It is Menomonee Falls, not Menominee Falls.

The army said no legal action would be taken against military officials over an artillery strike in Beit Hanun in 2006 in which an errant shell hit residential buildings and killed 21 Palestinian civilians. An army investigation concluded that the shell was fired based on information that militants were intending to fire rockets from the area, an army statement said. The civilian deaths, it said, were “directly due to a rare and severe failure” in the artillery control system. The army’s military advocate general concluded that there was no need for further investigation.

Ariel Sharon turned 80 at a medical center outside Tel Aviv, more than two years after he was rendered comatose after a stroke while prime minister. Dov Weisglass, formerly his top adviser, said there had been little change in his condition over the past year.

An article on Saturday about the death of an eighth-grade boy in Oxnard, Calif., whose killing is being called a hate crime by prosecutors, misidentified the group that is pushing for a legislative review of anti-bias policies in California schools. It is the Gay-Straight Alliance Network, not the Gay-Straight Alliance. (The network coordinates clubs in California schools that operate under the name Gay-Straight Alliance.).

An article in Business Day on Friday about Toyota’s global expansion misidentified the location of its European headquarters. It is outside Brussels, not outside Belgium. An accompanying article about Akio Toyoda, the grandson of the company’s founder and its probable next president, also misstated the location of Babson College, where he earned his M.B.A. It is in Wellesley, Mass., a suburb of Boston — not in Boston itself.

The European Court of Justice ruled that only the sharp hard cheese that has been made for some 800 years near the Italian city of Parma can legally be called Parmesan. In a case dating to 2003, the court condemned Germany for allowing sales of imitation Parmesan in violation of European Union food origin rules. The German producers will now have to change the name of their cheese. The German dairy industry estimates German farmers produce some 10,000 tons of “Parmesan” a year.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about a court ruling allowing Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, to review documents on certain questionable transactions that led to his ouster, misidentified the founder of A.I.G. It was Cornelius Vander Starr, not Mr. Greenberg.

A headline and an article in Business Day on Friday about a recall of 143 million pounds of beef, some of which was used in federal nutrition programs, misstated the reason for the recall. The federal Food Safety and Inspection Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, labeled the beef unfit for human food because of violations of food safety regulations. It did not deem it “tainted” or “contaminated.” (An article on Tuesday about some of the beef that was sent to New Jersey schools repeated the error.).

An article on Saturday about the death of an eighth-grade boy in Oxnard, Calif., whose killing is being called a hate crime by prosecutors, misidentified the group that is pushing for a legislative review of anti-bias policies in California schools. It is the Gay-Straight Alliance Network, not the Gay-Straight Alliance. (The network coordinates clubs in California schools that operate under the name Gay-Straight Alliance.).

The Books of The Times review on Feb. 15 of “The Middle-Class Millionaire,” about a new demographic group that can afford expensive new personal services, overstated the cost of concierge-type medicine. Patients pay a retainer of as much as $20,000 a year, not a month.
A military officer linked to crimes during Argentina’s dictatorship was found dead, the second in three months.

The economic fallout from South Africa’s electricity crisis continued to reverberate as Gold Fields, the second largest gold producer, announced that it might cut up to 6,900 jobs, 13 percent of its work force, because of a 10 percent power reduction by the state utility, Eskom. It said its production would decline by 20 to 25 percent this quarter because of the power cuts. The National Union of Mineworkers, which represents 320,000 workers, said its members would “take to the streets” if there were major job cuts.
The polygamist sect leader Warren Jeffs was handed over to the authorities to face sex charges stemming from the arranged marriages of two teenage girls to older relatives.
Lech Walesa, the former president of Poland, was tested for heart failure and evaluated as a potential heart transplant recipient, said the Methodist DeBakey Heart and Vascular Center in Houston.
Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles signed one of the nation’s toughest laws on pet sterilization, requiring most dogs and cats to be spayed or neutered by the time they are 4 months old.
Depressed teenagers who are not helped by antidepressants like Celexa or Prozac may improve if they switch drugs and receive a certain type of behavioral therapy, a review of studies found.
Three ministers accused a Greensboro police officer of ordering officers to destroy about 50 boxes of police files related to the fatal shooting of five people at an anti-Ku Klux Klan rally in 1979.
Pedro Martínez will not ask the Mets for an extension. But if the team wants to begin a dialogue with Martínez, he will embrace the discussion.
Nearly two years before Jay Leno can officially be courted, suitors are beginning to circle.
Two men posing as building inspectors carried out an extortion scheme that gave a sinister new twist to the idea of civic virtue.
The Fire Department on Tuesday defended an experiment with new dispatching rules in Queens, saying that it had sharply lowered response times.
Consumers’ pocketbooks are being hit hard as the oil shock coincides with turmoil in the credit and housing markets.
Investors were spooked by a report by the research firm comScore that said clicks on Google ads in the United States were flat in January.
Starbucks temporarily closed stores as it retrained workers and tried to revive “the romance of coffee.”
Winning over Youngstown’s lunch-bucket voters could make the difference for the Democrats in Ohio.
On Tuesday North Korean officials invited the superstar rock guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.
The Bill Clinton of January has been muzzled, as the ex-president makes a more subdued pitch for his wife.
On a frenetic day that included 25 trades, the Pittsburgh Penguins snatched the biggest prize, Atlanta forward Marian Hossa, adding one of the game’s best snipers to an already potent lineup.
Mets pitcher Aaron Heilman is a proud graduate of Notre Dame, which made Tuesday’s exhibition against one of his alma mater’s hated rivals, Michigan, a matter of great personal interest.
Over the past five weeks, undercover police officers and New York City agents fanned out and pretended to be real shoppers in an area the mayor called the “Counterfeit Triangle.”
Take-Two said the board’s decision to revise its management compensation, which came days after the bid, was not tied to the Electronic Arts offer.
A jail guard who ordered teenage inmates to assault others in an effort to maintain order and enforce discipline was arrested on Tuesday, prosecutors said.
The supervisor is said to have not adequately followed up a complaint against a Long Island woman who is now accused of drowning her three young children.
ABN Amro said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing “strategic reasons.”
Following the lead of Germany and Britain, other countries say they will investigate whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.
A Texas congressman criticized the Humane Society for waiting to inform the federal government of its video showing cattle being mistreated.
Elk calling is judged like figure skating, has regional competitions like basketball, but it is not for the faint of ear.
The United Automobile Workers called its third strike in five months Tuesday, sending some 3,650 workers at parts factories in Michigan and New York off the job.
President Bush sided with banks and mortgage lenders on Tuesday, threatening to veto a bill being offered by Senate Democrats.
The Rays left-hander Scott Kazmir missed a scheduled appearance in an intrasquad game after feeling discomfort in his elbow on his final warm-up pitch.
Fred Couples and Greg Norman, two of golf’s most popular figures and dominant players in the 1980s and ’90s, have been named captains for the 2009 Presidents Cup.
One of the five bidders for the development rights over the West Side railyards failed to submit a revised offer on Tuesday for the tract, the largest development site in Manhattan.
General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled auto and mortgage lender GMAC.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets American accounting rules, will have two fewer members and the power of its chairman will be increased, the board’s oversight body said on Tuesday.
Pacifico takes its advertising to the Internet, spending about $15 million this year on its online initiative.
The conservative radio host Bill Cunningham used Barack Obama’s middle name, Hussein, three times while introducing John McCain.
Mr. Shomron was in command of the Israeli paratroopers in the 1976 hostage rescue at Entebbe International Airport in Uganda.
A doctor faces three felony counts in a case that has sent a shudder through the field of transplant surgeons.
At the trial of a man charged in the killing of Nixzmary Brown, a medical expert called by the defense disputed the prosecution’s theory that long-term abuse helped cause the girl’s death.
Democratic Party officials are questioning whether John McCain benefited unfairly from rules that automatically placed him on the ballot in Ohio once he qualified for public campaign financing.
Jeff Orleans announced this week that he would step down as executive director of the Ivy League, leaving behind two decades’ worth of radical changes to a league synonymous with tradition.
The judge in the corruption trial of former Mayor Sharpe James of Newark expressed concern that many potential jurors questioned their ability to be impartial in the case.
Losses are mounting so rapidly at some banks that a small number of them, perhaps 50 out of the 7,500 nationwide, could fail over the next 12 to 18 months.
Households and businesses in southern Florida were affected in the outage that knocked out traffic signals and trapped scores of people in elevators.
News of the planned repurchase, equivalent to about 10 percent of the market capitalization of I.B.M., sent its stock up 4.2 percent.
A federal judge in New York ruled that a lawsuit contending that NBC’s “To Catch a Predator” played a role in a Texas prosecutor’s suicide could move forward.
Seventeen months ago, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra was overthrown in a military coup in Thailand.
Two Alabama football players were arrested in a span of six days, one player has been dismissed and linebacker Prince Hall has been suspended indefinitely.
Fourth-quarter profit fell more than 27 percent at the home improvement chain, as a slowing housing market led to the company’s first annual sales decline.
Congressional Democrats are trying to mount new lines of attack against the Bush administration’s policy in Iraq.
Raúl Castro seems inclined to govern more pragmatically than his more doctrinaire and romantic brother. Yet many Cubans say they see few signs of real change.
Members of two writers’ unions ratified a three-year contract with Hollywood’s movie and television production companies.
The city has agreed to pay more than $20 million to settle a class-action lawsuit charging that the Department of Parks and Recreation discriminated against black and Hispanic employees.
The contract, worth $28 million to $52 million, was directed to John Ashcroft’s firm by the United States attorney in New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, without any bidding process.
It would be deeply troubling if a partisan broadcaster could suppress information on the public airwaves and hide behind a technical fig leaf.
DreamWorks Animation SKG said its revenues rose 42 percent from a year earlier led by the blockbuster performance of “Shrek the Third.”
With a wiretapping law allowed to lapse in Congress, phone companies are no longer certain what they are supposed to do when the government comes to them with a wiretapping order.
One of the plot leaders, a 50-year-old Tanzanian-born preacher in a London mosque, called himself Osama bin London when first confronted by the police in 2004.
The food company said that its third-quarter profit edged slightly lower due to a steeper tax rate and rising commodity costs.
Saying New Jersey had reached a “turning point,” Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed a budget cut by $500 million.
Britain’s information commissioner has ordered the government to release the minutes of two cabinet meetings held in 2003 to discuss the legality of the allied invasion of Iraq.
Sirius Satellite Radio reported a narrower loss on Tuesday as it awaits regulatory action on its plans to combine with rival XM Satellite Radio Holdings.
St. Anthony High School of Jersey City has the No. 1-ranked boys basketball team in the country and six of its nine seniors have already signed to play for Division I teams.
Mexican lawmakers stripped a provision from their plan to overhaul the country’s judiciary that would have given police officers the ability to enter homes without obtaining warrants beforehand.
The world’s second-largest oil-exporting nation after Saudi Arabia, has been quietly preparing to switch trading in Russian Ural Blend oil to the ruble from the dollar.
Senator Barbara Boxer of California suggested a link to the denial of her state’s request to set rules for auto emissions.
Authorities hope to try the suspects as adults due to the horrific nature of the crimes.
The confluence of falling home prices and accelerating inflation is putting policy makers in an increasingly tough position.
The next American president will have to deal with a Russia that is not only nuclear-armed but increasingly wealthy and increasingly authoritarian.
Pakistan has arrested a suspected Qaeda militant in connection with the bomb attack last October against the slain opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.
The department store company Macy’s said that lower costs sent fourth-quarter profit up more than analysts had expected, while Target reported that its sales declined.
Regional government agencies around the Great Lakes say they need help to protect the lakes from invasive species, contaminated sediment and sewage overflows.
There has long been talk of a renaissance in Downcity, which covers a 36-block area, about a quarter mile long and a third of a mile wide, and progress has been made.
The CBS Corporation came through a writers’ strike relatively unscathed but issued a mild outlook on Tuesday for profit growth in 2008.
France may send hundreds of ground troops to eastern Afghanistan, where NATO-led forces are fighting insurgents backed by Al Qaeda.
Fewer than half of American teenagers asked knew when the Civil War was fought, and one in four didn’t know when Columbus sailed to the new world.
If a proposed bankruptcy provision becomes law, as it should, lenders will have a powerful incentive to modify troubled loans voluntarily.
The University of Kentucky has been wrestling with a false e-mail rumor that says the college dropped a course on the Holocaust because of pressure from Muslims.
Pfizer’s recent decision to drop Dr. Robert Jarvik was a telling reminder that consumers need to take what they see and hear with a large grain of skepticism.
Officials kept watch Tuesday on a wildfire threatening this town of 1,500 people, but evacuated residents were allowed to return.
If Jason Giambi, whose days as an offensive force are not far off, could play first base, then the Yankees could use all of their best hitters in the same lineup.
Genoa Leilani Keawe, widely known as Aunty Genoa, was one of the most enduring and beloved voices in Hawaiian music.
General Manager Daryl Morey made the announcement Tuesday, hours before the Rockets defeated the visiting Washington Wizards for their 13th straight victory.
Had 9/11 not happened, 2/26 would have been the worst day of terrorism in New York’s modern history.
Widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson raise the risk of death among cancer patients by about 10 percent, a newly published analysis says.
The Supreme Court ruled that evidence of a biased corporate culture may be admissible in court — some of the time.
A roadside bomb hit a vehicle carrying five policemen and a 3-year-old child in eastern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing them all, officials said.
William Bell did not want to go to the party. It felt awkward, going to his son’s bachelor bash at a strip club. It just was not his kind of place. “Be with your friends,” he told his son, Sean.
There has been a chain reaction in the fashion world, a move toward safe dressing, and it has finally reached Dior, a house that under the showmanship of John Galliano usually sparks change.
What if you had a majestic skylighted, columned hall in a Beaux-Arts ferry building at the tip of Manhattan and were required to use it as a public space?
Multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in parts of the former Soviet Union have reached the highest rates ever recorded.
Pitcher R. A. Dickey, who does not have an ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow, has defied skeptics to become one of the most intriguing players in any spring training camp.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,963 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
Recognizing Kosovo means saying, in effect, that Serbian democracy must be punished because a tyrant, Slobodan Milosevic, was left unpunished.
Sadly, America’s flood-protection system has long been undermined by bureaucratic turf wars, chronic underfinancing and a lack of political leadership.
When, early on in the race for the Democratic nomination, people wondered if black Americans would vote for Barack Obama, I never doubted.
Each fashion show is like an unusually complex piece of 15-minute theater, and typically there are eight every day.

An independent Los Angeles bookstore with a national following and local client base of writers and movie stars will close on April 30 after 23 years as a neighborhood meeting spot for dog walkers and a refuge for readers. Dutton’s Brentwood Books, in the Brentwood neighborhood, is known for its thorough stock of classic, new and esoteric literature and a staff of bibliophiles far more familiar with their wares than most employees at corporate chains. More than $500,000 of debt and competition from chain stores and online vendors led Doug Dutton, the owner, to announce his plans to close in a statement on the store’s Web site (duttonsbrentwood.com) on Tuesday. The property owners, Nancy and Charles T. Munger, said in a statement to The Los Angeles Times that they would allow Dutton’s to remain open rent-free through its liquidation.

It will be father-daughter night in Nashville on April 14 when Billy Ray Cyrus and Miley Cyrus, above, will be the hosts and perform at the seventh annual CMT Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Other performers on the country music awards show, to be broadcast live on CMT, include Alan Jackson, Brad Paisley, Carrie Underwood, Sugarland, Taylor Swift and Toby Keith.

Renovation of the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam is unlikely to be finished until late 2012 or 2013, Reuters reported. The Dutch culture ministry said that the renovations were to have been completed this year, but a dispute with the building contractor over costs led to new delays at the museum, a major tourist attraction and home to some of the greatest works of the Dutch masters. In a face-lift reminiscent of the modernization of the Louvre in Paris, the Rijksmuseum, designed by Pierre Cuypers (1827-1921) and opened in 1885, is to have a huge new underground entrance hall. Since the main building closed, in 2003, paintings by Rembrandt, Frans Hals and Vermeer have remained on view in a wing.

Anne Frank called Peter Schiff her “one true love.” Now his photograph, below, is to be displayed in the Anne Frank House museum in Amsterdam, which is dedicated to her memory, Agence France-Presse reported. The photograph was given to the museum by Peter’s childhood friend Ernest Michaelis, now 81, who visited the museum last month with his children and grandchildren. The Observer Magazine reported in London on Sunday that Mr. Michaelis came to realize that the childhood friend in a photograph given him as he left Germany for Britain was the 13-year-old boy that the 11-year-old Anne Frank later wrote about in her diary. “I’m such an idiot,” she wrote on Jan. 7, 1944. “I forgot that I haven’t yet told you the story of my one true love. I can still see us walking hand in hand through our neighborhood.” Anne Frank died in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp the next year. Peter Schiff, whose family, like Frank’s, fled Germany for the Netherlands, died in Auschwitz or Bergen-Belsen.

Reed Business Information said it had “suspended support” of the Quill Awards program, Publishers Weekly reported. Winners of the 19 awards for books, established in 2005 in an attempt to infuse the publishing industry with some pizazz, were selected by the public in online voting. A spokeswoman for Reed Business Information, a founder of the awards and a parent of Publishers Weekly and Variety, declined to give further details, the Canadian Press news agency reported. The company went up for sale last week. The Reed announcement said that as part of the “dissolution” of Quills, the remaining money of the Quills Literacy Foundation, a philanthropy associated with the awards, would be distributed to First Book and to Literacy Partners, nonprofit organizations. NBC televised the annual black-tie awards ceremony.

After 15 years of helping to build Sony’s globe-spanning video game empire, Phil Harrison, below, is leaving the company. Now president of Sony’s worldwide game development studios, Mr. Harrison announced on Monday that he would resign Friday. Mr. Harrison joined Sony in 1992 and has become perhaps the most public face of the company’s game business. After dominating the last generation of gaming with its PlayStation 2, the company has failed to maintain its leadership more recently with the PlayStation 3 amid new challenges from its rivals Microsoft and Nintendo. The company said that Kazuo Hirai, Mr. Harrison’s boss as chief executive of Sony’s overall game unit, would assume Mr. Harrison’s duties. Mr. Harrison raised eyebrows in the game industry last week when he criticized Sony’s failure to recognize the growth of casual, social gaming. Nintendo has embraced that trend while Sony has largely focused on complicated, sometimes violent fare directed at young men.
“Is He Dead?” is closing at the Lyceum on March 9 to make way for an eight-week run of “Macbeth,” starring Patrick Stewart.

Averaging 12.7 million viewers, ABC’s Monday broadcast of “A Raisin in the Sun,” with Sean Combs and Phylicia Rashad, lifted the network to No. 1 in that night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A made-for-television movie, it won every hour of prime time except the 8 p.m. slot, when it trailed NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” (15.3 million). After a six-week streak of leading on Monday nights among adults 18 to 49, NBC finished in second place over all as its new game show, “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad,” at 9 (7.8 million), suffered a decline of 2 million viewers from its debut a week ago. CBS and Fox were third and fourth for the night, with CBS drawing more total viewers and Fox, buoyed by “The Moment of Truth” at 8 (8.6 million), faring better with the 18-to-49 set. Fox’s “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” drew lower ratings at 9 (7.1 million). On Friday the cable series “Monk” ended its sixth season on USA Network, delivering the show’s largest audience on record, 6.9 million viewers.
Search the history of American art, and you will discover few watercolors more beautiful than those of Charles Demuth.
To the Editor:.
The philosophy of Joe's Pub is largely the work of Bill Bragin, a 40-year-old music obsessive from Long Island who has become one of the most influential figures in the New York live-music business.
The audacity and reach of “Cat’s Cradle” are impressive, but ambition ultimately runs away with the show.
To the Editor:.
A new textbook shows that the Holocaust has come a long way as a topic to be freshly considered by a new generation of German teenagers.
When Eric Clapton and Steve Winwood  got together at Madison Square Garden on Monday they paid homage to their cherished old Americana.
On Tuesday North Korean officials invited the superstar rock guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.

John Haney's memoir captures what it was like to grow up Cockney in postwar London on a diet of winkles, whelks and prawns.
Justin Bond’s revue is a celebration of transgender and queer culture.
The world’s largest natural gas producer acquired control of a major Russian coal company in a merger that extends its sprawling domestic business empire into electricity.
The four movements of  Ralph Shapey’s  Piano Quintet touch on the qualities you would expect in an early-19th-century work, from humor and introspection to vigor for its own sake.
Nina Ananiashvili  and the State Ballet of Georgia have arrived in New York City, where the company opens on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for four performances.
Central, Michel Richard’s new restaurant, is dedicated to letting you eat well without going broke.
“Mark Twain’s Blues” is more a staged 19th-century American Lit lecture than a play.
Tilth, whose name refers to tilled earth, boasts an organic certification — from the exacting Oregon Tilth association.
James Braly’s “Life in a Marital Institution” is an appealing, well-constructed monologue.
Charlie Trotter will open a restaurant on Madison Avenue, L’Entrecôte will close after 38 years, and more food news.
Handmade meatball sausages are subtly seasoned with onion, garlic, cumin, cinnamon, allspice and nutmeg and baked in a bubbling tomato sauce.
With the right planning and a little practice, there is a way to cook dinner without waking the baby sleeping in the next room.

MAXWELL--Sanders, 90, retired advertising executive and popular pianist, died February 23, 2008 after a brief hospitalization. Following a 40 year career at Young & Rubicam, Tatham-Laird & Kudner and J. Walter Thompson, he formed the Sandy Maxwell Band which played at area events up until his death, including such New York spots as the Century Club, Condon's, El Morocco, Jimmy Weston's and the Union League Club. A 1939 graduate of Princeton University, he was a trustee emeritus of the Triangle Club and played at over 60 Princeton Reunions. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 29, 1:00 pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, Princeton, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Triangle Club, c/ o William Lockwood, McCarter Theatre, 91 University Place, Princeton, NJ 08540.

Minton, Jr. and Emille Breaux of Pelham, New York. He leaves a wife of 57 years, Katharine, a sister, Barbara Minton of Somers, New York, and two children: a son, Robert Minton of New Rochelle, New York, and a daughter, Leslie Toscano of Rome, Italy, and five grandchildren. Robert and Caitlin Minton and William, Elena and David Toscano. At his request, no services will be held. Interment will be at a later date. Donations in his memory would be appreciated to Kids in Crisis in Cos Cob, The Cos Cob Library or Americares.

An article in Business Day on Friday about Toyota's global expansion misidentified the location of its European headquarters. It is outside Brussels, not outside Belgium. An accompanying article about Akio Toyoda, the grandson of the company's founder and its probable next president, also misstated the location of Babson College, where he earned his M.B.A. It is in Wellesley, Mass., a suburb of Boston -- not in Boston itself.

SMALL--Morris, resident of New York and Tamarac, FL, died on February 24. Tenacious and hardworking, he emigrated from Russia pennyless, but prospered as the owner of Danville Manufacturing Corporation, a sleepwear manufacturer, which sold to department stores across the country. Morris was devoted to his family and known for his commitment to charity. He was Vice President of the Jewish Federation of Ft. Lauderdale and David Posnak Hebrew Day School, and recognized as a leader and fundraiser for numerous other charities. He is survived by his wife, brother, three grandchildren, nephew and two great-grandchildren.

O'CONNOR--Robert J. of Manhattan died at age 72 on February 22, 2008 after a brief illness. He was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1935 to the late William and Kathleen (Cruise) O'Connor. As a child, Mr. O'Connor modeled in print media ads for war bonds, cereals and soap powders and was chosen to sit for famed artist and illustrator Norman Rockwell. In his youth, Mr. O'Connor acted in various stage productions including an appearance on Broadway in the original production of Showboat. He graduated from Immaculata High School in Manhattan and went on to major in Business at Brooklyn College. Thereafter, he began a successful professional career in publishing, retiring in 1991 as Publisher of Hearst Corporation's Motor Boating and Sailing Magazine. Mr. O'Connor was an active member of the New York Athletic Club for the past 28 years, serving on the Social Activities Committees as well as participating in many of the intra-clubs of the NYAC. During the holiday season he could always be counted on to escort local high school choirs around the club to sing Christmas Carols for the members. A strong vocalist, Mr. O'Connor often sang the National Anthem at major club functions and could always be counted on for a moving rendition of ''Danny Boy'' at the annual Irish Night event. In March 2006, he was honored as ''Man of the Year'' on Irish Night. Robert J. O'Connor was also a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the Knights of Columbus and was a communicant of St. Paul the Apostle Church in Manhattan. A life long Mets fan, he was eagerly anticipating a World Series Championship in 2008. He is survived by his loyal and loving wife Margaret Bergin O'Connor and a sister, Mary Jane Gavin. He is also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, grand and great-grand nieces and nephews. In sum, Robert J.O'Connor was known by all as a true ''good egg'' and he will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved him. Viewing will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home located at 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday from 7-9pm; Friday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held at St. Paul the Apostle Church on Saturday at 10:30. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting contributions to the Xavier Society for the Blind, 154 East 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.

Now that B.Y.O.B. (bring your own bag) is catching on in food markets, there are new additions to the bag wardrobe. Among them are ones made from tightly woven bamboo fiber that come in two designs meant for artisanal breads. The long one, or quiver, with a shoulder strap to wear while bicycling home from the bakery, is for a baguette; the pouch can hold two one-pound round loaves. A fresh baguette left overnight in its bamboo bag stayed fresher than one in a paper bag, and was pleasantly firmer and crustier than another one wrapped in plastic. Bagels stayed fresher in the pouch than when left out. The bags come from Berkeley, Calif., and are $16 each plus $2 shipping. Ordering information, as well as a diagram showing how to fold the bags into tiny packets, is available at bamboo-bag.com or (510) 926-7726.

Donations to honor Cynthia's memory may be made to the Peace Corps Education Fund, 1111 20th Street NW, Washington, DC 20526.

GAS PRICES CLIMBING Gas prices are surging again, dragging on consumers' budgets and leaving them with less money to spend elsewhere. The convergence of falling home prices and accelerating inflation is putting Federal Reserve officials in a quandary over interest rate increases. [C1.]

PEARSON--Amanda Maugham, age 65, died at home on February 23, 2008. Born in New York City, she was raised in Princeton, and was graduated from Miss Fine's School. She went on to Sarah Lawrence College (1964) and subsequently was awarded two Masters degrees from Bank Street College of Education. Amanda was an extraordinary woman and a lady in the true sense of the word. She'll be remembered for her charm, her kindness to others, her sense of humor, devotion to her friends and family, her boundless curiosity, and her great sense of style. But her most enduring legacy may be in the lives of the young children she taught during her long career in special education. Whether it be in the classroom or as a tutor, Amanda was able to develop a true empathy with her students. They trusted her and she gave them the confidence to risk new behavior and grow. Amanda is survived by her husband Harold, her daughter Diana, sister Liza, stepchildren Chris and Anne Pearson, her niece Jennie Cook, nephew Steve Cook, countless friends, colleagues and students. A memorial celebration of her life will be held on Sunday, March 9, at 2pm at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95 St in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Amanda's honor to the Rivendell School, 277 Third Ave, Brooklyn, NY, 11215.

9 P.M. (13, 49) PETE SEEGER: THE POWER OF SONG On Aug. 18, 1955, at the height of his popularity, Pete Seeger appeared before the House Un-American Activities Committee and refused to name names -- after which he was picketed, protested, blacklisted and banned from commercial television for more than 17 years. Yet he never stopped singing about the country or the issues facing it, including civil rights, the peace movement and the cleanup of the Hudson River, in songs like ''If I Had a Hammer,'' ''Waist Deep in the Big Muddy'' and ''Where Have All the Flowers Gone?'' This ''American Masters'' documentary, an authorized film biography of the 88-year-old Mr. Seeger, above in 1996, traverses his career in music and politics, and his belief in the power of song and of the individual. 8 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICA'S BALLROOM CHALLENGE The winners of the previous four competitions put their best feet forward in this grand finale.

WUNDERLICH--Eleanor Brandreth, passed away peacefully on February 21, at the age of 82. She was former president of Associated Visiting Nurse Services of Westchester, Secretary of NYS Council of Visiting Nurse Associations, and served on the advisory committee on Public Health Nursing for NYS. MILLER--Harold A., Ph.D. Born 1921 in St. Paul, MN, died in White Plains, NY, February 19, 2008 at age 87. He did his undergraduate work at the University of Minnesota and graduated from NYU in 1952. Commissioned as a Lt. Jr. Grade in the U.S. Navy in 1942 and served as a Radar Officer on the USS Champlain. Harold was discharged from service in 1946. He joined the Mearl Corp. in 1952 as a Research Chemist and retired as Director of Research. He was a member of the American Chemical Society, Society of Cosmetic Chemists, American Physics Society, a photographer, painter and world traveler. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, (Hermine) Mimi. Harold will be remembered at a Memorial Service on February 29, 2008 at 10:00am at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, of which he was a member for many years.

Intense, tart-sweet dried fruit is excellent to have on hand for snacking, to serve with cheese and to use in cooking. Many of the unusual varieties from Meduri World Delights in Dallas, Ore., have particularly bright flavors and are tasty without being sticky-sweet. Peaches from Chile, a mix of strawberries with rhubarb pieces, sour morello cherries and apricots from California are all excellent. The rosy pink lady-apple wedges, made from Pacific Northwest fruit, are especially alluring. I added some to the pan as I deglazed it with white wine after sautéing pork chops. Granny Smith apples are also available.

RUBIN--Albert L., M.D. The Board of Directors of The Rogosin Institute deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Albert L. Rubin. Dr. Rubin was the first nephrologist in New York to provide kidney dialysis (1956) and renal transplantation (1963). To implement his comprehensive, integrative approach to kidney disease, he created The Rogosin Institute, an affiliate of the New York - Presbyterian Health care System, 25 years ago and had been The Institute's President and Chief Executive Officer since then. He provided the remarkable vision, leadership and compassion that are the heart of The Institute's clinical and research programs. The Rogosin Institute now provides comprehensive treatment of renal disease for thousands of patients. In addition to his work as a physician and teacher, Dr. Rubin had initiated and shepherded The Institute's major research programs in renal disease, diabetes, lipid disorders and cancer. From the beginning of his extraordinary career he had promoted bringing basic research to the bedside as rapidly as possible in order to improve patient care and quality of life. His extraordinary vitality, enthusiasm and wisdom have nurtured The Rogosin Institute and enriched all those who have worked with him. He will be deeply missed. RUBIN--Albert, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Albert Rubin. The founder and director of The Rogosin Institute, a medical partner of New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, he was professor of surgery, medicine and biochemistry at Weill Cornell Medical College, where he received his medical degree and served as alumni association president. Beginning in the 1950s, Dr. Rubin was central to the introduction of dialysis and kidney transplantation to New York, helping to extend and improve the lives of countless patients. Today, as a result of his remarkable leadership, Rogosin is one of the world's largest kidney programs, performing more than 100,000 dialyses every year. A national and international advocate for organ donation and for making treatment affordable, he arranged the first kidney transplant between a Russian donor and a U.S. recipient, in 1977. A brilliant researcher, mentor and clinician, he inspired us with his steadfast dedication and compassion for his patients. Together with his wife, the late Dr. Carolyn Diehl, he contributed greatly to the life of our medical center. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the Rubin family, including his son, Marc, and three grandchildren. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital RUBIN--Dr. Albert L. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our cherished friend Dr. Albert L. Rubin. A true visionary in the field of medical research, he created The Rogosin Institute and built it into one of New York City's leading research centers, specializing in kidney disease but encompassing pioneering investigations into cancer, diabetes, and other pressing health concerns. Long before others embraced the concept of inter-institutional collaboration, he understood that advances in scientific research and medicine would only come from such sharing of knowledge, and he reached out to establish partnerships with other academic and medical research centers. We at Rockefeller were privileged to be among them. Together with his late wife, Dr. Carolyn Diehl, he will long be remembered as an example of the very best that the medical profession can aspire to. We will cherish their memories and seek to honor them through our work. Our deepest condolences are sent to the Rubin and Diehl families, and to the investigators and staff of The Rogosin Institute. Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief Russell L. Carson, Chair David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair RUBIN--Albert L. M.D. The Medical Staff and Employees of The Rogosin Institute mourn the passing of its founder and leader, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., who served as Director of The Institute from its founding until his death on February 23, 2008. We came to know him as a compassionate physician, accomplished scientist, wise teacher, and friend to us all. His vision and leadership created an Institute of which we are all extremely proud. The combination of the very best in patient care and innovative research programs to make that care even better was central to that vision. He made The Institute an exciting place to work, and we are glad to be part of it. We will miss Dr. Rubin deeply, but count on his example and inspiration to help us continue and expand the work of The Institute so that we can help many thousands more patients in the years to come. We share his dream of ending kidney disease as we now know it. We believe that his dream is one that can be realized, and we plan to work hard to achieve that. We cannot think of a better way to honor his memory. RUBIN--Albert L., M.D., a physician, researcher and executive of Englewood, NJ, died peacefully at home on February 23. He founded and led The Rogosin Institute, affiliated with New York-Presbyterian Hospital, from its inception in 1983 to his death, building The Institute into a world renowned treatment and research organization specializing in kidney disease. Born May 9, 1927, he attended Williams College from 1944 to 1945 and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He received his medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950. In 1957, he and his team performed the first hemodialysis for the treatment of kidney failure in the New York metropolitan area. In 1962, the unit became known as the Renal Laboratory located at the Cornell Division at Bellevue Hospital before moving to The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where it expanded to the Rogosin Renal Laboratories and to The Rogosin Institute in 1983. A true visionary, he pioneered the advancement of the treatment of kidney disease and spearheaded promising research and treatment programs in lipid disorders, diabetes and cancer. He was a talented physician and researcher who not only foresaw the future of medicine and the true purpose of research, but understood that collaboration and cooperation among institutions and organizations was necessary in order to bring developments to patients as quickly as possible. He will be remembered by many as a talented leader and inspirational mentor. He married Carolyn Diehl, M.D., in 1953, who preceded him in death by 20 months. He is survived by son Marc Rubin, M.D., his wife, Jennifer and three grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Rogosin Institute, 505 E. 70th Street, New York, NY 10021. A private service will be held Saturday, March 1. Family and friends are invited to the home of Marc and Jennifer Rubin, 130 Walnut St., Englewood, on March 1 from 3 to 6 pm. --Albert L., M.D. He was a pioneer in the treatment of kidney disease; a founder and leader of the pre-eminent Rogosin Institute; a visionary in patient care and research to cure a wide variety of severe illnesses. Dr. Rubin uniquely combined intellectual power, compassion, humor, force of personality and leadership ability. He left a model to follow for Rogosin's Medical staff, Employees and Board of Directors, and the medical profession; and he left to the echoes of applause from thousands of patients. Henry J. Leir, our late founder, was his close friend, kindred spirit and admirer. The Leir Charitable Foundations

PEARSON--Marge. It is with the deepest sadness that we mourn the loss of our dear friend and former colleague, Marge Pearson, who passed away after an extraordinary and valiant battle with cancer. Marge served with distinction for many years as a member of our sales management team. Her early leadership helped to provide the foundation for the success and strength of our rental division today. Marge's many years of community service were recognized in 2002 by her receiving the coveted Henry Forster Memorial Award from the Real Estate Board of New York. We join together in mourning Marge's memory as a leader who was a soft spoken, compassionate, caring and sensitive human being. Our condolences go out to Marge's family who was always her guiding light. In Loving Memory, From Your Friends At Prudential Douglas Elliman Real Estate.
