Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal held a 2 p.m. news conference to propose an alternative plan that would aim to reduce traffic by charging a $4 surcharge on all taxi and limousine rides. The “drop charge” — the flat fee imposed once a passenger enters a cab — would rise to $6.50 from $2.50, but the subsequent charge would be reduced to 35 cents per one-fifth of a mile, down from the current charge of 40 cents per one-fifth of a mile.

Nicolas Ghesquiere finally has someone to set his shoulder against. Tonight, Stefano Pilati hammered out his best Saint Laurent collection since he became creative director. This is the first group of clothes that has captured the energy of the Rive Gauche era and at the same time feels contemporary. You are no longer looking at any trace of the old Saint Laurent, except perhaps a jewel color, and yet it is Saint Laurent. Pilati carries forward the simplified lines of the spring collection and now adds more sex appeal, more flare to the geometry. The collection has a lot of versaility, but your eye goes immediately to the straight shoulders of unlined, cutaway coats in Donegal tweeds and then to the succinct volumes at the hem. Sharpness at the top, movement and freedom at the bottom, an effect repeated in wool felt coats and skirts.

There was a time when commodities markets were viewed with deep suspicion by farmers, who saw speculators and gamblers manipulating the prices of crops to benefit themselves and steal from farmers. In 1874, one house of the Illinois legislature approved a bill to make it a crime to trade a futures contract unless the seller actually had possession of the crop. The Chicago Board of Trade managed to water down the law to bar the trading of options, but not futures, and thus stayed in business.

Eight years ago, I traveled the country with Ralph Nader. He was sardonic and surprisingly funny. As we drove through post-industrial landscapes of depressing sameness, Mr. Nader kept up a constant monologue about the spiritual costs of box stores and fast food. I recall standing at an airport counter - it was Sioux Falls, or maybe Fargo - where the agent cheerfully informed Mr. Nader that he had been upgraded to first class; he protested vigorously and smoldered the entire flight home. After Mr. Nader was tossed out of the presidential debate site in Boston, he and I watched the next debate in front of the TV at the brownstone that was his Washington headquarters. I ate pizza as Mr. Nader paced the room trying out phantom debate lines and railing against the two "corporate supremacists" on stage, who, he pointed out, refused to mention the plight of the working poor, the tilt of the political system toward special interests, the human toll of free trade. Mr. Nader's candidacy took a dark turn in the closing weeks of the 2000 campaign. Until then, he had been running primarily to get the 5 percent of the vote he needed to qualify the Green Party for matching funds. But then Mr. Nader's consuming resentment - at the way leading Democrats pressured his friends to denounce him, at the way Al Gore refused to speak his name - seemed to possess him, and at some point he seemed to make it his mission to deny Mr. Gore the presidency, attacking his Democratic rival in swing states over the protests of his own aides. I've always thought that Mr. Gore probably could have avoided what came next simply by picking up the phone in those final weeks and making some small gesture of respect toward the man. But he didn't, and Mr. Nader got his wish.

Sometimes science imitates art. The Greeks myths told how Enceladus, a Giant who was buried beneath Mount Etna, caused earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. At Versailles, Louis XIV built a fountain in his honor. In the only conversation I've ever had with the movie critic David Denby, in a kitchen on New Year's Day, I mentioned some terribly obvious movie that had done extremely well despite Denby's (and everyone else's) having ripped it apart. He shrugged. "It's critic-proof," he said, and made a round motion with his hands. No point of critical entry. I think the most interesting thing about Thierry Mugler's Angel Men Pure Coffee, a limited edition scent landing this April and hanging around for a scant four months or so, is that it feels critic-proof as well. It is jarringly direct, like the person blithely unflustered by your eye contact. It is, in its friendly self-assurance, impossible to approach with any kind of critical knife; irritatingly disarming, it is as effortlessly pleasing as it is exasperatingly obvious. The one difference between Pure Coffee and the movie is that this scent is excellent.

ARAB JABOUR, Iraq - After a 15-month deployment in Iraq, the men and women of the 5-7 Cavalry, under the command of the First Brigade Combat Team, Third Infantry Division, out of Fort Stewart, Ga., will be returning home. With one month to go before the 5-7 was taken out of its area of operation, I was embedded with Troop B to pose a simple line of questions to a group of young men who had found themselves in extraordinary circumstances far from home for many months.

I'm sitting in my hotel room, it's 7 in the morning, and Carlos, the waiter in my hotel, has gratefully arrived with the black coffee and the boiled egg. A light rain is falling; my kind of day in Paris. Yesterday was a barn-burner: long, with deadlines and many shows, and not very good shows at that. Givenchy was the march of the toothpicks. Super-skinny pants with feminine blouses and jackets with Spanish or Sud de France embroidery. Either way, you felt the influence, from way, way back, of Ghesquiere (the Jules Verne collection, among others) and, much closer, Christian Lacroix, especially in the last black and white coat.
Bill Gates has changed his social networking allegiance.
MILWAUKEE (AP) — Kohl’s Corporation said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit fell about 15 percent as shoppers continued to pull back their spending.

LOS ANGELES (Reuters) — Gap Inc. said on Thursday that quarterly net profit rose, matching Wall Street forecasts, as the apparel retailer offered fewer price markdowns and tightened inventory in an effort to turn around flagging sales at its stores.
The world’s largest insurer swung to a fourth-quarter loss, hurt by a write-down of derivatives exposed to bad mortgage investments.
The owner of cable networks and movie studios said it saw no impact from a weaker economy, echoing similar statements from some of its big media peers.
On another day of unsettling economic news, President Bush and Democratic leaders went to war on how to deal with widening damage from the housing and mortgage crises.
Sprint’s stock slid more than 9 percent after the company announced a $29.45 billion fourth-quarter loss, due mostly to a huge write-off related to its merger with Nextel Communications.
A year after it began a fundamental transformation of its basic formula, Dell reported that its net income in its fiscal fourth quarter fell 6 percent to $679 million.
John McCain accused Barack Obama for the second day of a willingness to hand over Iraq to al Qaeda.
A trader at MF Global rang up the losses on the broker’s account this week, the company said. The trades cost the company almost a fifth of its market value.
Under the deal, eBay will buy three patents from MercExchange needed to run its Web search, online auctions and fixed price sales.
Using tough language, President Bush prodded Congress to pass his preferred version of surveillance legislation.
With 1.6 million people in prison, the incarceration rate is now the highest in American history, a new report says.
In “Daddy’s Little Phenoms,” Pat Jordan writes about Ginger and Robbi Howard, two junior golfers whose father has an ambitious master plan -- to create the Williams sisters of golf.
The goal of Dubai Sports City is both grand and simple: to be the ultimate destination for athletes and fans. And no expense is spared in the process.

“Though it seems innocuous, overtraining isn’t just a matter of having overdone things in a workout or two,” Gretchen Reynolds writes in her column, “Crash and Burnout.” Overtraining is a recognized illness, she writes, one that’s similar in some respects to chronic-fatigue syndrome and major depression, with symptoms that might include mood changes, insomnia and fatigue. And it can afflict both endurance and strength athletes, particularly those who train the hardest. The conundrum for elite athletes, then, is maximizing training without crossing the line into overtraining. While science doesn’t agree on how best to avoid crossing that line, there is consensus on how to treat it: “Rest, rest and more rest,” says Robert Schoene, a professor of medicine at the University of California, San Diego.

Jonathan Mahler writes in this weekend’s issue of PLAY about the succession strategy within the Yankees, with George Steinbrenner firmly in the background and his two sons taking over control of the team. Though the original Boss hasn’t left the scene entirely, this seems like a good time to take stock of his 24-year stewardship: When all is accounted for -- his six championships, his free spending, his blunders, his bluster, his impact on baseball overall -- how should the elder Steinbrenner be remembered?.

Fortunes have changed dramatically for the Boston Celtics this season. But as Chuck Klosterman writes in “What a Difference a Man Makes,” a number of players from the luckless 2007 team still play for the successful 2008 version, including several bench players. “These are the same people, living in the same city, holding the exact same jobs - yet so much about their lives has changed,” he writes. Credit Kevin Garnett, the Celtics superstar. Brian Scalabrine, a seven-year veteran in the league and one of team’s returning role players, tells Klosterman: “Look, I can keep saying a million clichés, but those clichés are going to be true... He demands a different level of focus from everybody.” Still, the question remains: Can the Celtics, built around aging veterans with little playoff success, have more than a good regular season?.

From the moment Hank Steinbrenner commandeered Jonathan Mahler’s rental car, navigated it through Tampa then swerved onto a walkway at Legends Field and pulled to stop a few feet from his offices, Mahler could sense something “very Steinbrennarian” about the older son who was taking command of the New York Yankees, along with his brother Hal. “Hank was in exile for so many years,” Mahler said the other day, “but he’s clearly quite comfortable stepping into this role.”.
Mr. Miles, a drummer in Jimi Hendrix’s Band of Gypsys and a hitmaker under his own name, was 60.
The Chinese government reported Thursday that the pesticide-laced dumplings that sickened at least 10 people in Japan might have been deliberately poisoned.
A $10 million contract for the construction of a heliport in Newark has been awarded to Air Pegasus Helicopters, a company that operates heliports in Manhattan and Washington.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted to more than triple spending for an AIDS program that has proven to be one of the Bush administration’s most successful and popular global foreign policy initiatives.
Despite trailing early, the Knicks earned their largest margin of victory since beating Detroit, 89-65, on Jan. 13.
David Tyree wore his Super Bowl helmet proudly in front of a hometown crowd and showed that it is possible to make history with Montclair, N.J., roots.

LeBron James returned from a first-half ankle injury to score 26 points and become the youngest player in N.B.A. history to reach the 10,000-point milestone, but the host Boston Celtics defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 92-87, on Wednesday night.
Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy this year.
With Rutgers’ victory over DePaul, C. Vivian Stringer became the third coach in women’s college basketball history to reach 800 wins.
DaJuan Summers made five 3-pointers and scored 21 points Wednesday night to lead No. 11 Georgetown to a 64-52 victory against visiting St. John’s.

A music review on Feb. 18 about two concerts by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the age of the twin children of the orchestra’s music director, David Robertson, who mentioned them in remarks before one concert. They are 5 months old, not 5 years.

A picture caption with an article in some editions last Thursday about concerns that New York City’s plans to rezone 125th Street in Harlem would force out many black residents and small businesses referred incompletely to a street scene along East 125th Street, shown in the picture at left. It was taken in 1975. (The picture at right showed a current scene of nighttime commerce between Fifth Avenue and Malcolm X Boulevard.).

An article on Monday about Argentina’s struggle to avoid energy shortages attributed an erroneous distinction to Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s president. She is the first woman to have been elected president — not the first woman to serve in that office. (María Estela Perón, known as Isabelita, became president in July 1974 after her husband, Gen. Juan Domingo Perón, died.).

A film review in Weekend on Friday about the three-part movie “The Signal” reversed the identities of two directors. Part 2 was directed by Jacob Gentry and Part 3 was directed by Dan Bush. The review also misidentified a character at one point. It is Lewis who is “now raging” in Part 2, not Ben.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about commercials that ran during the Academy Awards show on Sunday, referred incorrectly to “Killing the Blues,” a song featured in a commercial for J. C. Penney. Although the recording heard is from a new album by Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, the song itself is not new. (It is by John Prine and has been recorded by many artists.).

A chart with a sports article on Tuesday about the anticipated strength of the Detroit Tigers’ lineup misstated, in some copies, the year of the statistics for three players who are out of the lineup and for three additions to the team. The totals were from 2007, not 2006.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday by The Associated Press about the crash of a B-2 stealth bomber misspelled the name of the Air Force base in Guam from which the plane took off. It is Andersen Air Force Base, not Anderson.
A listing of American military deaths on Tuesday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the Iraq war as of then. It was 3,962, not 3,961. An updated Names of the Dead appears on Page A10 today.

An article on Feb. 12 about efforts by hospitals in New York City to expand their emergency rooms misidentified the hospital system with the busiest emergency department, according to the New York State Department of Health, which verifies figures provided by hospitals. It is NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, not Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

An article on Monday about Argentina’s struggle to avoid energy shortages attributed an erroneous distinction to Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s president. She is the first woman to have been elected president — not the first woman to serve in that office. (María Estela Perón, known as Isabelita, became president in July 1974 after her husband, Gen. Juan Domingo Perón, died.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed against energy companies by an Alaska Native coastal village that is being forced to relocate because of flooding caused by the changing Arctic climate misstated the estimated cost of moving the village. It could cost up to $400 million, not up to $400,000.
The Ottawa Senators fired Coach John Paddock on Wednesday, with 18 games left in the season.
The principal at a prominent Catholic boys’ high school in the Bronx was ousted after photos of nude men were discovered on his computer.
The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected to resign her post next month, according to people briefed on her plans.

The Manhattan district attorney is investigating the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International after an internal audit showed that hundreds of thousands of dollars was missing. The audit led to the dismissal of two foundation employees.
A video made by four white university students showed middle-aged black cleaning employees duped into eating food that had been urinated on.
Latin America’s largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, freed three men and a woman, all former members of Congress, held in captivity for more than six years.
Whatever their reason might be, a passing hearse or simple discomfort, Italy’s highest court ruled that men may not touch their genitals in public.
An intensely criticized plan for each fifth grader to study the life of a French child killed in the Holocaust was abandoned at the first meeting of a commission on the issue.
A small police plane crashed into a soccer field in Santiago, the capital, killing the six occupants of the plane and five people on the field.
President Idriss Déby agreed to an international inquiry into this month’s rebel raid on the capital, Ndjamena, and the disappearance of opposition leaders.
The radicals were sentenced to 5 to 14 years in prison on charges linked to the formation of a group whose leader plotted to blow up the court’s Madrid building.
A challenge Senator Barack Obama issued to others on public financing in the general election is now a test for him.

The federal receiver appointed to overhaul California’s prison health care system billed state taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars too much for benefits and travel expenses, the prison system’s inspector general said. In its first 15 months of operation, the office of the receiver spent more than $33 million, including paying more than $610,000 to employees to compensate them for not having benefits like pensions and health care coverage, the inspector general, Matthew Cate, reported. The report criticizes the high salaries paid to the former receiver, Robert Sillen, above, and his employees. Mr. Sillen was appointed in April 2006 after a federal judge found that the prison health care system was so bad that inmates often died because of malpractice or neglect. He was replaced in January.

The United States Mint has rejected three designs for a commemorative District of Columbia quarter because they include the slogan “Taxation Without Representation.” The Mint said the slogan was too controversial. Mayor Adrian M. Fenty says it is a fair assessment, and the slogan is on Washington’s license plates to draw attention to its lack of voting rights in Congress. But Mr. Fenty says the District will submit something else for its quarter. The District is being included in the popular state quarter program after 10 years of lobbying.

A former Canton police officer was sentenced to life in prison for killing his pregnant girlfriend and their unborn child. Jurors spared the defendant, Bobby Cutts Jr., the death penalty on the most serious charge, aggravated murder in the death of the fetus. Mr. Cutts, 30, said that the death of his girlfriend, Jessie Davis, 26, from an elbow-to-throat blow last June was an accident and that he had dumped Ms. Davis’s body in a park in a panic. Prosecutors said Mr. Cutts, who is married, killed Ms. Davis and the nearly full-term fetus to avoid paying child support. The couple’s son, Blake, then 2 1/2 years old, gave investigators their first clues to his mother’s disappearance when he said: “Mommy’s crying. Mommy broke the table. Mommy’s in the rug,” and later, “Daddy’s mad.”.

An Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent killed himself in Grand Prairie after an armed standoff with an officer and three colleagues, the police said. The police discovered a suitcase full of pornography, a flag bearing a swastika hung in a closet and more than a half dozen weapons after finding the agent, Mark Juvette, dead. Mr. Juvette, 40, was an agent with ICE’s Dallas Office of Detention and Removal, which transports detainees, manages them while in custody and deports illegal immigrants.

The Anchorage police have arrested a man in an armed robbery. Now they are trying to determine if the weapon was a spork, a hybrid of a spoon and fork found at fast-food restaurants. The police say a man tried to grab another man’s watch on Monday night. The victim says the assailant swung a pocketknife at him, but four parallel scratches on his side make the police suspect that the wound was administered with a spork. Peter Albert, 52, was arrested near the scene and charged with robbery. The police say Mr. Albert was carrying a pocketknife and a backpack containing sporks.
Harold M. Ickes, leading Hillary Rodham Clinton’s fight for superdelegates, may be her last hope for winning.

They are fixtures of New York City life: sidewalk peddlers and the grocers who try to shoo them away from their storefronts. The City Council grudgingly added to that time-honored clash on Wednesday, approving a bill that will increase the number of fruit and vegetable carts in the city’s poor neighborhoods.

Supporters of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge people who drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan have promoted it as a way to provide a steady flow of money to pay for improvements to public transportation for decades to come.

It was hoped the law could have eliminated severe electoral distortions that have left Kurds and Shiites with disproportionate power over Sunni Arabs in some areas, a factor that has fueled the Sunni insurgency.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve signaled his readiness to bolster the economy with cheaper money, though inflation is picking up speed.
An appeal of the biggest punitive damage award upheld in federal court led to a lively Supreme Court argument.
Once Guantánamo’s chief prosecutor and now its chief critic, Col. Morris D. Davis will testify on behalf of a detainee accused of being Osama bin Laden’s driver.
The Garden State’s woes should serve as a warning to other states, whose lawmakers might use budget gimmickry to get through fiscal troubles.
Perhaps the only relief for the Rams is that they have time to avoid breaking the N.C.A.A. record of 58 consecutive losses, set by Long Island University from 1987 to 1989.
Mayor Mike Fahey may face an uphill fight in winning approval for the new stadium it’s hoped will help Ohmaha keep the College World Series in town.
Under a plan that would be subject to the approval of the Czech Parliament, the United States would install a radar system.
Phil Mickelson’s barbed sense of humor, usually confined to P.G.A. Tour locker rooms, will be on display in a new batch of golf themed television ads.
I am not — and will not be — a candidate for president. But I’ll join others in helping a candidate with an independent, nonpartisan approach win the White House.
Justices ruled that failure to file a proper form to complain of age discrimination does not cancel a worker’s chance to go to court later.
The New York Philharmonic’s concert would have had more significance if it could have celebrated progress toward shuttering North Korea’s nuclear weapons program.
Black officials stumping for Hillary Rodham Clinton are being met with disbelief, disapproval and at times ridicule from black voters.
Mr. Buckley was firmly committed to civil discourse and showed little appetite for the shrillness that plagues far too much of today’s political discourse.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has worked to foster the sort of ethanol investments pursued by her husband’s friends and her political supporters.
Thousands of patients may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus because of an inappropriate medical practice at a Nevada outpatient clinic.
Prosecutors in the trial of three detectives accused in the shooting death of Sean Bell plan to call the detectives’ commanding officer to testify about the detail that he supervised.
The public is counting on Speaker Nancy Pelosi to stand fast and steer an overdue dose of ethics reform to passage in the House.
The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.
After decades in the shadows, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is turning heads by making high-profile investments across the globe.
John McCain was born in the Panama Canal Zone. So is he still a “natural-born citizen” and therefore eligible to be president?
Senate Republicans were commiserating over a fresh defeat and plotting a last stand for their beleaguered party.
It’s not at all clear how many supporters Ralph Nader has left, but when he announced that he was running for president yet again, he did cite one man who lives on Long Island.
Managers of the troubled Swiss bank won shareholder backing for a plan to raise capital, but only after facing criticism over the huge write-downs on subprime investments.
A lull in homicides was bound to end but Newark officials say that the past six weeks were not some bit of random luck but real dividends of a revamped policing strategy.
Regulators issued the company a $1.35 billion fine for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that it had abused its dominance.
The Humane Society sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a “loophole” that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.
What’s the cheapest way to text message your friends? For thousands of the city’s middle school students, the answer now is to earn an “A.”

The Tampa Bay Rays left-hander Scott Kazmir, the strikeout leader in the American League last season, will be sidelined for at least two weeks of spring training because of an elbow strain, although he said he remained confident he would be ready for opening day.

A front-page article on Saturday described a cocaine epidemic in Argentina fed by the consumption of paco, an addictive smokable cocaine residue. The article included an explanatory paragraph about paco’s addictive power and toxicity that repeated material from a 2006 article published in The Miami Herald, without attributing it to the newspaper. The correspondent, who had done his own research with Argentine and Brazilian officials on the drug and its effects, should have summarized it in his own words, or credited The Herald.
Lost amid their sparring is that both rivals have staked out nuanced positions in the past on Nafta, and have supported similar deals.
Whether the agent’s action was murder or self-defense is being resolved at a trial that began this week in the heated atmosphere over illegal immigration.
House leadership delayed consideration of an independent ethics panel to review House members’ conduct.
Though announced as a merger, it sounded like the Indy Racing League would be virtually swallowing up it’s rival, the Champ Car World Series.
Differing statements from the factory owner and traders highlight the difficulty of tracing the supply chain in China for the blood-thinner heparin.
The entire fleet of roughly 10,000 limousines that are used by businesses would be required to meet fuel-efficiency standards, attainable only with hybrid vehicles.
Government reports released Wednesday reinforced concerns that the economy was facing severe headwinds.
The idea that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would withhold his support could lead to friction, especially with officials who are weighing mayoral campaigns.
A mathematician turned investor has become Stony Brook University’s largest benefactor.
Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, confirmed his switch of support away from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern insisted that Congress need not legislate drug testing in the major professional sports leagues.
Senate Judiciary Committee members said recent court rulings had harmed citizens’ efforts to report fraud against the government.
General Electric is hoping to make a big splash at the Olympics and prove that the company’s creativity is translating into big sales in the developing world.
A man killed his ex-girlfriend’s current boyfriend, her mother and two other people on Wednesday morning and then killed himself.

PHILADELPHIA (AP) — The luxury-home builder Toll Brothers Inc. said Wednesday that it swung to a loss in the first quarter as write-downs on properties it could no longer sell at a profit more than doubled and sales dropped 23 percent.
Shares of Biogen Idec and the Elan Corporation fell Wednesday after the companies reported that some patients had liver injuries after taking the drug Tysabri.
Over a 50-year career, Mr. Watkin worked on more than 60 films and received the 1985 Academy Award for best cinematography for “Out of Africa.”
The owner of USA Today named Robert J. Dickey president of its newspaper division on Wednesday, succeeding Susan Clark-Johnson, who is retiring in May.
Lake County, Colo., officials declared a state of emergency over concerns that contaminated water could burst from the Leadville Mine Drainage Tunnel and flood the town.
The announcement came as the company dropped its plans to seek demolition of the 80-year-old Sears, Roebuck & Company building to build an office park.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine said that the cuts were unavoidable because two decades of profligate spending had left the state on the verge of fiscal ruin.
Surveillance is a delicate issue in Germany, which has a legacy of distrust of state intrusion through spying by the Nazi Gestapo and East Germany’s secret police, the Stasi.

An effective test for detecting human growth hormone will be in place for the Beijing Olympics, the head of the World Anti-Doping Agency said.H.G.H., considered one of the most widely abused performance-enhancing drugs, clears the system quickly, making testing difficult.“By the Olympic Games there will be a capacity to detect H.G.H.,” WADA’s president, John Fahey, said.Fahey said traces of the drug could be detected for up to eight years after a test, meaning users could lose their medals years later.

Carolina released quarterback David Carr and signed receiver Muhsin Muhammad to a two-year contract.Carr signed a two-year, $6 million deal with the Panthers last year after five years as a starter in Houston. Muhammad was released by the Chicago Bears last week.

The top-ranked and four-time champion Justine Henin was stretched to the limit by Katarina Srebotnik before winning, 7-5, 6-7 (6), 6-3, to reach the quarterfinals at the Dubai Championships.Second-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova cruised past Lucie Safarova, 6-1, 6-2, and will meet unseeded Amélie Mauresmo, the 2002 champion and last year’s runner-up.

Brian Boitano, Joan Benoit Samuelson, Oscar De La Hoya and David Robinson head a list of 18 finalists announced Wednesday for the United States Olympic Hall of Fame. The public will select six inductees.Boitano won the gold medal in men’s figure skating in 1988. In 1984, Samuelson won the first Olympic marathon for women. De La Hoya won boxing’s lightweight gold medal in 1992 and Robinson basketball gold medals in 1992 and 1996.The other individual finalists are Greg Barton (kayak), Bruce Baumgartner (wrestling), Jeff Blatnick (wrestling), Valerie Brisco (track and field), Teresa Edwards (basketball), Karch Kiraly (volleyball), Mary T. Meagher (swimming), Sheila Young Ochowicz (speed skating), Darrell Pace (archery), Michael Plumb (equestrian), John Smith (wrestling), Amy Van Dyken (swimming), Peter Westbrook (fencing) and Lones Wigger (shooting).

The longtime Pittsburgh Steelers broadcaster Myron Cope died Wednesday at 79.Cope died at a nursing home in Mount Lebanon, a Pittsburgh suburb, Joe Gordon, a former Steelers executive, said. Cope had been treated for respiratory problems and heart failure in recent months. Cope’s tenure from 1970 to 2004 as the color analyst on the Steelers’ radio network is the longest in N.F.L. history for a broadcaster with a single team and led to his induction into the National Radio Hall of Fame in 2005.

No Kenyan man has won four Boston Marathons, but three Kenyans have won three each. One of them is Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot, and race officials announced that he would return April 21 for the 111th running of the race.His main challengers will include Patrick Ivuti and James Kwambai, also from Kenya. In the Chicago Marathon last October, Ivuti outleaned Jaouad Gharib of Morocco, the world champion. Kwambai finished second in Boston last year.
A Delaware school district has settled a suit brought by two Jewish families over the pervasiveness of Christian prayer and other religious activities in the schools.
European Union regulators said they would investigate whether bailouts of two German banks hit by the subprime lending crisis had violated rules on state aid.
John McCain accused Barack Obama of being willing to surrender Iraq to Al Qaeda in a preview of a possible general election contest.
The earnings drop was the result of some one-time revamping costs and the continued erosion of revenue at its flagship newspaper.
A member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked about potential financial conflicts among doctors involved in the research that led to F.D.A. approval of an artificial spinal disk.
The telecommunications company reported a $957 million loss for 2007 and said it would cut 2,100 jobs and move 1,000 others, mostly to China and Turkey.
The World Health Organization confirmed the first cases of the disease in a Latin American urban area in six decades.
The unrest — the worst in more than 15 years in this oil-producing Central African nation — has resulted in at least six deaths since it began over the weekend.
The departure of Scott B. Meyer comes as The New York Times Company is under intense pressure from a major shareholder to increase its investment in Internet operations.
Bowing to critics, Aetna said it had suspended a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.
Limited Brands reported Wednesday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell nearly 12 percent on a substantial decline in sales after its decision last summer to get out of the apparel business.
In the Mets’ Grapefruit League opener against the Tigers, Mike Pelfrey threw two scoreless innings, but knows he faces stiff competition for the remaining No. 5 starter’s job.
In a move that could help the housing market, a federal regulator said that it was removing limits on the investment portfolios of the two large mortgage buyers.
The plans often cost beneficiaries more than the government-run Medicare program, Congressional investigators say.
In the adventure game The Experiment, the player sits in front of a computer screen playing a character sitting in front of a computer screen.
The recommendation expands by about 30 million the number of children who should get annual influenza shots.
Wall Street finished mixed in another seesaw session Wednesday after regulators allowed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to buy more mortgages.
The recommendation expands by about 30 million the number of children who should get annual influenza shots.
Want to quickly add a song in iTunes to a playlist without dragging it?
What does Outlook do that Outlook Express doesn’t do? Is there any reason to buy Outlook?
My broadband Internet connection seems to be slower than advertised. What might be causing this slowness, and how I can find out how fast my connection really is?
The classroom building at Northern Illinois University where a gunman killed five students and himself this month will be demolished and replaced.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,966 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
New parents are turning to a growing array of babytronics for child-rearing help.
In a testament to the globalization of the wine business in recent years, a Chinese businessman purchased a chateau in Bordeaux in January, a first in the region.
A former executive at UBS who sold information about the bank’s stock recommendations and a former trader who used those tips, pleaded guilty on Wednesday.
The Asus Nova P22, priced at $749 to $899 depending on options, weighs just under 4 pounds and measures 9 by 7.2 by 2 inches.
The Sony Mylo Personal Communicator COM-2, or Mylo 2, is a device situated firmly in the netherworld between laptops and cellphones.
While the rest of the world was fawning over Apple’s MacBook Air, Lenovo’s ThinkPad X300 entered the world with little fanfare, even though it is 0.1 of a pound lighter and runs Windows Vista.
The move comes three years after Thomas Krens won a showdown with the foundation’s biggest benefactor.
Aperture 2.0 offers a more accessible, streamlined facade and makes it easier to handle photos in full-screen mode.
The Beanie Babies 2.0 Collection has arrived in stores, with a Web-ready scratch-off code on every heart-shaped tag.
Orchid Extravaganza.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
A new musical by Stephen King and John Mellencamp is to open in April 2009 at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta.

A celebrity photographer who sued an Australian newspaper for defamation after it accused him of hounding Nicole Kidman has lost his case, The Associated Press reported. Not only did Justice Carolyn Simpson of the New South Wales Supreme Court find against the photographer, Jamie Fawcett, below, she also called his conduct “intrusive” and “threatening” and ordered him to pay the legal costs of Fairfax Media, the publisher of the newspaper he sued, The Sun-Herald. Ms. Kidman was a star witness in the case. Mr. Fawcett, who, the judge found, tried to bug the Kidman house in Sydney and engaged in a dangerous car chase, said he would probably appeal the court’s decision.

Michael Jackson could lose his Neverland Valley Ranch in California, above, unless he pays nearly $25 million before March 19. A five-page filing at the Santa Barbara County Recorder’s Office said, “You are in default of a deed of trust,” Reuters reported, citing FoxNews.com. “Unless you take action to protect your property, it may be sold at a public sale.” Mr. Jackson’s representative, Raymone Bain, did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Mr. Jackson has owned the 2,800-acre ranch in the foothills above the California coast since 1988. He has mainly lived abroad since he was acquitted of child molestation charges in 2005.

A collection of 725 works of modern art valued at $250 million has been bought for Britain for $52 million and will tour the country under the ownership and management of the Tate and the National Galleries of Scotland, the museums said on Wednesday. Described as one of the most important holdings of postwar and contemporary international art in private hands, the collection, featuring names like Diane Arbus, Damien Hirst, Jeff Koons, Sol LeWitt, Robert Mapplethorpe (whose portrait of Patti Smith is shown above), Gerhard Richter and Andy Warhol, was assembled over three decades by the art dealer Anthony d’Offay. Under the name “Artist Rooms,” reflecting the concept of devoting individual rooms to particular artists, the works will be seen at museums and galleries across Britain starting in spring 2009. The cost of acquisition, for a price described as Mr. d’Offay’s original cost, was met by the Scottish and British governments, the National Heritage Memorial Fund and the Art Fund. Prime Minister Gordon Brown reacted to Mr. d’Offay’s contribution by saying, “Individual acts of generosity like this impact on the lives of millions, and reinforce the U.K.’s richly deserved reputation as having a range of world-leading museums and galleries.”.

NBC’s new drama “Quarterlife,” which made its debut on the Internet, got off to a sluggish start in the network television ratings on Tuesday, drawing just 3.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series, from the creators of “My So-Called Life” and “Thirtysomething,” Marshall Herskovitz and Edward Zwick, finished third in the 10 p.m. time slot behind CBS’s “Jericho” (6.9 million) and ABC’s “Primetime” (7.6 million). NBC ranked third for the night over all in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, thanks to a solid showing for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10 (8.1 million). Fox dominated the night’s ratings with “American Idol” at 8 (28.5 million), followed by “Back to You,” which earned a series-high 12.3 million viewers at 9:30. CBS was runner-up in total viewers for the night but third in the 18-to-49 set. ABC finished fourth.

A lawyer for Amy Winehouse has asked a court in Norway to postpone a hearing on Friday related to her arrest in October on a charge of drug possession in Bergen, The Associated Press reported. She and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were held overnight at the time and released after paying fines of $715 each. She later appealed, contending that the police made mistakes in handling the case, involving a quarter-ounce of marijuana. ... A lawyer for the singer Bobby Brown said a Brockton County District Court clerk magistrate in Massachusetts had found no probable cause to issue a criminal complaint against Mr. Brown, whom the police found in possession of a small amount of cocaine in December. Mr. Brown, formerly married to Whitney Houston, agreed to a year’s community service, and the lawyer said the matter would be struck from the docket if no problems involving Mr. Brown arise in the next year.

Jim Shepard has won the $20,000 Story Prize. This four-year-old award for short-story collections honors his 2007 volume, “Like You’d Understand Anyway” (Alfred A. Knopf). ... A federal judge in Los Angeles has postponed the wiretapping trial of the Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano and co-defendants until March 5 to give lawyers more time to prepare. ... The modest East Hollywood bungalow that was once the rented residence of the hard-drinking poet and novelist Charles Bukowski (1920-1994) has been designated a civic landmark by the Los Angeles City Council, The Associated Press reported.

Last week’s Billboard chart had some rare good news for the music industry, with sales bumps for Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock in the wake of their Grammy victories. But now it’s mostly back to the doldrums. Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal) is No. 1 for a third week with a respectable 105,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. From there the numbers plunge. Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J) is No. 2 with 53,000, and Ms. Winehouse’s “Back to Black” (Universal Republic) is right behind it with 52,000; the new “Kidz Bop 13” (Razor & Tie) sold 49,000 copies to reach No. 4, and the soundtrack for “Step Up 2 the Streets” (Atlantic) rose five spots to No. 5, though its 43,000 sales were slightly less than the week before. Chris Cagle’s “My Life’s Been a Country Song” (Capitol Nashville) opened at No. 9 with 37,000.

8 P.M. (21) THE FOUR-WINGED DINOSAUR In 2002 scientists discovered a superbly preserved fossil that reopened the debate over the origin of flight. With four wings, including one on each leg, and intricate feathers, the crow-sized creature -- called Microraptor -- was one of the smallest dinosaurs ever found and like nothing paleontologists had seen. This ''Nova'' episode travels to the Chinese stone quarry where the fossil was discovered and follows experts in paleontology, biomechanics, aerodynamics, animation and scientific reconstruction as they put a replica of the fossil through a test flight in a wind tunnel and debate the evolution of flight in birds. 8 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES Gordon Ramsay takes on his biggest project to date with an overhaul of the 200-seat Granary, which, after a recent $4 million rehab, is still losing $8,000 a week. The locals in rural Hampshire think the modern British cuisine is too fussy. It's Mr. Ramsay's job to bring the restaurant back down to earth.

SMOLLON--William E. The family of William E. Smollon announces with great sadness the passing of Bill on February 26, 2008. He retired from The New York Times Mailroom after 45 years and was a proud WWII and Korean War Army Veteran. Bill's life was devoted to family and friends and his Catholic Faith, the kind of life we all aspire to and few of us get to witness firsthand. Those who knew and loved him consider themselves lucky. He will be greatly missed by all. The love of his life and wife of almost 60 years, Mary, predeceased him by two years. Loving Father of William Jr., John, Mary Elizabeth, Francis, Richard (deceased), Ann, Catherine, James and 10 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Visitation Friday only: 2-4:30 and 7-9pm. New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, March 1, 2008, at 9:45am Church of St. Anne, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, Donations to Lewy Body Dementia Assn. P.O. Box 451429, Atlanta, Georgia 31145 or Good Shepherd Hospice, 528 Mineola Ave., Carle Place, NY 11514.

ROSENFELD--Alfredo Fritz (Freddy), of New York, born June 2, 1921 in Nuremberg died February 9, 2008 in Zurich. Alfredo is survived by his beloved wife of 48 years Ruth Jackson Rosenfeld, adoring daughter Raquel, family and friends. Alfredo spent his late teens and early adult years in Buenos Aires. After WWII, he returned to Europe, which was the beginning of a rich lifetime of travel and adventure. He was a distinguished antiquarian horologist who recently discovered the joy of collecting antique books. Alfredo was an outspoken, free spirited, magnanimous man. A lover of classical music and opera, he was on vacation in Budapest enjoying the season there just prior to his sudden illness and death. Alfredo lived a full, satisfying life and will be missed by all whose lives he touched.

Borough Park, Brooklyn, a family neighborhood where a lot of cooking is done, now has a high-end cookware shop called Kitchen Couture. Sara Leibowitz, the store's owner, was formerly a cookware buyer at a Lower East Side store. She has stocked her store with pots, pans and gadgets from well-known manufacturers like Le Creuset, Calphalon and Henckels, as well as lesser-known brands like Swiss Diamond. Kitchen Couture offers a free home-consultation service, in all five boroughs, to advise people about equipping a kitchen. There is no registry yet, but brides receive a 5 percent discount. Kitchen Couture, 5213 13th Avenue (52nd Street), Brooklyn, (718) 686-8200.MARIANNE ROHRLICH

RUBIN--Albert L., M.D. The Board of Directors of The Rogosin Institute deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Albert L. Rubin. Dr. Rubin was the first nephrologist in New York to provide kidney dialysis (1956) and renal transplantation (1963). To implement his comprehensive, integrative approach to kidney disease, he created The Rogosin Institute, an affiliate of the New York - Presbyterian Health care System, 25 years ago and had been The Institute's President and Chief Executive Officer since then. He provided the remarkable vision, leadership and compassion that are the heart of The Institute's clinical and research programs. The Rogosin Institute now provides comprehensive treatment of renal disease for thousands of patients. In addition to his work as a physician and teacher, Dr. Rubin had initiated and shepherded The Institute's major research programs in renal disease, diabetes, lipid disorders and cancer. From the beginning of his extraordinary career he had promoted bringing basic research to the bedside as rapidly as possible in order to improve patient care and quality of life. His extraordinary vitality, enthusiasm and wisdom have nurtured The Rogosin Institute and enriched all those who have worked with him. He will be deeply missed. RUBIN--Albert L., M.D., a physician, researcher and executive of Englewood, NJ, died peacefully at home on February 23. He founded and led The Rogosin Institute, affiliated with New York-Presbyterian Hospital, from its inception in 1983 to his death, building The Institute into a world renowned treatment and research organization specializing in kidney disease. Born May 9, 1927, he attended Williams College from 1944 to 1945 and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He received his medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950. In 1957, he and his team performed the first hemodialysis for the treatment of kidney failure in the New York metropolitan area. In 1962, the unit became known as the Renal Laboratory located at the Cornell Division at Bellevue Hospital before moving to The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where it expanded to the Rogosin Renal Laboratories and to The Rogosin Institute in 1983. A true visionary, he pioneered the advancement of the treatment of kidney disease and spearheaded promising research and treatment programs in lipid disorders, diabetes and cancer. He was a talented physician and researcher who not only foresaw the future of medicine and the true purpose of research, but understood that collaboration and cooperation among institutions and organizations was necessary in order to bring developments to patients as quickly as possible. He will be remembered by many as a talented leader and inspirational mentor. He married Carolyn Diehl, M.D., in 1953, who preceded him in death by 20 months. He is survived by son Marc Rubin, M.D., his wife, Jennifer and three grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Rogosin Institute, 505 E. 70th Street, New York, NY 10021. A private service will be held Saturday, March 1. Family and friends are invited to the home of Marc and Jennifer Rubin, 130 Walnut St., Englewood, on March 1 from 3 to 6 pm. RUBIN--Albert L. M.D. The Medical Staff and Employees of The Rogosin Institute mourn the passing of its founder and leader, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., who served as Director of The Institute from its founding until his death on February 23, 2008. We came to know him as a compassionate physician, accomplished scientist, wise teacher, and friend to us all. His vision and leadership created an Institute of which we are all extremely proud. The combination of the very best in patient care and innovative research programs to make that care even better was central to that vision. He made The Institute an exciting place to work, and we are glad to be part of it. We will miss Dr. Rubin deeply, but count on his example and inspiration to help us continue and expand the work of The Institute so that we can help many thousands more patients in the years to come. We share his dream of ending kidney disease as we now know it. We believe that his dream is one that can be realized, and we plan to work hard to achieve that. We cannot think of a better way to honor his memory.

When she was 25, Alexandra Von Furstenberg helped revive the 70s-era classic wrap dress, along with her mother-in-law Diane's faded brand. Ten years later, mass labels like Banana Republic are pushing their own versions of the dress, while Ms. Von Furstenberg, the youngest of the oft-photographed heiresses known as the Miller sisters, is hoping to sell far less accessible objects. Ms. Von Furstenberg, left, who is now single and living in Los Angeles with her two children, is making sculptural high-gloss plastic tables that are injected with neon colors and named after diamonds (and priced like diamonds, too).

SINGH--Elizabeth Yeh. It is with great sadness and nearly unbearable grief that the family of Elizabeth Yeh Singh, 41, shares the news of her passing on February 25, 2008. A talented, accomplished, intelligent woman, Liz's singular personality brought joy to all who knew her. Born in New York City, she was raised in Miami, Florida, where she found and nurtured her first great passion, the piano. A New Yorker at heart, she always seemed to find her way back to the Big Apple. After graduating from Barnard College in 1988 with a degree in political science, Liz, who loved travel, circled the globe as a successful journalist. Starting out as a news writer in Miami and local on-camera reporter in Tallahassee, Florida, she doggedly worked her way up the ranks, eventually landing positions in Hong Kong and Singapore as an anchor for Asia Business News and in New York as a producer for CNNfn. In her mid-30s, Liz decided to shake things up and pursue yet another lifelong love, cooking. She co-wrote The Great Big Burger Book and took immense pleasure in showering family and friends with her culinary delights. Her great pride were the elaborate birthday cakes she lovingly created for her daughter Maya's birthday parties. Since 2006, Elizabeth has proudly served on the Board of Trustees of her alma mater, Barnard College. Elizabeth is survived by her husband Ravi, their adored daughter Maya, her parents Dr. Billy and Lydia Yeh, her brothers Brian and William, sisters-in-law Alicia and Gaylan, niece Sabrina, nephew William, and countless cherished friends. On Saturday, March 1, a viewing will be held from 9-11am, followed by a memorial celebration of her life at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, 10028. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the family in the name of: The Elizabeth Yeh Singh Foundation.

Horigan Urban Forest Products in Skokie, Ill., sells a variety of hardwoods, including black alder, silver maple and elm from trees in and around Chicago downed by storms, disease or construction. The company was founded in 2003 by Erika and Bruce Horigan, below, who were horrified to see trees going into wood chippers. They now have so much inventory that they recently expanded into a 4,200-square-foot warehouse. Prices are competitive with other hardwood sources (one-inch-thick quartersawn white oak, for example, is $5.50 a board foot), and the wood comes tagged with notes like ''Hackberry planted in Washington Park by Frederick Law Olmsted in 1873.'' ''One of the coolest things about my job is keeping the trees' stories alive,'' Mr. Horigan said. Information: (847) 568-1340 or horiganufp.com. LISA CREGAN

SCHOENFELD--Norman, 70, of White Plains, New York, passed away on February 27th in White Plains Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Schoenfeld was the loving husband of Michele (Buchholz) Schoenfeld; devoted father of Steven (Susan) Schoenfeld of Towson, MD, and Susie (Michael) Welling, of Port Chester; adoring grandfather of Jacob Schoenfeld and Matthew Welling; and beloved brother of Lester Schoenfeld (Linda) of Purchase, NY. Mr. Schoenfeld was born in Brooklyn, NY, to Edward and Alice (Forgosh) Schoenfeld and the family later moved to Haverhill, MA, where he attended Haverhill High School. A graduate of Clark University and a C.P.A., he began his career with Clarence Rainess & Company and later left public accounting to become Controller and Chief Financial Officer of several companies. He was a member of Willow Ridge Country Club, where he was a former member of the Board of Governors and a member of the Golf Committee, and belonged to Congregation Kol Ami where he had been a member of the Finance Committee. Services are Friday, February 29th, at 12 Noon at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains.

A kidnapped American aid worker and her Afghan driver are believed to be dead, the aid group, the Asian Rural Life Development Foundation, said on its Web site. Cyd Mizell, left, 50, a native of Eureka, Calif., who taught English, and Muhammad Hadi, a resident of Kandahar, were abducted in Kandahar on Jan. 26. While there has been no official confirmation ''we have received information through two police sources that they had been killed,'' said Micah Berry, the organization's financial administrator.

PEARSON--Marge. It is with the deepest sadness that we mourn the loss of our dear friend and former colleague, Marge Pearson, who passed away after an extraordinary and valiant battle with cancer. Marge served with distinction for many years as a member of our sales management team. Her early leadership helped to provide the foundation for the success and strength of our rental division today. Marge's many years of community service were recognized in 2002 by her receiving the coveted Henry Forster Memorial Award from the Real Estate Board of New York. We join together in mourning Marge's memory as a leader who was a soft spoken, compassionate, caring and sensitive human being. Our condolences go out to Marge's family who was always her guiding light. In Loving Memory, From Your Friends At Prudential Douglas Elliman Real Estate.

TANNENBAUM--Fannie. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital extends their deepest sympathies to trustee Michael Tannenbaum and his family on the passing of their beloved mother Fannie. Michael is a valued trustee and a strong advocate for providing compassionate care, dignity and respect to older adults. We hope the loving memories the family shares will comfort them during their time of loss. Gene D. Resnick, M.D. Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

Spring is in the air! All right, it's not. But springlike shoes are! Or rather, they're on your feet. Well, perhaps they will be, if you follow Karin Nelson's advice toward ''a pair of eye-popping shoes, worn with thick tights.'' If you don't have the budget for Christian Louboutin's yellow zipper sandals, try your luck at the Intermixwarehouse sale, starting today at the Metropolitan Pavilion, where you'll find shoes by designers like Stella McCartney, Chloé and Michael Kors at up to 70 percent off. O'CONNELL--John Joseph. Born Chicago, IL, February 24, 1918, died February 25, 2008. Loving husband of Loretta Jelinski (died 1954) and Margaret Kazarian (died 1999). Beloved father of John, Paula, Ruth, James and the late Dr. Alyce O'Connell Adler (died 2001). Veteran of WWII (USCG, 1942-1945). Teacher (NYC Board of Education, 1947-1991). Reposing at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, NY. Funeral mass Monday, 9:45am, Saint Sebastian R.C. Church, Woodside, NY. Interment at Cedar Grove Cemetery, Queens, NY. Visiting Sunday, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm.

With the help of students from P.S. 307, Tattfoo Tan, a Malaysian-born artist, has installed a mural on Front Street in Brooklyn, left, based on his ''Nature Matching System'' place mat, far left. The place mat was inspired by a visit to the Union Square Greenmarket. Mr. Tan photographed his purchases and, using Photoshop, created a grid of squares in colors that corresponded to particular foods. ''Marketers package food colorfully because color attracts people,'' said Mr. Tan, whose work often reflects the cultural importance of food. ''I wanted to create a visually tempting way to view the intangibility of nutrition.'' Like the place mat, the mural, made of 10-inch wood squares painted by the students, is a reminder to eat a kaleidoscope of fruits and vegetables, he said. The place mat is available free at Foragers Market, 56 Adams Street, Brooklyn, and tattfoo.com; the mural will be on view on Front Street between Adams and Pearl Streets in Dumbo through January 2009. HALEY THURSHWELL

GANNES--Warren A, on February 26, 2008. Loving son of the late Gerrie and Maurice. Loving father of Seth Crosby. Dear brother of Robin Gannes. Services today 1:30 pm. Graveside at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

FITZMAURICE--Mary, February 20, 2008. Mary Fitzmaurice of Westbury, NY. Funeral service Saturday, March 1, 2008, at 11:30am at Peck & Peck Funeral Home, Copake, NY. Further information is available at: peckandpeck.net.

BODNER--Philip, age 90, on February 24, 2008. Loving husband of Judith and the late Harriet. Devoted father of Mark and Beth, Neal and Pam. Adoring grandfather of Josh, Adam, Matthew, Justin, Danielle and Hannah. The musicians' musician, master of 12 woodwind instruments. Virtuoso to the stars including Sinatra, Fitzgerald, Torme, and many others. Prolific and sought-after NYC studio musician, jazz band leader, NARAS Musician of the Year awards recipient, record producer, composer, and publisher. His legacy lives on in thousands of recordings, movie soundtracks, and jingle advertisements. Service and interment Thursday, 1:30pm, Westchester Hills Cemetery.

IRVIN--George Richard, 81, on February 26, 2008 of Quogue, NY, and North Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Garden City, NY, after a courageous battle with Alzheimer's. Beloved husband of Barbara; devoted father of Barbara Mary Irvin Barnet of Garden City, NY, and Cynthia Irvin DiLonardo of Manhasset, NY; loving father-in-law of Michael DiLonardo; loving grandfather to Alexander, Christopher, Tyler and Brittany Barnet and Brynn and Chase DiLonardo. In 2005 his grandsons Alex and Christopher Barnet started ''For the Love of George'', a national non-profit organization for Alzheimer's. The family will receive visitors on Thursday, February 28, from 2-4 and 7-9 and Friday, February 29, from 3-5 at the Fairchild Funeral Home on Franklin Avenue in Garden City. Funeral mass Friday, February 29, 5:30pm at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in George's memory be made to ''For the Love of George'' at: Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 8th Ave, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10001.

SPRINGER--Gerard K. Beloved husband of Sylvia, cherished father of Tracy and Susan, adored grandfather of Ian, Nina and Lila. Passed away February 27, 2008. He will be greatly missed and always remembered for his love and devotion, fun-loving spirit, warmth and humor. Jerry was raised in New York City, lived most of his life in New Rochelle, New York and retired to McLean, Virginia. As an owner of Springer-Penguin, Inc., an office furniture and compact refrigerator manufacturer in Mount Vernon, New York, he was a leader and innovator in the fields of modern office furniture and refrigerator design and engineering. In his younger days, he was an active volunteer in Big Brothers of Westchester County. Service and interment Friday at 11 am at Mt. Eden Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York. In honor of his memory, donations may be made to Big Brothers and Big Sisters through Family Service of Westchester.

Updated, 9:40 p.m. | Even the most seasoned subway and bus riders might be a bit confused by some aspects of the fare increases that take effect at 12:01 a.m. Sunday. Passengers who buy regular pay-per-ride MetroCards will start to see odd amounts left over on their cards. Those who buy MetroCards at supermarkets and newsstands will find themselves paying amounts like $17.39 and $52.17. And New Yorkers who want to hoard unlimited-ride MetroCards at the present cost should beware: the M.T.A. won’t say how long the cards will be honored.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have finally put the kibosh on running for president this year, but that does not mean the independent stalwarts are giving up their dreams of electing a third-party president. Frank MacKay of the Independence Party of New York said on Thursday that Mr. Bloomberg’s decision not to run for president was “certainly disappointing” but not so much that anyone had been told “to keep me away from sharp objects or anything like that.”Indeed, he is already moving on, talking with other potential candidates to carry the torch now that Mr. Bloomberg won’t.

Updated, March 1 | Two female workers, ages 24 and 27, were stabbed — one fatally — inside a Key Food grocery store on the Lower East Side this afternoon, by a man who then fled and is still at large, the police said. The suspect, later identified as James Gonzalez, 42, ran from the store after the attack and apparently dropped the knife outside, near Avenue A and East Fourth Street, the police said. The 24-year-old, later identified as Tina Negron, was stabbed in the torso. At 5:45 p.m. she was confirmed to have died from her injuries at Beth Israel Hospital, where both women were taken for treatment.

"Tootsie" came out in 1982, when most Americans assumed that if you didn't catch a movie while it was playing in theaters, you might never see it. Moviegoers were largely ignoring the climactic developments in home-entertainment technology - including the so-called format war between Betamax and VHS - that would, in the coming decades, transform not just movie watching but also home design and romantic relationships. The best format for audiovisual data storage was still considered to be the human memory.

I love to think of this play as super-American, and that "American" is, as Jeff put it, "a big stew of meat and potatoes confrontations," and a brainy one at that. But "August" is not brainy to the degree of preachiness or wrought with heavy literary earnestness. It is not at all condescending, and - though I know America is so often perceived as haughty and arrogant - it is this America, this mix of high and low, as Frank points out, and this humor that's loaded with so much humanity, that I like to think of as ours. That the play is breaking rules that I haven't even considered, as Marsha so fascinatingly explained, is all the more reason to call it American to its core.

A new development rising on the shores of north Jakarta takes the nautical theme to a new extreme. Each of the 24-story towers in Regatta Jakarta is designed to resemble a tall ship, with wide "sails" and tall masts.

Our guest blogger of the week:
Two of the biggest trade deadline pickups played their first games with their new teams Thursday.
Three women converge on the road to self-awareness in “Vivere,” a moody drama from the German director Angelina Maccarone.
“The Unforeseen” explores the rights of man, the death of nature, the water below, the air above and all that going, going, gone green in between.
Like many of Will Ferrell’s recent films, “Semi-Pro” finds the sweet spot between sports melodrama and parody, and hammers it for 90 diverting minutes.
“Cinderella” meets “The Ugly Duckling” in “Penelope,” a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.
“City of Men” is a rootin’-tootin’ gangster movie shot in the notoriously lawless shantytowns overlooking the beaches of Rio de Janeiro.
The picture of Iceland that emerges in Baltasar Kormákur’s “Jar City” is vivid and powerful but not something the country’s tourist board would be likely to endorse.
It’s a free world, Ken Loach asserts in his latest film with well-practiced disgust and unfortunately little hope.
“Chicago 10,” Brett Morgen’s semi-animated, semi-documentary attempt to make the ’60s cool for a new generation of kids, does the opposite.
Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in “Little Chenier,” a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land.
Except for Jessica Lange’s silent, expressive close-ups, the women’s journey in “Bonneville” is aesthetically and dramatically unremarkable.
More slog than romp, “The Other Boleyn Girl” tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII.
This documentary feature follows 9/11 widows from suburban Boston, as they try to raise money to help war widows in Afghanistan.
Warren Buffett’s holding company said quarterly profit fell by 18 percent, hurt by lower earnings from insurance underwriting and a decrease in investment gains.
Faced with the loss of patent protection for its antidepressant Effexor XR, Wyeth received federal approval for a follow-on drug, Pristiq, that the company hopes will also become a blockbuster.
Four crucial witnesses will testify at the racketeering trial beginning next week for Anthony Pellicano, the infamous Hollywood private eye.
In a surprising reversal for the Boeing Company, the Pentagon awarded a multibillion-dollar contract to Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus.
G.M. said a strike at American Axle and Manufacturing has forced it to halt production at four of its five pickup plants and Chrysler idled an Ontario plant because of a supplier strike.
The man was staying in a motel where a powder that officials confirmed was ricin, a deadly poison, was found.
The Dow Jones industrials closed down more than 300 points after weak economic data reignited fears of an imminent recession.
Rising prices are forcing Americans to spend more and save less, even as income growth slows, reports showed.
Prince Harry’s previously secret tour of duty ended abruptly after reports on his presence in Afghanistan.
Iraqi leaders found a way out of a legal dilemma that had slowed the approval of Ali Hassan al-Majid’s execution.

The Philadelphia Eagles have released defensive end Jevon Kearse after four mostly disappointing and injury-plagued seasons. The Eagles signed him to a $66 million deal in 2004 that at the time made him the highest-paid defensive end in N.F.L. history. He ended up being benched last season.
The Bolivian Congress, in a vote boycotted by the opposition, approved holding a referendum on May 4 on a draft constitution.
Industry analysts say it has become more important than ever to understand the psyche of consumers.
Devin Harris came back for the first time since a sprained ankle in January to spur the Nets to victory with 21 points and 5 assists in 20 minutes of play.
The F.B.I. announced Thursday that it had opened a criminal investigation into whether Roger Clemens lied under oath.
The Rangers’ newfound attention to details in paying off with a string of victories. It was their third in a row and their sixth in eight games.
The Universal Music Group, the world’s biggest music conglomerate reached a deal to acquire the recorded music and music publishing assets of Univision.
David Padgett helped Louisville bring some order to the top of the Big East standings.
Trent Hunter scored off a face-off in overtime and the Islanders recovered after blowing a three-goal lead to beat the slumping Thrashers, 5-4, Thursday night in Atlanta.
Duke Crews seemed healthy until a health screenings administered to all Tennessee athletes found he had a condition blamed for the sudden death of more than a hundred athletes each year.

he government warned owners of about 4.6 million recalled Ford vehicles to bring their cars and trucks immediately to dealerships to disconnect cruise control switch systems that have been linked to engine fires.
The state sued the federal Forest Service for adopting a management plan that would allow for the construction of roads and oil drilling in California’s largest national forests.

The House ethics committee said it was beginning an investigation into the conduct of Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, who was indicted a week ago on conspiracy, extortion and other charges.

Two American families have been notified that they can bring home their adopted Vietnamese babies, who initially had been denied United States entry visas over concerns they were not actually orphaned.
Missouri and Illinois agreed to build a new Mississippi River bridge.

An article in some editions last Friday about a proposal for a waterfront park near the United Nations building in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the status of a request to Sheldon Solow, the owner of an adjacent site, for an easement allowing access to the park property. Although a member of a local community board said Mr. Solow “hadn’t said anything yet” about granting the easement, Mr. Solow’s company, East River Realty, said it had in fact responded to the request. In an e-mail statement issued the day that officials announced the proposal at a news conference, the company said, “We will certainly consider creating an easement.”.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a television station in Huntsville, Ala., that showed a black screen for 12 minutes on Sunday night during a “60 Minutes” report about possible political deception involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of Alabama referred incorrectly to one of the owners of the station. Robert M. Bass, manager of an investment company that bought the station, WHNT, last year, has been a contributor to Democratic Party candidates, but unlike his brothers in Texas, he has not been a contributor to President Bush. An editorial on Wednesday about WHNT going dark repeated the error. An article about an internal review of the incident by the Huntsville station is on Page C4 today.

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Brad Guzan, a promising goalkeeper for the United States national team who was close to joining an English Premier League club, referred imprecisely to a requirement for a British work permit that Guzan failed to meet. He needed to have played in at least 75 percent of his national team’s official matches in the previous two years, not one year.

An art review in Weekend last Friday about “Parmigianino’s ‘Antea’: A Beautiful Artifice,” at the Frick Collection, misidentified the arm of the painting’s subject that “looks illogically long” and has a gloved hand. It is her right arm, not the left.

An article on Monday about Ralph Nader’s announcement that he is again running for president misstated the percentage of votes Mr. Nader received nationwide in the 2004 presidential election. He won 0.38 percent of the vote, not 0.3 percent. The article also misstated the reason that Mr. Nader was not on the ballot in California in 2004. It was because he did not gather enough signatures, not because of lawsuits and challenges filed by the Democratic Party.

An article on Monday about Ralph Nader’s announcement that he is again running for president misstated the percentage of votes Mr. Nader received nationwide in the 2004 presidential election. He won 0.38 percent of the vote, not 0.3 percent. The article also misstated the reason that Mr. Nader was not on the ballot in California in 2004. It was because he did not gather enough signatures, not because of lawsuits and challenges filed by the Democratic Party.

A report in the Sports Briefing column on Thursday about the announcement that Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot will race in the Boston Marathon in April misstated the number of times the event has been held. This will be the 112th running, not the 111th.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the growing use of wind power in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount of money that Louis Brooks is paid for allowing 78 wind turbines on his ranch on the outskirts of Sweetwater, Tex. It is $500 a month for each, not $500 for all of them. The article also misstated the length of blades for new wind turbines that stand as high as 20-story buildings. The blades span about 200 feet; they are not “longer than a football field,” which is 300 feet.

An article on Feb. 13 about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, misstated the circumstances of his office’s prosecution in 2002 of James Treffinger, then the Essex County executive. Mr. Treffinger was seized by armed F.B.I. agents, but not at gunpoint. The article also misspelled the surname of a former prosecutor in Mr. Christie’s office who said partisan politics did not play a role in whom the office investigated. He is Scott Resnik, not Resnick.

An article in some editions last Friday about the painstaking removal of the stained-glass window at American Airlines’ vacant Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport misstated the given name of a flight attendant who was taking pictures of the terminal. He is Jeff Lonsinger, not Ken. (Ken is his brother, who was with him at the time.).

Alex Smith got a vote of confidence from San Francisco. The 49ers exercised a multimillion-dollar buyback clause in Smith’s contract that essentially extends his deal through 2010. General Manager Scot McCloughan said the overall deal was similar to one made last season by the Giants, who bought back two voidable years in Eli Manning’s contract for a reported $5 million.

Luke Donald’s opening round in the Honda Classic on Thursday was far from perfect. He missed five greens and seven fairways, including five straight. And conditions at windy, cool PGA National in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., were hardly optimal for scoring. Yet somehow, Donald found a way to post the event’s best score in three years. A bogey-free 64 gave Donald a one-shot lead over Brian Davis and a two-shot edge on Matt Jones after the first round of the Honda.

Mixed martial arts will be broadcast on one of the major television networks for the first time. CBS announced a deal with ProElite, which produces mixed martial arts events, to broadcast in prime time two-hour live specials four times a year on Saturday nights. Douglas DeLuca, the chief executive of ProElite, called it a “pivotal moment for the sport.”.

Major League Soccer officials announced plans for a new team in the Philadelphia area that will hold its inaugural season in 2010, ending a three-decade hiatus for outdoor professional soccer in the region. Previously home to two men’s soccer franchises in the 1970s, Philadelphia had been the largest city in North America without an M.L.S. team. The team will be carry Philadelphia’s name, but the stadium will be located in Chester, Pa., southwest of Philadelphia.

Top-ranked Lorena Ochoa got off to a fast start in her first round of the season, shooting a bogey-free six-under 66 at Tanah Merah in Singapore to take a one-stroke lead in the HSBC Women’s Champions.

After two months of reviewing videos second by second, Honolulu Marathon Association officials are giving up on getting precise results from the race. Officials said nearly 2,000 finishers were left out of the results and less than 8 percent of the nearly 23,000 finishers were timed correctly.

For the second time in three years, the St. Louis Rams released wide receiver Isaac Bruce, the last player remaining from the team’s 1995 move from Los Angeles. Bruce, 35, had been due a $2 million roster bonus Friday, and the Rams were unsuccessful in attempts to restructure his contract. Bruce is third on the N.F.L. career list with 14,070 yards receiving.

Derek Anderson, the 24-year-old Cleveland quarterback who stepped in as the starter after the first game and led the Browns to a 10-6 record last season, was tendered a one-year offer for $2.5 million. But Browns General Manager Phil Savage said that if Anderson receives a better offer, Cleveland would probably not match it.
Against a team that has a new look and new marquee player, the San Antonio Spurs kept up their winning ways Thursday by sticking to basics — namely, their own franchise player.
The pool is in a $66.3 million recreation building that was planned under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and was revived by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
