Amy Winehouse, above left, doesn’t have to worry about a hearing on drug-possession charges in Norway as long as her husband stays in a British jail. That was the essence of a court ruling on Thursday in Bergen, Norway, where the Grammy-winning Ms. Winehouse was scheduled to appear on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. “One of the people involved in the case, Blake Fielder-Civil, Amy Winehouse’s husband, is currently in jail in Britain and can’t make the trip,” said Anne Vedvik of the Bergen court. “The hearing has therefore been postponed to an undetermined date.” Ms. Winehouse, 24, her husband and her hairdresser were arrested in Bergen in October and charged with possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana. Ms. Winehouse was released after paying a $756 fine, which she later contested. Agreeing to a fine in Norway is equivalent to admitting the charges, which could make it difficult for Ms. Winehouse to obtain visas. Mr. Fielder-Civil has been in custody since November, awaiting trial on charges of assault and conspiracy to pervert the cause of justice. He is accused of trying to bribe a barman not to testify against him in an assault case. ... Boy George, above right, denied on Thursday that he imprisoned a 28-year-old Norwegian man at his London home last year, The Associated Press reported. Appearing in a London court under his real name, George O’Dowd, he pleaded not guilty to a charge of false imprisonment lodged by Audun Carlsen, who claimed that he was handcuffed to a wall after he went to Boy George’s apartment in April as a photo model. Boy George, 46, is free on bail and is to stand trial in November.

Back home in Thailand from a 17-month voluntary exile after his ouster in a military coup, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra began his new life as a criminal defendant. After a big welcome from cheering supporters at the international airport in Bangkok, police officers escorted him directly to the Supreme Court, where he faces charges of corruption. He was freed on bail, and a trial was set for March 12. ''I don't want to be involved in politics any longer,'' Mr. Thaksin, a billionaire, said after his arrival. ''I want to live peacefully with my family and die in this motherland.'' After the 2006 coup, he was barred from politics for five years. But he has already been active behind the scenes in the formation of the recently elected government that is packed with his supporters, and on Thursday a government minister said Mr. Thaksin would serve as an economic adviser.

In a coordinated operation, the Swedish and Norwegian security services arrested six people on suspicion of financing or otherwise taking part in terrorist activity. News reports described the suspects as being of Somali heritage and living in or around Stockholm and Oslo. In Oslo, search warrants were served on two Internet cafes, and officers were seen carrying out computer equipment. The three suspects arrested in Stockholm, whom the authorities said were Swedish, were accused not only of taking part in terrorism-related financial activity but also of ''preparations for committing terrorist crimes,'' said Jakob Larsson, the spokesman for the Swedish Security Service.

GALLAGHER--Lacey Wingham, 45, of New York, New York, beloved wife, daughter, sister, aunt and niece, died on February 27, 2008. Lacey departed this earth peacefully at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a three year battle with ovarian cancer surrounded by her family and a close friend. Lacey was born on June 28, 1962 in New York to Trudi and Hugh Gallagher. Lacey grew up on the east coast and abroad, most notably in Hong Kong and the Philippines. She graduated from Wellesley College and Princeton University's prestigious Woodrow Wilson School and had a distinguished career as an emerging markets economist, most recently as a Managing Director at Credit Suisse. She was also a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. Lacey loved travel, people and all things beautiful. She radiated joy to all who knew her. Lacey is survived by her husband, Mark Carlebach of New York City; parents Trudi and Hugh Gallagher of Armonk, NY; brother Keith Gallagher, niece and nephew Jessica and Matthew Gallagher of Scottsdale, AZ; uncle Roman Weber of Geneva, Switzerland; and minischnauzer, Trixie -all of whom loved her and felt loved by her. Family will receive friends on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Monday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (www. ocrf.org) or The Ovarian Cancer National Alliance (www.ovariancancer.org) in the name of Lacey Wingham Gallagher.

WINTER REP 2008 While a season of plays presented in rotating repertory is common practice in summer stock, it is not the norm in the Off Off Broadway world. But the Oberon Theater Ensemble, now in its 11th season, has been presenting shows this way for a few years, and its current offerings include ''Macbeth,'' with James Holloway, above left, and William Laney, and Michael Weller's ''Ghost on Fire.'' ''The two plays, if you have to boil it down to one word, are about ambition,'' said Brad Fryman, Oberon's artistic director. ''Macbeth's ambition comes from an unnatural place, and 'Ghost on Fire' is about these young people who entered the professional world and thought they could change it through film.'' The three central characters in Mr. Weller's 1985 play had grand plans when they were documentary filmmakers in college, but haven't reached their goals 15 years later. In comparison, it is not much of a stretch to guess that Shakespeare's Scottish Thane was once an idealistic young man too, before his motives darkened.

WRIGHT--Alan Harriman, 79, of Muttontown, NY, died peacefully at home early Monday morning February 25. Born in NYC on August 5, 1928 to Boykin Cabell Wright and Miriam Harriman, Alan is survived by his children, Melita, Glenn and Philip, seven grandchildren and his identical twin Boyd. He graduated from the Buckley School 1943, St. Paul's 1947, Princeton 1951 and Harvard Law 1954. In 1956, he joined the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, where he was admitted as partner in 1969. His principal client over the years was Citigroup specializing in the leasing of commercial aircraft. He is credited with a number of innovations to facilitate the purchases of airline equipment and retired in 1993. Alan served in the US Army 1954-1956 and later as Village Justice for the Village of Muttontown and as a Vestryman of Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, NY. The family is having an informal Memorial Service at 1100 Avalon Square, Glen Cove, NY, Tuesday March 4, 12-3. (avalonglencovenorth.com). In lieu of flowers, we request that donations be made to your local animal shelter.

KEELY GARFIELD At a recent rehearsal for her latest dance, ''Limerence,'' Keely Garfield recounted a conversation with her fellow choreographer Reggie Wilson about how unnerving it is to make and perform her emotionally intense works. ''Why don't you make a happy dance?'' Mr. Wilson asked, and then the good friends dissolved into giggles. ''I still have really high expectations that I'll make a happy dance one day,'' Ms. Garfield says. ''Limerence,'' a duet for her and Omagbitse Omagbemi, is not that dance, though this dark, prayerful meditation on affairs of the heart is shot through with her subtly mordant wit. Both women are fluid, smart movers, and Ms. Garfield is capable of producing tautly structured dances. Yet what captivates here is the awkward, uncomfortable space these dancers inhabit as they alternately minister to and grapple with each other. Ms. Garfield, left, gives her ideas a lot of space, and much of the action takes place in the loaded gazes the two level at each other; thankfully, the West End Theater is small, so viewers can get a close look.

KRAICHNAN--Robert H., died on February 26, 2008 at 5pm in Santa Fe, NM. He was 80 years old. Dr. Kraichnan was considered the father of modern fluid turbulence theory. He made basic contributions that dealt with the nonlinearity of turbulence and the construction of selfconsistent approximations. At the time of his death, Dr. Kraichnan was working on fundamental issues in quantum mechanics. Dr. Kraichnan received a Ph.D degree in theoretical physics from MIT in 1949. He was Albert Einstein's personal assistant 1949-1950. Later, he worked as a research scientist at Columbia and New York Universities. From 1962 until his death, Dr. Kraichnan was self-employed. He received prime grants from several Government agencies and served as consultant to a number of organizations. He was Homewood Professor in the Mechanical Engineering Dept of John Hopkins University from 2003 until his death. Dr. Kraichnan is survived by his wife, artist and photographer Judy Moore-Kraichnan, and by his former wife Carol Gebhardt, their son John Kraichnan, and granddaughter Sasha Kraichnan. Dr. Kraichnan was a member of the National Academy of Sciences. He received the Dirac Medal of the International Center for Theoretical Physics, the Lars Onsager Prize of the American Physical Society, the Adion Medal of l'Observatoire de Nice, and other awards.

'YEAR OF THE RAT' Kim Jones's war-torn, fluently hybrid art is more germane than ever, as proved by his latest exhibition at Pierogi. His primary theme, directly or indirectly, is war and its toxic effects, a subject inspired partly by his experiences as a marine in Vietnam. Mr. Jones erupted on the Los Angeles performance-art scene in the mid-1970s in the persona of Mudman, a shaman-warrior-penitent covered in mud and harnessed with a bristling mass of sticks. In the first room several stick apparatuses hang far apart on the walls, part forbidding traps, part power figures. Wavy-lined wall drawings flow between them like currents of attract-repel energy. Their dates reflect Mr. Jones's tendency to mend, resurface and refresh continually. The much-painted ''Rat Dog'' (1973-1980-1986-1998-2008), above, is at once a headdress, an effigy and a figure in a prison stock; it belongs to a rodent art tradition stretching from Disney's Mickey Mouse to Art Spiegelman's Maus.

THORNER--Dr. Gerald Charles, born on December 6th, 1922 in Brooklyn, New York passed away February, 26, 2008. After early graduation from Brooklyn College he volunteered to served in World War II as an Officer for the USAAF 20th Air Force Pacific Theater, Tinian. His B-29 and crew flew 17 missions. After his Honorable Discharge, he received his degree in Optometry from Columbia University, and established a practice of 35 year duration in Bay Ridge Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Thorner retired to Naples in 1988 and has been an active citizen of our city. He was the son of the late Isadore and Frances Thorner and was predeceased by his brother, Marvin and sister, Irene. He is deeply mourned by his wife of 55 years, Fritzi Kohlhagen Thorner, son Marc, daughter, Heidi, and her husband Dr Gary Layton as well as his sister-in-law Evelyn and three loving nieces and two nephews. Funeral services will be held at Naples Memorial Funeral Home on Friday, February 29, at 10:00am with Rabbi Brad Bloom officiating. Interment will follow at Naples Memorial Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at the family home on Friday, February 29, Saturday evening March 1 and Sunday March 2. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Parkinson's Association of South West Florida, Naples Memorial Funeral Home 239597-3101.

SINGH--Elizabeth Yeh. It is with great sadness and nearly unbearable grief that the family of Elizabeth Yeh Singh, 41, shares the news of her passing on February 25, 2008. A talented, accomplished, intelligent woman, Liz's singular personality brought joy to all who knew her. Born in New York City, she was raised in Miami, Florida, where she found and nurtured her first great passion, the piano. A New Yorker at heart, she always seemed to find her way back to the Big Apple. After graduating from Barnard College in 1988 with a degree in political science, Liz, who loved travel, circled the globe as a successful journalist. Starting out as a news writer in Miami and local on-camera reporter in Tallahassee, Florida, she doggedly worked her way up the ranks, eventually landing positions in Hong Kong and Singapore as an anchor for Asia Business News and in New York as a producer for CNNfn. In her mid-30s, Liz decided to shake things up and pursue yet another lifelong love, cooking. She co-wrote The Great Big Burger Book and took immense pleasure in showering family and friends with her culinary delights. Her great pride were the elaborate birthday cakes she lovingly created for her daughter Maya's birthday parties. Since 2006, Elizabeth has proudly served on the Board of Trustees of her alma mater, Barnard College. Elizabeth is survived by her husband Ravi, their adored daughter Maya, her parents Dr. Billy and Lydia Yeh, her brothers Brian and William, sisters-in-law Alicia and Gaylan, niece Sabrina, nephew William, and countless cherished friends. On Saturday, March 1, a viewing will be held from 9-11am, followed by a memorial celebration of her life at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, 10028. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the family in the name of: The Elizabeth Yeh Singh Foundation. SINGH--Elizabeth Yeh. The entire Barnard College community is deeply saddened by the death of our treasured trustee Elizabeth Yeh Singh. Ever curious, vibrant, and in love with New York, Liz graduated from Barnard in 1988 and returned to serve as a member of its Board of Trustees in 2006. She was an active and energetic member of several committees and took great pleasure in her position as chair of the committee on student life. Sincere condolences are offered to her husband Ravi, their adored daughter Maya, and her entire family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President

McLANE--Charles Bancroft, 88, on Saturday, February 23 in Hanover, NH. He was a retired Dartmouth government professor, specializing in Soviet-Third World Relations. Dartmouth B.A. (1941) and Columbia Ph.D. (1955). In retirement he co-authored, with his wife Carol Evarts McLane, volumes on the social and economic history of the Maine coast islands he and his wife deeply loved. He also published a novel, ''Red Right Returning'', in 2004. He was a competitive skier, captain of the Dartmouth College ski team in 1941, later the first volunteer for the US Army 10th Mountain Division Ski Troops. He was a cultural attache' at the US Embassy in Moscow for several years in the early 1950s. Survived by sisters Elisabeth McLaneBradley and Mary Craig McLane, six children and five grandchildren. Donations can be sent to Carol Evarts McLane and Charles B. McLane Fund for Island Education, Island Institute, PO Box 648, Rockland, Maine 04841.

ESPRESSO ENTHUSIASTS WORKSHOP A clock, a bathroom scale and a thermometer? I had signed up for a class on how to become a barista, but these were not the tools of the trade I expected. The session, held one Sunday a month in an industrial space in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, seemed like an enjoyable way to indulge my love of caffeine, and it started off promisingly: a sort of coffee klatsch with my fellow students as we drank rich espressos dashed off by our instructor, Rowan Tuckfield. His roasting company, Kitten Coffee, sells beans to restaurants and teaches professionals and civilians alike how to make a demitasse that's up to Italian standards.

SFJAZZ COLLECTIVE Transition has come again to the SFJAZZ Collective, an eight-piece band established in 2004 by the Bay Area arts organization SFJAZZ. For its first few years, the ensemble, which combines jazz repertory with original music by its members, had a clear public representative in the tenor saxophonist Joshua Redman. Then Mr. Redman bowed out of the band, with what seemed like a hint of relief. (His excellent Nonesuch album ''Back East,'' issued last year, gave the feeling of a big exhalation: Mr. Redman sounded appreciative to be making music with no larger responsibilities, projecting only himself.) Happily for everyone -- including Mr. Redman, who still serves as artistic director of the SFJAZZ spring season -- the collective has continued to thrive. The tenor saxophone chair now belongs to Joe Lovano, a worthy replacement with the proper perspective on jazz tradition and innovation. (In brief: a balance of each is best.) The band includes (from left, above) the vibraphonist Stefon Harris, the alto saxophonist Miguel Zenón, Mr. Lovano, the trombonist Robin Eubanks, the bassist Matt Penman, the trumpeter Dave Douglas, the pianist Renee Rosnes and the drummer Eric Harland. All together this crew represents not just a slate of improvisational all-stars but also a contemporary composers' club.

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE DEATH OF MR. LAZARESCU (2005) A cranky, ailing man (Ion Fiscuteanu, above) slowly dies as he is moved through a series of hospitals where doctors deny him treatment, accompanied only by a steadfast nurse (Luminita Gheorghiu) who refuses to leave his side. This Romanian masterpiece, directed by Cristi Puiu, ''explores the intersection of the social and the personal on the human body,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Over the course of the torturous, inept hospitalization that eventually realizes the threat of the film's title, Mr. Lazarescu's body becomes a field of meaning.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) THE DAY OF THE JACKAL (1973) Turner Classic Movies continues its Oscar tribute with a salute to the 70s, starting with this espionage thriller by Fred Zinnemann, adapted from the novel by Frederick Forsyth, about a British hit man (Edward Fox) -- code name the Jackal -- who agrees to kill Charles de Gaulle, the president of France, for half a million dollars. At 10:30 ''Three Days of the Condor'' (1973), starring Robert Redford as a C.I.A. researcher who uncovers top secret information and finds himself marked for death; at 12:30 a.m. ''Marathon Man'' (1976), with Dustin Hoffman as a graduate student who unwittingly finds himself involved in a mysterious plot involving diamonds and a Nazi war criminal (Laurence Olivier); and at 2:45 ''The Boys from Brazil'' (1978), this time with Olivier playing a veteran Nazi hunter and Steve Guttenberg as his green sidekick, who stumble upon a plan to regenerate the SS in Paraguay. Gregory Peck plays Dr. Josef Mengele.

DeSEVO--Marilyn, 59, on February 27, 2008 after a battle with cancer. Loving sister of Richard DeSevo and daughter of the late Gertrude and Alphonse DeSevo, adoring aunt of Allison Stevens and Julia DeSevo, and great-aunt of Cameron Stevens. Memorial service to be held at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 81st St. and Madison Ave. on Sunday, 11:30am. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

'HANSEL AND GRETEL' Make that Hank and Gertie. In this new musical from Manhattan Children's Theater the fairy tale has lost its Germanic tone in favor of an Appalachian twang. But even though the characters are thoroughly Americanized, the only sugarcoating remains on the witch's house. This story is still Grimm, and even a little grim. Written by a sister-and-brother team, Kristin Walter (book and lyrics) and Michael Walter (music), ''Hansel and Gretel'' begins with the old-fashioned narrative, as it is told to the siblings Hank and Gertie by their impoverished parents. But these down-on-their-luck mining folks can't finish the tale before bedtime. When the children go berry picking the next day, life slowly and insidiously begins to imitate art, at least after they relate the half-told story to a kindly woman in the woods. (You don't have to be a grown-up to figure out who she really is.)

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a television station in Huntsville, Ala., that showed a black screen for 12 minutes on Sunday night during a ''60 Minutes'' report about possible political deception involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of Alabama referred incorrectly to one of the owners of the station. Robert M. Bass, manager of an investment company that bought the station, WHNT, last year, has been a contributor to Democratic Party candidates, but unlike his brothers in Texas, he has not been a contributor to President Bush. An editorial on Wednesday about WHNT going dark repeated the error. An article about an internal review of the incident by the Huntsville station is on Page C4 today.

SCHOENFELD--Norman, 70, of White Plains, New York, passed away on February 27th in White Plains Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Schoenfeld was the loving husband of Michele (Buchholz) Schoenfeld; devoted father of Steven (Susan) Schoenfeld of Towson, MD, and Susie (Michael) Welling, of Port Chester; adoring grandfather of Jacob Schoenfeld and Matthew Welling; and beloved brother of Lester Schoenfeld (Linda) of Purchase, NY. Mr. Schoenfeld was born in Brooklyn, NY, to Edward and Alice (Forgosh) Schoenfeld and the family later moved to Haverhill, MA, where he attended Haverhill High School. A graduate of Clark University and a C.P.A., he began his career with Clarence Rainess & Company and later left public accounting to become Controller and Chief Financial Officer of several companies. He was a member of Willow Ridge CountryClub, where he was a former member of the Board of Governors and a member of the Golf Committee, and belonged to Congregation Kol Ami where he had been a member of the Finance Committee. Services are Friday, February 29th, at 12 Noon at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains. SCHOENFELD--Norman. The Board of Governors and members of Willow Ridge Country Club sadly note the passing of Norman Schoenfeld, a beloved member of this club. Our deepest condolences are offered to his wife, Michele Schoenfeld and to their entire family. Alan Schrager, President Board of Governors

Q My colleagues and I saw a raccoon sleeping the other day, in a treetop curled around the trunk of the tree, right outside an office window. Is this unusual? Do raccoons normally sleep in treetops? Is the statement that ''raccoons out during the day time'' should be considered dangerous (rabid) true? -- Irving A Raccoons do not hibernate during winter and are active from late afternoon throughout the night. During the day they sleep in hollow log dens, on tree branches and inside tree cavities. I remember walking through Central Park some years ago on a relatively warm winter day and seeing a raccoon fast asleep with its beautiful tail wrapped around its body, at the edge of a tree cavity.

Re "What That McCain Article Didn't Say" (Feb. 24): The beauty of the Feb. 21 front-page article about Senator John McCain is that it was constructed in such a way that The New York Times could go either way with it, depending on how the public responded.If the public bought in, the paper could leverage the impact with expanded editorial and Op-Ed coverage. If the public thought it was a lot of hooey, which they did, they could go to Plan B and send the public editor into the fray to apologize for any misunderstanding and point out that the story did not actually say what it was intended to suggest.Either way, The Times would keep alive a story that the public correctly recognized as insubstantial.Margaret McGirrGreenwich, Conn., Feb. 25, 2008

The smallest state is a big deal politically these days, as the candidates campaign in Rhode Island in advance of its primary on Tuesday. The Times's Abby Goodnough finds that while the state is heavy with Mrs. Clinton's base voters, young voters (who tend to support Mr. Obama) made up a disproportionate share of new registrants. The Washington Post also looks at the campaign in the state, including the Obama camp's efforts to lower Clinton morale by opening an office in what should be her stronghold.

Kyle Busch, the Nascar Sprint Cup series points leader, ran a fast lap of 182.352 miles an hour in his Toyota Camry to win the pole for Sunday’s race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. Carl Edwards qualified second with a lap of 181.586 in his Ford. Mark Martin was third in a Chevrolet.

NASA managers cleared the shuttle Endeavour for liftoff on March 11 to begin a 16-day mission to the International Space Station. The mission, which involves taking part of a Japanese science module to the station and conducting five spacewalks, will be launched at 2:28 a.m. William Gerstenmaier, the agency’s manager of space operations, also said that analysis of the debris from a disabled satellite that the Air Force destroyed last week created a “trivial” rise in risk.

The Department of Agriculture has suspended at least two federal meat inspectors after the largest beef recall in the nation’s history, a union leader said. Stan Painter, chairman of the National Joint Council of Food Inspection Locals, said the department confirmed it had placed a veterinarian and a floor inspector from the Westland/Hallmark Meat Company in Chino on paid leave. A spokeswoman said the agency could not comment on personnel matters. The department recalled 143 million pounds of beef from the Chino slaughterhouse on Feb. 17. The recall came after the Humane Society of the United States released undercover video showing plant workers trying to get sick or crippled animals to stand by shoving and dragging them with forklifts, zapping them with electric prods and aiming water hoses at their faces.

A sheriff’s deputy had legal cause to stop and search a car last summer that resulted in the discovery of low-grade explosives and the arrest of two Egyptian college students, a federal magistrate in Tampa said. If the advisory opinion from Magistrate Judge Mark A. Pizzo is accepted by the presiding judge in the case, the evidence found in the car can be used against the men at their April trial on charges of illegally transporting explosives. Lawyers for the defendants, Ahmed Abdellatif Sherif Mohamed and Youssef Samir Megahed, both former University of South Florida engineering students, say the materials in their car were to make fireworks. Mr. Mohamed, 26, and Mr. Megahed, 21, have been in jail since their arrests in Goose Creek, S.C.

Florida Power and Light says human error caused a power failure for more than half a million customers earlier this week. The electric company released a two-page preliminary report that placed blame on a field engineer who was investigating a switch that had malfunctioned at a substation west of Miami. The company says two nuclear reactors and a natural gas unit at the Turkey Point facility south of Miami shut down. Two other Florida Power and Light plants were also affected.

The San Francisco 49ers and city officials formally announced that their 48-year-old stadium would be known as Candlestick Park. The stadium was called Monster Park for the last three and a half years, although it seemed only the 49ers and their broadcasters actually used the name. Shortly after Monster Cable bought naming rights in 2004 for an estimated $1.5 million annually, San Francisco voters passed a proposition forbidding the city and the team to resell the rights when the deal expired.

Werner Heel of Italy edged Bode Miller to win a downhill on the Olympic course at Kvitfjell, Norway, for his first World Cup victory. Heel was 21st in the downhill standings going into the race, but sped down the 1.9-mile course in 1 minute 45.73 seconds to edge Miller by 0.10 of a second.

Blatter, the FIFA president, met with John Fahey, the WADA chief, and signed a letter of intent to adopt the code, which will take effect Jan. 1, 2009.

Federico Luzzi was suspended 200 days and fined $50,000 by the ATP for betting 273 times on matches. The ATP and an anticorruption hearing officer found “no evidence” he tried to influence the results of matches on which he bet. He was the fifth Italian player punished for gambling on matches. The ATP, the governing body of men’s tennis, said Luzzi placed one bet on himself — a $4.50 wager that he would win. Luzzi, 28, was ranked a career-high 92nd in 2002 and has an 18-31 career singles record.

The Arctic Monkeys, above, were nominated for seven awards and won three at the annual NME Awards in London, including best band, best video (“Teddy Picker”) and best track (“Fluorescent Adolescent,”), the BBC reported. The awards, named for the music magazine NME (for New Musical Express), are determined by readers, who voted Pete Doherty of Babyshambles “Hero of the Year,” and President Bush “Villain of the Year.” Winners of the other major awards included the Killers (best international band); the Enemy (best new band); Muse (best live band); Kate Nash (best solo artist). “Myths of the Near Future,” by the Klaxons, was voted the best album.

An exhibition of works by the artist Zhang Huan, right, was canceled by Shanghai’s local government just before it was to open this week at the Shanghai Art Museum. The Shanghai Cultural Bureau, which oversees the museum, declined to comment on Friday, as did museum officials and Mr. Zhang. But people in Shanghai closely involved with the exhibition said government officials seemed to be troubled by some of his installation works, including two sculptures, “Giant 1” and “Giant 2,” 16-foot-tall deformed creatures with human faces and body parts made from cowhide. The same people said that museum officials were still negotiating with the government and that they hoped that it would allow the show to open within a month. China regularly censors or closes art shows, particularly if they depict work that is overtly political or has sexual or violent themes. But in recent years the government has allowed many formerly banned artists to exhibit. Mr. Zhang was once known as a performance artist, whose provocative shows caused him to be blacklisted in China.

The British police are no longer investigating Amy Winehouse, the singer, on suspicion of trying to interfere with a court case involving her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, who was charged with attacking a pub owner and then conspiring in an attempt to bribe the owner to withdraw as a trial witness, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, 24, had been arrested in December, then released on bail. Mr. Fielder-Civil appeared in a London court on Friday, where he pleaded not guilty to the charges against him. His next court hearing is scheduled for April.

Robert Bly, who lives in Minneapolis, has been named Minnesota’s first poet laureate by Gov. Tim Pawlenty, The Minneapolis Star-Tribune’s Web site reported. In accepting the honorary post, the 81-year-old Mr. Bly — who has written more than 30 books of poetry but is probably best known for “Iron John: A Book About Men,” a 1990 prose exploration of mythology — said: “I don’t know of any official duties. I may do an anthology of Minnesota poets, but I won’t be writing any state poems. I’ll give it a year or two and then turn it over to one of the younger poets.”.

Experts have digitally rebuilt the face of Johann Sebastian Bach, Reuters reported. Using his bones and computer modeling, they have come up with an image of a thick-set man with closely cropped white hair. The new Bach face, the creation of a Scottish forensic anthropologist, Caroline Wilkinson, is to go on display at the Bachhaus museum in Eisenach, Germany, his birthplace, next month. “For most people Bach is an old man in a wig, it is a stylized image, we have no realistic portrait of him,” Joerg Hansen, the managing director of the museum, said. Bach’s bones were excavated in 1894 and first used to help create a bust in 1908. But it was mainly based on a portrait of him, and critics at the time said it was so inaccurate that it might as well have been Handel.

“Don’t Forget the Lyrics,” on Fox, drew its highest ratings ever on Thursday, delivering 14.6 million viewers and beating ABC’s “Lost” (12.8 million) at 9 p.m. But among adults 18 to 49, “Lost” held a slight lead. “Lyrics,” a singing game show, benefited from following Fox’s “American Idol,” which led the night with 25.9 million viewers at 8, Nielsen estimated. ABC ranked third for the night, trailing Fox and CBS, which ranked second, thanks to “Survivor: Micronesia” at 8 (12.5 million), followed by reruns of “CSI” (11.6 million) and “Without a Trace” (10.4 million). ABC ran close behind CBS in the 18-to-49 set. NBC was a distant fourth over all, drawing its highest ratings at 9 with “The Celebrity Apprentice” (7.6 million) but struggling at 10 with “Lipstick Jungle” (5.7 million).

Thomas Quasthoff, the bass-baritone who was scheduled to perform as soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday has canceled because of a severe cold. The Grammy and Emmy Award-winning rapper Eminem, below, is at work on a new book, “The Way I Am,” described as an intimate look inside his life, The Associated Press reported. His publisher, Dutton Books, a Penguin Group imprint, said the book was expected to reach stores in the fall. ... Gina Gershon and Mary McCormack have landed two of the three flight attendants’ roles in “Boeing-Boeing,” the 1960s Marc Camoletti farce scheduled to open at the Longacre Theater on May 4. Ms. Gershon, whose credits include the television series “Ugly Betty” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” will play Gabriella, the Italian attendant. Ms. McCormack, who played Howard Stern’s wife in the film “Private Parts,” will play Gretchen, the German flight attendant. The role of the third attendant remains to be filled. ... Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp will reprise their original Broadway (and film) roles in “Rent” in a 2009 national tour of that Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning musical, which will begin in January, Playbill reported. The Broadway production ends its 11-year run on June 1 at the Nederlander Theater. ... Rod Stewart will start an 18-city North American tour in Paso Robles, Calif., on July 30 and end it in Tampa, Fla., on Aug. 28, Reuters reported. ... The lineup for that 30th-annual event also includes Al Jarreau, Tower of Power, Keb’ Mo’, the James Moody Quartet and the Roy Hargrove Big Band.

SAUREL--Louise Hoguet, aged 92. Louise Saurel passed away peacefully at her home in New York City, February 23, 2008 after a brief illness and a full and active life. Daughter of Ramsay and Christine McCreery Hoguet, widow of Paul Saurel (died1994) and beloved mother of Paul Saurel, Marie-Noel Westgate, Louise Kari, Ramsay Saurel (died 1966) and Christine Saurel, grandmother of Ramsay, Katherine, Brian, Paul, Zita, Gabriela and Elena, proud great-grandmother of Bella and Sarah and ''adopted'' mother and grandmother of many. Her family will miss her and is thankful for the joyful times spent together. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste (Lexington Ave. and 76th St.) at 10am, Saturday April 5, 2008, with interment following, Sunday April 6, 2008 at St. Joseph's Cemetery in Stockbridge, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Art Students League of New York or Citymeals on Wheels.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Home.

KATZ--Zorland Lawrence The 92nd Street Y Board and staff deeply mourn the sudden passing of Zorland Katz, beloved husband of our dear friend and colleague, Helaine. We have lost a great supporter of the 92nd Street Y, in particular of his wife who, as the Associate Executive Director, has worked to enrich and add beauty to our world. Our hearts go out to her and their sons, Matthew and David. The entire Katz and Geismar families are in our prayers. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. FASHENA--Sidney. Died 3/1/03. Five long years without you, my love, and I've missed you every day. Our children and grandsons share my fond memories of you. Love, Peg

NANON--Patricia, of New York City and Chilmark, Massachusetts, died peacefully on February 29, in her home in New York City surrounded by her loving daughters. She was 84. Ms. Nanon, a choreographer, was a 1944 graduate of Bennington College and the Founder and long time Artistic Director of The Yard, a colony for the performing arts on Martha's Vineyard. The Yard is a treasured part of both the Vineyard and the contemporary dance world, which has often honored her for her vision and generosity. She is survived by her daughters Vicki Woolner Samuels of Chicago, Cate Woolner of Northfield, Massachusetts, and Justine Woolner Wise of Oneonta, New York, their families, many devoted nieces and nephews and their families, as well as many dear friends. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Martha's Vineyard at a later date.

ROSENFELD--Alfredo Fritz (Freddy), of New York, born June 2, 1921 in Nuremberg died February 9, 2008 in Zurich. Alfredo is survived by his beloved wife of 48 years Ruth Jackson Rosenfeld, adoring daughter Raquel, family and friends. Alfredo spent his late teens and early adult years in Buenos Aires. After WWII, he returned to Europe, which was the beginning of a rich lifetime of travel and adventure. He was a distinguished antiquarian horologist who recently discovered the joy of collecting antique books. Alfredo was an outspoken, free spirited, magnanimous man. A lover of classical music and opera, he was on vacation in Budapest enjoying the season there just prior to his sudden illness and death. Alfredo lived a full, satisfying life and will be missed by all whose lives he touched.

Entombment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. Visiting hours Saturday 7-9pm, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm.

10 P.M. (HBO) GEORGE CARLIN: IT'S BAD FOR YA Mr. Carlin, left, returns to this channel for his 14th original stand-up special, broadcast live from the Wells Fargo Center for the Arts in Santa Rosa, Calif. On his mind this time around, according to HBO, will be the advantages of being old, child worship and the failure of the ''self-esteem'' movement. It's material Mr. Carlin has been honing for the last two years. ''I can't do old material; I would feel like a failure,'' he has said. ''Essentially, this job is that of a writer, and in my case, the writer gets to perform his own material onstage.'' And the writer who doesn't keep producing new material? ''A typist.'' 8 P.M. (HBO) DISTURBIA (2007) A troubled teenager (Shia LeBeouf), who has nothing better to do than spy on his neighbors after being sentenced to house arrest for punching his Spanish teacher, begins to suspect the man next door (David Morse) of being a serial killer. ''There are no big surprises,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''but the jumps and jolts are well timed, and the overall mood is at once grisly and good-natured -- more diverting than disturbing.''

LANDES--Phyllis M. Mommy -We love you and will always be with you and you will always be with us. Prinny, Bunzo and the Boys LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Mom (Grandma-ma) thanks for everything! Always in our hearts and minds. Jeffrey, Andrea, Sophia and Robyn LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished and longtime member, Phyllis Markman Landes. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary --Phyllis Markman, of New York City and Naples, Florida passed away after a short illness on February 29, 2008 at her home in New York. Born in Brooklyn, New York and raised in Bradley Beach, New Jersey, she was an honors graduate of Vassar College. She also did postgraduate work at the New York Institute of Finance. Her first passion was her family. She was actively engaged in the arts and civic volunteerism and serving the community. She served as an honorary director of the Friends of the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, and she was a founding member of the Naples Museum of Art. She was also a trustee emeritus of the Community Foundation of Collier County. She is predeceased by her loving husband, Robert Nathan Landes, and survived by her three devoted children, Lucy Mayer Harrop, Kathy Mayer Braddock and Jeffrey Mark Landes, and her dedicated sons-in-law and daughter-inlaw Mark Delavan Harrop, Richard J. Zakin and Andrea C. Landes. She is also survived by four beloved grandchildren, Philip Wildman Braddock, Charles Gibson Braddock, Sophie Eva Landes and Robyn Nicole Landes. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, c/o Development Office, Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Box 14, Poughkeepsie, New York 12604-0014 and the Naples Museum of Art, 5833 Pelican Bay Boulevard, Naples, Florida 34108. The family will be receiving at the family home from 2-7pm on Wednesday, March 5th. LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Mommy (Mom), you will always be our inspiration and strength. With our love and devotion forever. Lucy and Mark

BAYER--Molly. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the loss of Molly Bayer, beloved mother of Virginia Bayer, Past President of the our Board of Trustees and current Trustee, mother-in-law to Robert Hirt and grandmother to David Slifka '93. Molly was an adoring, deeply supportive mother who had great pride in her daughter and grandchildren. Our hearts go out to the family and, in particular, Virginia who has been instrumental in so many important aspects of the Heschel School's growth and success including the development of our middle school and high school divisions. Her wise counsel and considered opinion is sought after by all our leadership. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School BAYER--Molly Jean, 92. Beloved wife of the late Merwin, perfect mother of Virginia and the late Hank, caring mother-in-law of Janice Bayer and Rabbi Robert Hirt, adored and adoring grandmother of David (Lisa) Slifka, Brad and Hilary. As services and burial have taken place, Shiva information is available through The Jewish Center, 131 West 86th St. May her soul be bound up in the bond of eternal life. BAYER--Molly Jean. Our condolences go to our friend Virginia Bayer on the loss of her beloved mother and her son David Slifka on the loss of his devoted grandmother. We send our deepest sympathy and love to Virginia's husband Rabbi Robert Hirt and the entire family. We will miss her dearly. The Tananbaum and Taubman-Kalisman Families

Two former presidents -- Corazon C. Aquino, who led the ''people power'' uprising that toppled Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986, and Joseph Estrada, who was ousted in the second one in 2001 -- joined thousands of priests, nuns, farmers, leftists and students in a march through Manila's financial district to press for President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's resignation over corruption allegations. It was one of the largest demonstrations against her. The police estimated the crowd at 15,000, while organizers put it at more than 75,000 people. Mrs. Aquino addressed the crowd from a makeshift stage. ''Gloria, it's enough!'' she said. ''Resign!'' Then it was Mr. Estrada's turn to speak. ''What should we do if someone is overstaying?'' he asked the protesters. ''Resign!'' they shouted back.

ELIAS--Julius A. May 25, 1925-February 25, 2008. Born in the East End of London to Annie and Max, he served as Chief of the Voluntary Agencies of the International Refugee Organization in Austria after WWII, helping Jewish orphans and victims of the Holocaust resettle. Emigrated to US in 1952, and completed his B.A., M.A. and Ph.D. in Philosophy at Columbia University. He rose to the rank of Professor and Chairman of Philosophy at CCNY. Elected first Faculty Ombudsman. Recruited to University of CT in 1974 as Deanand subsequently as interim Academic Vice President until retirement in 1992. Continued to teach philosophy, great books and opera. Published many scholarly articles and several books including Plato's Defense of Poetry (Macmillan, 1984), and The Antecedents of Nazism: Weimar (Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences, 2000). He served as the managing editor of the Journal of the History of Ideas for 12 years. He was predeceased by his wife, Wilma. He is survived by his son Anthony D. Elias, daughter-in-law Ellen Roy Elias, three grandchildren, as well as his extended family in London.

BRINA--Elizabeth, on February 29th, 2008. Survived by her sons Arthur, Peter and Philip, her sister Violet, brother Jack and granddaughters Elizabeth and Kate. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 7-9pm, at the ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., service Monday, 11am, at Christ and St. Stephens, 122 West 69th St., NYC.

KEENE--Louis (Ludwik), died peacefully at age 92, surrounded by his family. He leaves his wife of 63 years, Lilli and three children, Allan, Anette and Steven; four grandchildren and two greatgranddaughters. He was born in Krakow, Poland, graduated from the Jagiellonian University, spent WWII in the Polish forces in France and England, arrived in New York in 1944. He was a partner with his brother-in-law, Marvin Cantor at Henry Krieger & Co., a NYSE member firm founded by their father-inlaw, Henry Krieger. He had a long and full life and will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Services will be held Sunday, March 2nd, at 1 pm at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

TAM--Dr. Thomas. The City University of New York mourns the passing of our former trustee who served with admirable and exemplary distinction from 1989 to 1996. Dr. Tam was a highly regarded educator and beloved husband, father, and friend whose admirers stretched far beyond the Asian American communities he served in so many beneficial ways. Dr. Tam organized the first Asian American Higher Education Council, comprising faculty and staff throughout CUNY. Working closely with Professor Emeritus Betty Sung, Dr. Tam led efforts to establish the first Asian American/ Asian Research Institute at CUNY. Dr. Tam's professional career reflected his deep devotion to education, particularly at the collegiate level, and a special emphasis on community healthcare and education, both in New York City and elsewhere. His many contributions and achievements will be long-enduring. We extend deepest condolences to his family. Benno C. Schmidt Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

FRANK--Alan. Dear The, We will be missing you always and of course we will Follow the Queen in your honor every first Thursday. Rest in peace. We love you. The Knights of the Green Felt Table FRANK--Alan, age 58, suddenly on February 28. Beloved son of Blanchette and Jack Frank, brother of Sasha, devoted dear friend and adored uncle/godfather of so many. Services will be held on Sunday, March 2nd, at 12 Noon, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 90th and Amsterdam, 212-769-4400. FRANK--Alan. Dearest friend, extrodinary and generous host, lunch companion, dinner guest, apple picker and Captain. We will keep you in our hearts forever. Patty Burrows Milt Wolfson Jody, Jessica and Jordan FRANK--Alan. We will always cherish our good fortune in having your friendship. Thank you for your generosity, your kindness, your humor and your love. We'll miss you immensely. Arnie and June.

GROBSTEIN--Ruth Hirsch Beloff. Born to Bernard and Sarah Hirsch on January 2, 1924 in New York City, Ruth Grobstein died peacefully of pulmonary failure with her daughters at her side on February 25th. She was a woman of great strength and a distinguished biologist and oncologist, receiving a BA from NYU, Ph.D. in Biology from Yale, and M.D. from UCLA while in her 50s. She was the Founding Director of the Ida and Cecil Green Cancer Center at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, where she pioneered treatment of breast cancer without mastectomy. Ruth was predeceased by her beloved husband, Clifford Grobstein, and is survived by her daughters and sons-in-law, Sandy and Jim Wilbur of NYC and Vermont, Beth Beloff and Marc Geller of Houston, TX, and Robin Beloff-Wachsberg and Abe Wachsberg of Santa Rosa, CA, as well as 12 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Memorial service will take place on April 6 at 1:00 at the Inn at Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Her family will receive friends at her home following the memorial. Donations can be made to San Diego Hospice or breast cancer research.

SUSSER--Herbert, 92, of Clifton formerly of Paterson, retired Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey. Judge Susser was a former president of the YM YWHA of North Jersey, former president of New Jersey Federation of Y's and former president of the Paterson Lodge of B'nai Brith. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Community Synagogue and the Daughters of Miriam Home. Judge Susser is survived by his wife Gloria, his sons Jack (Bonnie) and Allen (Andrea) and grandchildren, Alexa, Alicia, Carly, and Mark. Services are Sunday, 11:30am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

BUNAES--Mary Louise. With great sorrow, family and friends announce her passing on February 21, 2008 while undergoing treatment for cancer in Prien-am-Chiemsee, Bavaria. Born December 18, 1939 in Stewart, Nevada, Mary Louise Grinnell graduated with honors from the University of Oregon, where she was a member of the local chapter of Delta Zeta sorority and of the Mortarboard Honor Society. Following graduation, she moved with her husband Bard Bunaes to his native Norway. They subsequently lived in England and France before settling in Irvington - on - Hudson, NY, where she devoted her considerable energy and talent to a variety of organizations and causes. A longtime member of The Thursday Club, which financially supports area charities, and the Garden Club of Irvington, she served as President of both organizations. She was also a board member of the National Trust for Historic Preservation at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown and was a fundraiser for Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow, where her husband currently serves as board chairman. She sang with the Soundettes, an all-female a capella group as well as the choir at the Church of St. Barnabas in Irvington, of which she and her husband were longtime parishioners. She was also a supporter of the (Episcopal) Church of St. Sacrement in Bolton Landing on Lake George. An ardent sportswoman, she was an aerobics instructor, tennis and paddle tennis player, golfer and skier. She and her husband traveled extensively and made active use of their vacation homes in Fisher's Island and Bolton Landing, NY, Deer Valley, Utah, and Indian Wells, California. In addition to her husband, Mary Louise is survived by their three children, Hans Paal of Jamestown, RI, Erik Christopher of San Rafael, CA, and Christina Louise of Cottonwood Heights, Utah, two grandchildren, Mia Louise and Jack Bard Bunaes, as well as three sisters, Charlene, Ramona and Darlene, and a brother, Ralph Grinnell. A memorial service will be held at 11am, Saturday, March 1 at the Church of St. Barnabas, 13 N. Broadway, Irvington. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Mary Louise Bunaes Scholarship Fund would be welcome at the Church of St. Sacrement, 4879 Lake Shore Drive, Bolton Landing, NY 12814. BUNAES--Mary Louise. The Board of Trustees of The American-Scandinavia Foundation extends its deepest condolences to our esteemed Chairman Bard E. Bunaes on the tragic loss of his wife Mary Louise. Richard E. Oldenburg, Deputy Chairman Edward P. Gallagher, President

MUNICH -- It was an oh-so-quiet day Sunday in Salzburg, Austria, where the visiting Red Bulls had the day off. Let's see, the seventh-place Rangers meet the eighth-place Flyers. They're 3 and 2 points ahead of the ninth-place Sabres, respectively. Will the game go to overtime? ... Why, yes, it will -- and both the Rangers and Flyers get a guaranteed point for that! What an unexpected outcome! How surprising that the first 60 minutes of their game should end in a deadlock! Unless I've missed my guess, that result benefits both teams. What good fortune for the Rangers and Flyers that the game should turn out that way!

Mark Zandi of economy.com, quoted in this NYT piece on the weak job market, has a nice turn of phrase for what I've been trying to say on a number of occasions: even during the best years of the "Bush boom," the job market never got remotely as good as it was in the late 1990s. I was really interested in Frank's question about why "August" has "connected with a large and diverse audience in a way that other equally well-reviewed plays have not." This question opens the floodgates to a huge issue, which is the relationship between critics and the audience. What responsibility, if any, do critics have to theatergoers? What is the purpose of criticism now? Is it anything more than what you'd find in TV Guide - who's in the thing and what's it about? Or is it sevice journalism - is this piece of entertainment worth 47 bucks of your hard earned cash? (That's the median price paid for a Broadway ticket, by the way.) What kinds of experience should be required before a person becomes a critic? Should they be held responsible to anybody or anything, or can they just write with a free hand, and be loose cannons for life, some of them?

Aired Friday night on CBS: I think the world of John McCain. He looks like the kind of guy who still talks real loud on a long-distance phone call. McCain looks like the guy you are waiting for to stop gabbing with the teller, you know. McCain looks like a guy who sits at his dinner tray and watches "The Beltway Boys." McCain looks like the guy whose wife forced him to go on a cruise. McCain looks like the guy you have to nudge when his name is called. McCain looks like a freelance crosswalk guard.

Robin Soderling advanced to his second consecutive ATP final, beating Radek Stepanek, 7-6 (2), 6-3, in the Regions Morgan Keegan Championships in Memphis. Soderling will play Steve Darcis, who advanced to his second career ATP final by defeating Jonas Bjorkman, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4.

Sergiy Stakhovsky of Ukraine won his first ATP title, defeating top-seeded Ivan Ljubicic of Croatia, 7-5, 6-4, and becoming the first “lucky loser” to capture a tournament in 17 years. A lucky loser enters the main draw of a tournament from the qualifying field at the last minute because another player is unable to compete.

A record field of mushers drove dog teams through Anchorage on Saturday in the ceremonial start of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. Well-bundled fans braved wind chills hovering just above zero to line up along the 11-mile run. Many in the crowd traveled to Alaska just to experience part of the race.“I decided if I wanted to see the Iditarod, I better get to doing it,” said 91-year-old Roberta Moore, of Sarasota, Fla.The actual start of the race is Sunday in Willow, about 50 miles to the north. There are 96 teams, including six past winners, competing this year.

The Japanese boxer Yutaka Niida stopped the challenger José Varela of Venezuela in the sixth round on in Tokyo to defend his W.B.A. minimumweight title. Niida sent Varela to the canvas at 2 minutes 16 seconds of the sixth round for his first knockout in a title bout. Niida, who first claimed the title in 2004, improved to 23-1-3 with nine knockouts. Varela fell to 15-4 with seven knockouts.

The St. Louis Rams replaced the retiring kicker Jeff Wilkins almost immediately, signing Josh Brown away from the Seattle Seahawks and giving him a $4 million bonus — the league’s largest for a kicker.Brown’s full deal would be worth $14.2 million over five years. Wilkins, the St. Louis Rams’ career-leading scorer and the best active long-range kicker in the N.F.L., announced his retirement Friday after 14 seasons.Shortly afterward, Brown was on the move. Brown, who spent the last five seasons with Seattle, was seventh in the league in scoring in 2007 with a career-high 127 points, including 28 of 34 field-goal attempts. He was a top priority for the Seahawks to re-sign last month, and Seattle was believed to have offered him $14 million to stay.The Rams, however, offered more. Linehan said the Rams judged Brown the best free agent available at any position.Wilkins, 35, had 1,223 points and 265 field goals with the Rams, finding a home after playing one season for the Eagles and two for the 49ers. He also leads the franchise in field-goal attempts (328) and had a success rate of 80.8 percent. He retired with chronic leg and lower back problems.From 49 yards or longer, Wilkins was 39 for 50 for his career and 38 for 49 with the Rams. Among active kickers with 20 or more attempts, his 78 percent success rate from 49 yards or longer is the best in the N.F.L. and his 25 field goals are the most in league history.
Arsenal scored a late goal to tie visiting Aston Villa, 1-1, but its lead at the top of the English Premier League was cut to a point after Manchester United won at Fulham, 3-0.

Teddy Sheringham, the former English national team striker who was pivotal in Manchester United’s injury-time victory over Bayern Munich in the 1999 Champions League final, said he would retire at the end of the season, concluding a playing career that began 24 years ago. Sheringham, 41, is currently with Colchester United of the second-tier Championship. He has played with eight other clubs and made 51 appearances for England.Sheringham helped Manchester United win three titles in 1999. He has 361 goals in his career, including 11 for England.The peak of Sheringham’s career occurred in the 1999 Champions League final match in Barcelona, Spain. Manchester United had trailed Bayern Munich, 1-0, since the fifth minute of the game. Sheringham tied the score in the first minute of injury time and set up Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s winning goal two minutes later. Sheringham started his career at Millwall in 1984.

SEAMAN--Barbara. Good night sweet Barbara. We'll miss you. Veteran Feminists of America SEAMAN--Barbara. History in Action, a cadre of inter-generational feminists, mourns the death of a sister, Barbara Seaman. Barbara's intrepid and original journalism saved countless lives, her fearless activism inspired many more, and her friendship enhanced the lives of all who met her. The mother of three wonderful children and four grandchildren, she was also the mother of the feminist health movement. Leading by example, she modelled the respect for women that she believed doctors, pharmaceutical companies, and elected officials needed to learn. Her impact on feminism is enormous and undeniable, but it is her superhuman generosity, her avid and intense interest in everybody she met, and her unique ability to make everyone a bit more smart and ambitious and brave after a few minutes with her, that will be most sorely missed.

LANDES--Phyllis M. Mommy -We love you and will always be with you and you will always be with us. Prinny, Bunzo and the Boys LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Mommy (Mom), you will always be our inspiration and strength. With our love and devotion forever. Lucy and Mark LANDES--Phyllis Markman, of New York City and Naples, Florida passed away after a short illness on February 29, 2008 at her home in New York. Born in Brooklyn, New York and raised in Bradley Beach, New Jersey, she was an honors graduate of Vassar College. She also did postgraduate work at the New York Institute of Finance. Her first passion was her family. She was actively engaged in the arts and civic volunteerism and serving the community. She served as an honorary director of the Friends of the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, and she was a founding member of the Naples Museum of Art. She was also a trustee emeritus of the Community Foundation of Collier County. She is predeceased by her loving husband, Robert Nathan Landes, and survived by her three devoted children, Lucy Mayer Harrop, Kathy Mayer Braddock and Jeffrey Mark Landes, and her dedicated sons-in-law and daughter-inlaw Mark Delavan Harrop, Richard J. Zakin and Andrea C. Landes. She is also survived by four beloved grandchildren, Philip Wildman Braddock, Charles Gibson Braddock, Sophie Eva Landes and Robyn Nicole Landes. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, c/o Development Office, Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Box 14, Poughkeepsie, New York 12604-0014 and the Naples Museum of Art, 5833 Pelican Bay Boulevard, Naples, Florida 34108. Funeral services private. The family will be receiving at the family home from 2-7pm on Wednesday, March 5th. LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Mom (Grandma-ma) thanks for everything! Always in our hearts and minds. Jeffrey, Andrea, Sophie and Robyn

KEENE--Louis (Ludwik), died peacefully at age 92, surrounded by his family. He leaves his wife of 63 years, Lilli and three children, Allan, Anette and Steven; four grandchildren and two greatgranddaughters. He was born in Krakow, Poland, graduated from the Jagiellonian University, spent WWII in the Polish forces in France and England, arrived in New York in 1944. He was a partner with his brother-in-law, Marvin Cantor at Henry Krieger & Co., a NYSE member firm founded by their father-inlaw, Henry Krieger. He had a long and full life and will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Services will be held Sunday, March 2nd, at 1 pm at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

THE NEWS Norway opened its ''doomsday'' seed vault to safeguard seeds from around the world against climate change, wars or natural disasters. BEHIND THE NEWS The Svalbard Global Seed Vault lies deep inside a frozen mountain about 600 miles from the North Pole on the island of Spitsbergen. About 268,000 distinct samples of seeds from more than 100 countries -- about 100 million seeds in all -- have already been placed there. The goal is to collect every type of seed from every seed collection in the world, especially those important for food production. ''We're at a critical period and if we don't act fast, we're going to lose a lot of plants that we may need,'' said one expert.

PEREZ--Segundo A., M.D., beloved husband, father, grandfather, doctor, art collector, artist, author, composer and friend, died on February 27. Born in Havana, Cuba, on April 29, 1928, Dr. Perez graduated from LaSalle College, received his medical degree from the University of Havana School of Medicine, and was pediatrician to thousands of children over more than 40 years, in Cuba, and then in New York and New Jersey. He delighted family and friends for nearly eight decades with his warmth, intelligence, charm, passion, wit, humor, erudition, many talents, zest for life and, above all, his boundless capacity for love. He is survived by his beloved wife of 45 years, Carmen Marques Perez, children, Gabriela Baron and Antonio PerezMarques, son-in-law Robert Baron, daughter-in-law Jessica Romm Perez, and adored grandchildren, Anthony Maxwell Baron and Cristina Elena Baron, all of NYC. Funeral mass Monday, March 3, 10am at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave and 84th St, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Dr. Segundo Perez to the Department of Pediatrics, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, Box 139, NY, NY 10065.

OUTPOSTS To win this election, as always, a candidate will need the most consistent voter: the reliable senior. In the last presidential election, one in four voters were over 60. That math would seem to favor Senator John McCain -- ''older than dirt, with more scars than Frankenstein,'' as he used to joke. McCain turns 72 in August, which means if he's elected, he would be the oldest president to enter the White House. (Ronald Reagan was 69 when he became president.) But McCain faces a mountain of doubt about people his age running the country. Only about 5 percent of Americans say they would refuse to vote for a black person. About 11 percent say they would not vote for a woman. And a whopping 42 percent -- according to Gallup -- say they would have trouble voting for someone age 72 or older.

BORROWERS with credit scores that are a few points from qualifying for a loan may be tempted to resort to credit-repair agencies for quick help in raising their scores. In some cases, the move can pay significant dividends. But industry executives and regulators say that it can often be a waste of money. ''Credit repair is sort of a pejorative term,'' said Norman Magnuson, a spokesman for the Consumer Data Industry Association, a trade group for companies that track consumer credit. This is because many credit-repair agencies promise more than they deliver, Mr. Magnuson and others said.

BUCKOUT--William Armstrong, 93, of Sanibel Island and Fort Myers, FL passed away February 18, 2008. He was born in Pleasantville, NY and graduated from Cornell University College of Architecture in 1937. At Cornell he was a member of Sigma Nu Fraternity, lettered in baseball and was team captain his senior year. He became President and owner of Fair-Chester Builders, Inc. of Pleasantville, NY. He was elected Mayor of Pleasantville from 1952 to 1959 and also served on the Planning Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals 1960 to 1972. He was a Rotarian and Paul Harris Fellow, a trustee of the Northern Westchester Hospital and took a very active roll in the development and construction of the hospital expansion during the years 1970 to 1972.

The Prototype column last Sunday, about technology to improve the performance of semiconductors, described the tiny transistors in a high-end chip incorrectly. They are no wider than the nucleus of a small cell, not of a bacterium. (Bacteria do not have nuclei.) The column also misstated the source of cost estimates for building a semiconductor fabrication plant, or fab. It is Synopsys, a chip design company, not VLSI Research. And the column misstated the name of the college at the State University of New York at Albany that runs a research fab. It is the College of Nanoscale Science and Engineering, not Nanoscience and Electronics.

Offense is back in the N.B.A. Look no further than the triple-digit scores now appearing nightly. And defense? After slowing the game in the '90s, it has lost a step. And yet defense is still critical to a title: 34 of the N.B.A.'s 61 champions led the league in scoring differential, a defining defensive measurement. By contrast, just 10 champs have topped the charts in scoring. Here, former head coach Jeff Van Gundy, now an analyst with ESPN, outlines ways to stop some of the game's most potent offensive weapons. THE FINE POINTS BY GREG BOECK

In the mid-1950s, short-sleeve coats and capes inspired by Balenciaga were the high-style look. While impractical for winter, the silhouette, with its attendant long gloves, was widely accepted. Now a new generation has discovered it, wind-tunnel sleeves and all. This is a case of vanity triumphing over function.

TAKING A SILICA MUD MASK AT THE BLUE LAGOON, GRINDAVIK, JULY 24, 2007 Lisa Nielsen, 29, left, a nurse from Aarhus, Denmark, with her mother, Bodil. ''I split up from my boyfriend in July and, yeah, it was very rough and I was very sad. My parents asked if I wanted to go away with them. My mother asked me where, and I said Iceland; I'm very interested in nature and there were so many different things to see there, geysers and glaciers for example. The Blue Lagoon is hot springs; you can't see from the picture but around the pool and outside it's actually quite beautiful. The water also looks much nicer from outside, much more blue. The bad side about the Blue Lagoon is that it smells terribly. But we went another place where there also were hot springs, and the smell was worse. After the trip I felt much better, mentally but also physically; still I was sad about our breakup. But it helped me to get away from Denmark for a while: we were in Iceland 10 days, drove about 4,000 kilometers and saw almost the whole country.'' As told to Seth Kugel

An article on Feb. 10, about concern over the fact that suburban communities use more energy and emit more carbon dioxide than cities do, misstated the energy resource purchased in an emissions-control effort by Northbrook, Ill., a Chicago suburb. It buys credits for 4,500 megawatt-hours of electricity a year from wind farms, not 4,500 megawatts.

An article last Sunday about Marilyn Heston, an owner of a public relations company who tries to persuade celebrities to wear her clients' clothing and jewelry at awards shows, misspelled the given name of an actress who performed a nominated song at the Oscars ceremony that evening. She is Kristin Chenoweth, not Kristen. The error also appeared the same day in The Times Magazine in an article about Anita Renfroe, a comedian who performs on the Christian women's circuit.

SLOCUM--Dr. Donald, a biochemist and resident of Convent Station, NJ, was justly proud of his invention of Corian solid surface, the first product of its kind and now widely used in homes and industry for counter surfaces and many other applications. This unique product created a major worldwide solid surface industry, which has grown every year for the last 40 years and now consists of dozens of products and manufacturers. In the biological sciences, Dr. Slocum was among the earliest researchers to propose and demonstrate the role of free radicals as agents in stimulated and aberrant growth of cells. He was a prolific inventor and creative scientist with several patented inventions. He also served in executive leadership roles in several major corporations, including DuPont, Hoffman La Roche, Curtiss-Wright, and Masonite, from which he retired as Senior Vice President of Technology. He also was a writer, lecturer and teacher during his highly active career. Dr. Slocum was born in Flushing, NY, and received degrees from Davis & Elkins College in West Virginia, the University of Vermont, and The Ohio State University. Dr. Slocum served in the Korean conflict in the 194th Engineer Combat Battalion and retired from the U.S. Army reserves as a Colonel after 30 years of service. He was highly decorated for his service and will be interred in the Arlington National Cemetery in Washington, DC. Don was an inspired scientist, a talented executive, a gentleman in every sense of the word, and an inspiration to others. Always humble about his accomplishments, he was still able to share his experiences in an engaging and enthralling manner. Dr. Slocum is survived by his beloved wife Barbara Ruane. Donations in Dr. Slocum's name may be made to the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center, DUMC 3624, Durham, NC 27710.

GAMING: Overseas, the annual arrival of Football Manager, Sports Interactive's awesomely nerdy soccer simulation game, is greeted with the sort of acquisitive giddiness we Yanks reserve for the opening of doughnut franchises. One year, the game was said to have figured in some 37 divorce cases in Britain, which is patently ridiculous for the simple reason that it suggests there are 37 Brits who don't play Football Manager. Here in the United States, Worldwide Soccer Manager ($29.99, Macintosh and Windows XP), as the game is known, arrived last fall as a far less mainstream proposition. But it has managed to find a following in the growing American community of soccer-mad brainiacs. The game features real players and real teams, with the user calling the shots from the front office and the sidelines. You control nearly every aspect of the game -- tactics, transfers, pep talks, press manipulation -- but the game itself, which unfolds as a clash of scurrying colored dots, looks like an ant farm with crowd noise.
Pop Jon Pareles

SCHWARTZ--M. Stephen, M.D., at home at the age of 95. Beloved husband and friend of Doris for over 60 years; loving father of Richard and his wife Jacqueline Olds; devoted grandfather of Nathaniel and Sarah. He was a graduate of Columbia College and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. A deeply caring and sympathetic physician, he retired from 54 years of private practice in Manhattan in 1991 but continued caring for patients at Bellevue Hospital until his own hospitalization in 1999. An Assistant Professor of Clinical Medicine, he was on the staff of NYU Medical Center for 55 years and on the staff of the New York Infirmary, Cabrini, Doctors and Midtown Hospitals. Col. Schwartz, USA Ret., served his country with distinction for five and onehalf years in World War II from April 1941 to October 1946, participating in the North Africa-Middle East and European Campaigns, landing on Normandy Beach DDay +3. He was decorated with the Bronze Star, Soldiers Medal, Croix de Guerre, New York State Conspicuous Service Medal, and Distinguished Flying Cross. He was a strong and gentle man, with a dry sense of humor, diverse cultural interests, and a depth of knowledge that only gradually revealed itself to those who knew him well. He was totally dedicated to his family and patients, encouraging of others, and reticent about his own achievements. Services Monday, March 3, 2008, 11:30am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway, Suite 300, NY, NY 10019.

WRIGHT--Alan Harriman, 79, of Muttontown, NY, died peacefully at home early Monday morning February 25. Born in NYC on August 5, 1928 to Boykin Cabell Wright and Miriam Harriman, Alan is survived by his children, Melita, Glenn and Philip, seven grandchildren and his identical twin Boyd. He graduated from the Buckley School 1943, St. Paul's 1947, Princeton 1951 and Harvard Law 1954. In 1956, he joined the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, where he was admitted as partner in 1969. His principal client over the years was Citigroup specializing in the leasing of commercial aircraft. He is credited with a number of innovations to facilitate the purchases of airline equipment and retired in 1993. Alan served in the US Army 1954-1956 and later as Village Justice for the Village of Muttontown and as a Vestryman of Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, NY. The family is having an informal Memorial Service at 1100 Avalon Square, Glen Cove, NY, Tuesday March 4, 12-3. (avalonglencovenorth.com). In lieu of flowers, we request that donations be made to your local animal shelter.

VOGEL--Dr. Leonard K., 99, Fifth Avenue Dentist dies in Colorado Springs, CO, February 23, 2008. Dr. Leonard Kenneth Vogel, died last Thursday evening. Dr. Vogel was a distinguished member of the New York Dental Society. He taught at NYU, lectured internationally, maintained a specialty dental practice on Fifth Avenue for thirty years. During WWII he directed the first dental hospital in China for the US Army, ascending to the rank of Major. He received numerous medals including: A Bronze Star, American Theater Campaign Ribbon, The Asiatic Theater Campaign Ribbon, and The Special Breast Order of the Cloud and Banner with Ribbon and Diploma awarded to him by the Chinese Government. He founded Vogel/Lorber, a Wall Street firm. A visionary in Real Estate, he syndicated investment groups developing Orlando and Sebring, FL in the early 1950s. He is survived by his wife of 72 years Cecile Vogel, and daughters Virginia and Lisbeth, grandchildren Erin and Craig and two greatgrandchildren. A ''Celebration'' of his life will be held Saturday, March 15, 2008, at 11am, at the Village at Skyline, Colorado Springs, CO. Contact Lisbeth Graham 719 530-2089.

GALLAGHER--Lacey Wingham, 45, of New York, New York, beloved wife, daughter, sister, aunt and niece, died on February 27, 2008. Lacey departed this earth peacefully at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a three year battle with ovarian cancer surrounded by her family and a close friend. Lacey was born on June 28, 1962 in New York to Trudi and Hugh Gallagher. Lacey grew up on the east coast and abroad, most notably in Hong Kong and the Philippines. She graduated from Wellesley College and Princeton University's prestigious Woodrow Wilson School and had a distinguished career as an emerging markets economist, most recently as a Managing Director at Credit Suisse. She was also a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. Lacey loved travel, people and all things beautiful. She radiated joy to all who knew her. Lacey is survived by her husband, Mark Carlebach of New York City; parents Trudi and Hugh Gallagher of Armonk, NY; brother Keith Gallagher, niece and nephew Jessica and Matthew Gallagher of Scottsdale, AZ; uncle Roman Weber of Geneva, Switzerland; and minischnauzer, Trixie -all of whom loved her and felt loved by her. Family will receive friends on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Monday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (www. ocrf.org) or The Ovarian Cancer National Alliance (www.ovariancancer.org) in the name of Lacey Wingham Gallagher.

Taking Play Seriously Robin Marantz Henig (Feb. 17) begins and ends her article with the psychiatrist Stuart Brown's focus on the meaning and joy of play, but she devotes the body of the article to looking for the reasons for play in recent interspecies studies. I half expected some researcher had claimed to have found a play gene. It is not enough to look at comparative brain studies. The interest generated by Brown's lecture at the New York Public Library calls for the addition of a more reflective approach from the social sciences and philosophy. Plato observed that play was a given quality of animal nature. In ''The Laws,'' he wrote that all young animals ''leap and bound, they dance and frolic, as it were with glee.''

BOWMER--John V. Jack died on February 23, 2008 after a long illness. Raised in Pittsburgh and Buffalo, he graduated from Amherst College in 1952. He completed Officers Candidate School in the U.S. Army just as the armistice was signed for the Korean War. Jack retired from Citigroup as a Senior Vice President after 35 years. He then held a consulting position with the Bank of New Zealand in Auckland, New Zealand for two years. Friends and associates will remember him for his strong professional ethics as a ''banker's banker'' and especially for his martini-dry sense of humor. Jack is survived by Janet, his wife of 34 years, his four children, Nancy, Deborah, John and James and by six grandchildren. There will be no services at his request. In lieu of flowers, the family would greatly appreciate donations to Huntington Hospital, Office of Philanthropy, 100 West California Blvd., Pasadena, CA 91105.

DEERING--Michael Joseph, age 51, died on February 29, 2008, peacefully at home surrounded by family, of a GBM brain tumor. Michael had a sterling approach to life filled with enthusiasm that inspired and delighted all who met him. His presence will be sorely missed by all. His courage and spirit resonate within us. Michael graduated from Nazareth High School. He became a member of the NYSE and a director at UBS. Michael is predeceased by his parents, Albert R. and Patricia (Farley). Michael is survived by his loving wife and best friend of 23 years, Janet (Saaf). He is also survived by eight devoted siblings, twelve nieces, three nephews, three godchildren, and was blessed with wonderful friends. Visiting will be Monday and Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm, McManus Funeral Home, 4601 Avenue N (Corner of E. 46th St.) Brooklyn, NY.
