NANON--Patricia N. The Yard, Inc. extends condolences to the family of our choreographer founder, Patricia N. Nanon. In 1972, Patricia established The Yard on Martha's Vineyard to foster the creation of new choreographic works. The dance world will miss Patricia's spark and pursuit of excellence. We salute Patricia's dedication to choreography and pledge ourselves to her legacy. The Trustees of The Yard, Inc. NANON--Patricia, of New York City and Chilmark, Massachusetts, died peacefully on February 29, in her home in New York City surrounded by her loving daughters. She was 84. Ms. Nanon, a choreographer, was a 1944 graduate of Bennington College and the Founder and long time Artistic Director of The Yard, a colony for the performing arts on Martha's Vineyard. The Yard is a treasured part of both the Vineyard and the contemporary dance world, which has often honored her for her vision and generosity. She is survived by her daughters Vicki Woolner Samuels of Chicago, Cate Woolner of Northfield, Massachusetts, and Justine Woolner Wise of Oneonta, New York, their families, many devoted nieces and nephews and their families, as well as many dear friends. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Martha's Vineyard at a later date.

DeLaCOUR--Margaret J. 63, of Brooklyn Heights and Glen Cove, New York died on Monday, February 18th, after a sudden illness on board the cruise ship Corinthian II, upon her return from a trip to Antarctica with the New York Yacht Club. Beloved wife of Willis S. DeLaCour Jr., mother of Dirk, Russell and Sophie, daughter of Bertha K. Jones and brother of David R. Jones, Peggy was born to Justice and Mrs. Thomas R. Jones in 1944. Raised in Bedford Stuyvesant, she attended Hunter High School and the University of Pennsylvania, where she graduated with a degree in History in 1966. She later attended Columbia University as a graduate student in Chinese studies, and received her MA in Public Administration from NYU in 1984. In her long career, she served in a number of senior level positions in New York City government, at the Department of Environmental Protection, the NYC Water Board and the Brooklyn Borough President's Office. Throughout her life she followed her pursuits with intensity, inspired by a love of learning and a thirst for knowledge. She served on a number of nonprofit Boards, including The Junior League of Brooklyn, Colony South Brooklyn, Grace Church School and the Planting Field Arboretum of Oyster Bay. She and her husband, Wids also supported numerous organizations dedicated to providing educational and outdoor opportunities for New York City children. Peggy was an avid traveler and a passionate gardener who appreciated every detail of life. She will be missed by all and remembered for her devotion to family and friends. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church on Saturday, March 15, at 4:00pm, located at 254 Hicks St., in Brooklyn Heights. The family prefers in lieu of flowers that contributions be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11225 or to the Planting Field Arboretum, Planting Field Foundation, PO Box 660, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

WEISS--Gloria (Dymond), age 85, on February 26, 2008. Born in Brooklyn, NY, October 20th, 1922, Gloria graduated Erasmus Hall High School at age 16, Brooklyn College at age 20, and received her Masters in Education at Columbia University. A New York City schoolteacher for 20 years at PS221 and PS132, Gloria was a longtime resident of Rockville Centre, NY and Hollywood, FL. Her vivacious spirit lit up all who came in contact with her. She was the daughter of the late Nathan and Rae Dymond, beloved wife for 47 years of the late Meyer (Mickey) Weiss, and devoted sister of the late Jonas Dymond. She is survived by her sons Jonathan (Kiyo) and Fredric (Fran), and her adoring grandchildren Taylor, Jacob, Kyra and Michael. Memorial donations may be made to Women's American ORT or Hadassah.

GALLO--Dr. Gloria. The Department of Pathology at New York University School of Medicine sadly notes the death of Dr. Gloria R. Gallo, our colleague and a major educator, investigator, and administrator for the past 52 years. Her laboratory contributed toward our understanding and treating manifestations of medical diseases of the kidneys. Dr. Gallo's good sense, generosity, and high spirits guided and inspired thousands of patients, students, and colleagues over the years. Contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated by her family and friends.

MOSS--Betty. The Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Betty Moss. Mrs. Moss served on the board for many years. Her late husband, Joseph Moss, also served on the board. Mrs. Moss passed away on February 29, 2008 at the age 97 in New York. Mrs. Moss was active in her community as a tireless advocate for the elderly. She was an officer of the Flatbush League and the Town League which were auxiliaries of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged before they became part of Metropolitan Jewish Health System. Prior to retirement, she worked at Moss Advertisement Agency for more than 30 years. She will be greatly missed. May her memory be for a blessing. Services will be held Sunday, March 2nd 2008; 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel. 180 West 76th St. New York, NY. Shiva at Alan Cornet, 185 Park Dr., Eastchester, NY. Shmuel Lefkowitz, Chairman, Metropolitan Jewish Health System Eli S. Feldman, President and CEO, Metropolitan Jewish Health System

GABRIEL--John, born January 27th, 1930 in Budapest, Hungary, died February 28th, 2008 in Nelville, NY. He was the beloved husband of Kathryn and father of Dan. Your good nature and sense of humor will be remembered by all who knew you.

GROBSTEIN--Ruth Hirsch Beloff. Born to Bernard and Sarah Hirsch on January 2, 1924 in New York City, Ruth Grobstein died peacefully of pulmonary failure with her daughters at her side on February 25th. She was a woman of great strength and a distinguished biologist and oncologist, receiving a BA from NYU, Ph.D. in Biology from Yale, and M.D. from UCLA while in her 50s. She was the Founding Director of the Ida and Cecil Green Cancer Center at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, where she pioneered treatment of breast cancer without mastectomy. Ruth was predeceased by her beloved husband, Clifford Grobstein, and is survived by her daughters and sons-in-law, Sandy and Jim Wilbur of NYC and Vermont, Beth Beloff and Marc Geller of Houston, TX, and Robin Beloff-Wachsberg and Abe Wachsberg of Santa Rosa, CA, as well as 12 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Memorial service will take place on April 6 at 1:00 at the Inn at Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Her family will receive friends at her home following the memorial. Donations can be made to San Diego Hospice or breast cancer research.

PRUYN--Emilia D. It is with great sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of Emilia D. Pruyn, 80, who died Wednesday, February 27, 2008 on Long Island, NY. A retired NYC teacher, she directed countless choruses, and worked with the Queens Borough Wide Chorus for a number of years. A member of NYSSMA, she taught piano and voice privately to many young people, inspiring and supporting their creative and intellectual talents. Emilia leaves behind her daughters Pamela and Deborah Pruyn, her sister Vanna Simonetta and two grandchildren who meant the world to her, Robert Pruyn-Bush and Samantha Guevrekian. Her love of life, passion for music, effervescence and total devotion to her family, will be sorely missed. She was our rock. Wake in Queensbury, NY at Sullivan, Minahan & Potter. Details: 518-792-2067.

FRIEDMAN--Selma, February 29, 2008. Beloved mother of Marcy and Richard Friedman and Betsy Friedman Vogel, grandmother of Lilli, Billy, Harry and Jack; sparkling wit; avid golfer. We will miss her immensely.

SOHIER--Walter Denegre, 83, of Manhattan, NY, and Paris, France, died February 26. Raised in Boston and Manchester, MA, he graduated from Harvard College and Columbia Law School. He served in the Army during WWII, receiving a Purple Heart for wounds inflicted during the Battle of the Bulge. He was General Counsel for NASA during the Kennedy administration and most recently worked for the firm of Frere Cholmeley in Paris, trying cases before the World Court in The Hague. He was also an accomplished pianist, a connoisseur of the arts, and a voracious reader. Known for his quick wit, great charm, and blazing blue eyes, Sohier was feisty to the end. His family and friends will miss his humor, brilliance, fairness, outspokenness, and bravery. His marriage to Wendy Burden (Morgan) ended in divorce. He is survived by his daughters, Elaine Sohier Gayler of Los Altos, CA, and Sage Sohier of Brookline, MA, and by his partner, Lee Hutton, of NYC. A private memorial service will be held in the Spring.

Most Connecticut syrup is sold directly to customers at sugarhouses, with some local product available at specialty stores and Whole Foods. The Connecticut Department of Agriculture provides the most complete list. (Click on link to ''Maple Sugarhouses'' at www.ct.gov/doag/cwp.) Maple syrup grades are based on color and flavor -- both of which are pretty much the opposite of what logic would suggest. The lighter the color, the more delicate the flavor, the higher the grade and the higher the price.

WELLS--Aaron, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Aaron Wells. Clinical associate professor of medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College and the former director of one of the country's first adult methadone clinics -the Adult Substance Abuse Program at NewYorkPresbyterian -he helped countless addicts recover and resume healthy and productive lives. In 1964, Dr. Wells was elected the first national chairman of the Medical Committee for Human Rights, working closely with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to bring medical aid to civil rights workers in the South. As founder of a task force to assist minority students at Cornell University, president of the Empire State Political Action Committee of Black Physicians, and a member of the board of Hale House, he was a leader and humanitarian deeply committed to the needs of the medically and politically underserved. An accomplished research scientist, he contributed to our understanding of opiate dependency. A thoughtful and erudite teacher, researcher, administrator, community activist and clinician, Dr. Wells, together with his wife, Rhoda Wynn Wells, was an active and much loved member of the Medical Center community. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wells family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

NOONAN--Patricia M., who died at the age of 41 on December 11, 2007, is to be remembered March 9 at NYU School of Law, Washington Square South at 3:00pm. Friends and colleagues are invited. Patty, a non-smoker and avid runner, was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer six months post partum. She bravely used up every last molecule of energy fighting the disease for nine months. Patty's sole purpose was to live as long as possible for her infant daughter Lily Frances; she met that goal dutifully and with grace. Raised primarily in Richmond, VA, Patty and her husband Christopher Malone lived for over 20 years in NYC before moving to Verona, NJ in 2005. Patty served as Sr. VP of policy and economic development at the Partnership for NYC & NYC Investment Fund at time of her death. She was a member of the 2000-2001 Coro Foundation's leadership NY class. The NYLCV newsletter stated ''New York City lost one of its best and brightest advocates for environmental sustainability''. Patty is survived by her daughter Lily, her husband, Christopher, her mother Beth Noonan, her father Jack Noonan and her sister Kathy Farrow. A fellowship has been established in Patty's name at NYU. Contributions can be sent to NYU-WagnerNoonan Fund, c/o Lisa Taylor; 295 Lafayette St., 2nd floor; NY, NY 10012. An education fund is being established for Lily Frances Malone. More information will be available at the March 9th event.

The Bronx district attorney’s office has decided to pursue criminal perjury charges against an engineer whose failure to fully inspect a Bronx construction job was cited in a Fire Department report on the deaths of two firefighters, John Sullivan reports. Firefighter Michael C. Reilly and his boss, Lt. Howard J. Carpluk Jr., were fighting a fire in a Walton Avenue discount store in August 2006 when rotting support columns gave way, the floor collapsed and they were trapped, the report concluded.

Since 1973, the griddled frankfurters at Gray’s Papaya, home of the $3.50 “Recession Special” (two franks and a 14-ounce drink), have been served with fresh fruit juices, tangy sauerkraut and a side of politics.Nicholas A. B. Gray, the chain’s founder and resident pundit, has offered endorsements of candidates seeking the presidential nomination from Jimmy Carter in 1976 to Bill Bradley in 1999 to, most recently, the noncandidate Michael R. Bloomberg.Last August, Mr. Gray, 71, began displaying signs at two of his three stores encouraging the candidacy of the mayor with the slogan “Run Mike, Run!” He told The Times in October that he was hoping for a Bloomberg run for the White House because “he’s cool under pressure” and he believed that the mayor’s personal wealth made him less corruptible.

The issue of New York magazine published today contains a lengthy profile of Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, by Geoffrey Gray. The article has caused a furor in Albany, with Mr. Bruno’s staff members asserting that the reporter violated the terms of the interview. The magazine says that it “fully stands behind” its story and that Mr. Bruno understood he was speaking on the record.

Updated, 5:45 p.m. | The first undercover detective to enter an exotic dancing club in Queens hours before Sean Bell’s shooting had misgivings from the start, telling his lieutenant he was uncomfortable with the size and rowdiness of the crowd at Club Kalua, the detective testified on Monday.“‘There’s more guys, it’s a lot rowdier,’” the detective, Hispolito Sanchez, 36, said he told Lt. Gary Napoli that night, Nov. 24, 2006. His fellow detective, Gescard F. Isnora, sat beside him, but Detective Sanchez was concerned about a man giving him “hard” looks from across the room. “I didn’t feel comfortable,” he testified.

Elliot G. Sander, executive director and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, used what officials called the first State of the M.T.A. address this morning to outline an ambitious plan for growth in subway, rail and bus service by the year 2050.

Mary Gordon was named the New York State author, and Jean Valentine was named the state poet today, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s office announced. The honorary two-year designations, which each carry an honorarium of $10,000, are made by the New York State Writers Institute. The two writers will promote fiction and poetry across the state through a series of public readings and talks.

Many parents think about how much TV their kids watch, and they worry about the content of television programs. But research shows parents also should consider the location of the set itself. My Well column in Tuesday's Science Times takes a look at the effect that a television in the bedroom has on a child. Studies show bedroom television is associated with poor schoolwork, sleep problems, obesity and even higher smoking risk.

Daniel Menaker's online book show, "Titlepage," makes its debut today. With all the standings from the European leagues circulating around Slap Shot, one might forget that hockey is also played on this side of the Atlantic.

Much as DealBook expected, Diebold is pointing to its bookkeeping problems as a reason shareholders should give the cold shoulder to United Technologies.

Barack Obama could be called as a witness for his longtime friend and accused Illinois fixer Tony Rezko, according to Chicago lawyers following the case."

Chelsea won handily at West Ham this weekend, 4-0, but the Blues lost the midfield engine Frank Lampard when he was shown a straight red card for reportedly shoving Luis Boa Morte. He was slapped with a three-match ban and, tempting fate, Chelsea has decided to appeal.

Since 1973, the griddled frankfurters at Gray's Papaya, home of the $3.50 "Recession Special" (two franks and a 14-ounce drink), have been served with fresh fruit juices, tangy sauerkraut and a side of politics.

According to an article in USA Today last week, memoirs have survived their James Frey moment and entered a new golden age. More memoirs than ever are being published, and last year they even outpaced first novels, 295 to 227.

Politicians and foreign manufacturers aren't the only ones besieging Ohio these days. On Sunday, Connecticut's United Technologies sent a "bear hug" letter to Ohio-based Diebold Industries. The letter proposed an acquisition of Diebold at a price of $40 a share and described a failed two-year courtship between the two companies.

With President Vladimir V. Putin's endorsement assuring more than enough votes for Dmitri A. Medvedev, the result of Russia's election was hardly in doubt. But there was room for debate on a finer point: would the protégé exceed his patron?
Get used to hearing the tagline "Fox is America's favorite."
Monday brought a slew of news about assassination plots at various stages of development.

ESPN, which dominates sports on television, is collaborating with Creative Artists Agency and Walt Disney Studios to produce and distribute theatrical films, Brooks Barnes reports in Monday's New York Times. The network "is also hiring 30 filmmakers to produce one-hour mini-movies to appear on the channel starting in September 2009."
(Francois Guillot/AFP/Getty)

When carrots are cooked, it's often a sad affair. They are boiled to death and presented almost as an apology. Yet when they're treated with the respect they deserve, even ordinary supermarket carrots can be among the most reliable and enjoyable of vegetables, especially from fall through spring. What constitutes respect? A technique that does not produce waterlogged, soggy carrots and one that complements their natural sweetness. Grilling and roasting do the trick with little trouble, but so does this braise-and-glaze technique, which can be varied at will and which can also be used with other roots, like beets, turnips and radishes.
CNBC interviews Floyd Norris, chief financial correspondent of The Times, on the number of foreclosures in some states exceeding home sales.

If there needed to be a reminder of how crazy college basketball can get at this time of year, this weekend certainly provided one. There were terrific individual performances, inexplicable losses and several off-the-court matters of intrigue.
A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

In Cambridge, Ohio, we sat down with one of our voters in the Open Caucus roundtable to talk about Tuesday's primary and the issues on the minds of Ohioans. Stephen Heine, 62, a moderate Republican, has decided to support Senator John McCain, although he said he had favored former Senator Fred Thompson before he dropped out of the race.
TOLEDO, Ohio - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would make no predictions about Tuesday's primaries in Texas and Ohio or comment on what the results might mean for her campaign.

Elizabeth Edwards and her family are in mourning today after the death of her father, a war veteran and, by her description, a man of many friends and many talents.

When I interviewed Jason Giambi for an article about Johan Santana's changeup, the Yankees' slugger segued into a discussion of Pedro Martinez and David Cone. Believe it or not, Giambi said that he loved facing Martinez and Cone because of their creativity. Giambi loves the challenge of guessing along with pitchers.

The event took place on Saturday, but given the subject - belittling of John McCain's wartime experience - and the speaker - Gloria Steinem - it's still the talk of the blogosphere Monday morning.
Congress is set to get serious about the federal budget this week as both the Senate and House begin writing spending plans in separate committee sessions.

One argument I've been hearing a lot lately runs as follows: "Low interest rates got us into this mess, so it's crazy to think that low interest rates are the solution."

In an "SNL" career that has spanned 27 seasons over 32 years, James Downey "has written much of the show's most enduring political comedy, anticipating the sentiment of the moment as often as responding to it," Dave Itzkoff reports in Monday's New York Times.
The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, said Monday that it had hired Oliver Sarkozy, one of UBS's top investment bankers for financial services deals, to work as co-head of a similar practice.

When Michael D. Eisner is behind an Internet hit ("Prom Queen"), you know the Web isn't in Kansas anymore. His old employer is not to be outdone either. Here are a couple of episodes from the ABC.com online series "Squeegees," about slacker window-washers:
E*Trade Financial, the online bank and broker, plans to give Donald Layton, currently its chairman, the additional role of chief executive, The Wall Street Journal reported.

China Merchants Bank is interested in buying into a planned initial public offering of shares by Visa, the credit card network, but any deal would first need Chinese regulatory approvals, its president Ma Weihua said on Monday.

Hundreds of skeptics in the global-warming debate are convening in New York today and tomorrow. The meeting, sponsored by the Heartland Institute, is an assortment of climate scientists, economists and free-market think-tankers -- some who have impressive credentials, some of whom are listed in the conference program simply as "Scientist" or "Meteorologist." Sorting out the wheat from the chaff will not be easy, but here's one way to start: Check out this report being presented at the conference today.
Does Wall Street underrate Main Street?

Countrywide Home Loans, the troubled mortgage lender that has agreed to be sold to the Bank of America, engaged in questionable conduct in a bankruptcy case involving two borrowers in Atlanta, the United States Trustee contended in a lawsuit filed late Thursday.

Phillip Goldstein, who two years ago successfully sued the Securities and Exchange Commission to overturn a rule requiring hedge fund managers to register as investment advisers, is planning to sue the regulator to lift its ban on hedge fund marketing and advertising.
As investment banks cope with the growing economic slowdown, so too are big law firms. According to the Legal Intelligencer, the latest to pare down its associates roster is Dechert.

When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesn't know when to leave the stage.
Companies have shelved initial public offerings totaling $21.4 billion so far this year, almost double the value of new equity issuance, Thomson Financial data showed.
A shareholder group has proposed the ouster of the entire corporate board at Circuit City Stores, the electronics retailer.
The German carmaker Volkswagen said on Monday it would raise its stake in a Swedish truck maker, Scania, to 68.6 percent, a move that may lead to a merger of Scania and the German truck maker MAN.
A shareholder group pressing for change at The New York Times officially proposed its own set of directors for four vacant seats on Friday.

Candover, the private equity firm, has made an approach to acquire Expro International, an oilfield services company, in a deal that could value Expro at 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion), The Financial Times reported.
Barclays , the British bank, acquired a Russian lender, Expobank for $745 million in its first overseas acquisition since losing the bidding contest for ABN Amro Holding.

Profit at HSBC, the European bank, rose 10 percent last year, just below analysts' forecasts, as strong gains in Asia helped it absorb a $17.2 billion hit for bad debts related largely to housing problems in the United States.

Xstrata said on Monday it was still in deal talks with Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil after reporting that its profit more than tripled for the year, helped by the $18 billion acquisition of Falconbridge and by ravenous emerging-markets demand for metals.

Y Combinator has seeded about 80 start-ups since 2005 through a series of remarkably small investments -- "just barely enough to cover living expenses for three months," the San Jose Mercury News writes.

The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett disclosed Friday that he had earned profits for shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway by speculating in the Brazilian currency, the real, and by buying a large stake in a French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi-Aventis.

HSBC Holdings, Europe's largest bank, said Friday it had received an offer of about $3.2 billion in cash for its French regional banking subsidiaries from France's Banque Federale des Banques Populaires.
Restoration Hardware, a retailer of home furnishings and gifts, accepted a buyout bid from Catterton Partners, a private equity firm, after deciding a competing bid from Sears Holdings was inferior.

A lawyer for Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader who Société Générale says cost it 4.9 billion euros in losses, on Friday accused the bank of not looking deeply enough at dozens of people in its management hierarchy during a recent internal investigation into the trading scandal.
Seven Bank, a Japanese bank that provides A.T.M. services, rose 24 percent on its market listing on Friday in the biggest initial public offering in Japan since October.

KKR Private Equity Investors, the publicly traded buyout fund of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, wrote down stakes in seven investments as a slowing economy hurt earnings and declining bond prices eroded the value of holdings.
Almost a decade after spinning off the auto parts maker Delphi and more than two years after Delphi filed for bankruptcy, General Motors still finds itself shelling out cash to its former subsidiary.

Yelp, whose Web site lets users review restaurants and other local services, isn't likely to hold an initial public offering anytime soon, its chief executive, Jeremy Stoppelman, told The Deal's VC Ratings blog.
An Australian miner, Oxiana, bid 6 billion Australian dollars ($5.6 billion) for Zinifex on Monday to expand its zinc output and diversify into other metals.

Hollywood and Silicon Valley have something of a Mars/Venus problem: the two sides are talking but they don't speak each other's language. A new venture involving a phone company may just add Pluto into the mix.

A partnership led by the billionaire investor Carl Icahn exercised an option to buy 50.1 million shares of Federal-Mogul, the auto supplier, raising his ownership to 75 percent, according to a federal filing this week.
Peloton Partners, the hedge fund manager that is liquidating a $1.8 billion asset-backed fund, says that it is a victim of Wall Street's reduced lending.

ARAB JABOUR, Iraq - A former stronghold of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, this rural and overwhelmingly Sunni area south of Baghdad on the west bank of the Tigris was once a country getaway for Saddam Hussein's cronies. His sons Uday and Qusay had a weekend house here.

At first glance, good news is tough to find in Ernst & Young's annual report on the state of the global real estate market. "The situation isn't likely to ease in 2008," writes Dale Anne Reiss, global real estate director for the consulting firm.

Donald Layton was appointed chief executive of E-Trade on Monday and said there were no plans to sell or break up the embattled online brokerage.
Sales, when adjusted for one more selling day in 2008, fell by at least 10 percent at all three Detroit automakers.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said that they would stop buying loans from lenders that do not use independent home appraisers, as part of an agreement with the attorney general of New York.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will establish a new home appraisal watchdog to prevent fraud as part of a settlement with Attorney General Andrew Cuomo of New York.
Gazprom cut about a quarter of the gas supply to Ukraine to try to force the country to settle a debt, but it took pains to emphasize that supplies to Western Europe would not be affected.
The Bush administration joined with the European Union in filing suit with the World Trade Organization to protest China’s rules governing foreign financial news services.
Dr. David B. Allison resigned as president of the Obesity Society, a research group, after being criticized for an affidavit he wrote as a paid consultant on behalf of the restaurant industry.
HBO is joining forces for the first time with the Postal Service, for a multimillion-dollar, multimedia campaign that is all about the write stuff.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Senator Barack Obama of deception as new evidence of discord surfaced within her own camp.
John Rigas, the Adelphia Communications founder, and his son, Timothy, lost their final appeal of their convictions for fraud that led to the collapse of the cable television company.
A divided Supreme Court is leaving intact a ruling favoring people who sued a pharmaceutical company, saying they had been harmed by a drug to combat diabetes.
Oil prices rose to nearly $104 a barrel, exceeding the inflation-adjusted high reached in the early 1980s.
Merck said that more than 93 percent of the 47,000 people who allege that the arthritis drug Vioxx caused their heart attack or stroke have submitted claims in the company’s settlement offer.
The European Union and the United States brought a case against China at the World Trade Organization over the way Beijing regulates foreign providers of financial information.
Stocks ended flat on Wall Street in a meandering day as record lows for the dollar and all-time high prices for oil and gold were offset by a better-than expected report on the manufacturing sector.
Asian stocks dropped and the U.S. dollar fell to a three-year low against the yen on speculation the Fed may lower rates further to soften a possible recession.
A veteran Newark police detective was charged with sexually abusing a teenage girl from West Orange repeatedly during a span of four years, according to the Essex County prosecutor’s office.

. Henry Cejudo earned an Olympic berth for the United States in the 121-pound freestyle division in the Pan American Wrestling Championships in Colorado Springs. Cejudo pinned Andy Gonzales of Cuba in the second round of their title match. Cejudo is not yet assured a trip to Beijing. Olympic qualifying events give berths to countries, not individual wrestlers. Cejudo and others still must qualify at the United States trials on June 13-15 in Las Vegas.
Echoes of his own life led a cab driver, who initially claimed that a stranger abandoned the baby in his car, to want the child to have a better life.

An article in some editions last Monday about an Oscar party in West Orange, N.J., to celebrate “Freeheld,” a film that chronicled the struggle of a lesbian Ocean County prosecutor’s investigator to win benefits for her partner, misspelled, in some copies, the surname of a partygoer who said she felt “a rush of joy” when “Freeheld” won the Oscar for best documentary short subject. She is Joan Hervey, not Harvey.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek of the Czech Republic misidentified the photographer in some editions. The picture of the two leaders in the Oval Office was taken by Larry Downing of Reuters, not by Stephen Crowley of The New York Times.

A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions last Monday about Lloyd Constantine, an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York who is backing Barack Obama in the Democratic presidential contest instead of the governor’s choice, Hillary Rodham Clinton, misspelled the surname of a former business associate of Mr. Constantine’s who he said convinced him that Mr. Obama was the candidate to back. He is Bob Rivkin, not Rifkin.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek of the Czech Republic misidentified the photographer in some editions. The picture of the two leaders in the Oval Office was taken by Larry Downing of Reuters, not by Stephen Crowley of The New York Times.

A picture caption with an article in Business Day last Monday about an e-mail newsletter on business journalists from Gorkana, a British public relations firm, omitted the credit. The photograph, of Rob Ingram, director of Gorkana in Manhattan, was taken by Annie Tritt for The New York Times.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the troubles of Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit carried an erroneous credit. As an another caption with the article noted, Rebecca Cook, who took the photograph of the mayor’s residence, works for Reuters — not for The Associated Press.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about the expanded Brooklyn Children’s Museum, which is to open in May, referred incorrectly to its possible certification as a “green” children’s museum by the Green Building Council’s Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design program. Other children’s museums have received such certification; the Brooklyn museum would not be the first in the nation.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about the N.F.L.’s modest free-agent market this off-season misstated the timing of an increase of more than $30 million in the league’s salary cap. It was put in place in 2005, not “this year.”.

Bluffton University played its season-opening game Sunday on a high school diamond in Sarasota, Fla., with the bleachers filled mostly with families and friends of the players. On the same day in 2007, a crash of the team’s charter bus in Atlanta killed five players from Bluffton, a small Ohio college, and two other people.Bluffton lost, 4-3, to Eastern Mennonite, the same team it was supposed to play on the day of the crash. “We haven’t forgotten our teammates, but we’ve kind of taken the next step,” said Bluffton’s Matt Perkins, who pitched eight innings in the loss. “We’re getting over it, and we’re trying to work through it, and I think today we focused a lot on baseball, and I don’t think a lot of us were thinking about the accident.”.

The former Iranian star Ali Daei was hired as the men’s national team coach and will try to lead Iran to a second straight appearance in the World Cup. In the last two months, the Iran soccer federation announced the hiring of at least two foreign coaches, including Arthur George of Portugal and Javier Clemente of Spain. Neither reached a final agreement.

The competitive portion of the 1,100-mile Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race started Sunday with Cim Smyth of Big Lake leaving the restart first in Willow, Alaska. The defending champion, Lance Mackey of Fairbanks, was fifth. Mackey is fresh off a close victory in the 1,000-mile Yukon Quest International Sled Dog Race, considered by many to be an even tougher race. Last year, Mackey became the first to win the Quest and the Iditarod.

The Ultimate Fighting Championship titleholder Anderson Silva choked out Dan Henderson, a champion in the rival Pride Fighting Championships series, at 4 minutes 52 seconds of the second round to claim middleweight supremacy at U.F.C. 82 on Saturday night in Columbus, Ohio.

Steve Darcis of Belgium won his second ATP title, defeating Robin Soderling of Sweden, 6-3, 7-6 (5), in the final at the Regions Morgan Keegan Championships in Memphis. Darcis won in the Netherlands last year as a qualifier. Soderling, playing in his second straight ATP final, upset top-seeded Andy Roddick to reach the semifinals.

The former Green Bay Packers receiver Max McGee, who scored the first touchdown in Super Bowl history, was investigated for illegal gambling by the F.B.I. after his career ended, newly released records show. Agents looked into McGee’s activities from late 1972 through September 1973 before dropping the case for lack of evidence, according to records released to The Associated Press under the Freedom of Information Act. McGee died in October.
The city’s Administration for Children’s Services is beginning a new advertising campaign that hopes to attract workers while informing them how difficult the job can be.
As many states contemplate painful budget cuts and wrestle with ballooning deficits, Gov. Eliot Spitzer has proposed adding about $6 billion to this year’s budget.
Prosecutors seek to prove that the three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell did not identify themselves before they opened fire.
Some states and cities say Wall Street ratings firms assign municipal borrowers inappropriately low credit scores.
Three days into the free-agent signing period, with every other marquee player already off the market, receiver Randy Moss remained available.

A man rammed a borrowed Cadillac into a crowd of people outside a Newark club early Saturday, killing a woman and pushing up the city’s homicide count to four in 2008.

Against San Antonio, the team with the best record in the loaded Western Conference, the Nets were behind virtually the entire game despite another strong performance from Devin Harris.

Steve Valiquette gave up one goal and celebrated a shootout victory as its most unlikely star. The win kept the Rangers in seventh place in the Eastern Conference.

After the magnetic resonance imaging test on Carlos Delgado’s right hip came back negative Saturday, the Mets announced that he had an impingement of his hip.

Cetera DeGraffenreid scored 14 points Sunday to help No. 2 North Carolina defeat No. 12 Duke, 82-51, in Chapel Hill, N.C.
Tatiana Aryasova of Russia made a smashing marathon debut Sunday, taking advantage of a head start on the male runners to capture the Los Angeles Marathon.
Andy Pettitte held the Phillies to a walk and an infield single and Jason Giambi pulled a Cole Hamels fastball for a three-run homer in the first inning of a 7-7 tie at Legends Field.

9:30 P.M. (TCM) THOU SHALT NOT: SEX, SIN AND CENSORSHIP IN PRE-CODE HOLLYWOOD This new documentary examines the era before the Production Code was enforced, beginning in 1934. It was one of the most intriguing periods in Hollywood history, shaped by social, financial and moral forces. TCM will also screen a few provocative examples, starting at 8 with ''The Divorcee'' (1930), starring Norma Shearer as a betrayed wife who retaliates, and continuing with ''Night Nurse'' (1931), in which Barbara Stanwyck (above right with a gun-wielding Ben Lyon and Clark Gable, left) plays a nurse who untangles a plot to murder two children, at 10:45; ''Three on a Match'' (1932), starring Joan Blondell, Bette Davis and Ann Dvorak as childhood schoolmates on very different paths, at midnight; ''Female'' (1933), with Ruth Chatterton as the head of an automobile company and George Brent as her right-hand man, at 1:15 a.m.; and ''A Free Soul'' (1931), starring Shearer again, this time as a lawyer's rebel daughter who is drawn to a thug (Gable). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE ROYAL FAMILY Barbara Walters takes viewers behind the palace walls for a glimpse into the private lives of the British royal family in this documentary pieced together from hundreds of hours of film taken in public and private settings over the course of a year.

Google has added a new front to its assault on Microsoft's software applications business. Last week, Google rolled out a rival to Microsoft's SharePoint, a program used for collaboration among teams of workers. Google's service, called Google Sites (sites.google.com), will become part of the company's applications suite, which includes e-mail, calendar, word processing, spreadsheet and presentation software. Like other elements of Google Apps, it will be free and require no installation, maintenance or upgrades.

STEPHEN MALKMUS & THE JICKS ''Real Emotional Trash'' (Matador) For almost 20 years, back to his beginnings in the band Pavement, Stephen Malkmus has been famous for writing lyrics that carried no trace of rock 'n' roll sentiment. High on their own internal music, juggling vocabularies and voices, they gave no warning when their stories or rants or descriptions were going to lapse into nonsense. They were powerfully, haughtily non-sequiturial, and sung in a non-singer's voice.

KATHLEEN EDWARDS ''Asking for Flowers'' (Zoë) A few of the characters Kathleen Edwards sings about on her third album, ''Asking for Flowers,'' are probably Ms. Edwards herself: a Canadian songwriter with a breathy but obstinate voice who has played her country-rooted rock on tour far and wide. ''I've been on the road too long to sympathize/With what you think you're owed,'' she jabs at a musician who ''spends his days living in egoland'' in ''The Cheapest Key.''

O'BRIEN--Kevin J. With great sorrow his family announces his passing on March 1, 2008 after a heroic five-month battle with lung cancer. Kevin J. Unlike pitches that challenge batters with overpowering speed (fastball) or change of direction (curve, slider), the changeup is all about deception. When thrown with the expertise of Johan Santana, the changeup offers only a fleeting visual key for the batter to use to identify the pitch and to react accordingly. Batters mainly have two opportunities to decipher a pitch: by getting a glimpse of the pitcher's grip (and sometimes his body position) and by reading the pattern that the seams on the ball create. Santana's changeup delivery looks like that of his fastball or his slider. So the batter starts his swing quickly to catch up to a 90-mile-an-hour pitch, only to realize -- often too late -- that it is a changeup traveling much more slowly and diving out of the strike zone. Whiff!

CROSBIE--John C.S., of Southbridge, MA, passed away Saturday February 16 after a brief illness. He was born on Staten Island, NY to William G. John is survived by his wife of 63 years, Ada Mae, son Thomas, daughter-in-law Araceli, son Christopher, two grandchildren, 10 nieces and a brother, William R. Crosbie. MICHAEL MCDONALD ''Soul Speak'' (Motown/Universal) Michael McDonald stretches out just a little on ''Soul Speak,'' the latest in a trilogy of jukebox releases that began with ''Motown'' and ''Motown Two.'' Like its competent and commercially successful predecessors, this new record mainly confirms Mr. McDonald's stature in the related realms of blue-eyed soul and adult contemporary pop. And despite some misguided song selections -- stretching out, even just a little, isn't always a good thing -- it's the strongest of the three.

An article on Feb. 18 about Arthur J. Cooperman, the State Supreme Court judge presiding over the trial of the three New York police detectives charged in the 2006 shooting death of Sean Bell, misstated the length of his tenure as a judge in one reference. He has been on the bench for 28 years, not 18.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about coral reef research misidentified the online journal of PLoS, the Public Library of Science, that published papers on fish and microbe prevalence at reefs. It was PLoS One -- not PLoS Biology, which published a commentary on the work, as the article noted.

DJ DRAMA AND B.G. ''Hood Generals: Gangsta Grillz Special Edition'' (mixtape) A little over a year ago DJ Drama, one of hip-hop's top mixtape D.J.'s, was arrested on racketeering charges by officers working in cooperation with the Recording Industry Association of America. The association considers mixtapes -- unlicensed compilations -- a form of piracy, but labels often use them as marketing tools. For a while DJ Drama laid low; then, late last year, with charges still pending, he returned with ''Gangsta Grillz: The Album'' (Atlantic), a licensed mixtape that was his underwhelming major-label debut.

Updated, 6:30 p.m. |In another sign of the troubling economy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today will ask all city agencies to find ways to trim 3 percent more from their budgets for fiscal year 2009, which begins on July 1. The step comes on top of 2.5 percent cuts they were asked to make in the last half of this fiscal year and a 5 percent cut next year. Those cuts ended up being about 2.7 percent in the 2008 fiscal year and 4.4 percent for the 2009 fiscal year.Mark Page, the city’s chief budget officer, blamed the need for the additional reductions on Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose executive budget, Mr. Page said, contains $747 million less in financing to the city than was anticipated when budget projections were made in January.

Updated, 5:48 p.m. | Service on all three main lines of the Metro-North Railroad — the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines — was suspended at 3:15 p.m. after a vacant five-story building collapsed at 124th Street and Park Avenue, one block from the 125th Street station in Harlem, where all three lines stop on their way to and from Grand Central Terminal.

The number of people living on the streets has dropped by 12 percent since last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said this morning at a City Hall news conference, citing his administration’s annual Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which was conducted on Jan. 28.The mayor and administration officials said the decline in the so-called street homeless population, which includes those living on the subways, is because of a number of approaches, like more aggressive clearing of encampments and offering housing options with fewer restrictions.

Columbia University is unveiling a new Web site — MAAP, for Mapping the African American Past — that will use video, audio and historic maps and images to showcase 52 historic sites and people in the city, ranging from the familiar (the African Burial Ground) to the rarely acknowledged.

The road to enact Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge drivers an $8 fee to bring their cars into Manhattan below 60th Street just got a little more twisted.A group of 20 City Council members sent a letter to Mr. Bloomberg urging changes so that New Jersey commuters pay a partial fee or so that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey use a portion of tolls it collects from Manhattan-bound drivers to pay for New York City mass transit, almost half the body which must, along with the State Legislature, approve the plan for it to qualify for federal financing.

The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which explores the stories of downtrodden immigrants exploited by employers and landlords, is now the subject of a unionization drive by nearly 30 part-time tour guides who say the organization has been blocking their efforts to organize for higher wages, better benefits and more regular work schedules.
John McCain comments on the results from the March 4 primaries. (NBC Video)

1:38 p.m. | Wrapup: Well, Caucus readers, all the networks and The Times have called Texas for Mrs. Clinton. But results from the Texas caucuses (the second part of that Texas two-step) are still a little fuzzy. Only about 13 percent of those results are in, and Mr. Obama is ahead 54 percent to 46 percent. As predicted earlier, Mrs. Clinton could win the popular vote while Mr. Obama wins more delegates. (Stay tuned to the nytimes.com throughout the wee hours for the latest results.)

Updated Representative Ron Paul has won his first Republican primary of the 2008 season, The Associated Press projects. Though his Internet groundswell did not translate into a nomination for the presidency, he easily held back a challenger for his Congressional seat in Texas's 14th Congressional District. With 56 percent of precincts reporting so far, Mr. Paul has 69.4 percent of the vote, while Chris Peden has 30.6 percent.
Former Gov. Mike Huckabee conceded; Senator John McCain and his supporters celebrated.

Here are a couple of updates on human activities down on our blue marble -- seen here in an image just released by NASA but taken last October by a camera aboard a satellite orbiting Mars (hat tip to Michael Schlesinger at UIUC).Population: In Beijing, state-controlled media denied reports last week that China was planning to relax its longstanding "one child" policy, saying reporters had misquoted a vice minister of the National Population and Family Planning Commission. But the new comments, from Wu Jianmin, a spokesman for the advisory body to the Chinese parliament, seemed to reaffirm that a shift was in the works. More here from The Los Angeles Times. In a comment to my initial post on the news, Max Zhang, a young Chinese student studying in Pennsylvania, provided a look at life as a single child in a single-child culture. Are there others out there who grew up in China from the 1970s on who can share experiences here, good or bad?

I gave a presentation last weekend at the New York Times Travel Show, a big exhibition at the Javits Center. It's a big extravaganza that gathers travel industry types from many countries and gives them booths to promote tourism in their lands. They extol the gorgeous contours of their countries, the exquisite cuisine, the warmth and generosity of their people, the beauty and creativity of their culture, etc. There was music, dancing, cooking demonstrations, and then there was me, all the way in a back corner of the Javits Center, leading a wine tasting over the beat of an African drumming demonstration going on next door.

The fake memoir wave continues. In Tuesday's Times, Motoko Rich reports that contrary to the premise of her new memoir, "Love and Consequences," Margaret B. Yesterday I asked you to analyze a report presented at the Heartland Institute's conference of global-warming skeptics. A lot of readers had the same reaction I did after I read the report and attended the conference yesterday: There are some interesting points here, but who knows? The skeptics point to some genuine discrepancies between the climate models and what's actually happened; they're probably right in criticizing the United Nations' I.P.C.C. for not paying enough attention to the impact of solar variations on the Earth's climate. But climate is so complicated, and cuts across so many scientific disciplines, that it's impossible to know which discrepancies or which variables are really important.

Kelly and I met Mario and Antonio at the off-ramp for Albenga, which might be thought of as the Castroville of Italy -- Castroville being the self-proclaimed artichoke capital of California. It was gray and cool, perfect artichoke-growing weather, and the broad area past the tolls was crowded with parked cars -- turned out this was a popular meeting place. We proceeded to drive in a convoy of three, up into the hills, to Onzo, about 15 miles inland. This is the part of Liguria west of Genoa, the less popular, less glamorous, slightly wilder (and also somewhat more commercially agricultural) region.

The troubled merger of Genesco/Finish Line has come to an ignominious end. Finish Line, a footwear chain, announced early Tuesday that the parties had agreed to settle all litigation among them relating to their proposed merger and UBS's financing of the deal. As part of the settlement, the merger has been dropped. Genesco will get $175 million -- $136 million of it from UBS, the rest from Finish Line -- as well as 6.5 million shares of Finish Line stock.

A Nascar appeals committee overturned the penalties levied against Rusty Wallace Racing for an infraction discovered on David Stremme’s car before the season-opening Nationwide Series race. Stremme was docked 25 points, the car owner Ed Rensi was also docked 25 points and the crew chief Steve Darne was suspended six races and fined $15,000. Nascar said the cover on the car’s oil tank was not securely fastened after qualifying at Daytona. Wallace appealed, and the three-member National Stock Car Racing Commission ruled that the cover was fastened. The violation was similar to one found on Carl Edwards’s car after his victory Sunday at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. The parts on that car were sent to North Carolina for review.Reversals are not common; in the 96 hearings held over the past eight years, the commission upheld 66 decisions. In two instances, the penalty was increased.
