A Google executive, Sheryl Sandberg, will join Facebook later this month as chief operating officer and will work closely with Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s co-founder.
The Federal Reserve chairman called for a “vigorous response” by industry and government to prevent foreclosures.
The Senate confirmed Mark R. Filip, a federal judge from Chicago, as deputy attorney general.
Two men and two women and two girls under the age of 5 were found dead in a single-family home in Binghampton in what news reports said was the worst mass killing there in at least 15 years.
Despite more off-court distractions involving Stephon Marbury, the Knicks hung with the Hornets, who own the third-best record in the Western Conference, until the final minutes.
Joe Alexander matched a career high with 32 points Monday night as West Virginia avenged an earlier defeat with a 76-62 win against visiting Pittsburgh.
Two police officers who were accused of leaving a teenager in an isolated Staten Island marsh on Halloween have been indicted on 33 counts, some of them felonies.
State police said that two 7-year-olds and an 8-year-old at Lebanon Elementary School were charged in a plot to hurt their bus driver with knives.
The top-ranked Huskies, avenging their only loss of the season, never trailed in dismantling No. 4 Rutgers, 66-46, to clinch the Big East Conference regular-season championship.
The chief of staff for former Gov. Frank H. Murkowski has agreed to plead guilty to fraud as part of an corruption investigation involving an oil field services company.
Although his play has improved drastically, Rangers forward Sean Avery has hit a roadblock in his quest to sign a contract extension.
Sharpe James fended off accusations in a federal indictment that he improperly helped a Newark public relations executive in favorable land deals.
The Jets continued their head-spinning free-agency spree Monday by signing linebacker/defensive end Calvin Pace and offensive lineman Damien Woody.
As a pitcher, Nelson Figueroa Jr. has to mix up the speed of his delivery and vary his release point to stay ahead of hitters. As an artist, he likes to change up images to keep people off guard.
Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw may not bring a team to Carnesecca Arena again.

The Advertising column in Business Day last Tuesday, about commercials that ran during the Academy Awards show, misidentified the writer of “Killing the Blues,” a song featured in a commercial for J. C. Penney. And a correction in this space on Thursday cited another incorrect writer for the song. “Killing the Blues” was written by Rowland Salley. It is not by Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, whose version of the song on their new album was heard in the ad. And it is not by John Prine, who recorded it, as did many other arists.

An article on Sunday about a Colombian announcement that security forces had killed a senior commander of the country’s largest guerrilla group in combat misspelled the province where the fighting took place. It is Putumayo, not Putamayo.

An article on Sunday about preparations in Baghdad for a visit by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran described Iran’s ethnic makeup incorrectly. Slightly more than half of the country’s population is Persian; Iran is not “overwhelmingly Persian.” (It is overwhelmingly Shiite Muslim.).

An article on Saturday about the resignation of Tim Goeglein, a White House aide who admitted repeatedly plagiarizing other writers for his guest columns in The News-Sentinel of Fort Wayne, Ind., misidentified the hometown of Nancy Nall, the blogger who first discovered the plagiarism. She lives in Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich. — not in Fort Wayne, where she was once a columnist for the same newspaper.

An obituary on Feb. 15 about Frank Piasecki, a pioneer in helicopter design, misstated the significance of the helicopter license he was issued by the federal government on Oct. 20, 1943, when he arrived in Washington to demonstrate his first helicopter. It was the first helicopter license issued to someone who did not already have a license to fly a fixed-wing aircraft; it was not the first government-issued helicopter license. (C. L. Morris, the chief test pilot for Igor Sikorsky, another helicopter pioneer, had received the first helicopter license, in March 1942.).

An article on Sunday about preparations in Baghdad for a visit by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran described Iran’s ethnic makeup incorrectly. Slightly more than half of the country’s population is Persian; Iran is not “overwhelmingly Persian.” (It is overwhelmingly Shiite Muslim.).

An article in Weekend on Friday about bluegrass and other acoustical music in New York referred incorrectly to a song performed by Levon Helm at a recent musical gathering at his home studio in Woodstock, N.Y. The song, “Long Black Veil,” is not on Mr. Helm’s new album, “Dirt Farmer.” (Mr. Helm is scheduled to play at the Beacon Theater this weekend.).

A front-page article on Friday about the return of Alexei Yashin and other National Hockey League players to Russia to join a resurgent professional league misstated the nature of Yashin’s relationship with the model Carol Alt. She is his longtime companion, not his wife.

Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend on Friday about “Gustave Courbet,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the region of France where Courbet’s birthplace, Ornans, is located. It is in eastern France, not the southwest.
Deron Williams had 20 assists to go with 17 points Monday and the Utah Jazz used a late 16-0 run to pull out a 116-110 victory over the visiting Dallas Mavericks.
A structural engineer was charged on Monday with lying to city investigators looking into the circumstances of a building collapse that killed two of their colleagues in 2006.
The Intel Corporation, the semiconductor maker, lowered its profit forecast for its first quarter, blaming a steep drop in prices for memory chips for the shortfall.
A federal court in Sacramento ruled that the Bush administration must reassess its plan to eliminate a down payment assistance program.

Zinifex, an Australian mining company that specializes in zinc and lead, agreed to be acquired by Oxiana, one of the largest mining companies in Australia, for 6 billion Australian dollars ($5.6 billion). The deal, which requires shareholder approval, comes after a year of discussions, the companies said. Oxiana agreed to pay 3.1931 of its shares for each share of Zinifex. Both companies are based in Melbourne.

The banking group HSBC Holdings reported that profit rose 21 percent in 2007 despite charges from subprime and other loans in North America. HSBC, which is based in London, said the outlook this year was uncertain. “The economic slowdown and the credit outlook in the U.S. may well get worse before they get better,” the chairman, Stephen K. Green, left, said. The company reported a profit of $19.1 billion, compared with $15.8 billion in 2006, largely on strength in Asia. HSBC said it absorbed $2.1 billion in write-downs on asset-backed securities and credit trading positions, leveraged and acquisition financing positions, and monoline credit exposure. Loan impairment charges related to the subprime mortgage problems in the United States and other credit provisions rose 79 percent, to $11.7 billion.

Samsung, the world’s largest electronics maker, said it was starting a major push into the personal computer and office equipment markets, leveraging its position as the leading maker of computer monitors. Jong Woo Park, the president for Samsung’s digital media business, announced the sales offensive in Hanover, Germany, as he introduced an expanded line of laptop computers and laser printers for business customers at Cebit, the largest European technology convention. The new line of laptops is geared toward business users, with models beginning at about $1,215.
The legislative package proposed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer would require lenders to try to work out repayments with borrowers before suing them.

Anna Kournikova will play for the St. Louis Aces during the World Team Tennis Pro League season. The Aces traded their first-round pick in the April 1 roster draft to the Sacramento Capitals for the rights to Kournikova and a second-round draft choice. Other players participating this season include Serena Williams (Washington Kastles), Lindsay Davenport (Newport Beach Breakers) and Andy Roddick (St. Louis). The league begins play July 3.

The National Track and Field Hall of Fame has agreed to provide memorabilia to the Sports Museum of America. The museum is scheduled to open in May at 26 Broadway in Lower Manhattan, next to the Charging Bull bronze sculpture and near the Statue of Liberty ferry.The track hall of fame is in the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. It will send the museum such archival material as a medal won by Jim Thorpe, a discus Al Oerter used in one of his four Olympic victories, Carl Lewis’s running shoes, Rafer Johnson’s Olympic uniform, and a cap worn by Archie Hahn during the 1906 Olympics.

Athletes who have served suspensions for major doping offenses will not be invited to compete at major European meets, a top organizer said. “It is a message to the new generation: ‘Stay off doping. And if you don’t, don’t come looking here,’ ” said Wilfried Meert, organizer of the Van Damme Golden League meet in Brussels. Meert said organizers would adhere to the policy even in the face of legal challenges. The measure has been adopted by organizers of Europe’s 51 major invitational meets, including all the Golden League and Grand Prix events, and applies to athletes who have been barred for two years.

Denver Broncos defensive tackle Marcus Thomas was arrested after the police said they found cocaine and a handgun in a pickup truck during a traffic stop in Orange Park, Fla. He was charged with possession of a controlled substance and released from jail Sunday after posting a $2,500 bond. Thomas slipped to the fourth round of last year’s draft because of off-field problems, including a positive drug test. He had been considered a potential first-round pick. Thomas and the truck’s driver were arrested early Saturday after the police received a call from the Florida Highway Patrol asking them to look for a pickup with a driver who might be impaired.

The two-time Olympic bronze medalist Lars Grael and Marcelo Jordao overcame a deficit of 30 boat lengths after the first mark and took the lead with an aggressive tack on the final upwind leg to win the second race of the Bacardi Cup Star Class Regatta off Miami. Grael and Jordao held the overall lead with four races to go, 1 point ahead of Miami’s Augie Diaz, the 2003 Yachtsman of the Year, who finished third with Phil Trinter.

DeeDee Jonrowe was the first musher to leave the Rainy Pass checkpoint and took the lead in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. Jonrowe spent five minutes in the cabin checkpoint, leaving at 1:21 p.m. Monday. She took the lead from the 2004 champion, Mitch Seavey, who was the first among the 95 mushers to reach Rainy Pass, 224 miles into the race. The defending champion Lance Mackey was in 11th place.
Parrying a television ad with another has typically taken days if not weeks, but Barack Obama’s team did it within hours on Friday.
The league set guidelines for Saturday’s do-over between the Atlanta Hawks and Miami Heat, who must complete the final 51.9 seconds of their Dec. 19 overtime game.
The Taliban knocked out two cellphone towers near the city of Kandahar over the weekend, carrying out a threat they made last week against all four cellphone companies in Afghanistan.
The government is offering to pay poor families nearly $3,000 to give birth to daughters and bring them up.
The authorities released Kashmir Singh, an Indian man who had languished in Pakistani prisons for 35 years after he was sentenced to death for espionage.
A young married couple, Austrian citizens of Arab origin suspected of having links to Al Qaeda, went on trial in Vienna on terrorism charges.
A court ordered that a Web site can no longer allow the practice of letting students anonymously rate teachers by name.
A United Nations helicopter crashed in bad weather in Nepal’s mountainous east, killing seven members of the United Nations staff and three crew members.
When the Blue Jays talk about Scott Rolen, a seven-time Gold Glove winner and a five-time All-Star, they are mystified how a player who gives maximum effort could have so infuriated Tony La Russa.
The move is expected to force lenders like Countrywide Financial to sell or spin off their appraisal businesses and will also create a watchdog to monitor the industry.
Only by bringing people onto the books, being realistic about the supply of visas, and letting people in through ports of entry will the country restore order to the broken system.
The voting in Ohio, Rhode Island, Texas and Vermont could be decisive in the race between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
March 3, 2008.
Federal inspections will be made at hundreds of plants where combustible dust is a hazard, a top safety official said.

A high school couple forced to break up spent a month plotting to kill the girl’s parents before her mother and two younger brothers were fatally shot and stabbed in a weekend ambush, according to records.

Closing a case that forced the resignation of the Harris County district attorney, county commissioners approved a $1.7 million payment to two brothers who said they were falsely arrested and abused for videotaping a drug raid by sheriff’s deputies on a neighbor’s home in 2002.

Formaldehyde levels in the trailers provided to Gulf Coast hurricane victims vary greatly by brand, and four of the six most commonly used brands are among those with the highest levels, a federal study found.
A school bus carrying 27 students overturned, and 11 students were taken to hospitals for treatment, the authorities said. None of the students were in critical condition, officials said.
A Fort Lewis soldier has been arrested for investigation of killing a military couple and abducting their 7-month-old girl, sheriff’s deputies said.
Nearly a dozen schools in Louisiana and one in Mississippi will get a share of more than $500,000 in grants from the Laura Bush Foundation to rebuild their libraries.
The Bronx apartment building where D.J. Kool Herc presided over a musical sound in 1973 that eventually became the hip-hop genre, may be saved from gentrification, for the time being.
Michael R. Bloomberg’s potential candidacy has faded from the improbable to a resounding New York fuhgedaboudit. But what about the vice presidency?
On Monday, with no other teams publicly stepping forward to pursue Randy Moss, the drama ended when he and the Patriots agreed on a deal.
Many young people in Iraq have grown disillusioned with religious leaders and skeptical of the faith that they preach.
A trail of deals done, and a deal with EMI that was not done.
The United States cannot pretend that Vladimir Putin and his allies operate from democratic intentions. They must push for more open elections and political and journalistic freedoms.
Mr. di Stefano was a flamboyant, sometimes erratic opera star who in his prime after World War II was lauded as the most thrilling Italian tenor in a generation.
A gunman dressed in a coat and tie walked into a Wendy’s fast food restaurant in West Palm Beach at lunchtime and opened fire, killing one customer and wounding four others before killing himself.
There has been little public conversation about the consequences of the costs of the Iraq war, which are like a cancer inside the American economy.
When Ohioans head to the polls Tuesday, Mark and Gina Wellman of Circleville, Ohio, will be watching another vote — what buyers are bidding for their home.
E.P.A. administrator Stephen Johnson’s decision to deny California the right to set its own emission standards is a blow to those worried about climate change.
Carlos Kauffmann pleaded guilty to taking part in a conspiracy to cover up Venezuela’s role in delivering $800,000 to the campaign of Argentina’s president.
The New Jersey Senate voted 30 to 7 on Monday to give adoptees access to their original birth certificates with only the names of their adoptive parents.
Senator John McCain entered into one of the most politicized scientific issues in a generation.
The footwear retailers Genesco and Finish Line said that they were terminating their merger plans and the financing commitment of the Swiss bank UBS.
Capping a relentless rise in recent years, oil prices hit a record high of $103.95 a barrel on Monday, then pulled back to close below the record.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s centralized oversight of the city’s 1,400 public schools came under sharp attack, prompting Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein to come to his defense.
Five luxury homes in a subdivision marketed as “built green” were destroyed or severely damaged by fire. The initials of a group linked to acts of ecoterrorism were found at the scene.
The typical American corporation probably has increased its savings enough to completely pay off its debts.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg provided $500,000 to state Republicans to help them retain control of the Senate, angering some Democrats, who said it would diminish support for his congestion pricing plan.
Sales of cars and trucks in the United States fell 10 percent in February as oil prices climbed past $100 a barrel and worries about a recession rattled consumer confidence.

The approved legislation offers those that take the leave two-thirds of their salary, making New Jersey the third state to give employees the right to take paid leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative.
The first undercover detective to enter the exotic dancing club in Queens where the fatal shooting of Sean Bell took place said he was uncomfortable with the size and rowdiness of the crowd.
More than 44,000 people have signed up for a piece of a $4.85 billion settlement over the withdrawn painkiller Vioxx, a sign that the deal is on track to go forward.
The Devils were in first place in the Eastern Conference when their game against the Montreal Canadiens began at 7:11 p.m. Saturday. By 5:40 p.m. Sunday, the Devils were in fourth place.
The Bush administration said mortgage companies were showing more willingness to relax loan terms for subprime borrowers in danger of losing their houses.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer has raised money beyond the cap he imposed on himself by directing donations to his party.
Thornburg Mortgage, the mortgage lender, said Monday that it had failed to meet a surge in margin calls, raising concern that it might need to seek bankruptcy protection.
The disgraced newspaper baron Conrad M. Black reported to prison Monday to begin a six-and-a-half-year sentence for swindling shareholders.
Separated by nearly 5,000 miles, the Chicago Fire and the Red Bulls, who are training in Salzburg, Austria, have rekindled what is quickly developing into a contentious feud.
The United States and the E.U. are protesting China’s requirement that foreign financial news services operate through a government-designated distributor.
A new line of shaving gels could have consumers asking: Is it a shaving gel or is it a night light?
Despite pleas from doctors, immigration law is preventing the sister of a legal permanent resident, whose wife recently died after giving birth, permission to visit to help care for the baby.
The Senate on Monday confirmed Mark R. Filip, a federal judge from Chicago, as deputy attorney general on a unanimous voice vote.
China is developing the ability to limit or prevent the use of satellites by potential adversaries, the Pentagon said Monday in a report to Congress.

PLAYER In Spain, Sergio Aguero, Atletico Madrid’s 20-year-old Argentine striker, scored two goals Saturday in a 4-2 victory against Barcelona. The defeat ended Barcelona’s eight-game unbeaten streak in La Liga and left it 5 points behind league-leading Real Madrid. Aguero, who is nicknamed Kun, after a Japanese comic book character, has 11 goals this season.
Former Astros Jason Lane and Morgan Ensberg are nonroster invitees to Yankees spring training and are auditioning for what might be just one open spot among position players.
Darryl Strawberry will serve as a special instructor for the Mets during spring training and as an ambassador once the season starts.
Patients might not like the new admission procedure at a growing number of hospitals: having an elongated Q-Tip stuck up their noses. But it smells great to Cepheid.
A 4-to-4 vote left the Supreme Court unable to decide a pharmaceutical pre-emption case, permitting a lawsuit to proceed against the Warner-Lambert Company, the maker of the diabetes drug Rezulin.
Mike Mussina, who threw 210 innings in his first full professional season, is somewhat bewildered as he watches the Yankees’ careful handling of their young pitchers.
An Obama card with his autograph, one of 15 made by Topps Company, sold for $3,122 on eBay this week, and a Clinton card with her autograph, one of 18, sold for $1,325.
Davey Lopes, the first-base coach for Philadelphia, has prostate cancer, and Phillies officials said he was expected to make a full recovery.
Coach Matt Painter has led the Boilermakers to a 23-6 record, a No. 15 ranking and a tie with Wisconsin for the Big Ten lead going into Tuesday’s game at Ohio State.
General Electric’s chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, was awarded $14.2 million in compensation last year, the company said Monday.
The chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, E. Neville Isdell, received compensation valued at $21.6 million in 2007, a more than 3 percent increase from 2006.
After years of small talk at the cash register, a barrista at a Starbucks offered to donate a kidney to a longtime customer suffering from polycystic kidney disease.
The board of the automated teller, office and voting machines maker rejected an unsolicited $2.64 billion takeover bid from United Technologies, a diversified manufacturer.
The Russian natural gas company cut about a quarter of the gas supply to Ukraine on Monday to force the country to settle a debt.
Three feet have surfaced on the rocky coastlines of three separate islands in the Strait of Georgia over the last six months.
Mr. Norman was a singer and songwriter considered by many to be the father of Christian rock despite years of being shunned by more traditional Christians.
Jeff Healey was a Canadian guitarist, singer and songwriter whose band sold millions of blues-rock records and who also pursued a passion for old-time jazz, playing the trumpet and clarinet.
My career as a singer and songwriter began because of a flight delay. One song, “Only My Credit Card Remembers Where I’ve Been,” is an ode to the frequent flier.
Dr. David B. Allison drew criticism from some members after he wrote an affidavit as a paid consultant on behalf of the restaurant industry.
The celebrity chef Robert Irvine will be replaced by the Food Network as host of “Dinner Impossible” after admitting to inaccuracies in his résumé.

Gustav Klimt’s monumental installation, “The Beethoven Frieze,” measuring more than 100 feet in length and celebrating the unification of all the arts, will be reconstructed at the Tate Liverpool museum in what is billed as Britain’s first comprehensive exhibition dedicated to the artist, Reuters reported. The show, scheduled for May 30 to Aug. 31 as part of Liverpool’s designation as a European Capital of Culture for 2008, will examine the role of Klimt (1862-1918) in the Secession movement, which inspired artists, architects, fashion designers and furniture makers. Klimt created “The Beethoven Frieze,” detail above, for the Secession’s 14th exhibition, in 1902. Though it was to be destroyed after the show, a patron of the movement ordered it removed and stored, and the Austrian state eventually acquired and restored it for exhibition in the Secession building in Vienna.

A plot by the Hells Angels, above with Mick Jagger at Altamont, Calif., in 1969, to kill Mr. Jagger nearly 40 years ago failed when the would-be assassins, traveling by boat, encountered a storm and were thrown overboard, according to a new BBC radio series. In one episode of the series, “The F.B.I. at 100,” a former F.B.I. agent, Mark Young, said that Angels became enraged in the aftermath of the Rolling Stones’ free concert at Altamont. During the concert a fan was stabbed and killed by the Angels, who had been providing security for the Stones. The Stones then distanced themselves from the Angels, which made the Angels angry with Mr. Jagger, the program said. “They were going to kill him in retribution for his firing their security forces,” Mr. Young said in the program, the BBC reported on its Web site. “Their plan involved making entry into his Long Island property, going by boat. As they gathered the weaponry and their forces to go out on Long Island Sound, a storm rolled up, which nearly sunk the watercraft they were in, and they escaped with their own lives.” Mr. Young told the program that the botched plot came to life much later, in the course of a wider investigation into the Angels’ activities. The episode is to be broadcast next week. A spokesman for Mr. Jagger said he would have no comment.

John le Carré, the British writer of literary spy thrillers, has returned to a previous publisher for his forthcoming novel, “A Most Wanted Man.” Mr. le Carré has signed a one-book deal with Scribner, a unit of Simon & Schuster, for the United States rights to the novel, which will be simultaneously published in Britain (by Hodder & Stoughton) in October. Mr. le Carré, above, is leaving Little, Brown & Co., the publisher of his last two books, “The Mission Song” and “Absolute Friends,” and returning to Scribner, which published “Single & Single” and “The Constant Gardener.” The new novel is set in Germany and takes place in one day. It chronicles the fate of a Muslim man who moves to Hamburg to enroll in medical school but because of his murky background ends up being followed by both local and other Western intelligence agencies. “It’s John le Carré, so of course you don’t know who to trust,” Susan Moldow, publisher of Scribner, said. “You don’t know who’s telling the truth. It’s wonderful mind games and also very reflective of how intelligence communities operate.” Michael Rudell, the lawyer who negotiated the Scribner deal for Mr. le Carré, declined to comment on the size of the advance but said it was a “very significant deal.”.

Stolen and damaged in an armed daylight robbery in 2004, the restored Edward Munch masterworks “The Scream,” above left, and “Madonna,” above right, will be returned to public view at the Munch Museum in Oslo in May, Agence France-Presse reported. A statement from the museum said that repairs were “coming to an end” and that the paintings would be featured in an exhibition from May 23 to Sept. 26. The museum was reluctant to discuss the damage, but Ingebjoerg Ydstie, a curator, said a humidity stain remained in a corner of “The Scream.” Munch painted several versions of the two paintings, but the ones in the Munch Museum are considered among the most complete. At the time of the robbery their worth was estimated as high as $100 million. Security at the museum has been tightened since the crime. Three men were convicted, but Bjoern Hoen, regarded as the mastermind, is to be retried.

Miley Cyrus, better known as Hannah Montana, has joined the lineup of entertainers at Nickelodeon’s 2008 Kids’ Choice Awards, to be broadcast from the Pauley Pavilion at University of California, Los Angeles, on March 29. Other participants in the show include Nickelodeon’s Naked Brothers Band, Steve Carell, Cameron Diaz, America Ferrara, Harrison Ford, Jennifer Love Hewitt, Heidi Klum, Shia LaBeouf, Hayden Panettiere and Ryan Seacrest. ... Kid Rock has pleaded not guilty to a misdemeanor charge of battery arising from a fight in October at a Waffle House after a performance in Atlanta, The Associated Press reported. The musician, whose real name is Robert James Ritchie, was not present in DeKalb County State Court for the plea.
In the latest of numerous management changes in recent months, Starbucks said Monday that Launi Skinner resigned as president of its United States business.
A panel dropped charges against two former high ranking Shiite government officials accused of using the Health ministry to run death squads and enrich themselves.
Security lines, delays and the removal of the guaranteed-seat policy have undermined the shuttles’ basic quick-turnaround formula.
Karl Rove’s coalition is gone, but will that help Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama?
Porsche moved closer to taking over Volkswagen, after the sports-car maker won approval from its supervisory board to raise its Volkswagen stake to more than 50 percent.

(21) HOLLYWOOD SINGING AND DANCING: A MUSICAL TREASURE Shirley Jones narrates this history of the Hollywood musical, from the Busby Berkeley films of the Depression and the patriotic salutes of the 1940s through the end of the studio system in the 1950s (above, a scene from the 1943 ''Lady of Burlesque''). Song-and-dance legends like Fred Astaire, Mickey Rooney, Judy Garland, Shirley Temple, Betty Grable, Frank Sinatra and Leslie Caron are shown hoofing their way through ''The Wizard of Oz,'' ''Dames,'' ''Fashions of 1934,'' ''Something to Sing About,'' ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' and ''Oklahoma!'' 9 P.M. NAGY--Gladys, 73, of New York, New York, died peacefully on March 2, 2008 at Weill Cornell Medical Center after a two year battle with ovarian cancer. Gladys was born on November 19, 1934 in New York City to Elizabeth and Louis Yager. Throughout her life, Gladys was very active in New Yorks Hungarian-American community, most notably as the chief organizer of the annual Piarist Ball, which benefits the scholarship and building funds of the American and Hungarian Piarist Schools. Gladys cherished family and friends, loved travel, derived great pleasure from decorating her East Side home and enjoyed sharing life with her husband. She had tremendous energy and youthful exuberance. Gladys is survived by her husband, Adam Nagy of New York City; son Adam P. Nagy of Phoenicia, NY; sister Katherine Schumacher of New York City; and foster sister Janet Gutyan of Pasadena, CA. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Thursday, 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (www.ocrf.org) in the name of Gladys Nagy.

KRESS--Jocelyn Heavener, 61, died peacefully in her sleep on March 1, 2008 in Tuxedo Park, following a courageous seven year battle with breast cancer. Born in New York City, October 7, 1946, Jocelyn attended the Spence School in New York City, graduated from Miss Halls School in Pittsfield, MA, and from Sarah Lawrence College, where she majored in Art History, studying for a year in Paris. Daughter of Rush Harrison Kress of Slatington, PA, and Virginia W. Kress of Maysville, KY, she is survived by her sons Zachary Kress Turner and Jedidiah H. K. Turner and his wife Agnes Ahlander Turner, and her former husband, Webb. Jocelyn worked at art galleries in New York before moving to Washington, D.C. to join Common Cause. She founded ArtNow, a foundation for promotion of the arts. Its exhibits included the first retrospective of American cartoon art, which occupied the entire top floor of the Kennedy Center. Jocelyn raised funds for the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine and more recently lectured on the history of the Kress collection. Jocelyn planned her memorial service as a celebration of her life, with the hope that her friends will continue to enjoy life as much as she. The service will take place at St. Ignatius of Antioch Church, 11 am, Wednesday, March 5, 2008. Jocelyn requests no flowers. In lieu of flowers, donations be made to St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, 552 West End Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

NANON--Patricia, of New York City and Chilmark, Massachusetts, died peacefully on February 29, in her home in New York City surrounded by her loving daughters. She was 84. Ms. Nanon, a choreographer, was a 1944 graduate of Bennington College and the Founder and long time Artistic Director of The Yard, a colony for the performing arts on Martha's Vineyard. The Yard is a treasured part of both the Vineyard and the contemporary dance world, which has often honored her for her vision and generosity. She is survived by her daughters Vicki Woolner Samuels of Chicago, Cate Woolner of Northfield, Massachusetts and Justine Woolner Wise of Oneonta, New York, their families, many devoted nieces and nephew and their families, as well as many dear friends. BOGDANOFF--James, 47. With great sorrow, family and friends announce the passing of our beloved Jamie, on February 29, 2008. Jamie represented all that is good in this life. He was a loving husband to Robin Messing, adoring Dad to Phoebe, devoted uncle to Justin and Russell Romano, James Sui, and Sofia Mia Canale, and beloved son of Phyllis. He will be missed by his close circle of family and friends. Jamie was born and raised in New York City and was a loyal summer resident of Monterey, MA. He graduated from Friends Seminary in 1978 and earned a Bachelor's degree from Clark University in 1982. Shortly after graduation, he began his Emmy winning Television news career, working in the library at ABC News. He spent seven years at ABC working his way up the ranks, followed by producing jobs at King World, Fox and Lifetime. In 2003, he returned to ABC as a senior producer for ''Good Morning America''. Everywhere he went, he was adored by those who worked for or with him. He was a rare gem in a crazy business, who will forever be remembered for his infectious smile, fun loving personality, obsession with sports, and passion for fishing. Services were held Sunday, at Riverside Chapel. For further information about Shiva, and donations in James' name to Clark University, please visit: www.caringbridge.org (jamesbogdanoff)

BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. A close advisor to D.K. Ludwig and executor of his estate, R. Palmer Baker Jr. was a major force in the 1971 creation of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, a not-forprofit organization with research activities spanning the globe. Mr. Baker was a longstanding member of the Institute's Board of Directors and served as Chairman of the Board from 1995--2005, guiding the Institute as it emerged into the world's largest international cancer research enterprise. Mr. Baker was also a Trustee of the Virginia and D.K. Ludwig Fund for Cancer Research, which, in 2006, made the largest single donation by a foundation to cancer research in the United States. Deeply admired by the entire community of Ludwig researchers for his contributions to the world of cancer research, his generosity of spirit and the high standards that he brought to all of his endeavors, Mr. Baker will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his daughter, Mary Baker Eaton, and to his grandson, Harold L. Fickett, IV. Lloyd J. Old, M.D. Edward A. McDermott, Jr. Andrew Simpson, Ph.D. BAKER--R. Palmer Jr. Cancer Research Institute (CRI) mourns the loss of R. Palmer Baker Jr., a true friend and ally in the fight against cancer. As former chairman of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR), Mr. Baker embraced and nurtured a close and rewarding partnership between our two organizations. His visionary support was vital to the creation of the CRI/LICR Cancer Vaccine Collaborative, a coordinated global network of 22 academic clinical and laboratory centers conducting early-phase trials of therapeutic cancer vaccines. This unique partnership pursues Daniel K. Ludwig's goal to eradicate cancer based on Dr. William B. Coley's pioneering ideas in cancer immunotherapy. Thanks in large part to Mr. Baker's commitment to this combined effort, CRI and LICR together are advancing cancer vaccine research and bringing new hope to cancer patients. Donald J. Gogel and Andrew M. Paul, Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees Lloyd J. Old, M.D. Director, Scientific Advisory Council Jill O'Donnell-Tormey, Ph.D. Executive Director Cancer Research Institute

CONTE--Francis Peter, 1927 - 2008, passed away peacefully at age 80 on Saturday. His family celebrates the life of a much loved husband, father, brother, and uncle. His good nature and exuberance for life inspired those around him. A native New Yorker and life long Murray Hill resident who summered in the Poconos. A U.S. Marine Veteran, union bricklayer/ mason contractor and co-founder of Conte Builders, Inc. Frank enjoyed hosting family and friends for home cooked Italian feasts! He will join his wife Gertrude Ann at Calverton National Cemetery to continue their loving relationship. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th St., on March 4th from 7-9pm.

LASKIN--Richard S., M.D., F.A.C.S., on March 1, 2008, passed away surrounded by his family. He was the loving husband of the Honorable Joyce L. Sparrow (retired), adoring father of Jonathan and Andrew and stepfather of Risa Gold and Doug Kane, and loving grandfather (''Poppy'') to Maxwell Gold, Dylan Gold, Samuel Laskin and Alexander Laskin. He was a Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, Co-Chief of the Knee Service at the Hospital for Special Surgery and an attending orthopaedic surgeon at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was also the Editor in Chief of the Hospital for Special Surgery Journal. Born and raised in Brooklyn and Merrick, New York, Dr. Laskin received his Bachelors degree, cum laude, in chemistry from Hofstra University in 1960. He received his Medical Degree from New York University in 1964. His passions included his model trains. Dr. Laskin traveled the world, learning the languages of the nations he visited and lecturing and training fellow orthopaedic surgeons in the field of total joint replacement. He often traveled with an extra suitcase, anticipating the trip to the model train store. Dr. Laskin had an accomplished military career serving in Vietnam and retiring with honorable discharge in 1991 with title of Colonel. The family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Dr. Richard Laskin Chair at the Hospital For Special Surgery. LASKIN--Richard S., M.D. The Board of Trustees, medical staff, administration and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community mourn the passing of Richard S. Laskin, M.D., orthopedic surgeon, teacher, researcher and cherished colleague. A key member of the HSS staff for more than 17 years, he brought enthusiasm and energy to everything he did. Dr. Laskin was Chief of the Division of Arthroplasty and founding Editor-in-Chief of the HSS journal. In 2007 he was honored with the establishment of the Richard S. Laskin, M.D. Chair. His academic accomplishments and incredible innovative ability are legend but his personal qualities of kindness, genuine caring for his patients and colleagues, and mentorship made Dick Laskin very special. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, the Honorable Joyce Sparrow, his sons Jonathan, and Andrew and wife Nicole and grandchildren Samuel and Alex, Joyce's daughter Risa Gold and husband Bruce Gold and grandchildren Maxwell and Dylan, and Joyce's son Doug Kane, and to the entire Laskin and Sparrow families. Dean R. O'Hare Aldo Papone Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro President and CEO

O'BRIEN--Kevin J. With great sorrow his family announces his passing on March 1, 2008 after a heroic five-month battle with lung cancer. Kevin J. O'Brien was born in New York, New York on March 12, 1934. He served in the U.S. Navy. He graduated from Fordham University (1959) and Columbia Law School (1962) where he was a Kent Scholar and Articles Editor of the Columbia Law Review. He was a law clerk for the Honorable Leonard P. Moore, U.S. Court of Appeals, Second Circuit 1962-1963. He joined Paul, Weiss, Rifkind Wharton & Garrison in 1963 and became a senior partner in their tax department, retiring in 2005. He always took great joy in his work and is remembered for his devotion to his family. He is survived by his wife of almost 50 years, Winifred, their three children Karen, Kevin and Susan, his brothers George and John, and six grandchildren. The wake will be held at Graham Funeral Home, 1036, Boston Post Road, Rye, New York on Tuesday, March 4 from 48pm. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection at 10am on Wednesday, March 5th. O'BRIEN--Kevin J. O'Brien. We express our deepest sympathies to his wife Winifred and the O'Brien family.

In its latest crackdown on bad landlords, the city’s Department of Buildings announced a push to sharply increase fines for chronic elevator violations and to shame the worst offenders into bringing their elevators into compliance.Beginning today, the agency will post the addresses and owners of the 10 buildings with the worst elevator violations on its Web site. (As for just how the list is expected to shame building owners is questionable, because while the Department of Building’s Web site lists the address of the offending buildings and will list the owner of record, the owner is often a faceless limited liability corporation or partnership.)

New York City, which has the largest public school system in the country, is in the forefront of a movement to pay for performance, even at the student level, Jennifer Medina writes. More than 200 city schools are experimenting with incentives, and at more than a dozen schools, students, teachers and principals are all eligible for extra money, based on students’ performance on standardized tests.

Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, insists that for the first time he is totally unclear which direction to take in his career. Facing a term limit, Mr. Markowitz is slowly approaching the end of his tenure in Borough Hall. And more than a few friends and supporters, he said, are urging him to run for mayor. Others tell him he would make a great public advocate, the No. 2 position under the mayor. “I have never been indecisive in my life,” Mr. Markowitz said in an interview on Wednesday. “For the first time in my adult life, I feel like I’m at a fork in the road and have no idea which way to go. Do I want to continue a career in elective office? Or do I want to open a new chapter in my life that doesn’t include public office. It’s difficult.”

Citing an increase in flu cases in New York City, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene today called on Albany to pass a bill allowing pharmacists to give flu and pneumonia shots. The bill, similar to legislation already adopted in 47 states, could increase the number of older New York City residents who get the shots by at least 50,000, officials said.

Tonight's column is my last from South Sudan, and it's really as much about "us" as about "them." I argue that the American presidential election may well affect poor countries like Sudan as much as America -- after all, we'll all survive a dreadful president, but in Africa the American president can make a difference of life or death.

As you know, all comments on this blog are moderated, and I'd love to get feedback about what we should allow and what we should delete. In general, I tend to let most things sail through, although I delete comments in all caps, or those in which people try to include a long text of a high school term paper.... I also delete obscenities or gratuitous insults against other posters (although I tend to leave insults directed at me, figuring that I skewer people periodically in my column and so should be able to receive what I dish out).

A hundred years ago today, three Model K Cadillacs made a historic journey. The cars were first driven 25 miles from London to the Brooklands racetrack, where each one was taken apart inside a brick shed. Three piles of parts -- some 720 parts per car -- were jumbled together. Then they were reassembled from the resulting shuffle and driven another 500 miles.

A Swiss bank on Wednesday moved to withdraw a lawsuit that it had filed against a Web site that it asserted had displayed stolen documents revealing confidential information about the accounts of the bank's clients.

Was - as some have suggested - the only real winner on Tuesday night John McCain?

An effort to restore the Grand Canyon after years of erosion began today as two pipes in the Glen Canyon Dam were opened wide, the beginning of a 60-hour flood. Authorities are hoping that sediment stuck at the bottom of the Colorado River spreads to depleted sandbars, which are used by endangered species and campers alike.

Before 2000, if you talked about having "the franchise" somewhere in America, it generally meant that you had secured the right to open a Subway sandwich shop or a Ben & Jerry's. But then came the nightmare in Florida, and ever since then, voters everywhere - and especially those in the Democratic Party - have talked about being "disenfranchised," in the political sense, as easily as they talk about being polled or being undecided. In my book, "The Argument," I described a 2004 party in which Lynda Resnick, an agribusiness billionaire who is active in Democratic politics, stood on the spiral staircase of her Sunset Boulevard mansion and exclaimed: "We're so tired of being disenfranchised!" More recently, the former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro argued in a Times Op-Ed that the Democratic voters of Florida and Michigan, whose primaries were disqualified by the national party, "surely don't deserve to be disenfranchised." A few Floridians have employed the same word in their comments here.

Philip Falcone is no stranger to taking on big tasks. There's not much love in legal circles for the so-called "business method" patent, an exclusive intellectual property right over a novel way of doing business. Critics of such patents - think Amazon "One Click" or Priceline's "name your own price" patents - argue that they clog up the United States Patent and Trademark Office, lead to excessive litigation and have little connection to real, physical invention.
A 311 call reporting a homeless person will now result in the city's Department of Homeless Services calling back on the same day with an update about what happened as a result of the phone call.

The Federal Reserve knows something about official economic statistics -- that they're not always a good guide to what's really happening. (I like to describe economic data as a peculiarly boring form of science fiction.) So the Fed also relies on an informal survey of economic conditions, the Beige Book. And the latest Beige Book does suggest a slowing economy, possibly even a recession.

Florida's Republican governor and Michigan's Democratic governor have one major gripe in common: the national parties have punished both of their states by limiting delegates to the national conventions. They released a joint statement today asking for their delegates to be seated.

It's fair to say that Citigroup has had a rough day -- and week, and month and year for that matter. The financial giant has been battered by a panoply of concerns, from fears that it may need to seek more capital to worries that it will take a hit from credit cards and home equity loans.

I work in the NYTimes.com feeds team. We handle retrieving, parsing and transforming incoming feeds from whatever strange proprietary format our partners choose to give us into something that our CMS can digest. As you can imagine, we deal with a huge amount of text processing. To handle all of these transformations as efficiently as possible we rely heavily on the magic of Perl. Recently, as feeds become more and more important, we have begun to feel pains caused by past impromptu segments of inefficient code written to meet quick, episodic deadlines. A situation that we are especially prone to as a fast moving news organization.

That phrase, an early favorite for "quote of the spring," came from Orlando Hernandez's mouth after he finished up a fairly intriguing bullpen session. After pitching the same way his entire life (42 years?) -- high leg kick, chin dropped down -- El Duque has changed his windup as a concession to the problems plaguing his right foot. He now keeps his back foot flat on the rubber, which reduces the stress placed on his toes, and pitches with a much lower leg kick.

China House, the Chinese restaurant of Bangkok's Oriental Hotel, is a handsome building near the hotel entrance. The interior is stunning: Modeled in black-lacquer, Shanghai chic, it's hard to imagine that the building once served as the Moroccan Embassy. It's also an ideal place for weekend dim sum. There's privacy here in the nooks and crannies of the duplex interior. And it's relatively quiet, making conversation easy.
Hillary Rodham Clinton, looking chipper after just a few hours of sleep, made the celebratory rounds on the breakfast news shows this morning.
Analysts are constantly churning out "buy," "sell" and "hold" ratings. But at two well-known Wall Street firms this week, "oops" seemed to be the operative word.

As critics increase their attacks on bankers' paychecks -- seen as excessive in light of today's market turmoil -- several financial firms are planning new guidelines on pay and bonuses, The Financial Times reported.

ABC Learning Centers, the largest child-care center operator in Australia, said Wednesday that it would sell 60 percent of its operations in the United States to Morgan Stanley's private equity unit, raising 750 million Australian dollars ($695 million).

Lately, a lot of people have been using the term "personal board of directors" to refer to the cadre of intimates they rely on when making big decisions -- from whether to start a company to how to dress for a first television appearance. It's not a new concept. I asked the career coach Michael Melcher, who has become a regular guest contributor to this blog, whether his clients are actually creating these things and he agreed that the idea is catching on. For today's guest post, Mr. Melcher gives some suggestions on how to get our own personal boards and how we can use them once we've put them together.

Top corporate executives often make large gifts of their company's stock to their family foundations shortly before the stock price drops sharply, according to a new study by a New York University professor. As a result, the executives are able to claim the maximum possible tax deduction and escape capital gains taxes.
JPMorgan Chase retained its position as the largest hedge fund manager in the United States as total assets of the biggest hedge fund firms topped $1.6 trillion as of Jan. 1.

The move to craft a new futures exchange gained ground Tuesday as reports emerged that Goldman Sachs may join 12 other banks in creating an alternative to the market-leading Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

The SLM Corporation, the educational lender known as Sallie Mae, had its long-term credit ratings cut by Moody's Investors Service to two levels above junk Tuesday on concern that a change in the company's strategy will erode profitability.

Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook is not stepping aside for a chief executive as Larry Page and Sergey Brin did at Google or as Jerry Yang and David Filo did at Yahoo. He is following the Bill Gates model and holding the top post as he hires a Google executive, Sheryl Sandberg, as chief operating officer.

Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.
A former executive at Broadcom will pay $1.4 million to settle claims she participated in a scheme to backdate stock options at the chip maker, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday.

In a move that could delay a proxy contest, Yahoo said it was extending the deadline for nominating directors to its board.
The senior pilot for Cathay Pacific was dismissed for making a low-level airfield fly-past that the airline says was unauthorized.
The motion to disqualify Roger Clemens’s lead lawyer, Rusty Hardin, said Hardin had a conflict of interest because he had represented Andy Pettitte and Clemens.
Barack Obama holds the delegate lead, but Hillary Rodham Clinton showed she can win the big states.
Senator Barack Obama’s advisers were planning to unveil a new strategy to persuade Democrats to coalesce around him for the good of the party.
Bones and a skull that may be human remains were found by teenagers playing in a Queens park late Tuesday afternoon.
It’s official: the networks no longer cover news, they slap it onto the bottom edge of their regular programming like Post-it notes.
Goaltender Wade Dubielewicz reprised his role as the unlikely hero in a shootout victory, rekindling memories of a similar victory last season in the Islanders’ desperate run at a playoff spot.
Tim Duncan had 29 points and 12 rebounds, and the San Antonio Spurs beat the Nets, 81-70, Tuesday night. Vince Carter led the Nets with 19 points.
Jamar Butler scored 23 of his 25 points in the second half as the Buckeyes defeated visiting Purdue, 80-77, on Tuesday night.
Prime Minister Wen Jiabao’s emphasis on inflation reflects public anxiety over rising domestic prices for food and other items, as inflation hit an 11-year high of 7.1 percent in January.
The $6.3 billion purchase by HSBC Holdings of a stake in Korea Exchange Bank will not hinder market competition, the Fair Trade Commission said.

JBS S.A., the world’s biggest beef producer, agreed to pay $1.27 billion in cash and stock for assets in the United States and Australia, including the beef unit of the pork producer Smithfield Foods.

Because of an editing error, the Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the shrinking television audience for the Academy Awards show, misstated the number of Oscars won this year by “No Country for Old Men.” The film won four Oscars, including best picture — not three. (Its writers-directors, Joel and Ethan Coen, shared the Oscars for best achievement in direction and best adapted screenplay, and Javier Bardem was named best supporting actor.).
A sports article on Feb. 23 about the Accenture Match Play Championship misspelled the surname of the Australian golfer who lost in the event’s title match in 2007. He is Geoff Ogilvy, not Ogilvie.

A sports article on Sunday about Milton Bradley, a talented outfielder now with the Texas Rangers who has a reputation for losing his temper, misstated the position played by Michael Young, a teammate who praised Bradley’s effort and baseball instincts. It is shortstop — not second base, which he played earlier in his career.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the Bolshoi Ballet’s appointment of a new artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, misstated the length of a predecessor’s service. The predecessor, Yuri Grigorovich, who has been named a staff ballet master, was artistic director from 1964 to 1995 — not to 1985.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about Barack Obama’s efforts to court Jewish voters misstated the year he was sworn in as a United States senator and the date’s relationship to a trip he took to Israel. Mr. Obama took office in January 2005, not 2006; he traveled to Israel in January 2006, not “weeks after he was sworn in.”.

An obituary on Tuesday about the Italian tenor Giuseppe di Stefano omitted the names of two survivors and referred incorrectly to his daughter Luisa in some editions. Luisa, who died in 1975, was not his only daughter. A second daughter, Floria, and a son, Giuseppe, both from his second marriage, also survive him.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about Barack Obama’s efforts to court Jewish voters misstated the year he was sworn in as a United States senator and the date’s relationship to a trip he took to Israel. Mr. Obama took office in January 2005, not 2006; he traveled to Israel in January 2006, not “weeks after he was sworn in.”.
Senator John McCain directed his campaign to study past methods of selecting running mates.
New York riders pay a considerably higher share of the cost of mass transit than riders in other cities. It is time for New York drivers to help carry the burden.
What the country needs is a uniform set of rules based on the soundest research to keep teenage drivers and everyone who shares the road with them safer.
Lenders and people who invested in the subprime loans of the bubble years are not doing enough to clean up the mess they created.
Congress still has time to stop some of the worst offenses of vote suppression by passing two bills intended to prevent cynical dirty tricks.
Porsche, the sports car maker, said its net income in the first half of its fiscal year nearly doubled, helped by a bigger stake in Volkswagen and better sales of cars.
Bank of Montreal’s first-quarter profit fell 27 percent, hurt by write-downs related to the capital markets and higher provisions for bad loans.
The Norwegian oil group StatoilHydro agreed to buy stakes in projects in Brazil and the Gulf of Mexico from the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation for up to $2.1 billion.
BP, the oil company, increased the amount of money it has set aside to settle claims from the deadly 2005 Texas City, Tex., refinery explosion by almost a third, to $2.1 billion.
Adecco, a temporary-employment company, said fourth-quarter profit fell 29 percent as hiring slowed in the United States.
Japanese companies cut spending on plant and equipment by 7.7 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the period a year earlier, below the median forecast for a 2.0 percent drop.
Train service to and from Grand Central Terminal was suspended after a vacant five-story building in Harlem collapsed.
As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to seek more time to find other partners or persuade Microsoft to raise its offer.
No. 24 Marist recently completed an 18-0 season in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, a first for the league since it expanded to 10 teams in 1997.
The case of Anthony Pellicano, the onetime sleuth-to-the-stars who is accused of eavesdropping, has a D-list of no-name defendants but big names may be called to testify.
The government is digging a 10-foot-deep trench around the capital, Ndjamena, to prevent a repeat of an attack last month, when rebels in pickup trucks rolled in and fought two days of heavy battles.
The California Supreme Court heard arguments in the most important same-sex marriage case since Massachusetts allowed gay and lesbian couples to marry there more than four years ago.
Britain needs a radical diplomatic shake-up and will move scores of diplomats from Europe to developing countries, said Foreign Secretary David Miliband.
Damion Henry, the first person charged under a new law that increased prison sentences for the attempted murder of a police officer, became the first person acquitted under the law.
The federal attorney general’s office said agents had uncovered 14 bodies buried in the backyard of a house in Ciudad Juárez.
The police have arrested 30 opposition activists and accused them of starting a riot on Saturday in which eight people were killed.
Investigators say they have found no evidence that a fire in an apartment building in the southwestern city of Ludwigshafen that killed nine Turks last month was a premeditated hate crime.
The police detained 14 people, including a family court judge and two social workers, on suspicion of participating in a scheme in which poor mothers were paid to give up their babies.
Colin Norris, a 32-year-old nurse convicted of killing four elderly patients in northern England with insulin overdoses, was sentenced to life in prison.
After a long malaise, CNN is finally getting its swagger back, in large part from high ratings from this year’s presidential race.

Kjetil Backen of Norway made it through heavy falling snow to be the first musher in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race to reach the checkpoint at Nikolai, Alaska. Backen coasted into the checkpoint, 347 miles into the race, at 10:39 a.m. with 15 dogs. The veteran Gerry Willomitzer of Whitehorse, Yukon, was second to reach Nikolai, the first of many Native villages along the 1,100-mile trail to Nome. Willomitzer clocked in at 11:17 a.m. with 14 dogs. A race spokesman said the temperature in Nikolai was in the 30s, which “is too hot for the dogs to run in.”.

Matthias Lanzinger of Austria had his lower left leg amputated Tuesday because of complications after breaking two bones in a crash at a World Cup event in Kvitfjell, Norway. Lanzinger, 27, broke his tibia and fibula Sunday during the super-G event. The double fracture severely damaged blood vessels, which hampered blood circulation in the leg. The Austrian ski federation said surgery Monday night was only partly successful and left doctors no other option in an effort to avoid further health risks.
Hedo Turkoglu scored 24 points, Dwight Howard overcame a slow start to collect 19 points and 14 rebounds, and the host Orlando Magic beat the Toronto Raptors, 102-87.

Shalane Flanagan, who holds the American women’s records for 5,000 meters outdoors and 3,000 indoors, has agreed to run in Central Park for the first time as a professional. The New York Road Runners announced that Flanagan would run March 15 in a women’s 8-kilometer (4.97-mile) invitational race. The field will include Katie McGregor, Jen Rhines, Carrie Tollefson, Amy Rudolph, Erin Donohue and Lisa Galaviz, all potential American Olympians, and Carmen Douma-Hussar of Canada and Liliya Shobukhova of Russia.The race is part of the Central Park Challenge, which will be highlighted by the national 8-kilometer championship for men. That race has attracted Alan Webb, Dathan Ritzenhein and Jorge Torres. Abdi Abdirahman, a two-time American Olympian, has withdrawn, saying he was not ready.

The Irish team of Peter O’Leary and Stephen Milne grabbed the lead at the end of the third leg of the Bacardi Cup regatta on Biscayne Bay off Miami. John Dane III and Austin Sperry of the United States, the 2006 winners of the Bacardi Cup, were close behind. Iain Percy and Andrew Simpson of Britain finished third to claim the overall lead in the regatta with three races remaining. The Brazilians Lars Grael and Marcel Jordao were in second.

JUPITER, Fla. (AP) — As the Florida Marlins took batting practice before an intrasquad game, the music over the stadium public-address system featured crooners from the 1950s, creating a mellow soundtrack that agitated the players.
The Bush administration and the Federal Reserve are inching closer toward a government rescue of distressed homeowners and mortgage lenders.
Investors and analysts have urged a breakup of Citigroup, saying the company has become too unwieldy to be managed effectively.
Isiah Thomas spent another day dodging questions about Stephon Marbury on Tuesday. More precisely, he spent about 129 seconds dodging the questions before cutting off the interview.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Eliot Spitzer feuded over the mayors budget, which called for new spending reductions to account for diminished state aid.
The Rev. Ian Paisley said he would quit in May as first minister of the 10-month-old coalition government and as leader of the Democratic Unionists.
The redfish of southwest Florida’s lower Caloosahatchee River estuary have a well-deserved reputation as some of the spookiest in the United States.
Many schools in New York City are experimenting with monetary incentives to promote learning.
New Yorkers may not jump off the Empire State Building, even with a parachute, after all, an appellate court in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday.

The proposal calls for a “relatively modest” income tax increase coupled with property tax rebates as a way to increase revenue and stimulate the state’s economy.
The plan met with objections from the public over the idea of opening a fancy restaurant amidst what was conceived of originally as a sanctuary for working people.

David Lee and Nate Robinson are both eligible to sign lucrative contract extensions this summer. But will financial security be enough for them to stay with the dysfunctional Knicks?
Zach Parise scored twice and Martin Brodeur made 40 saves for the Devils, who ended a three-game winless streak on Tuesday night with a 4-1 victory over the Maple Leafs in Toronto.

The president of the Dominican Republic’s baseball league said the nation would pull out of next year’s World Baseball Classic if it was not chosen as a site.
Former President Lech Walesa of Poland was discharged from a Houston hospital, four days after surgeons implanted a pacemaker.
Some 67,000 child car seats manufactured by Combi USA Inc., based in Fort Mill, are being recalled because federal tests show that the seats might separate from their bases in front-end collisions.

There were fewer accidents and deaths involving trains last year, but more railroad incidents involving hazardous materials.

The Books of The Times review in The Arts on Feb. 26 and an article in House & Home on Thursday described the experiences of Margaret B. Jones, who said that she had been a foster child and gang member in South Central Los Angeles and survived to write a book about that life. “Margaret B. Jones” turned out to be a pseudonym, and her story a complete fabrication, as The Times reported on Tuesday. An article about how her publisher, and the newspaper, failed to discover the truth earlier appears today in The Arts on Page E1.

The last ball Brett Favre threw was intercepted by Giants cornerback Corey Webster. It now belongs to Greg Gadson, a United States Army lieutenant who lost his legs in May while serving in Iraq.
Kei Igawa retired all six hitters he faced in the Yankees’ 2-0 victory on Tuesday, throwing his first three pitches for balls and then 14 of his last 16 for strikes.

John Fry’s path to the presidency of Franklin & Marshall College defies convention. He has no doctorate, did not teach, publish research, serve as a department chairman, dean or provost.
A marketer is plop-plopping a vintage brand character back into ads, hoping to generate some fizz-fizz among a new generation of consumers.
An isolated mountain hamlet in Britain has to handle tens of thousands of people who take part each summer in a hiking event held for charity.
The United States Trustee has filed a second lawsuit against the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, accusing the company of abusing the bankruptcy process.
Developers seem to be taking a second look at “brownfields,” which are heavily polluted sites ranging from derelict factories to municipal dumps.

Kenny Chesney was showedwith 11 nominations when the contenders for the Academy of Country Music Awards were announced on Tuesday, Reuters reported. Rodney Atkins was second with six nominations, followed by Brad Paisley with four as an individual and Big & Rich and Sugarland with four each as duos. Along with the nominations, announced in Nashville, came word that for the first time fans will choose the winner of the entertainer of the year prize. Voting will begin May 5; the awards will be presented on May 18 in a program to be telecast on CBS from Las Vegas.

Because the rock guitarist Eddie Van Halen, below, is undergoing tests for an unspecified medical problem, his band, Van Halen, has rescheduled four concerts. The March 3 Dallas show was rescheduled for April 24, the March 5 Cincinnati show for April 22, the March 7 Raleigh, N.C., show for April 13, and the March 9 Baltimore show for April 15, Billboard reported. Mr. Van Halen, 53, has dealt with cancer and alcohol in the past, but according to a statement released by the tour promoter, Live Nation, his physician said Mr. Van Halen was “undergoing a battery of comprehensive medical tests to determine a defined diagnosis and recommended medical procedures.” The band returned to touring last fall with its original lead singer, David Lee Roth, for the first time in more than 20 years. The tour has routinely sold out arenas in North America.
To the Editor:.

The Icelandic singer Bjork, above, stirred controversy in China when she finished her concert and a performance of her song “Declare Independence” at the Shanghai International Gymnastics Center on Sunday by shouting, “Tibet! Tibet!,” the BBC reported. China has ruled Tibet since 1951, and talk of independence is taboo. Some members of the audience were clearly uneasy and left hurriedly; others appeared not to have heard Bjork. Afterward, Chinese Web sites carried some negative reactions. “I like Bjork,” said one. “It’s O.K. for her to have a different point of view, but for her to do this is disrespectful to fans here — very selfish of her.” The state-controlled Chinese news media did not report on Bjork’s behavior.
Pete Doherty and Carl Barat, a former band mate from the Libertines, are writing a musical for the Donmar Warehouse in London.
The Royal Shakespeare Company, starting a new initiative to improve the teaching of Shakespeare, is recommending that children be taught his works beginning at 4.

CW, the fifth-place broadcast television network, handed pink slips to more than 25 staffers on Monday. The network eliminated its comedy department and merged two other programming units to create a single office for scripted shows. It also cut some marketing jobs from its cable channel operation. The moves were described by network officials as a restructuring of “some programming and marketing functions as part of an effort to streamline both areas.” The two-year-old network, which has lost 20 percent of its audience this season, currently schedules only one night of comedies, relying more heavily on unscripted fare like “America’s Next Top Model” and dramas like “Gossip Girl.” Also on Monday, the network announced the early renewals of six series for next fall, including the sitcom “Everybody Hates Chris” and the drama “Smallville.” Among the shows that are new this year, only “Gossip Girl” was picked up.

“Away From Her” was the big winner when the Genie Awards, Canada’s equivalent of the Oscars, were handed out Monday night in Toronto, Reuters reported. The film, about the impact of Alzheimer’s disease on a married couple, won seven awards, including best picture, best actor (Gordon Pinsent as the husband), best actress (Julie Christie as the wife), best director (Sarah Polley), best adapted screenplay (Ms. Polley), best supporting actress (Kristen Thomson) and the Claude Jutra Award for outstanding achievement by a first-time feature film director (Ms. Polley). “Eastern Promises,” the David Cronenberg film about the Russian mob in London, also won seven awards, including for best supporting actor (Armin Mueller-Stahl) and best original screenplay (Steve Knight).

Long live the interest in the royal family. A two-hour documentary about the British monarchy attracted 14.1 million viewers to ABC on Monday, making the network No. 1 for the night despite a poor performance for “October Road” at 10 p.m. The game show “Deal or No Deal,” in a new time slot at 9 p.m., averaged 10.8 million viewers, enough to earn NBC a second-place finish. CBS placed third, as strong showings by “Two and a Half Men” (9.9 million at 9) and “CSI: Miami” (9.2 million at 10) offset lower-rated sitcoms like the new series “Welcome to the Captain” (5.6 million at 8:30). In the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, ABC and Fox were tied for first place. Almost eight million viewers watched the conclusion of “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” on Fox.
In a recent study, researchers found that a $2.50 placebo works better than one that costs 10 cents.
If you live in the United States and like spicy tuna rolls, Puerto Rican roast pork or Thai noodles, there is a good chance you are eating, and enjoying, MSG.

CONDELLO--Vincent, on March 1, 2008 formerly of Teaneck, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10am on Thursday, March 6, 2008 at Saint Anastasia's R.C. Church, Teaneck, NJ. Services by Scanlan Funeral Home, Pompton Plains, New Jersey. scanlanfuneralhome.com

MACLEOD--Mary, on March 3, 2008. Born in Albany, NY, and moved to Washington Heights, where she attended schools. Mary started her career at B. Altman and then joined American Express for the prestigious Racket and Tennis Club on Park Avenue. Mary became president and then a partner for Continental American Travel. We remember her strong, appreciative spirit, and her deep concern for people. She made a difference just being herself. Service Thursday, March 6, 11:30am at Frank E. LAPPAS--Alexandra, of Fort Lee, New Jersey, and Singer Island, Florida, died on March 1st at her Florida home. Ms. Lappas was a graduate of Smith College and the Harvard Business School, where she received her Masters in Business Administration. After graduation, she was employed for many years as an executive at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. She also served as chairperson of the Makarios Scholarship/Theodore & Wally Lappas Awards. She leaves to cherish her memory her brother, Theodore; and sister-in-law, Yvonne; nieces, Michelle, Caren, and Corrine; nephews, Corey, and Charles; cousin;, Ruth; and many other family members, and most important Sheila, her dear and loving friend for over 15 years, as well as a host of dear close friends and associates.
