DeLaCOUR--Margaret. The Board and Staff of the Community Service Society of New York mourn the loss of a dear friend and sister of our president, David R. Jones. Along with her husband, Willis, Mrs. DeLeCour was especially committed to CSS's focus on supporting low-income New Yorkers, as exhibited through her sage counsel, ongoing involvement, and generous and longstanding financial support through the DeLaCour Family Foundation.

SILVER--Warren A., age 93, December 8, 1914-February 26, 2008. Died peacefully after a short illness in Deltona, Florida, where he resided for many years with his beloved and loving son, Marcelo. Warren graduated from Columbia University Law School in NYC in 1940, served as a U.S. Army officer in WW II and retired from a distinguished career in the U.S. Foreign Service, in which he traveled the world. In retirement he pursued his passion for writing novels and plays, publishing The Green Rose in 1977, a historical novel which portrayed the Jewish mystic poet Gabirol in 11th century Spain, a Golden Age of Jewish-Arab co-existence. Warren had a kind wit and was renaissance in his knowledge and interests. Loving, generous and loyal, he believed that the universe was divine, moral and purposeful. SILVER--Warren A., died in Deltona, Florida, February 26, 2008. Thank you dear Warren for your friendship, support and guidance over 53 years. Thank you Marcelo Silver for the love and care you gave your beautiful father all these years. As this successful and accomplished man often said, you were the best thing that ever happened to him. With love, Daniel J. Smith Ph.D., New York City and Allentown, PA.

BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. We mourn the loss of R. Palmer Baker Jr., our friend, colleague and mentor. A close advisor to D. K. Ludwig and executor of his estate, R. Palmer Baker Jr. was a major force in the creation of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research in 1971. The Ludwig Institute from its inception was designed to establish and integrate laboratory and clinical cancer research activities spanning the globe. Mr. Baker was a vital and long standing member of the Institute's Board of Directors and served as Chairman of the Board from 1995-2005, guiding the Institute as it continued to emerge into the world's largest international not-for-profit cancer research enterprise. Mr. Baker was also a Trustee of the Virginia and D.K. Ludwig Fund for Cancer Research, which, in 2006, made the largest single donation by a foundation to cancer research in the United States, establishing research centers at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Chicago and Stanford University. He was deeply admired by the entire Ludwig community for his contributions to the world of cancer research The generosity of spirit and high standards that Mr. Baker brought to all of his endeavors will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his daughter, Mary Baker Eaton, and to his grandson, Harold L. Fickett, IV. Lloyd J. Old, M.D. Chairman of the Board Edward A. McDermott, Jr. President Andrew Simpson, Ph.D. Scientific Director Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. Palmer was one of the incorporators of the Vera Institute of Justice in 1961, its first Secretary, and a valued board member until May 2000, when he was elected honorary trustee. He served us with knowledge, wisdom, integrity, style, and love. For 47 years, he endeared himself to scores of fellow trustees and to the staff with whom he worked. We will miss him. Laurie Robinson, Chair Michael Jacobson, President BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. Argus Community, Inc. mourns the passing of its long-time board member and chairman who contributed so much to this organization and to the South Bronx community that it serves. Palmer, as he was known to all, led this agency, founded in 1968 by his dear friend Elizabeth L. Sturz, with grace, generosity, vision, and always, kindness. The Board and the Executive staff counted on him for his guidance in all matters of governance and looked to him for wisdom when wisdom was needed. We will miss him greatly and extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter, Mary Baker Eaton, and his grandson, Harold L. Fickett, IV. Elizabeth L. Sturz, President Marion C. Katzive, Chair Samuel P. Peabody and Leslie A. Ross, Vice Chairs Richard Weiss, Chief Executive Officer

SEITZ--Frederick. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Frederick Seitz, fourth president of The Rockefeller University. During Dr. Seitz's ten-year administration, new basic research programs were started in reproductive biology, cell biology, molecular biology and the neurosciences as well as new clinical investigations at the university's research hospital, a joint M.D.-Ph.D. program in cooperation with Cornell University Medical College was initiated, and he established the 1,000-acre Center for Field Research in Ethology and Ecology at Millbrook, NY. Also during his tenure seven endowed professorships were created, the university completed construction of several critically important buildings and the Rockefeller Archive Center in Pocantico, NY, was established. Dr. Seitz also played a major role in launching the first development program in the university's history. A distinguished physicist and educator who held key government posts for over three decades, Dr. Seitz was a past president of the National Academy of Sciences, and in 1973 he received the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award in science. As president emeritus, Dr. Seitz remained an active campus citizen, prolific author of several books and an advocate for the university. We extend our deepest condolences to his son, Jack, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and his many colleagues on campus. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus

The TRW Automotive Holdings Corporation, the auto-safety equipment maker, said Tuesday that it reached an agreement to end a strike in Ontario that forced Chrysler to idle a minivan plant. About 170 workers at a TRW plant near Windsor, Ontario, who walked out Feb. 28 will return to work, the company's spokesman, Manley Ford, said.

TAM--Dr. Thomas, 62. Beloved father, husband, son, brother, uncle, teacher, artist and friend, died in New York City on February 27. He was a renaissance man, earning degrees in physics, film-making, public health and sociomedical sciences, and going on to teach at Columbia, Herbert Lehman College, and St. Joseph's in Philadelphia. Tom was a pillar of the city's Chinese community; he was the first Chinese-American appointed to the Board of Trustees of the City University of New York, and established a diverse group of Asian American organizations; the Chinatown Health Clinic, the Asian American Film Festival, the Asian American Higher Education Council and the Asian/Asian American Research Institute. Tom was an avid filmmaker himself; one of his many short films was exhibited at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Tom was a devoted father to his daughter Anika and the dedicated eldest son in his family. He is survived by Anika, his wife Margaret, his mother Shui Oi, his two sisters Pearl and Ning Chu, and his brother Heung. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 9th, from 2:30-5:00pm at the Asian/ Asian American Research Institute at 25 West 43rd Street, 18th Floor (between 5th and 6th Avenues). Further information can be found at http:// www.aaari.info/tomtamme morial.htm

BERWIND--Sigrid, known to her friends as ''Sigi'', died in her sleep Saturday evening March 1st at her home Marlborough Farm, Willistown, PA. She was surrounded by friends and family, and the gardens and countryside that she loved. She was 66 and died after a courageous 17-year battle with cancer. Born in Coesfeld, Germany in 1941, during the war, and suffering the loss of her father, Sigrid completed her primary and secondary school in Switzerland. In 1962, shortly after marrying Milton Ginsberg of Bryn Mawr, PA, Sigi moved to Philadelphia, studying at Bryn Mawr College, giving birth to her daughters Victoria and Kirsten, and beginning her life long passion for a fierce game of tennis. In 1979, Sigi married her second husband, Charles Graham Berwind of Bryn Mawr. While raising a young family, Sigi became an advocate for the quality of life in Philadelphia; serving for more than 30 years on various boards including: The Rosenbach Foundation, The Gesu School, The Philadelphia Zoo, The Franklin Institute, Philadelphia Green and Sacred Places. Outside of Philadelphia, Sigi's interest in the environment continued with her involvement in the Nature Conservancy, The Maine Coastal Heritage Trust, and the Jackson Laboratory. Late in life Sigi formalized her long love of gardening, completing her degree in Garden Design at the English Gardening School in London. To her friends and family, Sigi will be remembered as a spirited hostess, with an irreverent wit and an appetite for good conversation; sharing her beloved gardens and homes in Willistown, Palm Beach, Mount Desert Island, New York City and Harbor Islandeach place unique. It was her unconventional eye and innate ability to represent objects from around the world that defined the magic of her remarkable homes. Her unstoppable will and grit brought these visions to life. Within these worlds, Sigi established an endless extended family, mentoring countless young friends, all fortunate enough to fall under her spell. At the time of her death, Sigi was astonishing as she began to assemble antiquities and stones at Marlborough Farm for a new meditation garden set to the east, in the sand of an old horse paddock. Sigi is survived by her former husbands, Milton Ginsberg of Bryn Mawr and C. Graham Berwind of Philadelphia, her daughters Victoria Lunt of Greenwich, CT, and Kirsten White of Willistown, PA, and her six grandchildren Alexandra, Sarah, Laela, Maximilian, Chloe and Nicholas. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Gesu School, 1700 West Thompson Street, Philadelphia, PA 19121 or The Maine Coastal Heritage Trust, 1 Bowdoin Mill Island, Suite 201, Topsham, ME 04086. Services to be held at 4pm on Thursday, March 6th, at St. Malachy Church, 1429 N. 11th Street, Philadelphia, PA followed by a reception at The Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, 128 N. Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. Interment will be private. Services are being handled by The Donohue Funeral Home, 1627 West Chester Pike, West Chester, PA 19382. 610431-9000 and online condolences may be made at our website: www.donohuefuneral home.com

NAGY--Gladys, 73, of New York, New York, died peacefully on March 2, 2008 at Weill Cornell Medical Center after a two year battle with ovarian cancer. Gladys was born on November 19, 1934 in New York City to Elizabeth and Louis Yager. Throughout her life, Gladys was very active in New Yorks Hungarian-American community, most notably as the chief organizer of the annual Piarist Ball, which benefits the scholarship and building funds of the American and Hungarian Piarist Schools. Gladys cherished family and friends, loved travel, derived great pleasure from decorating her East Side home and enjoyed sharing life with her husband. She had tremendous energy and youthful exuberance. Gladys is survived by her husband, Adam Nagy of New York City; son Adam P. Nagy of Phoenicia, NY; sister Katherine Schumacher of New York City; and foster sister Janet Gutyan of Pasadena, CA. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Thursday, 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (www.ocrf.org) in the name of Gladys Nagy.

GOTO--Naoko Kobayashi, died in Tokyo unexpectedly on Tuesday, February 26, at the age of 46. Beloved mother of Lisa, daughter of Yakashi and Ayako Kobayashi, cherished friend of The Brearley School and Isetan Co., Ltd. communities. Naoko was raised in Tokyo and attended Gakushuin elementary school, high school and college and came to this country after marrying Morihiko Goto, managing director and head of international sales at Utendahl Capital Partners, I.P. Her father, Takashi Kobayashi, is an executive advisor of Fukoku Mutual Life Insurance Co., which he served formerly as chairman and chief executive officer. Her mother, Ayako Kobayashi, is a professor of English language and literature at Tokyo Kasei University. Naoko was a woman of exquisite grace and rare intelligence who prized friends and family most importantly, and gave unstintingly or her warmth to all she knew. She was an active parent at The Brearley School, one of many benevolent involvements. Naoko was a member of the Junior League and of Nadeshiko Kai, a Japanese women's organization; she was also a volunteer at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. Naoko worked in the New York office of Istean Co., Ltd., a leading Japanese department store, in administration and translation. An accomplished linguist, she had received a master's degree in German literature from New York University, had taught Japanese at The New School and was enrolled in the graduate program in English as a second language at Columbia University Teachers College. But her proudest achievement was her wonderful daughter, Lisa, whom she treasured. She will be missed by all those who loved her in the Brearley and Isetan communities, and in the many circles where she was known. She is survived by Morihiko, her parents, her daughter, Lisa, and by two sisters and one brother. A memorial service in New York will be held in the spring.

NANON--Patricia, of New York City and Chilmark, Massachusetts, died peacefully on February 29, in her home in New York City surrounded by her loving daughters. She was 84. Ms. Nanon, a choreographer, was a 1944 graduate of Bennington College and the Founder and long time Artistic Director of The Yard, a colony for the performing arts on Martha's Vineyard. The Yard is a treasured part of both the Vineyard and the contemporary dance world, which has often honored her for her vision and generosity. She is survived by her daughters Vicki Woolner Samuels of Chicago, Cate Woolner of Northfield, Massachusetts and Justine Woolner Wise of Oneonta, New York, their families, many devoted nieces and nephew and their families, as well as many dear friends. SEAMAN--Barbara. The National Women's Health Network is saddened at the passing of author and NWHN co-founder Barbara Seaman. Her work launched a political movement that resulted in more women doctors, safer contraceptives and consumers' right to information. We will miss her curiosity, humor and generous spirit.

NASSBERG--Jack, ended his journey of almost 93 years on Monday, March 03, 2008, in Indianapolis. He is survived by his loving family, including his wife of 55 years, Ruth Ellen of Tamarac, Florida and Haifa, Israel; his son, Barry, of Hong Kong and daughter, Michele, of Indianapolis; their spouses Nancy Wright and Gadi Boukai and adoring grandchildren Ben-Ari, Maya Tani and Victoria Ellen. He leaves also his devoted nephew Dr. Barton Nassberg, of Freehold, New Jersey, son of his beloved brother Max, sadly missed since 1971. Jack was a modern-day Renaissance man, whose life was shaped by tragedy, instinct for survival, great drive and a passion for education. He was a teacher, soldier, journalist, businessman and writer. A speaker of seven languages, most self-taught, he thrived on his keen understanding of the history of his people, and his passion for sharing it with others. Born in 1915 in Mikulince, in the Galicia region of the Austro-Hungary Empire, later a part of Poland, Jack experienced the horrors of the Holocaust when both his parents and sister perished during the invasion of his home town. Having already been drafted into the Polish Army, chance saved him from the fate of his family. Thus began a journey of escape from the Nazi advance that would take him through Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan and Persia. It would see him imprisoned by the Soviets in a labor camp, a further escape, and an eventual race to freedom. He would later in life devote years to recording his harrowing tale in a book of his war-time exploits. As a journalist in Italy in the post-war years, he traveled to Palestine on assignment, where he met his wife-to-be, Ruth Ellen, herself a survivor and refugee. They would marry in 1953. Jack eventually joined his brother Max, who had already immigrated to the USA, and entered the retail trade. Along with a cousin, Michael Lehrer, they would develop MacRae's Shops, a group of successful ladies wear stores in Queens and Brooklyn, New York. These thrived, and allowed Jack to realize his dream of re-building his life in his adopted and beloved country. A firm advocate of the Zionist ideal, Jack was a founding leader of the youth movement ''Gordonia''. He later supported organizations that promoted American assistance for Israel. He believed in the shared responsibility of the Diaspora to ensure a viable Israel, thus assuring the future of the Jewish people, no matter where they lived. Along with their Tamarac, Florida residence, Jack and his wife maintained a second home in Haifa, Israel, periodically spending time there. Both his children are graduates of Haifa secondary schools. Jack was the solid foundation of a dynamic family. A source of great inspiration to his children, he instilled in them a love of knowledge and education, commitment and a great sense of work ethic. He led by example, showing what could be achieved through hard work and devotion. He was the patriarch of the extended Nassberg family, an endless source of historical minutiae, whether on topics of politics or world affairs, faith and tradition, or the obscure roots of the family. He was an active member and officer of the Mikulincer Sick and Benevolent Association, a landsmanschaft (immigrants society) founded in 1899 and devoted to the well being of immigrants from his home town. He served as their President for almost thirty years. In recent years he meticulously researched and wrote a book on the genealogy of the Nassberg clan, providing the younger generation with a detailed look at the family's European origins. In 1993 Jack, accompanied by his wife and son, took his first trip back to his roots, visiting his home town (today located in the Ukraine) for the first time since the war. It would help bring closure to events that had defined his life. In 2004 Jack suffered a major stroke, paralyzing much of his body and speech. Despite his advanced age at the time, his extraordinary commitment to rehabilitation, along with the unfailing support of his wife, resulted in an almost miraculous restoration of most functions. In early 2005 they moved to Indianapolis to join their daughter and her family. This allowed Jack to enjoy his last years surrounded by his loving extended family. He thrived until just weeks before the end of his journey. Jack was an inspiration to his wife and children, his extended family, friends and all who knew him. His life story, his insight and wise counsel, his ever present cheer and good humor, touched the lives of countless people. He was the consummate gentleman. He took seriously his obligation to perfect the world (''tikkun olam''), and leaves a legacy of love, honor and social justice. His family now celebrates the conclusion of an extraordinary journey. Services will be held on Wednesday, March 5, 2008 at 1PM at the Aaron - Ruben - Nelson Mortuary, 1328 West 86th Street. Interment will be Friday, March 7, 2008 at 1PM at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, New Jersey. No flowers, please. Memorial donations to either Hooverwood Nursing Home, 7001 Hoover Road, Indianapolis, IN 46260 (317)251-2261 or the St. Vincent Foundation, 8402 Harcourt Rd. #

JAFFE--Paul, 81, passed away from complications of Parkinson's disease at his home in Bayside, NY, on March 3rd. He is survived by his loving and devoted family: his wife Roberta, his children Margot (Alfred), Joanne (Douglas), and Jonathan; his sister Selma, and grandchildren Keith, Christopher, Joseph, Jacob, and Elena. Paul attended Princeton while in the Army and graduated from L.I.U College of Pharmacy (1952). He was the proprietor of two drug stores in the Greenpoint/Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. A consummate professional, he dedicated his talent and knowledge to serving his customers with love and compassion. After selling his businesses, he continued working as a Pharmacist until he was no longer able to do so. Paul was kind, caring and selfless and always concerned for the underdog. He faught a valiant battle against Parkinson's. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, NY, NY, 10018. For memorial service and Shiva info call Sinai Chapels: 1-800-446-0406.

LEGAULT--Robert Paul, on February 22, 2008. Devoted brother of Jeanne Legault. Copy Editor of major publications here in New York City. Memorial service at Beth Abraham Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St, NYC, Sunday, March 9, 2008, 10:30am12:30pm.

8 P.M. (TCM) THE RAKE'S PROGRESS (1945) Turner Classic Movies celebrates the 100th birthday of that man-about-town Rex Harrison, starting with this drama from the director Sidney Gilliat about a 1930s playboy who finds redemption in World War II. The festivities continue with Harrison's best-known role, as Henry Higgins in 1964 in ''My Fair Lady'' (above right, with Audrey Hepburn and Jeremy Brett), at 10; ''The Reluctant Debutante'' (1958), in which he plays a British father aghast at his daughter's Americanization, at 1 a.m.; ''The Happy Thieves'' (1962), adapted from Richard Condon's novel ''The Oldest Confession,'' about art swindlers, at 3; and ''The Long Dark Hall'' (1951), in which he plays a naïve family man who is framed for the murder of a showgirl, at 4:30. 7 P.M. (Sundance) HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON: THE IMPASSIONED EYE (2003) As part of its ''Life in Focus'' series, the channel presents documentaries about two photographers, starting with Heinz Butler's film about the man many consider the 20th century's greatest photographer. The documentary ''is not a biography but an interview,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, ''conceived as a master class on art appreciation, with guest commentators augmenting Cartier-Bresson's own sparsely chosen words.'' Michael Almereyda's ''William Eggleston in the Real World'' (2005) follows at 8:15.

The top news in the city this morning is the small blast that damaged the army recruiting station in Times Square around 4 a.m. No one was injured, and subways and traffic are now running. City Room has all the details here and will continue with updates through the day.

A large majority of people in New York believe that global warming is happening because of human activities, and more than two-thirds think that parts of the city will even have to be abandoned over the next 50 years because of rising sea levels, according to survey results released this morning by Columbia and Yale Universities, which called the research the first comprehensive study of opinions from residents of the five boroughs about global warming.

The United Nations, which has long sought to renovate the Secretariat building on First Avenue and build a new office building, is considering a move to a proposed tower at a development site along the East River that is wending its way toward final approval by the city. The project is owned by the developer Sheldon H. Solow, who hopes to persuade the City Council to grant his $4 billion project final approval next week. The project, which includes seven glass towers along First Avenue, between 35th and 41st Streets, has come under criticism from community groups and Councilman Daniel R. Garodnick who contend that the buildings are too big and have urged the developer to eliminate the sole office tower from what they say is a residential neighborhood. The six other buildings are apartment houses.

Even directors of the Jacob K. Javits Development Corporation are unhappy about the state’s recently revamped plans for the convention center. Federal authorities have announced the arrests of four people accused of running an online prostitution ring that had clients in major cities from New York to Paris and took in more than $1 million in profits over four years. The ring was known as the Emperor’s Club VIP and had 50 prostitutes available for appointments in New York, Paris, Washington, Miami and London, according to a federal complaint issued in United States District Court in Manhattan.

Agnes Boulard, known as Mademoiselle Agnes on a popular French television series about fashion, did not get home until 7 o'clock on Sunday morning. She had been out dancing. By the time of the Lanvin show, she was remarkably changed-as Anna Wintour. Lots of people in the moments before the show assumed that Mlle Agnes was Madame Wintour. She had on a fur coat and dark glasses and looked ready for the models to get moving. The give-away was that the figure in the front row did not have a posse of Vogue editors around her. "It's hard being Anna," Boulard said, lowering her shades. (I just didn't believe it was her.) She and her Canal+ collaborator Loic Prigent, who made that great documentary about Marc Jacobs, do an irreverent segment called "Signe Anna," or signed Anna, for their show.

Bulgari's new masculine, Aqva Pour Homme Marine, which has been on the market for a few weeks, carries two fingerprints. The first is of its creator, Jacques Cavallier, a prolific perfumer so successful these days that he often seems to generate a quarter of each year's worldwide fragrance product. The second is the unmistakable scent of a molecule, methylbenzodioxepinone, also known to the trade as Calone. Cavallier, plucked it from the crowd and cast it in starring roles in several of the biggest commercial successes the perfume industry has ever seen. It virtually defined perfume style in the 1990s. Whether Bulgari is making a wise choice in launching an updated 90s scent in 2008 is another question.

Alaia offered me a chair next to the table. A number of writers had trooped by over the weekend and we probably all had the same thought: Gee, what a fantastic way to look at clothes.

The Sarbanes-Oxley Act has many detractors. They claim that the Act is an over-burdensome piece of regulation, one that has imposed costly and unneeded obligations on issuers. It has driven U.S. companies to exit the public markets and "go private," and it has deterred non-U.S. companies from raising capital and listing in the United States.

There was no question: I couldn't leave Penang, Malaysia without spending at least one night at the Cathay Hotel. But it was completely booked. I begged, shamelessly. I showed up twice a day to chat up one or another of the elderly Chinese men who manned the marvelous, Art Deco front desk with its vintage square 1950s clock above. I even pulled out my secret weapon: I chatted them all up in Cantonese.

Genoa doesn't have the, ahem, difficult reputation Naples does, but if anything it has fewer American visitors. In the case of both cities, this is near-tragic; in the case of Genoa it's unbelievable. Both are central cities of former kingdoms, and in both the evidence is plain to see. But in Genoa -- reminiscent of the Barcelona of twenty years ago -- much of the core of the ancient city remains intact, pleasant to visit and relatively ungentrified (that's changing of course).

Don't despair, Bill Gates: You may have lost your position atop Forbes's annual billionaires list, but you are No. 1 on another ranking this week: Vanity Fair's "Windfall Report," a rundown of the 50 biggest American paydays of 2007 and the people who got them. Bucknell not only overcame a 17-point deficit in the second half and withstood three overtimes to beat Navy in the Patriot League tournament. The Bison won because John Griffin made a half-court shot at the buzzer to give them an 87-86 victory.

In the latest offering from T: Online, we bring you exclusive access to the show everybody is talking about this morning - this year's Whitney Biennial. We sat down with curators Henriette Huldisch and Shamim M. Momin to get their distilled view of the contemporary art of the past two years. The results of their pledge to "look a little bit harder," and harness the organic and spontaneous art that often becomes institutionalized in typical museum settings, will be on view March 6 to March 23 at the Park Avenue Armory. Click here (or the video player below) for a preview of the plaster-coated sculpture of river debris by Charles Long, an installation entitled "Divine Violence" by Daniel Joseph Martinez and cast bronze "body masks" by Sherrie Levine.

Obama fans are protesting a Clinton attack ad that seems to darken Obama's complexion, inviting calls of racism. He's substantially blacker in the attack ad than he is in real life or in other videos. Factcheck.org, an indispensable site, investigated and concluded that the ad did indeed seem to be unusually dark. But it found that everything in the ad was dark, including Hillary. Apparently, it's standard to run attack ads in dark hues, so Factcheck says that this was evidence more of negativism than of racism. Incidentally, I recommend signing up for Factcheck's email notifications.

Latest Update, 10 p.m. | The police said the explosive device involved in the Times Square blast this morning was "roughly similar" to the devices used in two earlier bombings at foreign consulates in Manhattan, in 2005 and 2007, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said at an afternoon news conference [video]. The device had been placed in an ammunition box like the kind that can be bought at a military supply store. Officials said that in today's attack, a man bundled in a gray hooded jacket or sweatshirt and wearing a backpack was seen riding a bicycle around the recruiting station and acting suspiciously moments before the explosion. Video footage from a surveillance camera showed a bicyclist dismounting, approaching the recruitment center, then returning to the bike and riding away before the explosion occurs. (See a related slide show and the latest from Friday's print edition.)

And some of the undecided superdelegates are as flummoxed as ever.

In my last Shifting Careers column, I wrote about In Good Company Workplaces, an all-female, shared office space in Manhattan. When the founders gave me a tour of the space, they were especially proud of the spotless and well-organized kitchen where members can keep their food. The office offers free tea and coffee, and I noticed they also stocked Agave nectar, my sweetener of choice. I had another bout of workplace envy. It is relatively easy to eat good foods when you can control the choices, but how many times are we working somewhere and not in control of what we can eat?
Carl Edwards will be allowed to keep his U.A.W.-Dodge 400 victory, but he dropped from first to seventh in the standings and his crew chief was fined and suspended six races.

An article published in the April issue of Esquire magazine and written in the first person as if it were Heath Ledger’s own diary is a fictionalized account of his last days and ponders the indignities of celebrity.
Stock markets fell sharply amid renewed anxiety about the availability of bank loans — and fears that the Federal Reserve may be unable to curb the credit slump.
The legislation would create a public database of complaints about products and empower state prosecutors to take action to protect consumers in their states.
The F.A.A. will seek to fine Southwest $10.2 million for flying 46 older jets that it claimed were grounded because they had not been properly inspected for fuselage cracks.
Criminal charges have been filed against officials of two California companies that allegedly imported and distributed more than 70,000 tubes of Chinese toothpaste containing a poisonous substance.
A gunman opened fire inside a a famous Jewish seminary in the heart of Jerusalem, killing at least eight students and wounding at least nine others, Israeli police said.
Federal regulators said they would seek a penalty of $10.2 million against the airline for failing to inspect older planes for cracks and then flying them before inspections were done.
Apple unveiled new software that reflects its intensifying effort to court business customers and placate third-party developers who want to build iPhone applications but have been locked out.
Shares of American mortgage real estate investment trusts plunged after Carlyle Capital failed to meet margin calls and received a notice of default.
Geologists have concluded that the canyon formed 11 million years earlier than previous estimates.
The two bombings, which authorities said also wounded 123 people, were the worst attacks the capital has seen since early February.
A freshman at the University of California Davis has been arrested after the campus police found what they said were explosive materials in his dorm room.
The Carlyle Capital Corporation, which invests mainly in triple-A rated mortgage securities, became the latest investment firm to run into trouble amid deteriorating credit markets.
January pending sales nationwide were below analysts’ expectations and remained at the second-lowest reading on record, the National Association of Realtors reported.
Foreclosures surged at the end of the last year on adjustable-rate mortgages, an industry group reported.
Sam Zell, the new owner of the Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field, said last week that might sell naming rights to the historic ballpark. What do you think would be the best possible name?.
The decision by the European Central Bank and the Bank of England to leave interest rates unchanged highlights their differences with the Federal Reserve in the United States.

A study released Wednesday suggests that you may not need a Magnetic Resonance Image (MRI) to tell you what’s wrong with your creaky knees. Many physicians automatically order the expensive test for all patients with knee pain. But in the study, reported at the annual conference of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons in San Francisco, researchers at the University of Illinois at Chicago found that a simple X-ray uncovered arthritis more reliably and at a fraction of the cost of an MRI.

Of Brett Favre’s many amazing performances, perhaps none was greater or more memorable than the one he played the night after his father died in 2003, when in front of a Monday Night Football audience, he passed for 399 yards and four touchdowns. As Joe Drape reported for The Times shortly after Irvin Favre died, “Big Irv” possessed the same toughness as his son, and was known in his hometown of Kiln, Miss., where he had coached high school football, as “more than the daddy of Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre.”.

When Hank Steinbrenner disparaged the notion of Red Sox Nation and told PLAY Magazine “this is a Yankee country” (“Oedipus Bronx,” March 2), he sent another tremor along the New York-Boston fault line, with Red Sox owner John Henry playfully offering Steinbrenner a membership in Red Sox Nation and Steinbrenner standing his ground. Virtually overlooked was his contention that the idea was promulgated by ESPN, which Steinbrenner said was “filled with Red Sox fans.”.

March is here, and madness will soon be upon us. Heck, some conference tournaments have already started. PLAY caught up with Rob Weintraub, who previewed the N.C.A.A. tournament in “Main Event” for the March issue of PLAY, and got this thoughts on some of the story lines. Rob’s passion is beyond question: Even if he didn’t have a brand new daughter, he would still be up at 2 a.m.-- watching theBig Sky tournament.
The Federal Court of Canada has ordered an environmental review panel to take a second look at the greenhouse gas implications of oil sands project in Alberta.

The police were investigating the death of a woman who was scheduled to testify in two Manhattan criminal cases but died in a plunge from a Harlem apartment building on Wednesday, the authorities said.

Mike Rosario scored 19 points as St. Anthony of Jersey City, the No. 1-ranked boys basketball team in the country, beat No. 9 St. Patrick of Elizabeth, 64-52, for the North Non-Public B championship in Piscataway, N.J. If St. Anthony (29-0) defeats Trenton Catholic on Saturday in the Non-Public B final in Toms River, it will set a national record with its 25th state title. The Friars are tied with Central High School of Cheyenne, Wyo., with 24.
LeBron James was nearly overshadowed at Wednesday’s game by a spectator in a salmon-and-beige houndstooth coat. Hint? First name: Stephon.

The French bank Crédit Agricole posted a fourth-quarter loss after large write-downs related to the global credit crisis, but its shares rose as the bank said it was not planning any major acquisitions. Crédit Agricole posted a bigger-than-expected net loss of 857 million euros ($1.30 billion). The bank was hurt by a 3.3 billion euro write-down at its investment banking arm. A year earlier, it posted a net profit of just over 1 billion euros. “We have built a solid model,” the chairman, René Carron, above, said. “With its sound capital base, the group will make organic growth its priority and it is not considering any significant new acquisitions.”.

Balfour Beatty, Britain’s biggest builder, said full-year profit surged 66 percent as an acquisition in the United States increased military housing orders and as construction demand rose in Britain and Europe. Net income rose to £151 million ($300 million) from £91 million a year earlier. Revenue climbed 44 percent to £6.47 billion ($12.7 billion). Balfour said it had won contracts from the United States military and hotel industry valued at more than $1.2 billion.

New Zealand’s central bank left the benchmark interest rate at 8.25 percent, saying slowing growth will not relieve pressure on inflation until next year. “We expect that the official cash rate will need to remain at current levels for a significant time,” the Reserve Bank governor, Alan Bollard, said. Inflation is being fanned by a record low jobless rate, rising commodity prices and the promise of income tax cuts.

Australia posted its second-largest trade deficit on record in January as imports rose and floods disrupted exports of coal. The shortfall widened to 2.72 billion Australian dollars ($2.5 billion) from a revised 1.94 billion in December, the Bureau of Statistics said.

Adidas, the German maker of athletic apparel and sporting goods, said its fourth-quarter profit rose 62 percent on lower purchasing costs resulting from its acquisition of Reebok in 2006, but its results fell below analysts’ expectations. The company earned 21 million euros ($31.9 million) in the period, up from 13 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose to 2.4 billion euros ($3.7 billion) from 2.3 billion euros. Adidas said Reebok’s chief marketing officer, Uli Becker, would succeed Paul Harrington as chief executive of the unit.
Alexander Ovechkin scored twice Wednesday night, including his N.H.L.-leading 54th goal, in the Capitals’ 3-1 victory over the Sabres in a key Eastern Conference playoff-race matchup in Buffalo.

HOUSTON (Bloomberg News) — The Countrywide Financial Corporation, the largest American mortgage lender, did not show “bad faith” in the handling of a Texas homeowner’s mortgage and will not be sanctioned merely for unprofessional and unethical conduct, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.
Donte’ Greene had 19 points and 13 rebounds and Syracuse snapped a season-high three-game losing streak with an 85-73 victory over host Seton Hall.
The Boston Celtics are in the playoffs. The Detroit Pistons aren’t far behind.
There is probably a cautionary tale in the meteoric rise and current embattled status of Jeremy J. Shingleton, first selectman (read: mayor) of Cromwell, Conn.
A militant was sentenced to death in connection with organizing a 2006 suicide attack in Karachi that killed an American diplomat, David Foy.
The government hopes to start a baby boom by rewarding women who give birth to eight or more children a one-time bonus of $25 as well as free utilities.
A Russian opposition leader has gone on a hunger strike in St. Petersburg after being arrested before a march on Monday to protest the presidential election.
Francisco Rafael Arellano Félix, the eldest of five brothers who control the drug cartel in Tijuana, is back in Mexico after being freed from a United States prison this week.
The Dutch foreign minister met ambassadors from 30 Muslim countries to discuss the imminent broadcast of an anti-Islam film made by a right-wing politician.
After a standoff lasting almost three hours, the police shot and killed a man armed with explosives who took 10 Australians hostage on a tourist bus in the northern city of Xian.
The measure would impose an income tax increase of nearly 1 percentage point for the next five years on anyone who earns more than a million dollars a year.

Stony glares and bitter words between two families again filled the halls of the Queens County Courthouse on Wednesday, as another member of a family was arraigned in a tangled murder case that has plunged an immigrant community in Rego Park into crisis.
Ice climbing in California sounds a bit like surfing in North Dakota, but frozen waterfalls in the Sierra can become a shining vertical playground in winter.
As residents slept, a storm in Corona, Queens, blew down a 65-foot-tall silver maple that crumpled the front compartment of a minivan and shattered the windshield of another vehicle.

Headlines in some editions on Wednesday about testimony in the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the shooting death of Sean Bell outside a Queens nightclub in 2006 referred incorrectly to the case. It is being heard by a judge only; there is no jury.

An article on Monday about a decision to pursue perjury charges against a New York City engineer in connection with the deaths of two firefighters in the Bronx in 2006 misstated the number of inspectors hired by the Buildings Department in the past six years. It is 149, not “more than 500.” (The higher figure represents the total increase in staff over that time.).

A front-page article on Tuesday about the religious disillusionment among young people in Iraq carried an incomplete list of reporting credits. In addition to three Iraqi reporters who contributed from Baghdad, where the article was written, Iraqi employees of The Times interviewed residents in Basra, Falluja, Baquba and Mosul.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about India’s energy consumption misstated the number of people in the country who rely on animal waste and firewood as fuel for cooking. It is about 700 million, not 700,000.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about India’s energy consumption misstated the number of people in the country who rely on animal waste and firewood as fuel for cooking. It is about 700 million, not 700,000.

A headline on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about results from four presidential primaries on Tuesday misidentified, in some editions, one of the states that voted. It was Ohio, not Iowa.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about Brett Favre’s final N.F.L. pass misstated the military title of Greg Gadson, who now has the ball from that play. He is an Army lieutenant colonel, not a lieutenant.

A picture caption on Wednesday with a front-page article about cash incentives for students, teachers and principals in New York City public schools misidentified the position held by Dalia Johnson at Public School 188 in Manhattan. She is director of the middle school, not the school’s overall director.

An article on Monday about the impending trial of two former senior analysts for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, on charges that they violated the Espionage Act, referred incorrectly to Aipac’s work. The organization, a pro-Israel lobby, works in the United States to advance Israel’s interests. It does not work directly for the state of Israel or its government.

The TV Watch column, in some editions on Wednesday, about coverage of the presidential primaries on Tuesday night, misstated the year the war in Iraq started, a night on which MSNBC drew its highest rating until its broadcast of the Democratic debate last week. It was March 19, 2003 — not 2002.

A sports article in some editions on Sunday about the American Cup gymnastics event at Madison Square Garden described incorrectly a vault performed by Shawn Johnson, the world all-around champion, who finished second in the women’s competition. She completed a somersault and two and a half twists, not two and a half somersaults.

The United States routed China, 4-0, at the Algarve Cup in Albufeira, Portugal, on the opening day of the tournament. Denmark posted a 1-0 victory against Germany, the Women’s World Cup champion. The five-time champion Americans got goals from Lindsay Tarpley, Tobin Heath, Abby Wambach and Carli Lloyd in Group B.

Andy Roddick will face Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals of the Dubai Tennis Championships. Roddick had 13 aces in his 6-3, 6-4 victory against Paul-Henri Mathieu, and the second-ranked Nadal easily beat Mikhail Ledovskikh, 6-4, 6-0. The Australian Open champion Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray also reached the quarterfinals. Murray upset Roger Federer in the first round Monday.

The former champion Mitch Seavey took the lead at the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, becoming the first musher to reach the ghost town of Ophir, Alaska. Seavey, the winner of the 2004 race, overtook the earlier leaders, including the defending champion, Lance Mackey, who was first to the Takotna checkpoint. Seavey covered the 25 miles to Ophir — 444 miles into the 1,100-mile race — in just under three hours.

Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter who was barred from able-bodied competition in January, says new tests on his prosthetic racing limbs contradict an earlier study that led the International Association of Athletics Federations to declare him ineligible for the Olympics. The I.A.A.F., however, does not accept the new findings.“It is really not up to us to judge because we have already made a decision,” Nick Davies, a spokesman for the I.A.A.F., said Wednesday.Based on tests performed by the German professor Peter Brüggemann, the I.A.A.F. ruled in January that Pistorius’s carbon fiber prosthetic blades gave him an advantage. But Pistorius commissioned his own tests in Houston last month, and contends they produced different results that could enhance his chance of competing in Beijing.

Liverpool fans staged a protest during a Premier League match against West Ham on Wednesday, urging the club’s American owners to sell the team to a consortium from Dubai. Fans in the Kop — the area of the stadium filled with the most vocal supporters — stayed throughout halftime and chanted for the owners, Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr., to sell. The two rejected an $800 million offer from Dubai International Capital this week. Fans are upset that Hicks and Gillett, who took charge last March, have saddled the club with debt, failed to start building a new stadium and sought to replace the popular coach Rafa Benítez.
After Tuesday’s primary victories for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, her focus is momentum; for her Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama, it is math.

Penn State tight end Andrew Quarless was suspended indefinitely for an unspecified violation of team rules, the sixth Nittany Lions player suspended in the off-season. Last season, Quarless was suspended by Coach Joe Paterno for the first two games after a citation by the university police for under-age drinking.
After appearing nearly invincible last week, Barack Obama now faces questions about whether he can win states vital to a Democratic victory in November.
For election officials everywhere, Tuesday’s votes in Ohio and Texas were contentious and drawn-out reminders to expect the unexpected in a year of enormous enthusiasm.
The state is asking the drug maker to pay for the medical expenses of Medicaid patients who have contracted diabetes or other diseases after taking the drug Zyprexa.
A bid to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, fell flat on Wednesday, sending the company’s stock tumbling.
Many bills introduced in Albany have little hope of becoming law. But one measure dubbed “the Snowball’s Chance in Hell Bill” is perhaps worth a second look.
Many reform-minded politicians were barred from running, accused by a hard-line group of clerics that vets the candidates of not being loyal to the revolution.
Record oil prices are suddenly creating the sharpest tensions in years between the oil cartel and the U.S.

The San Jose City Council has rescinded its decision to call a Vietnamese retail area Saigon Business District. But the council members stopped short of renaming it Little Saigon. And that name was precisely what hundreds of speakers who showed up on Tuesday night wanted and did not get. Instead, the council voted 7 to 4 to set up a process for naming business districts in the future and give business owners the right to ultimately determine the names.
Across the country, substance abuse centers are reaching out to older addicts who have historically been ignored.

A Swiss bank moved to withdraw a lawsuit it brought against a Web site that it claimed had displayed stolen documents revealing confidential information about its clients. Lawyers in the case said the move by Bank Julius Baer & Company probably ends its battle against Wikileaks, a site that allows people to post documents anonymously “to be of assistance to people of all regions who wish to reveal unethical behavior in their governments and corporations.” Although the bank obtained an order last month from Judge Jeffrey S. White of Federal District Court in San Francisco that obstructed, but did not absolutely prevent, access to material on Wikileaks, the judge on Friday withdrew that order.

Federal job discrimination complaints by workers against private employers rose by 9 percent last year, the biggest annual increase since the early 1990s. The data released by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission showed that accusations of discrimination based on race, retaliation and sex were the most frequent. There were 82,792 complaints filed from Oct. 1, 2006, to Sept. 30, 2007. That was the highest number since 2002 and compares with 75,768 in the 2006 budget year.

Less than a week after plans were announced to raze the Northern Illinois University lecture hall where five students were killed last month, there is now talk that more thought must be given to the idea. Six days ago, the university’s president, John Peters, left, announced that the building, Cole Hall, would be torn down. Mr. Peters changed course on Tuesday and called for a campuswide discussion on the building’s fate. Also, the backyard gun shop where the gunman bought five weapons has closed. Special Agent Thomas Ahern of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said the owner of the shop, Tony’s Guns and Ammo in Champaign, gave up his federal dealer’s license this week and closed.
The city has given out at least 142,000 parking permits to public employees and others, an inventory reveals.
The company agreed to pay $8 million to settle regulatory claims that current and former employees accepted improper gifts in exchange for business.
It is hard to believe that in the 21st century the democratically elected governments of Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela would be talking about war.
Terry Francona and the Red Sox are trying to duplicate the Yankees’ consecutive titles.
March 5, 2008.
A half-dozen media companies have signaled that they plan to bid for the Weather Channel, which is up for auction, people involved in the talks said Wednesday.

TRENTON — Ever since Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is 84, made it clear that he intended to seek re-election in November, the conventional wisdom had been that health would be a factor in the race.
Mets fan Matthew Silverman has written or edited six books about his favorite team.
ATLANTA (Reuters) — The upscale retailers Saks Inc. and Neiman Marcus reported higher quarterly profits Wednesday, but both companies said that sales had softened recently.
Sprinter Dallas Robinson, 6 feet 4 inches and 210 pounds, is turning heads with some of the world’s fastest times, despite his limited training and tremendous size.
If a new set of science standards are strictly followed, Florida may finally be on the way toward improving the quality of its science curriculum.
It’s unclear how the Democratic campaign will end, but we’d like to hear fewer character attacks and a lot more discussion of the nation’s many problems.
The company’s English cousins in the Ford Motor Company family are in the final stages of being sold, leaving Volvo as Ford’s only European luxury brand.
A torrent of water was released into the Colorado River from the Glen Canyon Dam in Arizona, in a disputed effort to improve the environment for fish in the Grand Canyon.
After missing two and a half months last season with injuries, Mets outfielder Moises Alou is out of action again with a hernia that will require surgery.
Prime Minister Stephen Harper said the leak of a Canadian diplomatic memorandum about Senator Barack Obama’s position on Nafta was unfair to his campaign.
The advantage over computer-based social networks, companies believe, is the ability to know where a cellphone is, thanks to global positioning satellites and related technologies.
An explosion flattened a house in suburban Pittsburgh on Wednesday, killing a man, injuring his 4-year-old granddaughter and damaging neighboring homes.
Alaska Airlines is introducing a system on the Internet to create unique advertisements for people as they surf the Web.
That paved the way for opening arguments Thursday in what is expected to be an 8- to 10-week trial of Anthony Pellicano and four co-defendants.
As the clock ticks to a special election for the seat of Representative J. Dennis Hastert on Saturday, the race is a toss-up.
At a time when global financial turmoil would seem to require a firm hand at the economic tiller, Japan is facing the uncomfortable prospect of having no leader at its central bank.
The world appears to be on the verge of a boom in a little-known but promising type of solar power.
Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that it would stop making subprime mortgages through its First Franklin Financial unit and would eliminate 650 jobs.
Lawmakers warned they would kill a defense contract with Northrop Grumman and Airbus’s European parent if the Pentagon did not explain why it passed over Boeing.
Unlike the Fed, the European Central bank is skeptical of the notion that inflation automatically falls when growth cools, and it has a mandate to keep prices stable above all else.
After more than a decade of struggle, the House passed a bill requiring most group health plans to provide more generous coverage for treatment of mental illnesses.
Margaret Seltzer, the author who confessed this week to making up her memoir, appears also to have made up a foundation that she claimed was helping “to reduce gang violence and mentor urban teens.”
Hundreds of thousands of dollars are missing and presumed stolen from the chief fund-raising arm of House Republicans, according to party officials.

Hundreds of cafeteria and other food-service workers rallied in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon for higher wages and improved benefits as part of a continuing battle between the Aramark Corporation and Unite Here, a union that represents about 20,000 Aramark employees, including about 4,000 in the New York region.

Several organizations and agencies that specialize in substance abuse and aging have recently added educational material on their Web sites regarding addiction among older adults. These include pamphlets, data and fact sheets, geared to the public, as well as technical assistance, new research and power-point presentations designed for professionals.
The central bank presented a snapshot of an economy that is gradually slowing, weighed down by creeping inflation pressures and a more hesitant consumer.
Now that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has shown that persistence pays off, can she persevere to ultimately win the nomination?
In filing for bankruptcy, the publisher of technology and video game magazines cited a decrease in revenue from print advertising and subscriptions.
Some political strategists saw the former president’s declaration that his wife needed to win Texas and Ohio as a tactically shrewd effort to re-energize the campaign.
The Oakland Raiders have agreed to terms with the former Pro Bowl receiver Javon Walker and the free-agent offensive tackle Kwame Harris.
Donald Trump said that he would go to court for the right to expand a planned catering hall at Jones Beach to include a 26,000-square-foot basement to accommodate its kitchens.
As a kid, Ian Kennedy loved to pitch, but there was no need to practice; he simply threw hard, and the ball went where he wanted it to go.
The American Cancer Society is recommending virtual colonoscopies and stool tests be a part of colorectal cancer screening for adults 50 and older.
Federal programs offset only a fraction of the $1.23 billion spent by 24 counties bordering Mexico to arrest, jail and house illegal immigrants from 1999 to 2006.
At the trial in the police killing of Sean Bell, the sidearm that is believed to have killed Mr. Bell was displayed in court.
Three prominent U.S. universities are starting five-year partnerships, worth $25 million or more, with a graduate-level research university being built in Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Seitz, a renowned physicist who led both the National Academy of Sciences and Rockefeller University, became a prominent skeptic on the issue of global warming.

Wall Street managed moderate gains in an erratic session Wednesday as investors sorted through a downbeat Federal Reserve assessment of the economy and were disappointed by a plan to bail out a troubled bond insurer, the Ambac Financial Group.
Bartolo Colón is competing for the vacancy in the rotation created by Curt Schilling’s shoulder injury, which is expected to sideline him for at least half the season.
Ramón M. Barquín’s struggles to restore the rule of law in Cuba clashed with both the dictator Fulgencio Batista and later the revolutionary government of Fidel Castro.
A 93-year-old South Bronx courthouse that has been designated a landmark but has been boarded up for years will become a charter school in the fall.
Costco and BJ’s reported substantially higher profits on Wednesday, with both benefiting as cost-conscious shoppers favored lower-priced alternatives to department stores.
The former sailor, Hassan Abujihaad, was found guilty of leaking details about ship movements to an Internet site that prosecutors say sought to raise money for terrorist causes.
The digital video recorder maker reported a narrower fourth-quarter loss on Wednesday, as it cut marketing costs and pushed its high-definition product.
In the 19th century, a restaurant near Wall Street was a stop on the Underground Railroad — to Canada, and freedom.
Yahoo has amended its bylaws to give shareholders who want to nominate directors more time to do so, as it tries to buy time to explore alternatives to an unsolicited buyout offer from Microsoft.
New practices appear to have curtailed problems that gave the F.B.I. improper access to Americans’ personal information in terrorism investigations.
Courts in Rochester and Manhattan have begun to carry out what some say is the de facto legalization of gay marriage in New York by granting reciprocity to gay marriages from other jurisdictions.
The government will ask Saudi Arabia for clemency in the case of a 23-year-old Canadian who was convicted of murder and sentenced to death by beheading.
Even officials of Fatah — the more secular Palestinian party negotiating with Israel — think attacks may breed sympathy for Hamas by turning it into the victim, at least in the short term.
The soldier was reported missing after he and another member of its special forces strayed into Sudan from Chad and were fired upon Monday by Sudanese soldiers.
Mr. Rosenman was an Oscar-winning film composer who helped introduce avant-garde music to Hollywood movie scores.
The 10-day-old strike has caused more than 16,000 workers at General Motors and its suppliers to be temporarily laid off.
A nonprofit helps women build a sense of female solidarity and gain a foothold in a state’s economic mainstream.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,967 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:.
PicLens makes viewing photos on your computer screen a 3-D experience.
My Hewlett-Packard printer/scanner/copier prints basic documents, but the software crashes every time I try to scan. What can I do?
Everyone always says to change the password on your home wireless router from the default one. Why is this, and how do I change my password when the router is already up and running?
A West Texas school district has agreed to change the curriculum for a high school course on the Bible to settle a lawsuit that said it amounted to religious indoctrination.
Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company founded by Donald J. Trump, posted on Wednesday its biggest loss since emerging from bankruptcy in 2005.
Goldman Sachs & Company will donate $100 million to give at least 10,000 women a business education in Africa, the Middle East and other developing regions.
John McCain may be a conservative, but his unbridled free-trade policies don’t help make that case.
Franklin’s Speaking Spelling Bee, $100, has a 70,000 word vocabulary and let’s you create spelling lists, or play games.
Mr. Walter was a former premier who advocated for Antigua and Barbuda’s full independence from Britain.
The Sony ICD-UX80 audio recorder, which sells for $150, comes with two gigabytes of internal storage and has stereo microphones for realistic recording.
Gaming beasts like the Dell XPS 630 are paving the way for new machines with impressive performance and impressively low prices.
Game downloading services have been around for years and are only just beginning to make a dent in sales of packaged game software.
The Bluetooth connection in Callpod’s new Dragon headset can cover more than 300 feet, as opposed to the standard 30 feet.
To the Editor:.
Despite historically high oil prices, profits increased for the international air carrier on booming growth in Asia.
Designs in Swirl and Flourish.
Some 1,000 artists and arts organizations are now working in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, courtesy of the developers David Walentas and his son, Jed, partners in Two Trees Management.
Paul Taylor's current season at City Center is advertised as “The Dream Season,” principally because dreams are the subject of the two new works he is introducing to New York audiences.

The average price of movie tickets jumped 5 percent last year to $6.88; the number of tickets sold in the United States and Canada edged up three-tenths of one percent to 1.4 billion, and domestic box-office revenue rose 5.4 percent to a record $9.6 billion, according to an annual survey of the theatrical movie market released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America. During a conference call with reporters, Dan Glickman, the association’s chief executive, said the number of films taking in more than $100 million at the box office expanded sharply. “When people liked us, they really loved us,” Mr. Glickman said. According to the figures, compiled in partnership with Nielsen EDI, the international box office expanded about 4.9 percent to $26.7 billion. That figure was given a boost by the weakness of the dollar against some foreign currencies, including the euro. One of the more startling year-to-year changes was a sharp rise in spending by the studios’ specialty divisions, which make and distribute some films intended for the annual awards races and others aimed at getting fans of horror and other genres. According to the report such divisions’ investment in production rose 6 percent to an average $42.9 million per movie, while marketing costs jumped 44 percent to $25.7 million.

Jazz at Lincoln Center announced on Wednesday the 2008 inductees into the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame in Frederick P. Rose Hall on Broadway at 60th Street. They are Ornette Coleman, Gil Evans, Bessie Smith and Mary Lou Williams.

Academics at Charles University in Prague have initiated a petition urging the Czech president, Vaclav Klaus, to pardon the Ztohoven collective of young artists who superimposed an image of a nuclear explosion and mushroom cloud, above, over an image of the Krkonose Mountains, by hacking into a Czech Television CT2 weather broadcast in June, Agence France-Presse reported. Seven members of the group, which achieved international renown and won a national art prize for its images, are to appear in court on March 25, when they face sentences of as much as three years for scaremongering. The academics’ petition argues that the case is ridiculous and a waste of money. “The image introduced onto the broadcast was so absurd that it is impossible to regard it as scaremongering,” they said in a statement. Denisa Kera, a teacher and organizer of the protest, said the petition had gathered 3,500 signatures in its first three days.

The House of Lords in Britain has rejected an appeal by an evangelical lobbying organization seeking to prosecute the BBC for blasphemy for broadcasting the satirical musical “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” the BBC reported. Upholding a High Court decision and spurning the petition by the evangelical organization, Christian Voice, the House of Lords said it did “not raise an arguable point of law of general importance.” Christian Voice called the Lords’ decision an “ignoble move,” and Stephen Green, its national director, said: “It brings down the judgment of God on us all. I love my neighbor, and I do not want that to happen.” Mr. Green had argued that the musical included images that “vilify God and the Bible.”.

Craig Jessop, music director of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, resigned unexpectedly on Tuesday night. The decision by Mr. Jessop, who became the choir’s associate director in 1995 and director and conductor in 1999, stunned some members of the acclaimed ensemble when it was announced after a regular rehearsal, The Deseret Morning News of Salt Lake City reported. Mack Wilberg, the associate music director, will serve as interim director of the choir, which reached No. 1 on the Billboard Classical Music chart with several albums during Mr. Jessop’s tenure. He said he intended to remain active in music, including teaching, and hoped to spend more time with his family.

The new math of the music industry: Sell fewer albums but reach higher on the Billboard chart. Janet Jackson’s new record, “Discipline” (Island Def Jam), sold 181,000 copies last week to reach No. 1, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Her last two opened at No. 2 but sold better; “Damita Jo,” released four years ago, had more than twice as many opening-week sales as “Discipline.” This week’s No. 2 album, Erykah Badu’s “New AmErykah, Part One (4th World War)” (Universal Motown), is also new. Ms. Badu’s first full album in eight years, it sold 124,000 copies. Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal), the top seller for the last three weeks, dropped to third place with 92,000. “Savage Life 2” (Asylum) by the Louisiana rapper Webbie opened at No. 4 with 72,000, and Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J) fell three spots to No. 5 with 57,000 sales.

Television audiences preferred unscripted fare on Tuesday, as an hour of “American Idol” on Fox dominated the night’s ratings and two hours of “The Biggest Loser” on NBC gained viewers every half-hour from 8 to 10 p.m. Fox hoped that the 28.2 million viewers of “Idol” would stay tuned for the premiere of “New Amsterdam,” and almost half did. The drama about an immortal New York homicide detective averaged 13.7 million viewers. On NBC, “The Biggest Loser” drew 7.2 million viewers in its first hour and 10.2 million viewers in its second. A repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” delivered 9.4 million viewers, easily doubling the time period’s average from last week, when the Internet series “Quarterlife” made an attempt at television. CBS started the night strong with 10.5 million viewers for a repeat of “NCIS” but lost traction at 9 with “Big Brother” (7 million). At 10, “Jericho” delivered 5.9 million viewers, a million fewer than the previous week. Sitcoms did not draw many viewers to ABC, ranking it fourth for the night, although a “Primetime” hidden-camera newsmagazine averaged 7.6 million viewers, making it the most popular program at 10 p.m.

The Baltimore County Council voted on Monday to permit the Baltimore philanthropist Robert E. Meyerhoff, a major collector of post-World War II art, to turn his home and galleries into a public museum and study center under the supervision of the National Gallery of Art. In 1986 Mr. Meyerhoff and his wife, Jane, now deceased, began donating and lending works from their collection to the gallery. The collection includes paintings by Willem de Kooning, Jackson Pollock, Richard Serra, Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Ellsworth Kelly and Roy Lichtenstein, among others. The museum, on a 250-acre farm, is to open after the death of Mr. Meyerhoff, who is 84, The Baltimore Sun reported.

Relatively barren stretches of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans around the tropics have expanded about 15 percent since 1998, according to a new satellite study. The study’s authors said that the change could be temporary given the short period of observations but that it matches a slight but steady warming trend in the affected ocean regions and matches a pattern scientists have predicted would occur under global warming. The study’s authors, from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the University of Hawaii, said warm surface waters tended to block upwellings of deeper, nutrient-filled water necessary to support plankton and other marine life. The Indian Ocean has seen similar changes but with a less measurable trend, they said.

Agraria, the home fragrance company in San Francisco, has come up with a new way to release scent: through decorative tassels with fragrance beads hidden inside the fringe. ''I saw lots of tassels hanging in people's homes,'' said Jim Gentry, Agraria's president. ''Since we had a history of having tassels on our packages, I said, Let's put some fragrance in one of these tassels.''

BUCKHOUT--William Armstrong, 93, of Sanibel Island and Fort Myers, FL passed away February 18, 2008. He was born in Pleasantville, NY and graduated from Cornell University College of Architecture in 1937. At Cornell he was a member of Sigma Nu Fraternity, lettered in baseball and was team captain his senior year. He became President and owner of Fair-Chester Builders, Inc. of Pleasantville, NY. He was elected Mayor of Pleasantville from 1952 to 1959 and also served on the Planning Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals 1960 to 1972. He was a Rotarian and Paul Harris Fellow, a trustee of the Northern Westchester Hospital and took a very active roll in the development and construction of the hospital expansion during the years 1970 to 1972.

He was an attorney and a high ranking official in the Cuomo Administration. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Frances Ann Sama; his son Vincent (Gina) of Huntington, NY; two grandchildren, Christopher and Mia; one sister, Carmella Fiore (Jack) of Boca Raton, FL. Vincent was predeceased by his son Thomas Frank Sama in 1989 and also one brother, Frank Sama. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Friday, March 7, 2008, at 10:00am at St. Judes Catholic Church Chapel in Tequesta, FL. Final services and interment at St. Johns Cemetery, Queens, NY. Funeral services entrusted to Aycock Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL.

GOLDEN--Carl, died on February 29, 2008 at University Medical Center at Princeton. He was 81 years old. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he graduated from Boys High School, City College of New York and then from NYU School of Law. He served in the Navy during WWII. Mr. Golden was an Assistant US Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, and in 1964 he was promoted to Chief of the Civil division. He moved to Oceanside, NY and then to Monroe Twp., NJ. He was very active in the Jewish community. Mr. Golden was admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the United States at the recommendation of the Honorable Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall. He left the US Attorney's office and joined the law firm of Bergreen & Bergreen of New York City, where he was made a partner. Mr. Golden was married to the late Dorie (nee Kaplan). He is survived by his sons, Rabbi Steven Golden and Professor Jonathan Golden, a sister Sydell Markowitz and two granddaughters. Funeral services were conducted by Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Edison, NJ.

Norman was deeply devoted to his extended family and numerous friends. He will be remembered and missed by all those he inspired with his energy and courage. SORENSEN--Dr. Robert C. Trademark, market, and public opinion researcher, who applied social science to matters ranging from jury selection to trademark research, died in his Manhattan home at age 84 on Friday, February 22. Dr. Sorensen was a leading figure in the application of survey research to trademark litigation. He designed and administered opinion surveys to measure consumer perceptions, with special focus on public confusion over trademarks and product source. Dr. Sorensen provided expert testimony in over 70 cases in US District Courts, state courts, and proceedings of the Patent and Trademark Office and US International Trade Commission. Robert Chaikin Sorensen was born on September 7, 1923, in Lincoln, Nebraska. He earned his bachelor's, master's, and Ph.D. (1954) degrees from the University of Chicago, all in sociology. Between 1952 and 1954, Dr. Sorensen was associated with the Operations Research Office of Johns Hopkins University and worked on psychological warfare efforts for the US Army in Korea. From 1954-1958, Dr. Sorensen was Director of Audience Research and Analysis for Radio Free Europe in Munich, Germany, where he led efforts to measure the effectiveness of broadcasts to five Eastern European countries during charged Cold War years which saw the suppression by Soviet forces of the popular uprising in Hungary. In 1959, Dr. Sorensen settled in New York City, where he worked as Director of Research for This Week Magazine (1959-1961), VP and Corp. Director of Research at D'Arcy Advertising (1961-1966), Executive Director at the Center for Advanced Practice (1966-1968), and VP and Corporate Director of Marketing at Warner Communications (now Time Warner) (1972-1974). In 1968, Dr. Sorensen formed Sorensen Marketing / Management Corporation, where he pioneered the application of public opinion research techniques to trademark infringement and intellectual property issues. From 1981 to 1993, he was a professor of marketing at Rider University. Dr. Sorensen was Chairman of the boards of both Childreach/Plan International (formerly Foster Parents Plan) and the Scandinavian Seminar, as well as VP at the Institute on Religion in an Age of Science, and Board Member at the Center for Advanced Studies of Religion and Science, Primary Stages, Inc. (a theatrical company), Girl Scouts USA, and Scandinavian Seminar College. His publications include a book on adolescent sexuality (1973), a book, Free Will and Determinism (1987, edited with Viggo Mortensen), and numerous professional articles. Dr. Sorensen is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marjorie, and two sons, Robert ''Chris,'' of New City, NY, and David, of Copenhagen, Denmark. A daughter, Katherine, of Dallas, died in 2001. He is also survived by three siblings, Theodore, Philip, and Ruth, as well as four grandchildren, Hannah, Stephen, Nicholas and Axel.

GOTO--Naoko Kobayashi, died in Tokyo unexpectedly on Tuesday, February 26, at the age of 46. Beloved mother of Lisa, daughter of Takashi and Ayako Kobayashi, cherished friend of The Brearley School and Isetan Co., Ltd. communities. Naoko was raised in Tokyo and attended Gakushuin elementary school, high school and college and came to this country after marrying Morihiko Goto, managing director and head of international sales at Utendahl Capital Partners, L.P. Her father, Takashi Kobayashi, is an executive advisor of Fukoku Mutual Life Insurance Co., which he served formerly as chairman and chief executive officer. Her mother, Ayako Kobayashi, is a professor of English language and literature at Tokyo Kasei University. Naoko was a woman of exquisite grace and rare intelligence who prized friends and family most importantly, and gave unstintingly of her warmth to all she knew. She was an active parent at The Brearley School, one of many benevolent involvements. Naoko was a member of the Junior League and of Nadeshiko Kai, a Japanese women's organization; she was also a volunteer at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. Naoko worked in the New York office of Isetan Co., Ltd., a leading Japanese department store, in administration and translation. An accomplished linguist, she had received a master's degree in German literature from New York University, had taught Japanese at The New School and was enrolled in the graduate program in English as a second language at Columbia University Teachers College. But her proudest achievement was her wonderful daughter, Lisa, whom she treasured. She will be missed by all those who loved her in the Brearley and Isetan communities, and in the many circles where she was known. She is survived by Morihiko, her parents, her daughter, Lisa, and by two sisters and one brother. A memorial service in New York will be held in the spring.
