Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has often responded to criticisms about the prolonged Democratic battle with a nod back to another Clinton campaign. She did it again Wednesday. ''Remember, this is a long journey,'' she said on ''The Early Show'' on CBS. ''My husband didn't get the nomination until June of 1992, and I have every confidence that we're going to continue to pick up delegates as we go.''

THE bag is the new hat. That was confirmed on a trip to Paris, where plenty of men had traded in their fur trappers, watch caps and beanies for handsome leather carryalls. There was nothing timid about those bags. Weighty and capacious, they nudged aside the canvas backpack as a totem of hipster chic. Some were purely practical, large enough to transport documents, spare sneakers or, if need be, the contents of one's medicine chest. Others conveyed heaps of status. Wise to the power of a high-fashion label, Marcin Tyszka (bottom row, center) carried an envelope clutch by Louis Vuitton. Thomas Kirchgrabner (bottom, second from left) showed off a fringed satchel by Miu Miu. Nicolas Cisa (below) toted Gucci, while Jonathan Huguet (left) made an aggressive statement, swinging a large leather messenger bag from Yves Saint Laurent. Yes, it's a man thing.

SEITZ--Frederick. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Frederick Seitz, fourth president of The Rockefeller University. During Dr. Seitz's ten-year administration, new basic research programs were started in reproductive biology, cell biology, molecular biology and the neurosciences as well as new clinical investigations at the university's research hospital, a joint M.D.-Ph.D. program in cooperation with Cornell University Medical College was initiated, and he established the 1,000-acre Center for Field Research in Ethology and Ecology at Millbrook, NY. Also during his tenure seven endowed professorships were created, the university completed construction of several critically important buildings and the Rockefeller Archive Center in Pocantico, NY, was established. Dr. Seitz also played a major role in launching the first development program in the university's history. A distinguished physicist and educator who held key government posts for over three decades, Dr. Seitz was a past president of the National Academy of Sciences, and in 1973 he received the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award in science. As president emeritus, Dr. Seitz remained an active campus citizen, prolific author of several books and an advocate for the university. We extend our deepest condolences to his son, Jack, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and his many colleagues on campus. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus SEITZ--Frederick. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the staff of Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the death of Frederick Seitz, who served with great distinction as a member of MSKCC's Boards from 1969 until his retirement in 1997. During his tenure, Dr. Seitz served as Vice Chairman of the Boards of MSKCC and Chairman of the Board of Managers of the Sloan-Kettering Institute. He was a member of the Executive Committee and the Joint Committee on Financial Policy, and Vice Chairman of the Committee on Scientific Policy, and he was elected to the Board of Overseers Emeriti in 1997. A renowned physicist and expert in the field of materials science, Frederick Seitz was the first full time president of the National Academy of Sciences from 1963 to 1969, served as president of The Rockefeller University from 1968 to 1978, and was a member of the National Cancer Advisory Board from 1976 to 1982. He was the recipient of many awards, including the National Medal of Science in 1973. Dr. Seitz gave generously of his time and talents to further the goals of Memorial Sloan - Kettering, and we benefited greatly from his wisdom and experience. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. James D. Robinson III Honorary Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman Harold Varmus President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

KEEPING the children active is easy when all of the outdoors beckons. But what's a parent to do on bad-weather weekends? Being cooped up indoors can be a chance to turn exercise into a family affair, with the help of workout DVDs that disguise exercise as dance. Although dance workouts aimed at children are rarely interesting or challenging enough for adults, the opposite can be true. In late May, Zumba Fitness, a Florida company, will release a children's version of its signature international dance-workout DVDs, which have sold 3.5 million copies since 2002. ''We noticed a lot of kids coming with their moms to do Zumba classes,'' said Alberto Perlman, the company's chief executive.

He will always remain in the heart of the Fordham Law community. William Michael Treanor, Dean

LINNEHAN--John J., 75, of Haverhill died Monday, March 3, 2008. He was born in Haverhill on November 30, 1932 son of the late Helen Connell and C. Frank Linnehan. He graduated from Haverhill High School and Tufts University, Medford. He worked on Senator John F. Kennedy's 1960 Presidential Campaign and served in both The Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. He was Treasurer of Senator Edmund Muskie's 1972 Presidential Campaign. He also served as Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill's Treasurer for many years. He continued to be active in Massachusetts and local politics throughout his life. Mr. Linnehan served as Legislative Consultant for the National Funeral Directors Association and for over three decades he was the Legislative and Regulatory Affairs Committee Chairperson for the Massachusetts Funeral Directors Association. Mr. Linnehan succeeded his father as the owner of the C. Frank Linnehan and Son Funeral Homes in Haverhill and Bradford in 1973. Mr. Linnehan was the husband of Claire (Gaffey) Linnehan who passed away June 14, 1998. He is survived by daughters Courtney C. Linnehan of Boston and Seana and her husband Roger H. Wood, and grandchildren, Isabelle Wood, Aidan Wood, and Oliver Wood, all of New York City. The Funeral will be held Saturday, March 8 at 9:00am from the C. RATNER--Arthur. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Arthur Ratner. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Laura, and their family. Allan Greenblatt, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

MARKS--Alvin Bernard, almost 87, April 22, 1921-March 3, 2008. Passed peacefully at the Mollie and Jack Zicklin Jewish Hospice Residence. Born in the Bronx, the oldest son of Joseph of Lithuania and Dorothy (Dolly) Rosenblatt of Chinatown, NYC. Predeceased by brother Jacob. Alvin attended DeWitt Clinton High School and NYU School of Commerce. Upon graduation in 1942, he was drafted by the US Army and proudly served as a lieutenant for WWII where he received five battle stars for duty in combat areas of Normandy, Northern France, Rhineland, Ardennes, Central Europe. Returning to civilian life he joined both his father and father-in-law's manufacturing companies. His work career branched out to include sales and a passion for real estate finance. Married almost 56 years to the former Elaine Miller who predeceased him, he leaves behind his children Evan and Wendy, grandson Jeffrey, all of NYC and several nieces in England and nephew Emmanuel. Longtime member of the Willow Ridge Country Club, Harrison, NY, Hunters Run Country Club, Boynton Beach, FL, Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY, Park Avenue Synagogue, NYC. Influenced by the integrity of his immigrant father, he always had a joke or story to tell. A lover of literature, he possessed a warm and charming personality, clever mind and lived life his way until the end. His favorite poem, by Walter De La Mare: At the end of All the Ages A Knight sate on his steed, His armor red and thin with rust, His soul from sorrow freed; And he lifted up his visor From a face of skin and bone, And his horse turned head and whinnied As the twain stood there alone. No bird above that steep of time Sang of a life long quest; No wind breathed, Rest: ''Lone for an end!'' cried Knight to steed, Loosed an eager reinCharged with challenged into Space: And quiet did quiet remain. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, West 91st Street Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 11:30am, Thursday March 6, 2008, 212-769-4400, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Donations may be directed to: Dr. Howard Weiner, c/o NYU Division of Pediatric Neurosurgery Research Fund, NYU School of Medicine, 317 East 34th Street, NYC 10016 or The Hebrew Free Burial Association, 363 7th Ave., NYC 10001. Call for Shivah times. Sleep well Dad; forever you will remain in our hearts. MARKS--Alvin B. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted congregant Alvin B. Marks. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President

YOFFIE--Judith. The Union for Reform Judaism mourns with deep sorrow the passing of Judith Yoffie, mother of our president, Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie. May Judith's memory be for a blessing. Peter J. Weidhorn, Chairman

Urban locavores can learn how to grow food in window boxes and containers, raise bees, train vegetables to grow up (not out) on trellises, brew compost tea, plant fruit and nut trees and can the fruits of their labors from expert city farmers at the free ''Edible NYC: Green It! Grow It! Eat it!'' at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Owen Taylor, an author of ''The City Chicken Guide,'' a handbook put out by Just Food, will also share his secrets; 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, (718) 623-7209 or bbg.org. The same day, the Wave Hill garden in the Bronx will hold a workshop on urban beekeeping from 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. City beekeepers will discuss setting up a hive, the cost of equipment, where to buy bees and safe procedures for keeping a hive flourishing. Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale; for information and to register: (718) 549-3200, extension 305. ANNE RAVER

BAKER--R. Palmer Jr. R. Palmer Baker Jr., died on March 3, 2008 at the age of 89. Mr. Baker was predeceased by his wife Alma Nicoll Baker who died on March 4, 1990. He leaves his daughter Mary Baker Eaton and his grandson Hal Fickett. Mr. Baker, a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, was a gentleman and a lawyer. The burial service will be private. There will be a celebration of his life, gifts, accomplishments and the light that he brought into so many people's lives, at Chelsea Piers, Sunset Terrace, Pier 61 on May 6, 2008 at 6:00pm. In lieu of flowers, a gift may be made to one of the many charities and institutions that Palmer Baker loved so much. BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend R. Palmer Baker, Jr. A Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital and a member of the Board since 1965, he was named Honorary Member of the Department of Psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College in 1993 for his longstanding and enthusiastic support for advancing treatment and research of mental disorders. An active leader of numerous committees and initiatives related to psychiatry, he was instrumental in securing major financial support for the department. Among many other clinical and administrative areas to which he gave his energy and expertise was cancer research -a subject he knew well as chairman of The Ludwig Institute, one of the largest international academic institutes dedicated to the disease. Astute, gracious and kind, he will be greatly missed. We offer our deepest condolences to the entire Baker family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. We mourn the loss of R. Palmer Baker Jr., our friend, colleague and mentor. A close advisor to D. K. Ludwig and executor of his estate, R. Palmer Baker Jr. was a major force in the creation of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research in 1971. The Ludwig Institute from its inception was designed to establish and integrate laboratory and clinical cancer research activities spanning the globe. Mr. Baker was a vital and long standing member of the Institute's Board of Directors and served as Chairman of the Board from 1995-2005, guiding the Institute as it continued to emerge into the world's largest international not-for-profit cancer research enterprise. Mr. Baker was also a Trustee of the Virginia and D.K. Ludwig Fund for Cancer Research, which, in 2006, made the largest single donation by a foundation to cancer research in the United States, establishing research centers at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Chicago and Stanford University. He was deeply admired by the entire Ludwig community for his contributions to the world of cancer research The generosity of spirit and high standards that Mr. Baker brought to all of his endeavors will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his daughter, Mary Baker Eaton, and to his grandson, Harold L. Fickett, IV. Lloyd J. Old, M.D. Chairman of the Board Edward A. McDermott, Jr. President Andrew Simpson, Ph.D. Scientific Director Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research
McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Happy Birthday. Miss you! Miss you! Miss you! Love, Sissy

LEVY--Ernst, born in Hamburg, Germany June 28, 1906. He passed away quietly at 4:20pm at home on March 4, 2008 at the age of 101. Son of Albert and Paula Levy. Night manager for 47 years for the Plaza Hotel. He will be missed by many friends who have known him over the years.

9 P.M. (Sundance) TERMINAL CITY A cancer-stricken housewife unwittingly becomes a reality-television star in this 10-part Canadian mini-series created and written by Angus Fraser. Maria del Mar, left, plays Katie Sampson, a wife and mother who walks into a live broadcast of ''Post Op!'' on her way to a breast-lump biopsy. A star is born, albeit one whose illness and celebrity are racing at the same speed in opposite directions. Gil Bellows plays Katie's devoted husband, struggling to keep things real with his bickering children. Jane McLean is Jane Richards, the reality show's producer, who finds herself increasingly torn between wanting what's best for ratings and what's best for her dying new friend. 7 P.M. (Animal Planet) ELEPHANT DIARIES At the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust's elephant nursery in Nairobi, Kenya, keepers do whatever it takes to care for calves that have lost their families: nurse them back to health, feed and play with them and even sleep with them at night. Meanwhile at Voi, an orphan-release site in Tsavo National Park, the older calves live and learn until they're ready to join wild herds. This new series, which begins with three consecutive episodes, joins Michaela Strachan and Jonathan Scott as they follow a year in the life of these elephant families, whose members include Lualeni, a 4-month-old grieving the death of her mother, and 10-year-old Emily, who is about to take her first steps into the wild after being reared by humans since she was just a month old.

Tuesday was supposed to deliver clarity to the Democratic nomination battle. Instead, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's victories in Ohio, Texas and Rhode Island -- and the slowing of Senator Barack Obama's momentum -- left the political waters as murky as ever. And some of the undecided superdelegates are as flummoxed as ever. One, Muriel K. Offerman, said Wednesday that she had been hoping the decision would have been made for her. Instead, she said she was still weighing both candidates. Complicating the matter for Ms. Offerman, a Democratic National Committee member since 1989, is that her state, North Carolina, has not voted yet.

Those who are wondering what to do with their houseguests this summer -- and who have really, really big backyards -- might consider authentic East African safari tents, made in Kenya and sold by F. M. Allen. Then again, as these tents start at $15,000 (the one at above right, at $17,000), without any furniture, it might be better to send the guests to a hotel. Still, there is a lot of tent for the money. The basic models range from 10 by 15 feet to 15 by 30, and because they are all custom made, the size and design can be tweaked. They also have that evocative and romantic mesh-flap front door -- and the romance of a link to the Africa of Hemingway, Ava Gardner and the great safari hunters. Sort of.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's victories in the primaries on Tuesday barely dented Senator Barack Obama's lead in delegates, but they seemed to slow the Democratic Party establishment's move in his direction while giving her campaign time to try to turn the race in her favor. Mrs. Clinton's victories in Ohio, Texas and Rhode Island cut into Mr. Obama's delegate lead by 15 delegates at most, and by as few as 5, depending on the final accounting in Texas, which was expected Thursday afternoon.

Leonard Rosenman, an Oscar-winning film composer who helped introduce avant-garde music to Hollywood movie scores, died on Tuesday in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 83 and a former Hollywood resident. The cause was a heart attack, his family said.

Jean Royère, the French decorator, designed furniture that was elegant and unusually whimsical in shape and material. Starting Saturday, more than 100 pieces will be at the Sonnabend Gallery in Chelsea. One piece offered for sale is the 1939 ''Champignon'' lamp ($130,000), top left, whose perforated shades resemble the tops of poisonous mushrooms, said Patrick Seguin, a Parisian gallery owner who shared curator's duties for the show with Jacques Lacoste, another gallery owner. (They own the furniture together.) Other pieces include, clockwise from top right, a 1934 molded oak chair ($200,000 for a pair), a pair of 1953 armchairs upholstered in red wool ($400,000 for both) and a 1950s chest of drawers cradled in an ash frame upholstered in dark blue wool ($70,000). Through April 12 at 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018. ELAINE LOUIE

Monday, March 3

If there is any doubt that Denis Woychuk, the owner of the KGB Bar in the East Village and the writer of a new rock musical about a lawyer representing the criminally insane, knows what he is writing about, consider the grisly case of Daniel Rakowitz, the last person he represented in his 10 years working for mentally ill defendants. Mr. Rakowitz, also of the East Village, was charged in 1989 with killing his girlfriend and dismembering her. Accounts of what happened have varied over the years as Mr. Rakowitz’s story has changed, but one account, which he has denied, had him boiling the victim’s body into soup that he served to the homeless.

Can a black police officer be racist against black people? And how does that play out in the moments before a gun confrontation with another black man? Those questions were explored in a one-act play, “In That Moment,” and the subsequent panel discussion at John Jay College of Criminal Justice on Thursday night.How race plays out in policing (both for the officers and the public) is a theme in the play, but has so far been a subtler issue in the trial before a judge of the three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell, a black man who was killed in the early morning of his wedding day in November 2006.

Among many politicians in Harlem and beyond, it has been a period of reflections and day-after quarterbacking on the prospects of Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV. When David A. Karnes, a California lawyer, sent letters late last month to members of Congress with a picture taken of a man standing in front of the Times Square recruiting station, he could not have imagined that days later, F.B.I. agents would swarm his Los Angeles home and interrogate him. The authorities have ruled out a connection between the bombing of the recruiting station on early Thursday morning and Mr. Karnes, who has become an odd footnote to a story that has perplexed investigators.

Four bidders turned in their second-round offers on Thursday for the General Motors Building, the white marble real estate trophy on Fifth Avenue, according to an executive involved in the sale. But mystery surrounds the sale of the 50-story tower by its financially troubled owner, Harry B. Macklowe.There are reports that the bids topped $3 billion, but it was unclear exactly who made what would be a record-setting price for an office building. Joseph Cayre and S L Green did not submit new offers with the others, unwilling to go over the $3 billion threshold. And there is conflicting information whether another first-round bidder, the developer Larry A. Silverstein, made a second offer.

Samuel Johnson once cautioned against the practice of "recommending" Shakespeare through the greatest-hits approach of quoting selected passages. Remarkable as the chosen passages might be, Johnson warned, the critic who relied simply on quotation was like the man "who, when he offered his house to sale, carried a brick in his pocket as a specimen."

Here at the T Magazine office, several stylish staffers have placed their orders (me included). The consensus seems to be in favor of the sandal flats ($78), above, and the three-strap sandals ($98) - their wooden heels are amazing and a lot like the Chloé sandals that a lot of the girls already have (me included). GENEVA -- In the world of micro automakers, the French touch has a weird, innovative side. There is Guy Nègre, whose company MDI in the south of France has developed a car that runs on compressed air; the idea has been licensed to Tata in India. And there is Venturi, which actually has its headquarters in Monaco, whose solar-powered Eclectic, due in early 2009, will travel seven kilometers a day powered by the sun alone.

Click on certain streets and highways highlighted in blue on the map, and you get a panoramic street-level view of the place, including anyone who happened to be there when the Google camera van drove by to capture the images.

Olive oil remains unusual in sweet baked goods, but the flavor of extra virgin olive oil is a powerful and welcome addition to sweet and savory cookies, the type that are best nibbled with a glass of sweet wine. Olive oil is not butter, of course, and you will never get that incomparably tender crumb when using it in cookie dough. But olive oil does produce cookies with a caky interior and nicely crisped surface.

An article in Business Day on Feb. 23 about molecules used to make perfumes misstated the length of patents in the United States. It is 20 years, not 17. The article also misidentified the makers of two perfumes and misspelled the name of one of the perfumes. Polo Blue from Ralph Lauren is made by International Flavors and Fragrances, and Acqua di Gio (not Aqua di Gio) from Armani is made by Firmenich. Neither are made by Givaudan. The article also misstated the proprietary status of Amber Ketal, a scent used in both perfumes. It was no longer under patent when it was used in those two fragrances.

Tripp Isenhour, a PGA Tour player, was charged with killing a hawk on purpose with a golf shot because it was making noise as he videotaped a television show. Isenhour was with a film crew for “Shoot Like a Pro” on Dec. 12 at the Grand Cypress Golf course in Orlando, Fla. Isenhour, 39, whose real name is John Henry Isenhour III, was charged Wednesday with cruelty to animals and killing a migratory bird. The charges carry a maximum 14 months in jail and $1,500 in fines. Isenhour apologized in a statement and said he was only trying to scare away the hawk.

DeeDee Jonrowe beat the front-runner Paul Gebhardt to the checkpoint in Cripple, Alaska, by eight minutes to take the lead in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race early Thursday morning. Jonrowe, 54, had passed a musher going the wrong way, but she never expected it to be Gebhardt, 50, who was lost for at least six hours. By midmorning, 10 teams were parked in Cripple, the official halfway point and 609 miles from the finish line in Nome, on Alaska’s western coast.

The Connecticut Sun acquired the former University of Connecticut star Barbara Turner in a trade with Houston that sent forward Megan Mahoney to the Comets. Andy Roddick split with his coach, Jimmy Connors, ending a 19-month relationship. Roddick, the world’s sixth-ranked player, whose 24 singles titles include the 2003 United States Open, announced after defeating Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals of the Dubai Open on Thursday that he and Connors had severed ties. Roddick said Connors resigned. Roddick, 25, said the timing and logistics of his schedule made it difficult to work with Connors on a part-time basis.Roddick was ranked 10th in the world when he began working with Connors in July 2006. He rose as high as third in the world rankings under Connors.

The All American Football League will postpone its 2008 season unless it finds additional financial backing. The announcement came less than a week before camps were to open for the six-team league. An article on Thursday about reaction among Gaza residents to a weekend military incursion by Israel misstated the death toll in some editions. Cannotrustclinton.com? clintonisbad.com? At least 25 domain names related to Hillary Rodham Clinton have links to the Republican National Committee: the names were either registered by the R.N.C. last year or showed up on servers the committee uses. Half a dozen seemed to guess at Mrs. Clinton's eventual running mate, like clintonomalley.com, referring to Gov. Martin O'Malley of Maryland. The day after Barack Obama won the Iowa caucuses, the R.N.C. snapped up at least 20 domains related to his candidacy. Some of them may signal the party's future strategy: baracknotready.com and norealexperience.com. The party has also begun preemptively registering domains that could be used to attack John McCain, like mccainamigos.com, voteagainstmccain.com, flipflopmccain.com and hatemccain.com (ihatemccain.com was taken.) The Democratic Party and the campaigns have shown little of the verve and creativity of the R.N.C. The Obama campaign registered desperatehillaryattacks.com in December. The Clinton campaign registered votingpresent.com two days later, an apparent reference to Mr. Obama's votes as a member of the Illinois legislature. The party has been focused more on the national convention, registering variations of denverdemconvention08.com in February, but so far apparently no domains related to Mr. McCain. The election has ''triggered an avalanche of cybersquatter activity,'' according to NetNames, a domain name management service. Speculators have registered nearly 2,000 domain names related to presidential candidates as of last week. Names related to Mrs. Clinton's candidacy made up over half of the registrations, followed by Mr. Obama with 635 and Mr. McCain with 269. Domains registered by the R.N.C . or on servers used by the committee: 2007 calculatingclinton.com canttrustclinton.com clintonbabbit.com clintoncleland.com clintoncohen.com clintonisbad.com clintoniscorrupt.com clintoniswrong.com clintonkerrey.com clintonlibrarycard.com clintonlibraryresolution.com clintonomalley.com clintonsalazar.com clintonschweitzer.com clintontruthwatch.com hillaryiswrong.com hillarymythfact.com hillaryrecords.com hillaryspendometer.com hillarytaxplan.com hillarytruthsquad.com hopelesshillary.com outwithhillary.com thetwohillarys.com 2008 amateurobama.com barackisliberal.com barackiswrong.com baracknotready.com barackobamanotready.com barackobamatheliberal.com baracktheamateur.com barackthebeginner.com fauxbama.org hesnotready.com meetbarackobama.com norealexperience.com nowecannot.com nowecannot.net nowecannot.org obamaisliberal.com obamaiswrong.com obamanotready.com obamaspendometer.com obamatheamateur.com obamathebeginner.com yeswecandowhat.com yeswecanwhat.com

Here's a book that some people might find useful: ''10 Steps to Becoming a Published Author in Your Next Life.'' No? How about ''Napping: An Inexpensive Way to Stay Busy''? Or ''Craft Your Way to Mental Health,'' which has the picture of a heavily frosted gingerbread house on its cover? These are 3 of more than 200 volumes in Jean Lowe's laugh-out-loud exhibition. Based in San Diego, Ms. Lowe has specialized in constructing satiric museum-style period rooms out of papier-mâché and enamel paint. For this show she has created a library of invented titles and displayed them on bookshelves covered with wood-grain-patterned paper, right. Also made of papier-mâché and colorfully painted with a skillful, loose touch, the books imitate various genres, including self-help, children's storybooks, academic tomes, law books and popular potboilers. You can't open them -- they're blocky, sculptural volumes without inside pages -- which is just as well, because the covers are more than enough.

Most New Yorkers don't have to worry about lawns; a stoop is luxury enough. But if the architect and artist Fritz Haeg has his way, everyone in the country will not only be fixated on their lawns, but they will also be harvesting them. Mr. Haeg is the creator of Edible Estates, which aims to persuade homeowners to grow not grass but fruit, vegetables and nuts in their yards. The campaign began in 2005 with a commission from the Salina Art Center in Salina, Kan., the geographical center of the United States, where Mr. Haeg helped plant a mini-grove in the yard of a local couple. He was attracted to the area, he said, as a way to take a break from the ''cultural ghettos'' of New York and Los Angeles, where he had lived. More gardens were sown in New Jersey, California (above, his ''Edible Estates Regional Prototype Garden No. 2: Lakewood, Calif., 2006'') and London; Baltimore and Austin, Tex., are next. (Mr. Haeg hopes to do nine in all.)

Taylor Wimpey, Britain's biggest home builder, said annual profit fell 31 percent as property markets cooled in Britain, the United States and Spain. Pretax profit before one-time items totaled £536 million ($1.07 billion), compared with £777 million a year earlier, the company said. Revenue fell 12 percent, to £5.89 billion. Earnings in North America dropped more than 80 percent and Spain lost 70 percent as operating profit margins collapsed and sales plunged. The chief executive, Peter Redfern, said there was a seasonal sales increase in Britain in the first few weeks of this year, ''but it's still running some way below 2006's more normal levels. It's going to be quite a challenging year.''

Every year around this time undergraduate and graduate acting programs from near and far release a crew of young, trained actors onto the New York City theater scene. Most schools introduce their students with a night of scenes for agents and casting directors. But Boston University is planning something different: the weeklong Incite Arts Festival, which will include the traditional showcase, full-scale theater productions, an art exhibition and a concert. The event will feature the works of students and recent graduates from the departments of music, theater and visual arts, which together form the College of Fine Arts. In addition to the goal of helping the students gain exposure in New York, another motive is to ''serve the greatest needs of a cultural community that may not otherwise have the chance to see this work,'' said Jim Petosa, the director of the university's School of Theater.

No wonder the Surrealists loved the silent comedians. Buster Keaton, for one, had a knack for suspending the laws of the physical universe and for creating images with as much dream logic as humor. Take a scene from ''Seven Chances,'' which Keaton, above, directed and stars in as Jimmy Shannon, a hapless romantic who must marry by 7 p.m. if he wants to collect a $7 million inheritance. Jimmy -- neatly turned out in a morning suit -- dozes on a church pew unaware of the army of brides behind him: dream of salvation or nightmare? At just under an hour, ''Seven Chances'' (1925) seems the perfect length for children (not to mention adults sick of bloated Hollywood run times), and it's showing on a family-friendly Sunday afternoon in the Silent Clowns Film Series. (The series, at the New-York Historical Society, runs every other Sunday from October to April.)

Ten is a big birthday. It often signifies a time when children's thoughts begin to turn to adolescent themes. Something similar has happened to the BAMkids Film Festival, whose 10th edition this weekend will offer about 50 films from 18 countries, with more than ever for those 9 to 13. ''We were able to find some really interesting films for that age group,'' said Suzanne Youngerman, the festival's project director. ''And we have children who have been with us, if not for 10 years, then a good part of their lives. We hope we've grown with them.''

It's good to know that even the culturally elevated have their lowbrow moments. The choreographer and director Liam Steel was reaching for an Agatha Christie novel to ease the pain of a bad breakup when a copy of R. D. Laing's ''Knots'' fell off the shelf. (Clearly lowbrow has no chance in certain contexts.) The eventual outcome was a new work -- also called ''Knots'' -- made for the CoisCeim Dance Theater from Ireland and being performed this weekend as part of the Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey. The writings of Mr. Laing, a Scottish psychiatrist and psychoanalyst best known for his unorthodox views on psychosis, might seem an unlikely inspiration for a dance piece. But Mr. Steel immediately recognized parallels between Mr. Laing's work and his own. ''He was looking at relationships and condensing them down into poetry,'' said Mr. Steel, who danced with DV8 Physical Theater for eight years before working as a freelance theater director and choreographer and forming his own company, Stan Won't Dance, in 2004. ''It's about individuals being very different while the themes, our behaviors, are universal.''

8:30 P.M. (Sundance) BLACK WHITE + GRAY: A PORTRAIT OF SAM WAGSTAFF AND ROBERT MAPPLETHROPE (2007) Sam Wagstaff was a dashing museum curator and photography collector from an old-money New York background. The photographer Robert Mapplethorpe (above right, with Wagstaff), whom Wagstaff called ''my shy pornographer,'' was a punk from Queens. Together they climbed the art-world ranks -- ''a diabolical power couple who lived and died in a mad pursuit of aesthetic perfection and erotic sensation,'' Stephen Holden wrote in a review of this documentary in The New York Times. James Crump wrote and directed; Truman Capote, Dominick Dunne and the curator Henry Geldzahler, among others, ruminate on the couple. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE PRICE IS RIGHT MILLION DOLLAR SPECTACULAR Contestants bid and spin for a load of cash. Drew Carey eggs them on.

RICHARDSON--Joseph Jr. October 8, 1927-February 10, 2008. Joseph Chambers Richardson, Jr., 80, of Amarillo, Texas passed away Sunday, February 10, 2008. Memorial services have been changed to Wednesday, March 19, 2008 at 11:00am at Polk Street United Methodist Church. Rev. Marty Hamrick will officiate. Memorial services are entrusted to Schooler Funeral Home, 4100 S. Georgia, Amarillo, Texas 79110 (806) 352-2727. He is survived by his wife of twenty years, Susan Dixon Richardson; sister, Mary Ann Hanson of Fort Worth, Texas; daughters, Mary Lynn Holder of Fort Worth and Elise Wilkes of Atlanta; son, James Smith Dixon of La Jolla, CA; seven grandchildren; a great-grandchild; and loyal business associate of 27 years, Cheryl Lee Berg. The family would appreciate contributions made to either the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. Patrick Hwu, Melanoma Research Fund, PO Box 4486, Houston, TX 77210,l 800-525-5841 or the Joe C. Richardson Jr. Fund, Acct #

BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. Palmer served with great enthusiasm on the Board of Directors of the Ice Theatre of New York since its inception in 1984. He guided us with his considerable leadership qualities and showed us how to be graceful both on and off the ice. He will be missed by Board members, staff and hundreds of skaters who loved him dearly. Moira North, Founder BAKER--R. Palmer Jr., was a man of extraordinary intelligence, thoughtfulness, kindness, and understanding. With a wonderful smile and a twinkle, he could take on complex issues, ask key questions, and develop powerful new approaches. The Department of Psychiatry of New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center was one of the many beneficiaries of his compassion and capacities. He appreciated the value of research and academic training, and recognized the importance of psychiatry's future advances. Through his efforts, the legendary philanthropist DeWitt Wallace, the founder of Reader's Digest, agreed to facilitate and sustain our Department's work in these vital areas. The result was a gift of an endowment from the DeWitt Wallace Fund, thoughtfully administered through The New York Community Trust, to support the Department's programs. The endowment, and the significant funds provided over the past decades, constitute one of the great gifts in the history of American psychiatry, and will have a significant impact in perpetuity. We will miss our meetings and episodic lunches with discussions of his pride in his family, including the artistic talents of his daughter, Mary, as well as his personal interest and joy in learning about the successes and development of the Department's talented people and exciting initiatives. Those accomplishments, and many others still to come, are a direct result of the Fund that Palmer Baker did so much to facilitate and encourage. Jack D. Barchas, MD Barklie McKee Henry Professor and Chairman Psychiatrist in Chief Philip J. Wilner, MD, MBA Medical Director William A. Frosch, MD Professor Robert Michels, MD Walsh McDermott Professor Department of Psychiatry Weill Cornell Medical College New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center Payne Whitney Manhattan and Westchester

Something astonishing is now visible on Vesey Street: the Vesey Street staircase. Also known as the ''Survivors' Stairway'' for its vital role in the evacuation of hundreds of people from the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, the staircase has been largely obscured by fencing, equipment and its design.
TAMIS--Jack, age 106, on March 3rd, 2008. Beloved father of William Edna Goldin and Terri Doppelt. Devoted grandfather, great-grandfather, Master Goldsmith, and gentle man.

If people in the United States are mesmerized, and excited, by the primary races, so are the people in Britain. Newspapers there are awash in American political news that is as detailed and as breathless as in the states -- but with a decidedly Democratic bias. William Barnard, who heads the Democrats Abroad chapter in London, said he had to explain to his British friends that they were barred by law from donating money or volunteering to work for the Democratic presidential candidates.

Does Nicholson Baker throw anything away? He has written articles in defense of old card catalogs, chided microfilm-happy librarians for sending books to warehouses (and landfills), and founded the American Newspaper Repository, a home for abandoned historical newspapers. According to a profile in this week's Times, even the prospect of returning the library books he used to research his new book "Human Smoke" makes him sigh wistfully. (Is this because he doesn't trust librarians to safeguard them, or other people to actually read them?)

Russia has geared up fore a double-hitter holiday weekend that will offer an entertaining mix of Soviet and pre-revolutionary pagan traditions: Saturday, March 8 is Women's Day, an official Soviet-era holiday that has carried over to capitalist Russia. Sunday, March 9, is the culmination of Maslenitsa, a pagan celebration of spring that became the Russian version of Carnaval, which is being celebrated with new fervor as Russians re-embrace old traditions.

Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, has won the Morelia-Linares super tournament. It is the third time that Anand has won this prestigious tournament and the second time in a row. Magnus Carlsen of Norway was second, a half point behind, followed by Levon Aronian of Armenia and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, who were another half point back. A crosstable and games from the event, as well as information about the players and a list of the previous winners, is on the tournament's Web site. Interviews with some of the players, including Anand, are on the Europe-Echecs Web site.

MBIA, the bond insurance company, has asked Fitch Ratings to stop rating it. It seems that Fitch, unlike Moody's and Standard & Poor's, has not yet bought into the idea that MBIA deserves a AAA rating despite the structured finance debacle. (Investors don't buy it either, judging by the yields they demand on insured bonds.)

Here's a novel way to get a college scholarship: be the rapper son of a hip-hop mogul, the star of a kids' television show and a good friend of a highly touted prospect. The Wall Street Journal's Jon Weinbach reports on how this combination of factors seems to have helped Romeo Miller, better known as Lil' Romeo, get a scholarship to play at Southern California.

Updated For the time being, it doesn't matter whether the Clinton campaign's contention that caucuses are undemocratic is accurate - they count. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appears determined to break her all-but-Nevada (and New Mexico!) losing streak in them. Over the past several days, she and her family have been stumping around Wyoming, which is holding Democratic caucuses throughout the morning and early afternoon today. The intensity of her late efforts there appear to be helping her catch up to Senator Barack Obama, according to state party officials, even though he was more organized there, meaning we've got a real race today in Vice President Dick Cheney's home state.

Jeff Gordon, bouncing back from a hard crash last week in Las Vegas, won the pole for the Nascar Sprint Cup race on Sunday at Atlanta Motor Speedway. Gordon had a fast lap of 185.251 miles an hour on the 1.5-mile oval, easily faster than Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s 184.852. In Las Vegas, Gordon was not seriously hurt after bouncing off the car driven by Matt Kenseth and slamming into the wall. The impact tore apart the front of his car, leaving his radiator steaming on the track. On Friday night, Gordon said, “I was sore, but none of the soreness affected me in the racecar.” Carl Edwards, coming off two wins in a row, but under the shadow this week of a Nascar penalty, qualified fourth at 183.287. The seven-time Atlanta pole-winner Ryan Newman did not come close to the top spot, posting a 182.135 that left him 12th.
The loss marked the fifth straight defeat for the Knicks, and the fifth time they have had a losing streak of five or more games this season.
A video on the candidate’s presidential campaign Web site hinted that his long-shot contest for the Republican nomination might not continue.
Chris Paul had 25 points and 16 assists, and the New Orleans Hornets won their third straight game, 107-96 against the visiting Nets on Friday night.
Patrik Elias scored 4 minutes 2 seconds into overtime Friday night, lifting the host Devils into first place in the Eastern Conference with a 2-1 victory against the lowly Tampa Bay Lightning.

A student pilot was found stabbed to death in her hotel room at Sheppard Air Force Base in Wichita Falls, officials said. The woman, whose identity was not released, had been assigned to the base temporarily and was staying alone in the hotel, said a base spokesman, George Woodward. Sheppard, the largest technical training operation in the Air Force, has about 5,000 students on base at any given time, most arriving after completing basic training at another base.

A judge in Las Vegas agreed to delay the armed robbery and kidnapping trial of O.J. Simpson and two co-defendants until September to give the defense more time to prepare. The judge, Jackie Glass of Clark County District Court, refused to separate Mr. Simpson’s trial from that of his co-defendants, Charles Ehrlich and Clarence Stewart. She also refused throw out the charges against Mr. Simpson. The men are accused of kidnapping and robbing two dealers peddling Simpson memorabilia at a Las Vegas hotel-casino in September.

Two firefighters died and three others were injured while battling a huge fire that destroyed a woodworking company in Salisbury. The firefighters, Justin Monroe, 19, and Victor Isler, 40, died from injuries they got while trying to contain the fire at Salisbury Millworks, Fire Chief Rick Parnell said. A steady rain helped firefighters knock down most of the flames that once towered above the site, but there was little left of the millworks, which made architectural products like cabinets. The building walls had collapsed, and smoke poured from the smoldering rubble. The Salisbury Post reported that crews as far away as Charlotte, about 40 miles south, were called to fight the fire, which was reported around 7 a.m.

The police in Dallas said a motorcycle officer who died while escorting Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s motorcade crashed because he could not negotiate a curve, the final police report on the Feb. 22 crash said. Cpl. Victor Lozada Tirado’s motorcycle clipped a curb and hit a guardrail while he was escorting Mrs. Clinton’s motorcade to a campaign appearance. The report says Corporal Lozada’s failure to drive in a single lane was a factor in his being thrown from his motorcycle on a viaduct near downtown.

A regional land use commission has approved the construction of a home in Truro that some say will alter the landscape Edward Hopper saw from the cottage where he painted and lived. The Cape Cod Commission voted 11 to 1 to allow Donald and Andrea Kline to build a planned 6,500-square-foot home on the 9.3-acre property. The commission put restrictions on the parcel, including that the home be no more than 14 feet high, no additional structures can be built and an existing home on the land be preserved. Foes of the development are calling for an additional review of the plans, which still must be approved by the Town of Truro. Hopper spent summers in Truro from 1930 until his death in 1967.

The Interior Department’s inspector general has begun a preliminary investigation into why the department has delayed for nearly two months a decision on listing the polar bear as a threatened species. The decision was supposed to have been made by early January. But when the deadline came, the Fish and Wildlife Service, an Interior unit, said it needed another month. That timetable was also not met. A spokesman for the inspector general’s office said a case had been opened in response to a letter from several environmental groups. He said the preliminary inquiry would determine whether a full-fledged investigation was warranted. Scientists say the bear is under growing threat as a result of significant loss of Arctic sea ice because of global warming.

A front-page article on Sunday about Barack Obama’s effort to land a knockout blow to the campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton with large advertising expenditures referred incorrectly to the indie-rock band Arcade Fire, which performed a concert for Mr. Obama in Ohio. Some members are from Canada and some from Texas; they did not all grow up in Texas.

A picture in some editions on Wednesday of Hillary Rodham Clinton with supporters in Ohio carried an erroneous credit. It was by Todd Heisler of The New York Times, not by David Ahntholz. Another photograph on Wednesday, of a polling place in Cleveland, omitted a credit for Mr. Ahntholz.

An obituary on Sunday about John D. B. Lewis, a lawyer who fought for the rights of the poor, misspelled one of his middle names. He was John David Bonnor Lewis, not Bonner. The obituary also included erroneous information from his wife about a surviving brother, Salim B. Lewis. He lives in Essex, N.Y.; his whereabouts are not unknown.

A picture caption on Wednesday with coverage of Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre’s retirement described incorrectly, in some editions, the context for his wave to fans while walking off the field. It was after the Packers defeated the Seattle Seahawks in the playoffs in January, not after they lost to the Giants in the National Football Conference championship game. The caption also misstated the timing of the title game in some editions. It, too, was in January — not “last month.”.

A front-page article last Saturday about a decision by the Air Force to award a contract for aerial refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus referred imprecisely to the site of the plant where final assembly of the planes will take place. It is in Mobile, Ala., not “near” it.

An article in Business Day on Feb. 25 about Britney Spears’s finances in the wake of her public breakdown misstated the support she has given to her family, including her father, Jamie, since she first became a pop star in 1999. Although she has helped her father financially during that time, she has not been the primary breadwinner for Mr. Spears, who works as a caterer in Los Angeles.

A front-page article last Saturday about a decision by the Air Force to award a contract for aerial refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus referred imprecisely to the site of the plant where final assembly of the planes will take place. It is in Mobile, Ala., not “near” it.

A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Friday about an attack by a gunman at a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem referred incorrectly to comments by the police about the ages of the victims. Although the police said that many of the dead were thought to be in their 20s, they did not say conclusively at the time that they were. (On Friday morning the police released the names and ages of the dead, showing that they ranged in age from 15 to 26 and that most of them were teenagers.).
An obituary on Tuesday about the guitarist, singer and songwriter Jeff Healey misspelled the given name of his wife, who survives him. She is Cristie Healey, not Christie.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the innovative release of new music by the band Nine Inch Nails in various formats, including digital downloads, referred incorrectly to BitTorrent. It is an online protocol that can be used in the distribution of files, like the band’s new recordings. It is not a distinct file-sharing network. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the Web address of the company that oversees the protocol. It is bittorrent.com.

Marion Jones began her six-month sentence in federal prison Friday, punishment for lying to investigators about her use of performance-enhancing drugs and her role in a check-fraud scam. Jones turned herself in before noon at Federal Medical Center Carswell in Fort Worth, a prison spokeswoman said. Under the terms of her sentencing, she had until Tuesday to surrender. Although the prison specializes in medical and mental health services, it also has inmates who do not require such care. After frequently denying ever having used performance-enhancing drugs, Jones admitted she had lied to federal investigators in November 2003. Jones also admitted lying about her knowledge of the involvement of Tim Montgomery, the father of her older son, in a scheme to cash millions of dollars worth of stolen or forged checks.

The former three-time world champion Alexis Arguello has been nominated by the Sandinista party to run for mayor of Managua, Nicaragua’s capital. Arguello was approved as a precandidate for the November elections at a meeting of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, according to Daysi Torrez, a journalist who was nominated to run for deputy mayor. The selections will be ratified on Sunday by the party’s top decision-making council, and the candidates will be officially presented next week, Torrez said. Arguello, a former featherweight and lightweight champion, retired in 1995 with 80 wins in 88 fights, 64 by knockout. He was inducted into the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 1992.(AP).

The defending champion Lance Mackey and his 14 dogs sailed up a hill as the first team in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race to pull into Ruby, Alaska, on the Yukon River, about 600 miles into the 1,100-mile race to Nome. Mackey arrived at 7:32 a.m. Friday, more than two and a half hours before the four-time winner Jeff King clocked in with his 16 dogs. For beating the field to the Yukon, Mackey, 37, was treated to the traditional seven-course gourmet feast and received $5,000 in $1 bills.
The scene of the crime on Friday morning had no yellow “crime scene” tape blocking off the sidewalk, and no locks on the door. The door had been so badly shattered that it had to be removed.

Joshua Irizarry is 12 years old, but that hardly stopped him from applying for the job of football coach at West Virginia. Insisting it was a “completely serious offer,” Joshua, of Southington, Conn., outlined his skills in a letter to Mike Garrison, the university’s president, when the job opened in December. They included “making up new plays to fool defenses in local sandlot games.” He also has an eye for marketing. “Consider the publicity your campus would receive,” he wrote in the letter. Garrison eventually promoted the assistant coach Bill Stewart to replace Rich Rodriguez, but he honored the boy’s two alternative requests — a written response and an autographed photo of his favorite player, the freshman running back Noel Devine.

The trainer Steve Asmussen will look to extend his hot streak Saturday when he sends out the favorite Pyro and his stablemate J Be K in the $600,000 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans. With a win by Pyro a month after his breathtaking last-to-first Risen Star victory, Asmussen, who trained last year’s Horse of the Year, Curlin, would have a leading Kentucky Derby contender for the second consecutive year. A strong effort by the sprint whiz J Be K will put that colt in the Derby picture as well.Asmussen also trains the Risen Star runner-up Z Fortune, who is set to run in the Rebel Stakes at Oaklawn Park on March 15 in Hot Springs, Ark. At Aqueduct, Giant Moon, sporting a 4-for-4 record, is up against nine rivals in the $250,000 Gotham Stakes at 1 1-16th mile. Giant Moon, a hard-fought neck win in the Count Fleet on Jan. 5, will take on Visionaire, trained by Michael Matz, plus three 3-year-olds from the trainer Todd Pletcher — Holidaze, Southern Terminus and Texas Wildcatter.

When Gary Gygax, the intellectual and spiritual father of all modern role-playing games, died on Tuesday at 69, it prompted a reconsideration of the power of the imagination he unleashed, a power that continues to resonate and swell around the globe.

China will tighten its restrictions on foreign performers following an appearance last Sunday in Shanghai by the Icelandic singer Bjork, who shouted “Tibet, Tibet” after performing her song “Declare Independence.” China’s Ministry of Culture responded to Bjork’s action on Friday by posting a statement on its Web site, saying that she “broke Chinese law and hurt Chinese people’s feelings,” The Associated Press reported. Bjork has sung the song before in support of independence movements; performing in Japan in February, she dedicated it to Kosovo.

The Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago, now on Broadway with its production of “August: Osage County,” said its 2008-9 season would open with a stage adaptation of Haruki Murakami’s novel “Kafka on the Shore” by a Steppenwolf member, Frank Galati, who will also direct. “Kafka” is to be followed with a new production of Conor McPherson’s “Seafarer” featuring John Mahoney. The season also includes a production of Yasmina Reza’s “Art”; Shakespeare’s “Tempest,” directed by Tina Landau; and Bridget Carpenter’s “Up,” which will be directed by Anna D. Shapiro.

In the latest development in Britney Spears’s continuing family drama, a Los Angeles Superior Court commissioner ordered the troubled singer’s estate to pay her father, James Spears, $2,500 in weekly compensation, and extended his authority over his daughter’s affairs at least until July 31, The Associated Press reported. The commissioner, Reva Goetz, also ordered the estate to make a $58,800 payment to the court-appointed lawyer, Samuel D. Ingham III, who represents Ms. Spears in the conservatorship case, and authorized Ms. Spears’s psychiatrist to hire two other doctors and pay them retainers totaling $9,000 from her estate. Following Ms. Spears’s hospitalization in January, Mr. Spears was named her conservator and co-conservator of her estate.

A Tennessee judge has ruled that while Fisk University in Nashville violated the terms under which Georgia O’Keeffe donated art to the institution, it should not lose the works to a New Mexico museum, The Associated Press reported. Ellen Hobbs Lyle, a Davidson County Chancery Court judge, permanently banned the sale of the 101-piece O’Keeffe collection, but also ruled that Fisk must take the artworks out of storage and display them by October. Chancellor Lyle had vetoed previous efforts by the financially ailing university to raise money by selling the art, including O’Keeffe’s 1927 oil painting “Radiator Building — Night, New York,” above. The Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in New Mexico, representing her estate, had sued to get the collection, citing Fisk’s bids to sell the paintings and their removal from display as violations of the terms of the 1949 donation. Last month the judge rejected Fisk’s proposed $30 million sale of a half-interest in the artworks to the Crystal Bridges Museum in Bentonville, Ark., founded by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice Walton.

Spanning seven decades and including many objects seldom seen in public, an exhibition devoted to Man Ray (1890-1976), the American-born artist who was a father of Dada and Surrealism, opened at the Pinacothèque de Paris museum, The Associated Press reported. “The Workshop of Man Ray,” running through June 1, includes portraits of Picasso and Ernest Hemingway as well as oddities like a life-size pair of golden lips and a blue baguette that adorns the cover of a book of lithographs.

“American Idol” dominated ratings for a third and final time this week on Thursday, lifting the Fox drama “New Amsterdam” and giving the network an easy win for the evening, Nielsen estimated. About 26.2 million viewers watched the field of “Idol” finalists narrow to 12, and almost 10.6 million viewers stayed to watch the second episode of “New Amsterdam” at 9 p.m., a drop of three million from the viewership of its premiere on Tuesday. ABC won the 9 o’clock hour when 12.8 million viewers tuned in for “Lost”; CBS placed third with 9.8 million viewers for “CSI.” At 10 p.m., “Without a Trace” averaged 9.4 million viewers for CBS, beating the 6.8 million for “Eli Stone” on ABC and the 5.8 million for “Lipstick Jungle” on NBC.

A San Francisco Opera performance of Puccini’s “Rondine,” starring Angela Gheorghiu, will be presented on screen at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan on Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m. and on Monday and Tuesday at 7 p.m. (The same production is to open at the Metropolitan Opera in December.) ... Lou Pearlman, the music mogul behind the Backstreet Boys and ’N Sync, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal charges of conspiracy, making false statements during bankruptcy proceedings and money laundering, The Associated Press reported. He is scheduled to be sentenced on May 21 and faces $1 million in fines and up to 25 years in prison. ... Mario Lopez, once known as A. C. Slater in “Saved by the Bell” and more recently a second-place finisher in “Dancing With the Stars,” will be stepping into the role of Zach in “A Chorus Line” on Broadway from April 15 to Sept. 7.

BEIL--Sheldon L. There was only one Shelly Beil. Shelly was the most loving uncle, valued business partner and cherished friend. We will miss his humor and love forever. Our heartfelt sympathy and love goes out to Ruthie, Merrie, Stacey, Justin and David. Judi and Barry, Elizabeth and Jonathan, and Jeffrey BEIL--Sheldon. Loving husband of Ruthie, father of Merrie, grandfather of Stacey, great-grandfather of Justin and stepfather of David, died March 7, 2008. He knew how to live life to the fullest. He was a kind, warmhearted man who had a passion for helping people. He always had a joke to tell. You are the love of my life, my soul mate. You taught me so much in life and what true love is. Everyday you would say, ''Did I tell you I love you today?'' I miss you so much. I love you so much in the whole wide world. Ruthie

FEDEX KINKO CHIEF LEAVES The FedEx Corporation said Kenneth A. May had resigned as president and chief executive of its FedEx Kinko's office supply and copy centers, three months after the company said it would slow expansion at the unit. Mr. May, 47, had led FedEx Kinko's since January 2006. The change takes effect March 31. Brian Philips, 40, chief operating officer of the Dallas-based FedEx Kinko's, will become acting chief executive, FedEx said. The unit has ''underperformed'' since FedEx bought the business for $2.4 billion four years ago to compete with United Parcel Service's UPS Stores, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, James Corridore, said. Shares of FedEx fell $2.05, to close at $86.70. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

(Cinemax) HOT FUZZ (2007) From the warped British sensibilities behind ''Shaun of the Dead'' comes this spoof of Hollywood action films, in which a London cop (Simon Pegg) is banished to the hinterlands by his inept superiors (Bill Nighy, Steve Coogan and Martin Freeman) for being too good at his job. This being a testosterone-fueled domain, the most tender looks are exchanged between Nicholas Angel (Mr. Pegg) and his sidekick, Danny Butterman (Nick Frost, above left with Mr. Pegg). ''It's a world in which boys will be boys at every available opportunity,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''For the most part these are fine boys indeed,'' she said of the cast, which also includes Jim Broadbent, Paddy Considine and Timothy Dalton, adding that ''the emotional intimacy of Mr. Pegg and Mr. Frost's on-screen relationship suggests that there's more to these performers than parody.'' 8 P.M. Every once in a while I feel that it might be helpful to readers if I explained what it is I am trying to do in these columns. It is easier to state the negative: For the most part, it is not my purpose in this space to urge positions, or come down on one side or the other of a controversial question. Of course, I do those things occasionally and sometimes inadvertently, but more often than not I am analyzing arguments rather than making them; or, to be more precise, I am making arguments about arguments, especially ones I find incoherent or insufficiently examined.

Samuel Peter stopped Oleg Maskaev in the final seconds of the sixth round Saturday night in Cancún, Mexico, claiming Maskaev’s World Boxing Council heavyweight title with a flurry of powerful punches.Peter (30-1, 23 knockouts), a Nigerian who trains in Las Vegas, was more powerful and more poised than the 39-year-old Maskaev in front of a capacity crowd at Plaza de Toros, the bullfighting ring in Cancún and the unlikely site of Mexico’s first heavyweight title fight.

The defending champion Lance Mackey was the first musher out of the Yukon River checkpoint of Nulato, Alaska, in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, leaving with a team that he said was not running at full throttle.“I’m not sure they’re going to have what it takes,” Mackey said of his 14-dog team before leaving Nulato to head to Kaltag, 42 miles downriver. “But I’m not giving up. A lot can happen between now and Nome.”Mackey, a 37-year-old musher from Fairbanks, was the first to reach Nulato, 700 miles into the 1,100-mile race to Nome. He arrived exactly two hours ahead of the four-time champion Jeff King, whose 16 dogs looked alert and fresh.

Clemson running back Ray Ray McElrathbey, who gained national attention two years ago for taking custody of his 11-year-old brother, will not play for the Tigers in the fall.Clemson Coach Tommy Bowden said in a news release that McElrathbey, 21, would graduate in August. McElrathbey has two years of eligibility left and could play for another program or remain at Clemson to pursue a master’s degree.McElrathbey missed all of last season after knee surgery in September to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament. He has not said what he plans to do.

The Paris-Nice race is set to start Sunday even though teams that participate face sanctions from cycling’s governing body, the International Cycling Union, which says it is fighting for its ability to regulate the doping-marred sport.Pat McQuaid, the president of the cycling union, has urged riders to boycott the Paris-Nice race, the season’s first major stage race, calling it “illegal” because the race organizer, the Amaury Sport Organization, is holding it under French laws and outside U.C.I. rules.McQuaid has threatened teams with six-month suspensions, fines of up to $9,700 and bans from the track world championships this month, which would affect cyclists who are trying to qualify for the Beijing Olympics.But the International Association of Professional Cyclists ruled in favor of starting the race.

Stewart Cink’s fortunes turned quickly in a vicious wind that never went away. He made three straight birdies for a two-under 68 in the third round of the PODS Championship in Palm Harbor, Fla., before play was suspended because of darkness. Cink went from four shots behind to two shots ahead in a stretch of five holes, and despite a 30-mile-an-hour wind and 50-degree temperatures, he did not make a bogey until he was on the 18th hole. Cink was at five-under 208, two shots ahead of the former United States Open champion Geoff Ogilvy, who had a 69. The second-round leader Brandt Snedeker was three under and in the 16th fairway when play was stopped.

Matt Kenseth reached the Nascar Nationwide Series victory circle for the first time in nearly a year, passing Jeff Burton for the lead on Lap 186 of the Nicorette 300 at Atlanta Motor Speedway in Hampton, Ga. The race was extended three laps beyond its scheduled 195 laps because of a three-car crash.

The two-time Masters champion Bernhard Langer moved into position for his second Champions Tour victory by shooting his second straight six-under 65 to take a three-stroke lead at the Toshiba Classic in Newport Beach, Calif.

Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said he was optimistic that China could improve its famously bad air before the Beijing Olympics in August. Rogge said that Beijing was making big strides in cutting pollution. Rogge had warned that some events at the Olympics could be postponed if the air quality is poor, but he hoped much of the pollution will be cleaned up when the Games start. “We will see that they have made major progress,” Rogge said at the Fourth I.O.C. World Conference on Women and Sport in Southern Shuneh, Jordan.

An article in Play magazine last Sunday about the turnaround of the Boston Celtics gave an outdated name for the team’s home arena in two references. It is TD Banknorth Garden, not the Fleet Center. The article also misidentified the game in which Brian Scalabrine, now a forward and center for the Celtics, made four three-pointers near the end. It was the 2004 Eastern Conference semifinals, not the 2005 Eastern Conference finals. And the article referred incorrectly to the parquet floor used for Celtics games at TD Banknorth Garden. The team moved the floor to the Fleet Center from the Boston Garden, the team’s former arena, in 1995. That floor was replaced after a game on Dec. 22, 1999, so the team no longer plays on the parquet floor originally used in the Boston Garden.
An article on Feb. 24 in T: Women’s Fashion magazine, about the Osmothèque, a scent museum in Paris, misspelled part of the name of a cosmetics company. It is Helena Rubinstein, not Rubenstein.

Old-fashioned seems an odd way to describe the three hip-looking best friends behind Lova, a new men’s-wear label out of Los Angeles. While they definitely have the looks to make the fashion scene out there, Giuseppe Valentini, Nikolas Apostolopoulos and Daniel Murphy (above) have little interest in hanging out with Lindsay or Paris. In fact, they are as inclined to trawl the farmers’ markets as the bars, so they can serve up elaborate Greek dinners and anecdotes about their grandmothers in the three-bedroom duplex they share. The trio’s quaint sensibilities translate into pinstriped blazers, short-sleeved cashmere cardigans and narrow-collared shirts with buttons made of corozo nut. Rather than staging a runway show to showcase their line, the guys made a short film, which has the look of a Super 8 home movie taken at a sunny backyard barbecue — albeit one where all the guests are impeccably dressed bright young things. “Rather than just show the clothes, we wanted to evoke an emotion,” Murphy says. That emotion is suffused with hazy nostalgia, much like the collection’s creators. [?][?][?]JEN WANG.
ADRIANO GIANNINI.

Elvis Presley, with his assortment of bedazzled jumpsuits, may be the king of one-piece dressing, but thankfully he wasn’t the inspiration for this season’s styles. Designers like Miuccia Prada and Alexander McQueen were more interested in the functional garments first worn by workers and pilots; Dsquared went for pit stop mechanics; and Calvin Klein’s futuristic versions brought to mind “2001: A Space Odyssey.” Levi Strauss introduced denim “Koveralls” for children in 1912; Lee followed the next year with its Union-All suit, intended for farmers and factory workers. World War I pilots wore flight suits based on Lee’s adaptable model, and avant-garde artists zipped up after the war: the Constructivist artist Alexander Rodchenko had a two-piece “productivist” outfit designed to look like a jumpsuit. In the 1940s, cartoonists added fantasy to the onesie, outfitting the Flash and Green Lantern. But it took man walking on the moon to usher in the “golden age” of the jumpsuit — the 1970s. Soon, entertainers kicked it up a notch: David Bowie as Ziggy Stardust wore outrageous versions; Evel Knievel was sometimes carried into the emergency room in a star-studded red, white and blue leather number. Devo performed in yellow jumpsuits. And in the early 1980s, retro-futurist designers like Thierry Mugler introduced styles with padded shoulders. Oddly, it was President Bush who refocused the public’s attention on the flight suit when he modeled one in front of the infamous “Mission Accomplished” banner in 2003. And let’s not forget shackled terrorists and their orange prison suits. The latter can be had for $13.95 at nationaltextile.us. Surplus flight suits on eBay are $30, and a repro of Elvis’s Sunburst suit is $3,300 at b-k-enterprises.com. Zip carefully, my man. [?][?][?]ROBERT E. BRYAN.

The Samurai Sipper, an older sister, mourns the bygone era of sibling rivalry, when she routinely crushed her younger brother’s infuriating smirks in a salvo of right hooks so thunderous he called for his mommy. Ah, the glory days. The Samurai Sibling was just a big sissy pants till puberty, when he grew stronger and hairier and finally landed a monster uppercut on my jaw. We called it even. But Sipper’s superiority continues unchallenged in nonpugilistic matters, and if the Sib mutters “age before beauty” within earshot, I go below the belt and over his head with two words: Viagra and Rogaine.

When René Lacoste, one of France’s most tenacious tennis champions, stepped onto the courts of Roland Garros and Wimbledon in the 1920s, the concept of athletic clothing was nonexistent. The female champion Suzanne Lenglen was playing in long outfits by Chanel and Patou; it wasn’t uncommon for her male counterparts to duke it out in belted slacks, dress shirts and leather lace-ups. On occasion, espadrilles (a sartorial leftover from the Basque game of pelota) would lend a welcome — if sometimes ankle-wrenching — sense of ease to the proceedings.

I started wearing pajamas during the day shortly after I founded Playboy in 1953. It made sense because the first few issues were put together in my apartment, where I would often work straight through the night. In the early ’60s, when I moved into the Playboy Mansion in Chicago, I stopped going to the office altogether; by the ’80s, I had begun using pajamas in a more social way. When I had friends over for a buffet and a movie on Friday nights, I didn’t bother to put on a shirt or a suit, and people started to be disappointed if I didn’t wear PJ’s. I think I have about 100 different pairs in silk custom-made for me by a tailor named Mr. Brown. During the day I wear black; for weekends I prefer purple; and on holidays and special occasions, red. My bedsheets are black satin, and my girlfriends like to wear pink pajamas. Holly stays with me overnight, and my other two girlfriends, Kendra and Bridget, have their own bedrooms. It would be crazy if we all tried to sleep together, because Holly has four dogs that stay in our bed, Bridget has a dog and a cat, and Kendra has two dogs. But we like to throw pajama parties to give our guests the opportunity to dress the way I do. It’s very comfortable, and if you can pull it off, there’s definitely a certain style to it.

Men’s stores are going for a luxurious residential feeling, hoping their clients will never want to leave. Tom Ford started the trend with his New York flagship, which has a Claude Lalanne desk, plush sofas and butler service; his Milan outpost, opening this summer, will have an equally homey quality. Meanwhile, Ermenegildo Zegna’s new 9,200-square-foot Manhattan pied-à-terre (left) features architectural details designed to reference Zegna’s custom fabrics, artwork by Frank Thiel and a fireplace.

Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are cracking wise. The pair are holding court during Milan Fashion Week and appear surprisingly relaxed, given that the last few days have been one long Dolceandgabbanarama, including a V.I.P. dinner to celebrate a calendar featuring their new underwear model, David Gandy. “Did you see Silvio Berlusconi at the dinner?” asks Dolce, referring to the former Italian prime minister, who at one point during the night was cornered by a fashion-world gender illusionist who’s had more work done than Zsa Zsa. Says Gabbana, “I think Berlusconi thought it was Liza Minnelli.” Since Dolce and Gabbana are inexorably linked to a pantheon of cinema and sporting gods, they can afford to joke about the important business of dressing one of Italy’s reigning heartthrobs: Riccardo Scamarcio, the 28-year-old star of “My Brother Is an Only Child,” coming out this month. “Riccardo who?” Gabbana asks. “Seriously, he is becoming like Brad Pitt in Italy.” The clothes that the designers have chosen may require that Scamarcio do some advanced role playing. Which is perfectly O.K. with him.

If you fancy telling the story of style, one of the easiest ways to do it would be to chart the changing design of magazines. Not all of them, of course, just the ones that set the agenda for their particular era.

The multitalented Betony Vernon may be (ahem!) an educator, designer and author, but first and foremost she wants to teach the world some sexual common sense. “People are not natural born lovers,” she says. “We learn skills over time, like a painter.” Vernon, who designs a line of titillating “jewel tools” (read: sex accessories) sold at boutiques like Kiki de Montparnasse and Coco de Mer, recently opened a store-cum-boudoir in a historic 17th-century building in Paris and is at work on a book detailing “the possibilities of pleasure and erotic ceremonies.” Just don’t mistake her for a sex-shop habitué. “My work is a response to all things plastic, black, evil and cheap that don’t give people the chance to explore the power of the body.” Michel Foucault would be proud. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.
