Stanley Kirk Burrell, also known as MC Hammer, has had his fair share of lives. He started out as a batboy, became a rap superstar, was born again as a preacher and is now a Web entrepreneur promoting his site, DanceJam.com. Needless to say, that doesn’t include his sideline as a fashion icon. Did you know that Hammer pants are back? Labels like Dior (left) and Burberry have been doing really baggy trousers. Yes. To have invented the Hammer pants and have them re-emerge with a twist is an honor. When and how did you start wearing them? In the late ’70s, during the disco era, when we were going out to the clubs. The looser the pants, the more accentuated your dancing becomes. Initially I would buy triple-pleated zoot-suit trousers from the ’40s; when I became MC Hammer, I started having my own versions made. Did you wear Hammer pants later on, when you were a pastor officiating at the weddings of people like Corey Feldman and Mötley Crüe’s Vince Neil? I use Hammer pants to perform. For day-to-day life, I have 30 suits that I rotate. I’ve always been a high-fashion dresser and love the bespoke style. Once, I bought 80 suits from Versace in all the colors of the rainbow — as bright as canary yellow. To accessorize I had special-edition Versace watches and Rolexes customized with rubies and baguettes. And then came the earrings. Have you ever considered fashion design? Part of my vision is to have a clothing line with a great strategic partner. Not just upper-end, but scaled back to a great pair of Hammer-style jeans — baggy, but not the baggy kind that kids are wearing falling off the butt. I mean baggy Hammer in the crotch area — big difference. Maybe you should call some of the designers that are doing Hammer pants now and ask to be in their ad campaigns. I think you should suggest it, and I’d certainly be interested. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDE.
How two Dutchmen created two magazines, both audacious in style and content — and for completely different reasons.

Fad-prone Japan has yet another obsession: public displays of emotion. Groups of pent-up salarymen are swapping karaoke for “tear therapy” — the chance to rent a room and watch cinematic weepies like “Love Story.” So powerful is this mawkish urge that entrepreneurs have even started crying clubs, where otherwise stoic guys can bond over shame-free sobbing jags for about 1,000 yen ($9.40). The rock musician Tadayuki Inui organizes Minnade Nako Kai in Kyoto; the film buff and restaurateur Kosuke Kimura in Sendai owns Ruisen Kai (the Lachrymal Gland Club in English). England’s stiff upper lip is also quivering. The artist Viktor Wynd holds teary events called Loss: An Evening of Exquisite Misery (below), inspired by Günter Grass’s sad nightclub, the Onion Cellar, in “The Tin Drum.” Gloomy guests swoon around in vintage clothes, listen to fado music and carry peacock feathers, half-dead flowers salvaged from cemeteries or freshly signed divorce papers. Come midnight, attendees are handed knives and onions to chop to the sound of the Mozart Requiem. Overly chirpy attendees are fined one pound per smile and two pounds per laugh. “Melancholia is not such a bad thing,” says Wynd, who is hoping to bring his mournful bashes to New York soon. “I don’t know why people think they’re supposed to be happy all the time.”[?][?][?] MARK ELLWOOD.

To the Editor: Regarding your Check In/Check Out column, on the Danhostel Copenhagen City, on Feb. 3: No more Danhostel! It was also written about a year or so ago, and because my husband thinks anything in The Times is gospel, we stayed there in June of 2007. The rooms at Danhostel are like prison cells designed by the warden. Our room was on the third floor in the back, but the traffic noise was so unbearable I purchased silicone earplugs from a Mata store. The elevator key card reader had episodes of dementia. The seating for computer use should have come with a chiropractor coupon.

To the Editor: Your story “The Other Iran” (Feb. 10) prompted several letters reporting that Iranians evidence no anti-American sentiment but object only to our president. Fair enough. But apparently all of the writers were unaware of Iran’s brutal repression of individual liberties, suppression of women, support for terrorism and calls for the destruction of Israel. Otherwise they might have replied, “We’re not really sold on your president either”— and a real dialogue might have begun.

To the Editor: Your Practical Traveler column “Curves in the Road to Miles Redemption” (Feb. 10) was spot on — finding an award ticket or being able to use miles even for an upgrade on a paid ticket is like looking for a needle in a haystack. The problem has become such a headache that last year I converted all my credit cards from ones that gave you miles to ones that give you a percentage rebate at the end of the year. At least I can calculate the return and know when to expect it to be useful. Jordan Rosner.

HABER--Helen died on February 10 at the age of 81, at North Shore Hospital on Long Island. Beloved wife of Irving, mother to Stuart and Harriet, mother-in-law to Mary Ann and Neil, and devoted grandmother to Sam, Mitchel and Erica. Her love formed a dependable foundation for her extended family and friends. Born on Staten Island, she was a graduate of Brooklyn College, and worked as a bilingual New York City school teacher. Vibrant till the very end, she was an active member and a leader of several organizations, including B'nai B'rith. She will be deeply missed.

THE French handbag designer Jerome Dreyfuss will open his first store this week in Paris, right beside his wife Isabel Marant's shop in Saint-Germain. The space is designed to look like a Modernist locker room: lots of George Nelson-style platform benches and bags hanging like boxing gloves on the walls. He thinks it's very him. ''It's not so chic, la la, you know?'' he explained from his Paris studio. ''It's cool.'' Mr. Dreyfuss, 33, gained acclaim in the late '90s for being a wild-child couturier (his corset made of sticky tape hangs in the Musée de la Mode), but he has mellowed a bit with age. His handbag line, introduced in 2002, is less avant-garde and more attuned to a modern lifestyle. Cut from reptile skins and supple organic fabrics in slouchy multifunctional shapes, the bags assume an insouciant air of cool, not unlike the women (Jane Birkin, Vanessa Paradis) who carry them.

An article on Feb. 17 about the state of public broadcasting misstated the Nielsen rating for the wrestling show ''Friday Night Smackdown,'' whose viewership was compared with that of the average PBS prime-time show during the 2006-7 season. The wrestling show's average rating for all households over the first four weeks of February is 2.7 -- not 1.4, the average for PBS.

SCHATZBERG--Sheila, age 85, suddenly on March 6, following hip surgery at Lennox Hill Hospital. Devoted wife of the late Sidney. Beloved sister to Arnold and the late Selma, Hy, Julia and Alvin. Adoring aunt to nieces Robyne, Francine, Laurie, Elyse and Brooke, and to nephews Vance, Gordon and Robert. Cherished great-aunt to Marisa, Erica, Andrew, Perry, Emily, Sara, Keith, Derek, Harrison, Alexa, Elana and Allison. A spirited New Yorker who loved traveling, reading in Central Park, volunteering, good food and fine wine. Most of all she loved her family and friends and took pleasure and pride in everyone's accomplish ments. A woman of valor who could light up a room and whose memory will live in the hearts of those who loved her forever.

Tired of high-performance sneakers fit only for the playoffs in space? The reappearance of Superga this spring brings a much-needed dose of lo-fi Mediterranean cool to the rubber-sole geek set. Not unlike a European version of the classic Converse All Star, the laid-back canvas shoes are better suited for scoring at a bar than on a basketball court. Which explains why they appeal to players of all ages. Says the Superga designer Diego Ficili, ''In Italy, we wear them from zero to 100 years.'' From $80; go to stevenalan.com. Alex Hawgood

FOR a mortgage borrower verging on delinquency, a cheaper loan may be the best way to save a home. But Fannie Mae, which holds major sway in the mortgage industry, is offering another alternative: an additional loan. The company, which bolsters the mortgage market by buying loans from lenders and reselling them in bulk to investors, announced the HomeSaver Advance late last month. This program will enable borrowers to take out an unsecured personal loan to cover missed mortgage payments quickly.

STILL NO. 1 Mark Zuckerberg, the 23-year-old chief executive of the social network Facebook, has little interest in handing over the reins of his company to more experienced leadership. ''We decided it was more appropriate for me to stay as the C.E.O.,'' he said last week while discussing the hiring of Sheryl Sandberg, 38, a sales executive from Google who will become Facebook's chief operating officer. ''It's a more honest way to describe the arrangement than at some other places where you have someone called the C.E.O. but the founder is still running the company.''

BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. We mourn the loss of R. Palmer Baker Jr., our friend, colleague and mentor. A close advisor to D. K. Ludwig and executor of his estate, R. Palmer Baker Jr. was a major force in the creation of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research in 1971. The Ludwig Institute from its inception was designed to establish and integrate laboratory and clinical cancer research activities spanning the globe. Mr. Baker was a vital and long standing member of the Institute's Board of Directors and served as Chairman of the Board from 1995-2005, guiding the Institute as it continued to emerge into the world's largest international not-for-profit cancer research enterprise. Mr. Baker was also a Trustee of the Virginia and D.K. Ludwig Fund for Cancer Research, which, in 2006, made the largest single donation by a foundation to cancer research in the United States, establishing research centers at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Chicago and Stanford University. He was deeply admired by the entire Ludwig community for his contributions to the world of cancer research The generosity of spirit and high standards that Mr. Baker brought to all of his endeavors will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his daughter, Mary Baker Eaton, and to his grandson, Harold L. Fickett, IV. Lloyd J. Old, M.D. Chairman of the Board Edward A. McDermott, Jr. President Andrew Simpson, Ph.D. Scientific Director Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research BAKER--R. Palmer, Jr. The Board and Staff of Project Renewal mourn the loss of R. Palmer Baker, Jr., the founding chairman of our Board, our friend, and our mentor. Project Renewal was established in 1967 by the Vera Institute of Justice to offer treatment instead of arrest to homeless alcoholics, a visionary undertaking at the time. Palmer's judgement, compassion and commitment to helping homeless New Yorkers guided us through the early years of developing our programs and working through the stumbling blocks inherent in a new venture. Throughout the years, Palmer has remained a friend and a supporter whose intelligence and wise counsel were invaluable. We will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and his daughter Mary B. Eaton.

FREEDMAN--Bernard, 93, beloved husband of the late Doris, father of Steven (Lee) and Grace (Oz), brother of Norma, Sylvia and Rita, grandfather of Tom, Adam and Amos and uncle of many nieces and nephews, died on February 11, 2008. Born in Bayonne, NJ, he raised his family in West Orange from 1960. A 40-year advertising production employee of the New York Times, he retired to Lauderhill, Florida in 1995. Following his wife's death he moved to NYC to live near his daughter and her family. He served with honor in the Pacific Theater in the US Army during WWII. He was a lifelong supporter of Zionism and the State of Israel from its founding. An artist from youth, he began in retirement to paint award - winning watercolors, many now treasured by family and friends. Donations may be sent to: Brookdale Dept. of Geriatrics and Adult Development, c/o Mt. Sinai Development Office, Box 1049, One Gustave L. Levy Place, NY, NY 10029.

With ''heritage'' and ''authenticity'' the current buzzwords in fashion, it makes sense that design houses and trend spotters should seek out Brit Eaton, perhaps the closest we've got to a fashion archaeologist. He's the first domino in a chain that eventually tumbles into department stores. The discarded, often filthy garments and fabric swatches that he deals in not only hold the secrets to the shapes, dyes, weaves and details of the styles of tomorrow, they also represent a forgotten time and place. I first started seeing Eaton, a study in rugged masculinity in his head-to-toe old work clothes, about five years ago at the Rose Bowl Flea Market in Pasadena, Calif. (Like him, I also source and sell vintage clothing.) Denim and work wear have since become the stock in trade of his company, Carpe Denim, which specializes in beat-up work trousers, pre-20th-century denim, hunting jackets, boots, uniforms, athletic bags and farming sacks. His clients have included the Gap, Levi's, Ralph Lauren and many others whom he is not at liberty to disclose.

HENDERSON--Bruce F., an international banker for more than 50 years, passed away January 14, in Greenwich, CT. He was 77. Henderson held several fascinating positions in international banking across the globe. He worked in Brazil for 17 years, first with Citibank and later with Manufacturers Hanover Trust. He then proceeded to hold top-level positions with several banks, including serving as president of the Arab American Bank and president of Union Chelsea National Bank, both in New York. He spent seven years in Jakarta managing a large project with Bank Indonesia. Most recently, he was CEO of Rastriya Banijya Bank in Katmandu, Nepal. Henderson, beloved father and husband, is survived by four children, a brother and his wife.

THE NEWS Five unoccupied houses near Maltby, Wash., were destroyed or severely damaged Monday by fires that officials said were deliberately set. BEHIND THE NEWS The police and F.B.I. investigators said the fires might have been ecoterrorism: A handmade sign at the scene indicated that a nebulous group called the Earth Liberation Front was responsible, deriding the builder's claims that the houses had been built in a ''green,'' that is, environmentally sensitive, way and calling them McMansions. Local residents also opposed the luxury development in a wooded wetland; there had been earlier cases of vandalism; and the houses had sat on the market unsold for some time.
'I know I can play. But I don't think I want to.' BRETT FAVRE, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, announcing his retirement after 17 seasons in the N.F.L.

Faces of Social Entrepreneurship On the following pages you will meet four people who might broadly be defined as ''social entrepreneurs'' -- people who have sought to fill a societal need by starting their own organizations. With support from grant-giving nonprofits like Ashoka's Youth Venture and Echoing Green -- both of which provide seed financing to people with ideas for social change -- these men and women have sought to remake the world around them. ''Our generation is replacing signs and protests with individual actions,'' says Kyle Taylor, 23, an advocate for the social-entrepreneur movement who started his own mentoring organization. ''This is our civil rights movement and what will define our generation.''

LEVIN--Ed. Shaping American Design since 1950. Died February 23, 2008. Edward Levin, of Cambridge, New York, and Cedar Key, Florida, died February 23, 2008, at his home in Cedar Key, early in the morning, at age 87. Ed was born February 4, 1921 in New York City and grew up in Long Beach on Long Island. He was an artist, craftsperson, jeweler, painter, sculptor, ceramist, and inventor of machines, tools and processes to enhance creativity in jewelry-making. In 1950 Ed and his wife, Ruth Levin, founded Ed Levin Jewelry. Ed studied fine arts at Columbia University, and later at Alfred University, the New School, and the Barnes Foundation. He successfully obtained conscientious objector status during World War II. In 1948 Ed lived for the year in Buenos Aires, Argentina and studied with a Florentine master jeweler. In 1949 Ed married Ruth Perlmutter, and lived on the Upper West Side in New York City. In 1950 with his wife, he founded Ed Levin Jewelry and made jewelry on the stove top in their New York apartment. He traveled by bus throughout New England to sell his jewelry to college students. In 1953 they moved to Shaftsbury, Vermont, where Ed sold his artwork and jewelry from Ed Levin Arts Workshop, established in a building on their property. In 1964, he moved his workshop to Bennington where he opened a retail shop. In 1968, Ed married Ruth Pearl Bluestone Dale, bought a house in Cambridge, New York, and moved his wholesale business to Cambridge, as well. While Ed continued to design jewelry he also spent time in his studio at home painting, sculpting, throwing pots, and inventing tools. Ed Levin Jewelry, Inc., considered the oldest and largest hand-crafted jewelry manufacturer in the United States, is owned by the family and currently sells to hundreds of retail shops throughout the country. Ed was adamant in his beliefs and followed his own path. Life, for him, was a continuing exploration of ideas, the senses, and challenging the status quo. He actively supported peace, human rights, civil liberties, and environmental protection. Ed said, The diversity and richness of the natural world and all of the peoples who have inhabited it will always inspire both art and jewelry. The connections are not necessarily direct or obvious...Nevertheless, our present is still connected to the earth forms and ancestor creations that abound and still touch us. Ed was predeceased by his second wife, Ruth Dale Levin, and his brother, Ernest Levin. He leaves his first wife, Ruth Perlmutter Levin, his three children, Rachel Levin, Flo Levin, and Alexander Levin; and two stepsons, Paul Bluestone and Donald Bluestone. Ed will be buried in Cambridge, New York, in the spring. Contributions in Eds memory may be sent to: Allen Gilbert, ACLU Vermont, 137 Elm Street, Montpelier, VT 05602.

BALASNY - BARNES-Florence, 87, passed away peacefully on March 7th at the Crest Haven Nursing Center in Cape May Court House, NJ. She was a graduate of Wildwood High School and Ryder College. Formerly a resident of Wildwood Crest, NJ and Manhattan, NY, she was a founder of the American Ceramic Arts Society and a collector of American 19th century porcelain and pottery. Florence provided many items from her collection to the American Ceramic Arts Society, Brooklyn Museum of Art, Cincinnati Art Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Ceramic Art/NY, Newark Museum of Art, Philadelphia Museum of Art, and the Smithsonian Institution. She retired in 1986 from the Charles H. Greenthal Real Estate Firm as Vice President of commercial leasing and sales. She was predeceased by her loving husband Erik Barnes, brothers, Irving Balasny and Raymond Balasny, and sisters, Ella Darivoff and Yvette Gould. She is survived by nine of her beloved nephews and nieces. Relatives and friends are invited to attend graveside services Monday at 2pm at the Beth Kehillah Cemetery, Egg Harbor Twp., NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions in her memory may be made to Beth Judah Temple, Spencer and Pacific Avenues, Wildwood, NJ 08260. Services by Roth-Goldsteins' Memorial Chapel, Atlantic City, NJ.

THE WILD SIDE Until a few years ago, I tended to think of fossils as bones and shells -- the vestiges of animal skeletons. But all sorts of other things can leave fossils, too. Footprints are one. Feces, another. Impressions of skin and feathers. Leaves and pollen. Growth rings of trees. All of these open different windows onto the past; together, they help us construct a richer portrait of it than we could glean from skeletons by themselves. Widths of tree rings indicate rainfall, and thus, climate. Fossil leaves can show damage from the maraudings of ancient insects; analysis of leaf damage can thus illuminate the broader dynamics of ecosystems. Fossil feces (coprolites) reveal extinct diets; they can also reveal attributes of plants where actual plant fossils are missing.

Battle Company Is Out There Elizabeth Rubin's article (Feb. 24) is the best combat reporting to come out of a bewildering war since Marguerite Higgins, Homer Bigart and David Halberstam sent their dispatches from Vietnam. Her report, focused on soldiers rather than on strategy, produced an image of Afghanistan that shows its ridges and slopes are the front lines of the war on terror. Capt. Dan Kearney and his men -- along with the men and women in the sky above them -- are fighting a war that is about blood, death and uncertainty, not a war about freedom and political abstraction. THOMAS B. ALLEN

CONTRARY to popular belief, you needn't be a Vegas act to wear sequins during the day. Or be under 30, or with the band or walking the streets. And wearing shine in the a.m. need not mean you didn't make it home the night before. ''Although wouldn't that be a good thing?'' asked Alexander Wang, age 23. For spring, quite a few designers, including Mr. Wang, showed shimmering pieces in a laid-back, dressed-down manner. Dries van Noten used silver beads to trim the necklines of his fluid, color-drenched dresses. At Missoni, a muted silk skirt with oversize paillettes was paired, rather smartly, with a silk blouse; and at Balmain, Christophe Decarnin sent out an array of sequined boho-luxe pieces, including a $23,000 cardigan, casually tossed over a T-shirt like an old jean jacket.

SEATED within the white cube, silent and stylish, a look of ennui fixed on their faces, gallery assistants are a curious breed. You notice them; they don't really notice you. They are, in a way, part of the show. ''They play into the psychology of the gallery as this immaculate, encapsulated space,'' said the artist Brina Thurston. Her show, ''Dark Pump,'' which opens this week at Rivington Arms, brings the elusive gallery assistant into sharp focus. On opening night, seven of them, from galleries around the city (''Julie'' and ''Diane,'' above), will be stationed behind white desks. Ms. Thurston has asked them to dress as they would for an opening (''It's usually artfully assembled vintage,'' she explained. ''The job pays little.'') and do what they would at work (''mostly mailings''). Afterward, life-size cutouts will sit in their places, perpetuating the idea of the gallery assistant as a kind of art form.

ZELTER--Mary Gill, ''Cappy,'' a retired registered nurse and travel agent, and beloved mother of four children and 12 grandchildren, passed away on February 26, 2008. She was 86. Mary Ruth Gill was born in Tulsa, OK, on August 14, 1921. Like many during the Depression era, her family moved frequently as her father sought employment. When her mother died of pneumonia at age 39, Mrs. Zelter moved to Elmira, NY, to live with her maternal grandparents. After high school she went on to the Highland Hospital School of Nursing, where she earned certification as a Registered Nurse. She continued on to earn a Bachelor's degree in Nursing from the University of Rochester. Through the 1940s she served in a range of nursing and administrative capacities at Highland Hospital, and all her children were born at that same hospital, dear to her heart. On January 4, 1949, she married Charles Theodore Zelter of Rochester, NY, with whom she had four children and a full, active life. Mr. and Mrs. Zelter claimed as a fifth child the son of Mrs. Zelter's sister, Jane Gill Feagan, after she and her husband Kenneth Feagan passed away over two decades ago. She also was a warm and much-loved hostess, frequently entertaining at home and enjoying a vivid social life with a wide circle of friends. The children remember that at their Thanksgiving dinners, their parents regularly included others without local family of their own. She could be trusted to carry a jar of soup or a meal to a friend in need. Mr. and Mrs. Zelter lived in Rochester for over twenty years then moved to Pittsford, NY, at which time Mary became employed with the American Auto Association as a travel agent. Mrs. Zelter was herself an avid traveler, and took great delight in showing people the beauties of the world. Throughout her 50s and 60s, she could be found enthusiastically leading groups through areas as various as the Canadian Rockies and Egypt. Soon after Charles Zelter retired from the B. Forman Company in 1980, he and Mrs. Zelter began spending winters in Venice, Florida. The couple moved to Venice full time in 1995. Charles Zelter died in 2006, and Mary Zelter moved to Regal Palms, an assisted living facility in Largo, in the fall of 2007. Mary Zelter is survived by her four children, Barbara Zelter of Raleigh, North Carolina; Christine Berry of Faversham, England; Mary Frances (and Phil) Lallucci of Belleair, FL; James Zelter (and Vivian) of New York City; nephew Michael Caudell-Feagan (and Linda) of Arlington, VA; and 12 grandchildren, one of whom currently serves with the U.S. Navy in Iraq. A memorial mass in her honor will be private. Those wishing to offer donations may contribute to: The Highland Hospital Foundation in memory of Mary G. Zelter, at 1000 South Avenue, Box 40, Rochester, NY 14620.

O'CONNOR--Josephine. The Officers and Associates of The CM & F Group, Cotterell, Mitchell and Fifer, mourn the premature passing of our friend, supporter, colleague, and fellow officer Josephine O'Connor on 6 March. Josephine comported an aura of professionalism and confidence only surpassed by the reality of her high standards and remarkable competence. Her charm, grace and welcoming smile benefitted us all. Josephine's more than quarter century with The Firm was marked with contunal growth and enhanced contributions of her skills and support to the betterment of our clients, friends and collaborators. The sudden loss of her beloved Tom, her educator and umpire, dulled the edge of her joy but inspired her to greater service to CMF, and deepened affection and admiration for her daughters Chris and Cathy, their husbands and cherished children. Her enthusiastic devotion to them, including the late Dusty, was amply shown in the office by her family stories, pictures and pride. The loss of Josephine's special talents and the smiling support is great and deeply felt. Happily, the memory of her graceful and sincere support for us, her friendship and loyalty, the contentment of being so long together at William and Hudson Streets, will soften the hardness of our loss. The Firm extends its deepest sympathy to Jo's family, and all who, like us, loved her. For The Firm Richard J. J. Sullivan, Jr., President and CEO

MOVING EXPENSES, AND MORE It turns out that Kellogg could have saved a lot of money by simply paying the rent for its former chief executive, James M. Jenness. Mr. Jenness was living in Chicago in late 2004 when the Kellogg Company asked him to step in for Carlos Gutierrez, whom President Bush had chosen to be commerce secretary. The company, based in Battle Creek, Mich., agreed to cover the costs of Mr. Jenness's move and to protect him against any loss he might suffer on the purchase and resale of a home near the headquarters.

FOLLIS--Elaine. The Staff and Board of the Mary Baker Eddy Library will miss our friend, colleague, teacher, and mentor, Dr. Elaine Follis, who died on March 4. Before assuming responsibility for the Library's operations in May of 2007, Follis had been Chief Academic Officer at Principa College in Elsah, Illinois, where she held the title, Professor Emerita of Religious Studies. As the Library's chief executive, Follis supervised the Library's archival collection and its exhibits and public programs. The Library holds most all of the unpublished writings of Mary Baker Eddy, who discovered Christian Science and founded the Church of Christ, Scientist in the late 1800s. It is one of the largest archives in the world devoted to the life and work of a woman. Follis was active in the Boston non-profit community as well as a Christian Science practitioner. She received her A.B. and B.D. from Tufts University in Religion and her Ph.D. from Boston University. An accomplished scholar, she specialized in Old Testament history and culture, as well as Holocaust Studies, and was a member of the Society of Biblical Literature. A memorial service will be held at First Church of Christ, Scientist, 20 Greenleaf Street, at 11am on Saturday, March 29.

SOMMER--Susan (Suki) Thiemann, born in New York City, January 7, 1935, died at home in New York on March 4, 2008, after a lengthy illness. Ms. Sommer was the Acting Director of The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts (1999-2001) when she retired in 2001. She also was Chief of its Music Division from 1997 to 2001 and Head of its Circulating Collections from 1987 to 1997. She joined The New York Public Library in 1961. In 1969 she became head of the rare books and manuscripts section and curator of the Toscanini Memorial Archives in The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. She will also be remembered for nurturing many of today's music librarians lucky enough to have taken the famous course in music librarianship she taught for years at Columbia University. Suki was a product of the Greenwich, CT, public schools and was graduated magna cum laude from Smith College in 1956. After receiving a masters degree in musicology at Columbia and studying in Florence on a Fulbright scholarship, she gained a second masters at Columbia, in library service, and became a luminary in her chosen field of music librarianship. She served a term as president of the Music Library Association and excelled as the editor-in-chief of its journal, Notes, from 1982 to 1987, after years of writing and editing book and music reviews. She was awarded an honorary membership of the Association in 1994. She was active in the International Association of Music Libraries and edited that organization's journal as well, from 1992 to 2000 One week before her death, she traveled to Newport, RI, for the annual meeting of MLA, where she conversed with some 100 of her closest friends and admirers. She enjoyed a happy 38-year marriage to Robert C. Sommer, who died in January 2007. She is survived by her brother, Nicholas Thiemann, of Westport, CT, his wife Helen Clark Thiemann and her nephew, Clark Thiemann. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Music Library Association, the New York Public Library Music Division, and the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, whose Hospice Care program allowed her to live her final months at home in comfort and with dignity. A memorial service is in the planning stages. SOMMER--Susan T. The staff of The Music Division of The New York Public Library for The Performing Arts mourns the passing of our beloved colleague.

JABLON--Joseph, born in Warsaw, Poland in 1913, came to America at the age of six. Was a self made businessman, successful paint manufacturer. Died at age 95. Devoted husband of the late Mary Jablon, beloved father of Barbara Jurist. Cherished grandfather of Suzy JuristO'Shea and Eileen Prince. Worshipped great-grandfather of Alex and John O'Shea and Liam Prince. A gentleman and great family man who will be missed by all who were lucky to know him.

BEIL--Sheldon. My Shelly the last words you said to me were ''I love you''. My brother, my friend, my mentor, my strength, my guiding light. I don't know what I am going to do without you. The world is a much poorer place now that your gone. You will always be alive in my heart. Stephen Schwartz BEIL--Sheldon. Loving husband of Ruthie, father of Merrie, grandfather of Stacey, great-grandfather of Justin and stepfather of David, died March 7, 2008. He knew how to live life to the fullest. He was a kind, warmhearted man who had a passion for helping people. He always had a joke to tell. You are the love of my life, my soul mate. You taught me so much in life and what true love is. Everyday you would say, ''Did I tell you I love you today?'' I miss you so much. I love you so much in the whole wide world. Ruthie BEIL--Sheldon L. There was only one Shelly Beil. Shelly was the most loving uncle, valued business partner and cherished friend. We will miss his humor and love forever. Our heartfelt sympathy and love goes out to Ruthie, Merrie, Stacey, Justin and David. Judi and Barry, Elizabeth and Jonathan, and Jeffrey BEIL--Sheldon. With a heavy heart we say goodbye to our dear friend. We will miss his zest for life and will remember him always. Roseann and Irwin

Warmongering shows no signs of abating, at least on the fashion front. Yohji Yamamoto's collection of weathered military combos told the story of a soldier's homecoming; John Galliano's show (above) opened with the ominous thrum of helicopters, followed by a troop of soldiers decked out in fatigues, aggressive Mohawks, nylon flight jackets, Castro-like beards and Black Panther get-ups. The 25-year-old single-name stylist Molaroid has used guns as props in his magazine spreads starring Muslim and Jewish kids; he recently launched a glossy in England called War!, which he says was born out of ''a desire to address the climate of conservatism and institutional fear of the more mainstream fashion and news media.'' Add to that a spate of London club nights with names like ''We're All Going to Die'' and ''Nuke Them All,'' and you get the picture: the world may be coming to an end, so we might as well dance. DARYOUSH HAJ-NAJAFI

SEITZ--Frederick. Wilson College wishes to acknowledge its deep sense of loss at the death of Frederick Seitz, President Emeritus of Rockefeller University, and also our gratitude for his generosity and support over many years. This small women's college in Pennsylvania was the alma mater of Elizabeth Marshall Seitz '32, his wife of more than 50 years. Because of that fortunate association, Dr. Seitz maintained a benevolent interest in the sciences at Wilson. In 1996, he honored the College by allowing us to confer an honorary degree upon him. Most recently, Dr. Seitz was serving on the advisory board of Wilson's Institute for Women and Girls in Math, Science and Technology. We will miss him, and want to express our condolences to his family, friends and colleagues. Dr. Lorna Duphiney Edmundson, President Wilson College

YOUTH IS RELATIVE Having retired as chief executive of U.S. Bancorp last year at 63, Jerry A. Grundhofer would not be expected to lead a youth movement in corporate boardrooms. But if he is elected as a director of Lehman Brothers Holdings next month, he will pull down the average age of the board. With two 80-year-olds, Henry Kaufman and John D. Macomber, standing for re-election, Lehman has what may be among the grayest -- and most entrenched -- sets of directors in corporate America. On average, they are 68 and have held their seats for almost a dozen years.

SHERMAN--Devorah E., beloved wife of Saul S. Sherman, passed away on March 3, 2008 at the age of 88. Mrs. Sherman is best known for her philanthropic, political and artistic endeavors in the city of Chicago. Over the years, Mrs. Sherman served on numerous boards from the Chicago Youth Centers, to Columbia College, to Open Hand. Highlights of Mrs. Sherman's accomplishments include bringing Rev. Martin Luther King and Constance Motley to Chicago to speak, opening one of the first modern art galleries in the city, as well as being one of the founding donors to Brandeis University. In 1965, Mrs. Sherman was a recipient of the Thurgood Marshall Award for her work with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and a State of Illinois Governor's citation for her steadfast service to the youth of Illinois. She was a unique woman to have known and her generosity and kindness to the world will be missed. She is survived by her husband, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

These Calvin Klein frames, like Yoko Ono's signature Porsche wraparounds, resemble safety glasses, and that's exactly the appeal. The future may not be bright. You may want to wear these shades. de RHAM--Elizabeth (nee Evarts), born October 6, 1926 in New York City, died February 26, 2008 after an almost two-year battle with ALS. She was 81. Daughter of Katharine Avery Morgan Evarts and Jeremiah Maxwell Evarts, she was a descendent of Edwin D. Morgan, Civil War Governor of New York, and William Maxwell Evarts, US Senator from New York and defender of President Andrew Johnson at his impeachment trial. Wiz grew up in Windsor, VT, before moving to New York City in 1935. She graduated from the Brearley School in 1944. She attended Smith College for one year before marrying Marine second lieutenant Casimir de Rham, Jr. in June 1945. She is survived by her husband, four children Lizzie, Harry, Rufus and Jerry; Jerrys wife, Amy; and seven grandchildren Eruch, Elizabeth, Rufus, Daniel, Anna, Rose and Georgiana. A talented artist in many mediums, Wiz sketched and painted scenes remembered from her travels and experiences. A favorite subject was Cobble Hill Farm in Kent, CT where her beloved mother moved the family in 1941. In 1973, Wiz and Casie bought land in Webster, NH and built, with Casies help and that of their sons, the house Wiz designed, creating a place she had described in an early poem ''where flowers embroider forgotten lanes under suns and moons and quiet rains.'' Wiz recently donated 55 acres of that land to the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests to form ''The little brook Sanctuary'', extending in perpetuity a natural refuge for the animals and natural settings she loved. Wiz leaves her sisters Mary Steele and Kate Merck and her brother Jasper Evarts. Her older brother, Maxwell Evarts, prede ceased her. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Wiz's memory may be made to: Compassionate Care ALS, P.O. Box 1052, West Falmouth, MA 02574 or Chilton House c/o VNA Care Network & Hospice, 175 Highland Avenue, Needham, MA 02494. Services will be held at Christ Church, Cambridge at 3:00 pm on March 15, 2008.

GETTING THERE Visas are required of all American citizens to enter Vietnam and can be ordered by mail or in person at the Vietnamese Embassy in Washington (1233 20th Street NW, Suite 400; 202-861-0737 or 202-861-0694; www.vietnamembassy-usa.org). A one-month single-entry visa costs $65, or $85 for expedited service. Vietnamese embassies in Asia work faster and cheaper, and many tourist hotels in Siem Reap, Cambodia, secure visas in a day or two for about $75.

PHOTOGRAPHING THE DEVAS NEAR THE BIG BUDDHA, LANTAU ISLAND, SEPT. 23, 2007 Nicholas Zogopoulos, 38, an eyewear designer from Sydney, Australia. ''Minutes before that shot, that whole platform was covered with tourists. So it was quite hard to get a shot where it looks like you've just discovered it all by yourself. I was actually quite happy that it started raining: most of the tourists decided to abandon the Big Buddha and leave, and the statues started glistening. I was playing with the exposure compensation function, trying to get a silhouette, and I was trying to create motion by changing the shutter speed, slowing it down so you could see the rain. I haven't showed my photographs in an exhibition or anything like that. I show them to my friends, and now I'm starting to put them in Facebook.'' As told to Seth Kugel

What do we get out of looking at anonymous snapshots? Snapshots — small prints with basic compositions, smiling faces and commonplace subject matter — have not traditionally interested professional photographers and art historians. But in recent years scholars have started taking photographs much more seriously, not only as revealing artifacts of American society but also as works of art in themselves.

A brand-new 26-gate, $750 million terminal — designed from the ground up to serve a post-9/11 world and 44,000 JetBlue Airways passengers daily by year’s end — would be a high-profile project anywhere else. But at the corner of Kennedy International Airport where Eero Saarinen’s Trans World Airlines Flight Center has captured the imagination of generations of travelers, JetBlue’s enormous new terminal has a remarkably low profile, by necessity and design.As a result, travelers long accustomed to JetBlue’s makeshift accommodations at Kennedy may not be aware that all that construction behind the gull-winged T.W.A. terminal is supposed to yield an actual, usable Terminal 5 in six months.

In the 20 years since the federal death penalty statute was revived, no federal juries have been more reluctant to sentence federal defendants to death than those in New York, writes Alan Feuer. According to records compiled by the Federal Death Penalty Resource Counsel Project, which coordinates the defense of capital punishment cases, federal prosecutors in New York State have asked juries to impose death sentences 19 times since 1988. In only one case did a jury rule for execution.

The other day I realized how much the Fed's attempts to resolve the financial mess resemble sterilized foreign exchange intervention. That set me thinking about other parallels -- and I realized how much the stories now being told about "systemic margin calls" and all that resemble the stories we all tried to tell about the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98. Leverage, balance sheet effects, self-reinforcing financial collapse -- the details are different, but there are some clear common themes.

My friend Deanna and I were driving back from Asbury Park after seeing the New York Dolls at the Stone Pony - she's a young rock 'n' roll photographer and was working that night; I, somewhat older, was having an acid flashback to 1973 - and we started coming up with nominations for the most overrated band. She chose the Ramones, and I went with the Doors (certainly not the Dolls). The conversation turned to the most overrated book, and after first saying, "Everything I read in high school," she settled, decisively, on "The Catcher in the Rye." I wavered between "Women in Love" (unevenly written, philosophically confused) and the Bible (unevenly written, philosophically confused).

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a penalty proposed by the Federal Aviation Administration against Southwest Airlines for safety related violations misidentified the state represented by the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, Representative James L. Oberstar, who has asked the Transportation Department’s inspector general to investigate. He is a Democrat from Minnesota, not Michigan. The article also misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for the F.A.A.. She is Diane Spitaliere, not Spitalieri.

An article on Dec. 25, 2007, about Queen Elizabeth’s use of YouTube to broadcast her Christmas address misidentified the speech in which she used the phrase “annus horribilis” to describe a troubled period for the royal family. It was a speech at the Guildhall in November 1992, not her Christmas message that year. This correction was delayed because several e-mail messages from a reader went astray at The Times.

An article last Monday about reactions by parishioners at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to a New Yorker essay by Honor Moore revealing that her father, Paul Moore Jr., the late Episcopal bishop of New York, had a hidden homosexual life referred imprecisely to the timing of her realization that he had had gay relationships. The Norwegian sprinter Thor Hushovd won the Paris-Nice prologue in Amilly, France, racing along with 159 other riders despite threats of sanctions from the International Cycling Union.Hushovd, of the Crédit Agricole team, completed the 2.9-mile prologue around Amilly in 5 minutes 28 seconds. He was four seconds faster than Markel Irizar of Spain and five seconds ahead of Stefan Schumacher of Germany.Pat McQuaid, the president of the cycling federation, had urged riders to boycott the season’s first major stage race, calling it “illegal” because the race owner — the Amaury Sport Organization — was holding it under French laws and outside U.C.I. rules.McQuaid had threatened teams with six-month suspensions, fines of up to $9,700 and bans from the track world championships later this month, which would affect cyclists trying to qualify for the Beijing Olympics.The Paris-Nice race finishes March 16, with Monday’s first stage taking the pack on a mostly flat 114.4-mile route from Amilly to Nevers.

Sean O’Hair took advantage of a stunning collapse by Stewart Cink on Sunday to win the PODS Championship in Palm Harbor, Fla., closing with a two-under-par 69 to energize his PGA Tour career and earn a trip to the Masters.O’Hair, who had not won since 2005, his rookie season, made a 30-foot birdie and two par putts that were equally important on the back nine, building such a margin that he could afford a bogey on the last hole for a two-shot victory.“This is not going to hurt my confidence,” said O’Hair, who finished the tournament at four-under 280. “I’m looking forward to the rest of the year.” Cink had a four-shot lead after two holes Sunday, still had control on the back nine, then dropped four shots in a four-hole stretch along the back nine of the Copperhead Course at Innisbrook. Cink lost the outright lead when his tee shot rolled up against a tree on the par-5 14th, leading to bogey. The only consolation was making a 50-foot birdie on the 17th hole, allowing him to join a six-way tie for second.

Bernhard Langer outlasted Jay Haas, the defending champion, in the Toshiba Classic, birdieing the final hole of regulation to force a playoff and winning with a birdie on the seventh extra hole of the Champions Tour event in Newport Beach, Calif. The defending Iditarod champion, Lance Mackey, beat the four-time champion Jeff King out of the checkpoint at Unalakleet, Alaska, Sunday night, beginning the last leg of the 1,100-mile race.King was first to reach Unalakleet, arriving with all 16 dogs at about 2 p.m., an hour and a half ahead of Mackey, from Fairbanks. But Mackey was first out of Unalakleet, with a population of 750, leaving at 6:17 p.m., followed 44 minutes later by King.

Andrew Motion, the British poet laureate, is visiting the past again. Fresh from his memoir “In the Blood” (David R. Godine), he has written a poem for Harry Patch, at 109 the oldest surviving veteran to fight as a Tommy in the trenches of World War I. Composed under a commission from the BBC program “Inside Out West,” the five-section work explores different stages of Mr. Patch’s life, the BBC reported. Prince Charles described Mr. Patch as epitomizing “the courage, long-sufferingness and tenacity of his generation.” The poem moves from its subject’s childhood home to the battlefields of the Western Front, where he was wounded and, in its final act, to a nursing home in Wells, England, where he lives. Mr. Motion said of the poem, “It is by some distance the most interesting of these sorts of commissions that I’ve done.” Last month Mr. Patch attended a special event to hear the poem recited for the first time. He told Mr. Motion: “It’s a great honor to have a poem written for me by you. That’s all I can say.”.

Vulcan, a small Canadian prairie town, is bidding to be the host of the world premiere of the next “Star Trek” movie, Agence France-Presse reported. Situated among the oil wells, wheat fields and cow pastures of Alberta, the community is already home to a three-day annual “Star Trek” convention. Dayna Dickens, a spokeswoman for Vulcan, said: “Because the film’s story line is based on a young Mr. Spock and a young Captain Kirk in their early days at Starfleet and because we think of Mr. Spock as our native son, it would be a neat tie-in to bring Spock home for the movie launch. I mean, Vulcan is his birthplace.” Actually, a surveyor named the railroad stop in 1910 for Vulcan, the Roman god of fire. Ms. Dickens said the town had sent a proposal in September to the executive producers of the film, tentatively titled “Star Trek Zero,” and was told last month they were considering it, she said. Ms. Dickens noted that Vulcan has “logistical issues,” including no movie theater. But she said, noting that movies are regularly screened in the school gymnasium, “we can work around them.”.

Curators at Britain’s National Portrait Gallery, researching an exhibition that is to open on Thursday, rediscovered a painting of an 18th-century female scholar who was a member of the Bluestocking group of intellectuals who promoted the advancement of women, the BBC reported. The oil portrait, above, regarded as a major work, was created between 1735 and 1741 by John Fayram and depicts Elizabeth Carter as Minerva, goddess of wisdom and warfare. Carter was known for her translation of the Stoic philosopher Epictetus, but her friend Samuel Johnson said that besides her talent for translation, she could also make a pudding, work a handkerchief and compose a poem. The curators knew of the existence of the painting from a poem published in 1741 and a photograph sent to the gallery in the 1940s and found it in a private collection. Never previously on public display, it will be seen in “Brilliant Women: 18th-Century Bluestockings,” running until June 15.

The Chinese actress Tang Wei, right, has been blacklisted in China because of her role in Ang Lee’s erotic “Lust, Caution,” a drama that unfolds during Japan’s occupation of Shanghai in the 1940s, Agence France-Presse reported, citing The United Evening News of Taiwan. The newspaper said Chinese print and electronic news media were told on Friday “to immediately remove” any works and commercials featuring Ms. Tang, but it was not clear how long the ban would continue. The newspaper report, citing unnamed sources, said “Lust, Caution” was regarded as “beautifying” those who collaborated with Japan. In the film, Ms. Tang portrays a member of the Chinese resistance who is assigned to assassinate a collaborator, but she changes her mind at the last minute. In December, her performance won her honors as best new performer in Taiwan’s Golden Horse Awards, considered the Chinese-language Oscars. The report said that Mr. Lee, born in Taiwan and the winner of an Academy Award for his direction of “Brokeback Mountain” (2005), was not blacklisted; he is an artistic adviser to the summer Olympics this year in Beijing.

Janet Jackson, whose new album, “Discipline” (Island Def Jam), below left, was No. 1 on the Billboard chart last week, isn’t resting on that laurel. She is planning a world tour, beginning in the United States in mid-September, Billboard.com reported. “We’re talking about America first, but I think we’re going all over,” she said. “I think I’m going to go back to Australia, back to Africa, obviously go to Asia, go to Europe for sure.” Seven years after her last tour, she said, she is looking forward to being onstage. “I love being able to see the sea of faces, to have that connection, to feel that love,” she said. ... Paula Abdul is at work on her first new album since “Head Over Heels” in 1995, Billboard.com also reported. Still untitled, it will include remixes of her best-known hits, as well as new songs. ... The Police will hold an open-air concert on June 2o at Stormont, the Parliament building in Belfast, Northern Ireland, the BBC reported. The performance is being billed as their last performance in Ireland. First Minister Ian Paisley called the concert “a fantastic coup” for Northern Ireland. Others who have performed at Stormont, where Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said he hoped 35,000 fans could be accommodated, are Luciano Pavarotti, Elton John, Rod Stewart and the Eagles.

A movie with a big-number title, “10,000 BC,” brought in a big-number weekend gross — $35.7 million — according to figures compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers. The estimated North American gross for the film (from Warner Brothers), about early tribesmen on a rescue mission, earned it a No. 1 ranking in its debut weekend and far outstripped the $14 million earned by another new film, “College Road Trip,” a Disney comedy starring Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symoné as a domineering police chief and his teenage daughter on a journey to her interview at Georgetown University. Third place went to the thriller “Vantage Point” (Columbia Pictures) with $7.5 million in its third week. The No. 4 ranking and $5.75 million went to another holdover, the raunchy basketball comedy “Semi-Pro” (New Line), the previous weekend’s No. 1 film. Just behind, with $5.71 million in its debut, was “The Bank Job” (Lionsgate), a caper movie starring Jason Statham.

The revelation that Gov. Eliot Spitzer was a client of a high-end prostitution ring broken up last week by federal authorities has attracted international attention, threatening to end his career and throwing the political world of New York State into chaos. The New York Times, which broke the story on its Web site on Monday afternoon, has three front-page articles explaining the situation.In a main overview, Danny Hakim and William K. Rashbaum review the details of the federal investigation, Mr. Spitzer’s terse apology and the shock in Albany. In addition, Mr. Rashbaum explains that the federal inquiry into the prostitution ring began with a routine tax investigation after Mr. Spitzer’s bank noticed a series of unusual transactions. Michael Powell and Mike McIntire explore the dizzying rise and fall of Mr. Spitzer’s career, an arc that includes a sterling educational pedigree and eight years as a crusading state attorney general.
Updated, 10:13 a.m. | The Spitzer watch lasted all night.

A Port Authority police officer testified in the trial of three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell on Tuesday morning, recalling the errant round that struck the AirTrain platform near 94th Avenue on Nov. 25, 2006, as officers opened fire with 50 shots at Mr. Bell’s car on the street below in Queens. The damage to the AirTrain station was recorded on video and played on news stations repeatedly after the shooting, and that particular bullet became emblematic of the perception that the shooting was wild and chaotic.John Cea, the police officer, was standing patrol with a partner on the platform when the calm of the early morning was shattered shortly after 4 a.m., he testified.

I've mentioned this before, but anyone trying to understand what the Fed's up to should look at the 2004 paper Ben Bernanke co-authored on "Monetary Policy Alternatives at the Zero Bound". One alternative was "quantitative easing" -- basically forcing extra reserves on banks, whether they want them or not, which is what the Fed did in the first wave of panic. Another is "changing the composition of the central bank's balance sheet", that is, buying assets other than the usual T-bills.

They caught Spitzer with a wire, recording him soliciting a prostitute. And I'm thinking holy cow! We can't get bin Laden but by God, we got Spitzer. We got Spitzer!

Aired Monday night on NBC: Past couple of days -- you've all heard about this -- Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain have all claimed that they are the person who should answer the phone at the White House if it rings at 3 a.m., but most Americans think the White House should just get a receptionist.

Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters. Kicked to the Curb with a High Wooden WedgeNews broke yesterday afternoon that Chloé had ousted designer Paulo Melim Andersson, formerly of Marni, after a mere three seasons. Seems the market couldn't bear another pricey line of "interesting," clown-colored sack dresses, when Vera Wang had already gotten prime position on Marni's asymmetrical coattails. So Chloé hired successful previous designer Phoebe Philo's lieutenant, Hannah MacGibbon. WWD reports today that she had been offered the job before, but refused and stuck around as a consultant. Expect the brand to return to its Marcia Brady-style roots by next season.
Liz O. Baylen

There are pasta dishes of the desperate cook, the one who has been too busy to shop or too busy to think, or who must put dinner on the table in 20 minutes. I love those kinds of recipes. This is one of them, taught to me a decade ago or so by Arthur Schwartz, who knows as much about Italian food as any native New Yorker has a right to.

A United States Air Force jet plane has mistakenly dropped an anti-missile device over the British countryside, setting off a hunt for a device that could be dangerous to civilians who may stumble across it.

Today, T Online reveals an another intriguing fashion collaboration - the pairing of a supermodel, Mariacarla Boscono, and a supermusician, Sean Lennon. In "The Stranger," a Sean Lennon and The Pyramids' score provides the backdrop for the Italian catwalker's acting foray - a delicate portrait of three lives, intertwined in identity and intimacy. The director, Michele Civetta is no stranger to beautiful faces and tunes. The beau of Asia Argento, Civetta co-wrote (with Lennon) "Friendly Fire," a 52-minute surreal fantasy piece set to Lennon's album of the same name. The film featured Argento, Devon Aoki and Bijou Phillips. Now, dim the lights and click the player below.

The New York Public Library's venerable lion-guarded building on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street is to be renamed for the Wall Street financier Stephen A. Schwarzman, who has agreed to jump-start a $1 billion expansion of the library system with a guaranteed $100 million of his own.

Societe Generale, seeking to restore its status as a top-tier bank after a massive trading scandal, said Tuesday it had raised 5.5 billion euros ($8.44 billion) in new capital through a share offering.

John J. Mack stood before his board and shareholders at Morgan Stanley's 2007 annual meeting and struck an aggressive tone. Coming off a year of record profits fueled by using the firm's capital to take some highly lucrative risks - particularly by diving deeply into subprime mortgages, leveraged loans and complex derivatives - Mr. Mack had much to celebrate.

The Air France-KLM Group won approval Monday from its board to make a binding bid for the Italian state-controlled carrier Alitalia.
Bank of America plans to press ahead with its $4 billion takeover of Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender under F.B.I. investigation for possible securities fraud.
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has agreed to trade its 16.3 percent stake in the White Mountains Insurance Group for two subsidiaries and $751 million.

Dow Jones & Company, a unit of global media conglomerate News Corporation, said Monday it acquired Betten Financial News, a Dutch-language news service covering the corporate sector in the Netherlands.
Citigroup, the banking giant, moved Monday to shore up six of its hedge funds pressured by a tightening in the municipal bond market, the newest problem to entangle the struggling company.
The computer storage provider Iomega said Monday it had received an unsolicited acquisition offer from a rival, EMC for $178.1 million but said the offer was not superior to a share purchase deal.
Lazard said on Monday that its chairman and chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein, received a salary of $4.8 million in 2007.

It's officially playoff time in college hockey and 12 of the 59 Division I teams are already out of the NCAA Tournament picture after losing their first-round series over the weekend. Up for grabs for the remaining 47 teams are six conference auto bids and 10 at-large spots in the tourney. For a look at the conference playoff brackets go here.

Lawyers for the former St. Louis Rams player Willie Gary and three fans plan to withdraw a lawsuit that accuses the Patriots of cheating in the 2002 Super Bowl. The plaintiffs’ lawyers say they sued last month to secure sworn testimony from the former Patriots employee Matt Walsh, who might have taped a walk-through practice by the Rams before New England’s Super Bowl victory. But the lawyers call it an “exercise in futility” because they suspect Walsh would exercise his constitutional right against self-incrimination.

Nome, Alaska, prepared for the conclusion of the 1,100-mile Iditarod. The winner was scheduled to arrive late Tuesday or early Wednesday, and it remained a two-man race between the last two to win the Iditarod — Lance Mackey of Fairbanks and the four-time champion Jeff King of Denali Park — who were running a tight race on the last leg.

Tammy Thomas, a former Olympic cyclist charged with lying to a federal grand jury about performance-enhancing drug use, accused federal prosecutors of foul play by including “unnecessarily graphic details” of her medical records. She has asked a judge to throw out the case. Prosecutors included information on beard growth and voice changes in court filings last week. Thomas said those descriptions were meant to taint the jury pool.
Mr. Biegenwald was known as the Thrill Killer and was convicted of killing five people, including three young women.

The Marks & Spencer Group’s chief executive, Stuart Rose, left, will become the executive chairman of the company, the largest clothing retailer in Britain, starting June 1, when the current chief, Terry Burns, leaves, the company said. Mr. Rose will remain the chief executive as well, the company said. Ian Dyson will become finance and operations director, taking on responsibility for retailing and human resources, alongside his current responsibilities handling finance, information technology, logistics, property and store development, the company said.

Microsoft cut the prices of its Xbox 360 video game console in Europe by up to 28 percent to try to bolster sales in a major battleground in the fast-growing industry. The 80-euro decrease results in cuts of 18 percent to 28 percent across the three Xbox 360 models, bringing the cheapest Arcade version to 200 euros ($307.31) and the high-end Elite to 370 euros ($568.53). Price reductions in Britain range between £20 ($40.19) and £50.

The European Union began an investigation into United States laws on Internet gambling after European betting companies complained that the laws were infringing world trade rules. The investigation could lead the European Union to file a complaint at the World Trade Organization. Internet gambling is estimated to be a $15.5 billion business worldwide. “The U.S. has the right to address legitimate public policy concerns relating to Internet gambling, but discrimination against E.U. companies cannot be part of the policy mix,” the European Union trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, said. He said he hoped the issue could be resolved amicably. European companies say a United States ban that forced them out of the American market discriminates against them in violation of W.T.O. rules, while permitting gambling by domestic companies.

Nestlé, the food company, will open a Swiss research center that will develop new chocolate products to meet anticipated growth in demand for luxury and premium confections. The center will employ 30 chocolatiers and will open in the first half of next year at the candy maker’s factory in the Swiss town of Broc, Roland Decorvet, head of Nestlé Switzerland, said at a news conference. Nestlé will invest 20 million Swiss francs ($19.6 million) in the project.

Steel Partners, a hedge fund based in the United States, said it would seek a one-third stake in Sapporo Holdings, the Japanese beer maker, ending its push for a majority stake, and was willing to pay 6 percent more to get it. The revised terms, which would cost Steel Partners about 50.5 billion yen ($496 million), would raise its holding from just below 19 percent. The fund said in a statement it was willing to offer 875 yen a share for 33.3 percent of Sapporo, up from an offer in February last year of 825 yen a share for two-thirds of the brewer; it said it might offer more.

Autogrill, the manager of airport restaurants, agreed to buy a BAA unit and the shares it does not own in Aldeasa, the Spanish-based airport retailer, for $1.5 billion, becoming the world’s largest owner of duty-free stores. Autogrill, based in Rozzano, Italy, will pay £546.6 million ($1.1 billion) to purchase World Duty Free Europe from BAA, which is part of Ferrovial of Spain. Autogrill will also acquire the Imperial Tobacco Group’s 49.95 percent stake in Aldeasa for 275 million euros ($423 million). The takeovers will increase Autogrill’s annual revenue by about 1 billion euros, to 6 billion euros. BAA, under fire from airlines and travelers for worsening delays at London’s Heathrow, will use the sale proceeds to reduce £4.1 billion of debt.
The bank will inject $1 billion across six highly leveraged municipal bond funds with $15 billion in assets, which were sold under the names ASTA and MAT.

TEAM In Argentina, Arsenal played the final 45 minutes with only nine men, but managed to snatch a 3-3 tie with last-place Gimnasia when goalkeeper Mario Cuenca scored on a penalty kick in the final minute. Arsenal’s Darío Espínola and Aníbal Matellán had been ejected in the first half.

Ernie Els surprised the tournament host Arnold Palmer by withdrawing from the 30th annual Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill Club and Lodge in Orlando, Fla. The tournament — which features the return to play of the top two golfers in the world, Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson — had received an e-mail message over the weekend from Els’s management group that Els, ranked No. 3, might withdraw.

A day after Tony Stewart assailed Goodyear for the tires it provided at Atlanta Motor Speedway, three other drivers echoed his complaints — but without the same venom. “I think he went a little overboard,” the four-time series champion Jeff Gordon said. “He kind of made it personal.” Gordon, Greg Biffle and Ryan Newman all tested tires for Goodyear at the newly paved Darlington Raceway on Monday, and all agreed the rubber at Atlanta was not favorable for driving conditions. Goodyear officials participating in Monday’s test refused to comment, and the garage was closed to the news media.

In a settlement that ends a civil lawsuit in federal court, the University of Michigan has agreed to nearly quadruple the number of seats accessible to persons with wheelchairs in its football stadium. There were 88 such seats in Michigan Stadium last season; by 2010, the number will increase to 329 in the main seating bowl along with an equal number of companion seats for fans accompanying disabled persons.

Trent Green, who ended last season on injured reserve after his second concussion in 13 months, agreed to terms Monday on a three-year contract with the St. Louis Rams. In his second stint with the Rams, Green will be the backup to Marc Bulger. He was supposed to be the starter in 1999 before a preseason knee surgery paved the way for Kurt Warner, who led the Rams to their first Super Bowl victory. Green, who replaces Gus Frerotte as Bulger’s backup, was released by the Dolphins last month.
Wedged between an outdoor world championship and a particularly high-profile Olympics in Beijing, the indoor meet that ended here Sunday was for connoisseurs only.

The eight-time Olympic field-hockey champion India will not be at the Beijing Games, the first time in 80 years it failed to qualify for the competition. India’s hopes of making the Olympics ended Sunday with a 2-0 loss to Britain in the final of a qualifying event in Chile, prompting criticism from former players.
The president of the European Central Bank criticized the increasing volatility of the currency markets, which have sent the dollar to record lows against the euro.

The insurer’s $2.2 billion bid was a move aimed at simplifying the company’s ownership structure.

A traveling exhibit attempts to show that Turkey is a constantly changing kaleidoscope of different cultures, a view that stands in opposition to what the Turkish state says.
Midsize companies hope to hold business travel spending at current levels.

Daniel Walker Howe, a professor emeritus at University of California, Los Angeles, has won the third annual New-York Historical Society American History Book Prize for “What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America, 1815-1848” (Oxford University). The award, which carries a $50,000 prize, will be presented on April 4, when Mr. Howe will also be named American historian laureate.... Francine Prose, having finished her one-year term, has re-upped for another as president of the American center of PEN, the international writers organization, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Prose runs unopposed in a vote to be held this week.

Crosby, Stills & Nash; Mavis Staples, above; the experimental Brooklyn rockers Battles and Black Dice; DanceBrazil; and the Mexican pop singer Julieta Venegas will be among the performers at Central Park SummerStage this year, the City Parks Foundation has announced. Crosby, Stills & Nash will play on July 29 in one of the six paid benefit concerts during this 23rd SummerStage season. The other performances, along with the Afro-funk scion Seun Kuti and the vintage-soul revivalists Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings, are free, beginning with Ms. Staples’s concert on June 13. The complete lineup will be announced in April.
“American Idol” seems to have settled into the ruts dug by previous years.

London’s Olivier Awards proved a triumph for the West End production of the musical “Hairspray,” which won best new musical as well as the awards for best actor in a musical for Michael Ball, above right; best actress, Leanne Jones, above left; and best supporting actress, Tracie Bennett. Kristin Scott Thomas won best actress in a play for her role in “The Seagull,” and Chiwetel Ejiofor was named best actor for the title role in “Othello.” The latest production of George Bernard Shaw’s “Saint Joan” won for best revival, and Rory Kinnear was best supporting actor in a play for his performance in “The Man of Mode.” “The Magic Flute” was named best musical revival, and Simon McBurney’s production of “A Disappearing Number” was named best new play. Rupert Goold won the best director award for his production of “Macbeth,” which is now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Andrew Lloyd Webber was honored for lifetime achievement.

HBO, the Weinstein Company and the BBC have announced a partnership to create a television series from Alexander McCall Smith’s “The No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency” books. A two-hour pilot was filmed on location in Botswana, directed by Anthony Minghella, and 13 one-hour episodes will begin filming this summer. Jill Scott plays Precious Ramotswe, the proprietor of the only female-owned detective agency in Botswana; Anika Noni Rose plays her secretary, Grace Makutsi; and Lucian Msamati is Ramotswe’s devoted suitor, J. L. B. Matekoni.

Heath Ledger’s will left nothing to his former girlfriend and their 2-year-old daughter because it was filed in Australia in 2003 and never updated after they became part of his life, The Associated Press reported. A copy of the will, filed in Manhattan Surrogate’s Court, shows that Mr. Ledger, a native of Australia, left everything to his parents and three sisters. The will offers no hint at the size of the estate, but papers filed with it value the actor’s New York City assets at $145,000, including $100,000 in miscellaneous bank accounts. Mr. Ledger’s father has said the family would provide for the actor’s former girlfriend, the actress Michelle Williams, and their daughter, Matilda Rose.

An exhibition at the Vienna State Opera house that opened on Monday details how its Jewish employees were purged under Nazi rule, Reuters reported. Few of the 92 who lost their jobs and survived the war were reinstated. The exhibition is part of a national commemoration of Austria’s willing acceptance of annexation by Hitler’s Germany, whose forces took control on March 12, 1938. “The Opera is one of the institutions ready to face up to its past even if it was painful at times,” the Austrian chancellor, Alfred Gusenbauer, said in opening the exhibition. “Such institutions in Austria in 2008 are sadly still the exception.” The anniversary has prompted a wave of reflection, with special television programs and an appeal by the Roman Catholic Church to learn the lessons of the past. A candlelight vigil will take place on Wednesday, the anniversary, at the city’s Heldenplatz (Heroes’ Square), where jubilant Austrians gathered to greet Hitler days after the annexation, and both houses of Parliament will hold a special joint session on Wednesday morning to mark the anniversary.

The British government is trying to prevent a former MI5 member from publishing a book on the inner workings of the secret service, The Daily Telegraph in London reported. The 300-page manuscript is said to reveal some successes, failures and recruiting techniques of the covert organization. The author reportedly penetrated the Irish Republican Army and organized gangs and recruited agents to infiltrate jihadist groups plotting terror attacks in Britain. Legal proceedings, to be held in secret, are expected to begin at the High Court in London this week before a senior judge, who will rule on whether publication would breach national security. The controversy is reminiscent of the “Spycatcher” scandal of 1987, when the government unsuccessfully tried to prevent Peter Wright, another former MI5 officer, from publishing details of his work to uncover a traitor within the security service. Attempts to ban “Spycatcher” failed, and the book went on to sell more than two million copies.

“Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give” vaulted ABC to first place for Sunday night, according to Nielsen. “Extreme Makeover” was the most-watched program with 12.4 million viewers, and the second week of “Oprah’s Big Give” averaged 11.8 million, down 3.7 million from the week before, Nielsen estimates. Helped by an audience of 11.6 million for “60 Minutes,” CBS finished second for the night in total viewers but finished in fourth place in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. A two-hour “100 Most Outrageous Moments of All Time” on NBC added viewers every half-hour, peaking with 10.6 million viewers at 8:30. But a “Law & Order” repeat at 9 garnered just under seven million viewers for the hour. “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” delivered 8.5 million at 10. On Fox, the animated comedies “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy” averaged more than seven million viewers. Fox was fourth overall but second among the 18- to 49-year-old set.

Loving grandmother of Malcolm and Nora Spencer, and sister to Gail Sullivan, Jack Sullivan, and Jim Sullivan, Maura's fierce devotion to family, sharp witted Irish sense of humor, and fearless ingenuity in the kitchen will be missed by all who knew her. MIDWEST MINNESOTA: AL FRANKEN RIVAL STEPS ASIDE Mike Ciresi, a well-known lawyer and Democrat, announced that he was dropping his bid for a United States Senate seat. The departure leaves Al Franken, the former comedian, in a smaller field of Democrats, including Jack Nelson-Pallmeyer, a professor, seeking the endorsement of the state party at its convention in June. Mr. Ciresi had been viewed by some as Mr. Franken's chief Democratic rival. The Democratic nominee will most likely face Senator Norm Coleman, a Republican, in November. ''In my judgment, continuing the endorsement race would only lead to an unnecessary floor fight,'' Mr. Ciresi said in a written statement. ''It is time to step aside.'' MONICA DAVEY

COCHRAN--Wanda, Lyric Soprano. March 29, 1923-March 4, 2008. Wanda Cochran died in Croton on Hudson, NY on Tuesday, March 4th, 2008. Wanda was born in East Grand Rapids, Michigan, the only child of Marshall and Ida Cochran. Wanda won a scholarship to attend the American Conservatory of Music in Chicago where she graduated with a Masters in Music. She became the alternate for the role of ''Laurie'' in ''Oklahoma'' and won the lead in ''Irene'', touring 35 cities in Europe. Returning to New York, she joined the company of ''Brigadoon''. Wanda returned to Michigan to appear in several of her own shows on local radio stations. Wanda married Robert H. Rose and moved to Europe in 1948. They had a son, Harrison and a daughter, Miarka. In Paris, she featured at leading cabarets and nightclubs. She became the regular soloist with the Metropole Orchestra in Hilversum, Holland and broadcast for the Voice of America. After moving to England, she made appearances in concerts, recitals and oratorio. Wanda returned to New York in 1968. Surviving Wanda are her daughter Miarka Mazur and husband Ben of Gloucester, Virginia, granddaughter Amanda Mazur of London, England and former husband Robert Rose, of New York and London, England. An inurnment at the Columbarium in the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th St, NY, NY 10128 is planned for March 19th at 3pm. 212-289-4100 Ext 201.

GERARD--Karen, died March 10, 2008. Born on April 11, 1932. Karen grew up in Hewlett, Long Island. She attended the public high school and then Radcliffe College where she graduated magna cum laude in 1953. She then obtained a masters degree in economics from Columbia University in 1955. Her first job was as an economic researcher with The Bank of The Manhattan Company which soon after merged with Chase Bank. She became one of the first female vice presidents at Chase and the first who attained such a title while working 31/2 to 4 days a week while her children were infants. She, as an expert on New York City economics, advised the management of the Bank during the City's financial crisis in the 1970s. She then served as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development of New York City in 1981 and 1982 in the Koch Administration. In 1984, Harcourt Brace Jovanice published ''American Survivors, Cities and Other Scenes'', her book of essays on urban economics and social problems. In 1985, she joined Moran Stahl & Boyer an economic consulting firm and in 1989 she and two younger colleagues formed their own consulting firm, Kelly Legan & Gerard. She retired in 1993. During 1981 and 1982, she was the president of the Woman's Forum. She was a one time president and long time director of The Foundation for Child Development and for many years was associated with the Trickle Up organization which makes small grants to further entrepreneurship all over the world. She was an enthusiastic supporter of the Radcliffe Institute and the Schlesinger Library at Harvard. In her retirement, she was a docent at the New York Historical Society and for many years until her death she was a docent of the Morgan Library and Museum. She and her husband maintained a weekend house in Sherman, CT since 1966. She is survived by Egon, her husband for 53 years; her daughter Deborah and her husband Seth; her son Daniel and his wife Jani and four grandchildren, Jesse, Taylor, Cody and Lucy. She is also survived by a brother, Bruce Silberblatt. The date and time of a memorial will be announced. Instead of flowers, she has requested that people consider making a contribution to The Foundation for Child Development, 145 E. 32nd St, New York, NY 10016-6055. Funeral private.
