MANDEL--Michael, of New York City and Poughquag, NY, beloved husband of Penny Frank, adored father of Joshua, Matthew and the late David, and beloved brother of Margaret, died Saturday, March 8th. Family will be receiving at 316 West 84th St., apartment 3D, Wednesday, March 12th from 6-8pm.

CONNOLLY--Jerome E., formerly of Garden City, NY passed away on March 7 in Vero Beach FL. He served in the U.S. Army's 96th Infantry Division during WWII and was awarded two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club for over 60 years, was a nationally ranked squash player and is a member of Fordham University Athletic Hall of Fame for his achievements as a four year varsity track star. Those left to cherish his memory are his loving wife, Patricia, daughters Pamela and Barbara, sons Jerome Jr., Philip and James and 13 grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City Thursday, 9:45am.

FOSTER--Leslie. The Chamber of Commerce of Washington Heights and Inwood mourns the loss of our beloved President. FOSTER--Leslie. It is with profound sadness that Isabella Geriatric Center mourns the passing of our friend and colleague Leslie Foster, who has served our organization with distinction for over thirty years, not only as Isabella's voice in our community, but as an advocate for the people of Washington Heights and Inwood. For decades, her indomitable spirit has helped lead the way in the areas of civil rights, education and service to the elderly. Her accomplishments are legion, but she will surely be remembered for her work creating intergenerational programs that bring young and older people together. She served as current President of the Chamber of Commerce of Washington Heights and Inwood and was a founding member of the New York State Intergenerational Network. She chaired the Community Service Society's Retired Senior Volunteer Program and co-chaired the Washington Heights/Inwood Council on Aging. She also served on Community Board 12, the Community Health Council of the New YorkPresbyterian Hospital, the Board of the ARC XVI Fort Washington Senior Center and the Washington Heights and Inwood Coalition. Our deepest sympathy to her husband, Alfred Lurie, and the entire family. Northern Manhattan has lost a guiding light. Mark Lipton, Ph.D., Board Chair Mark J. Kator, President Isabella Geriatric Center

The law firm Milberg Weiss, set to go on trial later this year on charges of paying illegal kickbacks to clients, was the top-ranked class-action firm in the United States last year with $3.8 billion in settlement winnings for plaintiffs, according to a new report.
Sovereign wealth fund assets may soon surpass total official foreign reserves held by central banks and become the main vehicle for capital investment, a Morgan Stanley economist said on Tuesday.

The Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based hedge fund and financial services group founded by Kenneth Griffin, has hired a portfolio manager from Moore Capital Management to manage global macro strategies, marking the firm's first move into the industry's best performing investment strategy this year.

The refining company Valero Energy of Texas said on Tuesday it is considering selling nearly a third of its North American refineries amid an economic slowdown in the United States that is crimping fuel demand.

HSBC, the European bank, the Bank of China and Malayan Banking Bhd of Malaysia, have emerged as the final bidders for a stake in Bank Internasional Indonesia that is currently held by a Singapore state investor, Temasek, and is valued at more than $800 million, Reuters reported.
A Chinese medical device maker, Mindray Medical, said Tuesday it planned to buy Datascope's patient monitoring business for $202 million.
As firms continue to to pull the plug on initial public offerings in the United States, their European counterparts don't seem to be any more active.
BNP Paribas could set out terms for any offer for embattled rival Société Générale in May, La Tribune newspaper reported on Wednesday without saying where it got the information.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Yesterday The New York Times reported that New York Governor Eliot Spitzer was a customer of high-end prostitution ring and that the prostitutes knew him as "Client 9." Not surprisingly, Clients 1 through 8 were Charlie Sheen.

The comedian Sinbad, a Barack Obama supporter, is ridiculing Senator Hillary Clinton's claim in Iowa that she was sent on a dangerous foreign policy trip to Bosnia in 1996, replete with the threat of sniper fire. Sinbad was on the same trip (Sheryl Crow too), and according to the Washington Post blog The Sleuth:

Over and over for the last six months developers and property agents have repeated the same refrain: "The luxury market is not affected." Buyers of multi-million-dollar properties aren't bothered by the credit crunch; they don't need credit. They see deals, not troubled markets. The rich are only getting richer.
Numbers 5, 4 and 3 on Frank Bruni’s coast-to-coast ranking of 10 of the country’s top new restaurants.
The concrete block walls are painted orange, pink, blue and purple, the ceilings are yellow and the metal stairs are maroon.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
“In Search of Paradise” portrays Meat Loaf as an obsessive, self-punishing performer, striving in vain to put on a live show that matches the visions in his head.
“Blind Mountain,” the second feature from Li Yang, is a reminder that art sometimes keeps the truth alive far better than the news.
Reversing a proposed decision issued last December, Medicare said that it would continue to cover the use of a scanning procedure used to detect heart disease.
TiVo, the maker of popular digital video recorders, announced a partnership with YouTube that will deliver Web video directly to users’ televisions.
Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama staked out opposing positions on the impasse over the disputed primaries.
The airline said it had grounded the planes after questions arose as to whether required testing had been done.
There was one thing every politician in New York seemed to agree on: David A. Paterson is no steamroller.
The planes were grounded on Tuesday night as the airline dealt with fallout from using aircraft that had not gone through a required inspection for possible structural damage.
David A. Paterson, who is scheduled to become governor on Monday, has begun reaching out to Democrats.
Stocks surged Wednesday in Asia and Europe, but investors remained skeptical of the Fed’s move to inject liquidity into the financial system.
A political showdown is blocking Japan from selecting the next leader of its central bank, increasing the chances that the post could sit vacant at a time of growing financial turmoil.
Wall Street fell after overnight gains in Asia and Europe, a day after the Federal Reserve led global central banks in flooding the financial system with liquidity.
French authorities said they have arrested a broker at Société Générale in connection with a trading scandal.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer, reeling from a prostitution scandal, is expected to resign soon at his Manhattan office, where he will be speaking momentarily.

The two-time Pro Bowl wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald signed a four-year, $40 million contract with Arizona. The deal includes $30 million guaranteed, a generous figure for a franchise that was long considered stingy, and a no-trade clause.
A panel to investigate suspected wrongdoing by lawmakers was created, despite deep reservations from rank-and-file lawmakers from both parties.
Andre Carson, a Democrat, won a special election to fill the House seat formerly held by his grandmother Julia Carson, a Democrat who died of lung cancer last year.

Facing a mandatory life sentence, a man convicted in a drug case attacked a prosecutor in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday with a razor he sneaked into the courtroom, the authorities said.
Frustrated at every turn in a scoreless second half of their first game in the Olympic qualifying tournament, the Americans looked bewildered.

Carey Price made 38 saves for his second shutout of the season and Bryan Smolinski and Saku Koivu scored in the first period Tuesday night for the Montreal Canadiens in a 4-0 victory over the visiting Devils.
Japan’s upper house of Parliament cited concern over Toshiro Muto’s political ties to the finance ministry in rejecting his nomination.
Antawn Jamison scored 23 points, the rookie Nick Young had a career-high 22, and the host Washington Wizards rallied in the fourth quarter Tuesday night for a 105-97 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.
The victory gave UConn, the nation’s top-ranked women’s team, an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

Japan’s economy grew 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter, revised government data showed on Wednesday, in line with the initial estimate. The revised growth in gross domestic product exceeded economists’ forecasts for 0.6 percent growth. It translated into annualized expansion of 3.5 percent, compared with a preliminary reading of 3.7 percent.

The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about the Sony A300 digital camera, attributed an erroneous distinction to one of its features. The camera’s ability to display an uninterrupted preview of an image on the back-panel screen because of a second image sensor is a refined version of a system that appeared in the Olympus E-330 in 2006; it is not a “technical breakthrough.”.

A front-page article on Feb. 14 about a bombing that killed Imad Mugniyah, a Hezbollah commander blamed by the United States and Israel for numerous terrorist attacks, referred incompletely to accusations against him. While some American officials said he had not been involved in new attacks for more than a decade, reports in the Israeli press in July 2006 said he had been in charge of Hezbollah military operations in southern Lebanon since the mid-1990s and was believed responsible for the capture of two Israeli soldiers on July 12, 2006, an event that led to the Israel-Hezbollah war that summer.

An article on the Box Seats page in sports on Sunday by Oscar Robertson, a basketball Hall of Fame member, about his first game at the old Madison Square Garden in 1958, misstated the location of the Garden at the time. It was at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, not 48th.

European Union antitrust officials raided the offices of several international airlines as part of an investigation into suspected price fixing on scheduled flights between the Europe and Japan. Spokeswomen for Lufthansa of Germany and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, a unit of Air France-KLM, confirmed that their offices in Frankfurt and Amsterdam had been raided and said they were cooperating with the investigation. The European Commission, the European Union’s executive arm, said it and national competition regulators had carried out unannounced inspections at the premises of a number of international airlines. It did not identify the carriers. The commission believes that the companies may have violated its rules on restrictive business practices, officials said, without elaborating.

An article on Monday about an offer by two supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton to pay for restaging the Florida and Michigan primaries misstated the current standing of the Democratic presidential race. Senator Barack Obama has more delegates and has received more popular votes than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. They are not in a “virtual tie.”.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about plans by Hollywood’s big studios to release several comedies in the coming months referred imprecisely to the role of Shawn Levy in the production of one, “What Happens in Vegas,” coming out in May from 20th Century Fox. He is a producer, not the executive producer. (The executive producers are Arnon Milchan, Joe Caracciolo Jr. and Dean Georgaris.).
Audi, the luxury car maker owned by Volkswagen, said its 2007 profit climbed 26 percent on a sales rise of almost 8 percent worldwide.

An article on Monday about an offer by two supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton to pay for restaging the Florida and Michigan primaries misstated the current standing of the Democratic presidential race. Senator Barack Obama has more delegates and has received more popular votes than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. They are not in a “virtual tie.”.

An article in the special Museums section today about a 1975 video by two San Francisco art collectives that recreates the Kennedy assassination misidentifies, in some copies, the make of limousine used in the video. It was a Lincoln Continental, the same make President Kennedy rode in — not a Cadillac.
Société Générale, seeking to restore its status as a top-tier bank after an extensive trading scandal, said it had raised $8.44 billion through a share offering.

An obituary headline on Feb. 15 about Arthur D. Lewis, a transportation executive who was involved in the formation of Conrail, misstated his age. As the first paragraph of the obituary noted, he was 89, not 88.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the effect of proposed budget cuts in New Jersey on the state’s smallest towns misstated, in some editions, the percentage by which state aid would drop in Helmetta, a working-class borough of 2,023 people. Aid will drop by about 55 percent, not by about 40 percent.

A 911 operator in Detroit who the authorities say did not take seriously a young boy’s calls to report his mother’s collapse has been sentenced to a year of probation. The mother was found dead three hours after the call that was handled by Sharon Nichols. In January, a jury convicted her of willful neglect of duty, a misdemeanor punishable by up to a year behind bars. But prosecutors did not ask for jail time.

A man the police say is a member of a Los Angeles gang was charged with murder in the shooting of a high school football star. Pedro Espinoza, 19, is accused of killing Jamiel Shaw Jr., 17, a standout running back at Los Angeles High School, yards from his home in the Crenshaw area on March 2. Mr. Espinoza was charged with a single murder count with a special-circumstance allegation that could make him eligible for the death penalty, said Shiara M. Davila, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles County district attorney’s office. The special circumstance was that it was gang-related, Ms. Davila said.

The Kansas Supreme Court effectively killed a law banning picketing at funerals, ruling that it was unconstitutional for legislators to include language that required a court to uphold the law before it could be enforced. That “judicial trigger” was intended to prevent Westboro Baptist Church of Topeka from collecting damages from the state after a successful appeal of the law. The law was enacted in response to the church’s picketing of military funerals; the Rev. Fred Phelps and his followers say American combat deaths are God’s punishment for the nation’s tolerance of homosexuality. The court did not address the merits of the 2007 law.

A federal jury in Pittsburgh awarded $28 million to the father of a boy killed by the police in 2002. The jury found that two state troopers intentionally shot 12-year-old Michael Ellerbe in the back during a foot chase on Christmas Eve 2002 in Uniontown. The civil rights lawsuit was filed by the boy’s father, Michael Hickenbottom, who contended the troopers had no reason to shoot his son as he ran from a stolen vehicle the troopers had been pursuing.

The husband of the televangelist Juanita Bynum pleaded guilty to assaulting her, was sentenced to three years’ probation and then turned to her and apologized. Thomas W. Weeks III, a minister known to his followers as Bishop Weeks, was charged with beating Ms. Bynum in an Atlanta hotel parking lot in August. He must undergo violence and anger counseling and complete 200 hours of community service that cannot be church-related.

The police chief in Gary has retired less than a week after he and two top aides were indicted on federal civil rights charges. Chief Thomas Houston is accused of assaulting two people he suspected of burglarizing his home in June and of having four people arrested and detained without probable cause. Mayor Rudy Clay said the two men indicted with the chief had been reassigned to the homicide division with an emphasis on cold cases.

More people can survive a cardiac arrest when emergency medical workers use a new resuscitation method that starts with a round of 200 chest compressions before a defibrillator shock, researchers said. Rescue teams in Arizona who used the new approach on people who had a cardiac arrest outside the hospital tripled the survival rate of the standard technique. The new method increases blood flow to the heart and brain when the heart stops pumping blood. The study appears in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Federal judges agreed to give the public more information about cases in which judges are disciplined by their colleagues. Final orders on complaints will be posted on appeals court Web sites, and, in most cases, judges will be named if they have been sanctioned. But only a handful of cases advance beyond a preliminary review. The changes were adopted by the Judicial Conference of the United States, a 27-judge body led by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

Mike Green matched his career high with 24 points and No. 12 Butler used a big second-half run to beat Cleveland State, 70-55, for its fifth Horizon League championship and first automatic berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament since 2001.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to resign, but his wife is urging him to stay on, aides said.
Barack Obama built on his delegate lead as the fight heads to Pennsylvania for a six-week showdown.
President Bush told a group of Christian broadcasters that his policies in Iraq and Afghanistan are predicated on the beliefs that freedom is a God-given right.
The government and banks agreed to pay $170 million to compensate Jews whose property was looted by the Nazi occupying forces during World War II.
Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are sometimes overstating their own advantage as they woo voters and superdelegates.
Some 15,000 airport workers across India went on strike, a move that threatened to ground hundreds of domestic flights.
The top official of one of Britain’s largest police forces was found dead in the North Wales countryside a day after he left for a walk in the mountains, the authorities said.
Britain has barred an Israeli political advocate, Moshe Feiglin, from entering the country, saying his views could foment violence.
A government-appointed panel recommended that students pledge allegiance to the queen and take part in citizenship ceremonies similar to those held for immigrants.
Jacob G. Zuma is seeking to convince the Constitutional Court that evidence should be excluded from his trial in August on corruption charges.
The authorities arrested two sisters in Osaka who they said hid some $57 million in cardboard boxes to evade tax on their inheritance.
The propulsion problem with the European Jules Verne cargo spacecraft has been corrected, and the robot ship began maneuvers to take it to the International Space Station.
Germany and the United States will grant each other access to databases of fingerprints and DNA of people suspected of terrorist activity.
Japan’s upper house of parliament cited concern over Toshiro Muto’s political ties to the finance ministry.
The conflict over street preachers on H Street in Washington, D.C., is partly a reflection of social tensions as new businesses and better-off families move into the changing neighborhood.
Jefferson County is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy after a series of exotic bond deals. It’s an extreme case, but one with echoes across the country.
An F.D.A. advisory committee will consider placing further limits on the use of the Amgen drugs Epogen and Aranesp and the Johnson & Johnson drug Procrit.
A California doctor is being investigated to determine whether he illegally wrote prescriptions for patients, including major league baseball players.

Fernando Torres scored a second-half goal to give visiting Liverpool a 1-0 victory over Inter Milan and send the Reds to the European Champions League quarterfinals. Liverpool, which won the tournament in 2005 and lost in the final last year, advanced with a 3-0 aggregate after winning, 2-0, at Anfield in the first leg. Inter Milan played the last 40 minutes a man down after defender Nicolas Burdisso was sent off with his second yellow card. After the match, Inter Milan Coach Roberto Mancini said he would resign at the end of the season.Liverpool joins three other English Premier League teams — Chelsea, Manchester United and Arsenal — in the quarterfinals. It is the first time four teams from the same country have made it to the final eight.

A decision by soccer’s rule-making body to standardize the size of fields for international games will most likely not prevent Giants Stadium and other existing facilities from being used as sites. The International Football Association Board voted Saturday to institute a rule that matches involving national teams must be played on fields 105 meters long by 68 meters wide (114.8 by 74.4 yards). If applied to Giants Stadium, the new provision might rule out a possible June 8 exhibition game between the United States and Argentina. A spokesman for FIFA, however, said that the rule was not intended to be “retroactive” and that “the unification of dimensions is for new stadiums.”.

Connecticut Sun forward Nykesha Sales plans to sit out the W.N.B.A. season because of injuries. Sales, 31, said she needed time off to heal after playing a light schedule overseas in the off-season. She said she intended to return to the league. Sales played 248 consecutive games from 1999-06, the second-longest streak of consecutive games in the league.

Running back Jesse Chatman became the fifth unrestricted free agent to sign with the Jets in the past two weeks. Chatman, 28, who will join Thomas Jones in the Jets’ backfield, had career highs of 515 yards rushing and 276 receiving yards for the Miami Dolphins last season, his fifth in the N.F.L.

A woman who obtained a restraining order earlier this year in a domestic violence case against the New England Patriots star Randy Moss wants the case dismissed, court records show. Rachelle Washington, 35, filed papers March 3 with the Broward County (Fla.) Circuit Court clerk’s office requesting that the order be dissolved and the case closed. Moss, 31, denied that he harmed Washington at her Florida home on Jan. 6, or that he prevented her from seeking medical attention.
Adm. William J. Fallon’s public statements on Iran seemed to put him at odds with the Bush administration.
Several people involved in the discussions said a draft proposal calls for a new mail-in primary that would take place by early June.
The former attorney general responded angrily to suggestions that a no-bid contract directed to him by the Justice Department amounted to a “back-room sweetheart deal.”
Whose theory is it that prostitution is victimless? It’s the men who buy prostitutes who spew the myths that women choose prostitution.
As someone who has stood by her politician husband during his public — and anemic — mea culpa, all I can say is: It’s a personal decision.
A law enforcement official said the suspects forced the girl, a special education student, to perform sex on them and abused her with a broomstick.
A woman was left in a tiny holding cell in an Arkansas courthouse after a bailiff apparently forgot that he placed her there.
Ross Ohlendorf hopes to stand out as the Yankees thin the crowded herd of relievers. He is also a rancher, raising some 250 longhorns near Austin, Tex.
The Democratic Party of President Boris Tadic offers the most sensible policy among Serbia’s parties on how to proceed after Kosovo’s declaration of independence.

An article on Tuesday reported the reactions of political figures in Albany to the news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer had been a client of a prostitution ring. The last two paragraphs referred to remarks that Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson made at a breakfast meeting in October where he discussed his post, and it quoted him as saying he had been initially reluctant to attend a conference of lieutenant governors. The Times reporter and his editors were not clearly told by a contributing reporter that the quotation and the context had come from an article on the Web site of City Hall, one of the publications that organized the breakfast. The context should have been paraphrased and the information attributed to the site.
The Senate Judiciary Committee last week approved a potentially life-saving bill that would require federal judges to consider public health and safety before sealing court records.
A study of grizzly bears in Montana is hardly frivolous. It is a prerequisite for sensible administration of the Endangered Species Act.
A proposal to put a moratorium on spending earmarked for home-state projects now has the support of all three senators running for president.
The testimony on the second day of a trial to settle a dispute over the control of IAC/InterActiveCorp reduced a clash of billionaire titans to a debate about detail.
The old rivals now own the two worst records in the East, but while the Knicks seem hopeless, Miami is set up for a quick rebound.
Yankee Stadium has never been a baseball-only place. It’s been home to football, soccer, rock ‘n’ roll, and Pope Benedict XVI is on deck for April 20.
At $5.20 a gallon, the gas at the Amerigo Gas Station in Gorda, Calif., may be the costliest in the land.
Still feeling the sting of last year’s second-round loss, Edgar Sosa and Louisville are headed to New York for this week’s Big East Conference tournament.
W. R. Grace & Company has agreed to pay the federal government $250 million for environmental cleanup around its mining operations in Libby, Mont.
John Daly has been cut loose by the swing coach Butch Harmon, who said he was not going to waste his time with Daly because he was more interested in socializing than working on his golf game.
The California Nurses Association sent organizers to the state to break up an unusual deal between the Service Employees International Union and nine hospitals.
Mrs. Wells was the last surviving member of the 1930 Wiley College debate team, whose story was told in the movie “The Great Debaters.”
Turkey’s government is planning a series of investments in the country’s largely Kurdish southeast, in a new economic initiative intended to draw people away from militancy.
Not all analysts reached the conclusion that the video game maker’s improved outlook will help it in its battle with rival Electronic Arts.
Stocks had their biggest one-day gain in five years after the Federal Reserve said it would step up its lending to ease strain on the dysfunctional money market.
Initially combative in the face of a $10.2 million fine for inspection lapses, the airline said it had suspended three workers and hired an outside maintenance expert.
New York’s government cannot afford to be paralyzed while Eliot Spitzer games his political prospects or, as many suspect, tries to work out a better legal deal with federal prosecutors.
Athletic scholarships are not all games and fun. They can be overwhelming in their demands on a student’s time and energy.
The House on Tuesday failed to overturn President Bush’s veto of legislation that would have banned the use of a technique that simulates drowning.

Prosecutors displayed photographs on Tuesday of an injury sustained by one of the three detectives on trial in the killing of Sean Bell. The injury occurred when Mr. Bell’s car struck him before officers began a 50-shot barrage, the police said.
Net profit in J. Crew’s fourth quarter was $25 million, or 39 cents a share.
Considered by Kansans to have been one of the state’s greatest athletes, Mr. Schnellbacher was an all-pro defensive back for the N.F.L. Giants and also played pro basketball.
Although outside the major conferences, Xavier maintains a big-time attitude and aspires to be among the nation’s best programs.
The U. S. trade deficit widened slightly in January, as oil prices pushed imports higher, even though slow economic growth reduced the demand for many foreign goods.
Pedro Martínez is increasing his pitching volume, on track to pitch April 1, the season’s second game.
The grocery store chain said it topped Wall Street earnings targets despite a drop in profit, and it said the weak economy had not slowed its grocery store customers.
Children’s advocates contend that an Ohio hospital went too far by naming a department after Abercrombie & Fitch in exchange for a $10 million donation.
The retailer said it was helped by sales at its new stores, but it forecast lackluster results in the first quarter and 2008.
A former reporter for USA Today had been ordered to pay a daily fine for refusing to name the sources for an article she wrote about a former Army bioweapons scientist.
Allied Aviation Services agreed to pay $1.9 million to settle a lawsuit begun by 15 black and Hispanic employees at its Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport facility.
Millions of people are reluctant to change their technology habits just for the sake of progress.
Gen. Ante Gotovina was the commander of a military campaign in the summer of 1995 that put an end to the Serbian occupation of Eastern Croatia.
In its challenge to the Air Force’s award of a $35 billion contract to its rival, Boeing said the military had changed specifications to accommodate the bigger Airbus plane.
In the scam, “victims” of the fender benders were treated for fake cases of whiplash and back pain, the authorities said.
The State Department no longer considers China one of the world’s worst human rights violators, a decision that immediately earned the ire of human rights groups.
Aetna plans to provide the service, SmartSource, free to its customers, saying it wants to help people manage their own health care.
For more than 30 years, Mr. Irwin was a much-in-demand New York jazz bassist. His recent illness became a rallying point for jazz musicians without medical insurance.
An athlete’s worth to a college is often negotiated behind the closed doors, but the figures tend to get out. What happens next is not surprising: scholarship envy.
In a Rockland County hamlet, observant Jews who didn’t want a Wal-Mart in their backyard managed to derail a proposal by the retailer.

Robert E. Chambers Jr., who strangled Jennifer Levin, 18, during what he called rough sex 22 years ago, was addicted to heroin when he was arrested in October on drug charges, his lawyer said on Tuesday.
Shortly after the move, Google announced that it had closed the $3.1 billion acquisition and said the integration of the two companies may result in some job cuts.
A team of computer security researchers says it was able to gain wireless access to a combination heart defibrillator and pacemaker.

NEWARK — Exposing a deepening rift in this city’s Police Department, Chief Anthony Campos was suspended for five days on Monday by the department’s police director, Garry F. McCarthy, after the two disagreed over personnel matters, according to law enforcement and union officials.
Vendors and their supporters had likened a “regularization” of a permit process to a threat of ouster from Red Hook.
Time is running out on Josh Beckett’s slim chance of traveling to Tokyo to pitch in Boston’s first two regular-season games.
Headline: Man Convicted of Killing One Teenage Girl Is Charged in ’68 Death of Another.
Shivani Sud, a high school senior in Durham, N.C., focused her research on colon cancer to won the Intel Science Talent Search.
Lawyers for the man accused of killing Nixzmary Brown abruptly rested their case after the judge rejected their attempts to undo the damage that was caused by one of their own witnesses.
For one Arizona principal, a new illegal immigration law that caused some students at her school to drop out reminded her of divisiveness in her native Northern Ireland.
The Walgreen Company, the nation’s largest drugstore chain in sales, plans a three-level store with 16,200 square feet at One Times Square.
The mountains of Mungyong, South Korea, where miners once dug for coal, may one day offer a new source of income: tourists sailing down a waterway blasted though the hills.
A report by the United Nations says that a tenth of Afghanistan is off limits to aid workers because attacks by Taliban insurgents make it too dangerous.
A pro-government militia composed of former Tamil Tiger rebels won a local election in Batticaloa despite allegations that it had used child soldiers, extorted businessmen and carried out killings.
To the Editor:.
Tiny cameras, the rise of YouTube and the growing appeal of so-called citizen journalism has done for animal rights advocates what the best-organized protest could not.
The J. Paul Getty Museum announced Tuesday that it had acquired “Arii Matamoe,” an 1892 painting by Paul Gauguin that has been in a private collection in Switzerland for decades.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Reviews of performances by Stephen Hough, the English Voices and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, part of the Great Performers series at Lincoln Center and Romain Descharmes.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington announced on Tuesday the 2008-9 season of theater, dance, music, and children’s productions. The season will include “Arabesque: Arts of the Arab World,” a three-week festival that will bring Arab art and culture to Washington with dance, theater and music presentations from 22 Arab nations. It will run from Feb. 25 through March 15, 2009. “We really focused a lot on bringing unknown international art to Washington,” Michael M. Kaiser, president of the center, said of the show, which has taken years to plan. “We thought it was about time we looked at Arab cultures,” he added. The center’s newly renovated Eisenhower Theater will reopen in October with “Broadway: Three Generations,” followed in November by “Frost/Nixon,” with Stacey Keach playing Richard M. Nixon; in April a new production of “Ragtime” starts. The contemporary-dance series will include performances from the Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham, José Limon, Mark Morris, Alvin Ailey, Paul Taylor and Shen Wei companies. The ballet season will begin in October with performances by the Suzanne Farrell Ballet and include the American Ballet Theater, the Bolshoi Ballet, the Joffrey Ballet, the San Francisco Ballet and the Kirov Ballet.

Alondra de la Parra, above, a 27-year-old Mexican student at the Manhattan School of Music, has cut short her spring break to head for Florida. She’s not going to seek a suntan but to step in to conduct the Russian National Orchestra in concerts this week that feature the flutist James Galway on Wednesday, and the violinist Joshua Bell on Friday. Ms. de la Parra, a candidate for a master of music degree in May from the Manhattan School of Music, was studying conducting in Salzburg, Austria, during the break when a call came inviting her to step in for an ailing Teodor Currentzis, the director of the Novosibirsk Opera and Ballet Theater, who was to lead the Russian National Orchestra in the performances as part of the Festival of the Arts Boca in Boca Raton, Fla. Ms. de la Parra, the founder and music director of the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, which is based in New York, will lead works by Mozart, David Overton and Schubert on Wednesday and by Tchaikovsky and Debussy on Friday.

Fox News Channel, tinkering for the first time in eight years with its popular early evening lineup, is replacing its 5 p.m. news broadcast, “The Big Story,” with an election-theme program for the foreseeable future. The network confirmed this week that “America’s Election HQ,” a program that displaced “The Big Story” temporarily last month, would continue indefinitely. The program’s hosts, Bill Hemmer and Megyn Kelly, also anchor the network’s mid-morning newscast and are seen as rising stars on the channel. The change was first reported by the blog TVNewser.com. John Gibson, the longtime host of “The Big Story,” will continue to have a role on television, the network said, although it appears that his future for now lies mostly on radio. For two years Mr. Gibson, a conservative commentator, has been the host of a three-hour program for Fox News Radio immediately following his television show. Fox News Channel, the top-rated cable news network, has benefited in recent years from a stable programming schedule, while CNN and MSNBC have made multiple on-camera changes. The programming shift underscores the emphasis placed on election-year programming by the cable news networks.

Irked by a tax dispute with Germany, Crown Prince Alois of Liechtenstein has canceled a planned loan of family-owned art to the Neue Pinakothek museum in Munich, Bloomberg News reported. Last month Prince Alois, right, called the methods employed by Germany to obtain information on tax evaders an “attack” on Liechtenstein, which punishes infringements on its banking secrecy. And a written statement from the prince’s office said, “All other approved loans for exhibitions in Germany will also be retracted.” The Neue Pinakothek exhibition “Viennese Biedermeier Painting From the Collection of the Prince of Liechtenstein” was to have run from May 21 to Sept. 21. “It’s a shame,” said Herbert Rott, the curator responsible for the show. “We hope we can reschedule it for a later date.”.

One day after his induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Canadian singer and songwriter Leonard Cohen, 73, below, announced plans on Tuesday for his first tour in 15 years, Reuters reported. The tour, beginning in Toronto on June 6, will include an appearance at the Glastonbury Festival in Britain on June 29. The final announced date is Aug. 29 in Vienna, but organizers said more performances were expected. ... The rock band Van Halen has postponed all shows through April 19 while the guitarist Eddie Van Halen, 53, undergoes tests for an unspecified medical condition, Reuters reported. The announcement came a week after the band postponed four concerts for the same reason. Fans were asked to keep their tickets, which will be honored at makeup dates. ... The rapper the Game, whose real name is Jayceon Taylor, has been released from a Los Angeles jail after serving 8 days of a 60-day sentence for possession of a firearm in a school zone, The Associated Press reported.

“Canterbury’s Law,” the new Fox legal drama, felt dark, mature and realistic — fare found more often on cable than on broadcast television. Julianna Margulies, the show’s star, said the network wanted to “bring a little FX to Fox.” But young viewers showed little interest in “Canterbury’s Law,” as the show’s premiere finished in fourth place in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic at 8 p.m. on Monday, Nielsen reported. Fox suggested that the transition to daylight saving time might have had some impact on the ratings. “Canterbury’s Law” averaged 7.6 million viewers, enough to place second in total viewers behind ABC’s “Bachelor,” but delivered a disappointing 1.7 rating in the 18-to-49 demographic favored by advertisers. At 9 p.m. “New Amsterdam” picked up some viewers for Fox, averaging 8.8 million viewers and a 2.5 rating in that demographic. The 11.7 million viewers for “Two and a Half Men” and the 10.1 million viewers for “CSI: Miami” put CBS into first place for the night. NBC was a close second, as ho-hum viewership for “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” (6.9 million) was offset by high ratings for “Deal or No Deal” (11.6 million) and “Medium” (9.2 million). ABC placed fourth for the night with two episodes of the low-rated “October Road” (4.6 million at 9, and 4.8 million at 10).

KESTENBAUM--James Michael. A loving, sweet and funny man who brought joy to everyone who knew him. Jim passed away peacefully at home March 9, 2008. Survived by his loving partner Barrie, daughter Jennifer, son-in-law Scott Levine, son Matthew, daughter - in - law Kristine and his beloved grandchildren Sydney, Justin, and Kelsey. HELLMAN--Anne, died on March 10th in New York. She is survived by her children Barbara, Ronald, and Renee and her grandchildren Sarah, Jeffrey, Michelle, Andrew, and Suzanne. Anne loved unconditionally. Her daily gestures of kindness to friends, family, and total strangers were indicative of how she lived her life. Anne left Germany in 1938 and married the late Jack Hellman in 1946. That year, they founded Hellman Construction. Anne's life revolved around her family, giving tirelessly and generously. We will remember the taste of her sauerbraten, the smile on her face and sparkle in her eye, her laughter at our jokes, the chocolate she sent for every occasion, the commitment she had to keeping Jack healthy throughout the years. Anne's entire family feels great fortune to have had her as their mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, aunt, and friend. Her light and love will be palpably missed.

LARSEN--Eleanor Water house, died in New York City on March 6th, 2008. A longtime resident of New Jersey and wife of John W. Larsen, who died in 1990, she is survived by her four children: John W. Larsen Jr., Nancy Larsen Farrell, Gregory P. Larsen, and Melissa E. Larsen; her sister, Viola W. Toth; six grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. One granddaughter preceded her in death. Eleanor was a caring wife and mother, a committed and vigorous volunteer to the Girl Scouts, community churches and soup kitchens, and a companion to her husband's extensive charitable and fundraising efforts. She touched those she met with her goodness, warmth, grace, and intelligence. By her example, Eleanor set a high standard for personal performance and generosity. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10021 on March 24th, 2008 at 11am. The family may be contacted by mail at Eleanor W. Larsen, 785 Park Avenue #

GERARD--Karen, died March 10, 2008. Born on April 11, 1932. Karen grew up in Hewlett, Long Island. She attended the public high school and then Radcliffe College where she graduated magna cum laude in 1953. She then obtained a masters degree in economics from Columbia University in 1955. Her first job was as an economic researcher with The Bank of The Manhattan Company which soon after merged with Chase Bank. She became one of the first female vice presidents at Chase and the first who attained such a title while working 31/2 to 4 days a week while her children were infants. She, as an expert on New York City economics, advised the management of the Bank during the City's financial crisis in the 1970s. She then served as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development of New York City in 1981 and 1982 in the Koch Administration. In 1984, Harcourt Brace Jovanice published ''American Survivors, Cities and Other Scenes'', her book of essays on urban economics and social problems. In 1985, she joined Moran Stahl & Boyer an economic consulting firm and in 1989 she and two younger colleagues formed their own consulting firm, Kelly Legan & Gerard. She retired in 1993. During 1981 and 1982, she was the president of the Woman's Forum. She was a one time president and long time director of The Foundation for Child Development and for many years was associated with the Trickle Up organization which makes small grants to further entrepreneurship all over the world. She was an enthusiastic supporter of the Radcliffe Institute and the Schlesinger Library at Harvard. In her retirement, she was a docent at the New York Historical Society and for many years until her death she was a docent of the Morgan Library and Museum. She and her husband maintained a weekend house in Sherman, CT since 1966. She is survived by Egon, her husband for 53 years; her daughter Deborah and her husband Seth; her son Daniel and his wife Jani and four grandchildren, Jesse, Taylor, Cody and Lucy. She is also survived by a brother, Bruce Silberblatt. The date and time of a memorial will be announced. Instead of flowers, she has requested that people consider making a contribution to The Foundation for Child Development, 145 E. 32nd St, New York, NY 10016-6055. Funeral private.

A Bloomberg News article in the Today in Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the compensation of Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation, misstated his stock and options award for 2007. Mr. Katzenberg waived annual stock awards for the year; he was not awarded $11 million. (The $11 million reported in a company regulatory filing represented a prorated portion of the equity he received at the company's 2004 initial public offering, which vests in 2009.)

That second step of the ''Texas two-step''? It's lasting almost as long as a season of ''Dancing With the Stars.'' It will probably be almost three more weeks, March 29, until Texas election officials can report the outcome of the state's Democratic caucuses.

Mitt Romney emerged from hibernation Tuesday to do his first televised interview since he suspended his presidential campaign last month, saying he would be ''honored'' to serve as Senator John McCain's vice-presidential nominee. ''I think any Republican leader in this country would be honored to be asked to serve as the vice-presidential nominee, myself included,'' said Mr. Romney, according to advance excerpts from a scheduled appearance Tuesday night on Fox News Channel's Hannity & Colmes. ''Of course, this is a nation which needs strong leadership. And if the nominee of our party asked you to serve with him, anybody would be honored to receive that call.''

BRICKMAN--Herman Julian, 82, died March 8, 2008 at Greenwich Hospital. He is survived by his loving devoted wife Barbara of 47 years and two daughters, Jennette of Sarasota, FL and Blair Stuart and her husband Preston of New York, NY as well as two grandchildren, Sarah Brickman and Miles Stuart. Herman, born in New York City, graduated NYU. He served in the Army during WWII. He founded several international plastics manufacturing companies with factories in Connecticut. Herman was a member of Belle Haven Club of Greenwich and Harmonie Club of NYC, also one of the original members of the Greenwich Croquet Club. Memorial services will be held at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich on Friday, March 14 at 11am. Contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital.

O'MARA--John Louis, 64, formerly of Louisville, died Saturday, March 8th. John's intellectual and romantic nature thrived on words, people, art and the city of New York where he worked as a graphic artist for the majority of his adult life. There, he was one of the founders of the New York Mac Users Group (NYMUG). Most recently, he found new friends and family at the Gaylord Opryland Hotel in Nashville, TN where he worked. He is preceded in death by his parents, William J. and Anna A. O'Mara and his brother, William C. O'Mara. He is survived by his children, Patrick K. (Laurie), Jennifer, and Heather; granddaughters, Megan, Paige, Ashley and Hope; siblings, Kevin (Oreta), Mary Ann King (Nicholas), and Patrick (Janice); and four nieces and two nephews. Paterson, a former politician from Harlem. An extended version is at: nytimes.com/nyregion. As a disabled person, there's certain times that I don't want to appear to need that much help. When I was in college, when I was at Columbia, I had a professor -- I actually Googled him, he passed away in 1986 -- and his name was Basil Ruch, and he was a professor of history at Barnard College, and he showed me a picture of Franklin Delano Roosevelt being carried into the 1932 Democratic convention.

An article last Wednesday about the widespread use of monosodium glutamate by cooks around the world misstated the role of excitotoxins, which may include MSG. They can raise levels of glutamate, which can overstimulate neurons, not neurotransmitters. (Glutamate is itself a neurotransmitter.) The article also misspelled the given name of a biochemist at the University of Miami who was part of a team to identify human glutamate receptors. She is Nirupa Chaudhari, not Nuripa.

RIPOSANU--Marguerite Sisca, died peacefully at her home on March 9, 2008. She was predeceased by her husband Pamfil Riposanu in 1998. Marguerite Riposanu was a graduate of Port Chester High School and the College of New Rochelle where she received a Bachelor of Science degree in Business. She served her College as a Phonathon volunteer, Reunion Chair, News Agent, and perennial member of the reunion committees and was honored by the College in 2005 with the Ursula Laurus Citation in recognition of her distinguished service to the President and Treasurer of The Ridgefield Foundation. As a resident of New York City, she had in the past shared her talents with the Board of Directors of Hope for Diabetes and the Cotillion Committee of the New York InfirmaryBeekman Downtown Hospital. She was also a regular parishioner for many years at St. Catherine of Sienna Church where she was a daily communicant. She is survived by her daughter Ann Maria Riposanu ter Haar and her husband Jan, of Amsterdam, the Netherlands and Manhattan, her sister Angelina Gillingham, of Scotch Plains, NJ, her brother Francis Sisca and his wife Elvira of Greenwich, CT. She is also survived by her nieces and nephews, Steven Gillingham and his wife Sue, of Fairfax Station, VA, Elizabeth Burch and her husband Jay, of Landenberg, PA, Catherine Freeman and her husband Michael, of Oak Hill, VA, Barbara Mariano and her husband Frederick, of Shelton, CT, Sally Checca and her husband Stephen of Syosset, NY, Peter Sisca and his wife Carol of Port Chester, NY, Lee Ann Longo and her husband Joseph, Francis Sisca and his wife Beth, and Robert Sisca and his wife Jennifer, all of Greenwich, CT. She was predeceased by a niece, Marisa Sisca Sprague. Family will receive friends on Thursday 48pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral Mass Friday 10am at St. Catherine of Sienna 68th St. between 1st and York Ave. Donations may be made in Marguerite Riposanu's name to the College of New Rochelle or to St. Catherine of Sienna Church. The family would like to particularly thank the Smyth family for their loving and compassionate care.

PEPPERMAN--Mary (nee Novik), age 92 of Brooklyn NY, Manhattan, Westhampton Beach, NY and Danville, CA passed away on March 9, 2008, after a brief illness. Mary is survived by a daughter, Judith Pepperman Miller, and son-in-law David Miller of Concord, CA, grandchildren Paul Miller and his wife Erin of Seattle, WA, Andrew Miller of Moraga, CA, Rachel Miller of Seattle, WA, and Debbie Miller of Walnut Creek, CA. Mary was preceded in death by her husband Phillip ''Peppy'' Pepperman, and her brothers, Morris S. Novik, Harry Novik, Albert Novik and Ralph Novik, and her sister-in-law Manya Davidson Novik. Mary served for many years as secretary and administrative assistant at Downstate Medical Center in both the Departments of Vascular and Pediatric Surgery. She retired in June of 1983 and then continued employment part-time at the College of Nursing at the State University of New York. In 2001, Mary moved to California to be with her family. Graveside service will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on Thursday March 13, 2008 at 11:30am. The formal mourning ''Shiva'' will be observed at the Miller home in Northern California. Please contact the family at marypeppermansfamily@ gmail.com. The family wishes that memorial contributions be made to Bruns House c/o Hospice of the East Bay, 3470 Buskirk Avenue, Pleasant Hill, CA 94523 www.hospiceeastbay.org.

O'NEIL--Joyce Carroll, died on February 28, 2008, in Atlantis, Florida. Mrs. O'Neil's husband, William C. O'Neil, predeceased her in 1991. Mrs. O'Neil survived her brothers, Joseph and Richard Carroll, and her sister, Claire Carroll. Survivors include her nephews, Joseph F. Carroll, III and Stephen L. Carroll. A Brooklyn native, Mrs. O'Neil's family owned The Joseph F. Carroll Towing Co., a tugboat operator in Brooklyn. Mrs. O'Neil graduated from St. Saviors High School and Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart. Mrs. O'Neil resided in New York City, where she served as a Past President of the St. Vincent's Hospital Auxiliary and a Board Member of The Ladies of Charity, until she and her husband relocated to Palm Beach in the early 1980s. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday, March 12, 2008 from 7-9pm. Mrs. O'Neil will be buried on Thursday, March 13, 2008 at 11:00am at the Holy Cross Cemetery, 3620 Tilden Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11203.

VANCE--Amy Sloane, a lawyer and advocate for the poor and needy, passed away this past Monday after a long and brave struggle with cancer. A native New Yorker who spent her entire professional life in New York City, Amy graduated from Mt. Holyoke College and Fordham School of Law. As a young lawyer, Amy practiced law at the Carter Ledyard law firm before working as a program officer at the Ford Foundation. She then spent more than 20 years working for the New York State Office of Court Administration, most recently as Deputy Counsel to Chief Judge Judith Kaye, before retiring in 2007. Throughout her career and life, Amy devoted her heart and soul, intellect, energies and leadership to help the city's most vulnerable, applying her lawyer's training and problem solving talents to serve the needs of the poor. An active member of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, she was also Chairperson of the Board of Directors of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, supporting the Federation's historic legacy of caring for those most in need. Amy had a strong interest in health care ethics, serving on the Mt. Sinai Hospital Institutional Review Board. Amy was the daughter of Cyrus R. Vance, and is survived by her mother, Grace Sloane Vance, three sisters, Elsie Vance Askar, Camilla Vance Holmes and Grace Roberts Vance, her brother, Cyrus R. Vance, Jr., a nephew and niece, Simon and Clare Vance, step-nephew Kemal Askar, sister-in-law Peggy Vance, and brothers-in-law Attila Askar and William Holmes, and a large community of loving friends who were inspired by her courage, sense of humor, and commitment to public service. Services will be held this Thursday, March 13, 2008 at 4 pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. In lieu of flowers, Amy asked that any donations be sent to the Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center in memory of Amy Vance, P.O. Box 27106, New York, New York 10087.

Last summer, employees at a large New York bank detected something suspicious: Gov. Democrats tend to make celebrities of their campaign consultants, which is why anyone who has closely followed this campaign could probably pick out Mark Penn or David Axelrod, the chief strategists for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, in a bar. To simply refer generically to these strategists as "consultants," however, as if they were necessarily experts in the same craft, is to obscure important differences in how they got to where they are-differences that can often be important to understanding the arc of a particular campaign. This long and remarkable struggle between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama has been a study not just in the brilliance and the blind spots of the candidates themselves, but also those of their most trusted - and highly paid - advisers. Mr. Axelrod is an ad guy. A man who perfected the craft of encapsulating an entire life in 30 seconds, he has a gift for telling personal stories in ways that people can understand. As my colleague Benjamin Wallace Wells wrote in a Times Magazine profile last year, Mr. Axelrod's essential insight - the idea that has made him successful where others might have failed - is that the modern campaign really isn't about the policy arcana or the candidate's record; it's about a more visceral, more personal narrative. This is probably a big reason why Mr. Obama has, from the start, focused almost exclusively on broad themes of "hope" and "change," drawing heavily on his own life story, rather than staking out any particularly new policy ground. In its tone and emphasis, Mr. Obama's campaign reflects all the attributes of a truly great political ad: the stirring words, the beautiful pictures, the simple and elegant storyline of a ruined political system and the man whose moment has arrived.

Philosophers like to debate the "trolley problem," in which they try to decide if it's ethical to kill one innocent man to save five others from a runaway streetcar. That's fun and games for philosophers, but here's a problem from the real world. Following the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 in which 800,000 people were murdered in 100 days, the victimized Tutsis rose up and chased the killers, along with 2 million of their Hutu tribesmen, out of the country. Now the Hutus were camped along the border, and dying by the thousands each day from starvation and disease. You are the United Nations representative charged with assisting these desperate refugees. But the individuals who control the camps are the very people who committed the genocide, and since any relief you provide has to flow through them, your help necessarily increases their authority. What's more, they are hoping to return to their country and complete the genocidal work they began. Other humanitarian agencies are unwilling to aid the Hutus, even though it means that tens of thousands more may die, so you are their only hope. What do you do?

The "oriental" category of perfumes is basically defined as scents built on two materials, vanilla and labdanum. Vanilla is slightly problematic; the 1960s turned it into a sort of hippie cliché. Then there's labdanum, a natural resin from a Mediterranean bush that smells quite strongly like a dock worker's armpit. Shalimar, created in 1925 by the perfumer Jacques Guerlain, is historically one of the most important perfumes ever made as it is arguably the progenitor of the entire category of parfums gourmands (culinary perfumes). But Shalimar is also a true oriental, which means vanilla plus labdanum, and that in turn means that Guerlain faces the challenge of selling this great early 20th-century work of art in the 21st-century global marketplace.

Carlyle Capital, an affiliate of the Carlyle Group, the private equity investor, said on Thursday it was in default on margin calls of more than $400 million and said its lenders would likely take possession of its remaining assets.
The discount retailer Target said on Wednesday that it was in talks with an investment partner to sell an undivided interest in about half of its credit card receivables for about $4 billion.

It’s kind of a family tradition -- both his brother and his father have won the race through Alaska, which this year awarded the winner $69,000 and a new truck.

China’s retail sales rose 20.2 percent in January and February over the same two-month period last year, driven by strong income growth and rising inflation, according to data reported Wednesday. The growth was driven partly by a 27.9 percent increase in spending on food and growth of 33.8 percent in spending on automobiles, the National Bureau of Statistics reported. The country’s imports rose 35 percent in February to $78.8 billion, according to government data.
The growth, reported by the Census Bureau, was up from 3.8 percent in 2006 and topped forecasts for an increase of 5.2 percent.

Hannover Re, one of the biggest reinsurers in the world, said its fourth-quarter profit rose as lower disaster-related claims and taxes offset a decline in investment results and premium income. The company, based in Hannover, earned 144.4 million euros ($222 million) in the October-December period, up 7.5 percent from 134.3 million euros a year earlier. Its gross premium income slipped to 1.8 billion euros ($2.7 billion) from 2 billion euros a year earlier.

An article and headline on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Feb. 20 about the development of movie theaters with restaurants and other upscale features misstated the 2007 statistics for admissions to movie theaters in the United States and Canada and referred incorrectly to the status of the industry. Total admissions were 1.4 billion, not 1.39 billion, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. This figure was up 0.36 percent from 2006, not down 4 percent. Consequently attendance was not at a 10-year low, and cinemas are not using these new features to “stem attendance losses.”.

The Langen Journal article last Thursday, about a three-star restaurant in Langen, Germany, that reflects a surprising increase in the country’s haute cuisine misidentified an eating-induced malady attributed partly to the worsening nutritional habits of low-income Germans. It is Type 2 diabetes — not juvenile diabetes, also known as Type 1 diabetes, which is believed caused by an immune system disorder.

The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about coverage of the Eliot Spitzer scandal, referred incompletely to the departure of Mike Barnicle from The Boston Globe in 1998. In addition to having been accused of plagiarism, he was also suspected of having fabricated material in a column for The Globe. (Mr. Barnicle was cited in the column with other cable television commentators who have weathered their own scandals.).

An article on Sunday about the victory by Bill Foster in a special election in Illinois for a seat in the House of Representatives misstated Mr. Foster’s business involvement with a theater lighting company. He co-founded the company with his brother Fred; he was not the sole founder. (The error first appeared last Thursday in an article previewing the election.).

A picture caption on Tuesday with a theater review of “27 Rue de Fleurus” at Urban Stages, using information provided by a publicist, misidentified the actress shown on the left. She is Susan Haefner — not Sarah Chalfy, another cast member.

The Langen Journal article last Thursday, about a three-star restaurant in Langen, Germany, that reflects a surprising increase in the country’s haute cuisine misidentified an eating-induced malady attributed partly to the worsening nutritional habits of low-income Germans. Because of an editing error, an article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about museum directors who leave after the completion of expansion projects described the status of two directors incorrectly. Marc Wilson, director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., and Graham Beal, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, have not left their positions.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the rising price of diesel misstated the amount of diesel and gasoline used by Americans in 2007. They used about 3.395 billion barrels of gasoline, not 3.395 billion gallons, and about 1.55 billion barrels of diesel and heating oil, not 1.55 billion gallons. (At 42 gallons to the barrel, the correct figures in gallons are 143 billion gallons of gasoline and 65 billion gallons of diesel and heating oil.) The article also misquoted Jim Frieze, equipment director for O & S Trucking of Springfield, Mo., who commented on the driving practices of some truckers. He said that gearshifts that take the engine over 1,800 r.p.m. — not 8,000 r.p.m. — waste fuel.

A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of sea level changes over the last 80 million years misidentified the journal in which the findings appeared. It was Science, not Nature.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the politics of a meat recall, misidentified the location of the Westland/Hallmark Meat Company, where an animal rights organization filmed cows being abused. It is in Chino in Southern California, between Los Angeles and San Bernardino; it is not in Chico, in the northern Sacramento Valley.).

The founder of the “Girls Gone Wild” empire, Joe Francis, pleaded no contest to charges of child abuse and prostitution in Panama City under an agreement that allowed him to walk free after nearly a year in jail. The hearing in Bay County State Court resolved a 2003 case involving the filming of under-age girls. Mr. Francis, 34, said he pleaded guilty “just to get out of jail.” He pleaded no contest to one count of felony child abuse and two counts of misdemeanor prostitution.

Two men were charged with first-degree murder in the killing of the student body president at the University of North Carolina. One of the men, Demario J. Atwater, 21, left, of Durham, was arrested and ordered held without bond. The police said they were searching for the second person, 17-year-old Lawrence A. Lovett Jr. Chief Brian Curran of the Chapel Hill Police Department would not say which of the men had shot and killed Eve Carson, 22, of Athens, Ga., who was found a week ago lying on a street near campus.

Fifteen people were stranded for three days on a 24-foot vessel off the Pacific Coast after an apparent human smuggling effort from Mexico went bad, the authorities said. Two were arrested for investigation of smuggling. Their craft was found eight or nine miles offshore, said Vince Bond, a spokesman for Customs and Border Protection. There was no food or water on board. No one was seriously injured. Their nationalities were not immediately known.

A woman threw her two children from a Dallas freeway overpass in the morning rush before leaping off herself, the police said, but all three survived the 22-foot fall. The woman, Khandi Busby, 27, and her sons, ages 8 and 6, were hospitalized but able to talk to officers.. Ms. Busby could face attempted murder charges, Sgt. Gil Cerda said.

Proper upkeep would probably have prevented the explosion last month at a Georgia sugar refinery that killed 12 people, a federal safety official said. The Feb. 7 accident at the Imperial Sugar plant outside Savannah fits a widely understood pattern of dust explosions, said the official, William Wright, a member of the federal Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board.

Mexico’s national team will play exhibition games against China, Argentina and Peru in the United States as it prepares for the start of World Cup qualifying. El Tri will meet China at Seattle on April 16, Argentina at San Diego on June 4 and Peru at Chicago on June 8, Soccer United Marketing said.

Abby Wambach scored her 88th international goal to help the United States win the Algarve Cup for a record sixth time with a 2-1 victory against Denmark in Portugal. Wambach scored the winning goal in the 49th minute, sprinting down the right flank and breaking two tackles before exchanging passes with Natasha Kai and sending a low drive into the corner. Kai gave the Americans the lead with a header in the 14th minute, but Denmark’s Cathrine Sorensen scored in the 30th.

The suspected shooter in the murder of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor told the police that he and the other suspects burned their clothes in an attempt to cover up the crime. The statement by Eric Rivera Jr., 17, and those by two other suspects were released by prosecutors in Florida. All three statements were heavily redacted on a judge’s orders and do not contain outright confessions to the crime. But there are hints throughout of what happened and what led to the Nov. 26 shooting, which authorities say took place in a botched robbery attempt at Taylor’s Miami home.

Andy Roddick, the highest-ranked American player, will skip the Beijing Olympics, choosing instead to focus on preparing for the United States Open by playing in Washington at the hard-court Legg Mason Tennis Classic, which runs Aug. 11-17, the same dates as the Olympic tennis event. The United States Open begins Aug. 25.“My goal every summer is to win the U.S. Open,” Roddick said Wednesday in a statement released by Legg Mason organizers. “I have won the Legg Mason Tennis Classic three times and feel defending my title in Washington best prepares me for another Grand Slam title.”.

Autism Awareness, a $1,000 yearling who won last week’s El Camino Real Derby as a 62-to-1 underdog, has a knee injury that will keep him out of contention for the Kentucky Derby. To the Editor:.

“The Great Man,” a novel written by Kate Christensen and published by Doubleday, won the 2008 Pen/ Faulkner Award for Fiction. Described as the largest peer-juried prize for fiction in the United States, the award brings its winner $15,000. Ms. Christensen, whose book about a painter and the women in his life was chosen from nearly 350 novels and short-story collections written by Americans and published in the United States in 2007, will receive her prize at the 28th annual Pen/ Faulkner Award ceremony on May 10 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington. Prizes of $5,000 each will go to four finalists: Annie Dillard for “The Maytrees” (HarperCollins); David Leavitt for “The Indian Clerk” (Bloomsbury USA); T. M. McNally for “The Gateway: Stories” (Southern Methodist University Press) and Ron Rash for “Chemistry and Other Stories” (Picador USA). ... The Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award goes this year to Sonya Hartnett, an Australian who has written nearly 20 novels for children, young people and adults, Agence France-Presse reported. The prize, including $822,000, was established by the Swedish government and named for the creator of Pippi Longstocking. It will be presented by Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden in Stockholm on May 28.

Ned Rifkin, the under secretary for art at the Smithsonian Institution, will resign on April 11, the Smithsonian announced on Wednesday. Mr. Rifkin said he was stepping down in anticipation of the appointment of a new secretary sometime this month. The previous secretary, Lawrence M. Small, resigned last March after investigations into his personal spending. “I think it’s time to think about other things,” Mr. Rifkin said in an interview. “An institution with new leadership deserves to have the opportunity to restructure.” As the under secretary since 2004, Mr. Rifkin has overseen the Smithsonian’s art museums and organizations: the National Portrait Gallery; Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum; Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden; National Museum of African Art; the Smithsonian American Art Museum and Renwick Gallery; Archives of American Art; and Smithsonian Photography Initiative.

More than 31 million viewers watched the top 12 finalists perform on “American Idol” Tuesday night, down slightly from previous seasons, but still attracting more viewers to Fox than all the other broadcast networks combined, according to Nielsen. New viewers tuned in every half-hour of the performances, from 25.6 million at 8 to 31.6 million at 9:30 p.m. The two-hour broadcast averaged 29.3 million viewers and a 10.8 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Behind “Idol,” NBC’s programs fared best. “The Biggest Loser” averaged 7.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and a repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” was the second most popular show of the night, averaging 9.4 million viewers at 10 p.m. for NBC. On CBS, a repeat of “NCIS” attracted 8.6 million viewers, but many tuned out “Big Brother” at 9 and “Jericho” at 10 (5.9 million each). ABC’s sitcoms drew fewer than 5 million viewers, but the network showed life at 10 p.m. when a new installment of the “What Would You Do?” hidden-camera investigation show averaged 7.5 million viewers.

Papyless, an online book store in Japan, announced plans to sell digital versions of the work of Osamu Tezuka, known as the father of manga, Agence France-Presse reported. The works include “Astro Boy,” the atomic-powered robot, created in 1951 for the pages of a comic book, and “Black Jack,” the adventures of a doctor that drew on the medical training of Mr. Tezuka, who died in 1989. “Astro Boy” was developed into a cartoon, which was imported to the United States in 1963, and a CGI version is scheduled to hit the big screen in 2009. The online stories, at papy.co.jp/, will be available beginning on Tuesday and will cost about $1 to read a volume over two days.

A program exploring the arts through the lines and shapes of the artist Al Hirschfeld, above, was announced on Tuesday by the Al Hirschfeld Foundation and the New York City Department of Education. Called the Al Hirschfeld Project — after the artist most famous for his theatrical caricatures in The New York Times — the program will help public school arts teachers (grades K-12) educate students about the performing arts over the last century. The Hirschfeld curriculum was developed to complement the Department of Education’s Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, a set of standards outlining what students should know and be able to achieve in dance, music, theater and visual arts through high school.

A new album from the country star Alan Jackson toppled Janet Jackson from the top spot on the Billboard chart. Mr. Jackson’s “Good Time” (Arista Nashville), sold 119,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan estimated, dropping Ms. Jackson’s “Discipline” (Island Def Jam) into third place on sales of 57,000 albums. Climbing one notch from last week, Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” captured second place with sales of 65,000 copies. The rock band Flogging Molly and its new album, “Float” (SideOneDummy), took fourth place with sales of 48,000 and the Black Cowes’ “Warpaint” (Silver Arrow), selling 46,000 copies in its debut, was No. 5.

The prolific playwright Horton Foote turns 92 on Friday. In Chicago, where the Goodman Theater is running a Horton Foote Festival of plays, films and discussions through April 6, he is to appear on Monday night in connection with a screening of his films at the theater. ... The Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College, State University of New York, in Purchase, N.Y., plans to open a satellite museum opposite the New York Public Library in early 2009. Under an agreement with the SUNY College of Optometry, the museum will occupy 3,500 to 5,000 square feet of exhibition space on the ground floor of the college’s building at 33 West 42nd Street . ... Dawn Wells, above, who played the wholesome Mary Ann on “Gilligan’s Island,” is serving six months of unsupervised probation after a sheriff’s deputy in Idaho arrested her as she was driving home from a surprise birthday party in October, The Associated Press reported. The arresting officer, who described her driving as erratic, said he found half-smoked marijuana joints and two small cases for holding marijuana in the car. Ms. Wells, 69, said she had just given a ride to three hitchhikers and dropped them off when they began smoking. On Feb. 29 she was sentenced to five days in jail, fined $410.50 and placed on probation after pleading guilty to one count of reckless driving. Three misdemeanor counts, including possession of a controlled substance, were dropped.

Pivot, a console table with a slight profile, has a flexible fanlike structure that allows its drawers to open simultaneously. Each drawer is slightly taller in back, so it catches on the piece above, holding it in place; the back of the table attaches to a screw drilled into the wall. Shay Alkalay, the product designer who created the table with Yael Mer, his partner at Raw-Edges Design Studio in London, said he envisions it in an entrance hall. “You put in your eyeglasses and your mobile phone and your keys,” he said, “and in the morning, when you’re really rushed,” you can save time by opening both drawers at once. Pivot is 40 inches high and 31 inches wide, and comes in various shades of lacquered oak ($2,200) and in natural walnut ($2,350), at M2L, 215 East 58th Street, (212) 832-8222. ELAINE LOUIE.

Duane, a TriBeCa institution known for its for midcentury modern furniture, will hold a warehouse sale beginning next Wednesday. Merchandise includes vintage tables, chairs and lamps, at discounts of up to 70 percent off retail prices. A white Murano glass table lamp from the 1970s is marked down to $850 from $1,500 (above), and a 1960s Saarinen coffee table from Knoll with a round white marble top is reduced to $1,800 from $3,800. Other pieces include 1950s Drexel side tables with leather tops ($2,000 for a pair) and 1960s metal side chairs, painted gold ($4,000 for the pair). Through March 30 (except for Sunday, March 23) at 184 Duane Street (Hudson Street), (212) 625-8066. MARIANNE ROHRLICH.
