JESSELSON--Erica. The National Yiddish Theatre-Folksbiene wishes to express its deep sadness on the passing of Erica Jesselson. Erica was a longtime friend and supporter of our work. We wish to express sincerest sympathies to Michael and Linda, the children, and to her sister Lucy and the entire family. Koved ir likhtikn ondenk. We will miss her. Zalmen Mlotek, Artistic Director Jeffrey Wiesenfeld, Chairman of the Board JESSELSON--Erica. The Yeshiva University Museum is in mourning. We have lost our founder, the source of our inspiration, the towering personality that was Erica Jesselson, our shining star, whose brilliance, creativity, goodness, and personal piety piloted us for more than three decades. She was our lodestarshe showed us how to live, how to dream, and how to achieve-and everything we have become is a reflection of her remarkable persona. She will live forever in our hearts and minds, and in the hearts and minds of the tens of thousands whom she helped, guided, advised and influenced, in the Jewish world and beyond. May her soul be bound up in the bond of eternal life, and may her memory always be for a blessing. Sylvia A. Herskowitz, Director and Staff Theodore N. Mirvis, Vice Chair Museum Board of Directors JESSELSON--Erica. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Erica Jesselson. Erica and her late husband, Ludwig, were giants of Jewish philanthropy, providing strong leadership and role models to respond to the needs of Jewish communities in New York, in Israel, and throughout the world. Erica was a builder of Israel, a passionate advocate of strengthening Jewish education, and a patron of the Jewish arts and Judaica. The Jesselsons each escaped Europe during World War II and never forgot their fellow Jews and the less fortunate. For decades, members of the Jesselson family have been dedicated supporters and active volunteers for UJA-Federation. Continuing the values of his parents, the Jesselsons' son Michael serves on our Board of Directors and is chair of Planned Giving & Endowments. We extend our deepest sympathies to Erica's sons, Michael and his wife, Linda; Daniel and his wife, Yael; and Benjamin and his wife, Phyllis; to Erica's many grandchildren; and to the entire Jesselson family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO JESSELSON--Erica. Bar-Ilan University and its American Friends expresses deepest sorrow on the passing of our esteemed founder and matriarch, Mrs. Erica Jesselson. Together with her late husband, Ludwig, Z''L, Erica blazed a path of unparalleled achievement for Bar-Ilan University in the United States and throughout the world. Founders and benefactors of Bar-Ilan's world renowned Jesselson Institute for Advanced Torah Studies, the Jesselson's were in the forefront of a wide range of worthwhile projects at the University, especially during its formative years. Mrs. Jesselson provided a unique, creative energy to every activity at the University since its founding. The Jesselson family have been among the most prominent families and supporters of Jewish life, Jewish organizations and Israel for decades. We extended our heartfelt condolences to her devoted sons Benjamin, Michael (Chairman of our American Board of Trustees), Daniel and the entire family. May they be comforted among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman Chancellor, Emeritus Professor Moshe Kaveh President Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees Peter Rzepka, President, American Board of Trustees Mark D. Medin Executive V.P. and CEO American Friends of Bar-Ilan University Yehuda Halevy, Executive V.P. Emeritus, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University JESSELSON--Erica. The American Jewish Historical Society mourns the passing of Erica Jesselson, a longtime patron of our work and advocate for Jewish historical memory. Erica's contributions to Jewish culture, the world of art and the advancement of human understanding are her great legacy. We wish comfort to Michael, Linda and the Jesselson family. Daniel R. Kaplan, President Sidney Lapidus, Chairman Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Emeritus JESSELSON--Erica. American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's Board of Directors, staff and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra mourn the loss of Erica Jesselson, a Principal Benefactor and esteemed member of our American and International Boards. Erica dedicated her life to the enhancement of Jewish education, art and culture. Her love of music and Israel was unparalleled and her intellectual leadership and generosity will ensure the IPO programs for generations to come. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Zubin Mehta and Itzhak Perlman, Co-Chairmen Elaine R. Wolfensohn, President David A. Hirsch Charles I. Petschek Lauren Veronis, Vice Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot, Executive Director JESSELSON--Erica. The Center for Jewish History mourns the passing of our board member and vice chairman, Erica Jesselson, whose dedication and support was instrumental in the founding of the Center. We are eternally grateful for her intelligence, generosity and commitment to the Jewish community. We will miss our dear friend and leader. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Michael and Linda and to the entire Jesselson family. Bruce Slovin, Chairman, Center for Jewish History JESSELSON--Erica. Our deepest sorrow to Michael, Linda, Samuel, Roni, Jonathan, Mya and the entire Jesselson family. Ira and Diane Riklis JESSELSON--Erica. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Erica Jesselson. We will miss her lifelong passion, dedication and commitment to Jewish education, Israel and Jewish culture. She was a true woman of valor. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Burton P. Resnick, Chairman, Building Committee Daniel Reingold, President & CEO David Pomeranz, Associate Exec. Director JESSELSON--Erica. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of its ''matriarch'' Erica Jesselson, a beneficent philanthropist, passionate supporter of education and the arts, and singular Jewish communal leader whose generosity benefited a wide spectrum of humanitarian causes in the U.S., Israel, and around the world. Mrs. Jesselson and her late husband, Ludwig, made an indelible mark on the Jewish community and the arts and culture of New York. Mrs. Jesselson was the visionary and driving force behind the establishment of the Yeshiva University Museum which she and her husband founded and endowed. She served as the Chair of its Board from 1973 until her passing. She also played a critical role on behalf of the Yeshiva University high schools. Yeshiva University was able to acquire a number of rare materials (including Jewish Americana), publish a catalog of its incunabula and make its Judaica collection accessible to students and scholars through gifts from the Jesselsons and the Jesselson Family Trust. In 1983, Mrs. Jesselson was presented with the Distinguished Service Award by the University and in May 1998, she was the recipient of an Honorary Degree of Humane Letters at Commencement. The Jesselson family remained close to Yeshiva University and was an ardent supporter of its numerous schools for more than four decades. To honor her husband's memory, Mrs. Jesselson joined with other family members to establish the Ludwig Jesselson Kollel Chaverim (Institute of Advanced Talmudic Study) at YU's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Jesselsons' three sons, Michael (Linda) and Daniel (Yael), both residents of New York, and Benjamin (Phyllis), who resides in Israel, and by numerous grandchildren and greatgrandchildren as well as her sister, Lucy Lang. Michael has served on Yeshiva University's Board of Trustees since 1993. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Yeshiva University High Schools Miriam Goldberg, Chair, Board of Trustees JESSELSON--Erica. The Board and staff of the Gesher Foundation mourn the passing of our esteemed Board member and dear friend, Erica Jesselson. Erica, and her late husband Ludwig were founding members of Gesher and fervently supported building Jewish identity in Israel and around the world. She was a woman of grace and passion whose acts of charity and kindness have touched many. May her entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Danny Tropper, President and Founder Suzanne D. Jaffe, Chairman of the Board JESSELSON--Erica. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum mourn the death of our Founder and Board member, Erica Jesselson. She and Luddy played a pivotal role in the growth of the Museum's Judaica Department. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Jesselson family. Stephen S. Lash President, AFIM Judy Steinhardt Co-Chair, AFIM Board James S. Snyder Anne and Jerome Fisher, Director, IM Monique Birenbaum Executive Director, AFIM JESSELSON--Erica. We wish to express our deepest sorrow on the loss of our dear friend Erica, a most extraordinary person. We cherish our memories of the last 25 years we spent together on holidays with our children Michael and Linda and our grandchildren Samuel, Roni, Jonathan and Maya, the many trips we went on and our fun weekly card game. Our sincerest condolences to the entire Jesselson family. Egon and Lee Rausnitz

FLOWER--Robert E., 70, of Harrison, former Peekskill Councilman and ladieswear manufacturing executive died Tuesday, March 11 of lung cancer. He was President and CEO of Bliss Manufacturing Corporation and Nan Flower Lingerie of NYC and Peekskill, NY. Mr. Flower was also a City Councilman in Peekskill for eight years during the Pataki and Jackson administrations. A graduate of the Wharton School of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Flower was a former Chairman of the Peekskill Industrial Development Agency and was awarded a Distinguished Service Award in 2007 for his 21 years of service to the Agency and the City of Peekskill. A former President of the Peekskill-Cortlandt Chamber of Commerce and of the Paramount Center for the Arts, Mr. Flower was sought after by many organizations for his business acumen and his generosity of spirit. He sat on the Board of Directors of the First Federal Savings and Loan and was given the NYS Mental Health Award for giving employment to the mentally disabled. Over the years, Mr. Flower employed a thousand people from the Hudson Valley region in his Peekskill factory and in other locations in Puerto Rico, Georgia, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. A staunch opponent of NAFTA, in a NY Times article about the Act before it came into existence, Mr. Flower predicted it would be the end of clothing manufacturing in the United States. A prediction, unfortunately, fulfilled. A veteran who was a Captain in the U.S. Army, Mr. Flower is survived by his wife of 18 years, Claire Palermo Flower, his children Bruce of Wappingers Falls, Michele of Port Chester, his granddaughter Brianna, as well as his sisters, Frances Gochman of Lake Worth, Florida and Nancy Dvorkin of Boca Raton, Florida. Funeral services will be held Friday, at 10am at First Hebrew Congregation in Peekskill. Donations may be made to the Rotary Club of Peekskill-College Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 344, Peekskill, NY 10566.

The crossword puzzle on Monday gave an erroneous clue for 69 Across, seeking the answer ''Thee.'' The clue, ''For whom the bell tolls, in a John Donne poem,'' was incorrect because the well-known passage is from Donne's Devotions Upon Emergent Occasions, Meditation XVII, published in 1624; the phrase was not written as part of a poem.

As the Democratic primary race moves to Pennsylvania, an analysis of the television advertising spending in Ohio may offer a few lessons. About $8 million was spent on television advertisements there for Democrats, with 15 percent of that from outside groups like labor unions and new 527 organizations. According to an examination by the Wisconsin Advertising Project, based on data from the Campaign Media Analysis Group, a division of TNS Media Intelligence, of advertisements on local TV stations, Senator Barack Obama laid out about $4.4 million for more than 10,000 spots in Ohio, compared with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's $2.3 million for more than 6,000 spots. (Those figures cover from Feb. 1 through the primary, March 4.)

DECTER--Ethel, nee Hoffman, of Montclair, New Jersey and Amagansett, New York, died on March, 10 2008. Her capacity for friendship and loyalty, and her compassionate commitment to the well-being of her family, friends and clients will make her sorely missed. We treasure her zest for life, her intelligence, and admire her courage as she battled breast cancer. She was a graduate of Cornell University, had a Masters of Social Work from NYU, as well as a post-Master's certificate as a clinician. She built a thriving practice at the Montclair Counseling Center, where she was a beloved and admired therapist for 25 years. She leaves behind her devoted and adoring husband of 44 years, Dr. Julian Decter, her children Benjamin, of Los Angeles, and Catherine Sim of Montclair, New Jersey, her brother, Dr. Joel Hoffman, of New York City, her children-in-law, Jackie Sloan and Edward Sim, and her four grandchildren, Addie and Leo Decter, Lucas and Skylar Sim. A memorial service will be held at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey, on Friday March 14, at 11am. Donations in her memory can be made to the Ethel Decter Memorial Fund, Montclair Counseling Center, 183 Inwood Avenue, Montclair, NJ. Her life was as a blessing for us all and she will remain in our hearts forever, in our children, in our vision, and wherever there is good and beauty.

COLVIN--Dr. Stephen. The faculty and staff of the Department of Surgery at NYU School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the sudden and untimely death of Dr. Stephen Colvin. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Helane, his children, Laurel, Heather, Sean, Mikaela, and his entire family. Dr. Colvin supremely exemplified three highly commendable traits. He was: A devoted husband and a fanatically loving father; A brilliant theoretical, tactical and technical cardiac surgeon; A friend of incomparable magnitude, loyalty and generosity. He was an indefatigable flame who illuminated with his visionary approaches to minimally invasive cardiac surgery and pioneered techniques that saved thousands of lives. He educated and trained a generation of cardiac surgeons who disseminated Dr. Colvin's methods throughout all parts of the United States and many corners of the world. He was a maverick who was never complacent, never accepted mediocrity and made it his credo to always question. Accepted techniques were dissected under the microscope and discarded when alternative methods to performing surgery more efficiently and with better results were discovered. The beneficiary was always the patient. There was no greater joy in his life than sharing his discoveries with others. He was a motivator who could persuade, but could also be persuaded if the scientific facts proved otherwise. He was an inspiration to all those around him. The magnitude of our loss is immeasurable. H. Leon Pachter, M.D. The George David Stewart Professor and Chairman of Surgery, NYU School of Medicine COLVIN--Stephen B., on Saturday, March 8, 2008. Beloved husband of Helane Colvin, RN, NP, devoted father of Laurel (David) Tanier, RN, NP; Heather (Andrew) Colvin Kaufman, M.D.; Sean Isaiah Colvin and Mikaela Pearl Colvin. Cherished brother of Jody (Miri) Colvin, loving grandfather of Julia Tanier, Naomi Tanier and Samantha Kaufman and son of the late Irwin and Irene Colvin. Dr. Colvin was the founding Chairman of the Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery at NYU Medical Center, an internationally renowned leader in cardiothoracic surgery and co-founder of Project Kids Worldwide. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Cardiovascular Research Fund, NYU Medical Center, or to Project Kids Worldwide, both at 530 First Avenue, Suite 9V, New York, NY 10016.

Bear Stearns has gotten a temporary lifeline from the Federal Reserve and J.P. Morgan Chase. In the long term, though, its independence is in serious doubt.
At the end of this week, Bear Stearns is apparently finding itself a victim of rumors turned to reality.
Not since the near-collapse of Long Term Capital Management has Bear Stearns swung so low.

Bear Stearns said Friday that J.P. Morgan Chase had agreed to provide credit facilities for up to 28 days to help it deal with liquidity problems brought on by rumors of a cash crunch. The Federal Reserve will also have a hand in stabilizing Bear, providing J.P. Morgan with “back-to-back, non-recourse” financing for the facilities through its discount window, J.P. Morgan said in a news release.
Investors wiped another 7 percent or so off Bear Stearns‘ stock price on Thursday amid concern that it might run out of cash to pay its trading and financing partners.

Toward the end of a panel discussion on Wednesday night, Jimmy Breslin was talking about the legendary city columnist Murray Kempton, when he remembered Mr. Kempton’s outrage at a New York politician who had been caught paying for sex in Washington. According to Mr. Breslin, Mr. Kempton, who died in 1997 at age 79, remarked, “He’s spending that money outside his district!” Many could supposedly say the same about Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Mr. Breslin added, partly drowned out by the audience’s laughter. This week, amid all the scrutiny of Mr. Spitzer’s words and actions, past and present, one matter that has gotten some renewed attention is a case from 2004, when Mr. Spitzer was attorney general, in which he dealt harshly with a prostitution ring closer to home.

In a flurry of meetings with legislative leaders, news conferences and briefings, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson began quickly laying the groundwork for when he is formally sworn in as governor on Monday. At a news conference in Albany, he said he would try to govern through consensus and declined to rule out an income tax increase. Then, he took questions from an overflow crowd of reporters. The tone Mr. Paterson set in his appearances was the most marked shift from Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who favored stern and high-flying oratory over self-deprecating humor.

Lloyd Constantine, a mentor, friend and senior adviser to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has submitted his resignation but has offered to stay on until April 4, or slightly longer, to help Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, who will be sworn as governor in on Monday. Mr. Constantine’s resignation letter was dated Wednesday — the same day he announced that Mr. Spitzer announced he would resign — but was made available today.

On Wednesday, when Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced that he would resign, the American Foundation for the Blind issued a news release stating that Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson is “poised to become the first legally blind governor in United States history.” Countless news organizations, including The New York Times, repeated the same description, while also noting that Mr. Paterson will be New York State’s first black chief executive and only the fourth black governor of a state in the nation’s history.

Last night's "In Ballo in Maschera" benefit at the Frick Collection drew a predictably attractive crowd of men in dinner jackets and ladies in varying states of formality. The party's fancy name (translation: the masked ball), and corresponding dress code, made a veiled reference to a special painting on loan to the museum - a 16th century portrait of a mysterious woman painted by the Italian Renaissance master Parmigianino. While the invitation (above) decreed a dress code of "black tie e maschera," the uptown crowd's willingness to mask themselves varied. Over the course of the evening we witnessed all types - from The Classicist (in a Venetian-style eye mask con handle) to The Sex Kitten (a ribbon of fancy black lace tied over the eyes), from The Psycho (a terrifying translucent iteration of the "Eyes Wide Shut" mask) to The Jolly Enthusiast (a woman in a Vegas-style eye mask, a rhapsody in blue feathers). And, regrettably, plenty in the category of The Wimp (senza maschera).

The TED spread is the difference between the interest rate banks charge each other on 3-month loans (3-month LIBOR) and the interest rate on 3-month U.S. Treasury bills. It's a measure of financial jitters. If banks believe that their peers are solid, they should be willing to lend each other money on almost the same terms as money lent to Uncle Sam. When they start demanding a big interest rate premium, that's a sign of fear.

The Altai Republic in southern Siberia is notoriously quiet -- a mountainous territory of rural farmers, sheep herders and bee keepers largely free of major urban development. Occasionally, though, chunks of unwanted modernity in the form of rocket fragments shatter the pastoral serenity, spooking residents, wrecking crops and killing livestock when they crash to earth.

As much as I enjoy watching "Top Chef" and effortlessly rattling off choice entries in the foodie vernacular - ceviche, amuse bouche, molecular gastronomy - I'm not what you would call an adventurous eater. I convulse at the mere scent of banana and nothing embodies hell on earth for me quite like the texture of rice pudding. For better or worse, I was raised in a home where chicken was the norm and exotic dishes were discreetly fed to the dog as quickly as they were placed on the table. (I'm remembering one instance in particular involving a rice-and-beef-stuffed pumpkin so vile even Sparky wouldn't eat it.) As far as I can tell, I am the typical, boring American eater; I like cheesy, crispy, fatty, salty or sweet food made with ingredients I can pronounce. I crave preservatives and chemically enhanced juices; I crave red-white-and-blue-dyed snack cakes filled with liquefied marshmallow substitute. High fructose corn syrup figuratively - and probably literally - courses through my veins. So you can imagine my growing distress at America's growing palette.

How many people will inhabit the planet before population growth finally levels off? The figure most commonly used is 9 billion by 2050, up from 6.7 billion today -- an extraordinary number, considering that there were only 1 billion humans in 1830. (Right now there are a billion people just between the ages of 10 and 19.) But there's a growing debate about this projection and what it means.

The origins of French toast and torrijas are undoubtedly the same: yet another way to make good use of bread that's no longer fresh. Though torrijas, like French toast, can be served at breakfast, they can also be a knockout dessert. They are as moist as a good bread pudding, nearly as rich as a custard, as crunchy as a churro and hot enough to stand up to maple syrup or honey.

Steve Tisch has scored a remarkable honors double, winning an Academy Award as producer of “Forrest Gump” and a Vince Lombardi Trophy as co-owner of the Super Bowl champion Giants. “I think the Lombardi was probably more satisfying,” Tisch said.“If you look at how a movie is made,” he said at the IMG World Congress of Sports, “it’s scripted, it’s edited, it’s shot over a 70-, 80-, 90-day shooting schedule. It’s very different from a live football game. It’s unscripted. There’s no editing.”.

The jockey Rafael Bejarano was thrown headfirst to the ground in a spill during the eighth race at Santa Anita in California. He was unseated when his mount Parisian Art apparently had a fatal heart attack inside the eighth pole. Bejarano had eased the 3-year-old gelding to the back of the 12-horse field when Parisian Art suddenly dropped to the ground and Bejarano fell off. Bejarano, a 25-year-old Peruvian, is Santa Anita’s leading rider with 60 wins at the winter meeting. He led the nation’s jockeys in 2004 with 455 wins.

A front-page article on Sunday about the Senate record of Barack Obama referred incorrectly in some copies to his position on a drawdown of troops from Iraq. After joining the Senate in 2005 Mr. Obama spoke in favor of a drawdown, including in a speech on Nov. 22 of that year. He did not propose a drawdown “only after he was running for president and polls showed voters favoring it.” (What he did do after becoming a candidate was to propose legislation calling for a drawdown.).

Two people received the maximum allowable sentences for taking part in the torture of a young black woman this summer. The defendants, Karen Burton, 46, and Frankie Brewster, 49, pleaded guilty last month for their roles in the kidnapping and assault of the woman last summer in Big Creek. They were among seven white defendants charged in the case. The judge in the case, Roger Perry, of Logan County Circuit Court, sentenced Ms. Burton to 10 years for violating the woman’s civil rights. She also received separate 2- to 10-year sentences for assault charges. Mr. Brewster received 10-to-25-years for second-degree sexual assault.

The family of a deceased illegal immigrant who said he was denied medical care for cancer can sue the federal government, a federal judge ruled. The man, Francisco Castaneda, a Salvadoran immigrant, was denied a biopsy for a painful lesion on his penis for 11 months, despite doctors’ recommendations, according to records cited by the judge. He later received a diagnosis of penile cancer and died on Feb. 26 at age 36. Mr. Castaneda had been in immigration custody because he was in the country illegally. He told staff members at the San Diego Correctional Facility in March 2006, about the lesion, the judge, Dean Pregerson, of Federal District Court, wrote in a decision released Tuesday. A physician assistant requested a biopsy as did several doctors. But, Judge Pregerson wrote, a doctor at the federal Division of Immigration Health Services would not admit Mr. Castaneda to a hospital, saying her agency considered it “an elective outpatient procedure.”.

PERSILY--Nancy Alfred. No one, no one, no one embraced the joy of life more than you. No one understood the gift of life as you did. We joyed in the warmth of your laughter; the bounty of your table; the generosity of your caring spirit. We danced in the circles of your friendships -infinite in diameter, interlocking generations. We beheld your heart-filled love of family. Indeed, you lived a lifetime turning strangers into friends, friends into families. How lucky, how blessed we all have been. Alice and Peter Berglas

With a Pentecostal minister at the helm, the committee planning the Democratic National Convention in Denver this August is determined to demonstrate that the party has overcome its squeamishness about religion, and that its big tent will accommodate religious believers. For the first time, the Democratic convention will be kicked off by an interfaith prayer service, on Aug. 24 (although still to be decided is who will lead the prayers and where they will be held). And in another first, there will be a caucus during the convention explicitly for ''people of faith,'' to meet at the same time as the caucuses for African-Americans, Asians, Hispanics and other groups. (Delegates who are, for example, black AND religious will have to make a choice.)

COLVIN--Dr. Stephen. The faculty and staff of the Department of Surgery at NYU School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the sudden and untimely death of Dr. Stephen Colvin. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Helane, his children, Laurel, Heather, Sean, Mikaela, and his entire family. Dr. Colvin supremely exemplified three highly commendable traits. He was: A devoted husband and a fanatically loving father; A brilliant theoretical, tactical and technical cardiac surgeon; A friend of incomparable magnitude, loyalty and generosity. He was an indefatigable flame who illuminated with his visionary approaches to minimally invasive cardiac surgery and pioneered techniques that saved thousands of lives. He educated and trained a generation of cardiac surgeons who disseminated Dr. Colvin's methods throughout all parts of the United States and many corners of the world. He was a maverick who was never complacent, never accepted mediocrity and made it his credo to always question. Accepted techniques were dissected under the microscope and discarded when alternative methods to performing surgery more efficiently and with better results were discovered. The beneficiary was always the patient. There was no greater joy in his life than sharing his discoveries with others. He was a motivator who could persuade, but could also be persuaded if the scientific facts proved otherwise. He was an inspiration to all those around him. The magnitude of our loss is immeasurable. H. Leon Pachter, M.D. The George David Stewart Professor and Chairman of Surgery, NYU School of Medicine

Chrysler plans to halt virtually all operations for two weeks in July as part of its effort to cut costs and return to profitability. Summer shutdowns are longstanding traditions in the auto industry so plants can be retooled for the new model year, but they primarily involve only hourly workers. Chrysler told its salaried employees Thursday that, except for those who keep working in ''business-critical activities,'' they must use vacation time during the shutdown.

EVANS--Alfred J., 86, of New Milford, NJ. Born on February 28, 1922, died on March 13, 2008. Born in London, England, he was the son of Alfred and Ada (nee: Quick) Evans. A veteran, he served in the Royal Air Force (RAF) during the Second World War, where he flew Lancaster Bombers in the European theater. He immigrated to New York after the war. After living in Brooklyn, he moved to New Milford in 1955. He served on the New Milford Borough Council and the Planning Board, and was active in the New Milford Presbyterian Church. He worked for close to 40 years in the composing room of the New York Times, retiring as a composing room foreman in 1988. He was an accomplished cricketer (Staten Island Cricket Club); and played semi-professional soccer in England. He had a lifelong love of golf and played many of the public courses of Bergen County. He was preceded in death by his wife Reby, who died in 1992. He was devoted to his family and is survived by his daughter Pamela and her husband Bob of Miami, Florida, son Keith and his wife Lois of Glen Rock, NJ, son Bruce and his wife Terri of Natick, MA, son Timothy and his wife Amy of Portland, OR, son Geoffrey and his wife Patti of Chester, NJ, friend Ruth Todd of Monroe Township, NJ, formerly of New Milford, sister Mary Garson of Ashtead, England; an seven grandchildren: Maggie, Samantha, Deanna, Caitlin, Rachael, Nicholas, and Olivia. Relatives and friends are invited to a Memorial Service at the New Milford Presbyterian Church, 737 River Road, New Milford, NJ on Saturday, March 15, 2008 at 4pm. Cremation to be held in private. Services by Boulevard Funeral Home, New Milford. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, attn: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780.

FRACKMAN--Noel S., on March 10, 2008. After enjoying life to the fullest and facing death with great courage and dignity. Beloved wife of the late Richard B. Frackman. Loving mother of Dru Pyne and her husband David. Cherished grandmother of Dylan F. Pyne. Dear sister of Carol Plaut. A respected art historian, scholar, writer, and professor with a lifelong passion for 20th Century Art. She earned a M.A. from Sarah Lawrence College in English Literature and a M.A. and Ph.D. in Art History from the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University. She was an art critic for the Patent Trader Newspaper and the Scarsdale Inquirer, contributing editor for Arts Magazine, author of numerous catalogs including ''John Storrs'', for the Whitney Museum of American Art. For 19 years she was a faculty member at Purchase College, State University of New York. Her warmth, intelligence, independent spirit and youthful enthusiasm will be missed by all. Funeral services today 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Purchase College Foundation/Richard B. and Dr. Noel S. Frackman Graduate Program in Art History, 725 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, New York 10577.

ST. PATRICK'S DAY FESTIVITIES Sometime during the fifth century, the teenager who would become St. Patrick was captured in his native Britain and forced into slavery in Ireland. He escaped, only to return as a missionary and convert virtually the entire country to Christianity. March 17 -- the day he is said to have died -- was observed first with a feast, then with parades and now with a series of pub crawls featuring drinks tinted a radioactive shade of green. For those in New York looking to celebrate the patron saint of Ireland but who prefer a more entertaining activity than, say, monitoring the shade of your tongue as it progresses from lime to emerald with each successive beer, there are plenty of options. The first, on Sunday, is an open day at the Irish Arts Center. For the seventh year, the center has compiled a free sampler of Irish culture.

WILKINS--John J. III, of Athens, Georgia died on Tuesday, March 11, 2008. His wife Lovat Anderson Wilkins predeceased him on March 22, 2007. Survivors include his son, John J. Wilkins IV and daughter-in-law Pamela Hall Wilkins; his daughter Ellen Wilkins Wiley and son-in-law Floyd Murray Buck Wiley III; and two grandchildren, all of Atlanta; and his brother Thomas Hart Wilkins of Athens, Georgia. Mr. Wilkins graduated from Avon Old Farms School in 1952. He earned a BBA degree from the University of Georgia in 1957, where he was a member of Chi Phi Fraternity, Sphinx, and Gridiron. Mr. Wilkins followed his father and grandfather in the apparel manufacturing business they began 1907. Wilkins Industries, which he established in 1969, became one of the nation's largest manufacturers of women's jeanswear with offices in New York, London, and Athens, Georgia. The company was the first business in Athens to integrate African American women into the industrial workforce. Mr. Wilkins was a founder in 1966 of Athens Academy college preparatory school and served as chairman of the Board of Trustees until his death. Named in his honor in 1996 is the John J. Wilkins III Upper School Campus. Mr. Wilkins was a member of the Piedmont Driving Club and the Commerce Club in Atlanta and the University Club in New York City. Services for Mr. Wilkins are scheduled for 2pm on March 14 at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Athens, Georgia, with burial in Oconee Hill Cemetery.

'CAI GUO-QIANG: I WANT TO BELIEVE' Among the members of a certain demographic (O.K., my son and his 9-year-old friends), the prospect of a Sunday afternoon at an art museum is about as attractive as doing homework. If your children are similarly disposed, drag them to this recently opened exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum and park them in front of a video of Mr. Cai's ''explosion events.'' Crack-crack-crack-crack-crack! go the strings of firecrackers outlining the Taiwan Province Museum of Art. Ba-boom! Ba-boom! go the exploding shells at Edinburgh Castle. Cool, go the boys sitting cross-legged on the floor, smiles spreading across their faces. Ah, young art lovers are born.

THOROLD DICKINSON'S WORLD OF CINEMA Here's a fine opportunity to go spelunking in the perennially underestimated British cinema. The director Thorold Dickinson (1903-84) made only a handful of features and shorts during his career, which concluded with a long stint (at the Slade School of Fine Art in London) as Britain's first officially appointed professor of film. He remains best known for two rip-roaring thrillers he considered commercial quickies: the tense and claustrophobic 1940 version of Patrick Hamilton's stage play ''Gaslight'' and the genuinely creepy ghost story ''The Queen of Spades'' (1949). Both films will be shown in a weeklong retrospective of Dickinson's work that begins on Wednesday under the auspices of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Both happen to star the Austrian actor Anton Walbrook (''The Red Shoes'') as a schemer who seduces a naïve young woman in his drive to realize uncontrollable obsessions: the possession of a set of rubies in ''Gaslight'' (Wednesday and March 23, also starring Diana Wynyard, above) and of the Devil's own method of winning at cards in ''Spades'' (March 21 and March 22).

BRUCE NAUMAN: 'DRAWINGS FOR INSTALLATIONS' Ask almost anyone for a short list of the most influential contemporary artists, and Bruce Nauman's name will be there. This survey of drawings related to his architecturally scaled installations, ranging from 1968 to the present, suggests why. Some are preliminary sketches for later completed projects. Others are second-thought variations made after a piece was done. Still others -- a series of studies for underground installations, for example -- are hard-core conceptual projects realized only on paper. Above, ''Untitled (Drain 1/Drain 2),'' from 1978. In most cases the planned installation is based on the construction of a plain, empty, oddly configured space in some way designed to elicit paranoia, boredom and amusement in varying degrees. We are invited to inch sideways down a narrow space between walls. Or to walk down a corridor that hits a dead end when the walls meet in a point. Or to enter a cubicle flooded by a jaundice-yellow light that makes us more and more uneasy the longer we stay.

What do we get out of looking at anonymous snapshots? Snapshots -- small prints with basic compositions, smiling faces and commonplace subject matter -- have not traditionally interested professional photographers and art historians. But in recent years scholars have started taking such photographs much more seriously, not only as revealing artifacts of American society but also as works of art in themselves. Since 2002, Frank Maresca, a Brooklyn-born photographer and art dealer who specializes in the folk art of self-taught and ''outsider'' artists, has donated nearly 600 snapshots, most of them taken from the 1920s to the 1960s, to the Newark Museum. About 175 photographs from that collection are on view in an exhibition, ''Now Is Then: Snapshots From the Maresca Collection,'' which opened on Feb. 13 and runs through May 11.

8 P.M. (Sundance) BEFORE THE RAIN (1994) Milcho Manchevski directed this haunting, Oscar-nominated film in which three intertwined narratives explore violence and hatred between Macedonian Christians and ethnic Albanian Muslims. Grégoire Colin plays Kiril, a young Macedonian monk who has taken a vow of silence; Labina Mitevska is Zamira, a desperate Albanian girl; and Katrin Cartlidge is Anne, an English photo editor. At their center is Aleksandar Kirkov, played by Rade Serbedzija, above, a London-based war photographer who has returned home to Macedonia to find his village divided into hostile factions. Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, ''Mr. Manchevski tells his story elegantly and leaves his audience with a warning too strong to be ignored.'' 8 P.M. GERARD--Karen. The Board and staff of the Foundation for Child Development (FCD) celebrate the life of its longtime Board member and former Board Chair, Karen N. Gerard. She brought her experience in business and government to the Foundation's work. Karen also served as a member of the Finance Committee, Audit Committee, Centennial Celebration Committee, and advised in the design and relocation of the foundation's current offices. An independent thinker, she was a strong advocate for social justice in the foundation's grantmaking. She encouraged FCD to fund research on children living in immigrant families, and to develop the Child Well-Being Index, an indicator of how children are doing in America. Throughout her courageous struggle with declining health, she remained active in all aspects of the Foundation's work. Karen recently participated in FCD's annual Board dinner and program to discuss prospects for children in the federal budget. To the end, she remained committed to a society where all children have the opportunity to be their best. We will miss her distinctive and valued voice. P. Lindsay Chase-Lansdale, Chair Ruby Takanishi, President Foundation for Child Development

Board of Directors, The Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation RECHLER--Roger. The Long Island Kennel Club extends its heartfelt sympathy to Roger's wife Evelyn and the entire family. Barbara Miller, President RECHLER--Roger. The Rechler Family mourns the passing of Roger Rechler, a loving and devoted husband to Evelyn, father, grandfather, brother and uncle, a true renaissance man who made personal and professional contributions that shaped the landscape of Long Island, enhanced the world of real estate, and touched the lives of many. Co-founder of Reckson Associates and Managing Partner of Rechler Equity Properties, Rogers remarkable career was rivaled only by his accomplishments as a human being, including his passionate pursuit of a myriad of cultural interests that brought light and joy to the lives of all who surrounded him. His kindness, generosity and loyalty were returned with tremendous love from his family and a large community of friends who will forever keep his memory in their hearts. Born February 1942 and raised in the Bronx, Roger grew up in a loving family and developed a great entrepreneurial spirit. In 1968 Roger and his older brother Donald joined their father William in establishing Reckson Associates whose developments were bold and groundbreaking, changing the way commercial real estate was built and used on Long Island and throughout the region through innovations in upgrading industrial properties, reviving obsolete buildings, and setting new standards for office developments. Roger was the undisputed expert leading the construction and development of the companys many properties, executing each project with excellence. Joined by the third generation of Rechlers in the 1980s, Reckson Associates grew and eventually became a public company with more 25 million square feet of space across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Roger returned to his private entrepreneurial development roots as a Managing Partner with Rechler Equity Partners, the largest real estate developer, operator and owner on Long Island, with more than 100 properties. The opportunity to build beautiful and functional properties up to the end gave him tremendous satisfaction. Roger brought his trademark brilliance and distinction to all his undertakings, including the assembly of one of the largest collections of American classic literature; his accomplishments as a gourmet chef; his avid studies of architecture, landscape architecture, history, politics and sports; and leadership in the sport of purebred dogs. Roger was a towering figure in the breeding, showing and owning of dogs, specifically Afghan Hounds, since the early 1970s and making history for winning over 300 Best in Show awards with his family's 100 Grandeur champions. One of his champions achieved the ultimate distinction of being the number one show dog of all breeds in the United States in 1995 and a Westminster Kennel Club Group Winner. Roger will forever be known for the foundations of family and friendships he built just as beautifully as his buildings. He is survived by his wife Evelyn; his brother Donald; his children Gregg and Lisa; Scott and Debby; Todd and Michele; and Bill; his grandchildren children Wylie, Gabrielle, Elijah, Bailey and Logan. Funeral services will be held at the Nassau County Museum on Friday, March 14 at 10:00 am; 1 Museum Drive, Roslyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations in honor of Roger Rechler to Dr. Mark Kris Thoracic Research Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10016. RECHLER--Roger. You were a devoted uncle, partner, mentor and friend. I will especially miss our Wednesday partner's meetings reviewing Real Estate, and our Monday morning discussions reviewing Giants games. Debbie and I will carry you in our hearts forever. Mitchell Rechler RECHLER--Roger. The employees of Rechler Equity Partners extend their heartfelt condolences to the families of Gregg, Mitchell and Donald Rechler, and to Roger's beloved wife, Evelyn, and son, Bill. Many of us knew Roger for decades and his passing has moved us deeply. He was a true friend to everyone he knew and worked with. Roger Rechler possessed the qualities that make a man great. He was loyal, generous, and loving. Because of that he was respected by all. Rechler Equity Partners has lost a founder and a father. The employees of Rechler Equity Partners

PAT METHENY TRIO/JOSHUA REDMAN TRIO A few years ago Nonesuch Records took on a handful of the artists cut loose by its affiliates elsewhere in the Warner Music Group, which was then in the process of imploding Warner Jazz. Among them were the guitarist Pat Metheny and the tenor saxophonist Joshua Redman, two high-profile signings. Mr. Metheny, far right, is one of the only jazz musicians with a following worthy of a rock star; Mr. Redman, near right, has been a hero of the jazz mainstream at least since his precocious 1993 Warner Brothers album ''Wish,'' which featured Mr. Metheny. (They also share a bond with another Nonesuch acquisition, the pianist Brad Mehldau, who has now recorded and toured with each of them.) Perhaps not entirely by coincidence, Mr. Metheny and Mr. Redman each have New York engagements in a trio format next week. Mr. Metheny, 53, will perform at Town Hall on Tuesday, marking the close of a monthlong concert tour with the drummer Antonio Sanchez and the bassist Christian McBride. This is the same group heard on the recent album ''Day Trip,'' quite possibly the best of Mr. Metheny's trio recordings.

Violence has become so pervasive in the nation's schools that children as young as 7 simulate sexual attacks, according to a report by the South African Human Rights Commission. The research, over 18 months, was done mostly in Western Cape Province. Statistics were in short supply because most assaults in schools go unreported, the commission said, but it asserted that physical attacks were alarmingly commonplace.

CANADIAN FRONT, 2008 Denys Arcand's satire ''Days of Darkness,'' set in the very near future, takes place largely in the mind of Jean-Marc Leblanc (Marc Labrèche, above, in a scene from the film), a middle-aged civil servant who works in the provincial citizens rights department listening to the complaints of ordinary people whose problems he is powerless to solve. As his mind wanders, this harried milquetoast entertains grandiose Walter Mitty-worthy fantasies of fame, wealth and sex with beautiful women jockeying for his favor. One reason this concluding chapter of Mr. Arcand's Quebec Trilogy, which began with ''The Decline of the American Empire'' and continued with ''The Barbarian Invasions,'' isn't as strong as its forerunners is the speed with which satire catches up with reality. But the movie takes some amusingly nasty swipes at political correctness, as when Jean-Marc is brought before a committee and reprimanded after being overheard using the word Negro.

Updated, 7:40 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other top New York City officials held a news conference early Saturday evening to discuss the construction accident that occurred at 2:22 p.m., when a giant tower crane collapsed and crushed a town house, killing four people — all of whom were believed to have been construction workers. The mayor called it one of the worst construction accidents in city history and said an intense effort involving search animals and thermal-imaging cameras was underway to determine if anyone was trapped under the rubble. More than 300 firefighters and 150 police officers were at the scene of the accident, at Second Avenue and East 51st Street.
Six of the people who know him best talk about the experiences that have shaped the new governor of New York.
Milestones in the life and career of David A. Paterson, the new governor of New York.

Virginia Tech could have virtually secured a place in the N.C.A.A. tournament field with a victory against No. 1 North Carolina on Saturday in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament in Charlotte. After outplaying the Tar Heels but losing by 68-66 on a last-second shot by Tyler Hansbrough, the Hokies are firmly on the bubble.

My Sunday column again grows out of the Eliot Spitzer saga and argues that "Kristen" is very unrepresentative of the women out on the streets. Many of them aren't living a choice but a nightmare and are utterly in the control of their pimps; there should be a far greater outreach effort to crack down on the pimps and customers. Yet the Justice Department has been actively resisting such a crackdown, seeing this as an unwelcome expansion of federal power. More information about the legislation is available at the Coalition Against Trafficking in Women and Equality Now.
Though pressured from both sides, many Democratic superdelegates feel they should keep their options open at this point in the race.
Shelley Duncan has decided to appeal his three-game suspension for last Wednesday's brawl with the Tampa Bay Rays.

Two days after some of President Bush's most blunt statements to date about the current economic difficulties, Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson is on Sunday talk duty. He is slated for ABC's "This Week," CNN's "Late Edition" and "Fox News Sunday."
ATLANTA -- It was hard not to be struck by how organized Georgia Tech was despite having little notice before becoming the emergency host of the Southeastern Conference tournament.
The Lams' apartment on Ludlow Street consists of two rooms at the top of a five-story tenement.
At least four people were killed when a large crane collapsed at a construction site on Manhattan's East Side.

All winter, when I should have been sleeping, I was reading perfume blogs. I would lose myself in a sybaritic rapture, the clock on my screen racing toward morning as I played a bait-and-switch game with my senses, taking in words that describe smells by calling on images, textures, music. The sensory pileup felt good. The blogs tell me that scents ring, sing and lash out in fury; they also cradle, buffer, withhold. I believe them.

At first glance it might have seemed that Minnesota's Blake Hoffarber channeled Christian Laettner when he made a last-second shot to give the Golden Gophers a 59-58 victory against Indiana in the Big Ten tournament on Friday night.

ATLANTA -- When Georgia Coach Dennis Felton found out late Friday night the Georgia Dome could not be used again for the Southeastern Conference tournament because of damage from a severe storm, Felton suggested that Georgia's quarterfinal game with Kentucky, which was postponed Friday night, be the only game played Saturday.

The best line of the postseason basketball tournaments so far goes to Jeremy Schaap, who got a wonderful tweak in about Bob Knight's awkward transformation from media tormentor to media member. This comes courtesy the Times's relentless TV and business guru Richard Sandomir, who placed the wonderful nugget at the end of a column about ESPN this week.

In her Web column today, Helene Cooper writes about Robert Malley, a mid-level adviser to Senator Barack Obama's campaign who has been targeted by a handful of Jewish bloggers as anti-Israel, and a sign that Mr. Obama, too, if elected president, would carry out anti-Israel policies. Go to column

Providence College has fired its men's basketball coach, Tim Welsh, ending a 10-year run for one of the most respected coaches in the Big East. Welsh finished his tenure with a 160-143 record, but his ultimate undoing was his 1-9 record in the Big East tournament and the fact that his teams made only two N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, both losses.

PLAINFIELD, Ind. - Senator Barack Obama repudiated the "incendiary" remarks of his former minister today, imploring Americans to set aside racial divisions and heed the words that Robert F. Kennedy delivered not far from here the night the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated.
On Friday, it got to be too much for Alegre, a diarist on the flagship liberal blog DailyKos, who frequently writes in support of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Chris Pronger, the towering and ornery all-star defenseman for the Ducks, was suspended Saturday for eight games for stomping on the leg of the Canucks' Ryan Kesler after two got tangled up in back of the Anaheim goal on Wednesday.
Young doctors are moving away from treating serious illnesses and toward specialties like dermatology that offer better pay and hours.
Several new titles have moved onto this month's list, and are gaining ground.

Aired Friday night on NBC: This morning President Bush gave an optimistic speech about the economy even though the dollar fell even more, oil hit record highs and jobs continued to be lost. So when asked what part of the economy is working Bush said, "Hookers are doing well."
The worldwide headquarters for the cable news network CNN sustained damage from the tornado that rattled downtown Atlanta Friday evening.

I've been worried for a while about the fact that, according to financial reporters, the freezing up of the credit markets is causing a financial meltdown. The world is ending in ice and fire, simultaneously. But this is true cause for alarm:

The original headline for yesterday's column was "Desperately seeking traction." I had to can it because it didn't fit the layout (the problem with writing for a dead-tree publication). But looking at the above graphic from the Wall Street Journal it seemed to me that many people still don't quite get the Fed's problem.

ATLANTA -- There was more blue than red inside Alexander Memorial Coliseum and no one was surprised. Kentucky fans, even in a bizarre situation like this, were going to find a way to make their game with Georgia a home game.

G. Wayne Clough will take over a year after the institution’s former leader resigned amid a scandal.
The Panthers jumped on Marquette early and held on for a 68-61 victory that clinched a spot for the Panthers in the Big East title game for the seventh time in eight seasons.

ATLANTA (AP) — Jamont Gordon scored 23 points and Mississippi State survived a scary weather delay during overtime to beat Alabama, 69-67, in the Southeastern Conference tournament quarterfinals Friday night.
The new Canadian robot for the International Space Station, known as Dextre, had been unable to draw power from the station.

A man who gave a loaded gun to his suicidal friend to “snap her out of it” and then watched in shock as she killed herself was sentenced to up to five years in prison for his role in her death. The man, Christopher Burda, 46, was convicted of involuntary manslaughter for the November 2005 suicide of Nancy Choquette of Stamford, Vt.
A severe storm ripped through downtown Atlanta, damaging skyscrapers, hotels and two major sports arenas filled with thousands of basketball fans.
Top-seeded U.C.L.A. slipped past fourth-seeded Southern California after nearly blowing a 9-point lead in the final 10 minutes.
Deborah Voigt was in the middle of Act II of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” at the Metropolitan Opera when she suddenly left the stage, ill.
A student at a state college on Lake Ontario died on Friday from a suspected case of bacterial meningitis. Separately, two students at Cornell University have been hospitalized with the condition.
Tracy McGrady scored 30 points and the host Houston Rockets beat the Charlotte Bobcats, 89-80, Friday night to win their 21st game in a row.
Olli Jokinen scored a power-play goal 7 minutes 12 seconds into the third period Friday night to help the Florida Panthers to a 3-2 victory over the visiting Rangers.
Scott Schoeneweis, a left-handed reliever, had torn a tendon behind his left knee, near his hamstring, and the tendon remained torn as he toiled for the Mets last season.

Another burn patient has died of injuries suffered in an explosion at a sugar refinery in Port Wentworth, bringing the death toll to 13. Six patients remain in critical condition a little more than a month after the blast at the Imperial Sugar plant.

Hundreds of sick and dying cats were removed from a fortress-like sanctuary in a raid brought on by worried animal lovers and a former county worker who infiltrated with a hidden camera. The owner of the property in Tarentum, Linda Bruno, apparently meant well but lost track of the needs of the animals years ago, said Howard Nelson, director of the Pennsylvania Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which organized the raid. Ms. Bruno, 45, was arraigned on 13 counts of animal cruelty and neglect.

An Air National Guard jet mistakenly dropped a 22-pound, nonexplosive practice bomb on an apartment complex in Tulsa, damaging the foundation, but no one was injured, the police said. The military pilot thought he had dropped the bomb, equipped with a dummy warhead, over a field in Kansas during a routine training mission out of Tulsa. A couple returned home to the Canyon Creek apartment complex and found the ordnance partly buried in the foundation and the power knocked out, the police said. The aircraft was en route to Smokey Hill Gunnery Range in Salina, Kan., said a statement by the Oklahoma Air National Guard’s 138th Fighter Wing. An investigation has begun.

A former state treasurer convicted in a cocaine case won a reduced sentence of 10 months in prison in part for his insight about the drug scene in Charleston. Former Treasurer Thomas Ravenel, 45, who admitted he has used cocaine since he was 18, has a chance to have his sentence trimmed even more. The judge agreed to give lawyers five months to present more evidence before Mr. Ravenel goes to prison. Mr. Ravenel, once seen as rising star in the Republican Party, will have to pay a $221,000 fine and an additional $28,000 to the state as reimbursement for the special legislative session to elect his successor. He resigned about a month after he was indicted in June.

A man who gave a loaded gun to his suicidal friend to “snap her out of it” and then watched in shock as she killed herself was sentenced to up to five years in prison for his role in her death. The man, Christopher Burda, 46, a lighting company owner with no previous criminal record, was convicted of involuntary manslaughter for the November 2005 suicide of Nancy Choquette of Stamford, Vt. He wiped away tears throughout his sentencing in Pittsfield, then apologized to Ms. Choquette’s family and his own.

A front-page article on Thursday about a Pentagon review of videotaping of interrogations misstated the legal status of Ali al-Marri, who has been imprisoned by the military since 2003 after being designated an enemy combatant. Mr. Marri is challenging the Pentagon’s assertion that it has the right to hold him indefinitely; the issue of whether the Pentagon can indeed do that has not been settled legally. (A federal appeals court panel ruled 2 to 1 in June that Mr. Marri’s detention violated the Constitution, a decision that is under review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.).

West Virginia University and its former coach, Rich Rodriguez, will have a hearing April 3 in Monongalia County Circuit Court. Judge Robert Stone set the date and will hear several motions and counterclaims filed in the university’s lawsuit concerning a $4 million buyout clause in Rodriguez’s contract.Rodriguez resigned in December to take the coaching job at Michigan, taking some of his coaches and recruits with him. The university says that Rodriguez owes the full amount he agreed to pay in his contract. Rodriguez says that the agreement he signed included certain verbal promises, among them the reduction or elimination of the buyout clause — a promise the university denies.

Taiwan, South Korea and Canada will play baseball at the Beijing Olympics after finishing in the top three at a qualifying tournament Friday in Taipei, Taiwan. Canada and South Korea had 6-1 records; Taiwan was 5-2.The United States, Cuba, the Netherlands and Japan won earlier qualifying tournaments. China received an automatic bid as the host nation.

Lorena Ochoa shot a four-over-par 76 — her highest score in nearly a year — in the MasterCard Classic in Huixquilucan, Mexico, leaving her nine strokes behind Jill McGill after the first round.Ochoa, who won by 11 strokes two weeks ago in Singapore, had six bogeys and two birdies on the hilly Bosque Real Country Club course. McGill, who is winless in 13 seasons on the Tour, shot a 67.

The often-injured Derrick Ward re-signed with the Giants, reuniting with the halfbacks who replaced Tiki Barber and helped the team to a Super Bowl title.Terms were not immediately available. Ward, who was an unrestricted free agent, rushed for 602 yards and 3 touchdowns before breaking his left leg Dec. 2 in a game against the Chicago Bears. He also caught 26 passes for 179 yards and a touchdown.“The Giants gave me my start,” said Ward, who shared the halfback role with Brandon Jacobs, Ahmad Bradshaw and Reuben Droughns. “It feels good to come back to hopefully have a good year this year and be a part of the Super Bowl champion Giants.”.

The trial of Michael Vick, the suspended N.F.L. quarterback, on state dogfighting charges has been delayed. The Surry County Commonwealth attorney’s office in Virginia said the trial, originally set for April 2, would be rescheduled March 25.Vick is serving a 23-month prison term in Leavenworth, Kan., after pleading guilty to federal charges. Officials had already delayed the trials of his co-defendants, Quanis Phillips and Purnell Peace.

Louisiana State Coach Les Miles signed a renegotiated five-year contract agreement that, if approved, will make him the highest-paid football coach in the Southeastern Conference. The state university system’s governing board must approve the deal at its April meeting.Miles will earn at least $3.75 million in addition to $1,000 a year and possible incentives, nudging him ahead of Alabama Coach Nick Saban and make him one of the nation’s top-paid college football coaches.The new contract stipulates that Miles be paid no less than the highest-paid coach at a public university in the SEC, plus $1,000. Saban, who is guaranteed $3.75 million, was its highest-paid coach.
The nurses have not threatened to strike and stress that the hospitals should be generous in their contract offers in light of the nationwide nursing shortage.
Investigators said they had found another 19 bodies buried behind two houses used by drug dealers in Ciudad Juárez, bringing the total number of corpses found there to 33.
Zimbabwe’s police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, threw his support behind President Robert G. Mugabe in the March 29 presidential election.

The police said they arrested a 26-year-old Pakistani man “suspected of belonging to a global jihadist network which is preparing attacks in Western Europe,” including Britain, France, Germany, Portugal and Spain.
The new American peace envoy held his first three-party meeting with Israelis and Palestinians, but Israel’s defense minister did not attend, irking the Palestinians.

In an unusual burst of prosecutions, young women using drugs are being charged with harming their children.
The South by Southwest Music Festival in Austin, Tex., is partly a brainstorming session for a business in transition.
Lord & Taylor, the 182-year-old department store chain, has, improbably, come roaring back to life. Behind the resurgence is a most unlikely turnaround team.

An article on Friday about Tibetan protests against Chinese rule referred incompletely to comments by Robert Barnett, a Tibet specialist at Columbia University, about the last major protests in Llasa, the Tibetan capital. Mr. Barnett pointed out that the protests continued into 1989; he did not say that they took place only in 1987 and 1988.

The Federal Reserve’s unusual decision to assist Bear Stearns underscores a concern that one failure could spread across the financial system.

Pakistan’s new civilian leaders are undeniably flawed, but they deserve Washington’s support as they try to set their country on a new course.
While food costs increased, overall inflation held steady in February as the cost of gasoline declined that month, according to the latest Consumer Price Index.
The New York City Council has offered to split a bill on electronic waste into two. It is not the best approach, but it would at least get the ball rolling.
Koren Schram scored 13 of her 15 points in the first half as Dartmouth held off Harvard, 68-62, on Friday night in an Ivy League playoff game in New York.
Roy Hibbert of Georgetown had played his worst game of the season on Thursday, but he scored 25 points and grabbed 13 rebounds Friday night to lead the Hoyas into the championship game.

A foreign trip that Senator John McCain has repeatedly said is not political could be seen to serve as a promotion of his foreign policy credentials, and will end with the fund-raiser.
Only minute amounts of Xanax were found in the body of the Northern Illinois University shooter.
To a maddening degree, credit card companies will actually do O.K. while the rest of us suffer. Annoying, isn’t it?
Two rookie police officers have been disciplined for lying about making rounds in a housing project in Brooklyn where a woman was assaulted in a stairwell last week.
Allowing federal prosecutors to hand out patronage to their friends and allies corrupts the justice system. Congress should put in place strong safeguards against it.
The FDA said last week it found evidence of a contaminant in an ingredient of a blood-thinning drug, heparin, at a Chinese plant that supplied it to much of the U.S. market.

Eddy Curry will have arthroscopic knee surgery next week to remove a small piece of torn cartilage from his right knee, the Knicks announced Friday.
Elections officials in states with experience with mail-in voting suggested that the logistical challenges Florida would face could be daunting.
Lindsey Vonn and Bode Miller confirmed the obvious by mathematically clinching the overall World Cup titles that stand for consistent achievement.

Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey turned to his associate coach, Sean Kearney, with about two minutes left in Notre Dame’s Big East tournament quarterfinal loss to Marquette on Thursday and asked a simple question: “How did we beat these guys once this season?”.
With a 63-49 victory against Miami on Friday in the quarterfinals of the A.C.C. tournament, Virginia Tech made a strong argument for why it belongs in the N.C.A.A. field.
Assemblywoman Diane M. Gordon was heard on video tape suggesting former City Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten had received a bribe similar to the one she is charged with accepting.
Mr. Olah was a 4-foot-8-inch, 90-pound jockey who later became a giant in the thoroughbred industry among the jockeys and owners whose colorful silks he cleaned for more than 40 years.
South by Southwest thrives on the plain fact that people still love music: making it, hearing it, dancing to it, even marketing it.
Expedia’s expansion into India is part of an aggressive international growth strategy mapped out by its chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi.

Derrick Rose scored 25 points Friday and No. 2 Memphis advanced to the conference championship for a fourth straight year, defeating Southern Mississippi, 69-53.

Laurena L. Emhoff, assistant treasurer of The New York Times Company, has been promoted to vice president and treasurer.
The diner, at West 43rd Street and 11th Avenue, was a popular hangout for Frank Sinatra, the Westies gang and, in one episode, the characters in “Seinfeld.”
B. J. Ryan, pitching in a game for the first time since having elbow reconstruction surgery, struck out two of the three batters he faced during Friday.
The federal education secretary told a House committee that despite tight credit markets, students would still be able to get loans for college.
It is hard to know if the once-distinguished International Asian Art Fair has been dealt a fatal blow or just knocked backward into starter mode, a phase it had previously managed to skip.
The vote ensures that the months-long battle over the government’s wiretapping powers will drag on for at least a few more weeks and possibly much longer.

The Microsoft Corporation plans to buy Rapt Inc., plugging a hole in its suite of tools for Web publishers and advertisers.
Mr. Burke started the Trek company in 1976 with his friend Bevil Hogg, in a barn in Waterloo, Wis. It now has 1,600 employees.
What came through on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall is how assured and dynamic the relationship already is between Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic players.

The cream of the Hollywood press corps trooped far up into the Hollywood Hills on Thursday night to be introduced to “Paris Hilton’s My New BFF,” the working title for a coming reality series being produced for MTV.
Most managers are as unprepared now as they were a decade ago for recruiting capable workers.
Ms. Lubich became one of the most influential women in the Roman Catholic Church as the founder of the Focolare lay movement, which works to improve ties among faiths.

India’s top court suspended an arrest warrant on Friday against Richard Gere for kissing the Bollywood actress Shilpa Shetty at an AIDS awareness event in New Delhi on April 15 last year, The Associated Press reported. Chief Justice K. G. Balakrishnan and Justice R. V. Raveendran indefinitely stayed the warrant, which was issued by a court in Jaipur, a northwestern Indian city, for breaking public obscenity laws after Mr. Gere embraced and kissed Ms. Shetty on her cheek. Some religious leaders said the pair had offended the sensibilities of India’s traditionally conservative culture.

Stricken with Alzheimer’s disease, the British author Terry Pratchett, 59, has donated $1 million toward research into this debilitating brain ailment, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Pratchett, whose best-selling Discworld books (55 million copies worldwide) are set in a flat universe balanced on the backs of four elephants standing on a giant turtle, said insufficient funds and the perception that Alzheimer’s was a “fairly quiet” disease compared with cancer, were stalling efforts to learn more about it.

Michael Jackson has worked out a confidential agreement with Fortress Investment Group to retain ownership of his 2,500-acre Neverland ranch in Los Olivos, Calif., northwest of Santa Barbara, The Associated Press reported his lawyer as saying. Because Mr. Jackson owed $24.5 million on the property, it had been scheduled for auction on Wednesday. Mr. Jackson has not lived on the ranch since his acquittal on child molestation charges in 2005. A close associate of Mr. Jackson’s, who requested anonymity because of the difficult nature of the matter, said it was not clear whether Mr. Jackson would keep Neverland.

Playwrights Horizons has announced the first four of the six scheduled productions of its 2008-9 season. They are “Three Changes,” a world premiere of a play by Nicky Silver, directed by Wilson Milam; “Kindness,” a world premiere of a play written by Adam Rapp, who will also direct; “Prayer for My Enemy,” the New York premiere of a play by Craig Lucas, directed by Bartlett Sher; and “Our House,” the New York premiere of a play by Theresa Rebeck.

A previously unidentified portrait has been declared to be that of Mozart, Agence France-Presse reported. The oil painting was originally owned by the family of Johann Lorenz Hagenauer, a close friend of the Mozarts in Salzburg, Austria, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. “This is arguably the most important Mozart portrait to be discovered since the composer’s death in 1791 and only the fourth known authentic portrait of him from his Vienna years,” said Prof. Cliff Eisen of King’s College London’s department of music. Mr. Eisen has authenticated the work, which measures 19 inches by 14 inches and shows the composer in profile, wearing a red jacket that he once described in detail in a letter. Mr. Eisen, after studying Mozart’s correspondence, archival documents and estate auction records, said he believed that the work was painted around 1783 by Joseph Hickel, a painter to the Imperial Court of Austria. An American collector bought the portrait in 2005, unaware of its significance.

On Thursday CBS’s “Survivor: Micronesia” led with 13.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., followed by ABC’s “Lost,” with 11.9 million at 9, Nielsen estimated. “Lost” placed first in the coveted 18- to-49 demographic, but CBS won the night over all in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 set, thanks to “Survivor” and repeats of “CSI” (11.4 million) and “Without a Trace” (9.9 million). Fox placed second in total viewers , but third, behind ABC, among 18- to-49-year-olds. Low ratings for repeats of “My Name Is Earl” (4.3 million at 8) put NBC in fourth place, though “The Celebrity Apprentice” picked up some steam (8.1 million) at 9.
For her swan song on Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Rosamond Bernier wore a gauzy dress in which she resembled an exotic bird with green-and-black plumage.

Kristen Chenoweth, above, has withdrawn from the English National Opera production of Leonard Bernstein’s “Candide,” Playbill reported. A statement said she faced “unforeseen television filming commitments following the resolution of the Hollywood writers strike.” Ms. Chenoweth is a member of the cast of the ABC series “Pushing Daisies,” scheduled to resume filming in June. “Candide” opens in previews on June 23 at the London Coliseum. Ms. Chenoweth will be replaced by the American soprano Anna Christy in five performances, beginning with the first preview. Casting for later performances is to be announced.
Dr. Colvin promoted the now widespread use of a pioneering procedure for repairing a leaky heart valve, and also performed heart surgery on children all over the world.
The auction of greenhouse gas emissions permits could provide the foundation for a federal-state partnership to revolutionize energy use.

Juan Camilo Mouriño, the interior minister and a rising political star, has been accused of steering contracts with the state oil monopoly to his family trucking business.
The Panama Canal no longer divides Panama. Instead, the fissures opened three decades ago helped divide the United States.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,971 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:.
A judge was asked the definition of the second-degree murder charge faced by Cesar Rodriguez, the Brooklyn man charged with killing his stepdaughter Nixzmary Brown.
The former police officer who admitted she was driving while intoxicated when the fatal crash occurred, was sentenced to a year in jail.

SCHWARTZBERG--Steven Mark, 48 years old, passed away on Monday, March 10, 2008. Steven was a kind and tender man beloved by many. Steven had a lifelong passion for singing and dancing. Most importantly, Steven had a love of people and would do anything for a friend or family member. In addition to his beautiful voice, Steven's gift was his tender heart and caring soul. Steven was a beloved uncle, brother, son and husband and will be missed by all. We Love You Uncle Steven.
FINE--Martin R. With profound sorrow we mourn the untimely passing of our friend and longtime benefactor. He will be missed. The Jack Martin Fund

BARTH--Emanuel G. March 15th, 2003. Loving you and missing you every day. Your Family

Blessed grandmother of Andrea, Nathaniel, Melissa, Jennifer, Miriam, Max and Goldie-Rose. Devoted sister of the late Meyer and Harry Mandler. Services Sunday 10am, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave. J), Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah.

9 P.M. (Lifetime) WISEGAL Joseph Pistone, the F.B.I. agent who became known as Donnie Brasco after infiltrating the Bonanno crime family, is executive producer of this drama based on the true story of Patty Montanari and her ties to the Mafia. Alyssa Milano, left, plays Ms. Montanari, a young widow who begins a romance with Frank Russo (Jason Gedrick), a captain in a Brooklyn crime family. But when she discovers that Mr. Russo has murdered his own son, she fears for herself and the lives of her children. James Caan plays a Mafia don eager to exploit Ms. Montanari. 8 P.M. (Logo) PET SHOP BOYS: A LIFE IN POP A look at the life, times and sexuality of Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe, the duo behind '80s club hits like as ''West End Girls,'' ''It's a Sin'' and ''What Have I Done to Deserve This?''

FRACKMAN--Noel S., on March 10, 2008. After enjoying life to the fullest and facing death with great courage and dignity. Beloved wife of the late Richard B. Frackman. Loving mother of Dru Pyne and her husband David. Cherished grandmother of Dylan F. Pyne. Dear sister of Carol Plaut. A respected art historian, scholar, writer, and professor with a lifelong passion for 20th Century Art. She earned a M.A. from Sarah Lawrence College in English Literature and a M.A. and Ph.D. in Art History from the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University. She was an art critic for the Patent Trader Newspaper and the Scarsdale Inquirer, contributing editor for Arts Magazine, author of numerous catalogs including ''John Storrs'', for the Whitney Museum of American Art. For 19 years she was a faculty member at Purchase College, State University of New York. Her warmth, intelligence, independent spirit and youthful enthusiasm will be missed by all. Funeral services were held Friday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Purchase College Foundation/Richard B. and Dr. Noel S. Frackman Graduate Program in Art History, 725 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, New York 10577.
