JESSELSON--Erica. The staff and Board of Trustees of the Jewish Communal Fund mourn with sorrow the passing of Erica Jesselson, beloved mother of our esteemed former Trustee, Michael. The Jesselson family has been instrumental in establishing and strengthening the Jewish Communal Fund. Erica's deep and passionate commitment to the Jewish community and her dedication to making the world a better place have created a legacy for generations to come. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Jesselson family. May her memory be a blessing. Harold R. Handler, President Susan F. Dickman, Executive Vice President JESSELSON--Erica. Columbia University Medical Center is grateful for the life and generosity of Erica Jesselson, and for the enduring legacy she established in cardiology, orthopaedic surgery and research across our campus. We were fortunate to be among the many beneficiaries of Mrs. Jesselson's philanthropy. The entire Columbia community extends its condolences to her children, grandchildren and sister, and the extended Jesselson family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President, Columbia University Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Allan Schwartz, M.D. Chief, Division of Cardiology Louis Bigliani, M.D. Chair, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery Columbia University Medical Center JESSELSON--Erica. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member Erica Jesselson. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Richard Fleder, President JESSELSON--Erica. It is with deepest sympathy that we wish to express our most sincere condolences to Danny and Yael, Michael and Linda, Bunny and Phyllis on the passing of their dear mother and mother-in-law. Although their loss is personal, the community at large has also suffered a major loss as well. Anita and Hal Beretz Bea and David Tendler

KOHN--Jessel, on March 14, 2008. Loving father of David, Laura, and Alison. Dear brother of Ethel. Caring uncle of Howard, Herbert, and Belinda. Devoted, generous, and kind. He will be deeply missed by all who loved him. Graveside service Sunday, 12:45pm, at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

BARCHOFF--Lilyan Maxine, (October 20, 1918-March 14, 2008). International awardwinning sculptor, dedicated Jewish activist, avid opera patron, and devoted matriarch, she is survived by her husband Herbert Barchoff, her sons Michael and Jared Blum, daughter-in-law Katherine Kiggins, grandsons Jason, Eli and Gideon Blum, and brother William Zeitlin. Services Sunday, March 16 at 2pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to Anti - Defamation League, P.O. Box 96226, Washington, DC 20090

TURITZ--Sarah Saxe Shuman, of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, formerly of Brookline, Massachusetts, passed away peacefully on March 14, 2008, in Portland, Maine, at age 94 surrounded by her family. The second child of David and Etta Saxe, she was preceded in death by her brother Hyman G. Saxe and her sister Selma Spitzer. She was married to Saul A. Shuman of Brookline for forty years until his death in 1974. She is survived by her three sons, Stanley S. and Alfred J. of New York City and Barry M. of Boston. In 1977, she married Harry S. Turitz, a widower, of Portland, Maine, who died in 1999, three months before his 100th birthday. Sarah was beloved by her six grandchildren and one great-grandson. She will be missed by many nephews and nieces, her devoted daughters-in-law, her step-grandchildren, and three generations of the Turitz and Goldberg families. There will be a private graveside ceremony in Boston. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Etta and David Saxe Endowed Scholarship, Brandeis University, Office of Development, Mail Stop 126, Waltham, MA 02454.
LEE--Myrna. With her song that soared she was the wind beneath our wings. Friends may call March 17 at Guidetti Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC , between 2-5pm.

SPIELMAN--Bette Ann. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member Bette Ann Spielman. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President, Susan Zelman

KOPF--Deborah Albert. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Deborah Albert Kopf, beloved daughter of our former partner and of counsel, Neale M. Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share. The firm’s shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion. For DealBook’s full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.

The Los Angeles Angels will start the season without their ace, John Lackey, who is out three to four weeks because of a strained right triceps. Lackey, a right-hander, has started rehabilitation and will not participate in any baseball activities until he is re-evaluated, the team said. He won 19 games last season and led the American League with a 3.01 earned run average.

Clint Bowyer outraced Kasey Kahne and the rain to win the Nationwide Series race at Bristol Motor Speedway when it was stopped just past the halfway point.“It feels awesome,” Bowyer said Saturday after a lengthy stoppage in Bristol, Tenn. “I’ll take it any way you can get it.”Rain delayed the start of the race by two hours. When it finally started, the drivers knew they were running against the weather. Bowyer’s car was one of a handful not to pit when Mike Bliss spun to bring out the sixth caution 100 laps into the race. Knowing the race needed to go only another 51 laps to be considered official, Bowyer gambled that the cars who were not pitted would be unable to catch him before the rain came.

Elisabeth Görgl of Austria won the final giant slalom World Cup race of the season, defeating Manuela Moelgg of Italy.Kathrin Zettel of Austria finished third. Their teammate Nicole Hosp led after the first run but made a mistake in the second and dropped to 11th.Lindsey Vonn had her second-best giant slalom finish of the season, finishing seventh. Denise Karbon of Italy finished eighth.

Manfred Moelgg of Italy won the World Cup slalom title in the final race of the season.Moelgg led after the first run in Bormio, Italy, and finished in a tie for sixth place, good enough for the title after the prerace standings leader, Jean-Baptiste Grange of France, slipped in the second run and finished last.Reinfried Herbst of Austria won the race in 1 minute 51.31 seconds for his second victory of the season.

Daisuke Matsuzaka will head home to Japan after all — maybe to start the earliest season opener in baseball history. His wife, who is in Boston, gave birth Saturday to their second child, their first son. That allows Matsuzaka to travel with his Boston teammates to Tokyo on Wednesday. He is expected to start one of the regular-season games in Tokyo on March 25 and 26 against Oakland.

Manchester United beat Derby, 1-0, to tie Arsenal for first place in the English Premier League.Cristiano Ronaldo scored in the 76th minute. United and Arsenal each have 67 points. Kolo Toure’s late header gave Arsenal a 1-1 tie with Middlesbrough.

The Tampa Bay Rays left-hander Scott Kazmir will not start on opening day after having his first scheduled spring training start Sunday pushed back a few days. Kazmir has been slowed by a left elbow strain, which he felt while warming up for an intrasquad game Feb. 26. “We just want him to try and build up a little bit more arm strength before we put him back out there,” Rays Manager Joe Maddon said Saturday.Kazmir, the American League strikeout champion, went 13-9 with a 3.48 earned run average last season.

fragile / (fraj& el) / adj. / easily broken or damaged. An attribute of the materials that are enjoying a sudden revival among cutting-edge designers, as in, “Arne Quinze’s Fluid glass pieces are so fragile, I had to buy them their own seat on the plane home from Design Miami.” Could also be used to describe designers’ egos. In either case, handle with care.

Alexander von Vegesack was only 15 when he made his first acquisitions, at a Cairo bazaar: a Turkish coffeepot and an African spear, among other things. But throughout his career as a design historian and the director of the Vitra Design Museum, von Vegesack never lost his fascination with everyday things. It’s the glue that holds together the 2,000 objects and furnishings he’s collected over the past four decades, and also a new exhibition at the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli in Turin, Italy. “Adventures With Objects” celebrates the collector’s life and travels, and his obsession with the relationship between industry and traditional crafts. The usual suspects are here — Achille Castiglioni, Charlotte Perriand, Gerrit Rietveld. But so are leather saddles and a Navajo blanket. “To understand the connection of all these different things is to understand my biography,” von Vegesack says. MONICA KHEMSUROV.

A new project from the Italian luxury goods company Tod’s gives fresh meaning to the art of window-shopping. Curated by the Italian design impresario Giulio Cappellini and Diego Della Valle, the president of the Tod’s Group, the windows at select boutiques this spring will undergo a museum-worthy makeover courtesy of some of today’s coolest design stars. They’ve enlisted Ineke Hans from the Netherlands, BarberOsgerby from England and the Frenchman Patrick Norguet, whose multicolored shelves (left) were inspired by his famous Rainbow chair. No word yet if Zaha Hadid will be doing the shoe display. ALEX HAWGOOD.

When Peter Ting was a young man studying at the Farnham School of Art, near Surrey, England, he immersed himself in the tradition of British studio pottery and handmade ceramics. There he was influenced, if indirectly, by the work of the renowned 20th-century ceramicist Bernard Leach, a pioneer of the “honestly made object.” Leach, like Ting, was born in the Far East and spent time in Japan before founding his own pottery studio in England. Several of Leach’s disciples taught at Farnham, and Ting was so inspired he traveled to Japan to visit Shoji Hamada, who was Leach’s friend and collaborator. Leach’s ability to embrace both the Japanese and the British approaches to pottery resonated with Ting: “The East-West style fits into the way I look at the world.”.

When I first saw the 85 Bulbs Chandelier, by Rody Graumans for Droog, in 1993, I was immediately attracted by the efficient way it achieved its simple shape using nothing but bare essentials — some wire, some sockets and light bulbs. I was less attracted to its not so humble price of $3,000. Normally I prefer good cheap products over good expensive ones; besides being easy on the wallet, a low price makes them more difficult to design and thus more admirable. But when I renovated my studio five years later and it turned out that I still loved it, I bit the bullet. After 10 years it is still the centerpiece of our meeting room and has not aged a bit. I have never tired of its quiet wit, and incredibly, even though I had originally purchased matching replacement light bulbs, in 10 years of usage not one of its 85 bulbs has ever burned out. STEFAN SAGMEISTER.

Karim Rashid has never been one to turn the volume down on any project — except perhaps on the new range of sound-absorbing wall panels he designed for the Swedish furniture company Offecct. Rashid says he has always been interested in sound-dampening strategies, having “been to one too many restaurants where I cannot hear my dinner guests.” The Soundwave Flo tiles, made of molded recyclable polyester fiber, can be installed on walls or ceilings to help silence the busy boîte downstairs or your own heavy-metal jam sessions. Available in four colors (including a decidedly loud fuchsia) at offecct.se. ANDREAS KOKKINO.

China may be set to overtake the United States in the next decade as the world’s second largest consumer of luxury goods, but the question remains whether China’s new money will put their yuan behind products made — let alone designed — in their own backyard. “China Design Now,” at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London through July 13, takes an expansive view of China’s burgeoning design culture. Still, the fact that the curators saw fit to include projects like Rem Koolhaas’s CCTV headquarters and Herzog & de Meuron’s Olympic stadium as well as a pair of Nike Air Force 1’s could be taken as a hint. Meanwhile, the KT Wong Charitable Trust has commissioned the Chinese artist Shao Fan to create a garden for the Royal Horticultural Society Chelsea Flower Show in May. Fan’s design (above, right), which brings a contemporary perspective to the traditional scholar’s garden, is an elegant example of the Wong Trust’s ambition to foster an East/West exchange of a decidedly more cerebral nature. ALIX BROWNE.

Perfumes have structures just as buildings do, and many perfumers, like many architects, have imbibed modernism’s early-20th-century precepts: eliminate ornament, simplify line, derive form from contemporary materials.

The Samurai Shopper is weaving her jumbled thoughts on organic cleaning products into a sage and sanguine worldview. How best to fight tough grime? With cruelty-free self-righteousness? Or headache-inducing supermarket.
For the Spanish architect Enric Ruiz-Geli, there is poetry in technology. Nicolai Ourousoff does a close reading.
Where have all the great American furniture designers gone?

For those of you who can only dream about owning a piece of Jean Prouvé’s furniture, here is a book that at least provides a comprehensive (if pricey) look at his oeuvre, both design and architectural. “Jean Prouvé” ($250), is a handsomely produced, slipcased two-volume set that is co-published by Galerie Patrick Seguin in Paris and the Sonnabend Gallery in New York; the two galleries.
Cleverness and subtlety reign in product designer Naoto Fukasawa’s everyday objects.

For most real estate buyers, provenance counts. Special architectural flourishes, prior celebrity ownership, even anecdotal tales of happy years lived in a placid space add bonus value. When the photographer and fashion plate Manuela Pavesi came across a villa.
Some rock stars like to destroy hotel rooms, but Lenny Kravitz opts to design them instead.

Its football team may have had a disappointing season, but the University of Nebraska can now brag about its world-class quilt museum. The Lincoln campus’s International Quilt Study Center and Museum was designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects and largely funded by Robert and Ardis James, a couple from Chappaqua, N.Y., who have been collecting quilts for decades.

When the sculpture garden by Philip Johnson opened at the Museum of Modern Art in 1953, the paving stones of “cloudy” Carrara marble were meant to last forever. Unfortunately, during the museum’s recent renovation, many of the marble slabs broke. And since the original stone was no longer available, the entire lot had to be replaced. Enter Gil Shapiro and his design company Urban Archaeology in TriBeCa. Vintage marble from the Modern is not something he could pass up, so Shapiro bought all 600 remaining slabs, each measuring 30 inches by 58 inches. The slabs have since been used to decorate pools, garden paths, fancy loft buildings in TriBeCa and even bathrooms. The Shapiro-designed “MoMA Stone Washstand” is now available to order from Urban Archaeology’s salvage collection. ANDREAS KOKKINO.
Translucent, transparent, reflective or illuminated from within, this season’s furniture is all aglow.

Karl Lagerfeld’s interest in architecture isn’t limited to his many houses, as two new books of his architectural photographs so elegantly illustrate. “Karl Lagerfeld: Three Examples of 20th Century Modern Architecture” is a heavy-duty boxed set showcasing three of the most distinctive buildings in the world: Curzio Malaparte’s Casa Malaparte, Perugini’s La Casa Albero Nella Pineta di Fregene and Tadao Ando’s Vitra Conference Pavilion. “Konkret Abstrakt Gesehen,” on the other hand, finds our ponytailed polymath taking grainy, abstracted shots of sidewalk cracks, staircases and other fragments of urban existence. Despite his passion for architecture, Lagerfeld suggests that he has no plans to design a house any time soon: “Fashion, photography, books. That’s all.” ALEX HAWGOOD.

A friend Of Mine In Idaho Recently Tore Down His House And Is Constructing a new one on its footprint. The funny thing is that the old house looked new and the new house will look old, because he is building it with reclaimed wood.

Kiki Smith, who is known for her artistic explorations of the natural world, is no stranger to the domestic one; she has designed multiples for the Fabric Workshop and Museum and decorative glass objects for Steuben. Smith’s latest foray is the Maiden & Moonflower wallpaper for Studio Printworks, a company known for its collaborations with contemporary artists. The hand-printed wallpaper, which comes in six color combinations, depicts a woman standing under a tree, surrounded by nocturnal animals and stars. And, the better to protect the real natural world, this PVC-free paper is printed with water-based inks. Go to studioprint works.com. PILAR VILADAS.

Last June, among the slick, limited-edition minimalist and staid blue-chip vintage pieces at Design Miami/Basel, the locally based Chart Foundation showed a group of 1980s furniture designs that were notable for their raw, awkward energy and sharp social and aesthetic commentary. The most striking of these was a chair by the Zurich architect Stefan Zwicky. A sly poke at Le Corbusier’s famous Grand Confort chair, with its shiny tubular steel frame embracing fat leather cushions, Zwicky’s version is rendered in unforgiving concrete and framed in crude steel reinforcing bar. Provocative and gleefully anti-functional, it brought back memories of that heady, subversive decade in which seemingly anything went.
1. His quirky, high-concept Williamsburg design store may be called the Future Perfect, but.

Casino de Madrid is one of the Spanish capital’s most traditional members clubs, housed in an august building with a musty neo-Gothic library, sweeping staircases, painted vaulted ceilings and heavy-lidded patrons who look like they haven’t stirred from their well-worn sofas since the institution was founded in 1836. On the top floor, however, in the recently reopened La Terraza del Casino restaurant, the atmosphere is somewhat different.
The architect-activist Fritz Haeg, who encourages homeowners to banish grassy vanity lawns in favor of harvestable gardens, doesn’t let the grass grow under his feet.

The architect Sam Trimble has worked with some tough customers, the restaurateurs Robert De Niro and Michael Jordan among them. But these were nothing compared to the three orphaned grizzly bears for whom he has been commissioned to design a habitat in Alaska. “They might act like teddy bears, but they could devour you,” Trimble says. “And probably would if you got too close.” Getting (safely) close to the animals was just one of Trimble’s directives in creating the Bears of Alaska Discovery Center, an educational facility outside Anchorage. He was also asked to include a walk-in freezer for storing moose meat and an exhibition space for teaching humans bear safety. Trimble’s design, both environmentally and animal friendly, is an homage to indigenous Eskimo architecture, which he says “is the ultimate in sustainable green living: planted roof, locally sourced timbers, natural light and heat retention.” No doubt Patron and JB (siblings whose mother was shot) and Hugo (who was found limp after trying to eat a porcupine) will feel at home. DEREK BLASBERG.

Glass was a popular material at Design Miami in December, appearing in exhibitions like “Fragiles” (with work by designers such as Arne Quinze and Jerszy Seymour) and in shimmering cast-glass benches by Tokujin Yoshioka. But the event also offered the opportunity to see designers — including the Campana brothers and Matali Crasset — actually make objects at a traveling outdoor glass-blowing studio. GlassLAB, as it is called, resulted from a collaboration between the architect and product designer Paul Haigh,.

The husband-and-wife designers Jonathan Levien and Nipa Doshi have become famous for their melding of English austerity with Indian vibrancy (see their Charpoy collection for Moroso). But their newest project, a collaboration with the venerable English shoemaker John Lobb Ltd., is decidedly more Anglo. Realizing that reinventing the shoe was out of the question, their company, Doshi Levien, named the project “Apprentice” in deference to the master cobbler’s time-honored techniques. Their designs subtly tweak traditional handmade details: a scalloped cutaway side panel here, a traditional English brogue whose perforations snake around the shoe there. Bowler hats not included. ANDREAS KOKKINO.

When artists started using paint straight from the can in the 1960s and early ’70s, they forfeited their personal take on color and gave themselves over to the dictates of the mass market. “Color Chart: Reinventing Color, 1950 to Today,” a new show at the Museum of Modern Art through May 12 (sponsored, appropriately enough, by Benjamin Moore), looks at the start of what became a color revolution. With the arrival of fast-drying acrylics and other mass-produced paints heavily marketed to a nation of do-it-yourselfers, art began to resemble a ready-made commodity, taking its hues from packaging, billboards, magazines and comic strips.
NICE KITTY.

Now it’s China’s turn. The signs of progress that have marred Europe and America for the past century have lately been unleashed in the world’s fastest growing economy, and the eyewitnesses are lining up to testify. Not surprisingly, money is talking loud enough to drown out any dissent, as the fate of an ancient society increasingly rests in the hands of real estate developers. If ever there were an exercise in urban planning, this is it: how to modernize a civilization without obliterating its heritage; how to accommodate density without compromising quality of life; how to learn from the mistakes of the so-called developed countries, now congested and polluted, their major cities homogenized and colonized by the same handful of global brands.

The legendary Italian architect Andrea Branzi has spent more time trying to break things down than he has trying to build them up. A new show of his work at the Fondation Cartier in Paris (March 28 to June 22) is a case in point. Branzi has created two installations: an elliptical enclosure woven from glass, metal, hemp and plant matter; and a sort of decorative gazebo containing a modular work/sleep unit (above). Difficult to understand as actual structures, perhaps, but elegant metaphors for a society whose needs have become more fluid — and to which architecture has yet to fully catch up. ALIX BROWNE.

John Brady and Willard Ford know that consuming less is one way to cut your carbon footprint. Nevertheless, the two former bike racers joined forces in 2006 to open the FordBrady design gallery in downtown Los Angeles, with the explicit purpose of selling furniture. Much of that furniture, however, is made from materials destined for landfills or incineration. Their finds, including the benches produced by the Thai company Osisu from compressed milk cartons and reclaimed teak, or the Fast Forward Chair by Chulaphun Chulanond (above), have attracted clients like the architects Marmol Radziner, Graft Lab and Ray Kappe. Even the showroom — in a former theater on the edge of Chinatown — abides by this philosophy of reuse. A FordBrady line of outdoor furniture is in the works. STACIE STUKIN.

“Maelstrom/Before” The disorienting details in Francesca Gabbiani’s paper and acrylic collages — labyrinthine passages, mirrors within mirrors, wallpaper patterns that jump off the canvas — can leave the viewer with a touch of vertigo. “It’s like being trapped inside,” says the Canadian-born Gabbiani, based in Los Angeles. Her inspirations are as eclectic as they are horrific — say, Edgar Allan Poe’s “Fall of the House of Usher” or the ’70s Belgian vampire film “Daughters of Darkness.” But in her work, blood and gore are replaced with a cool detachment, “as if something bad just happened or is about to happen,” she says.

If you look at highly successful people, they make the same number of mistakes as others, but they recover quickly.

To the Editor: Regarding “Amazing Grace: The Art and Ordeal of the Kimono” (March 2): I was rather disappointed to see a Japanese kimono school referred to, by an acquaintance of the author, as a “geisha school.” These schools are, rather, designed for women across the spectrum of Japanese society who wear kimonos for weddings, festivals, tea ceremonies and numerous other occasions.

To the Editor: As a frequent traveler to Berlin and many other cities, I have to wonder what the Travel section thinks it is doing in “One Wall Down, Thousands to Paint” (March 2) by glamorizing a man who leaves “his mark on a telephone booth, a dozen doors and a concrete wall next to the train tracks.”.

McCLURE--Barbara , of San Francisco, formerly of NYC, February 29. Widow of S.R. Kerner, Chef Marcel Pailhes. Leaves a daughter Alison, sister Janet, many friends. A graduate of The Northfield School, she worked at Angel Records, Carnegie Hall, RCA Victor-Joy!

RIDING THROUGH THE VALLEY OF THE FLOWERS NEAR TASIILAQ DURING THE 2007 SIKU EXTREME ARCTIC CHALLENGE, JULY 22, 2007 Prof. Jacqueline McGlade, 52, executive director of the European Environment Agency in Copenhagen. ''Over five days, the race combines 250 kilometers of hiking and climbing up 800-, 900-, 1.000-meter peaks, biking across rough terrain and kayaking about 65 kilometers through the glacier fields and fjords, amongst all the icebergs. You find yourself being guided into parts of Greenland where you wouldn't go unless you were a very experienced adventurer. It pushes you beyond the limits -- but safely. I was truly impressed with how the local community was already adapting to climate change, having to fundamentally change the way they live. This race is part of them deciding not to go for mass tourism, but to go for a very special kind of tourism, not ruining the environment, but bringing people to it in a very open way.'' As told to Seth Kugel
TENNYSON By Lesley M. M. Blume.

COCHRAN--Wanda , Lyric Soprano. March 29, 1923-March 4, 2008. Wanda Cochran died in Croton on Hudson, NY on Tuesday, March 4th, 2008. Wanda was born in East Grand Rapids, Michigan, the only child of Marshall and Ida Cochran. Wanda won a scholarship to attend the American Conservatory of Music in Chicago where she graduated with a Masters in Music. She became the alternate for the role of ''Laurie'' in ''Oklahoma'' and won the lead in ''Irene'', touring 35 cities in Europe. Returning to New York, she joined the company of ''Brigadoon''. Wanda returned to Michigan to appear in several of her own shows on local radio stations. Wanda married Robert H. Rose and moved to Europe in 1948. They had a son, Harrison and a daughter, Miarka. In Paris, she featured at leading cabarets and nightclubs. She became the regular soloist with the Metropole Orchestra in Hilversum, Holland and broadcast for the Voice of America. After moving to England, she made appearances in concerts, recitals and oratorio. Wanda returned to New York in 1968. Surviving Wanda are her daughter Miarka Mazur and husband Ben of Gloucester, Virginia, granddaughter Amanda Mazur of London, England and former husband Robert Rose, of New York and London, England. An inurnment at the Columbarium in the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th St, NY, NY 10128 is planned for March 19th at 3pm. 212-289-4100 Ext 201.

To the Editor: As a frequent traveler to Berlin and many other cities, I have to wonder what the Travel section thinks it is doing in ''One Wall Down, Thousands to Paint'' (March 2) by glamorizing a man who leaves ''his mark on a telephone booth, a dozen doors and a concrete wall next to the train tracks.'' There are many of us, hipsters and otherwise, who understand the damage these mindless taggers cause to a city. They are not mindful of anyone's property, or that of the cities in which they live. That they (or Mr. Tzortzis, for that matter) value the vain scribble of a name over an architect's design shows a profound ignorance of respect.
Pit Bulls Are a Breed That Is Worth Sparing

The Boss column on Feb. 24, about Dan Schulman, chief executive of Virgin Mobile USA, referred incompletely to his role in the founding of the company. While he was the first chief executive in 2001, work on setting up the company had begun more than a year earlier.

BLOCK--Elaine Carlin . 82 of New York and Paris, on March 7, 2008, daughter of the late Dr. Philip and Flora Cohen; beloved mother of Randall and his wife Karen Davis, Laurie Spigel and her husband Gerry, and Linda; loving grandmother to Kaley, Leanne, Kalman, Solomon, Jeffrey, and Peter. Retired Professor of Elementary Education at Hunter College, founder of Misericordia International, and author of the multi-volume Corpus of Medieval Misericords. Dedicated to teaching teachers how to help children discover their passion; mentor to scores of future New York City teachers; finding her own passion in uncovering the beauty and meaning of carvings under the seats of medieval choir stalls throughout Europe. Her spirit lives on in her family, friends, colleagues, and students. A memorial service is being planned. PADDOCK--William Carson , a plant pathologist credited with writing extensively on world food issues and population, died on February 28, 2008 in Antigua, Guatemala. He was 86 and died from complications of a stroke. Born on September 23, 1921 in Minneapolis, MN, he was the third son of Sarah Lee and Paul Ezekiel Paddock of Marshaltown, IA. He was a graduate of The Loomis School (1938) in Connecticut, and Iowa State University (1943) at Ames, IA. He served in the US Marine Corps during WWII, for which he received the Purple Heart after being gravely wounded in Okinawa, Japan. After the war, he received a Ph.D. from Cornell University in Plant Pathology and Plant Breeding. Dr. Paddock was an Assistant Professor at Pennsylvania State University and a Professor at Iowa State University prior to moving his family to Antigua, Guatemala in 1952 to serve as the Director of the Iowa State College Guatemala Tropical Research Center, where he developed Tiquisate Golden Yellow Corn--a disease resistant corn high in vitamin A. In 1957, Dr. Paddock replaced Mr. Wilson Popenoe as Director of El Zamorano, the Pan American School of Agriculture in Honduras. During his tenure, El Zamorano became the first college in Agriculture in Latin America. Dr. Paddock returned to Washington, D.C. in 1962 where he was named Director of Latin American Affairs for the National Academy of Sciences under the Kennedy Administration. Dr. Paddock's first article on the world food crisis ''Can We Make the World Feed Us All?'' appeared in the Saturday Evening Post in 1952. With his extensive knowledge of tropical agriculture, world hunger, and populations issues he went on to write and co-author several books: ''Hungry Nations.'' ''Famine-1975,'' ''We Don't Know How,'' and ''Time of Famine.'' Dr. Paddock also worked as a private consultant in tropical agricultural development. Central to his research and writings was the belief that famine and population growth were intrinsically linked and that the Green Revolution need to also address overpopulation. ''If you eliminate famine through an increase in food production and ignore overpopulation, you simply pass today's problems on to the next generation.'' Retired for many years but always active, Dr. Paddock was involved with and served on the boards of various organizations including the American Phytopathological Society, FAIR (Federation for American Immigration Reform), ZPG (Zero Population Growth), and was a founding member of the Guatemala branch of ''Democrats Abroad.'' Dr. Paddock is survived by his beloved wife and partner of 64 years, Elizabeth; his son, daughter-in-law, and granddaughter, Paul, Anne, and Laura Lee Paddock of West Palm Beach, FL; his daughter, Ana Livingston Paddock of Santa Fe, NM, and his granddaughter, Lee Livingston Dolan of NYC. He was predeceased by his two brothers, Paul Ezekiel and Richard Lee. A memorial service will be held in Antigua, Guatemala in May and a private family service in Blue Mountain Lake, New York this summer. Letters of condolence may be sent to Elizabeth Paddock at PO Box 669004, A-308, Miami Springs, FL 33266.

WALWORTH--Nancy Zinsser Author of children's history books, former New Canaan selectwoman, and longtime New Canaan, CT resident, died March 4 after a brief illness. She was 90 years old. Mrs. Walworth grew up on Long Island in the then-rural township of Kings Point. She graduated from the Brearley School and Smith College and received a masters degree in English literature from Radcliffe College. Mrs. Walworth was an educator at heart. While raising four children in New Canaan, she determined there were few history books aimed at middle-school children, so she co-authored three with close friend Polly Schoyer Brooks. Years later she wrote two more. Always active in New Canaan civic life, Mrs. Walworth served on the Park and Recreation Commission and on the boards of the New Canaan Library, the League of Women Voters, and the ABC ''A Better Chance'' House. As New Canaan selectwoman from 1971 through 1975, she was a strong advocate for public recreation, securing funding for new public tennis and paddle tennis courts and initiating a push that led 20 years later to the popular municipal pool at Waveny Park. Her husband Edward Walworth died in October, 2007; the two were devoted to each other for 63 years. Nancy Walworth will be remembered as a wonderful mother and friend, very funny, endlessly curious, committed and caring, always in your corner, rain or shine. She is survived by her sister, Polly Zinsser Steinway, and her brother, William Knowlton Zinsser; four children, Edward, Joyce, Seth, and Cornelia; and nine grandchildren. A third son, John, died in infancy. We all loved and admired her greatly. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New Canaan Library, Book Group Collection. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

OUTPOSTS At the dawn of the 20th century Butte, Mont., was a hard-edged, dirty, dangerous town on the crest of the Continental Divide, and if a single man lived to his 30th birthday he was considered lucky. Yet entire parishes left the emerald desperation of County Cork, Ireland, for the copper mines of Butte, fleeing a land where British occupiers had once refused to let mothers educate their children, and where famine had killed a million people in seven years' time. ... I heard something in a graveyard there about 10 years ago that has stayed with me. I was strolling through St. Patrick's Cemetery, looking for family clues. My grandmother had lived in that part of Montana for a spell, and she didn't miss it -- the 20-below-zero days, the air so full of grime that the streetlights were turned on at midday. Among the rows of Dalys and Grogans and O'Farrells I started up a conversation with a man who was tending the tombstones.
SHELF LIFE The bookcase turns a new page.

JUST as wives found themselves wondering about the intimate stranger on the other side of the marital bed last week, men were measuring their own private lives against that of Gov. Eliot Spitzer. While some, like Gary Rabkin, 41, a technology lawyer in Manhattan, said he and his friends were ''really disgusted'' that Mr. Spitzer had betrayed his wife, many focused on the tactical, rather than the emotional, aspects. ''Men and women react differently to Spitzer the way they react differently to the movie 'Titanic,' '' David Zinczenko, editor in chief of Men's Health, wrote in an e-mail message. ''Women are touched by the tragic love story. Men just want to know the mechanics of how the ship sank.''

JOFFEE--Patricia , born on November 12, 1947 in Highland Park, Illinois died on Sunday, March 9, 2008 in Washington, DC. Patty is the daughter of Norman Joffee and Betty Berger, the sister of Robert Joffee and the stepdaughter of Robert Richheimer, now all deceased. She is survived by her beloved children, Kate Kramer and Andrew Kramer of Arlington, Virginia. Patty Joffee graduated from The Francis W. Parker School in Chicago and Tufts University. ELKIND--Bernice passed away March 7, 2008 at age 88. Bunny, as she was called by all who knew her, was born August 23, 1919 in Brooklyn, NY, one of six children of Max and Mary Halwer. After graduating from Brooklyn College Bunny had a long career teaching English in the New York City public schools, becoming Dean at Washington Irving High School in Manhattan until her retirement in 1980. She and her husband, Rod Elkind, were a devoted couple for 67 years. Bunny and Rod lived in lower Manhattan, and were among the original residents of Stuyvesant Town. Bunny loved New York. She enjoyed walking in the city and attending the theater. She was an avid reader of the NY Times, and was remarkably expert at the Times crossword puzzle. After retiring, Bunny and Rod moved to Heritage Village in Southbury, Connecticut, and spent winters in West Palm Beach, Florida. In 2006 they moved to California to be closer to their son, Dr. Les Elkind, and daughter - in - law, Francine Genta, in Santa Cruz. Bunny is remembered by all who knew her for her quick mind, her ready smile, and her extraordinary empathy and kindness. She saw good in everyone, and will be forever in the hearts of her family and those who loved her.

ELIAS--William Dean . William Dean Elias passed away on Wednesday, March 12, 2008. He was 56. Bill was born at Doctors Hospital in New York City, August 30, 1951. He was educated at the American School in London, England and then graduated from the Brunswick School in Greenwich, Connecticut. He received his MBA from the Wharton School of Business at The University of Pennsylvania. Bill moved to Toronto, Ontario, Canada in the early 1970s where he met his future wife Pauline Rosenberg. He established a successful advertising agency, Elias Marketing and Communications, which specialized in real estate marketing and research. He then moved his family to Palm Beach, Florida in 1990 to follow his love of beautiful homes and architecture and established Elias Management and Construction, Inc. which he ran with joyful passion until his passing. He is survived by his mother, Rea Elias of Jupiter Island, a brother Albert Elias of West Palm Beach, by his daughter Vanessa Elias Krelstein and her husband Lee Krelstein of Miami, his two sons Jonathan and Benjamin Elias, his granddaughter Stella Rose Krelstein, his ex-wife Pauline Elias and his partner Dale Henderson. He was an adoring and devoted father, son, husband, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. He will be deeply missed. Bill was a generous supporter of many causes and community organizations, including Unity of the Palm Beaches, The Palm Beach Human Rights Council, Comprehensive Aids Program, The Foundation for Comprehensive Community Care, The National Association of Children of Alcoholics, The Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation and United Cerebral Palsy. A Celebration of Life Memorial Service in honor of Bill Elias will be held on Tuesday, March 18th, 2008 at 4pm. The service will take place at Unity of the Palm Beaches located at 1957 South Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. A reception will immediately follow the service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation, 875 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 3100, Chicago, Illinois 60611. questforthetest.org ELIAS--William. The Board of Directors, volunteers, consumers and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City sadly acknowledge the sudden passing of Bill Elias. His late father, Albert J. Elias, was a longtime member of our board and an Honorary Director at the time of his death in January 2007, and the Elias family has continued its decades-long support and generosity. We extend our deepest sympathy to all of the family, but especially to Bill's mother, Rea, and his brother Albert, an employee at UCP/NYC from 1979 until his retirement. THE NEWSEliot Spitzer resigned as governor of New York after investigators say he was caught on a federal wiretap making plans to meet a call girl from a high-price prostitution service. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Spitzer's undoing began after a bank alerted the Treasury Department to suspicious wire transfers to shell companies from his account. Investigators discovered the companies were linked to a Web-based prostitution service. The wiretap of ''Client 9'' arranging the illicit assignation at a Washington hotel seemed to explain the transfers. Mr. Spitzer, a fierce enforcer of ethics in public life, said: ''I am deeply sorry that I did not live up to what was expected of me.''

QAt a recent annual shareholders' meeting, my co-op had a vote to increase the flip tax. To pass such a change would require the affirmative vote of two-thirds of all outstanding shares. The tally was about eight percentage points short of the necessary 66.67 percent. In the days after the meeting, certain board members campaigned in the lobby to get votes from people who had not attended the meeting or submitted a proxy. During the next few days, the requisite number of votes was secured, and the board declared the new flip tax to be in immediate effect. Is this valid?

To the Editor: In the Next Stop column about Prato, Italy, ''In Tuscany, the Revealing of a Forbidden Love'' (March 2), Prato's so-called favorite scandal would have benefited with a few additional facts about the Renaissance painter Fra Filippo Lippi. As recounted in Frederick Hartt and David G. Wilkins's ''History of Italian Renaissance Art'' (Prentice Hall, 2006), Lippi was born about 1406 into an impoverished family and entered the Monastery of the Carmine in Florence at an early age, taking his vows in 1421. (He would have been 15 years old.) He was appointed chaplain of Santa Margharita in Prato in 1456 and fathered a son who became the painter Filippino Lippi, then a daughter, with Lucrezia Buti, a nun from the convent.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Amazing Grace: The Art and Ordeal of the Kimono'' (March 2): I was rather disappointed to see a Japanese kimono school referred to, by an acquaintance of the author, as a ''geisha school.'' These schools are, rather, designed for women across the spectrum of Japanese society who wear kimonos for weddings, festivals, tea ceremonies and numerous other occasions. As a scholar of East Asian culture and history, I have long watched as people in Europe and North America have stereotyped Japanese and other East Asian women as sex objects, glossing Japanese and other East Asian cultures as utopias of pleasure for the gratification of Western sexual fantasies. The New York Times should know better than to contribute to this process.

Critiquing the style spectacle seen from a sidewalk cafe in Paris is a major spectator sport that hits its peak during Fashion Week, an intense series of designer shows that ended earlier this month. Women -- and a few men -- who dress as an art form mixed in with models wearing exotic hairstyles (far right, second row) rushing from show to show. Celebrities either passed nearly unnoticed (can you spot one here?) or were chased by paparazzi. Known for her exotic hats is the Italian Vogue editor, Anna Piaggi (top left corner and throughout the second row). The latest twist: skirts shortened to expose lacy undergarments (far right at bottom). And that celebrity? Kanye West, third from right at bottom.

SCHMITT--Jane . Cherished wife, adored mother, prized teacher and volunteer, passed away on February 15. She was an inspiration, encompassing the truest sense of selflessness.

LEVINE--Howard (Howie) Always full of warmth and love, Howie was giving and inspirational to his family. He was Andi's husband. Father to Lesley, Eric, Ilissa and Samantha. Grandfather to Bari, Max and AJ. Great-grandfather to Dylan and Alexis. Son-in-law to Marion Bickman and brother-in-law to Barbara Jacobs. True and beloved friend to many. He was a ''dynamite'' Restaurateur and founder of Manhattan's EJ's, Carmine's, Angelo & Maxie's, Docks and Covent Garden. Howie brought his charisma, warmth, humor and genuine love of people and food in to all of his Restaurants. Howie resided in Boca Raton, FL where his dream became a reality. He loved Woodfield Country Club and played an active role on its Board while chairing the food and beverage committee. He wore rose colored glasses throughout his life, call his cell phone and you'll here: ''The birds are chirping, the Jasmines blooming, I'm having a ball in Florida''.

JPMorgan Chase is obviously acquiring a lot in its $236 million purchase of Bear Stearns. For pennies on the dollar, the banking giant is buying extensive prime brokerage and clearing operations, as well as a $1.2 billion office building.

Even in the bright light of Monday morning, it remains one of the most remarkable financial deals in recent years. Bear Stearns, the 85-year-old investment bank that lay bleeding from its mortgage-inflicted wounds, agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for the still-unbelievable sum of $2 a share.
It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns‘s stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet even more.
Investors in financial stocks were heading for the exits Monday after Bear Stearns‘s bargain-basement sale stoked fears about the fate of other Wall Street firms.
From DealBook’s colleague Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:
Last January, Bear Stearns traded above $170. Since then, the troubled investment bank plummeted more than 80 percent, beset by the earthquake that rumbled through the world financial markets.

Hoping to avoid a systemic meltdown in financial markets, the Federal Reserve on Sunday approved a $30 billion credit line to engineer the takeover of Bear Stearns and announced an open-ended lending program for the biggest investment firms on Wall Street.

Agreeing to guarantee a 28-day credit line to Bear Stearns, by way of JPMorgan Chase, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York conceded last Friday that no sizable firm with a book of mortgage securities or loans out to mortgage issuers could be allowed to fail right now. For The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson, it was the most explicit sign yet of the Fed’s “Rescues ‘R’ Us” doctrine that already helped to force the marriage of Bank of America and Countrywide Financial.

Several high-profile hedge funds have moved to sever ties with Bear Stearns since Friday’s rescue, inflicting further damage on its once market-leading and lucrative prime brokerage business, The Financial Times reported.
The cash squeeze that brought Bear Stearns to its knees is fanning fears that other investment banks might be vulnerable to the crisis of confidence gripping Wall Street.
Will JPMorgan Chase’s stunning $2 a share deal to buy Bear Stearns put a crimp in Visa‘s plans to go public this week in what is expected to be the nation’s biggest initial public offering?

After being sworn in as New York State’s 55th governor today, David A. Paterson thanked a litany of dignitaries in the audience, including two former governors, Hugh L. Carey and George E. Pataki. But Mario M. Cuomo, who was governor for three terms, from 1983 to 1994, was absent. Why?

Chilly temperatures and a mazelike grid of barricades did not deter thousands of people from turning out along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Monday for New York’s 247th annual St. Patrick’s Day Parade, and the spectacle was as much on the sidelines as on the streets, with traditional garb often giving way to the gaudy.Tam o’ Shanter style hats were outnumbered by floppy striped felt versions seemingly inspired by Dr. Seuss. Dangling green beads looked more like Mardi Gras than County Mayo. There were also feather boas, dyed beers and three-leaf clover green antennas.

When David A. Paterson is sworn in as New York’s 55th governor at 1 p.m. today, his current job — lieutenant governor — will be vacant. It will remain that way through 2010, under the terms of the State Constitution.City Room interviewed three former lieutenant governors — Alfred B. DelBello and Stanley N. Lundine, who served under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and Betsy McCaughey, who served under Gov. George E. Pataki — for their thoughts (and frustrations) about the time-worn but poorly defined position of lieutenant governor.

Updated, 2 p.m. | Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson gathered with leaders of New York State’s Legislature and judiciary in the Assembly chamber at the State Capitol in Albany at 1 p.m. and then took the oath of office as New York State’s 55th governor. In a 26-minute inaugural address — the first half of which was devoted to humor-filled acknowledgments of dignitaries and family members — he warned that “our economy appears to be headed toward crisis,” but also called for a bipartisan spirit of unity and hope. He made indirect reference to his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, who announced his resignation on Wednesday amid a sex scandal, pledging to move beyond the often confrontational style Mr. Spitzer exhibited in his relations with the Legislature.

Although caricatures won't sway an election, they can influence public perception. Through caricatured distortion President Lyndon Johnson, with his elephantine ears and hooked beak, and President Richard Nixon, with his exaggerated five o'clock shadow and witches peak, were made equally buffoonish and demonic. Last week I made a kind of frittata with potatoes and asparagus. The interesting thing to me was that, as usual, I was rushed. I wanted the potatoes crisp-ish, but I wanted them soft, and I wanted them done fast. So I nuked them for a few minutes, then quickly peeled and browned them: perfect. Meanwhile, I briefly nuked the asparagus. Took them out, browned the asparagus a bit, lowered the heat, added the eggs, tucked the potatoes on top (better browned side up, for cosmetic purposes), and cooked the eggs while I went about my business.

The sea-faring La Dame de Canton rocked its way to middle age this winter, turning 30 while bobbing along the River Seine. In its early life, this replica of a 17th century Chinese junk sailed on the winds of the world, but nowadays La Dame is a funky Parisian nightclub that lists to the eclectic beat of old French songs, Balkan reggae or Mardi Gras manouche. You won't find many tourists aboard this ship, which has been keeping the same rhythm as a nightclub for the last 13 years at the foot of the Bibliotheque Nationale, a riverside refuge for other floating clubs. La Dame used to ply the club trade under the name of the "Guinguette Pirate," but for its 30th birthday the owners decided to shift back to its original name when the junk logged 38,000 miles and 17 countries

Here's one way to think about the liquidity trap -- a situation in which conventional monetary policy loses all traction. When short-term interest rates are close to zero, open-market operations in which the central bank prints money and buys government debt don't do anything, because you're just swapping one more or less zero-interest rate asset for another. Alternatively, you can say that there's no incentive to lend out any increase in the monetary base, because the interest rate you get isn't enough to make it worth bothering.

Bacterial meningitis was the probable cause of death for a Long Island man who died on Saturday, health officials said on Sunday.

Denis Watson won the AT&T Champions Classic for his third Champions Tour title in two seasons, beating Loren Roberts with a birdie on the third hole of a playoff at Valencia, Calif.Watson, the 2007 Senior PGA Championship and Boeing Classic winner, birdied the par-5 18th in regulation for a seven-under-par 65 and a share of the top spot with Roberts (70) and Brad Bryant (72).
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said elements of the proposed missile-defense system in Europe would not be turned on until Iran had demonstrated it had a missile capable of reaching Europe.

Louise Friberg of Sweden won her first L.P.G.A. Tour title in her fourth career start, closing with a seven-under-par 65 on Sunday for one-stroke victory over Yani Tseng of Taiwan in the MasterCard Classic in Huxquilucan, Mexico. Friberg, 10 strokes behind Ji-Young Oh at the start of play Sunday after opening rounds of 72 and 73, had an eagle, six birdies and a bogey.

Brian McBride beat Tim Howard, his former teammate on the United States national team, with a 67th-minute header, and Fulham used all five of its American players in a game for the first time in defeating visiting Everton, 1-0, in the English Premier League. McBride, Fulham’s captain, started along with goalkeeper Kasey Keller and Eddie Johnson. Defender Carlos Bocanegra entered in the 74th minute, and Clint Dempsey replaced McBride in the 88th.

Davide Rebellin of Italy won the Paris-Nice race by three seconds in the closest finish in the event. Rebellin was followed in the final standings by Rinaldo Nocentini of Italy. Yaroslav Popovych of Ukraine was third, 48 seconds behind. Rebellin was the runner-up in 2007.

Lewis Hamilton, last year’s Formula One runner-up, was never seriously threatened in winning an accident-filled Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne to open the season. Hamilton, 23, a British driver for McLaren, started from the pole and claimed his fifth victory in 18 Grand Prix starts. He finished in 1 hour 34 minutes 50.616 seconds. BMW-Sauber’s Nick Heidfeld was second, 5.4 seconds back.

Tony Graziani threw six touchdown passes — three to Chris Jackson — to help the Philadelphia Soul beat the visiting Dragons, 63-42, in the Arena Football League. Aaron Garcia threw 6 touchdowns passes for the Dragons (1-2). Kevin Swayne had seven receptions for 84 yards and 3 touchdowns.

Manny Pacquiao’s won a narrow split decision to claim Juan Manuel Marquez’s World Boxing Council 130-pound title in a fight that left both boxers bloody Saturday night in Las Vegas. Though Marquez landed more punches in this rematch, Pacquiao (46-3-2) knocked down Marquez (48-4-1) in the third round and persevered through a nasty cut.

Jeff Francoeur was beaned in the second inning of the Atlanta Braves’ game against the St. Louis Cardinals, and was down for a few minutes before walking off the field. Francoeur did not lose consciousness after being hit by the Cardinals’ Todd Wellemeyer in Jupiter, Fla.
The right-hander Josh Beckett will stay behind when the Red Sox fly 7,500 miles to Tokyo on Wednesday, even though he threw a ball 75 feet without back pain in Fort Myers, Fla.

An article on March 7 about arts education in New York City public schools incorrectly described the results of a city survey about instruction in the arts. Only 4 percent of the city’s elementary schools meet the state’s requirement for arts education, not 4 percent of all public schools. And fewer than 30 percent of middle school students — not middle schools — meet the state’s requirements in arts instruction. (Such instruction is offered by 79 percent of middle schools.).

KATZ--Helen D., of New Rochelle, New York died peacefully at home on March 12, 2008. She was the devoted wife of Martin J. Katz, sister of Muriel Elkind, mother of Linda K. Crollick of Florida, Paul K. Katz of Maine and Todd E. Katz of Alabama. The number of undecided superdelegates has fallen in recent weeks as both candidates have picked up support -- Barack Obama more so than Hillary Rodham Clinton, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News. Mr. Obama has gained the support of about 60 superdelegates in the last month while Mrs. Clinton added more than half as many. Still, just under half of the total 795 Democratic party leaders who will cast votes at the convention have not expressed a preference for either candidate. Some say they will vote according to their state's primary or caucus while others want to see how the next few months of the campaign play out. *Superdelegates from the Democrats abroad delegation get half a vote each, and those from Florida and Michigan were not included in the totals. The latest telephone survey of superdelegates was conducted March 12-14.

ARSENIO RODRíGUEZ ''El Alma de Cuba'' (Tumbao) This new six-disc boxed set by the Cuban bandleader and guitarist Arsenio Rodríguez, is a G.T.O.: a Great Thing, Objectively. First, it gets the stuff out there, collecting in one place nearly every scrap of music Rodríguez made for RCA Victor between 1940 to 1956, before he left Cuba for good (for New York and Los Angeles). His music has not previously been so well documented, in a large-canvas, year-by-year sense, and RCA has been a poor custodian of it. Second, it treats Rodríguez with a care equal to his importance, with dozens of pictures, extensive information on every recording session, a short biography in Spanish and English.

BERROL--Selma Cantor, of Manhattan. Beloved wife of Edward Berrol (deceased). Mother of Philip Berroll and Ann Berrol Newman; motherin-law of Jacalyn Filler and Bruce D. Newman, grandmother of Tracy Newman, Marc Filler-Berroll and Steven Filler-Berroll. Honors graduate of Girls High School (Brooklyn) Hunter College, and the City University of New York's Graduate Center. Professor Emerita, Baruch College, CUNY, and for 25 years Professor of History at the same. Official historian of Baruch College. Published works include ''Getting Down to Business: Baruch College in the City University of New York'' (Praeger, 1980). Dr. Berrol served as Baruch's Assistant Dean of Liberal Arts for many years, and was the first women to hold this position. Funeral services will be held today at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 12:45pm. Dr. Berol's son and daughter will be having Shivah at Mr. Berroll's home Monday through Wednesday.

An article on March 7 about arts education in New York City public schools incorrectly described the results of a city survey about instruction in the arts. Only 4 percent of the city's elementary schools meet the state's requirement for arts education, not 4 percent of all public schools. And fewer than 30 percent of middle school students -- not middle schools -- meet the state's requirements in arts instruction. (Such instruction is offered by 79 percent of middle schools.)

STRAWGATE--Bertha Heller, born December 12, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY to Lillian and Herman Heller, passed away of post-operative complications in L.A., CA on March 14, 2008 surrounded by her four loving daughters. She was predeceased by her three siblings and a stepsister. Betty was filled with a zest for life that kept her active, independent and colorful. She was the light of many lives including her daughters Laurie Kanefsky, Diane Rudolph, Susan Code and Pamela Strawgate, her sons-in-law Paul, Mark and Howard, her beloved grandchildren Jeremy, Jesse, Emily, Ethan, David and Rachel, and the many close friends she gathered throughout her 79 years. She will be missed beyond measure. A Memorial Service was held in L.A. on March 16, 2008. Memorial Services will be held Friday March 21, 2008 at 2:00pm at Congregation Sons of Israel, Briarcliff, NY. Malinow & Silverman Mortuary, 800-710-7100. Donations in her memory can be made to the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation.

Contributions to the Jewish Guild for the Blind would be meaningful.

BERGER--Herbert. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. Born July 4, 1919 in New York. Passed away on Saturday, March 15 after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. Herbert was very active in his Temple/Temple's men's club and with little league Baseball, in addition he was a member of the NY Mets Booster Club where he helped organize their welcome home dinner from spring training for many years. Herbert was also an accomplished writer and maintained his passion for writing up until his passing. Professionally he was employed by the NY State department of labor where he served as an administrator for forty years. ''Peta'' as he was affectionately known by his family is survived by his loving wife Thelma, sons Steven and Joel, brother Bertram, daughter-in-law Gail, grandchildren Ross and Ian, great-grandchildren Kayla, Jasmine, Travis and Casey, and other family members. He will be missed by all who knew him.

News Web sites are the third most popular destination in the information category, just behind search and weather, with sports a close fourth, according to M:Metrics, which measures mobile use. Other activities in the news and information category include choosing movies and restaurants and calling up traffic reports and maps to find the way. If the sports component were included, then ESPN places strongly, along with Fox and CBS. Most of the mobile users said they got their news and information through Yahoo, which is excluded here because it is also a portal. SHELLY FREIERMAN

TONY SCHERR ''Twist in the Wind'' (Smells Like) Tony Scherr has a few different profiles as a musician, each of them sharp-honed, peer-reviewed and generously melding into the others. Among jazz fans he commands respect as a bassist in settings either twangy (Bill Frisell) or twitchy (Sex Mob). He's also a known associate of Norah Jones, having played guitar on all of her records. And he's a singer-songwriter of deep and palpable conviction, as he proves with his second album, ''Twist in the Wind.''

HABERMAN--Jules J. Dr. Jules J. Haberman of Bethel, ME, a medical licensing and marketing consultant, died March 12, 2008. He was 86. A veterinarian by training, Dr. Haberman specialized in helping scientists and inventors develop, license and market medical devices, veterinary products and drug delivery systems. From 1956 to 1971 he was a copywriter and account executive with several New York advertising agencies. From 1972 to 1983 he was Director of Life Sciences for University Patents, Inc. (CTT), working to license and market medical inventions for universities, including Arizona, Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Case Western Reserve, New Mexico, Chicago and Pennsylvania. In Weston, CT, where he and his family lived for 35 years, Dr. Haberman, in 1982, founded H & H Consultants, Inc. with his wife, the former Mary Holcomb. Jules and Mary moved to Sierra Vista, AZ in 1989 where he continued his consulting work. In 2004 they relocated to Bethel, ME. Theater was Jules lifelong passion. Co-founding the Westport Community Theatre in 1956, he chaired its board for two years and directed many productions. Throughout his life he relished opportunities to mentor young people in both theater and business. Jules grew up in Brooklyn, NY receiving his BS and DVM degrees from Cornell University in 1945 and 1946. He spent two years as a game pathologist for the New York State Department of Conservation before moving to Los Angeles, CA. There he worked for the US Department of Agriculture, wrote and collaborated on musicals and radio scripts by night and authored two veterinary and agricultural books for Prentice-Hall. He subsequently served three years as a captain in the US Army Veterinary Corps. Dr. Haberman is survived by his wife Mary, four children Nancy Jo Cravalho (Edward), Elizabeth Meadows (Edward Easter), Jonathan Haberman (Anne), and Margaret Haberman (Landon Fake), six beloved grandchildren and his brother Philip. In his memory, donations may be made to the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, 130 East Seneca Street, Suite 400, Ithaca, NY 14850.

If the results of the ESPN.com N.C.A.A. tournament picks are indicative of the thinking of the people you share cubicle space with, here is a little strategy to get ahead in your office pool. The No. 1 bracket rule is to never pick the overwhelming favorite, as you would have to pick a nearly perfect bracket. So here is the counter-intuitive thought -- pick Kansas over North Carolina. The Jayhawks have the casual fans spooked after first-round losses in 2005 and 2006. But they are playing well, and you will have a better chance of winning with a slight risk instead of following the party line.

To the Editor: Thank you for publicizing the plight of satos -- street dogs -- in Puerto Rico in ''Scrutiny for Puerto Rico Over Animal Treatment'' (news article, March 9). Sadly, the situation in Puerto Rico is replicated in countries around the world where hundreds of millions of dogs live as strays, abandoned by the humans they have come to depend on for food, shelter and companionship. Change will take place only when governments work with local and international animal welfare groups and concerned individuals to address the root of the problem through education and humane methods of population control, such as spaying and neutering. As one animal advocate put it, ''we need to work together and keep the finger in the side of government.'' Thank you for doing just that, by telling the American public what's happening in Puerto Rico through your compelling article and photographs. Allan Kornberg Boston, March 11, 2008 The writer is executive director of the World Society for the Protection of Animals.

Investment banks and brokerage firms started cutting their payrolls last fall as the weakening market for mortgages translated into huge losses, Patrick McGeehan reports, and the collapse of Bear Stearns, Wall Street’s fifth-largest bank, has contributed to fears about a worsening local economy. Bear Stearns had about 14,000 employees, and as many as 8,000 of them worked in the city. Last year, those workers collected more than $3.4 billion in pay and benefits, or an average of about $242,000 per employee. The firm was one of the 25 largest employers in the city and accounted for about one of every 25 jobs in the city’s securities industry.

Updated, 2:10 p.m. | One day after taking office, Gov. David A. Paterson held a noontime news conference to discuss news reports that he and his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson, had extramarital affairs during a strain in their 15-year marriage. He acknowledged having affairs with “a number of women,” including one state employee, “several years ago,” but said that the relationships were over and that he and his wife had repaired their marriage.With his wife standing by his side, Mr. Paterson, 53, expressed regret for past mistakes but said he was coming forward to clear the air and avoid any “innuendo” or speculation that might arise. “I didn’t break the law,” he said, toward the end of his news conference, at the State Capitol in Albany. “I didn’t violate an oath. I didn’t use knowingly campaign funds. I didn’t use state funds at all. I know that. I don’t think institutionally there were any violations here. However, the public wants to know who its elected officials are, and sometimes, even though you are human and you are someone that just has feelings and has faults, there comes a time, perhaps, when you have to tell the public.”
Ah, Albany politics.

The other day, I went to the supermarket to buy a pineapple. I didn't select the one that smelled the ripest, but the one with the most impressive leaves: tall, bushy and uncrushed by the journey from Costa Rica. When I got it home, I put it in the kitchen sink, turned on the tap, and watched how the water gathered and formed pools in the spaces between the leaves. And I began to imagine that I was not a human in an apartment in London, but a small frog in a tropical forest, climbing up the leaves of a plant like a pineapple, looking for a pool where I could deposit the tadpole I'm carrying on my back.

Jean Todt resigned as chief executive of Ferrari on Tuesday, leaving the reins of the prancing horse to Amadeo Felisa, who had been Ferrari's general manager. The move wasn't wholly unexpected, as Todt had said that he would serve as chief executive only while Ferrari chairman Luca Cordero di Montezemolo served as chairman of Italy's employers lobby, a term which has recently ended. Mr. Todt says that his retirement will allow him to "dedicate more time to myself and the things I'm interested in."

From the beginning, the rationale for Barack Obama's campaign has been his call for Americans to transcend their differences -- both ideological and demographic. But Rev. Jeremiah Wright's comments would seem to have forced Senator Obama to choose sides -- to either stand with Reverend Wright and others who support his condemnations of the United States, or with those who think they should be rejected out of hand. But Senator Obama didn't choose: he criticized Reverend Wright's statements as wrong and divisive without being willing to distance himself from the pastor who has been so instrumental in the development of his religious faith. That's certainly Senator Obama's prerogative, but it doesn't answer a number of questions that he will continue to face in the days ahead.

For more than a week, since the media began to report on Rev. Jeremiah Wright's sermons, the anger has been building. First from whites who found these sermons filled with "hate," "race baiting," and "dangerous radicalism." And then from the black community, who defended Reverend Wright as a modern-day prophet and a speaker of views that resonated with "mainstream black America."

On Sept. 11, 2001, Tim McLaughlin, from Laconia, N.H., was a Marine Corps first lieutenant working in Room 5E678 of the Pentagon. He had broken his leg in training and was temporarily serving in an administrative capacity. He helped fire and rescue teams from within the Pentagon that day. A year and a half later, he commanded the first American tank that rolled into Baghdad's Firdos (Paradise) Square shortly after 4 p.m. on April 9, 2003, signaling the end of Saddam Hussein's rule. It was his Bravo Company, Third Battalion, Fourth Marines, First Marine Division, using a Hercules tank-recovery vehicle and a heavy chain, that helped Iraqis pull down Mr. Hussein's hollow metal statue before the world's television cameras. It was Lieutenant McLaughlin's Stars and Stripes flag given to him by a friend in the aftermath of the Pentagon attack that a marine briefly draped over the statue's head that day, an image that symbolized and outraged in equal measure. He left the Marine Corps as a captain on Sept. 1, 2006. Now 30, he is a second-year law student at Boston College.

In my Findings column on weird names, I reviewed the shifting views of pyschologists on the effect of unusual or cross-gender names. Four decades ago, there were studies suggesting that children suffered as a result of odd names, but subsequent researchers concluded otherwise. They found that once you adjust for the socioeconomic variables, children with unusual names do as well as others, and that boys with cross-gender names like Leslie turn out just fine -- in fact, they have more self-control than average.
