Two of Wall Street's top investment banks reported earnings well below the heights of last year, but still ahead of analysts' expectations at a time when investors are still on edge following the collapse of Bear Stearns.
Sendup of "Juno," with a schmear:
Shocked by the rapid demise of Bear Stearns and its fire sale to JPMorgan Chase, investors sold off the stock of Lehman Brothers and several other financial firms Monday.

The last thing anyone wants to do is to give iPhone users another chance to crow about their phone's slick interface and seamless connection to the Web. But, until now, little was known about the media habits of iPhone users and how they have diverged from the activities of mere mortals who own run-of-the mill smartphones and regular mobile phones.

In what is good news for the likes of George Clooney, Dustin Hoffman, and Arnold Schwarzeneggar, Tesla Motors on Monday moved into commercial production with the Tesla Roadster, an all-electric sports car.
SendMe Mobile, a provider of direct-to-consumer mobile entertainment, has raised more funds to extend its market share for its core brands and to expand upon them.

The decision by Chancellor William B. Chandler III in Jana Partners's proxy dispute with CNET is causing a kerfuffle among the New York law firms. Cleary Gottleib even went so far as to state in a client e-mail alert distributed over the weekend that "[w]e believe that this decision is wrong for a variety of reasons."

Shares of UBS, the biggest Swiss bank, fell the most in almost a decade on Monday amid concern that the lender might have to take further write-downs and after media reports suggested that it might cut as many as 8,000 jobs, raise more capital and sell its American brokerage business.

Pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines appear to have given up efforts to combine their seniority lists, which was considered essential to the two carriers' hopes for a merger without crippling rancor, The New York Times reported.

An agreement struck by The New York Times Company with a pair of hedge funds that want to shake up the company marks the first time since the Times Company went public in 1967 that it has accepted directors nominated by outsiders.

Visa, which plans to float shares on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday in the biggest initial public offering ever in the United States, will not be deterred by market turmoil that has taken a severe toll in recent days, analysts told Reuters on Monday.

The Renaissance Group, an investment bank based in Moscow, was expected to announce Tuesday that it had raised $660 million for a private equity fund, highlighting the rising demand from investors to put money into buyouts of Russian companies.

The outlook for New York City's economy and its main engine, the financial services industry, had already taken a bleak turn before the sudden failure of Bear Stearns, the fifth-largest firm on Wall Street.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):
Iomega, the storage technology company, said Monday it was prepared to begin acquisition talks with EMC after EMC raised a proposed buyout offer to $3.75 a share.
A $32 billion segment of Canada's debt market was placed under bankruptcy protection on Monday after a committee established to restructure the troubled debt missed a settlement deadline.
It's the spool-of-cable guys:

While turmoil in the financial sector has caused worries about the health of pending merger and acquisition deals, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan says there has been no change in process regarding its 34.8 billion Canadian dollar ($35 billion) takeover of the Canadian telecom BCE.

A French appeals court ruled Tuesday that Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader that Société Générale has blamed for nearly $7.7 billion in losses, should be released from jail while the investigation into his alleged fraud continued.

Eliot Spitzer wasn't very original, Science Times reports today. Infidelity is common to tens of thousands of other species -- like the great grey shrike, an elegant raptorlike bird with a silver cape, white belly and black tail:
The meltdown of Bear Stearns , which has been handling prospective buyers for the Tropicana Casino & Resort, will not affect the Atlantic City casino's sale, according to The Associated Press.
Pogo Jet, a start-up aiming to provide private jet charter service, said Monday it had postponed its planned initial public offering, citing unfavorable market conditions.
The Renewable Energy Group, a producer of biodiesel fuel, filed on Monday with federal regulators to withdraw a planned initial public offering of its common stock, citing current market conditions.
CSX, the railroad company, is striking back against two hedge funds that it says are more interested in controlling the company than in good corporate governance.

Deutsche Telekom took a step Monday toward gaining control of the former government-owned telecommunications company in Greece, in what would be a rare case of two former European telephone monopolies getting together.
The Supreme Court handed Microsoft a defeat on Monday by refusing to rule on its request to halt an antitrust suit against it.
Luminus Devices, a company that wants to change the lighting systems in digital TVs and in buildings, has raised $72 million in its latest round of funding.
A systems management company, BMC Software, said on Monday it intends to buy BladeLogic for $28 a share, or about $800 million net of cash acquired.

Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Did you hear, a bar in New York City has banned the song "Danny Boy." On St. Patrick's Day! Isn't that outrageous? It's like West Hollywood banning the song "It's Raining Men."
Will you buy a diesel?
A French appeals court ruled that Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader Société Générale has blamed for billions in losses, should be released from jail while an investigation continues.

With interest waning in "Old Europe," Moscow and Istanbul are seen as the top markets for property investment and development, according to the Urban Land Institute's latest "Emerging Trends" report for Europe.
Set amid the members of a high school faculty, “Miss Guided” belongs to the universe of stunted-growth comedy.
Properties on the market in Hawaii, New Mexico and Massachusetts.

The Wisconsin Badgers were probably upset enough after they were swept by St. Cloud State in the first round of the WCHA playoffs. But this didn't make them feel any better. Thanks in equal parts to their disappointing series and Colgate's upset of Clarkson, the Badgers are now on the outside of the NCAA Tournament looking in.
New York Gov. David A. Paterson took office under pressure to balance the state's budget. Albany bureau chief Danny Hakim reports.
What sets Fred Kaplan’s “Daydream Believers” apart is his emphasis on the Bush administration’s failure to come to terms with a post-cold-war paradigm.
While adept at hawking car insurance, the gecko is not the greatest climber. However, it recovers from slips with the help of its tail.
It’s effective, but only recently have scientists begun to understand how DEET works to repel insects.
Switching to electric cars would reduce dependency on oil, but few consider the how surge in electricity usage would impact our water supply.
While Eliot Spitzer’s use of a prostitute displayed his hypocrisy, impulsiveness and self-indulgence, he was decidedly unoriginal.
Dr. Terri Brentnall has identified a gene that may be one cause of an inherited form of pancreatic cancer.
Mr. Clarke was a writer whose seamless blend of scientific expertise and poetic imagination helped usher in the space age.
Visa Inc., the world’s largest credit card network, Tuesday raised $17.9 billion in an initial public offering, the largest ever in the United States.
A majority of the Supreme Court appeared ready on to embrace an interpretation of the Second Amendment that protects the right to own a gun for personal use.
The reduction of the benchmark interest rate to 2.25 percent was less than investors had been hoping for, though it was one of the deepest in Fed history.
Gov. David A. Paterson of New York admitted that he had had affairs, including one with a woman on the state payroll.
A former dentist from New Jersey is charged with running a corrupt $4.6 million enterprise to harvest and sell human tissue from funeral homes.
The British filmmaker won an Academy Award for his direction of “The English Patient.”
The request, while politically embarrassing, is not binding, and Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick has promised not to quit, even as the number of people saying that he should is growing.
For small business owners, forging a good working relationship with your banker is crucial, and it can result in more credit, lower fees and streamlined paperwork.
A Brooklyn jury convicted the 7-year-old girl’s stepfather of first-degree manslaughter.
Senator Barack Obama declared that it was time to “move beyond some of our old racial wounds.”
Investors sent stock markets soaring to their highest gains in a week after the Federal Reserve slashed its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a point.
Businesses paid more for consumer goods, cars and nonenergy products last month, raising inflation fears as the Fed considers how much to cut rates.
Stocks rallied in early trading as investors, relieved by better-than-expected results from Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs, also anticipated a big interest rate cut from the Fed.
Housing starts in February fell by 0.6 percent to a higher-than-expected annual rate while building permit activity dropped off 7.8 percent, the government said.
Producer prices rose by 0.3 percent in February as expected, the government reported, but a key measure of core inflation at the producer level climbed at the fastest pace in well over a year.
Lehman said it earned $489 million, compared with earnings of $1.15 billion in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

The investment bank said first-quarter earnings fell by half after it recorded steep losses on corporate loans and other assets, yet the results exceeded expectations that have fallen in recent weeks.

Astronauts from the shuttle Endeavour completed the assembly of a giant robot called Dextre on Monday in the third of five scheduled spacewalks outside the International Space Station. Dr. Richard M. Linnehan and Maj. Robert L. Behnken of the Air Force removed thermal covers from the Canadian-built maintenance robot’s 11-foot arms and attached a 5-foot metal boom to its front for holding equipment and tools. They added a holder for three tools under the 3,400-pound robot’s right arm and a pan-and-tilt color camera on its body so operators can observe its work. The $209 million robot, which has passed initial operating tests, will be attached to the station’s Destiny laboratory module.

The man at the center of a ricin scare at a Las Vegas motel said he never had any intention of hurting anyone with the deadly biological agent, his brother told The Associated Press. The man, Roger Bergendorff, who regained consciousness last week after almost a month of hospitalization, possessed the ricin powder found in his motel room in February and believes that he was contaminated by it, said Erich Bergendorff, who talked to his brother on the phone Sunday. “He just confirmed that it was not intended for anybody,” Erich Bergendorff said. “It was something that would be used for his own purposes, for self-defense.” Roger Bergendorff, 57, was upgraded from critical to fair condition Monday. Erich Bergendorff said his brother was cooperating with investigators.
Mike Bibby scored 23 points and Joe Johnson added 18 points and 10 assists to lead the Atlanta Hawks over the host Washington Wizards, 105-96, on Monday night.

The Big City column on Friday, about the clash between fantasy and reality in the prostitution scandal that ensnared Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, referred incorrectly in some editions to Kristen, the prostitute he is said to have met in a Washington hotel last month. She was not in fact a client of Emperor’s Club V.I.P. (It was Mr. Spitzer who was a client, according to a federal affidavit.).

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Saturday about Michael Levy, the lawyer representing a potential witness in the spying scandal involving the New England Patriots, misstated the title for Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican who has been critical of the N.F.L. in the matter. He is the Senate Judiciary Committee’s ranking member — not its chairman, a position held by Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.

A picture caption in some editions on Saturday with a sports article about Georgetown’s 72-55 victory over West Virginia in the Big East men’s basketball tournament misidentified a Hoyas player who was shown defending Joe Alexander of the Mountaineers. It was DaJuan Summers, not his teammate Chris Wright.

An article on Saturday about the impasse over the disputed Democratic primaries in Michigan and Florida rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Stacie Paxton, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, whose chairman is Howard Dean. Ms. Paxton said, “It’s never productive to negotiate through the press, but make no mistake, Howard Dean will continue to lead the effort to find a workable solution that’s fair and consistent with the rules.” She did not say, “It’s never productive to negotiate through the process.”.

An obituary by The Associated Press on March 1 about Ben Chapman, an actor who had the title role in the 1954 film “Creature From the Black Lagoon,” misstated the name of the California town where a surviving stepdaughter, Elyse Maree Raljevich, lives. It is Coto de Caza, not Coto De Gaza.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the coming presidential election in Taiwan misattributed a quotation about a referendum that will ask Taiwanese to choose the name under which the country will apply for membership in the United Nations. It was Hsiao Bi-khim, a former lawmaker and spokeswoman for Frank Hsieh, one of the candidates, who said, “We see China as a giant with its hands around our neck, trying to suffocate us, trying to shut off our space on the international stage.” It was not Mr. Hsieh himself who made the comment.

An article on Sunday about the appointment of a new leader of the Smithsonian Institution, G. Wayne Clough, misstated the timing of the retirement of the former director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian in recounting issues of oversight and accountability with which the institution has been wrestling. While the former director, W. Richard West Jr., remained on the Smithsonian’s payroll until the end of last year, his retirement in December preceded a Washington Post report about his spending on travel; he did not retire after the report was published.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the coming presidential election in Taiwan misattributed a quotation about a referendum that will ask Taiwanese to choose the name under which the country will apply for membership in the United Nations. It was Hsiao Bi-khim, a former lawmaker and spokeswoman for Frank Hsieh, one of the candidates, who said, “We see China as a giant with its hands around our neck, trying to suffocate us, trying to shut off our space on the international stage.” It was not Mr. Hsieh himself who made the comment.

An article in some editions on Sunday about the deadly collapse of a construction crane on the East Side of Manhattan included an erroneous spelling from city officials in some copies for the surname of one victim. He was Wayne Bleidner, not Binder.

A headline and an article in the Connecticut section on Sunday about Toquam Magnet, a K-5 school in Stamford, referred incorrectly to its status. A committee of the Stamford School District board is to vote on Wednesday night on whether to close the school, and the full board will take up the matter later; the board has not already closed the school.
The Jets signed the three-time Pro Bowl tight end Bubba Franks to a one-year deal.
It seems hard to imagine now, in the waning weeks of what could be the worst season in Knicks history, but Isiah Thomas was once considered a very capable head coach.
Right wing Kyle Okposo will be making his N.H.L. debut Tuesday night, when the Islanders play host to the Toronto Maple Leafs.

An Arizona prosecutor has filed a motion to dismiss 2 of 10 charges against the polygamist sect leader Warren S. Jeffs. The Mohave County attorney, Matt Smith, filed a motion on March 10 to dismiss one charge of sexual conduct with a minor and one of conspiracy to commit sexual conduct with a minor in a 2005 case. Those charges stem from the arranged marriage of a 16-year-old girl and her cousin, who was more than a decade older. In the motion, Mr. Smith says the girl has indicated through her lawyer that she will not testify against Mr. Jeffs. Mr. Jeffs, who was already prosecuted in Utah, is charged as an accomplice with incest and sexual conduct with a minor.

The head of a state licensing bureau was fired on orders from Gov. Jim Gibbons, part of a housecleaning effort after a hepatitis C outbreak in Las Vegas. But three doctors on the State Board of Medical Examiners whom Mr. Gibbons wants replaced did not resign. Mr. Gibbons wants them replaced because of their associations with Dr. Dipak Desai, owner of the Endoscopy Center of Southern Nevada. Officials last month said that through unsafe syringe use, six patients at the center were infected with hepatitis C. Another 40,000 people are being notified to get tested. Tony Clark, the board’s executive director whom Mr. Gibbons also wants replaced, said he would not step down at Mr. Gibbons’s request, but would follow the board’s direction.

A House committee opened an investigation into potential conflicts of interest in scientific panels that advise the Environmental Protection Agency. The House Energy and Commerce Committee cited the case of eight scientists who were consultants or members of agency science advisory panels assessing the health effects of toxic chemicals while getting research support from the chemical industry on the same chemicals they were examining. In two cases, agency advisers were employed by companies that made or worked with manufacturers of the chemicals being evaluated, the panel said.

Younger emergency room patients with heart attack symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, anxiety and palpitations should be asked if they have recently used cocaine, the American Heart Association warned doctors. For these patients, honesty can be a matter of life or death because some heart attack treatments can be deadly to someone using cocaine. Guidelines published online Monday in the American Heart Association journal Circulation say that doctors should be aware that symptoms of a heart attack in younger patients with no risk factors may be caused by cocaine.

The Hannaford Brothers supermarket chain announced a security breach that began Dec. 7 and led to thefts of customer credit and debit card numbers from more than 200 stores. Hannaford says the security breach affects all of its 165 stores in the Northeast, 106 Sweetbay stores in Florida and a smaller number of independent groceries. The company estimates that 4.2. million credit and debit card numbers were potentially exposed, and that there have been about 1,800 cases of reported fraud related to the breach, said Carol Eleazer, Hannaford’s vice president of marketing in Scarborough. The company says card numbers were stolen in the authorization transmission process.

Volvo said it had reached a three-year agreement with workers at a plant in New River Valley, Va., ending a strike there. About 2,600 workers at the plant, which makes Mack and Volvo trucks, have been on strike since Feb. 1. Volvo said the employees would return to work on March 24 and would begin ramping up production to 146 vehicles a day. The company, based in Gothenburg, gave no details of the agreement.

Deutsche Telekom, the European telecommunications company, said it had agreed to buy a stake of almost 20 percent in Greece’s biggest phone company, Hellenic Telecommunications Organization, in a $3.9 billion deal and hopes to increase the stake. Deutsche Telekom, based in Bonn, said it would buy the shares from a Greek private equity firm, the Marfin Investment Group, for 26 euros ($40.46) a share. Mike Cansfield, an analyst at Ovum, said the attraction for Deutsche Telekom was Hellenic’s mobile phone unit, Cosmote, which has investments in Bulgaria, Macedonia, Romania and Albania. “Mobile growth is difficult to find in most countries, but in the Balkan states and some Eastern European markets, the potential is there,” Mr. Cansfield said. Deutsche Telekom, which owns T-Mobile, said it hoped to hold talks with the Greek government, Hellenic’s largest shareholder, about increasing its stake in Hellenic even more.

The Aluminum Corporation of China, the nation’s biggest producer of aluminum, posted a 25 percent fall in second-half profit after prices declined and raw material costs increased. Net income dropped to 3.8 billion yuan in the six months ended Dec. 31, from a revised 5.1 billion yuan a year earlier, the company said. Aluminum prices in China dropped 7.7 percent in the second half from a year earlier after producers increased supplies too quickly. The company said higher prices of raw materials, power and transport would put more pressure on costs this year.
A Roselle, N.J., police officer who wounded a teenager will not face criminal charges.
The Carolina Panthers came to terms with the Seattle free agent D. J. Hackett on a two-year, $3.5 million deal.
The Davis Cup captain Patrick McEnroe has decided not to return as the United States Olympic coach.

The defending champion Rafael Nadal defeated the 18-year-old Donald Young in their first meeting, and James Blake evened his record against his familiar foe Carlos Moyà in third-round matches at the Pacific Life Open in Indian Wells, Calif.Nadal won, 6-1, 6-3. Blake took a methodical 6-3, 6-4 victory against Moyà, who at 31 had been the oldest player left in the men’s side of the tournament..The two-time women’s title winner Lindsay Davenport, who often seemed her own worst enemy, bounced back from a second-set loss and had to overcome 48 unforced errors to defeat Chan Yung-Jan, 6-4, 5-7, 6-2. Jelena Jankovic, the women’s No. 3 seed, romped to a 6-1, 6-1 victory against Ai Sugiyama.
The national champion Axel Buescher tested positive for an EPO masking agent, the German Billiard Union said.
Paul Lo Duca and Lastings Milledge sat in the opposing clubhouse and did their best not to say anything controversial about the fact that they no longer play for the Mets.
The San Francisco 49ers signed receiver Bryant Johnson, adding another veteran pass catcher from a division rival to the new coordinator Mike Martz’s offense.
Dan Klecko signed a two-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles, who planned to convert him from defensive tackle to a full-time fullback.
The Olympian Darren Chiacchia remained unconscious and in critical condition with a severe head injury after falling off his horse during a weekend competition in Florida.
Athletes who take human growth hormone might not be getting the boost they expected.
Juan González missed his seventh straight spring training game Monday and is losing ground in his effort to win a spot with the St. Louis Cardinals.
The city’s stricter policy would require next year’s eighth graders to pass classes in core subject areas and to score at a basic level on standardized English and math exams.
Elif Shafak was put on trial for “insulting Turkishness” for her novel “The Bastard of Istanbul,” now longlisted for a prestigious British fiction prize.
The Fed is putting its reputation and resources on the line to rescue Wall Street’s biggest institutions from their mistakes.
If the U.S. government doesn’t stabilize the markets, foreign governments increasingly will, in exchange for an ever larger stake in the American financial system.
Whatever gain China may have gotten from being elevated above the likes of North Korea, Myanmar, Iran and Sudan was lost by the crackdown on Tibet.

When the Gators lost in the first round of the Southeastern Conference tournament, they knew it would keep them out of the N.C.A.A. tournament field. They had no idea it would also get them kicked out of their practice facility.
It may not be possible to completely remove the risk from large-scale building projects, but the public is entitled to know that every reasonable step is being taken.
The bill would pre-emptively bar New York City and other school districts from linking teacher tenure to students’ test scores.
The White House faced accusations that it is helping a corporate giant but doing little to aid people facing foreclosure.
The rivalry between Connecticut and Tennessee in women’s basketball took a step toward renewal on the court when each team was awarded a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament pairings.
Evan Lysacek and Johnny Weir share nothing — except their status as the top two figure skaters in the United States.
For the Supreme Court to choose this moment to strike down reasonable gun rules would defy common sense, and needlessly put innocent people at risk.
In the debate over relicensing two nuclear reactors, it’s risk versus benefit.
Dennis P. Gallagher resigned from office and pleaded guilty on Monday to two misdemeanors, admitting that he sexually abused a woman while he was intoxicated.
The dismantling of Dodgertown, the Dodger’s home since 1948, represents another wrecking-ball blow to baseball’s tradition.
Officials believe they can establish a posture of deterrence adapted to the global jihadi terrorist movement.
Throngs of construction employees from across the city took a break from work to wait at the site of the crane collapse and pay their respects.
An investigation into the cause of Saturday’s deadly crane points to a $50 piece of nylon webbing that may have broken while hoisting a six-ton piece of steel.
Critics of the Federal Reserve’s role in the sale of Bear Stearns have raised the specter of moral hazard. What is moral hazard?
The dollar, which tumbled to an almost 13-year low against the yen on Monday, may soon find a protector here — the Japanese finance ministry.
The CME Group said Monday that it would buy the New York Mercantile Exchange in a $9.4 billion cash-and-stock deal.
A closely watched measure of manufacturing activity in the New York area plunged in March to the lowest level on record.
Gov. David A. Paterson offered wisecracks to an audience that clearly ached to move beyond a sordid ordeal.
Kenyan government and opposition leaders helped finance and organize violence that left more than 1,000 dead, a Human Rights Watch report said.
A suicide car bomb killed seven soldiers and civilians in an attack at a bazaar in southern Afghanistan.
Some 30 paintings by such masters as Monet, Cézanne and Corot and a Rodin sculpture were stolen from the home of an antiques dealer near Paris.
In a solemn ceremony in Paris, France paid tribute to its last World War I veteran, who died last week at 110, and the other 8.4 million Frenchmen who fought in the conflict.
Former President Valéry Giscard d’Estaing is selling the 23-room, 15th-century La Varvasse chateau he inherited in Chanonat, in the Auvergne region.
Cuba has lifted a ban on some farmers buying supplies in the latest sign that the new president, Raúl Castro, is turning to individual initiative to stimulate food production.
Defense Minister Fatmir Mediu resigned after a series of explosions at a weapons depot near Tirana on Saturday and Sunday killed at least 16 people and wounded nearly 300.
A naked assailant was shot to death as he grappled with a female officer.
As Major League Soccer expands to 15 teams next year, then to 16 teams in 2010, and with more expansion expected, the league plans to search for more foreign players to fill out its rosters.
Pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines appear to have given up efforts to combine their seniority lists.
For employees of Bear Stearns, many of whom have spent most of their professional lives at Bear, the sudden collapse was unfathomable.
The $6-billion acquisition makes International Paper North America’s largest maker of corrugated boxes.
The justices agreed to give the F.C.C. a chance to defend its decision to start punishing broadcasters for the isolated and fleeting on-air use of expletives.
The outlook for New York City’s economy and its main engine, the financial services industry, had already taken a bleak turn before the sudden failure of Bear Stearns.
The new governor’s speech expands students’ ideas of what is possible, said Bernadette Kappen, executive director of the New York Institute for Special Education.
Kevin Love is the athlete of the moment in Southern California, a 6-foot-10 freshman center leading the top-seeded U.C.L.A. Bruins into the N.C.A.A. tournament.
Bear Stearns’s downfall and subsequent sale to JPMorgan Chase on Sunday was orchestrated by some of the most powerful people on Wall Street and in Washington.
A $32 billion segment of Canada’s debt market was placed under bankruptcy protection on Monday after a committee established to restructure the troubled debt missed a deadline.
Société Générale, the French bank hobbled by a trading loss of more than $7 billion, announced Monday that it was reorganizing its senior management team.
Photos tracking the paths of 20 bullets that pierced Sean Bell’s car when police fired at it outside a Queens nightclub were admitted into evidence.
The decision allows the State Police and law enforcement officials in 17 of New Jersey’s 21 counties to resume using a new breath test known as the Alcotest 7110.
At Major League Baseball’s first game in China, things that seem normal in the United States translated in odd ways.
A federal appeals court panel reversed the insider-trading conviction of Joseph P. Nacchio, ruling that a federal district court judge had wrongly excluded a witness.
The bipartisan plan would require all residents to have health care coverage within three years.
Metropolitan Laurus’s most historic moment was an exchange of kisses on the cheek last May with the Patriarch of Moscow, Aleksei II.
The Center for Genomics and Health Disparities will aim to untangle the genetic, economic and social factors that contribute to differences in disease rates among races.
A report cites failures by the F.B.I. and its sister agencies to update information about suspects on the list and to remove names of others found to pose no threat.
The disasters Ms. Taft dealt with in 1988 alone included a Bangladesh flood that left 25 million people homeless, Ethiopian famine and a poisonous gas eruption in Cameroon.
Workers had put 99 tons of sand on the roadway directly over two of the bridge’s weakest points, according to a National Transportation Safety Board report.
The New York Times Company has struck a deal with a pair of hedge funds, giving the funds two seats on the board in order to avoid a proxy fight.
The pilot, John J. Cota, is charged with causing the ship to strike the Bay Bridge and spill some 58,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil into San Francisco Bay.
The Golden Gate National Recreation Area and the National Park Service are facing a federal lawsuit claiming parks do not provide adequate access to the disabled.
Nervousness pervaded Wall Street despite the efforts by the Federal Reserve to restore order within the financial system.
Shaking up its leadership for the third time in six months, Citigroup has named John Havens as the new head of its investment banking and alternative investments group.
The investor is buying the mortgage servicing business of H& R Block for $1.1 billion.
Conservatives controlled about three-quarters of the more than 200 races decided so far in the 290-seat Parliament, the Interior Ministry said.
MADRID, (AP) — Ola Brunkert, a former drummer for the Swedish pop band Abba, was found dead on Sunday with cuts to his neck in the garden of his house in Arta, on the Spanish island of Mallorca.
The Supreme Court handed Microsoft a defeat on Monday by refusing to rule on its request to halt an antitrust suit against it.
Jurors’ questions indicate they may be weighing the three most serious charges against Cesar Rodriguez, accused of fatally beating his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown.
While the machines at Gold’s Gym in Haiti’s capital are state-of-the-art, those at the humble “Temple of Pain” are made of scrap metal.
The only meeting in March between the Yankees and Red Sox seemed incidental to the upcoming trips for both teams.
At a time when most companies are scrambling for a prime seat on the green bandwagon, why not a company-branded wind farm?
The World Health Organization said the findings were worrisome, threatening to increase the risks of transmitting drug-resistant strains.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,981 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
The strength of an economy comes, fundamentally, from what it can produce. Can America still produce homes? Yes.
The mobile check-in may well be the first step in direct communications between airlines and passengers as they travel.

ABC had the most viewers on Sunday night, thanks to new installments of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give,” which delivered 12 million and 9.7 million viewers at 8 and 9, respectively, Nielsen estimated. ABC’s “Here Come the Newlyweds” at 10 (7 million) led its time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” rerun (7.7 million) over all. CBS’s “Dexter” was third in the hour (6.4 million). CBS and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place that night. CBS’s “60 Minutes” drew the network’s largest audience, with 11.1 million at 7. Fox placed fourth in total viewers, but second in the 18-to-49 set.

Taslima Nasreen, right, the exiled Bangladeshi writer, said she would leave India after living in hiding there for nearly four months, because of failing health, Reuters reported. Violent protests by Muslim groups in November forced Indian authorities to move the writer from her home in Calcutta to an undisclosed safe house in New Delhi, where no visitors were allowed. “I have not been able to see a good cardiologist for the last few months, and I have a serious heart problem,” Ms. Nasreen, 45, said. She fled Bangladesh in 1994 when a court ruled that she had “deliberately and maliciously” hurt Muslim religious feelings with her Bengali-language novel “Lajja” (“Shame”), in which she argued that the country’s Hindu minority was poorly treated. Ms. Nasreen, who had made her home in Calcutta since 2004, said she would move to France or Germany.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music will open its third annual Sundance Institute series on May 29 with the documentary “American Teen.” Written and directed by Nanette Burstein (“The Kid Stays in the Picture”), “American Teen,” which won the Sundance Documentary Directing prize, tracks the lives of four Indiana high school students over one school year. The Sundance Institute series of breakout films from this year’s festival will run through June 8. The full schedule will be announced on April 15.

The 68,000-square-foot C. V. Starr East Asian Library at the University of California, Berkeley, opened to the public on Monday. The library, designed by the New York-based architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, holds more than 900,000 volumes, as well as manuscripts, bronze objects and the most comprehensive collection of historic Japanese maps outside of Japan. The building also incorporates the Center for Chinese Studies Library, the largest academic repository in the United States of materials on the People’s Republic of China.

Wally Lamb, the novelist twice chosen by Oprah Winfrey for her book club, is scheduled to publish his first novel in 10 years this November. “The Hour I First Believed” is Mr. Lamb’s third novel, and like his second, “I Know This Much Is True,” it’s a long one: 800 pages. The new novel, which will be published by Harper, an imprint of HarperCollins, begins with a married couple moving to Littleton, Colo., in 1999 to take jobs at Columbine High School, where the wife ends up cowering in the library the day two students go on a shooting rampage. In the aftermath the couple moves to the husband’s family farm in Connecticut. She tries to recover, while the husband stumbles on a series of family secrets. Mr. Lamb’s first novel, “She’s Come Undone,” was originally published in 1992 by Pocket Books; 4.5 million copies are now in print. “I Know This Much Is True,” published by Regan Books in 1998, has 2.8 million copies in print. Harper has announced a first print run of 500,000 copies for the new novel.

While grappling with MSNBC and CNN for viewers, Fox News has also been battling a smaller, more insidious enemy closer to home: bed bugs in its Midtown Manhattan newsroom. In an interview on Monday, Warren Vandeveer, senior vice president for operations and engineering at Fox News, said the cable channel had realized it had a problem a few weeks ago, when an employee “caught a bug and showed it to us.” An exterminator determined that the incursion was limited to a “very small area in the newsroom.” But the source of the bugs was not determined until the exterminator inspected the homes of about 20 employees. Mr. Vandeveer said the exterminator later described one employee’s home as having “the worst infestation he had seen in 25 years in the business.” After making large bags available for employees to stash their belongings, and replacing a number of fabric-covered desk chairs, Mr. Vandeveer said that the treatments had ended about a week ago, and that the problem had been contained. “It’s totally eradicated,” he said.

A British judge awarded Heather Mills, right, a total of £24.3 million, about $48.9 million, in her divorce settlement with Paul McCartney. In a summary of his decision, the judge in the case, Hugh Bennett, said that Mr. McCartney would pay Ms. Mills a lump sum of £16.5 million (about $33.2 million); this would be in addition to Ms. Mills’s current assets of £7.8 million (about $15.7 million). Mr. McCartney, 65, must also provide the equivalent of about $70,000 a year for the couple’s 4-year-old daughter, Beatrice, and pay her school and nanny fees. The judge said that Mr. McCartney had about £400 million in assets, and that Ms. Mills, 40, had originally asked for almost £125 million. They married in 2002 and separated four years later. After the decision Mr. McCartney left the court, declining comment; Ms. Mills spoke at length to waiting reporters. Among other things, she accused Mr. McCartney of wanting their daughter to fly economy, while he flew first class. The judge said he planned to make his entire ruling public; Ms. Mills said she would contest that.

A rebound in car sales lifted Canadian manufacturers’ sales in January, rebounding from a three-year low set a month earlier. Statistics Canada said factory shipments rose by 1.3 percent, to 49.3 billion Canadian dollars ($49.8 billion), after sliding 3.7 percent in December. With the exception of December, though, factory sales were still at their lowest since March 2005, as manufacturers struggled to compete amid a strong Canadian dollar, higher energy prices and the downturn in the United States. Excluding auto sales, which rose 4.5 percent, factory sales gained 1.1 percent in January. Auto sales fell 25.6 percent in December to the lowest level in almost a decade.

HIGHER FARES, AGAIN Another sweeping fare increase by major domestic airlines seemed to be holding on Monday even after United Airlines and Continental Airlines partly rolled back some of their increases over the weekend, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of FareCompare.com. The rise in prices, the fourth this year, was initiated late last week by United Airlines, which raised fares $50 on round-trip routes of over 1,500 miles each way. United’s competitors among the six so-called legacy carriers followed with similar increases over the weekend. Mr. Seaney said that the scattered rollbacks of the increases on some routes appeared to be responses to “normal competitive pressure” rather than a signal of a broad retreat from the increases.

FREEMAN--Muriel, at the age of 91, passed away at her home in New York City on March 15th, 2008, leaving her son James and daughter-inlaw Laura, three grandchildren; Rebecca Freeman, Hadley Lehrman and Jim Freeman, grandson-in-law Gary Lehrman, two great-grandchildren, Jacob and Andrew Lehrman and her closest friend Dorothy Collier. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday March 18th at 5:007:30pm. Service Wednesday, March 19th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell. FREEMAN--Muriel Leopold, January 2, 1917--March 15, 2008. Author, sportswoman and philanthropist passed away at home in New York City on March 15, 2008. Muriel Freeman was born on January 2, 1917 to Mildred and Arthur Leopold in Woodmere, Long Island. She graduated from Wilson College where she was head of the equestrian team and regularly competed at the National Horse show at Madison Square Garden. Muriel was married to Bunny Freeman on September 17, 1937 until his untimely passing in 1972 at 55 years old. He was an avid golfer and encouraged her to take up the sport. During the 1950s, 60s and 70s, she won the Women's Long Island Golf championship seven times, The Cross County Championship five times, the Women's Metropolitan Championship once and was the New York State Championship medalist in 1957. During the 1960s and 70s, she became more involved in the dog show world. In the 1980s Muriel was the first non-German and first woman to judge the Rottweiler Bundesieger in Germany--considered to be the pinnacle in Rottweiler knowledge--and would do it again a few years later. She also traveled extensively, judging at prestigious dog shows all over the world. Muriel Freeman was best known in recent years for her extraordinary knowledge of working and herding dogs. In 1984, she wrote The Complete Rottweiler. It is in its 26th edition and has sold more volumes than any single breed dog book. It was required reading for new AKC judges working with larger breeds. In 1989, she judged Best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club Show at Madison Square Garden--considered to be pinnacle of the U.S. dog world by the cognoscenti. As part of her interest in dogs, Muriel Freeman worked with and endowed many significant studies at the University of Pennsylvania Veterinary School and the Orthopedic Foundation for Animals (OFA) to define and limit hip dysplasia and the other diseases that strike larger dog breeds. Muriel Freeman passed away at her home in New York City on March 15 leaving her son James and daughter-in-law Laura, three grandchildren, Rebecca Freeman, Hadley Lehrman and Jim Freeman, grandsonin-law Gary Lehrman, two great-grandchildren, Jacob and Andrew Lehrman, and her closest friend Dorothy Collier. Friends and family are invited to the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, Tuesday evening from 5:00-7:30 pm. The funeral will be Wednesday at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations to The University of Pennsylvania Veterinary School would be appreciated.

EGGERT--Frederick W. (Bill), Jr., Judge, died at home in East Hampton on March 4 after a long illness. Born in the Bronx on June 28, 1917, he graduated from Evander Childs High School, Fordham College and Fordham Law School. During World War II he was a Captain in the US Army and commanded the 225th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Battalion from the Normandy invasion to V-E Day. He was awarded the Bronze Star and five battle stars. He served as an Assistant District Attorney of Bronx County, and later was elected to the state Assembly, representing the Bronx's 12th District for five terms. During that time he practiced law, initially as a sole practitioner and later as senior partner with Eggert and Higgins. In 1973, he was elected to the Civil Court of the City of New York, Bronx County. Four years later he was elected justice for the Supreme Court of that borough, where he served until retirement in 1993. Judge Eggert participated in the formation and growth of the Advisory Committee on Judicial Ethics. He was married to the former Doris T. Higgins, who died in 1974. He is survived by three sons, William, John and Christopher, and three daughters, Mary, Anne and Elizabeth Talmage, and four grandchildren. There will also be a Mass at 11:00am on Saturday, April 19 at the Fordham University Church at 441 E. Fordham Road. The family requests donations to the Inner-city Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10022 or to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

WHARTON--Irving L., died peacefully at home on March 16, 2008; he was 96 years old. Mr. Wharton led an exemplary life, rich in accomplishments. He enjoyed the respect and affection of all who knew him. He was an honor graduate of the St. John's University School of Law. As a young attorney he was a public defender. In 1938 he, together with Paul O'Dwyer, argued before the appellate division in People vs. Forte which established the law in New York against the admission of lie detector testimony. As Executive Vice President of J. Halperin & Company, he designed the financing for Levittown, Long Island and Levittown, Pennsylvania which brought a new concept of ownership housing to thousands following World War II. As the President of I. Wharton & Company, he was recognized as an authority on FHA financing of multi-family housing and nursing homes. He also served as Trustee in Bankruptcy for Continental Vending Machine Company which broke new ground in such areas as accountants' liability. From 1957 he served as a trustee of Long Island Jewish Hospital and two terms as its Chairman. He was honored by the National Counsel of Christians and Jews and UJA Federation as their Man of the Year. His wife, Sally Price Wharton, died in 1974. His son, Robert Wharton, died in 2003. He is survived by his companion Ruth Donner; his son, Geoffrey P. Wharton and his wife, Susan; his daughter-inlaw, Karen Levine and his grandchildren, James Wharton and his wife Sara, Sarah Wharton, Kate Wharton Cury and her husband Peter and their son Julian, and Seth Wharton. Donations in his memory can be made to the Northshore LIJ Health Care System. A family graveside burial service was conducted. WHARTON--Irving. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club, record the passing of our long time member. Mr. Wharton has been a member of the club for over fifty years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Allen Kaplan, President Victor Linell, Secretary WHARTON--Irving. Service Guild of LIJ offers condolences to his family. Irving was a staunch supporter of the Guild since its inception. Beverly Sutton Fran Balke WHARTON--Irving L. Died peacefully at home, 96 years old, best friend and soul mate of Ruth Donner, sweethearts for 36 years. I will always love him and miss him. Ruth Donner WHARTON--Irving L. The trustees and staff of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are deeply saddened by this weekend's passing of Irving L. Wharton of Floral Park, NY, our chairman emeritus, who was instrumental in guiding LIJ Medical Center's growth from a community hospital in the 1950s to one of the region's preeminent teaching hospitals. A lawyer and expert in real estate financing, he became LIJ Medical Center's fifth chairman in 1976 and personally raised millions of dollars on behalf of the hospital. He was dedicated to many healthcare and social causes, and was instrumental in establishing medical school affiliations on behalf of North Shore-LIJ hospitals. His late wife Sally was one of the founders of the LIJ Service Guild. He is survived by his son Geoffrey P. Wharton, also a North Shore-LIJ trustee, and his near and dear friend Ruth Donner. We extend our most sincere condolences to the entire family. Contributions may be made in his memory to the North Shore-LIJ Health System. Saul Katz, Chairman Michael Dowling, President and CEO WHARTON--Irving. A treasured confidant, a true gentleman, and a tireless fundraiser. Irving, you set the standard for the definitions of devoted friend and dedicated trustee. Your passing creates a void that can not be filled. Sincerest condolences to Ruth Donner and the entire Wharton family. Irving Schneider and family

SHUMAN--Sarah Saxe Turitz, of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, formerly of Brookline, Massachusetts, passed away peacefully on March 14, 2008, in Portland, Maine, at age 94 surrounded by her family. The second child of David and Etta Saxe, she was preceded in death by her brother Hyman G. Saxe and her sister Selma Spitzer. She was married to Saul A. Shuman of Brookline for forty years until his death in 1974. She is survived by her three sons, Stanley S. and Alfred J. of New York City and Barry M. of Boston. In 1977, she married Harry S. Turitz, a widower, of Portland, Maine, who died in 1999, three months before his 100th birthday. Sarah was beloved by her six grandchildren and one great grandson. She will be missed by many nephews and nieces, her devoted daughters-in-law, her step grandchildren, and three generations of the Turitz and Goldberg families. There will be a private graveside ceremony in Boston. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Etta and David Saxe Endowed Scholarship, Brandeis University, Office of Development, Mail Stop 126, Waltham, MA 02454.

KLEIN--Irene, at the age of 94, died peacefully at home on March 15, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Stanley and loving grandmother of the late Peter. Beautiful and courageous, she decided it was time. Her memory will be cherished by her sons, John and Mason, daughters-in-law, Helga and Elizabeth, and her brother, Howard. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hospice of Palm Beach County. A private family service will be held in Vermont.

SANDERS--I. Lee, 20 February in Seattle WA of lung cancer... A US army veteran and a diplomat in the US Foreign Service; had lived in DC and New York City. KAHN--Stephen. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Center for Educational Innovation - Public Education Association mourn the untimely passing of Senior Fellow, Stephen Kahn. Leon Wieseltier is a fixture of American cultural life. He has been the literary editor of The New Republic for 25 years, written numerous noteworthy articles, including reviews for The Book Review, palled around with writers like Maureen Dowd, even made a brief appearance in an episode of "The Sopranos." (For all his accomplishments, I suspect it's this last that is most envied by his friends and acquaintances.) Wieseltier has always enjoyed a good literary brawl, most famously perhaps, with his long takedown years ago of the work and career of Cornel West. The current financial crisis has been going on for seven months now, and many people probably feel as if they should understand it. But, says The Nw York Times' David Leonhardt, they don't, not really. And, he says, the confusion is shared by many people who are in the middle of the crisis.

More than 70 hedge funds -- including those run by Blackstone Group and Goldman Sachs -- are rushing into the melee to snap up distressed mortgages and securities from banks battered by the subprime meltdown, according to Bloomberg News.

One of the question marks hanging over the remains Bear Stearns is what will become of the bank's underwriting commitments. The Deal.com's Dealscape blog notes that Bear has a sizable stable of upcoming deals.

Funding of so-called Web 2.0 companies in the United States reached a record $1.34 billion last year, up 88 percent over 2006, according to a report from Dow Jones VentureSource. But there was some sobering news in the report as well: The rate of deal growth slowed, and a single company, Facebook, accounted for 22 percent of the total.
BNP Paribas, France's biggest listed bank, said on Wednesday that it has decided not to pursue a possible tie-up with rival Société Générale, which has been hit by a trading scandal.

Intel and Microsoft said Tuesday that they planned to finance two groups of university researchers to start over and design a new generation of computing systems intended to break the industry out of a technological cul-de-sac that threatens to end decades of performance increases in computers.

China's Alibaba Group is seeking investors to buy the 39 percent stake in the Internet company held by Yahoo, according to Reuters, outlining a plan that could stop Microsoft from getting the Alibaba stock.
Lawyers who specialize in private-equity deals remain in hot demand despite the cooling off in leveraged buyouts.

Amid reports that pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines appear to have given up efforts to combine their seniority lists -- considered essential to the two carriers' hopes for a merger without crippling rancor -- industry observers and analysts are wondering: What next?

Luminus Management dropped its high-profile push to get TransAlta to load up on debt to fund stock buybacks on Tuesday, saying it is encouraged by the Canadian power generator's recent moves to boost its share value.

Spurred on by booming commodity prices and unfazed by financial market turmoil, Canada's fast-growing Sherritt International has unveiled a 704 million Canadian dollar ($708 million) stock-and-cash bid for full control of the country's largest thermal coal producer.

Investment Corporation of Dubai's 1.95 billion euro ($2.98 billion) plan to break up troubled Spanish property group Inmobiliaria Colonial edged closer to completion Tuesday, after the Spanish real estate company's board backed the arrangement.

Advanced Power Projects, a new start-up that promises to make new and existing power plants run more reliably and produce less greenhouse gas emissions, has raised an undisclosed amount of funding by Bay Partners, Sequoia Capital and Redpoint Ventures.

CardioNet, a health care technology start-up which Citigroup is taking public on Wednesday, cut the number of shares it allocated in half and lowered the price after several big shareholders backed out of the offering.
Federal prosecutors overseeing a big tax shelter case involving former employees of the KPMG accounting firm brought a separate charge Tuesday against one of the defendants in that case.
Former sub-prime mortgage lender Fremont General said Tuesday that it was trying to restructure some of its debt and would delay making a $6.6 million payment during the negotiations.

Today's Minimalist column (and video) is about a very wet cake; to me, sticky toffee pudding is the epitome of same. Not everyone loves this sweet, gooey dessert, but you can count me as someone who does. If you're in my camp, you have to try this easy-to-make version from my friend the English chef John Burton Race (who appears on my public television show, "The Best Recipes in the World").

The N.F.L. got its chance to see Boston College quarterback Matt Ryan throw, and he didn’t do anything that would keep him from being picked early in the draft.Perhaps even first over all. Ryan worked out at Boston College’s Pro Day, throwing to former teammates for 42 scouts and other personnel evaluators from 22 N.F.L. teams. He completed 48 of 52 passes — three drops, one overthrown — from three-, five- and seven step drops, from the pocket and on the run, throwing to both sides of the field. “I made every throw you need to make in the N.F.L.,” said Ryan, who didn’t throw at last month’s combine in Indianapolis. “I thought it went well. It was the first opportunity I’ve had to throw in front of the scouts live.”.

Northern Rock, the bank that got a £25 billion ($50 billion) bailout from the British government, will cut about a third of its 6,000-person work force and reduce mortgage lending to help repay state loans. The bank, based in Newcastle, plans to become a “smaller, more focused, financially viable mortgage and savings” company, it said. The job cuts will be complete by 2011.

Lindt & Spruengli, the oldest Swiss chocolate maker, said profit rose 20 percent in 2007 on stronger sales of higher-priced dark chocolate confections. Net income climbed to 250.5 million Swiss francs ($255 million) from 209 million francs in 2006, the company said. “Thanks to numerous innovations and targeted marketing activities, the group outpaced the growth of the overall chocolate market and gained substantial new market share,” the company said. Lindt, based in Kilchberg, said in January that sales increased 14 percent, to 2.95 billion francs, last year.

The Democratic Party of Japan, the country’s largest opposition party, decided to reject the government’s second nomination of a former finance ministry executive to head the central bank. The party said in a statement on its Web site that it is set to reject Koji Tanami, left, now governor of Japan Bank for International Cooperation, in a parliamentary vote Wednesday, the same day the current Bank of Japan governor’s term ends. The decision makes it inevitable that the central bank will at least briefly lack a top leader for the first time since World War II. The opposition has been urging the government to pick someone not politically connected to the nation’s powerful bureaucracy to ensure the independence of the Bank of Japan.

An article on Friday about Senator Barack Obama’s mother misidentified the profession of his half-sister, Maya Soetoro-Ng. She has a Ph.D. in comparative education and works as a teacher; she is not an anthropologist.

The chairman of UBS, Switzerland’s largest bank, is taking a 90 percent pay cut for 2007, the bank said in the aftermath of huge write-downs linked to the United States mortgage market. The chairman, Marcel Ospel, will receive a salary of $2 million plus benefits and pension credits, compensation totaling $2.6 million, the bank said in its annual report. In 2006, Mr. Ospel received $27 million , which included performance-based compensation. UBS shares have dropped by nearly two-thirds since last year. Losses related to subprime mortgages forced the bank to write down more than $18 billion in assets and analysts expect more write-downs to come.
The attorney general moved to shut down payday lending companies in the state, saying the fees they charge harmed the working poor.

The Netherlands set a world record in the women’s 4x100-meter freestyle relay at the European swimming championships with a time of 3 minutes 33.62 seconds.The Dutch team of Inge Dekker, Ranomi Kromowidjojo, Femke Heemskerk and Marleen Veldhuis led throughout in front of a raucous home crowd in Eindhoven, easily beating the old mark of 3:35.22 set two years ago by Germany.

Loree Moore, a guard for the Liberty, agreed to a three-year contract extension. Moore scored a career-best 9.6 points a game and ranked fourth in the W.N.B.A. with 4.8 assists last season. Her 2.2 steals a game ranked second in the league.

The heavily recruited high school quarterback Terrelle Pryor will announce where he will attend college at a news conference Wednesday.Pryor, from Jeannette High School near Pittsburgh, was ready to sign a letter of intent with Ohio State at a news conference Feb. 6, the first day of the national signing period for football recruits. He decided at the last minute to delay his selection. His father, Craig, said he wanted him to take more time to consider attending Penn State. Pryor said his final choices were Ohio State, Michigan, Penn State and Oregon.

Zhang Dan and Zhang Hao of China executed a flawless short program Tuesday to take the lead in the pairs competition in the World Figure Skating Championships in Goteborg, Sweden. Aliona Savchenko and Robin Szolkowy of Germany were second and Yuko Kawaguchi and Alexander Smirnov of Russia third. In ice dance, Isabelle Delobel and Olivier Schoenfelder of France have the lead after the American favorites Tanith Belbin and Benjamin Agosto had a rare fall in the compulsory dance. Belbin and Agosto are in fifth place.

A wide receiver for the University of Central Florida died after voluntary strength and conditioning drills, the day before spring practice was set to begin.The police said there was no obvious cause for the redshirt freshman Ereck Plancher’s late morning collapse. Keith Tribble, the university’s athletic director, said the players had been lifting weights, then ran for about 10 minutes. As everyone was leaving after the workout, Plancher took a knee in obvious distress, Tribble said. Trainers immediately provided C.P.R. and he was taken to the hospital by an ambulance.

Preliminary statistics from a new on-track injury reporting program showed fatality rates among horses that run on synthetic surfaces are nearly identical to the fatality rates of horses that run on traditional dirt tracks.Synthetic tracks averaged 1.95 deaths per 1,000 starts over the course of the study, compared to 1.96 deaths per 1,000 starts for horses that ran on dirt. Mary Scollay, the program’s developer, said more studies had be done before the effect on safety could be determined.

Ryan Shay, who died during the Olympic trial for the marathon, had cardiac arrhythmia caused by an enlarged heart and died of natural causes, according to the New York City medical examiner’s office.

The sixth-season premiere of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted 20.9 million viewers on Monday, Nielsen estimated, leading ABC to first place for the night. The premiere of “The Bachelor,” which followed “Dancing With the Stars,” averaged considerably less: 9 million viewers from 9:30 p.m. to 11 p.m. CBS earned a solid second place thanks to the return of its comedy lineup: “The Big Bang Theory” at 8 (9.1 million), “How I Met Your Mother” at 8:30 (9.7 million), “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14 million) and “The New Adventures of Old Christine” at 9:30 (11.5 million). NBC was third over all, with “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” at 8 (4.7 million) and “Deal or No Deal” at 9 (9.9 million).

Days after announcing it would replace its chief series programmer, HBO has canceled a series before broadcasting it. The network said on Tuesday that it would not go ahead with “12 Miles of Bad Road,” a satirical “Dallas”-like series created by Linda Bloodworth Thomason, whose last big hit was “Designing Women,” which ran from 1986 to 1993. “12 Miles,” starring Lily Tomlin as a wealthy Texas matriarch, had shot 6 of a planned 12 episodes before HBO executives decided it was not up to HBO standards. Two recent HBO shows, “John From Cincinnati” and “Lucky Louie,” did not perform well. Several other networks have been approached about picking up “12 Miles of Bad Road,” most recently Lifetime. A Lifetime executive said on Tuesday that the channel was not interested.

Van Halen has rescheduled a series of dates on its reunion tour, which has been plagued over the last year by delays and postponements related to Eddie Van Halen’s health. This time the group said only that Mr. Van Halen, right, was undergoing “medical tests.” The tour resumes on April 19 in Las Vegas and continues through June 2 in Grand Rapids, Mich., with performances at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on May 13, and Madison Square Garden on May 23. Tickets for all postponed shows will be honored.

Barbara Walters, right, and “60 Minutes” shared the award for television news magazines at the 19th annual Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards in New York on Monday, Reuters reported. Ms. Walters won for “My Secret Self: A Story of Transgender Children,” on ABC’s “20/20,” and “60 Minutes,” on CBS, won for “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,” about the United States military’s policy on gay and lesbian service members. The award for outstanding film in limited release went to the Hebrew- and Arabic-language film “The Bubble,” about a love affair between and Israeli soldier and a Palestinian man. “For the Bible Tells Me So” was named outstanding documentary. Among the other honorees for coverage of gay and lesbian issues were The New York Times, GQ magazine, CNN.com and the television series “Boston Legal.”.

Webster Hall, a 19th-century East Village assembly space where F. Scott Fitzgerald once reveled and Emma Goldman urged social change, was one of several buildings designated historic landmarks on Monday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. Designed by Charles Rentz and built in 1886, with an annex added in 1992, Webster Hall, a Renaissance Revival structure at 119-125 East 11th Street, is clad in red Philadelphia pressed brick with brownstone trim and red terra-cotta ornamentation. (A mansard roof was destroyed in the 1930s.) The hall, seen above in the 1910s, became famous for masquerade balls after a 1913 fund-raiser for the socialist magazine The Masses and became a hub not only for Village bohemians but also for gay men and lesbians. The artists Charles Demuth, Marcel Duchamp and Man Ray used the hall, as did F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald and political and labor leaders like Goldman, Samuel Gompers, Margaret Sanger and Dorothy Day. The Progressive Labor Party was established there in 1887, and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America in 1914. In the 1950s and ’60s, RCA Victor operated a studio there, where Arthur Rubinstein, Duke Ellington, Louis Armstrong, Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Ray Charles, Marian Anderson and many others recorded. Webster Hall later became a rock club. Three other East Village structures also received landmark designation: the 11th Street Public Bath, at 539 East 11th Street, a Beaux-Arts structure designed by Arnold W. Brunner and completed in 1906; the Beth Hamedrash Hagadol Anshe Ungarn, at 242 East Seventh Street, a Beaux Arts synagogue built in 1908 for a congregation of Hungarian Jews; and the Elizabeth Home for Girls, at 307 East 12th Street, a High Victorian Gothic brick and sandstone structure built in 1892 for use by the Children’s Aid Society.

After a critically lauded run last year at Primary Stages, Horton Foote’s “Dividing the Estate” is moving to Broadway. Lincoln Center Theater will produce the play, a comic portrait of a Texas family, at a Shubert theater to be announced. Performances are to begin on Oct. 23, with opening night scheduled for Nov. 20. Michael Wilson is directing; Elizabeth Ashley, Arthur French, Hallie Foote, Penny Fuller and Gerald McRaney star. ... “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps” is moving to the Cort Theater, following its limited engagement at Roundabout Theater Company’s American Airlines Theater. Performances continue through March 29 at the American Airlines and will resume April 29 at the Cort. Opening night is May 8. ... The Irish Repertory Theater will extend its run of the musical “Take Me Along” from April 13 to May 4. ... Sierra Boggess and Sean Palmer, from “The Little Mermaid,” will make their Town Hall debuts in “The Broadway Musicals of 1954” on April 7, part of the “Broadway by the Year” series. The show includes songs and dances from “The Pajama Game,” “Peter Pan,” “The Boy Friend” and “Fanny,” among others. Emily Skinner, Noah Racey, Cheyenne Jackson and Kendrick Jones will also appear. ... “I’ve Got Your Number: Romance, the Rat Pack and Carolyn Leigh,” part of the 92nd Street Y’s “Lyrics & Lyricists” series, will run from March 29 to March 31. Miley Cyrus, below, whose given name is Destiny Hope Cyrus, has filed papers in Los Angeles County Superior Court to change her full legal name to Miley Ray Cyrus, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Cyrus, 15, who plays an undercover singing star on the series “Hannah Montana,” is the daughter of the country singer Billy Ray Cyrus, who filed the papers Friday with his wife, Leticia. Mr. Cyrus said the request was filed “to make her commonly used name the same as her legal name.”.

SACKETT--Paul. 70, resident of Stamford, and until 1983, of Wilton Connecticut, Mr. Sackett attended Princeton University, where he was a founding member of the Ivy League Cycle Racing Circuit in 1955. He was a graduate of The Choate School and CW Post College. Paul had a passion for engineering and electronics, and was a lifetime member of The National Association for Amateur Radio. Lafayette Electronics in White Plains, NY employed him for many years as an electronics sales specialist. A member of the First Presbyterian Church and the Social Registry of New York. He is survived by nephews Alan and John Borst, a niece, Anna Benson Borst Henry, and seven grandnephews and grandnieces who will hold Paul's wit and beautiful nature forever in loving remembrance. A funeral service will be held at Wilton Congregational Church on Thursday at 1:00pm followed by interment at the Hillside Cemetery.

Spring 2005. The hushed excitement before the first chords of a symphony. I was sitting in a darkened theater with hundreds of Iraqis, breathing together in collective expectation. Beethoven washed over us like a wave. At the time, Baghdad was plagued by bombings. Later they would seem almost old-fashioned: blind strikes with random victims, different (though no less destructive) from the murderous sectarian hunts of 2006. The concert hall was full of interesting people: a physics professor, a pilot, a professional cellist, a businessman. They had a guarded hopefulness that I admired. ''It's the beginning of a new life,'' said the professor, holding his 11-year-old, Ali, by the hand. ''It's a birth.''

8 P.M. (TCM) THE CAINE MUTINY (1954) ''Mutiny Scrutiny'' is the evening's theme. The skirmishes begin with this drama based on the 1951 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Herman Wouk, starring Humphrey Bogart, above at lectern, as an inflexible United States Navy commander with a tenuous grip on his sanity. In ''Mutiny on the Bounty'' (1962), at 10:15, Marlon Brando plays First Lt. Fletcher Christian, and Trevor Howard is the ill-fated Captain Bligh, bound for the South Seas in 1789; in ''Damn the Defiant!'' (1962), at 1:30 a.m., Alec Guinness is the even-keeled Captain Crawford, and Dirk Bogarde is his sadistic first lieutenant in a British naval drama set at the beginning of the Napoleonic Wars. And at 3:15 a.m. comes the American broadcast premiere of the 2005 restoration of Sergei Eisenstein's silent classic ''Battleship Potemkin'' (1925). 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL After a tutorial in catalog, commercial and couture photo shoots from the model Vendela, the women strikes poses on New York streets.

April 9, 2003, the day Baghdad fell. In an old notebook, seeds of the future. By dawn most of Saddam Hussein's military had melted away. American troops already controlled the west bank of the Tigris, and their colleagues on the east advanced through the morning toward the city center, hourly shrinking the bubble of Saddamist control.

The profound mistake of Reverend Wright's sermons is not that he spoke about racism in our society. It's that he spoke as if our society was static, as if no progress has been made. BARACK OBAMA, on statements by his pastor. [A14]

BLITZ--Rebecca (Reva), April 9, 1922-March 17, 2008. Beloved mother to her two treasured daughters and sons-in-law, Trudy LaPan Edelman and Richard Edelman, Abigail LaPan Stamou and Telis Stamou. Devoted and adored wife of the late Dr. Calman Blitz, her soulmate. Loving sister to Herman (Hank) Soifer, his wife Arlene and caring aunt to their children and grandchildren. Born Rebecca Soifer in Russia, Reva lived and worked in NYC since arriving here as a baby. Hunter College alumna, Brooklyn resident and dedicated teacher at PS99 (then named Reva LaPan) she was an art lover, a feminist, a liberal, a Zionist and an advocate for the hearing impaired and for all people. She continued her studies at Brooklyn College until her recent illness. Reva is also survived by family and friends in the Americas, Israel and Europe. Donations in her memory may be made to your charity of choice or to the NCJW. Private family funeral.

WHITEHEAD--Allen, Pioneer and Protector of Authors' rights dies. Allen Burke Whitehead died peacefully on Friday, February 29th, 2008. Allen was born July 17th, 1919 in Rocky Mount, NC. He attended The University of South Carolina before serving in the Navy from 1942-1946. On his way to Yale Drama School he was sidetracked in New York City to 'fill in' for a theatrical agent, never left, and joined Frank Loesser at nascent Music Theatre International (MTI) when the company was less than two years old. He stayed for 40 years. During that time he had close dealings with the great names of Broadway, representing the dramatic rights to some of the most successful musicals ever written: ''Guys And Dolls'', ''Meredith Willson's The Music Man'', ''Fiddler On The Roof'', ''West Side Story'', ''Annie'', ''A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum'', ''The Fantasticks'' and hundreds of others. Allen's professional life was devoted to enhancing authors' rights and maximizing revenues to provide ongoing income streams to authors, their families and heirs. Allen developed inventive resources to help prolong the legacy of the works, including the printed notation of Jerome Robbins' original staging of ''Fiddler On The Roof'' (still used today by schools and theatres around the world). His spirit and memory is kept alive by his wife of 44 years, Rosemarie, and his children, Marc, daughter-in-law Lisa, and grandchildren Cooper and Gabrielle of Wilmington, NC and daughter Gabrielle Stevenson, son-in-law Doug and grandchildren Kendall, Brett, Hailey and Kyle of Southport, CT. Freddie Gershon and the MTI family mourn for him and his family and honor his memory and his life's work and mission every day at MTI.

ROSENBLOOM--Mary. Born October 17, 1915 in New York City, died peacefully in her sleep on March 14, 2008 in San Francisco, age 92.

Each of us had his own moment of recognition, when we knew the insurgency was not just a scattering of street gangs, but a movement that was blossoming on the support it enjoyed among the country's Sunni Arabs. My moment came in Mosul. It was drizzling when I arrived. Broken glass was splayed across the pavement. The American truck had already been towed away. It had gone like this: Two soldiers with the 101st Airborne Division had climbed into a regular S.U.V., no armor, and driven off the base and into Mosul at rush hour. They were supposed to have known better than to go out alone. One of the soldiers was Jerry Wilson, 45, of Thomson, Ga., the 101st's command sergeant major, meaning he was the unit's senior enlisted man. The other soldier was a specialist named Rel Ravago IV, 21, from Glendale, Calif.

ARNALL--Roland. The Yeshiva University family deeply mourns the loss of Roland Arnall, who strengthened the Jewish community as a generous supporter of Jewish causes around the world. With his beloved wife, Dawn, as Benefactors to YU, they helped establish The Center for the Jewish Future and supported education and research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. They also established the Roland Arnall Presidential Fellowship at YU. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife and children, Daniel and Michelle; his brother, Claude; and nephew, Adam Bass; and to all members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees

O.K., you can give up the obsession with Marshmallow Peeps. Now that you're an adult (sort of), it's time to upgrade your Easter/springtime sweets. (But still have them, obvs.) At Batch, Pichet Ong's new bubble gum-pink take-out shop, you can buy Vietnamese coffee cake, yuzu shortbread and durian ice cream, or packages of cookies and biscotti. At Betty Bakery in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, get holiday-ready with marzipan bunnies and chicks. Leave the Peeps on the shelf, because seriously, those things don't degrade. ARMOUR--Yolande, passed away peacefully on March 14 surrounded by family three weeks before celebrating her 100th birthday. She was born April 3, 1908 in Pittsburgh, PA. Known to her friends as ''YoYo'', she was an accomplished artist, painting in oils as well as illustrating many books. She was a devoted mother to Frani Ridder (Mrs. Daniel H.) and Gretchen Leach (Mrs. Howard H.), an adored grandmother of seven and a great-grandmother of 18. She was a huge part of all of their lives. She was married to David L. Cooper, M.D. and David Armour and widowed twice.

COWL--Ruthe B. The National Yiddish Book Center mourns the passing of Ruthe B. Cowl of Laredo, TX. A woman of valor, she cared for the needy, championed culture, and put into daily practice the Jewish vision of social justice. Her support for the Cowl Center for Jewish Culture and the Cowl Fellows will ensure that young people continue her good works for generations to come. Z''l-May the memory of the righteous be for a blessing.

The Periodic Table of the Tournament in sports on Monday, with coverage of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament field, misstated the seeding for one team, the record for another and the type of berth for yet another in some editions. Gonzaga is a No. 7 seed, not a No. 17. Coppin State is 16-20, not 14-20. And Wisconsin received an automatic berth, not an at-large bid.

Five years have passed since I stood on the border of Iraq and Kuwait, watching the predawn sky for the first salvos in the Iraq war. I am reading political analysis and historical accounts of years that are past. I am thinking of all of the things that had not yet happened as I stood in the desert sand that day. Whatever war is, it is a deeply personal experience for those who live in it. I am a photographer and have captured thousands of images of Iraq and the war there since that day. But when I stop reading about the war, I guess I get that faraway look I always saw, as I grew up, in the eyes of countless veterans and civilians who lived through war, including my mother. I don't wonder what they see anymore.

Facing budget woes and a recruiting crisis, the city’s Police Department is poised to shrink to its smallest size in about 15 years, a reality reflected in a plan by the Bloomberg administration to trim funds for 1,000 police officer positions this year, Al Baker reports. Facing in hiring fluctuations, military leave and recruitment challenges, a low point of 34,624 officers is projected for the end of June. That is just below the 34,641 officers in June 1993, a time when a program by Mayor David N. Dinkins to pump up the police force was under way. The number peaked in October 2000 with 40,800 officers. The first new officers of Mr. Dinkins’s program were entering the police academy by 1993.

The poll also found that four-fifths of voters supported Eliot Spitzer’s decision to resign as governor amid a sex scandal.
