Marquette, has been arrested and charged with lying to New York City authorities about inspecting the crane that collapsed on Saturday afternoon, killing seven people, injuring dozens of others and causing widespread property damage. Officials issued a stern warning that corrupt workers will be punished, but said the failure to inspect the crane on March 4 was almost certainly not a factor in the deadly collapse, which officials think may have been caused by the failure of a nylon strap, which led to a large steel collar coming loose.

Update: With Stanford polishing off Cornell, 77-53, the attention turns to the Cardinal's second-round matchup with Marquette. That game will feature a contrast of styles and personnel. Marquette depends on its diminutive guards while Stanford leans on its inside presence. The Lopez twins should be able to score inside, assuming they can stay on the court. That's not a given. The penetration of the Marquette guards puts Stanford's big men in risk of picking up fouls early. If they're sitting on the bench it could be a long game for the Cardinal.

Just a quick note on Thursday in Malaysia before we move into overdrive tomorrow. A couple of things got inversed in the move of the F1 circus from Australia to Malaysia within the same week. First, it was Australia that proved to have the Malaysian weather, where Malaysia now has weather we should have encountered in Australia. At practically 38 degrees Celsius everyday in Australia and with no rain and only sun, you'd have thought it was the Kuala Lumpur race. Here in Malaysia today, by contrast, it was maybe only 28 degrees Celsius - a veritable refrigerator by comparison - and there was rain yesterday and today. Rain is in the forecast at the track for every day this race weekend.

Now, a Democrat, either Hillary or Barack would win if only wine drinkers voted. But here's the interesting part, if we all got really drunk on tequila, Ralph Nader might actually have a shot.

All of the outrage over privacy on the Internet is nothing compared to what may be coming. For years, Web companies have been trying to gather shreds of information about users in order to show them ads for things they are most likely to buy. These schemes have been accelerated over the last year, as the big Web companies like AOL, Microsoft and Yahoo have been trying to combine information they gather on their own sites with data about users gathered from networks that place ads on other sites.

C'est La Fête!, which launched in 2007, is a creation of Inter-Parfums, one of the mid-sized perfume licensees. Its splendid Paris offices are located on the exclusive Rond Point of the Champs-Elysées, in the eighth arrondissement. But Inter-Parfums, which owns Lacroix's license and creates scents bearing the designer's name, is under the same, not-so-splendid financial constraints faced by the other licensees (like those of Lauder to LVMH). It takes money to make a perfume; like most things in life, the better the raw materials, the more they cost. There are several ways of dealing with this. One of them is known as front-loading.

Toss spinach quickly in hot olive oil scented with garlic, follow with a squeeze of lemon, and you already have an appealing dish. The next level up is still easy: make a topping of crisp-fried shallots for the greens. By themselves, these crunchy slices are irresistible; combined with tender spinach, they create an alluring contrast in flavor and texture.

Aired Wednesday night on CBS: John McCain recently said he supports George Bush's Iraq policy. I said, "Well, sure, slice me eight more years of that, will you? Let's go!"

Way back in 2004, when the war in Iraq was barely a year old, Tom Miller and Gregory McNamee at Kirkus Reviews wondered why novelists hadn't yet tackled it as a subject. At that early date the question seemed more than a little tongue in cheek - they acknowledged that Stephen Crane didn't write "The Red Badge of Courage" until decades after the Civil War had ended, and their suggested Iraq titles included "The Oil Man and the Sea" - but now that the war's five-year anniversary is upon us, it's starting to feel like they had a point. Where's the first wave of Iraq War fiction? By Sept. 11, 2006, after all, there were already enough 9/11 novels to constitute a mini-genre.
Talk about a problem child.
As China plays defense by plugging up the usual sources for anyone trying to follow the spreading unrest in Tibet on the Web, an innovative site has a counter-strategy: play better offense.

Every year around this time we're reminded of the infamous Vendredi Saint brawl at the Montreal Forum between the Canadiens and Nordiques. It happened in 1984, an endless donnybrook, simple lawless frenzy, and it went on so long we need two videos to show it.

On a recent visit to Iraq, my first trip back in over three years, a few things surprised me. There was the "countdown calendar" to President Bush's last day in office, sitting openly on a soldier's desk. There was the high-up United States official who told me, by way of introduction, that he did not believe the decision to invade Iraq was "reality-based." Before leaving to spend a few days with American troops, I worried about bringing along a book critical of the war. I shouldn't have.
On Friday, YouTube announces the winners of its Video Awards.

Smart's party, tied to the release of its commissioned book Sideways, a compilation of words and images offering new takes on environmentalism, was held on an unfinished high floor of Larry Silverstein's 7 World Trade Center. The décor - blue lights and walls of stretched cellophane -- was the work of Lot-Ek, the architectural firm known for its use of recycled shipping containers.

DENVER -- Two years ago, George Mason and its coach, Jim Larranaga, made an out-of-nowhere run to the Final Four. The day after the Patriots beat the heavyweight UConn in the regional final in Washington, George Mason's campus in Fairfax, Va., was one giant party: the bookstore had lines out the doors; the admissions office could barely keep pace with phone calls; reporters could not fit inside Larranaga's office. The bronze statue of George Mason wore a T-shirt and balloons tied at the wrist.
Auto shows are all about the unveiling of new models. But before they are unveiled, cars must be veiled.
The aftermath has flowed predictably enough since Feb. 13, when Danish newspapers reprinted cartoons that sparked fury among Muslims around the world in 2006: There was more fury.

At 12:20 Eastern, Georgia and Xavier start up this year's N.C.A.A. tournament with their West Region matchup in Washington D.C. -- quickly followed by enough rapid-fire action to keep any college basketball happy for the next 12 hours.

Jon Stewart last night:

More than 11,000 pages documenting Hillary Rodham Clinton's tenure as first lady were released yesterday, and they contain "all the emotional punch of a factory-worker's timecard," concludes John M. Broder of The New York Times.

Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people, is threatening to resign if the conflict with the Chinese doesn't stop. Not only that, he also says he might refuse to be reincarnated again.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Dalai Lama is threatening to resign from his position as the spiritual leader of Tibet. Yeah. When asked why, the Dalai Lama said, "I promised myself I'd quit the moment it stopped being fun."

To many people, mortgage-backed bonds and securities are radioactive waste. But it appears that for some traders, they're a potential gold mine.

Credit Suisse warned it was unlikely to be profitable in the first quarter, partly because of this month's tough markets and partly because of previously flagged pricing errors that it said Thursday stemmed from "intentional misconduct by a small number of traders."

Borders Group, the struggling bookstore chain, said Thursday it hired JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Borders initially rose in Friday trading but soon moved sharply lower.
PepsiCo and the Pepsi Bottling Group said on Thursday they have agreed to buy 75.53 percent of the juice business of Lebedyansky, Russia's leading juice producer, for $1.4 billion.

In an unusual move to calm investors' nerves, two of Britain's top financial authorities stepped forward on Wednesday to quash a spate of rumors that had sent some financial stocks in London into a tailspin.
Citigroup plans to lay off another 2,000 investment bankers and traders before the end of the month, according to The New York Times.
Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda unit's planned spinoff.
Guy Hands, the founder of Terra Firma, is threatening to move part of his private equity group offshore in response to the latest tax rises on capital gains and non-domiciled residents in Britain.

Catapulted by the biggest initial public offering in American history, Visa shares soared 28 percent in their stock market debut on Wednesday as investors bet an accelerating shift to electronic payments will enrich the company.

The actor and director was best known for playing the radio techie Sgt. James Kinchloe on the 1960s sitcom "Hogan's Heroes," but his work included vivid portrayals of American black struggles. Read his obit here. This clip illustrates not only his small role in "Hogan's Heroes" but also much more about identity politics (or the lack thereof) on TV in the 1960s:
The Ping An Insurance Company, a leading life insurer in China, has agreed to pay 2.15 billion euros ($3.4 billion) for 50 percent of Fortis's asset management business, the companies said.
Morgan Stanley gave Wall Street a shot of confidence on Wednesday morning, reporting profits that surpassed analysts' estimates, but the dosage soon wore off.

The Bush administration is planning to tap a Silicon Valley entrepreneur to head a new inter-agency group charged with coordinating the federal government's efforts to protect its computer networks from organized cyber attacks, The Washington Post reported.
Retrevo, the Silicon Valley company that helps you shop electronic products, and then helps you after the purchase, has raised $8 million more in a second round of financing.
Barington Capital Group, the hedge fund that has been pressing for changes at Dillard's, is making its move to wrest more control of the department store chain.
The Sundance Channel, the cable network spawned from Robert Redford's eponymous annual film festival, is up for sale, The New York Post reported.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Chairman and Chief Executive Harry Sloan's plan to rebuild a full-fledged movie studio is not sitting well with the private equity firms backing the studio, according to The New York Post.

The booming commodities market has become increasingly attractive to investors, with hard assets like oil and gold perhaps offering a safe hedge against inflation, as well as the double-digit gains that have fast been disappearing from the markets for stocks, bonds and real estate.

Howard D. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, announced sweeping changes on Wednesday for the company as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.

With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nation's two largest mortgage finance companies, eased a major restriction on the companies on Wednesday in an effort to unfreeze credit markets and stabilize housing prices.
It appears that there is some confusion over who is to blame for holding up the buyout of Clear Channel Communications and now, according to a report, the deal may not close at all.

Susan Sparks sits at the intersection of a bevy of career trends. First, she needs a rather long string of words to describe what she does, usually beginning with something like "I'm a lawyer-turned-Baptist preacher who moonlights as a stand-up comic." As a preacher/comic, she's a slash and a hyphenate. As someone who uses her skills as a lawyer in her current career -- her church relies on her for the occasional legal perspective on everything from property to contracts -- she leads what Penelope Trunk calls a "braided career."
On Tuesday the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio performed with Leila Josefowicz, a prominent solo violinist, and Michael Tree, the violist of the Guarneri String Quartet.
After discovering that its testing equipment was past an inspection deadline, United Airlines said it was retesting altimeters on seven of its Boeing 747s.
The nation’s cellphone companies won big in a record-setting government airways auction, with Verizon winning nearly every license in the consumer-friendly “C block.”

The commercial finance company said that it was drawing on $7.3 billion of bank credit lines to help conduct daily operations, highlighting its difficulty in raising cash.
Melvyn I. Weiss, a prolific filer of lawsuits against publicly held corporations, has reached a plea agreement with federal prosecutors in Los Angeles, according to his defense lawyer.

I made a great discovery this week: there is a TV right here in the office that gets the Golf Channel. So while the March Maniacs -- many of whom don’t pay any attention to sports the rest of the year -- are tuned into CBS this afternoon, I’m going to be watching Tiger Woods at the CA Championship in Florida. A month from now, who will remember which beanpole hit the 3-pointer from the corner for the mid-major from Ohio? But Tiger right now is on a streak -- seven tournament wins in a row -- that people will be talking about for many years. We don’t often get to see perfection in sports, but lately he’s come close, and if you think it’s more fun this weekend to watch guys run around in a gym than to see Tiger tackle the Blue Monster at Doral, then that’s really Madness.
Factory activity in the Mid-Atlantic region shrank for the fourth consecutive month in March, a survey showed, though the rate of retrenchment lessened.
Upsets? Overtimes? Emotions? The deluge of games? What is your favorite part of March Madness?.

Can we now call it official, that snowboarding’s transgressive days are over? Even at Taos Ski Valley in New Mexico, the most famous skiers-only holdout in the country, the slopes were opened to shredders yesterday.

The N.C.A.A. Tournament is one of the few events that brings together sports fans of every stripe. But since we’re feeling ornery and contrarian this morning — like Dick Vitale before his first 15 cups of coffee — we thought we’d weigh in on the downside. So here are five things we are rooting against:.

When the 2002 Winter Olympics were awarded to Salt Lake City in 1995, Snowbasin ski resort reaped some of the benefits, as an influx of money went into new buildings and a new lift system, The Times reports today. Now, the ski area, located 33 miles northeast of Salt Lake City, has over-the-top facilities to match the over-the-top terrain. “Unlike other resorts that have lavish on-mountain amenities by so-so skiing, Snowbasin’s expert terrain is on par with higher-profile areas like Taos or Crested Butte,” the article says. “Real skiers come here, not just people who like to dine or shop against a steep and snowy backdrop.”.

Ryan Lochte, perhaps the best American male swimmer not named Michael Phelps, swims 3 to 5 miles most days, sometimes even twice a day -- a distance that few non-Olympic hopefuls could replicate. But other aspects of the 23-year-old Lochte’s training (such as his use of fins and buoys) and routines (his dryland exercises) can be adopted by recreational swimmers or athletes. In the first article in a series featuring Beijing Olympic hopefuls offering training and fitness tips for everyday athletes, The Times today explains how to employ Lochte’s techniques at your local pool to improve your stroke.
A wave of upbeat economic news helped reverse a recent investment trend on Thursday, as commodity prices plummeted and the Dow gained 261 points.
The Conference Board said that its index of leading economic indicators declined 0.3 percent in February following a revised drop of 0.4 percent in January.
The chairman of the House Financial Services Committee called for Congress to consider creating a “financial services risk regulator” with broad powers across a wide range of financial institutions.
Gold prices fell to a one-month low as traders, eyeing a firmer dollar, took their gains to pay for losses in other markets, while oil and industrial metals fell on worries over demand outlook.
Citing large write-downs and losses related to “intentional misconduct” at its trading desk, the Swiss banking giant said that it expected to post its first quarterly loss since 2003.
Applications for jobless benefits totaled 378,000 last week, the government said. It was an increase of 22,000 from the previous week and a far bigger jump than had been expected.
FedEx said that its third-quarter earnings fell 6 percent on high oil prices and a slow American economy, but beat analysts’ expectations.
The bookseller, which has lost market share both to online companies and to Wal-Mart, said that it has lined up $42.5 million in financing to help continue operations.
IKB has received another injection of taxpayer money in anticipation of additional write-downs on a portfolio of risky assets it was struggling to sell.

Marreese Speights had 18 points and Nick Calathes had 16 points, 5 rebounds and 5 assists as Florida (22-11) ended a four-game skid with a 73-49 victory over San Diego State (20-13) in Gainesville during the first round of the National Invitation Tournament. ... A. D. Vassallo made 11 of 14 field-goal tries and had 27 points in 25 minutes as Virginia Tech (20-13) won, 94-62, against Morgan State (22-11) in Blacksburg, Va.
Anna McLean had 24 points and 18 rebounds as Iona (20-13) beat Quinnipiac (25-6), 71-59, in Hamden, Conn., in the first round of the women’s N.I.T. Iona will face St. John’s on Monday.

Federal investigations into the Mount Vernon, N.Y., city government culminated in two sets of mail fraud and conspiracy indictments on Wednesday. One case alleged fraud of more than $1.5 million by the former planning commissioner, and the other accused trash haulers of overcharging the city $1.25 million.

A. D. Vassallo made 11 of 14 field-goal tries and had 27 points in 25 minutes as Virginia Tech (20-13) won, 94-62, against Morgan State (22-11) in Blacksburg, Va., during the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.
Jeremy Crouch scored 20 points to lead Bradley (18-15) to a 70-67 victory over Cincinnati (13-19) in Peoria, Ill., during the opening round of the College Basketball Invitational.
A racial divide, once lived, dwells in the deepest parts of the psyche. This is what was captured by Barack Obama’s pitch-perfect speech on race.

The United States national team will play England in an exhibition game at Wembley on May 28. The match will be the first between them since England beat the United States, 2-1, at Chicago’s Soldier Field on May 28, 2005.

Connecticut said it self-reported a secondary violation of N.C.A.A. rules involving Maya Moore. The violation occurred in 2005, when the women’s basketball office arranged for Moore to tour ESPN in Bristol. The university said it learned of the violation last year, and recently completed a review, resulting in the university reporting it to the N.C.A.A.
Vince Carter had a season-high 39 points and 10 assists and the Nets moved into a tie with visiting Atlanta for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.
The Devils played most of the game with a 1-0 lead, but Chris Drury tied the game with less than 5 minutes left to send the game to overtime.
Duaner Sánchez has yet to pitch on even as little as one day’s rest, so real doubts remain as to whether he’ll be ready for the March 31 season opener.
This is the second consecutive year that Rick DiPietro has needed hip surgery. He had an operation on his left hip after last season’s playoffs; now the right one needs repair.

An article on Tuesday about the discovery of the bodies of three more victims of a construction crane accident in Manhattan misstated, in some copies, the given name of the victim from South Florida found in the rubble of a town house at 305 East 50th Street. The victim, who was visiting a friend in New York, was Odin Torres, not Olida.

Toshiba, the electronics maker, lowered its earnings forecast for the year, blaming in part the 45 billion yen ($460 million) in costs associated with abandoning its HD DVD next-generation video business.
An agreement in the stalled Doha round of World Trade Organization talks may be near, Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva , and the European Commission said on Wednesday.
Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda unit’s planned spinoff.
Investigators took documents from the headquarters of BP’s Russian joint venture, TNK-BP, which has had rocky relations with the Kremlin.
British Airways said it had bought about another 3 percent of the Spanish flag carrier Iberia Airlines, raising its stake to 13.15 percent.
The Ping An Insurance Company, a leading life insurer in China, has agreed to pay 2.15 billion euros ($3.4 billion) for 50 percent of Fortis’s asset management business, the companies said.

A Philadelphia agency has ruled that English-only signs at a famous cheese steak shop are not discriminatory. The Commission on Human Relations said in its ruling that the sign at Geno’s Steaks did not violate the city’s Fair Practices Ordinance. Joe Vento posted signs at his shop in October 2005 that read, “This is America: when ordering please speak English.” Critics said the policy discouraged customers of certain backgrounds from eating there. Mr. Vento says he has never refused service because a person could not speak English.

The White House named Kenneth L. Wainstein, a senior Justice Department official, to be President Bush’s homeland security adviser. Mr. Wainstein now heads the National Security Division, which coordinates the Justice Department’s counterterrorism, intelligence and counterespionage efforts. He was formerly the top federal prosecutor in Washington and general counsel and chief of staff at the F.B.I.

A son of an auto wrecking yard owner shot four people to death at the business in Santa Maria, including at least one relative and two employees, the police said. Panicked customers fled the busy yard as the gunman shot his victims at close range, the police said. Lee Isaac Bedwell Leeds, 31, was booked for investigation of murder and was held without bail.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to charge drivers who enter the busiest parts of Manhattan, already on the ropes in Albany, was dealt a further blow on Wednesday when Gov. David A. Paterson declined to support the idea — despite an impassioned pitch from the mayor.

A man who sent a letter to his father indicating he was going to kill his children was found dead with the three youngsters in a wooded area, the F.B.I. said. Investigators declined to say what led them to the four bodies in a rural area about 90 miles southwest of Atlanta or how they died. Investigators have said they did not know what led to 28-year-old Eddie Harrington’s decision to leave his Columbus home with his twin 23-month-old girls and his 3-year-old son.

The band manager whose pyrotechnics display caused a nightclub fire that killed 100 people in 2003 was released from prison after serving less than half of his four-year sentence. Daniel Biechele, 31, the former tour manager for the 1980s rock band Great White, pleaded guilty in 2006 to 100 counts of involuntary manslaughter for his part in the fire at the Station nightclub in West Warwick. The parole board unanimously decided in September to release Mr. Biechele early, saying he had shown genuine remorse and had the support of family members of victims. Prison officials in Mr. Biechele’s home state, Florida, have said he would serve his parole there.

An out-of-control sport utility vehicle plowed into crowds at an auto auction, injuring 15 people. Five were critically hurt. The vehicle was inside the Tri-State Auto Auction building in Crestwood when it suddenly sped up, struck a group of people and hit a minivan. It then drove out a doorway and plowed into another cluster of people, a witness told The Chicago Tribune. The police are investigating.

Rafael Nadal, the defending Indian Wells champion, came back to win the final five games and beat Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, 6-7 (4), 7-6 (3) 7-5, in the fourth round of the Pacific Life Open. James Blake won, 6-4, 6-2, over Richard Gasquet, and Mardy Fish beat the two-time Indian Wells champion Lleyton Hewitt, 7-5, 3-6, 7-6 (4), to also advance.

Tennessee Titans center Kevin Mawae was elected president of the N.F.L. Players Association as the union braces for a potential labor fight. Mawae, 37, replaces Troy Vincent, the union’s president since 2004.
Nike said that its third-quarter net profit rose, helped by strong international sales of shoes and clothing that were buoyed by a weak dollar.
The F.C.C. unanimously approved a rule banning exclusive telephone service agreements in apartment buildings, giving tenants their pick of providers.

John Brady was hired as coach of Arkansas State less than six weeks after being fired by Louisiana State. He inherits a team that finished 10-20 this season and has not been to the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1999. Brady went 192-139 in 11 seasons at L.S.U., including a Final Four appearance in 2006.

Aliona Savchenko and Robin Szolkowy of Germany won the pairs title at the world figure skating championships in Goteborg, Sweden. Savchenko and Szolkowy, also the Grand Prix and European champions, took advantage of their hugely difficult routine to win the title, beating China’s Zhang Dan and Zhang Hao by more than 5 points.

Iowa, ranked No. 1 and the Big Ten champion, goes for its 21st national team title at the N.C.A.A. championships, which begins Thursday in St. Louis. The Hawkeyes, 21-1 in dual meets, are one of five teams to qualify nine wrestlers for the event. Minnesota, ranked No. 8, won last year’s championship and is seeking its fourth national title in the past eight years.

Cristiano Ronaldo scored twice to give Manchester United a 2-0 victory against Bolton and a 3-point lead atop the English Premier League. In another game, Robbie Keane scored the game-tying goal with two minutes left as Tottenham earned a 4-4 draw with Chelsea to stop the Blues from pulling even with second-place Arsenal.

BMW Oracle Racing, the American syndicate set to challenge Alinghi in the 2009 America’s Cup, will be co-skippered by the three-time Cup winner Russell Coutts. Coutts will share skipper duties with the Australian James Spithill, who guided Luna Rossa to the most recent Louis Vuitton Cup final.
NEWARK — When she talked to detectives back in September, the 20-year-old woman said her boyfriend, now on trial on murder charges, had threatened to kill her if she talked to the police.
Isiah Thomas dodged questions about his job security amid reports that longtime Indiana Pacers executive Donnie Walsh may join the Knicks as the team president.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y. (AP) — A black man was sentenced on Wednesday to two to four years in prison for fatally shooting a white teenager during a racially charged confrontation, enraging the family of the victim.

The Defense Ministry began to auction off parts of some of its World War II-era tanks, including 140 Soviet T-34 tanks that guarded the country’s border with Turkey.
Millions of Greeks in a broad range of professions walked off work, bringing the country to a standstill to protest sweeping pension changes proposed by the government.
Islamic militants in Somalia welcomed being added to the United States’ list of terrorist organizations, saying they wished only that the designation had come sooner.
For the Brooklyn prosecutors trying Cesar Rodriguez in the beating death of his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, a plea deal was not an option.

The controller of one of Harlem’s best-known apartment complexes has been accused of stealing more than $1 million from the building’s management company and spending the money on furs, jewelry, leased cars and restaurant meals for herself, her family and her friends.
In a state where basketball is the unofficial religion, the Indiana Pacers’ on, and off-court struggles are resulting in a major crisis of confidence for the franchise.

Tiger Woods is creeping up on Byron Nelson’s 1945 record of 11 consecutive tournament victories in a row, but it’s the career of Jack Nicklaus that he measures his against.

Fabio Coicou testified that he did not argue with Sean Bell outside a club and never heard anyone threaten to get a gun, contradicting the version of events given by the three detectives who are on trial in the killing of Mr. Bell.
Disparaging remarks Bobby Gonzalez made about a referee after his team lost to Rutgers have knocked him out of next season’s first Big East Conference game.
Winning the nomination has seemed something of a long shot for Hillary Rodham Clinton since February, but it now seems to have grown a bit longer.

Even affluent consumers with annual incomes of $100,000 or more are increasingly being ensnared in the home mortgage crisis.
Catapulted by the biggest I.P.O. in American history, Visa shares soared 28 percent in their stock market debut as investors bet an accelerating shift to electronic payments will enrich the company.
In some of the most colorful testimony so far in the Hollywood wiretapping trial, the actress Linda Doucett accused the private eye Anthony Pellicano of threatening them.
The Police Department is poised to shrink to its smallest size in about 15 years, reflected in a plan by the Bloomberg administration to trim funds for 1,000 police officer positions this year.
A House committee and the Pentagon are investigating whether shoddy wiring on U.S. military bases in Iraq led to the deaths of at least12 soldiers and marines.
Hillary Rodham Clinton framed her argument in the context of voting rights, drawing cheers from an ethnically diverse crowd.
The compensation committee at Bank of America has reduced the bonuses of the bank’s top executives.

In the absence of clear federal emissions mandates, states that have been proving grounds for new environmental approaches to energy are becoming battlegrounds as well.

George Clooney will screen his new movie “Leatherheads” in Maysville, Ky., on Monday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Clooney’s father, Nick, said that the actor will visit this northern Kentucky town, which is approximately 16 miles east of Augusta, Ky., where the star grew up. Nick Clooney and George Clooney’s aunt, Rosemary, were born in Maysville, and the town holds special significance for the family: it’s where Rosemary Clooney’s movie “The Stars Are Singing” was given its premiere in 1953. The Times reported Wednesday that Greenville, S.C., where the movie was filmed, will have its own premiere, probably without Mr. Clooney and the cast. More than 400 extras from the Greenville area are in the film.

The New Yorker leads the list of 128 finalists with 12 nominations for the 43rd annual National Magazine Awards. Marlene Kahan, executive director of the American Society of Magazine Editors, made the announcement on Wednesday. The 2008 awards, known as the Ellies, had a record-setting 1,964 entries from 333 print and online magazines, the society said. Twenty-five winners will be announced at a gala on May 1 at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan. Other publications with multiple nominations include New York, Vanity Fair, National Geographic, GQ and The Atlantic; first-time finalists include Babble, Bloomberg Markets, Budget Travel, Chow, Condé Nast Portfolio, Domino, Good, The New York Times Magazine, Paste, Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine, Radar and T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

A $1,000 bench warrant was issued for the actor Shia LaBeouf on Tuesday after he failed to appear in court on a charge of unlawful smoking, The Associated Press reported. According to the warrant, which did not contain details of the location of the offense, Mr. LaBeouf, 21, the star of the forthcoming “Indiana Jones” movie and the blockbuster hit “Transformers,” was cited last month. He was scheduled to appear in a Los Angeles County court Tuesday on the misdemeanor offense, but neither he nor his lawyer showed up, according to court documents.

The Sundance Channel, a joint venture of NBC Universal, the CBS Corporation and the actor and director Robert Redford, is up for sale, a media analyst said Wednesday. Sundance, a 12-year-old cable channel currently accessible to 26 million homes, is seeking more than $400 million, according to the analyst, Richard Greenfield of Pali Research. A spokeswoman for the channel declined to comment in an e-mail message. If neither NBC nor CBS decide to take full ownership, Mr. Greenfield said, Cablevision, Time Warner and Viacom could be interested. Some cable customers receive Sundance as part of a digital channel package; others must subscribe separately. The Sundance Channel promotes itself as “independent-minded” and shows films, documentaries and original programming. It operates separately from the Sundance Film Festival but seeks a similar audience. Its programs include “Iconoclasts,” in which two famous people interview each other, and the environmentally oriented series “The Green.” Rather than running standard commercials, the channel has allowed marketers to sponsor specific programs.

ABC’s celebrity dancers were no match for Fox’s would-be celebrities in Tuesday’s ratings. Fox’s “American Idol” easily earned the night’s largest audience, averaging 27 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. The Fox show also outpaced ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” by more than 10 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour when the two series went head to head. The dance competition drew 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 10:30 p.m., giving ABC a second-place finish for the night behind Fox. The premiere of ABC’s “Miss Guided” at 10:30 attracted 10 million viewers. NBC was third for the night, nearly tying ABC among adults 18 to 49 thanks to the strength of "The Biggest Loser" in that demographic from 8 to 10 (7.9 million). CBS finished fourth over all.

The Sci Fi Channel has approved a two-hour pilot for the prequel to “Battlestar Galactica,” according to The Hollywood Reporter. The announcement was made at the cable channel’s presentation of its new schedule Tuesday in New York. The prequel, “Caprica,” created by David Eick and Ronald D. Moore, the team behind “Battlestar,” is set 50 years before the hit show.
The Broadway musical “Curtains” will be closing in June, and the Guthrie Theater announces productions of Tony Kushner plays for its new season.

The Miami rapper Rick Ross, who made it big two years ago with a hit ring tone (“Hustlin’”), has scored his second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with “Trilla” (Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam), left. Nielsen SoundScan reported that it sold 198,000 copies in the United States, significantly more than Snoop Dogg’s “Ego Trippin’,” (Geffen), which moved 137,000, bowing at No. 3. The pop compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music,” usually a blockbuster, had notably slow sales for its 27th volume. It moved 169,000 copies to reach No. 2, the lowest opening-week sales for the series since its first volume 10 years ago. Other Top 10 debuts this week include Fat Joe’s “Elephant in the Room” (Terror Squad/Imperial), at No. 6, and Miley Cyrus’s “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert” (Disney), at No. 10.
